It also has great stories of doomsday preppers which are cool and funny at the same time although some may find them over the top in the prepping area but the book itself is less over the top and more practical information. It is a welcome addition to my top book collection. It's also a Great gift idea for friends and family. As I do think more people should be prepared at home and in their car, it's just common sense as murphy's law happens to us all at some point!overall: buy it, great read, better info and really comprehensive in types of environments covered.

Smell great and are tough and large enough to clean both hands well and even wiped the steering wheel down at work! When purchased got a deal for 5 boxes of 24 in each box. Great deal and come in handy. Spread them out between work and home, car and first aid kits even my hiking packs. My only choice in hand wipes great quality!

Nice light weight warm winter boot that don't dig into you calf while driving. Many people at work purchased the bugaboo Omni-heat boots only to return them for leaking in water and for the high stiff fit of the boot as well as the clunky-ness. The liftop boots are really quite good, the mens are a bit clunky looking but are very light. I work outside all day and was surprised at just how warm they are with a pair of wigwam el pine wool socks on in -20 with no toe warmers, as they died 1/2 way through my day, my toes were a bit cold but not frozen!!! So far three people at work have returned their boots trying to get these as they seem far more popular and have sold out quickly. I didn't read anything on being totally waterproof but tested them by walking through snow taller than the boots all day and no leaks! The traction is really very good, my kitchen floor gets one drop of water on it and normally your on your but, not in these, they stuck right to the floor and gave me a very confident feeling outside in snow. Not bad on ice but would recommend glacier chains as their cheap and work better than the rolled spring type. The lacing system on these boots really let you dial in the fit. They feel to me about 1/2 bigger than the size stated but work great with wool socks mid weight and up to thick. The toe box it self is wide but not tall, as to keep the air space to a minimum. You can get one pair of toe warmers in with wool socks on. The toe warmers really come into play when its below zero, haven't needed them above 10 degrees. They have a great feature on the shaft of the boot above your ankle which looks almost like pleated material. The boots break-in quickly and that feature above the ankle takes the pressure off your calf while walking and driving. Other models have complaints on their full leather shaft and rough break-in period. Again it really depends on your use of them and personal preference. I also just noticed they have a liftop Omni-heat version of these and would love to buy them if I could find them that is!! The liftop 2 boots seem to have a stiffer shaft that these, an no pleated look at ankle.Bottom line: Best boot purchase so far! light, warm and easy to get custom fit while tying up. Have recommended multiple times with lots of happy warm feet in my area!! No problems even in the -45 to -30 we've been having. BUY THEM, if you can find them!!!

I purchased the womens version of this jacket but it was too tight in the mid section, not a bell shape I guess!! so I got the guys version for some room when sitting around the house. Its a very comfortable and warm jacket but got the tusk/grill color thinking it was light and dark grey opps! oh well ugly but very happy with it as it fits well and is very soft and warm on winter days in a drafty house. The price was a steal on sale for about $20. At that price would buy again but the nicer colors run about $36.

It concerns me that wonderful author G. M. Malliet might get pigeonholed into the "cozy mystery" category. I have described her books as such myself, and it's true that her mysteries are "cozy" rather than brutally graphic and upsetting. But that does not detract from the exquisite way she plies her craft.Case in point: "The Haunted Season," the latest in her wonderful Max Tudor series. In this outing, we find Max and Awena married (not a spoiler; we know this right at the beginning) and new parents (ditto) to the most perfect baby in the world in his parents' eyes--Owen. Max is blissfully happy and we are happy for him, but as we all know, "murder follows Max." Having escaped the world of M1 espionage, become an Anglican priest and happily entered into rural English life, the last thing Max wants or needs is to be solving crimes. But once again, murder finds him--again very close to home--and he cannot help but be drawn in to the mystery.You can change an ace spy into an Anglican priest, but as Inspector Cotton (a wonderful regular from previous books) knows all too well, when there is a murder mystery afoot, Father Max morphs into a crime-solver.I really do not want to explain the plot, because there are so many twists and turns here. I will say that Malliet delivers a hilarious take on the upper-UPPER classes, which adds to the fun despite the gruesome murder Max is investigating. And I will also say that this is the darkest of the Father Max books, and I am not going to say why. Read it and see.HIGHLY recommended.

This is a terrific resource for children, especially those who have not been raised in the faith. I used this for my RCIA students, ages 7-11, and they were enthralled by the various activities, and were learning at the same time without knowing it. I plan to order more this year so perhaps each child can have his or her own copy.

This is the only product I have ever found that totally removes scuffs, stains and dirt from my white countertops. Yes, of course I clean my countertops daily, and yes, they look clean. But then I use my Magic Eraser--and gone are stains that I thought would never go away, and back comes the gleam. These erasers work just as well on woodwork, in the bathroom, on tile, on just about everything. I honestly consider this a miracle product. My daughter took my advice and started using them in her apartment--she is a clean freak and cannot be without them now!

I read this book and its predecessor, The Winds of War, when they first came out eons ago. I read them as a young woman whose major interest was the romantic entanglements. Did I even read the brilliant, insightful descriptions of key battles in the war? I have no idea. But NOW I can admire Wouk's brilliance anew, with much more wherewithal to appreciate his historical analyses of key battles in Europe and in Asia. Truly, these two books, and especially this one, are a tour de force. If you have not read them, you will learn a lot about our own past, which adds a great deal of understanding of the way our country has evolved. If you have not read them in many a long year, treat yourself to a re-read!

These teacups are so beautiful, so charming, so pleasing to the eye! I collect teacups and saucers, and am quite picky about what I choose to display. I actually had ordered these to USE, but once I set eyes upon them, I immediately made room in my very full dining room cabinets. You would never know that they did not cost three times as much. I am so happy with them!

I have hung this calendar every single year since the very early 90s when it first came out. I never tire of it, and I can't live without it. I have already ordered my 2016 wall calendar, and it is safely here in my office, ready to replace my 2015. The pictures are always high quality, restful, beautiful and inspiring, and each is accompanied by a quote from a book...sometimes, the quotes have inspired me to find the books and ready them. A win-win!

I use this engagement calendar every year, and have already started filling in appointments--it's only September, which goes to show you how much I rely on these appointment books! The pictures are outstanding, one for each week, and the spaces within which to write in appointments are just large enough, with no "extras" like lines and quotations and things that drive me crazy. Love, love, love this product.

We had purchased these stairs for use by our elderly dog (since deceased) and his much younger sibling, who had sustained a bad injury to her leg and was not allowed to jump on the bed. Neither dog took to the stairs at all, no matter how much we coaxed. However, we have two very elderly cats and a juvenile cat as well--and all three love it. The juvenile, of course, does not need the stairs, but the stairs have changed the lives of the elderly cats for the better. They can easily climb up to the spare-room bed, where they like to sleep, and back down again. The stairs are sturdy and handsome, a good buy for sure. I am thinking that smaller dogs (our two are Labradors) would love these stairs as well.

This is truly one of the most brilliant books I have read in my long (never mind how long) life. A sequel of sorts to "Life After Life," it is nevertheless a standalone book--and it completes Atkinson's utterly masterful narrative of World War II. For those who read the former book, which featured Ursula in the most amazingly creative of ways, "A God in Ruins" is about her younger brother Teddy, whom we knew as a favored child and who is now an adult, a former fighter pilot whose memories of the war and his role in it never leave him throughout his life.The characterizations in this book are so rich, so fully drawn, so -- I have to use the word again -- masterful, that the reader becomes completely immersed. I forgot where I was when I was reading this. I was in pre-war Britain. I was in wartime Britain. I was in the air, fearing for my life in daring raids over Germany. I was terrified of a serious health problem (no spoilers here). I was everything and everybody.When I finished the book, I was almost paralyzed with admiration and real grief that the book was over. Needless to say, I highly, and totally, recommend this book.

I thought this was going to be so inspirational, but it left me bored, impatient and uninterested. God forgive me, but it read to me as a self-serving tribute to the author--by the author! I'm not saying others will read it that way, but I certainly did, and could not finish the book, no matter how much I tried. I wound up reading half, then speed reading to the end--and nothing changed.

I love these shoes so much that I ordered another pair in silver (I had virtually worn out my first silver pair) along with the gold. These shoes go with EVERYTHING, from dresses to casual jeans to everything in between, and for me, they are very comfortable. They do run small, though. It might be wise to order a size up, just to see. And they do have elastic around the entire rim of the shoe, so if you have a particular foot problem, these might not be the best for you. At this price, I would order and see!

How can I even describe how joyful I was at receiving this collection? After a disastrous move in which my entire collection of demitasse cups went missing (and was never found), I had given up my hobby of collecting porcelain. But I saw this teacup collection on Pinterest, and was instantly smitten. These are full-sized cups and saucers, and oh, so beautiful!The box was almost as good as the cups: A hatbox arrangement, which each cup and saucer carefully packed. I didn't want to remove the cups! Now, all five teacups are on display in my china cabinet, and I can't wait to get the next set in the series. These are 1950 to 2000; I'm looking forward to 1900-1950!!!

I loved this sweet, short story from the moment that Isabel looked out her window early in the morning and spied Brother Fox. Those who know the series will certainly share in the warm, fuzzy feeling I got!There is nothing new or earth-shattering in this e-book; just a charming tale of a normal "day in the life" of the wonderful Ms. Dalhousie, Jaime, and Charlie. Definitely worth reading, definitely a lovely interlude between full books!

This is the best scale I have ever used. First, it's extra wide, which means that I am not always shifting my feet to make sure my full weight is on the scale (my husband is a large guy, and this feature is invaluable for him!). Next, the digital readout is large and clear, so I don't have to squint at the numbers. Third, the very thin size and neutral color makes the scale blend in bathroom and bedroom. I had to order this scale again, because my cat peed on the first one (TMI?)! It came quickly, packaged properly, and was put to use almost immediately. Highly recommended!

I first "met" G.M. Malliet because my local library, in its monthly e-mails to readers, recommended her Father Tudor series, which I gobbled up. Her St. Just (a police detective) series came first, and as soon as I had finished the last available Father Tudor book, I snapped them up to read on my Kindle. Death and the Lit Chick is the second in the series; an utterly wonderful play on the Agatha Christie novels, with no apologies to the late, great mystery writer.A group of authors meets in an old, supposedly haunted castle in Scotland that is now a choice venue for weddings and other events, and in fact they are all there for a literary conference. We meet them one by one, and what a cast of characters!!!! But the one who draws the most attention, the one whom they all loathe for her sudden huge success and her preening over it, is Kimberlee, the author of a "chick lit" mystery that threatens the genre of the mystery novel for the rest of them.Our gallant and handsome police detective, St. Just, is there to give a presentation, not in any official capacity. But that all changes when there is a murder at the castle. Who did it? Why? The plot thickens--and thickens again, before it speeds to its utterly satisfying conclusion. I thought I had the murderer figured out rather quickly...then I changed my mind and figured it was somebody else. I was wrong on both counts. Utterly wrong.Do yourself a favor and cleanse your reading palate with this wonderful book!

Oh, PUHLEEZ!!!!First, let me state that I love Mary Gordon, have read many of her books, and admired them all. But I had a very strong urge to hurl this one across the room, and in fact it took me many weeks to finish, as I could not stomach more than a few pages at a time. Why did I finish at all? Because of my respect for Mary Gordon...I grew up in the era when the two protagonists were growing up. I knew Miranda and Adam types, and I probably was more a Miranda than an Adam. But two more unlikeable people I could not describe. Yuck! I will not belabor the plot, as so many reviewers have done so, so I'll cut to the chase. Decades after their torrid but doomed love affair, two older people meet by chance in Italy, slyly brought together by a long-time friend of each of them. They meet at first in the villa of the friend--whose over-the-top mother with dementia gives an impassioned and deplorable speech praising Mussolini. OK, then. WhatEV, as my daughter says.Fast forward to the two "old friends" meeting for coffee. Each is happily married, each is secure, but the unspoken "unfinished business" between them hangs heavily. And so we embark on several days of their meetings in Italy, each more pretentious and boring than the next, where this reader came to loathe Miranda first--and then Adam. OK, Miranda, you were a dedicated left-winger in the 60s who actually went to global trouble spot to help save the world. Good for you. Adam, you were a dedicated and promising pianist who hid all your emotions and responsibilities behind your music. Bravo.Eventually, we have flashbacks to when the two were lovers, and the young Miranda is no more likeable than the old one, and Adam is a caricature. How can I say this: I didn't care. I didn't care if they met again, if they slept together again or not, if they lived to be 100, I cared not at all about either one of them. I did not see the point of the book, and if there was one, my feeble mind simply missed it.Much as I truly love Mary Gordon, and much as I will continue to read her books as long as she writes them, I cannot recommend this to anyone.

I absolutely love this series, and this one was the best. For those who can't understand a nod to the past--genteel "country" mysteries with a nod to modern technology thrown in, I am sorry for you. Everything about these novels is delightful, and Malliet has a way of telling tried and true stories with a new twist. Besides, who can resist Father Max?In this outing, things at home are tranquil and lovely as Max and Awena await the birth of their first child. This romance alone is worth the price of the four current books! Max is busily wading through his daily life: sermons, competing singers for an upcoming church musical and so forth, when once again he is called to investigate a crime, this time a suspected poisoned fruitcake! Can the otherworldly and gentle nuns at the nearby convent really have tried to poison the odious Lord who lives nearby?Max does not want to leave his parish and his pregnant significant other, but his Bishop insists. So off Max goes to the convent--where he uncovers centuries of secrets.Loved it, loved it, loved it! I was so afraid this was the last book, but I see a new one is coming out later this year, and I've already pre-ordered!

It takes a fine author to keep a recurring character fresh, interesting, and--well--"in character," but wonderful Sujata Massey has done it. What a joy to encounter enchanting, fey, quirky and utterly unique Rei Shimura again, as though she has been a very real friend all these years, and not simply a creation on a page!Rei is now living in Hawaii with her husband Michael (this is not a spoiler; we know this almost immediately), and is so happy that I found myself smiling for and with her! All is well until the horrific earthquake and resulting deadly tsunami hit her beloved Japan. In her anxious, nerve-wracking efforts to reach her friends and family, Rei learns that her beloved mentor, the antiques dealer Mr. Ishida, has gone missing--right in the heart of the area hit hardest by the tsunami. And Rei being, Rei, she defies every obstacle in her path to go and find him.It is here that Sujata Massey again shows her marvelous talent, as she weaves the doings of Rei, who will NOT be daunted, as we all remember so well--with the horror and grief of the aftermath of the tsunami. I remember when the tsunami hit, and I read every press report I could get my hands on, as well as donating to relief, but I don't think my concern touched the surface. As Rei searches for Mr. Ishida, volunteering for rescue work, we can see, smell, gasp and suffer along with the people who had their homes, their neighborhoods, and loved ones snuffed out by the relentless water.Massey adds many details: the stink of the myriad dead fish in the mud; the horror of dead bodies; the misery of those who survived but have no place to go; and the shining hope of a little girl whose father and beloved pet dog are missing.Add a strange mystery about the whereabouts of a blue-haired girl to the mix, and you have a perfect mystery that only Rei Shimura would attempt to solve with every obstacle, literally and figuratively, in her path.Brava, Ms. Massey!!!(Free copy of book supplied in return for an honest review.)

If you like Debbie Macomber, as I do, you will find this charming book as comforting and enjoyable as a hot cup of tea in a favorite chair by a sunny window. In this entry in the Rose Harbor series, we learn more about the enigmatic Mark, the very gruff but secretly caring handyman who has a hidden past. And Proprietor Jo Marie has the usual assortment of interesting guests, each of whom has a different problem, including an Internet romance that may not be what it seems; and a pregnancy that should be joyful, but is anything but.This is just a lovely, lovely book, typical Debbie, and a joy to read.

Sigh. What can I say without being cruel to the author, who began her Three Pines series with such promise? Let me say this: The first three books in the series were brilliant. The last several have been less so, and this entry had me very badly wanting to throw the book against the wall--except that I would have broken my Kindle. Myriad reviewers have described the plot and the familiar characters--many of whom have become idiotic caricatures (think Ruth). So I'll just add my thoughts:1. The existential, "out there" prose and poetic warbles drove me absolutely insane. They came off pretentious and silly and meant nothing. And I do mean nothing.2. I am tired of the main characters being dirty (unkempt, horrendous hair with bits of food in it; dirty hands; etc.) and being loved for it.3. I am VERY tired of every character we came to love in the first few books having "secret" and unsavory pasts.All I can say is: GOODBYE, Three Pines! Don't call me. I'll call you.

Sherryl Woods really cannot write a bad book. It would be so easy for her to rest on her laurels and coast for a few books, as many authors in her position have done (I won't name names; read my reviews!), but she never lets the reader down.Seaview Inn is a charming story that on its face has been told many times in many books: Divorced mother of college daughter returns to her home town that she fled many years ago. College daughter, doing well at Stanford, suddenly takes a leave of absence from college for very emotional reasons. Grandmother wants to keep the inn that has been in her family for generations; daughter believes she should go in assisted living. Trouble Iraq War veteran comes to his birthplace to sort out his soul.OK, if that were the plot and there was nothing more, I might have given this book a whirl--or maybe not, as I have read so many similar books. BUT... we have more to this story.First, we have a poignant and realistic look at the anguish an adult child feels when her parent or grandparent can no longer continue in the life she loves. What should be done? Is assisted living the answer? Or is it unspeakably cruel? Next, we have a very realistic look at a recent breast cancer survivor who, having watched her own mother die of the disease, cannot believe in her own future. The terror is very real and beautifully described. And then we have the bitterness of a wounded war veteran who comes home to find that his wife has dropped him for his best friend.It all sounds so very melodramatic, but it isn't--not when Sherryl Woods is writing the book! Her compassion, her honesty and her very real wisdom shine through on every page. I've already ordered the next in the series, and I can't wait to read it.

Having just discovered Liane Moriarty this summer, first with "The Husband's Secret" and next with "Big Little Lies," I decided to read her earlier works as well, and "Three Wishes" was next on my list.My first thought was, "Oh, this isn't quite as polished and brilliant as her latest two." Well, maybe not--but I couldn't put it down. Moriarty has such an amusing and fresh way of "outing" real, and very serious problems, in a deceptively breezy, fun, "frolic" (I dislike that overused word, but it really fits in this case) that the reader scarcely realizes that she is coming face to face with terrible truths--in this case, mental abuse, which can be as serious and life-defeating as physical abuse--and that is the point of this story.But it's all wrapped up in a funny, original tale about 30-something triplets (two identical; one fraternal, and boy, has THAT been an issue all their lives!) in suburban Australia whose somewhat ordinary lives are anything but. Told with tremendous wit, this story introduces each triplet in turn, and with great sympathy, the author shows us that all is not what it seems.I won't do any spoilers here, but I will say that this is more than a beach read, and well worth reading. Is it as good as Moriarty's later works? No...but it's a preview of her brilliance to come.

How easy is it for an educated, upper-middle-class, successful wife and mother to become an addict? All too easy, and the slope is more than just slippery. It has an elevator!!!Here is the story of likeable, suburban working mom Allison Weiss. She has a difficult but loveable child, her marriage is a bit iffy but not something that can't be fixed, she has the usual worries about her aging parents, and her daily routine is over the top--but not more so than most of today's "I can do it all" mothers. Except Allison can't keep up--not with her impossible expectations of herself, not with the equally impossible demands of the uppity private school her daughter attends; not with the children's birthday parties that are akin to a major wedding; not with the competitive achievements of her wealthy neighbors. So Allison gets help--in the form of prescribed pain pills that she can rationalize away because "after all, they are a prescription!"The scary and very real story of how Allison's "just one pill to get me over this hump" behavior ends up with 60 (SIXTY!) pain pills in two days, is well told, and so very, very real. While falling deeper and deeper into addiction, Allison fools herself (I am NOT like addicts; I am a successful working wife and mother! I am educated! I know the pitfalls! This is under control!), her husband, her mother, and everybody else...until she winds up lying in her own vomit.What is so frightening about this book is that it truly CAN happen to anymore. So, so, easily. And that is the point of this book. It's a warning of sorts, but told with such sympathy and such empathy that any person who has thought longingly of that spare Xanax in the medicine cabinet, or the Percocet left over from a wisdom tooth extraction, or whatever else is hanging around, can react with a twinge of fear.I haven't read Weiner in a very long time, and I'm glad I came back to her with this outstanding book. Well done!

Liane Moriarty is an author you can't take for granted. She has the enormous skill of delivering cogent truths in disarming, seemingly lighthearted stories that just skip along--until the "Pow" of the underlying plot hits you smack in the face.Like "The Husband's Secret," "Big Little Lies" is a book within a book within a book. Let's begin with the fun romp that forms the plot line. In suburban Australia, in a beautiful beach town, several "mums" meet and form alliances on the first day of their respective children's kindergarten. Any mother who has experienced the first day of school with her child will find herself smiling--who hasn't met the "blond bobs," the helicopter parent, the smug parents of "gifted" children? I found myself laughing aloud.The main characters are simply wonderful, and so finely drawn! Madeline is an over-the-top, in-your-face hilarious woman who seemingly has no other interests than shoes. Shy, shrinking Jane, the youngest mother, has some obvious problems and needs to be taken under somebody's wing. Celeste is so gorgeous that she stuns anyone who looks at her, and she's wealthy too. Is she happy? If not, why not? Renata is a caricature of every bossy, smug and nasty "power mother" we've ever met.On this level alone, the book is a fun, fast, marvelous read. But there is more. Oh, so much more. Beneath these aptly drawn and right-on caricatures is another story entirely, one that is deep, frightening and all too true. And that's where Moriarty's talent lies. She can make you think, and think hard, at the same time that you are enjoying what seems to be a bon bons-and-champagne beach book.We know almost on page 1 that there has been a murder, so I am not introducing a spoiler here. But who? Why? What could possibly have gone so wrong in a group of largely upscale, well-meaning parents?The answer will stun you.Brilliant!!

I ordered a pair in my normal size (8) before I read all the reviews about fit problems, so I was really worried. But I need not have worried at all. The fit is PERFECT, and I absolutely love these slings to death. They are vastly comfortable, look great, and are perfect for the hot Houston climate. I am so thrilled with them that I plan to order several more pairs.When you are in flip flops/sandals for half the year in a warm climate, and you find something that fits this well, feels great and looks terrific, you know you've found a winner.Definitely recommended.

I love these leggings so much that I'm already wearing them to death. Here in Houston, they are perfect, paired with a long tank and a pair of sandals. I ordered a medium, and it is perfect: not too tight, not too loose, perfect length, perfect everything! I probably would prefer a logo-less pair, but the Spalding logo is just below the waistband, and I am too old for crop tops. Therefore, nobody can see the logo--including me. I have not yet laundered these leggings, but I'm sure they will be fine laundered in cold water.This is really a quality product and I am so happy with my purchase that I am thinking of ordering several more pairs, just so I won't wear them out!

Many reviewers have said that this is a book about ballet. And that is true. But it is SO much more, so multi-layered, so intense, that I cried at the end of the book, not because of the plot, but because of the absolute brilliance.Yes, this story is certainly about ballet. And since I was a roaring balletomane in the time period in which this book takes place, I loved the references. I loved figuring out who was who (Balanchine? Check. Nureyev? Check. A bit of Baryshnikov thrown in? Check. Suzanne Farrell? Check. In fact, the story of the ballet master picking a perfume for each ballerina based on her personality is straight out of real life: Balanchine did that for his dancers as well, and at the time (in the 70s), I thought it was the height of romance.So I loved the plot. I loved the story of the dancers: their competitiveness, their obsession with their bodies, their constant need to be better--and most of all, LIFE LIVED IN FRONT OF MIRRORS.It was only at the end of the book that it hit me between the eyes: The mirrors are fun-house mirrors. The truth and reality reflected back at the dancers has a hidden, dark side. A VERY dark side. And so I have to ask: Was this just a lovely novel about the world of ballet? Or was it an absolutely tour de force...a plot within a plot that reveals a sinister underside--a reality so upsetting, so diabolical that it puts an entirely different twist on the story.SPOILER ALERT:Was Joan indeed a Frankenstein, as her poor husband Jacob says toward the end of the book? Did she actually create and mold a human life to complete her own failed fantasies? And if that is true, is she a devil? Is she evil? Or is she simply a misguided, self-absorbed person with, as she herself says (in different word), a vague, unplanned agenda? We do not know. We will never know. And that is the genius of this book.

This second in the charming Lowcountry Summer series was better than the first ("The Summer Girls"), and kept my interest from start to finish.First, let me say that I am an intense fan of Mary Alice Monroe, have read everything she has written, and look forward to every book. I felt that the first in the series was a tad slow, but this one enlarged upon the characters, gave us something to hold on to, and as always with Monroe's books, made us care about a wild species, in this case, dolphins.We first met Delphine the wild dolphin, a viable character in her own right, in "The Summer Girls." Spoiler Alert if you have not read this one: Delphine meets with a possibly fatal accident due to the carelessness of humans. Enough said. In THIS book, there is quite a lot of information about dolphin conservation and care, and I ate it up. It was secondary to the plot, but melded in beautifully, just like Monroe has melded in her stories of wild turtle conservation in so many of her previous books.Yes, Monroe has an agenda, and that is the preservation of the Low Country's creatures, beaches, environment, and charm. And yes, she preaches her message, but unlike other authors of the same ilk, she draws the reader in without lecturing or badgering. Maybe that's because she always weaves her tales around such interesting people, and this book is no exception. The main characters, five women in different stages of their lives with different problems and agendas and yet bound together by family, are well drawn and totally believable. Each has to solve a problem on her own, some very serious life-altering problems--but each has the love of the others to keep her strong.This book left me very anxious to read the last in the trilogy. I hope it appears soon!

I don't know whether it's the combination of these particular authors, or what, but this new NYPD Red series reads like the old Patterson before he was writing a book a week! I couldn't put it down.In this second in what I hope is a long series, our elite "Red" team goes after a serial killer/vigilante who may be the most diabolical yet. The embattled incumbent mayor wants the case solved NOW so he can win reelection. His opponent (both the mayor and his opponent are hilarious caricatures of the real thing--but quite believable) may be tampering with evidence so that SHE can win. And then, just to add some spice, we have a Mafia family worthy of the Corleones. Put them all together and you have a fast-paced, thrill-a-minute, perfect summer read. Does it all make sense? Who cares?I am not going to pretend that this is great literature, but it sure is a fun read around the pool, at the beach, in the shade--or in my case, hunkered down in the AC while the heat simmers outside.

I am probably the millionth reviewer of this wonderful book, but I loved it so much that I felt I simply had to add my two cents.First, I had never read Moriarty before, because I had a snobby, stupid sense that she was "merely" a "chick lit" author who would bore me. I have read and loved my share of "chick lit" (I hate that phrase) in my time, so don't get me wrong, but at this particular time in my life, I pick and choose very carefully. And I did NOT choose "The Husband's Secret." Until I said, "What the heck, it's been on the best-seller lists forever; I'll check it out." And I did.And what I found was a truly well-written, well-phrased, ingenious story that held my interest from start to finish. The Pandora's Box premise reminded me strongly of Kate Atkinson...the idea that one act can change not only a single person's life, but fan out to change myriad lives in ways one never would have, or could have, predicted.I found the characters believable and sympathetic, and I was constantly surprised--especially at the end. Things certainly are rarely what they seem to be, and Moriarty tells her tale with compassion and skill.

I purchased this for a friend of mine, a dedicated chef whose entire culinary efforts revolve around her food processor. Her ancient Cuisinart had bitten the dust, and she was devastated. I read the reviews of many food processors, and this one was in my price range and seemed to be a good replacement. I sent it as a surprise and waited with bated breath to see what she thought.She LOVES it. This is a serious cook. She cooks for a hobby, and her life is trying new recipes, almost all of which require a food processor at some stage. She says this one is "a dream to operate," easy to use, meets all her needs, and is a revelation to her after using the clunky Cuisinart she had thought was the be-all and end-all.Now I, who rarely use a food processor, am looking forward to ordering my own.

Well, gosh darnit, every single time I think that Patterson could not POSSIBLY write anything worth reading anymore, he surprises me. And this book was a major surprise.I had purchased NYPD Red on the way to a quiet summer vacation on the river...nothing to do but read pulp fiction and veg. So I expected very little, and that was fine with me. I have read enough Patterson to know that he will always at least entertain me, and I can check my brain at the door. But THIS book grabbed me!These days, a good serial killer yarn is hard to pull off, as the market is so saturated, and God help us, the REAL-LIFE serial killers are bad enough. And yet, I don't know why, maybe it's his new coauthor's "fresh blood," but Patterson managed to create a serial killer who not only held my interest, but with whom I could almost sympathize! I found myself at times hoping he could pull off his next horrendous murder!!! (No, I am not a serial killer wannabee.) It was just that interesting.So here's the verdict: If you want a fast-paced, riveting page-turner with a hero/heroine set of police partners to love, and a villain to hate, here is your book. If you are looking for insightful, brilliant crime writing like Deaver and Baldacci consistently deliver, this is not your choice. But for me? I'm already reading NYPD Red 2.

I don't know what to say...But I'll try. Let's start with the Good.No matter what, Dorothea Benton Frank's love for the Low Country, which I have never seen in person but feel I know so well from her books alone, shines through each and every book, and this one too. So, too, does the fact that she is a nice person. Nothing in her books is ever snarky or mean, and this one is no exception.How about the plot? To me, it made very little sense: Eighty-year-old Maisie has a 65-year-old live-in boyfriend. Possible? Yes...but could I believe it for one second? No. Absolutely not, for so many reasons, and not because I have any prejudice against 80-year-old women, believe me; I hope to become one! Her daughter, fifty-something Liz, is the quintessential put-upon Southern housewife--and yet she is also a high-powered fund raiser for battered women. I couldn't buy it, and every time the author went on a diatribe about battered women, a cause I FULLY SUPPORT, mind you--it made me impatient and more than a little bored. Liz as a mouthpiece took some suspension of belief! Then there is Ashley, portrayed as a strong, modern woman--who blindly falls in love with an almost cartoonishly abusive man because she has a fantasy of becoming the next Jackie Kennedy.Whew.Here's the thing...The reality and heartbreak of battered women is real, frightening, and horrible, and I applaud Ms. Frank's desire to champion their cause, just NOT in the middle of what is a beach read, plain and simple. Her plan backfired. My reaction was to become more and more impatient and negative about the cause in general. I'm sure she did not intend that reaction!And, how could I forget this: Liz and her husband Clayton kept reminding me of Les and Wes, the identical couple in "The Last Original Wife." I kept forgetting which book was which!OK, all that having been said, I have loved Ms. Frank all these years, and cannot imagine giving her up. I feel guilty even giving her a "meh" review. As others have said, and I agree, authors these days are expected, and I expect it's in their contracts, to produce a book a year, whether they are ready or not. And the quality goes down exponentially with each book. "The Hurricane Sisters" is no exception.

I have been a fan of Anne Rivers Siddons since her very first book, and have loved them all, some more than others, but each was a pleasure to read and a thoughtful and well-written story. Until now. I found this terrible book excruciating to read, and it left me literally crabby at the end.OK, the premise is the usual pro-forma story of gal pals (I HATE that moniker, and use it here for a reason) who have vacationed together each August for 20 years, through thick and thin, yada yada. Gotcha. So now they are going to a largely uninhabited island, courtesy of the young trophy wife of their friend Teddy, who has remarried after a tragic car accident that killed his wife, their dear friend and contemporary. So, like the mature, 40-ish woman that they are, they have it in for the trophy wife, named "Baby" (I'm not making this up!)Fast forward to the car, where one of the women rips the cell phone out of Baby's hand and hurls it out the window, because she doesn't like her texting. REALLY? I hated this character for the rest of the book. Once they get to the island and the gorgeous family home that Baby is extending to them for their vacation, they snipe at her right and left; they ridicule her behind her back (and often in front of her); they drink enough alcohol to kill the average person, and they snipe, snipe, snipe away.Oh. And there are some "heartfelt secrets." Of course.And on top of that, nothing in the story rings true, nothing makes sense...I paused so many times to say, "WHAT?" Oh, my God, this book is a train wreck. It hurts my heart to say it, because I love Siddons, but she had no business publishing this book.

I read this on vacation, and absolutely gobbled it up. Is it great literature? No. Has Thayer written better? Yes. But who cares? The story held my interest from start to finish and was perfect for a lazy, hiking/swimming/reading break from all life's cares. One of the main characters in this story (I won't say who) reminded me a great deal of a character in Susan Wiggs' Lakeshore Chronicles series, but that was not a bad thing and it didn't bother me at all. I only mention it because I had the thought so often while reading the book.Thayer's obvious love of Nantucket shines through the story and in my case, makes me want to move there immediately. I won't belabor the plot, because so many reviewers have already discussed it, but the love between the two female protagonists, from childhood through life's pain and cares to adulthood, rang true and was very touching. OK, maybe the idea of rich girl/poor boy is a cliché, but the characters were so likeable and the tale so beguiling that it worked for me.I really don't have a negative thing to say about this book. If you are looking for brilliance, it probably won't appeal to you. If you want a nice, good read for a lazy summer day, this is your book.

I see I am in the minority here, and I don't want to ruffle any feathers, but this book made me crazy. First, let me say that I am a big fan of the Women's Murder Club series, and have read every single one. And it seems to me that the women get more and more stupid with every book, and the plots get more and more off the wall. Yes, I kept turning the pages, because Patterson does know how to hook the reader--even me. But I found myself getting increasingly annoyed.We'll start with my beloved Lindsay Boxer. She has a beautiful baby girl, whom she actually sees awake maybe 10 minutes every three days. She not only has to work late, to which all working mothers can relate, but when she CAN get home, she goes out instead with her girlfriends. Her mothering is confined to a kiss on the head and warm, fuzzy feelings--and oh, yes (spoiler alert): taking the baby out in the stroller when she knows there is a psychopathic serial killer after her.Then we have Claire, the ME, whom I always have loved...and SHE (another spoiler alert) is sneaking alcohol into the hospital room of her badly injured friend, because, being a doctor, it would never occur to her that alcohol might not mix with the pain killers and other meds that her friend is taking. REALLY?And Cindy, the Journalist Extraordinaire. She decides all by herself to single-handedly stalk one of the most dangerous psychopathic serial killers (see above) in the world. She puts herself in infinite danger, for a story. OK, we know she has an ego and wants the Pulitzer, but she has been a lot smarter than this in all the other books, and her navete is infinitely annoying.Yuki is Yuki, and I love her. She seems to have stayed true to type.Now let's go to the over the top plot(s). There are three intense plotlines going at once. That's fine; lots of authors of this genre do that. But each ONE is completely and totally off the wall, and to have all three going at once is like having one dessert too many...a type of sustained, out-of-body experience. Two of the plots are suddenly and quickly resolved. One is not, so now we know the subject of Book 14, which I WILL read, no matter what, because despite my criticism, I still like this series. Go figure.

I had misplaced my previous pair of these wonderful shears (I'll probably find them buried in a pot full of soil next winter!), and I felt lost without them. From gently pruning a wilting branch on a delicate annual to pruning a full-grown and pesky rose bush, these shears are easy to us, easy to handle, and perform as though they cost $100.Great value, great bargain, invaluable gardening tool!

Oh, how I loved the Claudia books in my early years. I can't even remember how many times I took them out from the library, reading and re-reading, loving them to death. And they stayed in my memory for decades. So very recently, I decided to see if I could find them again--and I did, right on Amazon, and was lucky enough to get an original copy, published during wartime (World War II)--complete with a plea for War Bonds on the back flap! Wonderful.And then I started reading, with great anticipation. And soon I was very, very sorry. First, let me say that I know the original stories were written in 1938, a far different time in so many ways. But the pompous young husband, whom I IDOLIZED when I was young, and the airhead young wife, who doesn't even know what a mortgage is, but has to have her Godlike husband explain it to her--do we really want to return to those days, if they ever existed?With mounting disappointment, I kept reading--while Claudia proudly glories in the fact that she was so "bad" that her husband David had to turn her over his knee and spank her--"just like a caveman," and wasn't she lucky to have such a masterful husband?Ew, Ew, and Triple Ew. This "ideal" actually helped shape my early views of marriage and womanhood, and thank God I got over it!I kept looking in vain for the lovely charm that I remembered from these books, which, I must reiterate, I truly loved. But I could find no charm at all, only stereotype after stereotype, from the stolid, fat German servants to the "intellectual" sister-in-law (who of COURSE cannot have children) to Claudia and David themselves to just about everything else.Oh, how I wish I had left this book in my memory.

This is just a sweet and good book, a reminder of an era gone by, when people still had sensibilities, when there was no Internet, when life was handled without cell phones and texting--and when religion was a very serious part of life.This gentle story of a recent widower, a devout Catholic, and the nun at his church who is questioning her vocation could be cloying and over the top. But it is not. It is written with such love, and such respect, that it is peaceful to read. The subject matter could be offensive to some readers, but I do not see how. The nun who is questioning her vows is so good, so deeply troubled by the thoughts she cannot pray away, that it is impossible not to be in her corner. Ditto the man whose life is shattered by the untimely loss of his young wife, as he struggles to come to grips with his still alive virility and his desire to be a good man and a good father.This book takes place in the time before Vatican II, when life could be very rigid for devout Catholics, so the anguish these two protagonists feel is very real and very palpable.I had never read LaVyrie Spencer before, and I am so glad that this is the book I chose.

I devoutly hope that this is not the last John Puller novel from Baldacci.I am no stranger to Baldacci ... I have read all his Camel Club books, all his King and Maxwell books, one Robie (and soon to start another), and more. I also discovered "Zero Day," his first John Puller novel, and liked it--and the character--very much. So I ordered "The Forgotten." And not only did I fall in love with John Puller all over again, but I was so ensnared in the plot that I could barely tear myself away!I am reviewing this after 3,000 people have gone before me. So it's ridiculous to even discuss the plot in any depth. But I will say this: It is hard to keep my interest. I am an editor by trade, and I read all day long, and by the time I have time for personal reading, I'm somewhat burned out and my attention span is not what it should be. But I was hooked from page 1.First of all, unlike many other popular authors of this and similar genres, Baldacci writes well. He truly does. So I do not find myself exasperatedly "editing" the sentences as I go along. Second, no matter how much I think I know what will happen, and even when I am RIGHT about what will happen, Baldacci never fails to surprise me. This book had me on the edge of my seat, especially in the last 100 pages--and I stayed on the edge of my seat until the last word of the last sentence of the last page of the book.Did Puller survive? I wasn't sure that would happen. Did the heroes survive? Did the bad guys get their just desserts? Maybe--and maybe NOT. You'll have to read it to be sure. And that's what makes a good book.

This is a stunning statement piece, but larger than I had expected it to be. I receive compliments every time I wear it, but for me, it is not a daily necklace. It is bold and gorgeous, but in my opinion, best saved for special occasions. However, that's my own style. It is truly a beautiful piece of work.

I wear this small, unobtrusive medal all the time, night and day. Whenever I touch it, which is often throughout each day, it is my way of asking Saint Monica to intercede for me, a mother who is praying for her son. The ad says that Saint Monica is a patron saint of abuse victims, but she is also a comfort to mothers. And this medal is so dainty and small that I can wear it daily, as I do, with everything.
Just stunningly made and very beautiful. I am amazed by the quality and the beauty of Our Lady's face. So glad I ordered it. The picture does not do it justice.

I don't know what I hated more about this book: The absolute predictability (spoiler alert): Well of COURSE she is going to be pregnant; she couldn't stomach her meals practically on page 1. Well of COURSE there is tons of "tension."Instead of eagerly turning the pages to see what happened next, I found myself increasingly annoyed, both with Macy, whose naivete was a bit more than I could stomach, and with everybody else.I do like a good romance, and I do like a good story, but all I felt when reading this book was impatience.

I read this book when I was a teen in the 60s, and it never left me. I never forgot the characters, from foolish, dreaming Matthew Soames to practical Callie to any of the daughters, most especially Jessica. I won't belabor the plot here, since so many have aptly described it, and to me, the plot was secondary.When I read this book (and I read it many, many times) I WAS the characters. I was there. I could smell it. Feel it. Taste it. I knew Jessica's desires and felt her reality. I understood Callie. Mathy? It was all understood in the end. What is it about this book that has stayed with me my entire life?It's sad that Jetta Carlson only wrote one book--but what a book. I look forward to reading it again now that I am considerably older, and to see if it has the same effect on me as it always did.

I read this book in less than a day. I could not put it down. And yes, I sometimes get snobby too about "romance" novels, but this is neither a romance nor a "throwaway" book. Debbie Macomber is always a good storyteller, but this novel, about three women who choose to be nuns before Vatican II and what happens in their lives is moving, spiritual and has a truth that resonates.I'm not going to do spoilers and retell the plot, but I will say that I was deeply drawn to each young woman who took the step in becoming a Sister. None of the three was fey or silly about her decision; each prayed long and hard and believed she was making the right choice. The very real struggles, heartaches and triumps of these women, and their heartfelt wish to be good members of their convent, moved me deeply.This is a beautiful, beautiful book, well worth the read. It won't leave me soon.

This first in what I hope is to be a long series about bucolic, hippie dippie Trafalgar, British Columbia, is simply a delight. Although it starts a bit slow, it soon picks up as we learn the ins and outs of the very outspoken townspeople, and get to know our heroine, rookie constable Molly Smith, aka "Moonlight," so named by her "stuck in the 60s" mother.Told with gentle humor and obvious love and respect for the characters, this murder mystery unfolds with tension so subtle, that the reader is drawn in and holding his breath without even realizing it! Seemingly mundane in nature (a loved-hated developer, who has a lot of opposition in Trafalgar, is found brutally murdered and everybody and nobody is the suspect), the plot proverbially thickens until just about everybody is a suspect.I just loved the combination of love and humor Delany uses when describing Molly's over-the-top mother and other hippies who don't know what year it is--having lived in that generation, I could relate!Excellent novel; on to the next!

While a fast, competent read, as are all of Siddons' books, this one is full of unremitting distress, broken by some oases of happiness that are as over the top as the distress, making the reader dread the next chapter.Our heroine and narrator, Thayer, is a very likeable woman, from childhood on. She is strong and vibrant--and yet seems unwilling or unable to resist the unspeakable cruelty of her mother, even though she knows from a very early age what her mother is, and what she is capable of. So when Thayer goes repeatedly into a type of psychic trance every time her mother attacks (and in one memorable scene, attacks in a way that will leave Thayer damaged for life), it is hard to believe. She didn't see it coming? She didn't figure it out? WE did...over and over and over.There is magic, both imagined and maybe real; there is madness; there is true cruelty; there is some laughter and love...and through it all, Thayer floats around with a "bubble" around her, protecting her from all knowledge of what is going on. It's the way she survives--or maybe not.I did not understand the ending at all, and still don't. It was told in metaphors and allusions--and I didn't get them. Am I alone?I love Siddons, have read everything by her, but this was very strange and very unsatisfying.

OK, let me start out first by saying that, flawed as this book is, it held my interest during one heat-wave-plagued weekend where I was forced to sit reading in the AC or melt. I hardly put it down. So obviously, the book is not a complete dud.However, the more I read, the more I said to myself, "Oh, another disaffected Catholic book"; I've read many, and that was how I saw it and it got on my nerves no END. That having been said, this book is NOT funny, NOT lighthearted, NOT a breeze read. The main character, Alice, is one of the most hateful protagonists I've encountered in a long time, and despite her guilt over her long-kept secret, I had no sympathy or understanding. She was simply hateful.Her daughter and granddaughter were interesting, if not cliched...surprisingly, the only woman in the book I felt sorry for and interested in was the "goody-two-shoes" daughter-in-law, Ann-Marie. My heart broke for her on many different levels, and I felt she was more finely drawn than the others, more believeable, more likeable, more real.I can't say not to read this book, but do not expect what the blurbs say, and do not expect a resolution or any kind of meaningful wrapup at the end!

I am a rabid Frank fan and have read everything she has written and loved it all. I understand Frank's ambitious desire to tell the story of Dorothea Heyward, and applaud that. But I think it should have been a book on its own, perhaps a real biography, or at least a fictionalized bio, a la "The Paris Wife" (about Hemingway's first wife; a work of fiction, but based entirely on fact).As it is, God forgive me, I felt my heart sinking every time we segued into yet another sloooooooooow and, forgive me again, boooooring look at Dorothy and DuBose. I found myself wanting to skip over those parts, even though I did find the subject matter interesting--but not in the middle of an entirely DIFFERENT book, one that I found funny and interesting.Great effort, it just didn't work.

I picked this up because I needed a bare-bones MIDI interface to control a piece of audio processing gear (not a MIDI keyboard). I did notice ahead of time that there were mixed reviews, but the low price made it worth a gamble.  While it might indeed have some issues under heavy load, it has worked without issues in my application.  I've used it both under OSX and Windows.  Because it's class-compliant, there's no need to install a driver in either OS.For modest needs, it's certainly worth a try.

It's looking more and more like the Wachowskis had one good movie in them.  "The Matrix" was extraordinary, with compelling visuals and a taught, original story line.  The sequels were best forgotten.  And now this overstuffed mess.The plot, such as it is, could have used some serious paring down.  There are countless characters who find their ways into the action with no apparent reason.  There are zillions of different species--all creepy and all bad--who exist only as an update to the Star Wars cantina scene. At any time some decent dialog would have done the trick you're instead assaulted with CG. The primary attribute of this bloviating mess is noise--visual and audible.  It claims to be an allegory about waste and corporate greed.  Yeah, and I'm a fish.There's a wasted performance by Eddie Redmayne--quite creepy--as well as a wasted score by Michael Giacchino.  But the biggest waste was two and a half hours watching this tubby vanity project.

Anybody likes an occasional disaster flick.  Unlike many Hollywood disasters, Pompeii actually happened. This is the unlikely love story of a Celtic gladiator and the daughter of the local burgomeister. That's improbable enough, but hey--go with it.  It's even kind of fun to see a reconstruction of this once-thriving small city.But it's all sunk by the stinker of a performance given by Kiefer Sutherland as the evil Roman senator. My spouse and I couldn't agree on which was worse--his absolutely awful British accent or his wooden performance.  I've got scaps of wood in my shop that could have done a better job with the role. In a movie like this, you look forward to some scenery-chewing by the designated villain.  Not here.  He dragged every scene down quicker than the ships sinking in the harbor.We saw this one as part of a freebie weekend from the cable company.  Sure glad we didn't pay for it!

Charles Ives--while never quite invisible--endured a long period of relative obscurity.  As his centennial approached in the 1970s, interest in this unusual composer began to increase.  Young musicians found a kindred soul.  More established musicians found good reason to program Ives's music (this was before the days when orchestral boards demanded pablum). This was the time that I first encountered Ives. His music has been an occasional companion ever since.It should be said that a little Ives can go a long way.  He was prolific and perhaps not particularly disciplined as a composer, and left us many pieces in varying condition.  His style--a casserole of sentimental music, layered with abrupt changes and discordances, often makes it hard to distinguish one piece from another.  But among all of this music are some real gems.  The Piano Sonatas and the 4th Symphony are solid and serious pieces.  So is "Three Places in New England".  The St. Gaudens movement (inspired by a powerful bas relief on the Boston Common) is a slow march of ghosts.  There is supreme irony in the use of "Old Black Joe" as primary material.  "Putnam's Camp" gives us a tangible feel for an army campsite, with marching soldiers, campfires, caissons and onlookers.  "Housatonic" interweaves long horn and string lines with the fog of string tremelos.  This is really effective tone painting.  The second orchestral set, also on this CD, is less successful although the opening movement has much to recommend it.I've often thought of Carl Ruggles as something of a one-hit wonder.  But oh what a hit!  "Sun-Treader" has one of the most breathtaking introductions of any piece I know.  It's a fortissimo timpani beat with a searing brass crie du coeur.  After decades it still makes me sit up straight. The overall sensibilities of the piece are quite German. It is a sonata form, but virtually all development is contrapuntal.  There are inverted canons, retrograde canons, bits of counterpoint long and short.  There's a quite logical sense of the long line throughout these 15 intense minutes.  The coda mixes the original material with a powerful recitativo in the strings.  This is a stunning piece of music.Ruggles wrote only a handful of pieces and destroyed most of those.  The other piece included on this CD is "Men and Mountains".  While it has its moments, the dissonance feels gratuitous and the form is disjunct. It feels like all of his other music pointed the way to "Sun-Treader"There was a pleasant surprise for me on this CD.  That's the "Andante for Strings" by Ruth Crawford (Seeger).  I'd heard the String Quartet from which this movement was derived, but it made little impression on me at the time.  I'm going to have to rethink that.  The Andante in its orchestral form has a pulsating and needful urgency.  If you were told it was Ligeti or Lutoslawski, you wouldn't have any trouble believing it.  It's a single phrase that builds to a logical peak and then dies away.  Ruth Crawford had just begun to make a name as a composer when she turned away and began editing collections of folk music.  That is our loss.This CD is twenty years old, and I'm sorry I'd missed it until now.  Dohnanyi gets to the core of the music and the recording is quite good. These are essential pieces for any collection.

I've had many years of experience as a bass and guitar player. But I've always used a traditional 4-string. I needed a 5-string for various reasons, but I wanted to start out with a minimal commitment. I've had previous experience with Ibanez and always felt that the brand gave a satisfactory experience for reasonable dollars.That's the case here. There are few obvious places where corners were cut.  Knobs and machine heads aren't top of the line--but they're serviceable. Pickups might be improved, but those are really very personal choices for a player.  And the finish won't knock you over with beauty.  But the positive attributes outweigh the negative by a long shot.  The neck has a fairly flat profile and is easy to get around on. It's actually quite straight--I've see far worse necks on more expensive instruments. The whole instrument is quite light.  This may mean that it doesn't hold up in gigging situations where it gets knocked around.  But it's a spare studio instrument for me and will be treated tenderly.The thing I like least is the active pickups. There's a knob that goes from flat at one end to a hypered bass/treble boost at the other.  Gain and distortion go up as a result.  You're far better off managing the EQ in your amp.  You can find simple plans on the web for bypassing this circuit, and that's the route I'll take when I've got a little time.But again, you've got to think about what you're paying (which isn't much).  This is a value instrument for either a starting player or for someone who needs a spare.

There's always something that needs hanging on a wall.  Whether family photos, certificates or fine art, it always appears that there's one more nail to drive.  Velcro has a nice solution for things of moderate weight.  It's really just a variant of the old Velcro trick--only a bit less noticeable for purposes of display.The hook side of the Velcro glues to the back or your objet d'art.  The cloth piece (white in color and thinner than typical velcro) goes on the wall.  Simple enough.  I've hung several 8.5 x 11 items on my wall and they're staying where I put them.  It's worth mentioning that the cloth piece is about twice the size of the hook piece.  That makes it much easier to reposition.Simple solution.  Works fine.

I've been playing with various sets of Elixer strings and I like what I've been finding. These are similar to the nickel strings of the same gauge, but have a brassier sound.  If string-snapping is part of your repertoire, or if you like a crisper sound from your bass, these are worth a try.  I've found the gauges of these Light/Medium to be a little more tonally balanced across the set than the pure Light strings.It's unusual to find a new kid on the block in the venerable business of instrument strings, but Elixer strings have made a strong entry.

This cable has an interesting finish.  It's plastic, but made to look like braided metal (as you'd see in a coax cable). That may give an impression that it's tougher than it might really be.  Only time will tell in that regard.Construction and build quality look OK.  The cable is just a bit stiffer than other cables, but it still wraps up fairly small if you need to tuck it into a laptop case. It charges my iPhone and that's all you can ask it to do.

Because my computers are in a separate room from my workspace, I have longer cable runs than most people.  In setting up a secondary system, the run length exceeded the 15' cable (also Cable Matters) that I already had.  This extension covered the gap.  No problems at all with a 1920x1200 monitor at 60Hz.

There are perhaps two primary targets for this work center.  General contractors will set it up somewhere on the job site and cut framing all day. Then there are homeowners with limited room in their shops.  I fit squarely into the latter category. I seem always to be setting up temporary tables or even extending my saw table to hold a workpiece while I drill, cut, sand or whatever I'm doing.  For my needs, there are many very good ideas in this stand:First of all, the legs fold up underneath without requiring disassembly. The wheels allow you (if you're very careful) to roll the stand into a corner for storage. The outrigger extensions will hold large pieces fairly steady, with a decent amount of height adjustment.  The built-in power strip is tremendously welcome, and the gooseneck LED light--even with a too-narrow beam, helps to illuminate key areas of the piece you're working on.The most notable feature is the pair of extension locks.  These clamp on to the main frame very easily, and hold your miter saw, drill press or other tool.  They should also be able to hold any sort of jig you might need to make for pipe-bending or some other purpose. There's an easy hand grip on each arm that makes attaching and removing a snap.But there are some serious fit-and-finish problems here as well. There are adjustment knobs to hold the outrigger extensions--basically just a bolt with a plastic knob.  One had molding problems and came apart in my hand.  The other looks like it will soon follow suit.  The "tool storage" area is laughably small with a plastic door that's waiting to come apart.  There are cross-braces for the legs that are clearly an afterthought.  They provide minimal stiffening and must be removed in order to fold the legs into the body.  But the biggest issue I encountered is the support T's that slip into the outrigger extensions.  The fit is so tight that it's almost impossible to move the T's up and down.  Both T's had this problem.  I inspected them carefully to try and find any sign of shipping damage, but there were no bends or distortions.  The rough finish of the T, combined with the low tolerance hole, means that the thing is simply too tight.  I'll probably try a bit of graphite first, followed perhaps be a silicone lubricant. But I have doubts as to my success.  It took a rubber mallet to get one of them to move and the other wasn't much better. The operator's manual could use a bit more detail as well.I think that Porta Mate has the bones of a very good product.  Whether the problems I encountered are design, manufacturing or quality-assurance problems, I simply can't say.  But I think they're addressable and I hope the appropriate steps are taken.

The Case Logic brand is the first place I look when I need some sort of carrying case.  I rarely have to look any farther. I picked this up for my 2014 MacBook Pro 15".  Computer slips right in, power supply goes easily in the side pouch, and there's still plenty of room for business cards, writing pad and pen, and anything else you might need on a short business trip.  And--as with all other Case Logic bags--the whole thing is smaller than other bags.  Quality is good and the whole thing will fit easily under an airline seat.

I've got a 2014 MacBook Pro, which of course has no hard connection for ethernet.  This adapter changes that.  It's small enough to go into the bag with your computer.  Wish it was a little less pricy, but it works fine.

If you're under the sink dealing with a balky flare joint, you will sometimes need an extra hand to hold a nut in place or to loosen it. A locking plier of this type might be the answer.  This trio covers most necessary sizes, and has a nice wide maw to get the tool into place before clamping down. The Vise-grip style lock is sturdy enough to hold sufficiently for most cases.I do wish the set was better-built though.  The business-end--the jaws that hold the nut itself--is a little rough and uneven.  It's enough that you might find yourself needing to replace the nut after a use or two. Welds at the angled portion are also crude.  I think they're more than solid enough, but they just don't look like quality.I will commend the manufacturer on simple packaging--a cardboard box and acid-free paper around the tools.  It's plenty protective enough for shipment and doesn't have the waste or cut-potential that you'd find with blister packs.

Once upon a time, a laser printer was a luxury item. Those of us who couldn't justify the cost found ourselves first with dot-matrix and then with inkjets.  While it's true that a high-quality inkjet will now give better overall results than a laser, it comes with a high cost for consumables and a certain level of fussiness.  That cost isn't always justified when you're printing primarily documents or drafts.This very nice printer from Brother now brings all the advantages of laser printer at a very low cost. It's impressive right out of the box. There are no flimsy plastic extensions to manage paper flow.  The paper tray is internal (it looks like it will hold a full ream) and the paper output sits nicely in an internal tray.  This should help keep dust from accumulating on paper and going into the printer mechanism. It's clear this is a monochrome printer--the documentation steers you toward ordinary bond paper and away from all the coated papers you might use with a photo printer. The print quality is quite readable.  It's not as black as a good inkjet black, but I was able to print at 5-point resolution and easily read the result.  And a very big plus is the ability to do double-sided printing without swapping paper around.  Just specify double-sided output, queue the job and that's what you get.  Nice.  It's a little on the loud side: not terrible, but noticeable, and you will need to be prepared for a slight whiff of ozone when you print.There are two ways you can set this device up--the touch-screen display and a browser interface.  You'll find yourself gravitating toward the latter choice.  The color touch screen is bright and attractive, but it's also quite small.  It's almost impossible to enter text there.  My fingers were simply too large, and I could barely get by with a small pencil eraser as a substitute.  Good enough for running a copy, but that's about it.  The browser interface on the other hand is quite nice.  Using that (and a temporary USB cable--not included) it's very easy to set up your wireless networking and to perform status checks at any time.Copying and scanning can be done easily enough from the front panel, but scanning is more easily done from the host.  Windows software is included and support is built into the Mac. Scanning quality is good (up to 600DPI), but it's not photo-scan quality. Colors are a bit washed and detail is a little soft.  But as a document scanner it's perfectly sufficient.Additional kudos to Brother for providing a real printed manual.  It's not the complete manual (that's available online), but it's a lot more than the two pages of cartoon drawings you get with most hardware these days.I'm using the device wirelessly.  It goes only to 802.11/n --no C--but it does receive on both popular bands. I'm using a Mac, running Yosemite.  In setting up the wireless connection, I encountered a bug.  Strangely enough, that's one of the reasons I'm recommending this printer strongly.  The bug appeared in the failure of the device to wake from sleep (it goes to sleep after a minute of inactivity, unless you change that value).When testing a device like this, we don't always get the chance to comment on the quality of customer service. Most problems don't appear until later, so followup comments in reviews may never be seen.  So it's always a positive to be able to report on the experience that a few users will invariably encounter.  I contacted Brother's customer support (available in several modes--I chose chat) and described my problem.  I did not identify myself as a reviewer.  The representative was courteous and professional and knew her stuff.  We walked through a set of tests and procedures and never once did I sense impatience, even though we took well over an hour. When it appeared there really was a problem, she escalated the call and told me I would hear back within 24 hours.  She was as good as her word.  I was contacted by technical staff the next morning.  We went over a number of things and finally settled on a workaround.  The problem will have to be fixed, and I'm sure it will be, but they didn't let me go until I had a working printer.This is a company that makes a quality product and stands behind it. I've experienced all sorts of levels of support (and evasion) from different companies.  But these guys do it right.

This is the movie that begat a whole stream of very funny movies from a great ensemble cast.  Rob Reiner got the ball rolling with Spinal Tap, and then Christopher Guest kept it going with Guffman, Best in Show and several others.Heavy Metal rock is often an unintentional parody, which explains the fact that many original viewers thought this was a documentary.  And the fact is that it's only a slightly enhanced version of the truth.  My business puts me in contact with a fair number of old rockers, and this movie could have easily been about many of them.  From the unenlightened lyrics to the woozy sophomoric philosophy, this captures an age.It looks great in BluRay and the bad music sounds--perhaps not 'great', but clean. If you're of a certain age you'll see things you remember (and possibly see yourself)--if you're able to see through the tears of laughter.

One of the residents of my household is a medium-sized parrot.  He's had one of these for years and it's a favorite toy. He alternates between guarding it and rolling it out for a game of toss.  I can say that it's taken a beating, but has still held up for all that time. It's a good-sized toy for medium/large parrots.  They can easily pick it up and shake it, giving the reward of the bell inside.  If you know birds, then you know the more noise, the better.We've picked up a second one as a reserve.  As well as the old one has lasted, it won't go forever.  Good to have a reserve.

I first encountered Tasc shirts though the Vine review program.  The shirt that I was sent was an immediate hit.  Soft, with a tailored look (for a Tee Shirt), it fit nicely and was comfortable as could be.  it's now several months later, and that shirt has kept its softness and flexibility.  After repeated washings it's still nearly new.So what to do?  Get more. It's now cooler weather here, and the long sleeves add just that extra bit of warmth.  I've ordered several more Tasc shirts in varying styles.  Even at a premium price, they're bargains.

I first encountered Tasc shirts though the Vine review program.  The shirt that I was sent was an immediate hit.  Soft, with a tailored look (for a Tee Shirt), it fit nicely and was comfortable as could be.  it's now several months later, and that shirt has kept its softness and flexibility.  After repeated washings it's still nearly new.So what to do?  Get more.  I've ordered several more Tasc shirts in varying styles.  Even at a premium price, they're bargains.

George Van Eps is a name known by guitarists--even without knowing his music.  It's not far off the mark to describe him as one of the progenitors of modern jazz guitar. Before Van Eps, the guitar was a resident of the rhythm section and rarely stepped out to the front of the band. Van Eps--along with his 7-string guitar--envisioned a guitar that could be an equivalent to piano.  And he got there.  It's hard not to hear his chord passages as an antecessor  for the later work of guitarists like Wes Montgomery or Howard Roberts. Although he lived a long and productive life, his playing never had the prominence of contemporaries like Charlie Christian or Montgomery.  But he deserves a listen and the listener will be rewarded.The recordings on this CD are all from the late 1940s, and most sound like they were transcribed from 78s.  They haven't gotten--and may never get--the sort of detailed cleanup that many vintage recordings deserve.  You'll need a first pass just to get through the technical limitations.  But after that, you'll begin to to hear what Van Eps was doing.  His chording is firm and precise and his lead work is restrained and always tasteful. There is no slop in this playing. His guitar sound is basically acoustic, with just a bit of amplification (a guitar sound that's still never been surpassed).Most of the performances are here in multiple takes, and each take is rather different from the others.  That's jazz. Enjoy.  It's a treat.

I've been through a few routers in my day.  All have strengths and drawbacks and this unit from Belkin is no exception.  But the strengths outnumber the drawbacks and many users will find this does a great job for them.The first thing you'll see on starting up (like all routers, it provides a browser window) is an attempt to hook up to the web.  Before you start that, you'll need details from your ISP, including the communication methodology (PPPoE, etc) and any passwords. Some ISPs require a specific MAC for the router (mine does), so you'll have to bypass this automatic method and go straight to the control panel. Once you're connected, you'll be able to fine tune the router.  You'll head to the control panel for this as well.The control panel is pretty easy to navigate, and you can find and adjust the features you need pretty easily.  If you've been around routers, you'll have few problems.  If not, you'll get less help than you need from the user guide (downloadable PDF). It's incomplete and doesn't begin to describe the capabilities of the router.  This is an area where Belkin needs to apply some effort.
