I was happy to find that the default security settings were pretty strong.  You can tighten them up by restricting known phishing sites and so on.  I do wish that the default for SSID broadcast was OFF, but maybe that's just me (This is the point that someone invariably posts a comment that SSID broadcast doesn't matter.  I don't disagree when you're talking about the creep in the coffee shop who knows his way around Wireshark.  But most of these systems will be in residential areas where you're just worried about a neighbor grabbing some free bandwidth for something he shouldn't be doing).  I also wish that Guest access was off by default. Naive users tend to leave these things on, and that's not the right thing to do in a world where security takes on increasing importance.Wireless performance was quite good.  My ISP gives me about 60 MB/s and I had no trouble getting that performance a floor away. When I was a floor away and about 40 feet laterally, it fell to about 20 MB/s.  Another very good Buffalo router (802.11/n) falls to just over 2 MB/s at that same distance. The antenna is inside the case, and you don't have to twiddle with external antennae (that's usually a pointless endeavor anyway).There are two USB connections on the unit.  One is USB2 and the other USB3. You can connect a media drive to either of these and use the included Twonky DNLA server software.  I like Twonky a lot: it's easy to use it as the heart of a media center.There is one drawback (in addition to the poor user guide).  This unit does not support reserved DHCP.  I have an unusually large network for a residence, since that network is also supporting two businesses.  I prefer reserved DHCP for many devices in this network because it lets me easily save links to the control panels of devices on the net without having to slog through network logs to determine the current IP address.  I think that Belkin could improve this in a firmware update and I hope they do.  This drawback keeps me from using this as a replacement for my Buffalo router.  However, it still works very nicely as a wireless access point, so I've connected it that way and still improved the overall performance of my network.Belkin has come some distance from their starting point of cheap cables and hubs.  This is a nice step along the way.
Our parrot (mid-sized) has played with these for years.  Easy to pick up and throw, so they're good for a game of catch.  Perhaps a bit pricey, but they'll take a lot of abuse.

LED lighting has come a long way in just a few years.  The first generation showed promise, in a dim sort of way. But they're now ready for prime time. Many users are now replacing unloved CFLs with cooler and safer LEDs.  Most of the fixtures in my house have made the transition, and just about all that's left is a few long 40-watt fluorescents.The first thing you'll notice is the relatively small diameter of the tube.  The next thing you might notice is a label claiming 32 watt equivalency (hold that thought). A minute on the stepladder and bulbs were swapped.  That 32-watt equivalency turns out to be noticeably brighter than the 40-watt it was replacing. I was also pleased at the nicely-diffused light.  Those earliest LEDs tended to be very directional, with hot spots and lots of shadowy areas.  These Sylvanias have a perfectly smooth pattern.  Another pleasant surprise.The package claims a life of 45 years.  I'll have to get back to you on that.

I've long enjoyed Michael Shermer's one-page essays in Scientific American.  For that reason, I looked forward to spending time with this book (it's a big book, so you'll spend lots of time with it). Having said that, it took me some time to warm to the task.  It started out feeling rather like a compendium of information I already knew--with particular debt to the work of Steven Pinker. But it picks up steam rapidly and ends as a quite worthwhile experience.You can't have a book about morality without defining your terms.  For some, morality is a set of dictates from a bearded man in the sky somewhere. For others, it's simply a group of rules created ex nihilo--with the aim of controlling people. Shermer spends a good amount of time showing the evolutionary roots of morality and how we can still see those early forms at work in the animal kingdom. He defines morality a number of times, but each shaded definition feels much like the old Golden Rule. Our actions, if they are to be moral, should be felt as fair by the recipients of those actions.No discussion of morality is complete without talking about religion. In recent years, a number of writers (Dawkins, Harris, et al) have written strong arguments against religion.  There's a certain "rah rah" nature to many of these books, and I don't find a hint of that here.  At the same time, Shermer shows clearly that religion has always been a clear reflection of culture--pro-inquisition, pro-slavery, anti-female, anti-gay--until a changing culture drags it along, usually kicking and screaming.  Religious readers may not be comfortable with this section, but it's written fairly and without anger. Moral behavior is concerned more with actions than with belief.One cannot speak about moral behavior without talking about IMMORAL behavior.  What do we do about it? Leaving aside issues that may be contentious, we would all argue that stealing and violence must be controlled in a successful society.  Shermer's chapters on justice constitute the real heart of the book for me. He defines types of justice.  Of those, two stand out:  Retributive justice (lock 'em up and throw away the key) satisfies our baser instincts, but often leaves little satisfaction and no compensation in the hands of the victims.  Restorative justice (there's a great example from New Guinea) shares the aim of punishing the criminal while still trying to give reparation to the victim and strengthen the society.The final chapter is given over to speculation.  Where might we go in the decades, centuries and millennia to come? Will our current bloated nation-states wither away?  Will visiting aliens be moral or Conquistadores?  Shermer is an optimist (probably more so than I am), and his thoughtful book provides a persuasive argument that we're on the right course.

Over the years, there have been many movies that manage to cross boundaries.  Whether it's 'The Princess Bride' or 'Up', some works of fantasy are justifiably loved by young and old.  Well-drawn characters become parts of our own narratives.'Guardians' is not that.  It's hackwork.  It substitutes noise and kinetic distraction for thoughtful writing. I'm happy that many fine actors found a payday in this movie, but I hope they have all gone out and found new agents. They deserve better.It appears that Stan Lee and his minions have an endless fountain of these characters and I fear the onslaught is not yet over. But I prefer movies that take longer to write than they take to watch.

There's always an element of adventure when heading to a new format. For me, that's the H.265 codec.  With less-than-ideal bandwidth in my media center, lowering the bitrate can be helpful.  Of course, H.265 is a new codec and continues to undergo development.  It was with full knowledge of this that I decided to try this: one of the earliest devices to support H.265.I could deal, if only barely, with the terrible excuse for English in the user interface and the user guide.  The device is made in China, but there are plenty of Chinese who speak excellent English.  Perhaps this company should consider hiring one.  My excitement faded further when I saw what an absolutely impenetrable mess the user interface is.  It's covered with "apps", most of which I'd delete--if I could.  Doesn't seem to be permitted. The UI always seemed to go to the wrong place.But where they lost me was the wireless hookup.  I try to keep my home network secure, and one of the things I do is hide my wireless SSIDs.  This device offered no way to type in an SSID, so the ID had to be visible.  I turned on SSID broadcast on my router and eventually got connected.  Reasoning that the SSID would stay in the device's memory, I then turned off broadcast.  No dice. The player disconnected.How was the H.265 playback?  Fine, but that's because it's a new chip that's available to any manufacturer.  I'll wait for it to appear elsewhere.  The Tronfy was rushed to market and it shows.  Back it goes.

Over the last few months, I've had the opportunity to test a number of headsets which are supposedly targeted at gamers. While there may be a few elements of industrial design which appeal to a gamer's sensibilities, in the end these must pass muster as headsets. They need to sound reasonably good.  They need to have decent microphones without significant breath or handling noise. And--perhaps more than anything else--they need to be wearable for hours on end.These phones satisfy those requirements better than most.  The sound is nicely balanced.  There's low end without being too exaggerated. Highs have presence without being painful. They don't have the presence of true high-end headphones, but they don't have the price either. The microphone does a good job of eliminating breath noise, and has a good enough sound for talkback or podcasting.  I also like the way that it slides back into the ear cup when not in use.As far as the final criterion--comfort--these are among the best in this category.  As with my very high-end AKGs, these are supported mainly by a flexible sling that passes over the head. There's very little actual pressure (I've tested headphones that felt like clamps).  Combined with the overall lightness of the set, you should be able to wear these for hours.

Donald Hall no longer writes poetry and that's our loss.  But he shows considerable powers as an essayist in this concentrated little set. There's a nice circularity here: he begins with a description of his day--compressed into just a few small rooms of his old farmhouse. He then takes us through a group of set pieces, a newlywed drive through Yugoslavia, illnesses that stole a wife, honors (and dishonors), and then increasing infirmities that bring us back to life in the here and now. There are moments of great seriousness, but just as many that show a wonderful dry wit (his one-sentence description of Mick Jagger is worth the entire book).At most times, Hall maintains a certain distance: just as he did in his poetry.  He's not dispassionate, but instead he's leaving room for the readers to experience their own emotions--to inhabit the world with him.  This is not what you might expect from a valedictory, but it shows a real generosity.  He's not preparing to die.  Instead he's learning to live in a smaller world.I'm now at the boundary between late middle age and whatever we might call the next stage.  Most of Hall's experience of old age lies in front of me (let's hope).  But much of what I see in my ancient parents and their diminishing circle is well-described here. It's an interesting land of hope, disappointment and grace.

One shouldn't expect caviar on a peanut butter budget, and this headset is no exception.  The phones are functional, and actually don't sound bad.  Ergonomically, they need some work.  Even though they're lightweight, they still don't sit comfortably: in order to get a reasonable seal around the ear, they feel clamped-on.  I couldn't wear them but a few minutes before I had to take them off. The microphone would also benefit from a wind-screen. There's no way I could eliminate the sound of the wind stream from my nostrils. Other headsets have success in this area, and it seems that Turtle Beach could do some work here.  While targeted at gaming, these things are often used for multiple jobs: this would not be a good choice for Skyping or podcasting.I did appreciate the connection flexibility.  There's a mini-phono connection for use with smart phones.  There's also a USB adapter (with volume control a a bit of bass-boost) for use on a regular computer. But for me, these positive attributes were outweighed by ergonomics.  Gamers often play for hours at a time, and it's hard to see how you could endure these.

In my house there's a small table by the door.  It seems to be the place where all devices go to charge.  There always seem to be more devices than wall outlets, so oftentimes it's one device after another. This little multicharger is a handy way to charge things all at once. The power cable is quite robust--it actually looks like it could carry considerably more current that would really be needed.  I can't say I've had all four outlets in use, but I have been using three--bluetooth earbuds, iPhone, iPad--and there doesn't appear to be a penalty for multiple simultaneous charges.  I do have to note that the iPad 2 will charge slowly.  It will claim that it's not charging at all, but it will be accumulating a charge.  This is an issue with most chargers and appears to be specific to iPad.It's a small point--but it matters to me--that the charger comes in a minimal package.  It's a simple cardboard box and is only what's needed to get the box from Amazon to you. Easy to open, perfectly protective and a bit easier on the environment.  I wish more manufacturers would follow this lead.This is simple technology, to be sure, but it addresses one of those nagging little problems that modern life has brought along.

This is an interesting bit of technology that needs a little more work to make it a solid recommend. Let's talk about what I liked first.  The sound is excellent.  Bluetooth streaming tends to have a lower bitrate than wired headphones and that's often noticeable.  While these buds won't replace my Shures, they sounded quite good--unforced with just the tiniest bit of midrange honk.  They also do a good job of measuring heart-rate and of pacing a workout.  The hear-rate measurements themselves were very good and the buds also managed a pretty good approximation of the pseudo-distance I covered on my treadmill, coming within about 10 percent of the number given by the treadmill.  I can only speculate about how this works.  I assume there's a built-in accelerometer that works in conjunction with the height I type in on the personal information.  I wasn't bothered at all by the small deviation.I was more surprised by the variance in calorie burn.  The Jabra system gave me only a fifth of the calorie consumption computed by the treadmill.  Of course the treadmill knows that I put it on the "straight uphill" setting and the earbuds have no way of knowing that.  Still, it was a very large variance.  If my workouts were targeted at calories, I'd be concerned that either the earbuds or the treadmill was way off.The physical design of the earbuds is pretty nice--they stay in place because of a soft rubber tine that nestles into the ear.  I've had lots of earbuds slip out when I get sweaty, but these weren't a problem.  However, one of those rubber pieces must be moved out of place to slip in the charging cable and it can easily fall off the earbud and get lost.  I think this needs addressing.Of course to get any of this stuff working, you need the software.  It was easy to download (free) on my iPhone, but I've got to say the software is something of a mess.  The first piece you get is a music app--completely unneeded on an iPhone.  From there, you download the sport app which can track your workouts.  Unfortunately, some of the features (like resting heart rate) are recorded in the music app.  This is nonsense.  Why the sport app can't be completely self-contained is beyond me.But my biggest concern is privacy.  This is an app that connects to the cloud, and the potential for abuse--either by Jabra or by people who hack Jabra--is high.  There is not a statement about privacy with the software and there are no preferences that allow you to control where your information goes.  It's an absolute black hole.  It may be that absolutely no data leaves your phone.  Or it may be that you get data-mined in every way possible.  It's a total mystery and I hope that Jabra will comment on this review and clarify what's going on.  I'm concerned enough about the potential for abuse that I'm likely to forgo the many positive characteristics of these buds and remove the software.  Perhaps it will integrate more directly with the built-in Apple software in future.  There's absolutely no way I'd trust these apps on an Android system.So it's a tough call.  If your concerned about security, then I'd wait for a definitive statement from Jabra.  if not, then it's a pretty nice little system.

It was just over a year ago that I review this device's predecessor, the Ambient Weather WR-111B Emergency Solar Hand Crank AM/FM/NOAA Digital Radio, Flashlight, Cell Phone Charger with NOAA Certified Weather Alert & Cables.  Very little has changed, and that's a positive. The two models are externally indistinguishable and basic performance and battery life are about the same.  There are two very minor new features: There's now a siren mode (it really sounds more like an electronic phone ringing) and an emergency light blink.  There may be a few cases where this is useful. But since the siren doesn't sound like a siren, it may not really summon needed assistance.  There's also a mode in which the radio is permanently connected to power.  A loss of power will cause the light to come on automatically.  I'd be surprised if many people will give up a power outlet or USB slot for this feature.So if you've got the earlier model, there really no need to replace it.  But if you don't have an emergency radio in a handy location, this is a few dollars well worth spending.

What can you say?  This is among Hitchcock's 3 or 4 best films and stands head and shoulders above most of the work coming from Hollywood--then or now. Casting is perfect and the writing is taut.  The BluRay transfer was well worth waiting for.  It's an essential part of any film-lover's catalog.

There's really not much to say about an entry-level switch.  This one works with no diminution of speed (compared to my primary switch) using a NAS drive.  It couldn't be easier to use--plug it in--so it's a nice choice for a small office or simple home setup.  There's no port prioritization, so there are likely to be better choices if a media server is part of your system.  But it's dirt-cheap and does the job.The biggest problem is the wall wart provided with the switch. the plug-end is configured so that it will take up three spaces on your surge protector.  A simple 90-degree change in the orientation of the plug would have made a big difference.  So if your surge protector is close to filled up, you may need to budget for another one.  That makes this switch just a bit less of a bargain.

This is what science fiction is all about.  It's not about intergalactic princesses, bug-eyed monsters or dogfights in spaceships.  It's about us. It's a story that could occur in a possible future (not too far away) and brings us face-to-face with a number of ethical dilemmas.  It forces us to consider our growing power in biology and it shows us a whole new kind of slavery.It's almost all Sam Rockwell, who has only the voice of Kevin Spacey and himself to play against.  It's a really fine performance by an actor who often seems to fly under the radar.  You'll think about this movie.

This review was originally very positive.  I really liked this keyboard for quite a while.  Then...The keyboard began to have battery-charging problems after a few months.  After investigating online, I found that this was a fairly common problem with this keyboard.  So finally in late August of 2014 I contacted the Logitech service department.  The technician was friendly and walked me through a set of questions.  In short order, she promised me she'd have a new keyboard sent to me.  In just a few minutes I received an email requesting sales receipt and a snapshot of the serial number.  I sent the information right back to them.  So far so good.  But I received no shipping information and contacted them through the service account.  I was once again asked for the receipt, so I sent it again.  Then I stopped hearing from them.  I received no further reply to numerous emails and requests for information through the support account. The case appears to have disappeared from their online service department.  At this point I can no longer log into the service account, and the "reset your password" results in no email being sent to me. It appears that my account has disappeared. This is not how you treat your customers.I've nursed this keyboard as far as I'm able, but it's now time to purchase a new one.  It won't be Logitech.

There are few things that rival the excitement of a delivery truck arriving with a large power tool.  This saw comes well-packed, in 3 containers, with perhaps the largest chucks of polystyrene padding I've ever seen.  First look at the saw is impressive, but my ardor was cooled a half-hour into the build.  Let me say right here that the saw cuts nicely, but what I experienced during assembly was enough to concern me about the longterm prospects.  I'll also say that the "control" saw was my 30 year-old Craftsman--a saw that still cuts beautifully.Among the first things you do when the saw is still in the inverted position, is to attach casters and leveling feet.  Here's where the first problem arose.  While one foot went in easily, the second could only make 3-4 turns before it would go no further.  A careful inspection revealed that the hole had not been fully tapped, or perhaps that the threads had been badly crushed (I think it was the former).  I had to retap the hole.  A tap-and-die set is not part of every woodworker's kit, but I was glad I've got one.After I finished assembly of the base, it was time to flip the saw rightside-up.  The table is absolutely drenched in machine oil.  While the argument could be made that this preserves the saw from rust, other manufacturers manage to clean this up before shipment.  You'll have to be very careful to remove all this oil before any wood touches the saw table.  It was during this cleanup that I was snagged by the second gotcha--literally.  While passing a rag though the guide groove for the miter fence, an edge sliced right through the rag and into my fingertip.  Can't somebody do the final stage of polishing off their machining?  After a week, the finger was healed up, so it's back to assembly.At this point it's time to remark that the assembly portion of the sparse user guide is absolutely terrible.  Illustrations are miniscule and there are no exploded diagrams of key assemblies.  Everything, whether a bolt or a screw, is called a screw.  There's a difference.  On top of that, the bolts/screws described in the assembly section don't match what's in the parts list.  It's also a mix of SAE and metric sizes.  Why?  I'll gladly admit that someone intending to do woodwork should have basic assembly skills, but this is inexcusable. But the real kicker is attachment of front and back rails.  The rails are drilled with more holes than this saw needs (perhaps because they're used for multiple saws), but you're really on your own figuring out which holes to use.  The back rail is shown upside-down from its intended assembly position.  I stood there for the longest time before I realized the manual should be ignored in this regard.The wooden extension table has a vinyl veneer on a low-quality plywood base.  A little pre-drilling would be helpful here, but you're on your own.  Be sure to start with a pilot hole (the manual recommends going right for the 1/4 bit) so that the plywood doesn't splinter.  And when the leveling tool is used you'll find that the feet for the extension are too short (yes I had the feet on the base at their lowest position).  Plan on keeping a chunk of wood around to place at that end of the saw.But I finally did--after far too much time--get the saw assembled and aligned.  My first project was a cabinet.  The included blade is pretty generic, so I removed it and went for my fine-toothed blade.  I was actually pretty happy with the result. Miter cuts were accurate, the gauge on the rip-fence is spot on (you can actually cut on either side of the blade).  I also appreciated the fact that a plastic pusher tool was included.  Even when ripping a 1" slice, the guide was narrow enough to safely push the work piece through.  I'm a stickler for saw safety, and I really do appreciate this.  The extended table is also nice for setting up work.I've gone back and forth about whether to go with three stars or four for this review.  The saw cuts well (but no better than my 30 year old Craftsman).  Setting up a series of cuts is smooth, and the vacuum attachment is appreciated.  But the initial quality was much lower than it should be, and my overall impression is that it's a little thrown together without a top-down sense of what it should be.  I have no idea how long the motor's going to run.  If it's still going several years from now, I'll gladly come back and tack on the extra star.  But based on what I've see thus far, I can't give it the benefit of the doubt.

Over the last few years there have been quite a few entrants into the category of 'gaming' headsets.  It's a little difficult to determine exactly what qualifies headphones as 'gaming'.  Perhaps it's the presence of a microphone or its ability to connect to an Android or IOS device.  Go figure.The first peek at this headset was not overwhelming--it's over-packaged in a box with lots of throwaway plastic and the industrial design is an angular throwback to the 90's.  It didn't fit my definition of beautiful. Two cables are provided--one very short single-connector cable and a slightly longer cable with dual-connectors.  The single-cable connector matched with my iPhone, so that's the way I tested.  Unlike many headsets of this nature, the microphone isn't on a boom.  It's on one of the cups, so it stays out of the way.  There's a little toggle switch to mute the mic.The phones are quite lightweight and fairly comfortable.  The over-the-ear design doesn't quite seal you off from the outside world, but it works well enough for most situations.  There is a volume control on the left cup.  Unlike some devices, this does not control the level on the iPhone itself.  It simply modifies the level sent by the phone.  You'll need to set a max level of the iPhone and then tweak from there.  The microphone button works as you'd expect. Press it to take an incoming call.  Or press it to summon Siri, from there allowing you to set up an outgoing call or a voice memo or whatever you'd like.  Music playback is paused and muted during this period.The sound is OK, but not particularly compelling.  There's not a whopping bass boost or brain-frying treble, and I really appreciate Mat Catz restraint in that sense.  But the overall sound is a little distant and veiled. Fine for gaming, but not quite there for serious listening.There are many headsets to choose from.  These are fine if the look works for you.  But there's nothing particularly stand-out about them.

It took Amazon quite a while to find this CD: it's surely been long out-of-print, and the original recordings are over a half-century old.  But my patience was rewarded.  Some of Britten's finest (and least-known) work was done in a liturgical context. While "Noye's Fludde" requires larger forces than "The Burning Fiery Furnace", it's clearly a kindred spirit.  Here's the ancient story of the flood--a staple of Middle Eastern prehistory--and this setting comes from a Chester miracle play, the same source of much of Stravinsky's wonderful "The Flood".Britten's best work is amazingly strange: fundamentally tonal, but highly flexible. The core orchestra of strings, piano and percussion is augmented by a group of bugles and other instruments more frequently heard in the hands of amateurs.  Spoken and sung parts come both from professional soloists and a boys  choir.  The bugles--natural instruments without equal temperament--create an archaic and heraldic sense.  A final processional (I assume it's the animals leaving the ark) is magical, with a oddly fragile combination of piano, handbells and recorders underlying the choir.  This is a piece well worth hearing many times."The Golden Vanity" is considerably less substantial.  It's an entertainment piece for childrens choir with much stamping of feet and other comedic effects.  It's probably great fun to perform and to see, but to ears alone it doesn't really offer much protein.  No matter.  "Noye's Fludde" is well-worth the price of admission.

It's hard to see a guitar these days without a tuner on the headstock.  For the last couple of years I've used a Snark tuner.  But that was then.  This D'Addario is an improvement in every way.  For starters, it's small and light with a display that has enough illumination to see in a dark venue.  The display swivels easily, but the characters can also be inverted in the case of a very unusual mounting. Buttons are raised and textured so that even calloused fingers can navigate without looking.The tuner itself goes from A-410 to A-480, using increment/decrement buttons.  There's also a metronome (no sound--just a left/right/left/right blink on the display) which goes from 20 BPM to 270BPM.  I'd have gladly traded the slowest rates for a little more on the 'Presto' side. When either of those parameters passes max, it starts again at min (of vice-versa). I'd rather it peg at the extreme value, but it's a small objection.But the most noticeable thing is that this tuner is FAST.  The Snark needs a few seconds to settle in, especially with long wavelengths (low notes).  The D'Addario is almost instant, and the display gives very good hints about which way to go (the sharp symbol "'#' is a little hard to read).  I tested this on 5 instruments--classical, steel-string acoustic, solid-body electric, archtop electric and even an electric bass.  The tuner was fast on all of these instruments and tuning was a snap.  Any player should keep one in the case.

I have quite a selection of Perky-Pet feeders around the yard, both for hummingbirds and songbirds.  If you know hummers, you'll know they're pretty feisty and it's best to have a selection of feeders spread over the yard (a single feeder will get hogged by the dominant bird). This one went into an unoccupied corner and it took all of 3 minutes to have its first visitor.  We're lucky to have three species--Blackchin, Rufous and Broadtail--and they've all been to this feeder.  It appears that variety is important, so we have white, yellow and red "flowers" all around.  I wonder if they taste different to the birds.Perky-Pet has taken many steps over the last few years to make their feeders easier to fill and to clean.  The wide top on this one makes filling a snap.  The base comes apart into many pieces, simplifying cleaning.  But you do have to be careful putting it together and transporting it. Even when properly assembled it will leak a bit if you handle it by the base.  So fill it outdoors and hang it carefully on the stand.  Then enjoy the birds.

I'm continually amazed that you can purchase a very nice large screen television for just a few hundred dollars.  Great picture and great features, but usually a little lacking in the sound department.  While this Vizio unit won't turn your home into a high-end theater, it will bring a nice improvement in your experience while taking virtually no room.  It packs decent stereo speakers, along with an amp--and even a clever little subwoofer--into a package that you just place underneath your TV.There are few televisions that won't connect to this unit.  If you've got a digital out (either coax or optical) or even an old pair of RCA connectors, you're ready to roll.  The package comes with all cables, so there won't be an emergency trip to the box store to get overcharged. The user interface is simple--perhaps just a bit too simple--and consists only of a row of lamps on the front.  A small remote comes along.How does it sound?  Not bad at all.  While I'm not sure it really gets to the claimed 101 dB, it's more than adequate for a small or medium-sized room.  The little sub does a decent job of give some depth to the system, but it begins to show the strain before the rest of the system does.  The Peter Jackson remake of 'King Kong' has quite a few low tones for animal grunts.  At high level, they were just a bit too much for the sub, which began to break up.  I could improve this by using the minimal tone control (bass/treble with no indication of where the filter frequencies were).  Unless you're pushing it though, the frequency response is well-balanced, lacking a only bit of definition in the high midrange.  But if you're looking for an audiofile system, you wouldn't be looking here.  This is for an apartment or a family room.There are a couple of DSP modes with the unit, provided by DTS.  There's a dynamic range compressor--useful for late-night viewing.  There's also a pseudo-surround mode that impressed me more than I expected.  There are a number of acoustic tricks that go into making surround without surround speakers, and I usually dislike them.  But this was a pleasant surprise.  You do have to be close to the centerline, but there was a nice overall sense of space.  Airplane flybys were pretty convincing, too. My hat is off to DTS for this one.There's a remote mode mentioned in the manual for those with Vizio televisions. I assume it means you'll be able to use the TV remote in place of the little one in the box.  I have a Panasonic in this room, so I wasn't able to test that feature.  It's likely to take some fiddling around with remotes and codes, but with some luck you'll be able to do some consolidation and keep this remote in a drawer.Inexpensive HD TVs with week sound have spawned quite an aftermarket for soundbars and auxiliary systems. This is a nice entry in that arena.  It's unobtrusive and sounds quite nice.

It's no secret that I'm a fan of Western Digital network drives.  I use a pair of high-capacity RAIDs as backup for my business and I've long used the MyBook series as media servers.  I didn't need much persuading to try out this new drive.The first thing you'll notice is that WD has been moving their look from black to off-white.  While my drives typically live out of sight in a machine room, this is still an attractive enclosure that will look decidedly less "techy" if perched beside a television or in another visible location. Basic setup couldn't be simpler: plug in the network cable (provided) and attach the external power supply.  The power cable is a little longer than you'll see with many systems and that's much appreciated.  You can install a provided application that will then help you find the drive, or you can simply look for the IP address in your router log.  Once that's done, all setup and maintenance can be performed from the web browser of your choice.As soon as you connect to the device, you'll be given the opportunity to register and create a My Cloud account.  Then you're taken to a main screen that provides basic status, firmware version and a few panels that will give access to more common functionality.  While it's true that I have expertise in the network area, I still appreciate how simple WD makes this device--over the years I've seen steady progress.  The first thing I do with a new NAS is a system diagnostic (that takes several hours) and a speed test.  Even over gigabit ethernet, this won't set any records.  Average read/write speeds were 77/31 respectively.  That's not likely to be a problem with the applications that My Cloud is targeted toward.You can create user accounts as needed, whether for family or employees, and you can divide the disk into some number of shares that can be private for each user or can be shared in whatever fashion you need.  You can attach USB drives of any sort--either to extend the amount of space or provide a backup area.  Setting up cloud access is relatively simple unless you're a complete tech novice (in which case it's time to buy a beer for a friend and ask for a little help).  You can then see files on the device from any remote location as long as you log in properly. You CAN see the files from a web browser but WD recommends against it, for the security problems inherent in Java.  They provide apps (I tested on a Mac and an iPad) which are somewhat more secure.One place where Western Digital really excels in in DLNA (a core technology for home media service).  With a device like this on the network and a TV-Live beside the television, you can encode in just about any format you like.  There are few--if any--NAS devices from WD that can't act as DLNA servers. Another nice feature is the notification feature.  You can have the device email any address(es) whenever an update is available, or whenever it's powered up or shut down.  This can be helpful if you float among several computers.  Unlike many of these devices, you DON'T have to enter your own account information to enable this.  The device contacts WD and WD contacts you.There is a question you should ask yourself, and that's whether or not you should put your information on the cloud. I don't think it's always a good idea, since it provides an attack vector into your system.  Still, if you're careful with passwords and maintenance, it can be a great way to share family photos and such with at least as much privacy as commercial alternatives.  There are many companies making NAS drives, but Western Digital is always my first choice.

Time is kind in many ways when we think of Beethoven.  Errors have been well-corrected in the majority of his scores so that we have a good chance of hearing the notes he intended. The greatness of most of his pieces is reflected in the frequency of performance, with hundreds of recordings available stretching over nearly a century.  A good student orchestra can manage a few of the symphonies and his piano sonatas are staples of advanced recitals all over the world.But time has taken away many things as well.  We're no longer surprised or angered by his key changes or his protean forms.  We don't get many of the jokes embedded in his pieces.  After over a century of equal temperament we don't even hear the underlying reasons for his choice of keys.  And when we look at his many portraits we don't see the face considered to be ugly in his own time.  It's just Beethoven. At the worst, Beethoven has become comfort for many--a pleasant set of tunes that let the listener avoid musical challenges. How wrong that is.Jan Swafford has done much to take us back to Beethoven's own time: to know the man and to know the music. As a composer in his own right, he's well positioned to explain the true nature of the music.  And he's at less risk than most when he delves into the thinking behind Beethoven's choices. The reader should be warned that this is a book for musicians.  There's much to learn and enjoy in learning about the person, but there's also a lot of shop talk here: musical examples and musical terminology.  There's a helpful appendix, but if you don't read music you'll often be missing the point of what Swafford is saying.Because the book itself has a dual purpose, it might be worth taking some to to divide the review.  So let's take a look at the man we find in those pages.  Beethoven was the son of a mediocre tenor (and drunkard) and the grandson of a kappelmeister (another Ludwig).  In those days a musician was just another servant--poorly paid and dispensable.  By the standard of the day he was a man of low birth. His town of Bonn still felt the last gasps of the Enlightenment, but that was really more lofty talk than anything.  Ludwig surely felt every slight, and over-reacted at every opportunity. The patterns of his life appeared early on.  He loved humanity in the abstract, but in reality was misanthropic and narcissistic.  He managed to alienate every single person he knew, whether friends from childhood, other musicians, or nobles who could do him some good.  He courted many women (at least in his own mind), all unavailable in some way.  They may have been put off by his appearance or by the knowledge that he'd have made a miserable husband.  A few loyal friends stayed with him, enduring his paranoid rants, but he still managed to find a lonely life for himself.  It's the current fashion to provide a psychological diagnosis in many biographies (however misguided that might be).  Swafford wisely ignores that, providing the facts as best shown in accounts and correspondence.  Of necessity he interpolates on occasion, but he's clear in those cases.  This is neither a hatchet job or a hagiography.  Instead it's a sensitive account of a life that would have been painful to live. As bad as being around Beethoven could be, it must have been terrible to BE Beethoven.One thing that struck me throughout was how astutely Beethoven built his reputation. He moved to Vienna (a town he hated) when Mozart and Haydn ruled supreme. While he admired them both, his relations with them were wary.  He knew that Mozart "owned" opera and Haydn owned the string quartet and symphony. So he began building his composition reputation with cello sonatas--a form unexplored by his seniors. He moved into larger forms gradually, when he thought his pieces could hold the stage alongside acknowledged masterpieces.  And every challenging piece was accompanied by something gracious and accessible.  I found his sense of musical place both calculating and admirable.Interspersed along with the biography are a great many musical details.  In an early section, Swafford discusses tunings.  The equal temperament we've known for the last century was not widely in place.  Keyboard instruments of the day were still tuned in various forms of "just intonation".  Swafford goes into a brief explanation of this and demonstrates why intervals are strikingly different, depending on key.  Remote keys, like D-flat, were considered barely usable by many.  Beethoven chose his keys precisely because of these tuning aberrations and was consistent throughout his lifetime.  While there are a few musicians who still tune their instruments in this way, the opportunity to hear the "Emperor Concerto" in a true E-flat is denied to most of us.  The real shock of a Beethoven modulation can only be inferred, not experienced.At several points along the way, in pieces Swafford considers uniquely formative, there's a more complex analysis.  So you'll find score examples and in-depth discussion of the 3rd and 9th Symphonies, the Missa Solemnis, the late B-flat string quartet and others. This is the place where some musical training is critical.  One can't help but be reminded of the essays of Donald Francis Tovey. Swafford's passages here are equally concise and informative.  Swafford does a creditable job of avoiding flowery language when simple technical terms will do. But there are places where he can't conceal his excitement and the occasional high-flown phrase is completely forgivable.I must admit to mixed feelings about the form of the book.  While each analysis is placed chronologically where it belongs, there's a bit of a jarring feeling when jumping from biography to analysis and back.  As well as it works in its current form, I still wonder if it might find a wider audience if divided into sections for biography and essay.  It's a small quibble.I haven't begun to touch on the scope of this book--Beethoven's recurring health woes, his abortive guardianship of his nephew, the bright and talented women performers who were the backbone of his early reputation, the hangers-on who created a romanticized view that prevailed for a century.  I haven't mentioned the mechanical amplifiers on his pianos or the terrible performances that plagued him.  I haven't even mentioned his deafness.  But it's all here, in a book that's both sensitive and compelling.

I've had quite a few A/V receivers over the years--several HK units, along with a number of Onkyos.  This is my first Denon, and the differences were immediately apparent.  This thing simply SOUNDS better.  A lot better. I'd passed on Denon a few times when considering a new receiver.  While the sound was always highly-rated, Denon always fell a little short on the system control feature list.  That's no longer the case.  There are more than enough HDMI inputs, along with a pair of outputs for mirrored monitors. To that array of inputs you can add several flavors of Internet radio, along with Apple Airplay and Bluetooth streaming and even a direct iPod connection.  Up to 7.2 can be supported (in my test room I have 5.1).Perhaps it's because I've been at this for a long while, but I tend to do setup without consulting the user guide.  I like to see how intuitive operation can be, and I'll only consult the guide if I'm really stuck.  I got a long way and only had to hit the guide for a few more esoteric things.  Unfortunately Denon follows the practice of providing the guide as a PDF on a CDROM (C'mon Denon, don't cheap out with the manual). Upon power-up, assuming you've plugged in the monitor, there's a quite thorough setup walkthrough--even down to individual speaker cables.  The back-button on the remote will get you out of this so that you can set up at your own pace.It's worth pointing out that the remote is nicely organized, with the important MUTE button in a sensible position. If the phone rings, you can quickly cut the sound without hunting all over a crowded remote.As with any high-quality receiver, Denon provides a calibration microphone and an automatic room EQ program.  Kudos for Denon's practical sense of humor.  For people who don't happen to have microphone stands, Denon includes a stand made of several folded pieces of cardboard.  When assembled it looks like a toy rocket.  You'll chuckle, but it works.  Clear instructions are displayed on the monitor for microphone positions and other aspects of the procedure.  I have to say that the calibration on this receiver is much more successful than on many others.  Additional tweaking is usually required, but this unit was ready to go.  And it really sounds nice.  There's a tremendous sense of integrated surround with good source material, whether on BluRay or satellite.  The orchestra stays clear of the screen and gives a lovely sense of being out in the room.  Effects pans move smoothly from speaker to speaker without jumping. You can tweak if you need, but that's only for the fussier among us.  Dynamic range compression works smoothly and unobtrusively.  There are four basic "Sound Modes" accessed by dedicated buttons on the remote--primarily for film, music and games.  Denon can't resist a couple of those awful reverbs for those who want the sound of a stadium or nightclub.  I'd rather have an accurate representation of what the mixers did in the studio.  Thank goodness that's there in spades.Network setup is quick and easy.  I have a wired network in this room, but Denon will support either wired or wireless.  A firmware upgrade was available, and installed smoothly in about twenty minutes.  There's an interesting menu entry that hints at additional bits of software--apps, I suppose we'd have to call them--but nothing is yet available.  The network supports internet radio in several forms and a nice favorites page will let you save the stations you like.  Denon also supports audio-only DLNA.  It did strike me as a little odd that there's no video DLNA support, but almost every receiver or TV does a terrible job with it.  I'm happy to stick with an external DLNA box.There's still more if you happen to have other gadgets floating around.  Apple's Airplay is supported.  As soon as I started streaming from my iPad, the Denon began to play it back (there's a bit of optional EQ to get around the worst artifacts of lossy compression).  I then used Bluetooth to pair with my iPhone and was quickly able to play back from that device.  Unfortunately, you'll have to control playback with the iPhone itself--there's very limited menu control in the Denon.  And finally there's a free app in the iTunes store that will let you use your IOS device as a remote.  I tested it and it works, but it's really hard to see the point of it.  The remote that comes with the receiver works perfectly well.While HDMI control between devices is an option, I should say that I had a few issues here.  I'd like to set up the system so that turning on my TV will also turn on the receiver, or vice-versa.  That works, but a little too well.  I've set a predetermined start-up volume on the receiver so that I don't wake up the house when I switch on the early morning news.  That works perfectly, as long as I turn on the receiver first.  But if I turn on the TV first, the TV will also ship its own volume level (maximum) down to the receiver in addition to the turn-on signal.  This is NOT pleasant and resulted in my turning off HDMI control.  I hope that a future Denon update allows a simple on-off-only mode for HDMI control.In summary, Denon's done a good balanced job of providing rich features along with very high quality sound.  I've got a receiver graveyard in the basement, but I don't think Denon is going there any time soon.

I've never had a problem attractive hummers to a Perky-Pet feeder.  The streak continues with this midsize model.  I filled it and hung it up.  Within 5 minutes the Blackchins were investigating.  In another 5 minutes they were fighting over it.Assembly is quick, and this model follows the example of recent units in that the lower part disassembles easily for cleaning.  The wide-mouth top fill is a welcome addition and means that the sugar solution goes into the feeder instead of down the side.  The ant trap is also effective, but will need to be filled daily in our dry Western climate.I have only the smallest complaint.  As with other feeders from this maker, there's a little wire hanger taped onto the inside.  This is far too small to hang onto a typical cast iron feeder stand.  A larger wire loop would be a better choice.  Other than that, it's quickly become a popular addition to the back yard.

I'm not a gamer, but after decades in the field of audio I know my way around headphones.  I've been looking for an extra set of courtesy phones, so I thought I'd give these a shot. As phones for gaming or perhaps podcasting they're more than adequate.  For more serious listening they do fall a little short but that's not their intended market.  They're a little pumped in the bass and at the high end.  The bass is far from taut--it's a bit flabby--but for FX it's fine.  The midrange is a little on the murky side, but considering the price I've heard much worse.Gain on the microphone was surprisingly low and I had to raise my voice to get reasonable levels.  On the positive side, it did a good job of resisting wind noise, pops and sibilants.  I had no difficulty using this headset with my iPhone and iPad--devices the headset is intended for.  I must admit to a small amount of surprise that USB isn't supported, but as long as you've got a mini jack you'll be fine.The headset is quite light and should be wearable for a fair amount of time.  There is some questionable copy associated with the headset--"Acoustically Angled Speakers" is a phrase with little meaning--but for general use these should do the job.

I replaced a pair of accent floods with these LED lamps.  A few things were instantly apparent when I flipped the switch:  The color temp felt just a little warmer than the 2700K specification.  This is not a bad thing at all.  The lights were also a bit brighter than I expected--more lumens per watt.  And finally, the light didn't have hot spots.  With a number of LEDs, the light isn't well diffused and illumination is uneven.  With these, the illumination was quite smooth--perhaps even a bit better than the incandescent bulbs they replaced.It's encouraging to see LED quality going up at the same time prices begin to come down.  CFLs were a temporary solution that few of us will miss.  These bulbs are a good step in the right direction.

I've just had the interesting opportunity to compare two different SSDs in the same system.  One--this Seagate--is ready to go.  Just plug it into a USB3 socket.  The other was a OCZ bare drive, which I placed inside a Thunderbolt enclosure.The test subject was my Mac Mini (vintage 2012).  This small machine is hampered by a 5400 RPM hard drive that really hurts its otherwise exemplary performance.  Using the Blackmagic disk speed test, the Mini's hard drive comes in with R/W speeds of 89/85 MB/sec respectively.  I applied the same test to the Seagate, which gave me read/write speeds of 418/398 and faster. This was appreciably faster than the OCZ unit, at the same time demonstrating that USB3 can easily perform as well as Thunderbolt in many situations.  It should go without saying that this little Seagate SSD has now become the system drive of the Mac Mini.For situations where large storage is needed, an SSD is not likely to have enough capacity.  But it's plenty large enough for system, applications and basic user data for just about any user.  And the difference can be quite surprising.

Solid-state memory is rapidly taking the place of small-medium capacity rotating memory. This has given many users the change to upgrade the performance of existing machines without reverting to replacing the whole system.  Case in point is my Mac Mini (vintage 2012).  This otherwise very capable machine is hampered by a 5400 RPM hard drive that makes molasses look fast.  Using the Blackmagic disk speed test, the Mini's hard drive comes in with R/W speeds of 89/85 MB/sec respectively.I placed the OCZ package inside a Thunderbolt enclosure (made by Seagate) and connected it to the mini.  Read/write speeds jumped to 367/357 MB/sec--no small improvement.  I immediately moved my Windows virtual machine images to this drive.  There's no doubt about the improvement.I did not test the included Acronis disk-closing package.  I already have Carbon Copy Cloner (a very solid package) so I had no need to install even more software.In the review title, I mentioned that the speed--however great--doesn't break records.  On this particular mini, a Seagate SSD (USB-3, yet) bests the OCZ by a noticeable amount.  Still, you can't overstate the improvement that comes from chucking the old HD and popping in the OCZ.  It's worth mentioning that OCZ provides an adapter for installing this into 3.5" drive systems.

New Balance has quite a pedigree, going back to the original running craze of the 70s.  I've tried them from time to time, generally having some trouble with fit.  Although the shoemaker's 'last' is probably long gone, there is still a model foot that these shoes are built for.  They've always run a little on the narrow side for me.  With this 'D' width, I'm getting a better fit than I have before.The shoe is obviously built well, even though it's unfortunately following the garish clown-shoe look of recent years.  This is not an improvement over their older and more-restrained appearance.  Although I rarely run these days, I'm an inveterate walker.  A few miles on these shoes has not convinced me to change over from my Asics.  Lateral stiffness and support just aren't there, and the shoes feel a little squirmy.  Although there's no guidance on the product page, there's a distinct inward push on the front of the foot.  This would indicate that the shoe is more appropriate for over-pronators.  My pronation is pretty neutral and I found myself fighting the shoe with every step.I'll happily wear these shoes as general-purpose sneakers, but the absence of good lateral support keeps me from recommending them to runners or serious walkers.
Nice patch, exactly as described. Bought for a major Monsters Inc. fan.

The content is fine, but once again the publisher is clearly taking advantage of students. This was a required text for a college course, and every reader has to buy a brand new copy to have access to the online components of the course. That would all be fine if the online components were compelling, but like all of Pearson's online content, "Racial and Ethnic Groups" too has pretty questionable online content that serves as copy protection for students to prevent them reselling their textbook rather than as a true added benefit to the student.This book is a loose leaf book, it isn't even bound. I don't know why colleges don't demand a better deal for their students.

I bought this book because I have an interest in becoming an top Amazon reviewer myself. For Johnson, this book is a bit like an autobiography of her life as a reviewer.Johnson details her interests and strategy as a reviewer. One thing that is clear is how important a part of her life reviewing and reading are. She clearly is devoted to this almost as if it is was a job, which I guess for her is kind of an apt description.As a coherent book, there are a few problems here. It seems like parts of the book are a little disjointed. She has some parts that explain her habits and thinking which are the strongest parts, there is a list of different milestones, and other parts are like a web FAQ where she answers questions. The last two pieces seemed a little lengthy and sometimes repetitive. They could stand to be shortened up quite a bit. Johnson is a good writer and the book would be stronger if more of it were directly written rather than broken up by questions.

Disclaimer: The manufacturer provided this product to me to evaluate.This is an interesting and even a pretty fun product, but understand its limitations.The iGearPro USB Voice Recorder looks almost exactly like any other USB drive you have ever seen, and few would notice its extra features unless you pointed them out, or examined the device closely. If you look carefully you can certainly see that something is different but few will ever do this.The device functions as a regular USB flash drive. However, in several tests I found the write speed to be just over 1MB per second (this is quite slow). But that isn't why you would purchase this device, it is a very compact voice recorder and could work well as a simple tool to have in your pocket when you want to make a quick voice dictation for later. You simply flip the single switch, the device begins recording and stops when you flip the switch off.To play back your audio, or charge the internal battery, you just plug it in to any USB port on a computer and can access all of your recordings in WAV format easily loadable into almost any audio player.The device will work as a drive and for playback on a Mac (which I tested) but the simple utility program which sets the date is a windows only application. After a bit of time off of the charger, you have to rerun this utility again to set the time and date if you want this to be part of your recording. Otherwise all of your recordings were in January of 2000!The Sound quality is pretty good if you are holding the mic right to your mouth like a typical microphone, if you have it sitting on a table a few feet from you or from whatever you are recording, you get kind of a muffled sound. You can hear things, but they become less clear, and you'll need to crank up the volume on your device.Pros-Small stealthy recorder-Builtin rechargeable battery-Works pretty well for dictation-Compatible with many computing devicesCons-USB transfer speed is very slow, don't buy it for this!-The microphone is not great for noisy rooms, or many people talking, lots of room noise will be picked up-Needs to be recharged, probably daily if you want it to be ready to goRecommendation: If you need a simple always available voice recorder this is not a bad solution at all, just hold it close to your mouth. Alternatively, if you have a young teen or pre-teen that fancies himself a James Bond Junior, this could be a really fun gift. It is small, subtle, and easy to use.If you are looking for a high quality general recorder, or want to record music, you should look elsewhere and you will probably need to spend quite a bit more to get something good.

Disclaimer: The manufacturer sent me an example of this product to evaluate for this review.I have to say this is a very nice and high quality product. I have used many types of USB cables, some feel obviously cheap. This isn't one of them. This cable felt immediately to me like it was well made. One obvious thing to think about here, this is a new type of USB connector, double check that this is the type you need before you order it!I did not have a device that used this type of connector, so I borrowed a friends Samsung Note3. The cable fit great and had what I consider to have been excellent throughput. In transferring a 3GB file to the Samsung Note3 it transferred the data at 174MB/sec. This isn't the theoretical max, but when does anyone ever get that?Pros-FAST compared to most other USB cables-Amazingly cheap-Quality of cable and connectors seems very goodCons-Not really any-You do need the right kind of device (New type of connector-See attached image)Overall Recommendation: I have no worries about this cable it seems great and it is a good value.

This book may be a bit complex for those that are new to investing or don't want to get too far into the details. But if you want to understand how markets and investing work, and want to build a simple, sound, and low fee portfolio, the answers are here.Much of my love for economics and investing topics came from reading this book when it was originally published. I set my portfolio up using the principals outlined here and have made very few adjustments since. The advice I implemented has both saved me huge amounts of money in fees and earned me a market return that I am very pleased with.Some principles outlined in the book:-ALWAYS buy your investments through a very low fee investment firm (Bernstein recommends Vanguard, and I agree)-Did I mention that HIGH FEES WILL KILLL YOUR RATE OF RETURN-Most of your investments should be in highly diversified index funds-There are a few tricks you can implement that will make very slight improvements in your return (e.g. occasional portfolio rebalancing)-Active managers will win some years, maybe even several in a row, but they will never beat the market over an entire career, therefore you won't either-Getting a market return is a WIN-The guy on the other side of the transaction knows more than you do, you are playing with fire if you think otherwiseThe advice and concepts that Bernstein advocates are certainly not completely unique. He has been very influenced by Malkiel, John Bogle, and others. And much of the advice has become common wisdom now and followed by many. But there are many pitfalls for the amateur investor, Bernstein will help you to avoid them.I actually enjoyed reading this book, it is not just that the advice is important, it is well written and impactful. The book may seem a bit technical for some, but if you read and implement it, you will be  a much savvier investor than almost anyone else that you know. I could not recommend this book more and even though it was written in 2002, its advice is just as worthwhile today.

This was a Christmas gift for my wife who really wants to learn sewing. It is a great device, with pretty comprehensive and amazing capabilities. This is clearly not what a sewing machine was like even a few years ago. This device is very high tech and able to do many different kinds of stitches, monograms, and way more than you might imagine. Brother as a company has many products that are pretty impressive, this is one more in a long line. The only possible downside here is that it is a complex device that might overwhelm if you let it.
Cheap memory is the top way to bring life back to an aging computer. This stuff did the job, runs much faster now. If your computer supports it, go for no less than 4 Gigs, 8 Gigs would be better.
It is a plastic toy. Doubt that it will last too long, but this is exactly what the giftee was looking for. He seemed quite happy.

DISCLAIMER: This product was provided to me by the manufacturer in order to allow me to review it. With that said, I was not compensated in any way for this review, and no promises were made that I would either review this product, or review it positively after receiving it. Please see my profile for more info.Product: ECSEM Mini Lightweight Wireless Stereo EarbudsGeneral Impressions: The product is well packaged and probably looks pretty good on the shelf if you were to buy it in a store. It has a number of accessories, the most important being several sizes of rubber or silicone earbud covers so that you can size them to fit your ears. The biggest surprise to me is that functional bluetooth headphones can be produced and delivered for such an inexpensive price (on sale for $11 at the time of this review). They seem like an incredible value and the price point makes them barely more expensive than wired earbuds.The product also has an interesting design with the two pieces attached by a short cable that i have not run across before. It actually works quite well from a design perspective.Quality of Product: The quality is OK, it is not great, but not bad either. They seem like they would last a while, although one never knows how easy it would be to lose the rubber cups that fit in your ear or break the wire until it happens.The biggest issues for me with a product that I will be wearing in my ears for potentially hours is the comfort of the fit and the quality of the sound. I found both to be acceptable, but not great. Earbuds can have problems developing enough bass response to sound good, and these really lack a clear bass sound. They seem pretty tinny to me, very strong high pitches, pretty weak bass, and so so middle. There is also the issue of comfort. I listened to these for several hours straight listening to several familiar albums. My ears felt a little fatigued after the listening session.Issues: I have used a number of sets of Bluetooth headphones over the years, one issue that often comes up is the Bluetooth connection cutting out between devices. I had this issue come up a few times with this product. It worked pretty well, but had a few noticeable dropouts during several hours of listening.Comparisons to Other Products: My main set of headphones is a set of Motorola buds. Build-wise and sound quality-wise these are better, but they also cost three times as much money. I won’t be getting rid of my Buds, but I also wouldn’t loan them out to a teenager. I would have no problem buying this set of earbuds and giving them to a teen and not worrying what happens to them!Pros:-These are an unbelievable value.-They do the job, and would make a great gift for a teenager, or to have available as a backup set of earbuds.-Bluetooth pairing went very smoothly.Cons:-They don’t seem “expensive”, but of course they aren’t!-Somewhat more expensive headphones have a noticeably better sound quality and more comfortable fit.-Occasional Bluetooth connection drops.Protip:-Turn down the volume of your device before you start playing your music, it was shockingly loud at first until I could turn down the volume by about 30%.Final Verdict:I struggle with how many stars to give this product. In comparison to my Motorola Buds,these earbuds just aren’t that great, but they are SO INEXPENSIVE. The value angle is the main thing that ECSEM has going for them here. For under $20 it is hard to go wrong.Updates: I will update if anything comes up with this product as I use it.

This mask is kind of cool looking, but when actually worn it looks a little creepy, like you are about to be mugged!I think it probably makes a lot more sense as a wall decoration then to actually be worn. It also seems a bit expensive for what you actually get.
Purchased this as a gift. Exactly what the receiver wanted and he couldn't be happier.

This product is ok, but like a lot of third party items sold through the Amazon Marketplace, it was inexpensive to buy and really expensive to ship. I probably wouldn't buy this again. It was worth $5 but not $12 once shipping was added in.The pennants are plastic and thin. They are appropriate for a party and then to be thrown away. This is not a decoration that you would keep around after more than one or two uses.

Sons of Anarchy is addictive. This is a fascinating show. Having no actual experience with Biker gangs I have no idea what level of realism is on display here, but the characters are interesting, the plots are winding and keep your attention. Well worth watching.

Inexpensive and great for its purpose. I bought two of these for my amplifiers, they work perfectly to angle the amps for optimal sound.Pros:-Inexpensive-Perfect for in home use-LightweightCons:-These don't seem very durable for constantly being moved around by a gigging musician-They are angle adjustable but not height adjustableWhere I gigging anymore, i would probably chose a different amp stand, but for use at home these are great and affordable.

This thing is huge, it seems very durable just like all Rubbermaid products. We are planning to use it to store cushions for our outdoor chairs. I think it will work perfectly for this purpose.Setup was easy, maybe 15 minutes to put it together. It is light and easy to move around. We are very happy with this purchase.

So far I couldn't be happier with this drive. The software that comes with the drive makes transferring your files to the new drive easy.A little, background on my setup. On the Windows 7 machine that I put this drive in, I have all of my documents on a second large drive. Windows and all applications were running on the main drive which I transferred to the Samsung 840. The whole process probably took about an hour.PROS:-The transfer process was fast-The drive is very fast, especially in comparison to a spinning diskCONS:-It is smaller than my older drive and more expensive than a mechanical drive, but so is every SSDTIPS:-Have two drives, one fast small one for your applications and OS, and a bigger slower one for your files, especially media files which can be very large.-Any drive over about 120 gigs is probably plenty big enough for Windows and your apps.

DISCLAIMER: This product was provided to me by the manufacturer in order to allow me to review it. With that said, I was not compensated in any way for this review, and no promises were made that I would either review this product, or review it positively after receiving it.
