It has a number of accessories, the most important being several sizes of rubber or silicone earbud covers so that you can size them to fit your ears. The biggest surprise to me is that functional bluetooth headphones can be produced and delivered for such an inexpensive price (on sale for $11 at the time of this review). They seem like an incredible value and the price point makes them barely more expensive than wired earbuds.The product also has an interesting design with the two pieces attached by a short cable that i have not run across before. It actually works quite well from a design perspective.Quality of Product: The quality is OK, it is not great, but not bad either. They seem like they would last a while, although one never knows how easy it would be to lose the rubber cups that fit in your ear or break the wire until it happens.The biggest issues for me with a product that I will be wearing in my ears for potentially hours is the comfort of the fit and the quality of the sound. I found both to be acceptable, but not great. Earbuds can have problems developing enough bass response to sound good, and these really lack a clear bass sound. They seem pretty tinny to me, very strong high pitches, pretty weak bass, and so so middle. There is also the issue of comfort. I listened to these for several hours straight listening to several familiar albums. My ears felt a little fatigued after the listening session.Issues: I have used a number of sets of Bluetooth headphones over the years, one issue that often comes up is the Bluetooth connection cutting out between devices. I had this issue come up a few times with this product. It worked pretty well, but had a few noticeable dropouts during several hours of listening.Comparisons to Other Products: My main set of headphones is a set of Motorola buds. Build-wise and sound quality-wise these are better, but they also cost three times as much money. I won’t be getting rid of my Buds, but I also wouldn’t loan them out to a teenager. I would have no problem buying this set of earbuds and giving them to a teen and not worrying what happens to them!Pros:-These are an unbelievable value.-They do the job, and would make a great gift for a teenager, or to have available as a backup set of earbuds.-Bluetooth pairing went very smoothly.Cons:-They don’t seem “expensive”, but of course they aren’t!-Somewhat more expensive headphones have a noticeably better sound quality and more comfortable fit.-Occasional Bluetooth connection drops.Protip:-Turn down the volume of your device before you start playing your music, it was shockingly loud at first until I could turn down the volume by about 30%.Final Verdict:I struggle with how many stars to give this product. In comparison to my Motorola Buds,these earbuds just aren’t that great, but they are SO INEXPENSIVE. The value angle is the main thing that ECSEM has going for them here. For under $20 it is hard to go wrong.Updates: I will update if anything comes up with this product as I use it.

January 11-2015 Update:So I have had these cables for about six weeks. I started with a 4 star. Today I am dropping the review to a two star. I have five cables, two are in varying states of not really working anymore. They look great, but I have bent the micro side on one to the point that it no longer works and the second one will not stay in my phone, even though there is NO reason it shouldn't. Going forward I will look elsewhere for USB cables. Too bad, these are really cool looking cables. Oh, I should mention, I am not someone that is hard on my electronic equipment and cables, things usually last a long time for me.Original Review:Nice cable, could use a manufacturing tweakI both like and am a little annoyed with this product. I will elaborate on both. Build quality seems excellent. They are really nice looking and I love the retro braid in the cable. The thing that annoys me is the micro side. I have ordered a number of these and have got what appear to be quite different versions and I can't tell you why because I don't know why. If you look at the attached picture you will see three different Micro B connectors. The one on top is a generic cable. The two on bottom are both 9 to 5 cables. As you notice the bezel on the two is substantially different in size (the smaller bezel is a 6 foot, the larger is a 10 foot, I also have several 3 footers and they all have the larder bezel). I have four different 9 to 5 cables ONE is small the others are all the larger bezel. In some devices, especially with a protective case, you will find that this larger bezel might prevent your device from charging. This is a potential issue and you just have to try it and see. I would prefer it if all of the 9 to 5 cables had the smaller bezel.Pros:-Cool Retro Look-Nice build quality-Usually works as it shouldCons:-May not fit your device well if there is not enough space where the USB cable connects or you have a case, cover, or bumper attached

I have mixed feelings here. I love iHeartRadio, we use it on our Roku all the time. I wanted to get this to use for our brand new Fire TV stick, but wait, no it doesn't work for the Fire TV. I am not sure if this is the app developer or Amazon's fault. But what are you guys waiting for?

I had a very hard time finding one of these locally, thank god for Amazon where there were many options.This comb was affordable, seems durable, and well suited to its purpose. It has some fairly tight teeth which is important for getting a beard/mustache well groomed.I would recommend this comb.

I have been watching Boardwalk Empire since the series began. This is just a great story, told by an amazing writing/directing team, with top notch actors.Sadly this is the last season and a somewhat short one at that. Eight instead of the usual ten episodes. This season fast forwards into the future a bit over season four, but also offers some insights into Enuch and Eli and their childhood origins. Very interesting stuff.The show is great but one criticism I will offer, I normally purchase the standard definition versions on Amazon Prime. They are both cheaper, and I have never yet noticed a single artifact that made it obvious that there was a difference. Not so with this one. If I had it to do over again, I would buy the HD version. There are many noticeable and obvious artifacts in the SD version. I cannot tell you if this is HBO's fault or if it is Amazon's, and I should also say most people won't notice, but I did.One positive I will give HBO here. I love several of their series, but it is often very difficult to purchase an HBO show in a timely manner. I still had to wait until the season was over, but the whole season was released just a few days after the season ended. I would still prefer to get these weekly as the show is played, but the current situation is much better than waiting a full year which has been the prior pattern.It is a little baffling that HBO and so many other companies have been so slow to recognize that people will purchase their shows with real money instead of pirating them if they are just given the opportunity to be honest. So this is an improvement.

The BoxWave sleeve does the job it is intended for, but feels a little cheap (well it actually is cheap, so I guess that makes sense).Background, I have had my Nexus 4 for almost two years. I had the original google bumper for a year or so until I broke it and then I never replaced it. Things were going along swimmingly until our last ride on Space Mountain at Disneyland where the pressure from the seat restraint cracked the back of my found in a lovely spiderweb pattern. I picked up this cover while waiting for a replacement back glass so that I wouldn't start finding glass in my pocked.The case fits the phone snuggly and I guess it looks pretty god. I do like that it is partially transparent. However, it really does look a little cheap especially when you compare it to other available cases. For the price it is well worth it, but it doesn't really feel like it is as high quality as the phone it is protecting.

This is both the most popular and most interesting show on TV. Fun to watch, always a surprise or two, and it has now become something of a cultural phenomenon. Everybody is watching this show, why not you?I won't give any spoilers, but they are taking the show in a different direction for Season 5, the group is growing (a bit) and has become a bit nomadic. It will be interesting to see where the writers take us. Can't wait to find out.

Tiny, affordable, fast. This is a high speed Class 10/UHS I card that I purchased to go with my new GoPro camera. The most difficult part of buying flash memory is understanding the speed of the cards and what the designations mean.In the older speed system cards were measure on a class 1-10 basis with 10 being the highest. Added in to the mix is the new UHS designation which has to do with the bus speed. Many UHS-I cards are available, and I am starting to see UHS-II cards too. All else being equal, I would recommend always buying the fastest card you can for future proofing. Memory has become pretty cheap which is great, it wasn't that long ago that I can remember people bragging about their 1gb flash drives! Now it seems to be a race about speed, and while you may not think that this is important, HD video is becoming a very common video format, this format eats up space, and demands speed. Many cameras will not work with slow memory, or your burst or recording format options may become very limited.

Cool idea. We bought this for a teenager who wanted some dance party atmosphere in his bedroom. Unfortunately, the device immediately fell apart on first use. The build quality is not good. When we plugged the USB style cable into one of the towers, the circuit board just fell apart! Not an auspicious start.It was sent back to Amazon (with no trouble at all) and we are waiting for a replacement. Hopefully, the next one will be better. If it isn't, there won't be a third one.

It is a Keurig, and works as expected.Three things you should know about Keurig's:1. The newer versions have some kind of detection system designed to prevent you from using NON-Keurig K-Cups. Personally, I find this behavior in a company abhorrent. I chose this model because this new "feature" wasn't included.2. Keurig coffee is INSANELY EXPENSIVE. It is, without exaggeration probably 90% cheaper to buy raw coffee and use a non-K-Cup coffee maker.3. The coffee is good, but NOT great. In taste tests around the internet you will discover that the coffee produced while ok, is not by any means great. Keurig's are not for someone who is a connoisseur.For great Coffee go in this order: 1. Good quality Espresso machine, 2. Coffee Press, 3. Good quality drip coffee machine, 4. Everything else including Keurig.So why buy a Keurig? They are convenient and easy to keep clean. I purchased this device for use in a staff lounge to allow many users to utilize it, so far it works great. At home I use a Super-Automatic espresso machine that makes better coffee this is dramatically cheaper to boot.

As several other reviewer have mentioned this bed is deceptively light weight. You are kind of expecting it to be not that great. The reality is that our dog instantly liked it and now uses it constantly.We have an 80 pound or so Rhodesian mix. He is starting to get a little older and is having some joint issues. He loves this bed and uses it all the time. It is very light weight so extremely easy to move around when needed. We like this bed so much we are planning on buying a second one.

This is a fun product. I bought it as a gift for my sister whose current obsession is permaculture. Great quality cards and a fun way to review different elements of permaculture or to introduce it to those who are new to the concepts.

I don't know what you can say about a gift card pack. Exactly as described! The only way this could be better is if there were a discount for buying them at Amazon. As always, Amazon shipping was fast!

Inexpensive, fast, and compatible with Linux.This is just a cheapish video card that I wanted to throw into an old machine that I was going to run using Linux. The responsiveness is amazing. VERY fast. Mind you I am not playing games with this card. But as a desktop/office video card it works extremely well and I can hardly see how you can go wrong.One thing that I wasn't quite expecting, the heat sink is gigantic. You can kind of see that in the picture. On my mother board it was a tight fit as the heat sink ran right smack into my main motherboard power connector. I was just able to squeeze it in, but considered trimming off some of the heat sink, but in the end I did not need to.PROS:-FAST for desktop use-Lots of memory-No fan, so dead silent-Cheap!MAYBE CONS:-Very large heat sink (make sure it will fit

I haven't really had a chance to cook with these yet, but after unboxing and cleaning them (which took just a minute) I have loaded them into my oven. They seem like they are of excellent quality and I am eager to try them out.I was all set to go buy some cheap tile at my local home improvement store ala Alton Brown. But I just got a bit paranoid after about all the potential chemicals that are not labeled on tiles that were never designed to be food grade. Look around and you will see what I am talking about. These tiles cost more, but I would rather not have to worry.As a replacement for my old pizza stone, I am certain that these will be an improvement.After I have cooked with these for a while I will probably come back and update my review with my experiences.PROS-Food grade-Excellent quality-No need to worry about unsafe chemicals...CONS-More expensive than buying a few cheap but potentially unsafe tiles at a home improvement store
This might as well have been an exact replacement for the original. Exactly what we needed for our Nutone whole has vacuum system.

This book is 17 years old and INSANELY expensive for what is basically a photo copied spiral bound text. Pearson publishing should be ASHAMED of themselves for inflicting this on students at up to $180+ in college bookstores. Unbelievable. I am sure that when the book was written in 1997 it was less than $20. While the content may not need updating they sure have updated the price!!!!

Love this device. Synology has by far the best webmin interface I have every used. It is practically like running a full desktop, yet runs completely in your browser. Their software is top notch and VERY fast.This is the first Raid I have owned, but I have owned other NAS devices before.I did a great deal of research in choosing which Raid to purchase. Unfortunately, I missed one little thing that was important to me. There are other Synology Raids that are aimed at media/video serving roles. These models have a somewhat more powerful processor so that they can transcode video. They also allow for the installation of the Plex Media Server which is way better than the standard Synology media server. All of my video is pre-transcoded, so I didn't feel the need to spend the money on the more expensive media version. I didn't quite catch that Plex would not run on this version. This is at least partially my fault, but it is a bit hard to tell when reading about on the web. My solution which is working fine, is that I do have my Synology holding and serving all of the media files, but I have continued to run the Plex server on my Win7 machine. This adds a bit of network overhead no doubt, but it has run beautifully. I would love it if they would deliver a version of Plex that ONLY serves files and does not transcode.If you are planning on doing a lot of video serving, your should probably go with the more powerful Synology devices.The device is built well, the software is top notch. I do feel that it is pricey, but I was willing to pay it for the security that adding a Raid device adds to the protection of my files. I have files on my computer going back almost 20 years. I have a cloud based backup, but I really wanted a second backup that I was in control of, the Synology provides this backup as well as serving media files.I have Mac, Windows, and Linux devices on my home network. The setup process is quite different for each, and so far it works well with all three. I will tell you there is a bit of a learning curve here, and it wasn't always obvious how to go about making connections between devices. If you are on Windows download the Synology Assistant which makes adding network drives MUCH easier. There is a version of this app for OS X, but it seems to be less featured, and connecting to my Mac was much more involved than the Windows setup. I would like to see some more work on this app.PROS:-Amazing Webmin interface-Once setup works very well for backup and file serving-Small and convenient to hide in a closet-High quality case and hardwareCONS-Kind of expensive-Arm version does not support Plex-Setup is not for users who do not know what they are doing-I get some dodgy connections with my Macbook (it works then it doesn't, no explanation why)I would buy Synology again, and probably will, though doing it over, I would probably get the more powerful processor.

This didn't come with anything but the bracket which I guess is fun, but most mounts come with bolts and accessories, this one doesn't, be prepared.The other surprise I didn't expect is that my SSD did not really fill out the bracket. The bracket is really designed for a regular 2.5" HD, not what most SSD's actually look like.So how to solve these problems... Zip ties and washers. It doesn't look super pretty but it is solid and works fine. I could not have used actual screws because my SSD and the brackets holes were not lined up, but the zip ties made that point moot. This was a much better solution then my first idea of drilling my own holes.

This show was a great surprise. The Vikings seem so barbaric and yet so humane at the same time. Even though I am ethnically English, I found myself clearly and completely rooting for the Vikings, I am sure you will too.
Working great so far.

So this is one of the best oral history books I have ever read. Never mind the fact that the history itself is totally made up. Zombies are really cool right now, but this book was a good read before the current craze started. Brooks retells the story of the Zombie Wars from the perspective of the survivors years later. It is a riveting read and something that you will thoroughly enjoy if you like zombies or oral history.Sadly, the Brad Pitt movie was a total bus and disappointment. There are only vague and occasional questions between the two. The book just doesn't work as a movie, as a episodic television series it could be gold. If only...

HDTV never looked this good. We are toward the outside edge of this antenna's range. It went up on the roof without too much trouble, all though I had a handy friend help out. Reception is outstanding and I couldn't be happier.

Bought this to stream movies from our computer. It just wouldn't work even though spec-wise it should have. Sent back, bought an Apple TV2 instead, we have been somewhat happy with it, but have moved on to a Roku 3 which we LOVE.

My in-laws take a lot of cruises.  We bought this for them as a gift and they love it. As you likely know, the airlines have become ridiculous in their baggage restrictions in the last few years. Get one of these and never worry about paying an overweight bag fee again!!!

I usually use the solid crystal version, but this works well too (it seems like you need to reapply more often though).I have used Naturally Fresh for over a decade. To be clear, typical deodorants do work better. However, right around my 30th birthday I became allergic to ALL of them. All deodorants give me a horrible rash. Naturally Fresh is the only alternative that works that doesn't make me completely uncomfortable.
A friend had her laptop power pack sparking in an unsettling way. This is the replacements and has worked perfectly since buying it.
Bought for a friend whose old laptop battery died. It is a perfect fit and holding up well to use. No complaints so far, except that original batteries should last longer!!!

I have done concrete before, and if you haven't the first thing that you should know is that working with concrete does to your body something like what a professional boxer does to a punching bag. It is a lot of lifting, kneeling, being on your knees, and generally feeling like you've been thoroughly pummeled. If you have never done it before, seriously consider asking an experienced friend for help. If you can afford to hire this out to a pro, you will probably be glad you did!That said, with careful planning or doing a little bit at a time, you can make this work. As others have said if you are doing many of these, either borrow, rent, or buy a concrete mixer. They are not that expensive and are well worth it for making the job more tolerable. If you are just doing a handful, a shovel and wheel barrow will do fine. I already own a cement mixer, and I am putting 80 of these in, so you know what I am using!Concrete will set up differently based on the amount of water you put in, and the amount you "work" the concrete. While I have put in several slabs of concrete, I have never poured it into molds, so this is a bit of a new one for me. The molds work great, although they are not super strong. We broke one before I poured the first square, fixed it with a piece of duct tape which is still working fine!If you follow the directions on your concrete mix it will probably be too dry and look very rough. You will likely need to add a bit more water, but go easy on it, it should be wet but not soupy. If it is too wet, it will not hold up on its own once you pull out the mold. If you are doing many of these, I suggest that you start in the place where the look is least important and make a few till you get the technique down, then go gangbusters. I find that I can do about six of these in 90 minutes, if someone else is helping.When we are done we will acid stain and then seal them. They should look very nice and last many years. My only regret right now is only buying two. I wish I had at least three if not four, but I am making a lot of squares!Update: October 15, 2014So we are done with the project now (except the final acid staining and sand). It went pretty well, but there is definitely a learning curve here! The ones that I liked the least it turns out are the squares that were a little on the dry side. It was hard to get them to finish right and I had to redo some chunks that crumbled. By the end of our project I was pretty good at this and could usually get the look that I was going for.Figure out a process that allows you to be productive and quick. I did the following:1. Level my molds (stick an old piece of tile or something flat underneath the edges of two or more molds, so that they are level.2. I would mix two bags, pour them out into the molds and spread the concrete.3. Mix two more finish filling the first mold.4. Mix two more, flatten the tops with a trowel, take the first molds off, and set up for the next set of molds.5. After your concrete is starting to setup I would use my trowel to smack the molds to give the concrete some texture.6. Repeat until you are done pouring for the day.7. About 20 minutes after I was finished pouring I would use a broom to lightly wipe the tops of the concrete to give it a little broomed texture. This looks nice and decreases your chance of slipping when they are wet.Pro-tip: If you are doing a lot, have your local home store deliver the concrete. It doesn't cost that much and will save you MANY trips to load and unload the concrete yourself. I had two pallets worth dropped in our front yard and wheel barrowed them in three at a time.

The main advantage here is that this is probably 40-50% cheaper on Amazon than it is at our local pond supply store. As far as I can tell, they aren't available at the big box home improvement stores, so this is the best place to get this if you need one and can wait a couple of days for deliver. Quality is great and it keeps the pond clear!

Bought this the other day to go with the Nexus 7 we just purchased. The magnetized case seems to work very well. It snaps on easily and fits perfectly with the Nexus 7. So far I am satisfied, It is "leathery looking" but if you get close you can tell it is plastic. A lot of complaints on Amazon about it not holding up to use, hopefully we don't have the same issue, but there were enough people that liked it and it was inexpensive enough that I thought it was worth the risk.

So I have been trying to do some organizing and preparation for emergencies. The idea is a few simple but useful tools, flashlights, batteries, emergency food and water for 3-4 days. While ever needing these things is mostly unlikely, it is always good to be prepared, you never know what might happen. The purchase of this battery organizer was part of that plan. Who wants to try and find batteries in a drawer or store them in a ziplock (which is what I was doing before). This organizer is tidy, well built easily attaches to any wall. The Tester works great as well. I am totally happy with this and very glad that I bought it!!!

Very simple and small device.This is my first inductive charger, so I have nothing to compare it with. It is small, it looks nice, and much more affordable than some of the other Qi chargers out there.It works great if you get your phone nicely centered on the device. It will make some rather loud beeps if someone bumps your phone out of position, so be ready for that! (I wouldn't keep it in a bedroom!)Charging speed seems quite a bit slower than USB. Keep this in mind, this device might be better as a top off device rather than your full time charger.

Our wand died after about 6 years of use. It was honestly a little confusing trying to figure out which wand would work with our whole house Vac system since NuTone's current product line has had a lot of change in the past few years.Upon ordering this, I wasn't totally sure it would fit our system. NuTone needs to do a better job clarifying their product line and making it transparent what you are buying and what fits with what. Their lack of info is why I am dropping a star.The wand itself is well made, and if anything I would say the quality is superior and it seems more durable than the wand we replaced. The telescoping ratchet works really well, and I would recommend this purchase assuming it fits your system.

Fast and large SD card. There isn't much more to say here. I have had many SanDisk's now and have nothing but good things to say about them.One thing I would mention, make sure you need the size card you are buying. We are using this in a 12 megapixel camera, and rarely fill it to 25% before unloading it into the computer. Do some calculations on what you will realistically use, you might be fine with an 8 or 16 GB card, and be able to save yourself some money.

We have been mostly happy with this. It has been installed for about 2 years. We have an 80 pound Rhodesian Ridgeback, he is a big boy and runs through this thing at sometimes pretty high speed. After some time, parts on this thing have begun to break. The screws go into plastic and these are now sheering off. I have repaired it a few times, but likely I will need to replace it soon.I am doubtful that there is a better product available as cheap plastic seems to be what is around with everything nowadays. I sure would like something more durable though.When the product was not broken, it did a nice job insulating with the double rubber doors, and the insulation was the reason that we purchased this since we were doing a remodel and spending a bunch on insulation for the rest of the house.

PLEASE SEE MY SIX MONTH UPDATE AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS REVIEWI want to give this five stars, but I can't. I pre-ordered this from Roku the day it was announced. It is pretty much exactly what I wanted, most of the features of the Roku 3 (which I LOVE), but in a small package that can be hidden behind the TV and powered by the USB port. You may know that Roku took an earlier stab at this with a device the required an MHL port (kind of a super HDMI port), this meant it only worked with some TV's and the device never took off.I don't know if the very inexpensive Google Chromecast was the push that Roku needed to try to get the Roku Stick right, but sure enough they are back with a device very similar to the original stick but that uses USB and HDMI, instead of the MHL port. So far so good... It should work with any TV that has an HDMI port, but there is no Ethernet so make sure your Wi-Fi is solid.I received this in the mail today and immediately started setting it up. This process took much too long compared with my setup of the Roku 3 a few months ago which was easy and FAST. I had some trouble getting the device to connect with the remote (I think it was confusing my Roku 3 remote and the newer Roku remote, I finally took the batteries out of the older remote to ensure they didn't stomp on each other).With the remote connected, I moved onto Wi-Fi, it connected to the Wi-Fi but would not connect to the internet. After going through all sorts of attempts and settings, I decided to hotspot to my phone to see if that would work, and this allowed me to run the Roku updates and load in the channels. After the software update was complete, I connected back to my regular house Wi-Fi and all was well! So this must have been some kind of issue with the combination of the initial Roku Stick software and my network.After the network was updated then it was on to setting up the individual accounts (Netflix, Amazon VOD, and iHeartRadio being the important ones for us). So I would love to know why Roku does not store the login information and transfer it to all of my devices? (UPDATE: In the comments to this review it was mentioned that Roku does not store ANY of your account information to protect your identity. This is plausible and likely true, but it would be nice if setting up a new device was simpler.)But no, you have to do this manually. Going through this process brought me to the thing that I am really worried about: the response of the remote sucks, it sticks, it lags, and sometimes you are waiting a long time for it to catch up with you. I cannot EVER recall waiting on the Roku 3, at least in regards to responding to commands from the remote.The last concern I have is the size of the stick and it's fit in the TV. I didn't imagine this would be an issue, and hopefully it won't turn out to be, but when I installed it in the back of the TV, the fit was very tight and there was noticeable pressure put onto the USB cable and the HDMI connection. I am hopeful that this will not cause any issues going forward and I may look at moving it to a different HDMI port to see if there is a better fit, if you encounter this problem, you may want to look at getting a short HDMI extension to avoid putting undesirable pressure on the device.The Good:-Roku's software and interface are the best I have used, and this is exactly like the Roku 3-Streaming quality seems to be very good thus far-I've tested all the services we use, and though the setup was tedious everything works and the quality is excellentThe Bad:-The installed software that needed immediate updating has issues-Initial setup was NOT smooth (I have done this before, so it should have been!)-Device response to the remote can lag a lot (this may be the thing that ruins the stick for me)This device is BRAND NEW, so I am willing to be a little patient with Roku, hopefully as they roll out more updates in the next few weeks some of the issues will be worked out, the remote lag is a MUST fix. People will abandon a device that seems flaky (this is why I am getting rid of my Apple TV's). I am kind of surprised that all of the reviews so far have been almost completely positive, at this point I am a bit disappointed when comparing this to my Roku 3.After a few weeks and hopefully some updates, I will revise this review, I am hopeful that I will be able to add more stars, but the jury is out on that until I have lived with the device for a while.UPDATE: October 15, 2014 My Almost Six Month UpdateI have not quite given up the device (we still use it all the time). However, if I were making this purchase now I would not buy the Roku Stick, I would buy another Roku 3. It turns out that the Roku Stick has a MUCH less powerful processor than what is in the Roku 3 (a device that is almost a year older). The specs were not released until after the device was on sale as far as I can tell. Were this device to have the power of the Roku 3 (maybe next year!) I would recommend it.A few issues and work-arounds:-Start-up is SLOOOOWWWWW. I initially had it powered by the USB port on my television. This meant waiting at least a minute from turn on time to watching a show. Way too long. What I have done instead is powered the Stick from a regular power outlet and the USB power supply. This means as soon as you turn on the TV it is ready to go.-It has periodic crashes, mostly this just means it won't do anything. So at least weekly restarts are required. While many people are used to this these days it shouldn't be this way. I restart most of my computers at most once a month and often I go months between restarts. The Roku should be less fragile than it is (the Roku 3 IS less fragile).-The Netflix app, in my opinion, is too demanding for this device. This is particularly noticeable when rewinding a video (at least at 1080p) which is essentially impossible. It just doesn't work. You lose control of the remote and the rewind just doesn't work. I am considering moving this to a 720p TV, it may work better with a smaller fire hose of video attached.-Amazon VOD in contrast to Netflix works pretty well on the Roku Stick. I have far fewer issues with Amazon, so if that is your primary video source, maybe this isn't such a bad idea.-I use this on a 1080p TV with a FAST connection to the internet. Once the video is playing, the quality of video and audio is EXCELLENT. It looks great, and once it is rolling everything is fine as long as you don't want to do a quick rewind (which won't work).-I had an issue with the device not fitting well into an HDMI port. I switched it to a different port, fortunately my TV has several, and it fits fine there, in the comments several people mentioned that you can buy (and maybe request from Roku) a small HDMI extension cable if it will not fit in your TV. I didn't need to do that, but some people might need to do so.

We are now going on two years with our Ooma (also bought one for my in-laws and they love it too). We have a very fast cable internet connection, and I couldn't figure out why I was still paying the phone company. We plugged the device into our home network, registered, and ported our number, that did take a few days to finalize and we have been going strong ever since. We did pay a bit extra for the upgraded package, this works out to around $13 a month. Call quality is excellent, at least as good as the phone company. We would highly recommend this to anyone, so long as you have a reliable internet connection. One weird thing that I noticed, when you answer the phone there is just an ever so slightly long delay before the person can hear you. I usually say "hello" twice, they hear me the second time. After that there is never any perceptible delay that I have ever noticed. The voice mail feature is outstanding and you can have it forward voicemails to your cel phone, e-mail, etc.The Great:-Call Quality is Excellent-You can use all of your old phones and wiring-It is MUCH CHEAPER than the phone company-Call forwarding-You can take the device with you and plug it in to any network (My in-laws do this multiple times per year)The Not So Great:-You really need a decently fast and reliable internet connection-Short delay on beginning of a call-You probably need a bit of networking knowledge to make the install go easy

This seems indistinguishable from the Apple original. We purchased this to replace a misplaced original charging cable. So far it is working perfectly and we couldn't be happier. Even though this should be a very inexpensive item, as it is a simple cable, if you've looked at Apple replacement parts, you will not be surprised that many are looking for cables like this one.On the whole it was cheap enough to buy, shipped and arrived VERY fast. We couldn't be happier.If something goes wrong later, I will update this review.

Installed this on a rental. We are probably just at the edge of the usable range for this antenna to the local TV towers, and yet once installed it worked perfectly to bring broadcast TV in in all its HD glory. This was an easy install that we attached to an eave on the side of the house so that we could take it down later (which we already have done after moving).It was a very easy install, just a couple of screws. If you don't have existing wiring probably the hardest part will be running the COAX to your TV. We had wiring to piggy back on so the install was a piece of cake. Probably took at most 30 minutes and the signal was strong.

We built a new house with a basement and wanted to include carpeting below ground level, but water is always an issue. We used a combination of RadonSeal on the walls and Ion-Bond on the floors. After over a year there are no leaks and the basement is very dry and I couldn't be happier especially since the basement was a real stressor in our construction plans.Even just a few days after application it was obvious that this stuff was working great. Any water sprayed on the surface immediately beaded up and did not penetrate into the concrete. We did a lot of testing to see if there were leaks after the first application and did find a few which we sealed up and reapplied a second coat of the RadonSeal (to be clear the leaks were caused by gaps in the grout, not the RadonSeal). With the problem solved everything was tight and so far after a year totally water proof.This material seems a little on the expensive side, but it is really effective. I have tried a few other methods and I don't think you are likely to find a better product on the market for basement sealing.

After over a year there are no leaks and the basement is very dry and I couldn't be happier especially since the basement was a real stressor in our construction plans.Even just a few days after application it was obvious that this stuff was working great. We were doing a construction project, so what the heck, lets add a wine cellar too.After doing a bunch of research it became clear that Gold's book was the best choice. It was recommended by many reviewers. I read the book thoroughly and incorporated a cellar into our construction plan. Reading the chapter on the vapor barrier and insulation are critical if you are going to pull off a passive wine cellar. Moreover, I wouldn't even try to go passive unless you are building mostly below ground.It is fairly obvious that the cooling systems that are available for non-passive wine cellars are problematic and extremely unreliable, so passive is best.In our situation we had a mostly below ground basement level. We bumped up the insulation on the inside and added some outside as well since the building was already trenched. We also added a vapor barrier. The room so far stays very cool even though we aren't quite done. There is also a whole chapter about how to construct the perfect door. It turns out that it is almost impossible to buy an adequately insulated door, but it is not that hard to build one yourself if you are handy enough or can hire a contractor.If you are looking for a prestige wine cellar to show off and impress people with, be warned that Gold is pretty negative about these, and won't help you much there, this is about storing and protecting wine, and Gold doesn't care too much about impressing people. He does offer some great advice about how to build your own effective shelving system and how and where to buy wine that are quite insightful.If you are building a wine cellar, get this book, and maybe one for your contractor.

(This review is based on the uncorrected/unformatted PDF version from the author's site, along with the Kindle preview of the finished book as I'm still waiting for my physical copy to arrive)For anyone starting to learn about biology, getting a grip on the spatial and temporal dimensions of things going on in cells can be a challenge. Some things happen incredibly fast, others are surprisingly slow. And even after you come to know the names and functions of many of the molecular species found inside cells, there are lots of questions about numbers that suggest themselves. Just how many ribosomes are there in a typical cell? How long does it take to transcribe DNA to RNA and then translate it into protein? How many photons does it take to make a cyanobacterium? etc. Along the way we learn other interesting facts such as that there are estimated to be 100,000,000 times as many virus particles as there are human cells in the world.The authors have been compiling interesting numbers about biology at their web site www.bionumbers.org for several years. Now they've produced this book which explores many numerical properties of cells. How many, how fast, how much energy, how big, etc. They perform back-of-the-envelope calculations and walk you through coming up with answers to many fascinating questions.This book would also serve as a good, if somewhat less formal, introduction to the field of physical biology.In any case, it's a fun and enlightening read that will have you thinking about cells in new ways as you begin to attach some concrete numbers to the conceptual ideas of traditional molecular biology. I very highly recommend this book to anyone learning, or simply interested in, the workings of the cell.G.

This is horribly designed. In order to get the physical product to work (rather than the in-app-purchase version) you have to hold a paper "passport" card up against the screen. Yeah, you heard that right, not hold it up to the camera, but up against the screen of the phone itself! How is this even supposed to work? Of course nothing happens, there's no feedback, and according to the View Master site, it may not work at all with phones that are in a case and/or have a screen protector installed.I'm sorry, but I'm supposed to destroy my screen protector and disassemble my case in order to try this? I don't think so.Fortunately the other reviews suggest that the experience isn't all that great even if you do get it to work.IF you want to try out this product then *don't* buy the physical version. The in-app-purchase version is the same price and you won't have to jump through the impossible security hoops. You won't get the AR feature, but honestly that seems rather pointless anyway since it's VR not AR that is the goal here.Disappointing.So far all my phone-based VR experiences with Google Cardboard or similar have been horrible unpleasant blurry/grainy pixelated experiences.G.

These work really well. I used one on a really dusty car dash and it ended up looking like new!The fluffy part does have a sort of pocket into which the handle inserts, so the plastic isn't scraping on everything you're dusting.They absorb quite a bit of dust and dirt, but I don't find them that reusable so they're not cheap but they are very effective and for many of us that will justify the cost. You pretty much just run them over a surface and ALL the dust is cone in one swipe.The refills seem dry, so I think there's less worry about them drying out the way the Swiffer floor products can over time or if you don't get the lid back on.The separately available extension arm is highly recommended for getting at all those cobwebs, but then you'll be able to use it everywhere and will probably go through a lot more of them! It's great being able to throw it away when you're done dusting rather than having to keep a yucky dusting tool around.G.

After buying an OtterBox Commuter for my 6s+, I've now had a chance to try both the Defender and this Symmetry model, as well as the Symmetry case for the regular 6s.The Symmetry cases are nice because they're a single piece made of two kinds of plastic molded together. This gives them the benefit of a more protective rubber frame and internal structure, plus a harder plastic back that supports the whole thing. As a result they're the thinnest/smallest of the OtterBox cases that I've tried and the dual-material molding is a more advanced technology than their traditional multi-part cases. The back of the case is solid plastic with no opening over the Apple logo as their other cases have.The Symmetry case has no flaps over the connectors, with openings for speaker, mic/headphone, lightning, and the silence switch. The up, down, and power buttons are covered by the rubber case which has raised rubber areas to push and requires slightly more force than the bare phone would.Installation is pretty easy, just a matter of pressing the phone into the case. Getting it back out is a bit harder due to the rigid back of the case that makes it hard to bend away from a corner of the phone. All the OtterBox cases seem to like to hold on tightly to your phone so you really don't want to have to swap cases frequently.No screen protector is included with the Symmetry cases (the Commuter comes with a very basic plastic stick-on protector and the Defender has a thicker plastic screen cover that's part of the case).It fits the 6s+, and supposedly is newly designed for it, though it feels almost like this is still a 6+ cover that happens to squeeze in a 6s+ well enough. Once in the case, the rubber case edge ridge is only a millimeter or two higher than the surface of the screen. It's ok face down on a flat surface but you would want to be careful with any rougher surface. I'm not as impressed with the fit of this case on the 6s+ as I was with a Symmetry case for the smaller iPhone 6s. The Symmetry 6s case is my favorite so far for that phone, but on the 6s Plus, it doesn't fit and look as nice and I really think the case needs to be just a bit thicker. Much of this may just be the proportion differences on such a very big phone. On the smaller 6s, the Symmetry cases feel awesome, but on the big 6s+ proportions are such that it doesn't feel as adequate.It's still very nice and should provide good protection for a very slim case. I had higher hopes though for this one though, and I've put my phone back in my OtterBox Commuter case for now. If you have a 6s, then the Symmetry case is an absolute winner. On the 6s+ however it just feels like not quite enough case for me and I prefer the slightly bulkier Commuter version.I'm going to say 3.5 stars rounding up to 4. As thin cases go it's still nicer and probably more protective than most even if the case does seem just a touch smaller than it should be.G.

The whole family has been loving 3.0 and the Start Wars figures. We have 1.0 but never picked up 2.0, so there's a lot that's new for us and the game really seems more polished and there's a lot more to do now than there was back in 1.0.The 3.0 software lets you play with the 1.0 and 2.0 characters, but does not include any of the older play sets, so you have to start up with the older software versions when you want to revisit the old worlds.These games really capture the Disney experience, and Disney is making the most of their intellectual property now that they own practically everything as you constantly run into mini-characters from their vast and diverse catalog.The 3.0 game would be worth it just for the toy box hub activities and things like your own interior home that can be expanded into a huge labyrinth of rooms, hallways, secret doors, etc. and each room can be extensively customized as you unlock designs and items. This mini-game alone can keep just about anyone occupied for days.Note that there are going to be *three* Star Wars play sets for 3.0 it looks like. One comes with this the regular starter edition.This review is for the XBOX 360 version, it looks and plays great. Maybe there's something in the XBOX ONE version that would make it more worthwhile, but if you're still on the 360 and not planning on upgrading this Christmas, then this is a great game to get and will breathe some more life into your old console.Great fun, highly recommended.

OtterBox has two relatively new case lines, the Symmetry and MySymmetery. Both have single-piece multi-material moldings with a plastic back and rubber sides that wrap around the front of the phone.This is one of the My symmetry cases where the back of the case is clear, and you can either leave it that way to expose the pack of your phone, or put a patterned insert in the window to give it a different character. The inserts are paper and opaque, printed on coated heavy card stock, and each case only comes with one. I think it would have been nice for them to include an assortment of backs with each case.You can also print and cut out your own customized backs, and you can get PDF templates to help with this at their web site at http://www.otterbox.asia/myotterdesign/The case feels very good in the hand and fits the iPhone 6s well. The plastic back is smooth but not overly slippery, and it has a good tactile feel as it's slightly flexible and not rigid or brittle. The up/down/power buttons are completely covered by the rubber part of the case and rubber buttons are provided which will increase the force required to activate the buttons a bit. The mute switch, headphone/mic, Lightning connector, and speaker are all uncovered by openings through the case.The phone feels well protected. Not as much as the more serious OtterBox cases, but better than your average case. The [My]Symmetry cases are the most compact and give the best look and feel of all the OtterBox models. Yes, there's less overall protection, but the advanced multi-material moldings really help simplify things compared to the older multi-part cases.Note that the [My]Symmetry cases do not come with any screen protector so you'll probably want at least a basic plastic screen protector to go with this case.4.5 stars rounding up to 5.G.

I have tried three different Otterbox cases for the 6s and 6s Plus so far, two of which I bought, and this one that Vine offered me to test.This is the Defender, the classic Otterbox design that offers the most protection of any of their cases. It consists of an inner two part rigid plastic box that snaps together around the phone which has a sealed window over the hole on the back that you see the Apple logo through, and a sealed screen protector that's permanently part of the front half of the inner case. The hole in the screen protector for the home button is covered with a thin rubbery material to let the Touch ID work while still keeping the display sealed. It's not waterproof as the earpiece/front camera, speaker, rear camera, and microphone are all exposed, but it could save you from drops and splashes that almost all other cases would not.The screen protector is smooth thin plastic that still lets you transmit pressure to the screen. It does unfortunately look like a plastic layer over the screen and detracts from the beauty of the naked iPhone screen (as do all screen protectors to some degree). I've seen some people talk about using a heat gun to remove the built-in plastic screen and using a separate tempered-glass screen protector. But honestly if you want the protection that the Defender provides, then you're already giving up some convenience and aesthetics, so you might decide just to live with the plastic screen. It does not in any way limit what you can see and do on the phone.A rubber shell covers the back and sides of the inner box. Getting this off the first time is a bit of a challenge as it comes around the front and seats into a channel that goes around the front of the bezel so you have to pry it up and out of the channel before you can peel it back around.The rubber shell has flaps that seal the headphone, lightning, and mute switches. The mute switch one is rather a pain to open and get at the tiny switch, so if you like being able to easily switch into and out of silent mode then this may not be the case for you.In addition, there's a large rigid black plastic cover that snaps over the front and serves to completely protect the front of the phone. This has a large plastic spring-loaded belt clip directly in the center that rotates 360 degrees, snapping into 12 detent positions. For the 6s Plus and other huge phones, this ends up being quite a beast of a case arrangement and will be a challenge to wear on a belt without looking completely ridiculous. But if you want a belt case, this is a good option (also check out http://tuff-as-nuts.com/ for really nice custom leather cases, but again it's tough to pull this off with a phone so large).So let's compare this to a couple other cases, the Otterbox Commuter and the Otterbox Symmetry.The commuter Is a two-part case with a rubber inner case that wraps around the phone and a rigic back that snaps around it. It does not have a window over the logo opening on the back (it's open) and it comes with a very ordinart plastic adhesive screen protector with no covering for the home button. It does not have the belt-clip cover. There is no door over the mute switch so it's much easier to access (still fairly recessed though). When you hold the Defender you're touching the slightly tacky rubber outer case so it has a pretty good grip. With the Commuter, you're holding the  hard plastic back on the sides so it's more slippery. Overall it's a lot more compact while still providing much better than average protection.The Symmetry is a very interesting and somewhat more high-tech case than the other two. It consists of a single piece that is molded as a hard plastic back with an inner honeycomb pattern rubber backing which also comes up and around the bezel. It comes with no screen protector whatsoever. It's the smallest of the Otterbox cases and looks and feels really good. If you want a minimal type of case then this one will probably provide more drop protection than any of the typical cheap "skin" cases.All three cases cover the Up/Down and Power buttons completely with the rubber part of the case, and require a bit more pressure to activate as a result.The Defender however is clearly among the top choices if you are really worried about damaging your phone's screen, or if you need to use it in a more rugged environment. It's not small and will make an already slab-like phone into more of a brick, but for some that will be completely justified by the added peace of mind.

Feels very rigid and stable, even when standing on the top step. The size is excellent, giving you about a ten foot reach which is enough for pretty much any indoor task (that you'd want to stand on a ladder for) and even some outdoor work. It's large enough to solve most ladder-requiring problems, yet small and light enough to store anywhere and carry up and down stairs without breaking your back or smashing it into everything.Convenient enough to grab each time you just need an extra step to reach that top shelf, and tall enough to change all those pesky ceiling mounted light fixtures, install and remove draperies and other window treatments, and effortlessly reach all those cobwebs.There's a mostly gravity operated latch that holds the top step down when opened up, and requires almost no effort to unlatch when you're down and ready to fold/move the ladder. It does not latch closed in the stored position.Good stuff. Easy five-star rating and recommendation.G.

These are pretty good. Think dark chocolate compressed brownie with some broken pieces of cashew nut pressed into the surface.The pictures on the box show big chunks of dark chocolate and piles of whole or half cashews, but neither are much like anything you'll find inside the wrapper. The nuts looks like they started out as reject crumbs and broken pieces from a regular cashew packaging line. I've never found a piece larger than an eighth of a nut so far. There's nothing like a cashew "layer" in these, nor do the nuts seem to be mixed directly into the chocolate flavored bar. It looks like they just sprinkle a few nut crumbs into the bar mold and they end up pressed into the surface of the bar.So somewhat disappointing from a nut point of view.The chocolate part of the bar holds itself together well so it produces a relatively low amount of crumbs when you eat one. However the bars are a bit prone to having pieces of cashew fall off the surface of the bar as you're eating.The taste is fine but nothing I'd reach for as "candy". The specs aren't bad, 40g (1.41 oz) bar with 11g protein, 15g carbs, 1g fiber, 9g sugars, 9g fat, 3g saturated. Gluten free.Ingredients start out: Soy protein isolate, brown rice syrup, roasted cashews, chocolate liquor, sugar, crystalline fructose, almond butter, dutch-process cocoa, etc.I give em 3.5 stars, rounding up to 4.G.

We've been munching on these for the past couple days and have really enjoyed them. The assortment is good, substantial amounts of hazelnut flavor, some crunch, and a bit of cream and caramel. There are a couple almond ones with a whole almond on top, and one with crushed almonds on top but otherwise no noticeable nut texture or chunks or nut inside.The packaging is excellent, with multiple layers of packaging to open. It came in an outer brown box with a form-fitting insert holding the get and brown slip-case candy box, inside of which was a red-paper wrapped inner package and ultimately a clear plastic-wrapping on the box with a custom tray and a 1/4" springy paper pad on top of the actual chocolates.The outside of the package has a narrow vertically-oriented booklet attacked with 10 pages describing and identifying each type of candy that's included in English and French.Most of the varieties have two pieces each, but there were about four which were unique.Included were (if my memory is correct):Simply Almond x2 - Smooth dark chocolate praline topped which a whole crunchy roast almond.Avelotte Caramel x2 - Hazelnut cream with a hint of caramel.Velvet Bliss x2 - Hazelnut praline coated in milk chocolate.Dark Lemonnette x1 - Rich cocoa center with a hint of lemon.Gianduja x2 - Hazelnut cream with silky milk chocolate shell.Cocoa Dentelle x2 - Foil wrapped, intense notes of cocoa subtly blend with lightly-roasted nuts and crispy wafer pieces.Almond Caramel x1 - Soft caramel with a hint of salt in a dark chocolate cup with almond crumbl on top.Intense Dark x1 - Intense dark center coated with crunchy dark chocolate shell.Triangle Crisp x2 - Milk chocolate triangle, lightly roasted almonds and crispy wafer.Creamy Cup x1 - Creamy center inside a milk chocolate cup.Excellent.A note on shipping: The box arrived with no protection other than the outer brown cardboard packaging, and was left leaning up against our front door by UPS. The candy was fresh and in perfect condition, but as nothing was done to ensure that it remain refrigerated (or even cool) during shipping, if the sun had been on the front of the house and the package had sat there in the sun for very long then things might not have turned out so well.G.

This is a very interesting survey of the effects, both known and speculative, that quantum mechanics has on the micro-world of the cell and the resulting effect it has on Biology.There are two main reasons I think that people get interested in "quantum biology". The first is that at the scale of the cell, QM is going to dramatically affect the way chemistry happens. I think traditionally biologists have tended to just assume that these effects get abstracted into the behavior of the molecules so they don't need to think about them outside of areas like trying to design proteins from scratch and so leave such topics to the quantum chemists to deal with. But the topics discussed in the book suggest that maybe QM is adding into the behavior of the molecules in a way that you can't easily ignore, and that by considering the quantum mechanical effects you will be able to go deeper into understanding the interactions between molecules inside cells and thus reach an understanding that would not be possible otherwise.The second reason people get interested in QM is because they're looking for some "magic" to help explain how life is somehow special, or they want to find a basis for consciousness and self-awareness that is magical enough to fit with whatever philosophy appeals to them.There is much that is speculative in this book, but it's all at least grounded in the current science, so it's a fun read and give you a lot of things to think about.G.

It's really well made and powerful (I can't imagine needing any more power than it provides). I'm still getting the hang of using it as I hadn't used a string-trimmer before (eye protection and long pants are a must, lol).I get somewhat better than the 10 minutes of run-time that people are complaining about here, but I'm mostly going around touching up spots here and there rather than edging or something that would run it continuously.The weight is reasonable and the electric and cordless is about as convenient as you can get. Charging is pretty quick and convenient and I always top off the battery before using it.Assembly was pretty simple (had to track down a screw that had gotten loose in the box, but it turned out to be in there after all).G.

This seems to be one of the best review books currently for the NCLEX. My wife is going to be taking the test in the next few weeks and has been using the Kaplan review and study materials. She also took the Kaplan four day NCLEX prep class, which was mostly about test-taking skills, but then they send you off with a plan for content review for 6-8 weeks before you take the test. All of the question sources like this and the old NCLEX 4000 software seem pretty good, but she has been disappointed in the reationale contant of the Kaplan online practice tests and rill questions when compared to the NCLEX 4000 software.But until you take the test it's really hard to know what's the most useful. I'll come back and update the review after she takes the test and report which things she thinks helped the most.G.
This was a very cute and enjoyable book told from the point of view of the dog.It has the approval of the local 9 year-old.G.

The last OS this can be made to work with is 32-bit Windows 7. It will not work on any 64-bit windows (7, 8 10) as no driver exists in the world for the USB chip in this thing. It only comes with drivers for XP/98/2000. You can find 32-bit drivers for windows 7 if you're willing to download from the one or two people who have put them up. Beware of generic "driver" web sites that want you to download their driver repair software which is often malware.

This is a marvelous bike for the price, and you'd have to spend over twice as much before you'd notice any improvement I think (and then you'd be constantly worrying about something happening to it).I like that the handlebars allow a more upright riding style for casual trail riding more like a cruiser.The seat is shockingly comfortable coming from an old cheap mountain bike.Quite modest weight with its aluminum frame, very sturdy, perfectly at home on good dirt trails as well as pavement of course.Got mine for $279 before tax from my local Dick's Sporting Goods using one of their frequent one-day-only 20% off deals. Free store assembly and $8 for a kickstand if you want it.If you're looking for a comfortable hybrid bike you just can't go wrong here for the price. Basic but totally competent and good quality. More comfortable than many much more expensive bikes.Highly recommended.G.

The resident 8yo ate it up in an hour or so and seemed to enjoy it. Pig's writing is full of "creative" grammar, so some teachers may cringe when looking at this, but it seems pretty harmless overall. It uses a handwritten style of type along with bold type for every character name reference, as well as numerous illustrations to hold the reader's interest and attention.The level of humor is definitely "juvenile", but it's the sort of thing that most kids (and some adults) will probably love.

Ours seems to have a bit of Corgi in him as he's proportioned a bit different than int the pictures. Made of painted cloth stretched over a large wire loop, with a sheet of plastic inside to keep the ears upright. Can be folded up like one of those circular sun-shades for storage. Comes with two metal stakes which make it easy to place him out in the yard.Looks pretty realistic from a distance, especially if placed among some weeds/brush.

This is a complete system that does not require a computer/phone, but will also let you stream video and interact via iOS which is pretty cool.The camera is pretty small and has a very broad pan and tilt range, so it should work pretty much anywhere you can place it on a high enough vantage point.The remote and the camera are powered using the same micro-USB power charger (it comes with one for each). The remote is rechargeable so you can take it anywhere within WiFi range, and beyond that you can use your iOS device wherever you are.The remote display has a fold up antenna (usually seems to work fine without it folded out), and a metal stand tab that folds out from the back to prop it up.Overall the quality feels very good, though not as absolutely rock-solid as one might expect from the Motorola brand historically. The display interface is touch-based and can be a little fiddly. It's got a completely proprietary user interface so it takes a few minutes to get the hang of it, but you can pretty much figure it out by messing around with it. Volume of audio in both directions is adequate, but not booming.If you don't have the remote turned off completely it starts beeping if it loses the signal from the camera.There's a micro-SD card you can record to, but the process to do so is a little fiddly going through the menus.You can (in theory) buy a second camera to work with the system so you can monitor two locations without relocating the camera.Overall the video quality is excellent and the night-vision works well. The pan/tilt response is rather typically laggy and sometimes moves more than you'd like but generally it's quite controllable and lets you get it pointed where you want without too much trouble.There seems to be no provision for an earphone/headphone.If you want an expandable all-in-one monitor this one seems to be about as fully featured as you can get. Might be a little overwhelming for grandma to operate though.4.5 stars.G.

This is another of those breakthrough books that popularizes recent discoveries in science, and in this case it's doubly exciting because it's introducing an area of health science that is directly applicable to everyone, AND it's something that (unlike say your own genome) you can actually do something about today.I would put this in the same category as some of my other favorite science popularization books like Chaos: Making a New Science and The Epigenetics Revolution: How Modern Biology Is Rewriting Our Understanding of Genetics, Disease, and Inheritance, books that really open your eyes and let you in on things that are on the cutting edge of discovery.From its cover the book looks like yet another fad health and diet book, but don't let that fool you, this is a science book first, written by two researchers at Stanford who are working to unlock the secrets of the microbes that live in your gut, and they tell the exciting story of our new understanding of their complex behavior and how they interact in very complex and highly evolved ways with the rest of our bodies.They suggest that through our western diets and other effects we have been killing off the diversity of our intestinal biome and that this may well be directly associated with many of the new epidemic health issues like gluten sensitivity, obesity, diabetes, etc.The science is fascinating and you'll discover that there's an entire universe of complex life living inside you that you probably never imagined.While there's far more yet to discover than has been unearthed so far, the authors feel that there are things we can do today to promote a healthier and more effective microbiome in our guts, and to that end they offer practical advice on diet (including recipes) to keep your tummy critters happy and healthy.It's great stuff that everyone should read and I give it all possible stars.G.

I really enjoyed this. It's a very candid (and very British) view of what it's like to be a Neurosurgeon. Very down-to-earth, not pretentious or self-aggrandizing at all and in fact the complete opposite of that.A very worthy memoir of a life spent in medicine. A quick, easy, and entertaining read.Perhaps not the thing to read right before you go in for brain surgery however (or maybe it is, I'm not sure).Anyhow, recommended.G.

This is a nice little portable USB 3 drive. It's molded into a reasonably rigid plastic box with a slight texture to it as shown in the product photo. The plastic is not super thick, so if you squeezed the case hard enough you could pinch the drive inside, so probably best not to store a bowling ball on top of it, but otherwise it should be pretty rugged.I was not able to take it apart or otherwise determine exactly which physical drive is inside and whether it's using drive-integrated USB 3 or whether there's a separate interface board. I suspect from the size that it's using one of the newer drives that has USB functionality mostly built into the drive itself.The only opening into the enclosure is the USB 3 Standard B jack. The drive gets power only from the USB interface, and will work with USB 2 or USB 3 ports. It comes with a USB 3 A to B cable that's about 18 inches long. There are basically no instructions or documentation other than a photo of plugging the cable into the drive and a USB port, plus some disclaimers in a couple dozen languages with a note that it you want to know what the warranty is or anything else that you should go to Seagate's web site. The box it comes in is not too much bigger than the drive itselfThe drive was NTFS formatted out of the box, with a usable capacity of 2,000,396,320,768 bytes or 1.81 TiB. The drive comes empty apart from a Seagate setup program that I didn't run because the drive worked perfectly out of the box under Windows 8.1 on my laptop.Doing a full backup of my Windows 8.1 laptop with a 256GB SSD over USB 3 to the drive using Acronis 2015 took about 40m and copied 152GB of  data to the drive for a throughput of about 60MB/sec. Copying a 5GB movie from the laptop by dragging it from the Windows desktop to the drive went at 52MB/sec. Copying it back from the drive to the latop the same way went at 122MB/sec."Ejecting" the drive from Windows both unmounted it and powered it off before it was unplugged.It's virtually silent (I can't really hear it at all in a quiet room) and has only a very slight vibration when spinning.There's nothing especially epic about it, but so far it has worked perfectly out of the box and performs well, so I like it.By the way, this drive has a capacity 362,000 times bigger than the first hard drive I ever owned, and per byte it's more than seven million times cheaper.G.

Spring is just starting to arrive here so it's too soon to be certain, but these seem to be a perfectly acceptable equivalent to the other major brand and are a bit cheaper.Applies easily, no untoward side-effects so far.

This series of toys isn't quite as well done as some others we've had, but it's still pretty fun.The way this one works is that you place Frank against the fence at the top, and then launch the included Lightning McQueen up and around the bend where he hits a lever while going around the top. The third time you do this, the fence drops and Frank rolls forward a few inches to block the track and knock down the ramp which flips into the path, allowing you to launch Lightning once more and he will go up the ramp and jump over Frank (and fly off the back of the set) to "escape".You have to hit the launcher button almost as hard as you can to get Lightning to make it around the track. When you don't quite hit it hard enough, he will roll backwards and get diverted around the side path where he causes the little tractor to "tip" momentarily.When Lightning does make it around the track he comes down nose-first against the launcher, so you have to pick him up and turn him around for the next launch.That's about all there is to the operation of the set, and after a few times it will probably get boring and the kids will start to explore alternative play ideas, so I think there's limited long-term potential here. This is one in a series that can be connected together to build larger layouts with interchangeable launchers etc. To some degree you can mix and match parts.So 3.5 stars, rounding up to four here.G.

Once broken apart, the edges don't feel like perforation at all. They have a slightly rough edge, but I've had professionally made cards that felt about the same. It's more noticeable when you have a stack of the cards, but when holding one card it feels excellent, and I would have no worries handing these out that they will come across as unprofessional somehow. The thickness is exactly what I'd expect and want in a professional business card, not too thin that they feel like paper and not so thick that you can't fit more than a couple in a wallet.The color "ivory" is a light cream that adds a nice touch to the design of your cards. If you want pure white then you want a different product, but if you like a little extra warmth in the result then these are great.I ran them through a couple of Epson all-in-one printers that have a pretty tight paper path and they survived fine, though if your printer has a single-feed / straight paper path then that's better as these are relatively heavy card-stock. Check the back of your printer to see if there's a fold-down single-sheet feed feature as many printers have these, but many people will never use them as they never knew (or forgot) that the printer has this feature.They took the ink fine and the results look good. The ability to print both sides of the cards opens up all kinds of design opportunities. I like to have my regular business card info on the front, and then offer some technical quick-reference information on the back that gives people a reason to hang on to the card and keep it handy.Excellent product.G.

I really enjoyed the book. I had never read or listened to any of his stuff before. It's really very well written and readable, and it gives you a real feeling for what it must be like to do that job in New York.It's an easy read, and the chapters stand alone as individual stories so you can consume them over time rather than having to feel like you need to read the book all at once.Great book!G.

These are very nice towels, the bath sheet is huge and heavy and feels good. Color is as shown in the picture (at least for blue). Should last a long time and a good choice for a medium to high-end towel.

I'm comparing this book (MB) to Molecular Biology of the Cell (MBoC), which is probably my favorite textbook of all time.This one (MB) is not as much of a general cell biology book as it primarily covers only the elements of the so-called "central dogma" of molecular biology. DNA replication and transcription into RNA, and RNA translation into protein, plus all the regulatory aspects of those processes (as well as chapters on the cell cycle, DNA repair, transposable elements, and genomics), unlike MBoC which spends more or less the first half of the book on those topics and then devotes the second half to the further biology of the Cell, covering things like membranes, energy conversion, cell signalling, cancer, and the immune system.Both books do a good job of introducing the Biochemistry you need in order to understand what follows. MB has a great first chapter that gives an overview of the book (basically "Molecular Biology in 30 pages").Where MB shines though is in its more in-depth coverage of the topics it touches on. It devotes about twice as many pages to these topics as the current edition of MBoC does. MB is also wonderfully illustrated and does a good job of visually explaining things. MB contains lots of "experimental" panels that talk about how various aspects of the cell were discovered.Both books include chapters on techniques for manipulating the genetic material in cells. I thought the current edition of MBoC felt slightly more up to date, but both books are very current editions with a good overview of the current state of the art.Both books are quite readable. I would give the edge to MBoC here in terms of ease of reading as MB seems just a bit denser to me. But both are very easily understandable.I can highly recommend this book (MB) to anyone looking for an in-depth coverage of the central themes of molecular biology (how DNA and genes work). It goes pretty deep for a first course, but it does not presume much of any background knowledge so it would be an appropriate book to introduce someone to the subject who wants to understand things very thoroughly.If I had to choose only one or the other I'd still prefer the new MBoC edition due to its much broader coverage of cell biology (it's also 50% larger and twice as expensive though), but this one is really excellent at what it covers. I bought it after previewing the "Look Inside" pages and I have not been disappointed.If the mechanics of the functioning of cells interests you then you'll probably be fascinated and really enjoy the depth of knowledge you gain from this book, and it's something you'll want to keep and probably use frequently as a reference if you progress further in the study of biology. If you find the details tedious, then this one might be more depth than you want, and something like Essential Cell Biology, 4th Edition might serve you better.Currently this book is not available as a Kindle "Print Replica" e-textbook yet, where the other titles mentioned here are.Really happy with the book, easily a 5+ star experience.G.

The salad spinner works well and is not fussy about the lid mating with the basket, etc. There's a brake button to slow the rotation to a stop after spinning. The outer rim of the base has a rubber ring that helps keep it in place on the counter when in use. It works but could be a little grippier than it is.Once spun, you can take the spinner top off, take out the basket of greens, wipe out the bowl, dump the greens into the bowl, and then attach the mandolin lid and use it to add sliced and grated ingredients to complete a salad. The mandolin holder/handle/safetyguard has four prongs to hold the thing you're slicing/grating, but it only pushes down to the last 1/4-1/3" or so (resist the temptation to run the last couple slices across the mandolin blade without using the handle!). There are three interchangeable blades for the mandolin. A regular sharp mandolin slicing blade, and a medium and small grater attachment.
