The lid also has a course grater/grinding surface as well that's separate from the mandolin itself. the interchangeable blades are nice, and it allows you to store the sharp blade where fingers won't get to it accidentally (the two blades not in use go into slots behind the slot for the active one).Once you're done you can server the salad in the bowl, and there's a plain lid for the bowl to save the leftovers for later. It all sounded a bit gimmicky at first, but it all actually works pretty well and clean-up isn't too bad. Recommended.G.

I remember back in 1996 or so when Java was new and people had been talking about it for a while but I had yet to put my hands on it. That all changed because of two things. The first was the release of Symantec's Visual Cafe, a $99 Java IDE for Windows that was just incredible, and the publication of the first edition of Java in a Nutshell by David Flanagan. While much of that book was also spent trying to document the (then manageable) Java API, the magic of the book was in its concise description of the Java language and the programming examples in subsequent chapters.Over the years I've bought each edition of the book, but I've always looked forward more to the language description and examples in order to get up to speed with new features than to the quick-reference material, especially as the volume required to cover things even at a high level became unmanageable. So I for one am happy to see them jettison the mostly useless API reference section of the book.Now nearly ten years (seems hard to believe!) after the last edition of the book David Flanagan has apparently moved on, but new author Ben Evans has done a good job carrying forward the legacy and holds true to the spirit of the original.The book is written for Java 8. There's no separate "What's new in Java 8" section, so those looking for that specifically might be better off looking elsewhere. But for a new Java programmer or someone wanting an up-to-date introduction to the language, this book remains an excellent choice.I would have no hesitation in pointing someone to this book as an excellent way to get started learning the Java language or to keep for the working Java programmer as the authors describe it, "sitting faithfully by your keyboard as you program".G.

For my door the only issues I had were that the door did not have the recessed in-cut for the bolt plate (requiring chiseling out the door frame to make it deep enough to fit well) and the new frame-side strike plate also needed a small bit of frame chiseled away, and mounting it was tricky as the old screw holes were just a bit off from where the new plate wanted to be, requiring filling the old holes and then drilling new ones. Neither of these issues reflect badly on this lock set of course.Installation is otherwise quick and straightforward, and everything needed was included (9v battery for example).You can program in quite a few additional lock codes, which makes it convenient to grant temporary access to a new user and then later be able to revoke that access without everyone else having to learn new codes. There's no key (which might be considered a plus) and if you find yourself locked out with a dead battery then there are a couple metal studs on the outside that you can touch a 9v battery to in order to power-up the lock so you can enter your code and get in.The lock/unlock thumb-turn on the inside is actually just connected to a microswitch that connects into the lock electronics. However the inside lever will always open the door, even if the thumb-turn is in the locked position (and opening the door in this way does not change the position of the thumb-turn, i.e. if the door was locked it will remain locked after you exit).The lighted keypad is a nice touch, but there's essentially no tactile feedback from the keypad so opening the lock in poor visibility or with gloves can be a bit tricky. Not a good choice for someone with poor vision I think.There's no access log or other way to communicate with the lock.The electronics are all in the outside half of the mechanism, though the battery goes in the inside half. There's a wiring harness that connects the power and thumb-turn state through the door.The body of the lock is fairly thick, around 7/8 of an inch on the outside, so the door handle will probably protrude more than a simple key lock set would, which you should keep in mind if you have a screen or other door outside the one you install the lock on to make sure there's enough clearance.Overall the look and feel is really nice, and the mechanism feels good when it operates. My only complaints are that the 9v battery backup access mechanism is a bit weird (potentially having to drive to a store and buy a replacement battery before you can get in) but perhaps better than always needing to carry a key as a backup, and the lack of tactile feedback on the buttons could be improved on I think. So 4.5 stars rounding down to 4.G.

This is the "Problems Book" that goes with the sixth edition of Molecular Biology of the Cell. Doesn't sound all that exciting does it? But actually the problems book is just as fascinating and informative as the textbook it's a companion for. And there have been enormous improvements over the previous (fifth) edition here too. I've been working my way through the new edition of MBoC and loving it, and just got around to taking a look at this new problems book and WOW.The problems typically start out with an interesting fact and then ask you a question about it that will require some creative thought. The background information provided for each question is often fascinating and goes into all sorts of areas with detail that there isn't room for in the main textbook. Here's an example question from p.6:"1-45: Giardiasis is an acute form of gastroenteritis caused by the protozoan parasite Giardia lambila. Giardia is a fascinating eukaryote; it contains a nucleus but no mitochondria and no recognizable endoplasmic reticulum or Golgi apparatus--one of the very rare examples of such a cellular organization among eukaryotes. This organization might have arisen because Giardia is an ancient lineage that separated from the rest of eukaryotes before mitochondria were acquired and internal membranes were developed. Or it might be a stripped-down version of a more standard eukaryote that has lost these structures because they are not necessary in the parasitic lifestyle it has adopted. How might you use nucleotide sequence comparisons to distinguish between these alternatives?"In the previous fifth edition, a CD-ROM was provided with the book that included PDF chapters of the answers for each problem chapter in the book. This was inconvenient at best. But now for the sixth edition all the problems AND all the answers are printed in the book. You get over 400 pages of problems followed by another 400+ pages of answers, so you can read and think about a problem and then flip to the answer to read their explanation. This gives the printed version of the book a significant advantage over the Kindle version in my option, since it's much easier to flip back and forth in a physical book than it is in the Kindle reader app (if only they could provide active links between the questions and answers...)The answers are as extensive as the questions, and provide lots of additional interesting information, history, etc. The answer to question 1-45 above takes up half a page and includes a paper reference.There are several styles of problem. Each section contains one ore more of the following: basic vocabulary (match the term to its definition), True/False questions, Thought Problems (as the example above, and there are lots of these), Calculations that ask you to figure out some (usually fairly simple) quantitative value to illustrate some fact about the spatial or temporal world of the cell, Data Handling questions that present information in terms of experiments and then ask related questions, Medical Links questions that connect the basic science more to human clinical practice, and new MCAT style questions that consist of a passage of text followed by questions.There are plenty of illustrations and diagrams, some repeated from the textbook and others original, in both the problems and answers sections.The book is now printed in color and this greatly improves the usability of the book and its figures, and it substantially improves the look and feel of the book overall.If you want to see more before you decide to buy you can get the first 47 pages or so via the Kindle Preview option if you have a tablet or PC/Mac Kindle reader app. The answers are all in the second half of the book so the preview will just show you more questions as well as the front-matter of the book. The Kindle version is a "Print Replica" so it's an exact reproduction of the physical book (like a PDF).Besides the Problem Book's own questions and answers, it also includes answers to all the end of chapter questions from the main textbook.This book is as much a source of new knowledge as it is a way to test your knowledge of the subject matter in the textbook. You can think of it as another nearly 1,000 pages of fascinating molecular biology presented in a Socratic style. Like the textbook itself it's extremely well written and very approachable, and is one of those rare "wow" book experiences.It's great if you want to learn and think more about cell biology (and life in general), as well as its applications to human health, and even if you've just been assigned this as an additional book for a class using the main textbook then I think you'll really enjoy it.G.

These are very good functional headphones that also work great out of the box (driverless) in Windows 8.1, which lets you have one pair of headphones that you can use on both platforms.Battery life is good (they claim 10 hours and a micro-USB charging cable included), audio is good as well as voice quality through the extendable mic.Operation is relatively simple without a zillion controls. Power is switched on and off by holding down the center of the back of the left ear cup. This button also serves as a mute switch and there's a red/blue LED in the mic to indicate when you've muted it, though even with the mic extended it's pretty near the edge of your visual field. Pressing the button while wearing the headphones produces a loud physical button pop which is annoying. If you make frequent use of the mute function then honestly I'd recommend you look for a different headset.Volume is a simple old-fashioned knob at the back of the left ear. A Mode button is the only other user-interface control and it switches between two modes. There is a line-in jack for connecting directly to an audio source so you can use it as a wired headset as well.The USB transceiver module is pretty long so you would probably not want to use it with a laptop.The blue lighting is at least a good reminder that you've left them turned on. Otherwise they probably mostly serve to reduce battery life. If you like the look then they look great.Overall they're simple and work well and are more flexible than average in terms of supporting connectivity to multiple gaming and audio platforms. They're in the medium to heavy range for height of headphones, though we've worn them for extended periods without excessive fatigue. I don't really find them to be awesome in any particular way and they're not the cheapest option in this functionality range, but they have held up under heavy use for the last 30 days with no problems at all.G.

This review is based (mostly, see update at the end) on the Kindle edition of the book, which is a "Print Replica" edition which exactly matches the printed textbook (it's essentially like a PDF of the entire book). For textbooks, even the most valuable (like this one) that I love and plan to keep for a long time, I now much prefer electronic versions for many reasons, not the least of which is that it's easier to hold up and read a tablet than a seven pound tome. You can also zoom in on text and figures as needed, and the illustrations are almost all in "vector" form meaning they stay sharp and detailed as you zoom in. You can also search the complete text of the book, do electronic underlining, set bookmarks, etc.Yes, the Kindle textbooks have DRM that restricts what you can do with it, but I find the Kindle restrictions less onerous than many, and in most cases they give you an option to "rent" textbooks for the duration of a class which might be as economic as buying a physical copy and then reselling it when you're done with it. But if you want complete freedom to resell what you buy, or maybe you just like the feeling of holding a real book in your hands, then the printed copy would probably be what you want. Note that I believe the physical version comes with a disc containing the movies and supplemental materials for the book (turns out it doesn't, see update below), but you can also find all of this free on the Garland Science web site if you buy an e-book version.So with that out of the way let's talk about the book! There are basically two groups of people who are likely reading this. Either you've had this book assigned as the textbook for a class or you haven't. If this has been assigned as a textbook, first make sure you're looking at the correct edition. This sixth edition is very different from the fifth (the authors point out that five million scientific papers were written since the previous edition) and you might *not* get away with buying a cheaper used previous edition. If your class is going into enough depth that it needs this book over something like Essential Cell Biology, 4th Edition then chances are you really do need the correct edition. Also the sixth edition is brand new as of this writing, so make sure you're not being asked to get the previous (fifth) edition!This is one of my favorite textbooks of all time. A really good textbook is designed to prepare students to be practitioners in a field, not just to try to keep bored students awake and hold their hands through a class they really wish they didn't have to take. This is a great textbook and it's THE book to get if you want to learn as much about cell biology as is possible from one volume. It's also now entirely fresh and up to date (as of 2014), something absolutely critical in a field like Biology which advances daily. Everything in here is fascinating. If you think this stuff is boring then I feel sorry for you :) Life is cells, and this is "everything we know about how cells work" so it's directly applicable to an understanding of every (known) form of life, from bacteria to you and me. Even if your class doesn't go down into the depths and fine details, this is a great book to have for later self-study if this stuff interests you. This can be a textbook you keep for years and refer to frequently.This is also a surprisingly accessible work for those interested in learning about modern Biology on their own. If you're someone who is scientifically minded and wants to understand how life works, then most of what's in here is easily comprehensible and highly enjoyable. Unlike many fields, there aren't years of prerequisites needed to start the study of cutting-edge Biology. If this were Physics, you would need to have had ten years of math and boring low-level physics before you could ever hope to begin to understand things like quantum mechanics or the general theory of relativity. But there's no math requirement for understanding Biology (though it's starting to become more quantitative and newer fields like Physical Biology are growing rapidly). A little knowledge of concepts from Chemistry is helpful, but again very little of the discussion in this book is quantitative so there's generally nothing to calculate, no equations to solve, etc. Cell Biology is much closer to something like computer programming in terms of the mental aptitude needed to understand it. To get started I recommend reading chapter 1 thoroughly, then read chapter 2 but if your eyes start to glaze over then just skip the rest of chapter 2 for now (the chemistry, while obviously fundamental and critically important is not necessary to understand deeply in order to understand the rest of the book, just as you don't really need to understand voltages and transistors in order to learn to program a computer), and then read Chapter 3 thoroughly which is all about how proteins perform most of the work in the cell including acting as microprocessors, motors, pumps, etc. By that point you'll likely be hooked and you can go back and appreciate the rest of chapter 2 when you're ready for it.So how does this Sixth edition compare too the Fifth? Well, first of all it has been seven years since the previous edition, which is nearly forever in the world of Biology, so just on that basis alone the new edition is going to be a big advance. In general the fundamentals are the same, but the fine details of understanding have advanced a great deal.An ongoing problem for the authors is the incredible volume of knowledge that exists and the near infinite and subtle complexity of even the simplest cells. This means the book could easily be three times its current size, a pressure which the authors must find a way to resist if the book is to remain portable and affordable. In the fifth edition, the book exploded past its covers and the standard edition was forced to relegate the last five chapters to PDF supplements (a huge Reference Edition with over 1600 pages was available with all chapters printed, and the e-book versions include all chapters). This was not a popular decision as it meant that even after buying and lugging around a big expensive tome, you still didn't even have all the content printed.The sixth edition now includes the entire content of the book, and there's no need for a "Reference" edition. This means however that even though the printed book has gotten slightly longer, they have had to shorten the effective size by about 250 pages! This has resulted in a lot of editing and a reduction in the number of figures. In some cases this means more effective and concise content, but in other places interesting material and in-depth discussion has been eliminated. Taking as an example chapter 4, Control of Gene Expression, the current edition has 79 figures where the previous edition had 115. Also the chapter on Sexual Reproduction has been eliminated entirely (you can download the fifth edition version of this chapter as a PDF, see the update below) though some of its material has been integrated into other parts of the book.I cannot help but wonder if the authors have really made the right decision here. Choosing to reduce the (effective) size of the book by around 15% at a time when knowledge in the field is growing so rapidly seems rather limiting. I would personally have rather seen them embrace the idea that many of their readers will be using e-books where the length has no physical effect, or even consider breaking the book into two volumes as is often done in fields like the study of medicine. But in the end this is still intended to be a textbook, and many students will likely appreciate anything that reduces the number of pages they have to read :)A lot of work has been done to clean up the design, and they have re-created many illustrations in a more consistent style. This edition uses a pleasant blue theme in comparison to the reddish-pink of the fifth edition. It has a cleaner look overall, and I think the changes in title/heading color are a definite improvement for on-screen reading. There are a few places where figures include small areas of white-on-lime-green text that I have to zoom in on to read, but generally the changes are improvements.The content in general has been brought up to date with many sections extensively updated or re-written. Interestingly, as a sign that classic quantitative methods from Physics are starting to creep further into Biology, there's an extended section in chapter 8, Mathematical Analysis of Cell Functions, which gives some mathematical (ZOMG! some math in a Biology book!) treatment to things like gene product equilibrium and gene regulation and serves as a good introduction to the field of Physical Biology, which is another interesting way of approaching the study of life (if you find this interesting then I can also recommend Physical Biology of the Cell which I bought and have been enjoying).Anyhow, MBoC gets all the stars as being one of those magical books that takes you deep into a whole new and fascinating world, one where you'll learn how each individual cell in your body has much more in common with a modern supercomputer than it does with that soggy old frog you dissected in high-school. The practice of modern cell biology is nothing less than hacking into alien computer systems (not designed by the mind of man) looking for technology we can appropriate or adapt to cure disease, reduce world hunger, produce clean cheap energy, and otherwise improve our lives.An exciting book for exciting times.G.Update: I've now purchased a copy of the physical book as well, just because I like it so much. It's a six pound, 13 ounce tome that's two inches thick. It's hardbound, and has the same feel and quality as the Reference edition version of the fifth edition. Paper quality (thickness, brightness) are again similar to the fifth edition. It's definitely not as lap-crushing as the old Reference edition (that extra pound or so makes a big difference).The physical book does NOT come with CD media for the supplemental movies and stuff, so you need to go to the Garland Science site to find them (under the Student tab you can search for the movie numbers from the book without needing to create an account, or you can create an account and add the book to it to make accessing things a little easier). The GS site still seems to be rolling out information on the new edition so at some point they may have a page/site dedicated to the book as they have for some other recent textbooks. They have also now added a downloadable PDF of "MBOC, Fifth Edition - Chapter 21: Sexual Reproduction: Meiosis, Germ Cells, and Fertilization" in the sixth edition downloads area. This chapter got eliminated from the sixth edition (the meiosis section in the Cell Cycle chapter was extended a bit to compensate) so this is a useful reference to have.Update 2: I just picked up the new version of Molecular Biology of the Cell 6E - The Problems Book and it's got many VERY nice improvements over its previous version. It should really be considered "part two" of the textbook. There's a huge amount of additional knowledge in here and it's great to just read, not just as a workbook. Go check it out.

The GT1 is a 440-470MHz FM transceiver. It's about the size of a typical FRS/GMRS radio. Small, but not tiny. The hardware feels great and looks good the radio has a very clean design and seems very well constructed. It comes with a drop-in desk charger, a single mono ear-piece with a Mic and PTT blob on the cord, a screw-attached belt clip (plastic clip but the attachment plate is metal as are the screw holes on the radio, so it seems very secure), hand strap, rechargeable battery, and a "manual" in a nice box well packaged. It uses two (three contact I presume) jacks for Mic and Speaker (and programming).So, this is a  Bofung, ok "pofung" (Bofung seems to be changing their branding) radio. That means of course that the manual is relatively worthless so expect to be on your own to google up what you need to know to use this radio. Actually the manual isn't as terrible as it could be, and manages to cover some of the operaiton of the radio at least.There is no display. You get a green/red RX/TX indicator, a white LED operated by the button below the "MON" function button which acts as a flashlight (on) or repeating S-O-S Morse code blinker, MONItor (bypass squelch) button, PTT button (hard plastic, short throw, positive click, feels pretty good), power/volume knob, and a 16-position rotary channel selector knob (which stops at each end of its travel so you can tune by counting clicks if you need to). There's a recorded voice that tells you "power on" when you turn it on and will speak a number from 1 to 16 when you change the channel knob. The channel number is spoken only when you settle on a channel, so going from 1 to 16 does not speak all the numbers in-between unless you pause at each one.If there's no channel activity then there's absolutely no way to tell if the radio is on or off without pressing MONI or wiggling the volume knob or something. Easy to forget to turn it off. There's supposed to be a low-battery alert tone and blinking TX indicator but I haven't experienced it yet.Unfortunately (and why I can't give the radio more than two stars) the radio is mostly unusable out of the box because you have no way to program it. You will need to obtain the proper programming cable and software (no indication of which is the correct cable in the manual or where to get the software). Of course if you know anything about baofeng radios you probably already know you're going to need the two-prong to USB cable (in a form actually supported by the operating system you're using which seems to be a tricky issue at the moment) and you'll want the free CHIRP radio programming software, because everyone says the baofeng software is rubbish. Unfortunately as of this writing, the radio is so new that CHIRP does not list it s a supported radio, and neither does the official baofeng software web page as far as I can tell. This is likely to change before too long, but today you may be out of luck accessing any advanced feature of the radio like, oh, I don't know, actually tuning it to a frequency of your choice.The radio apparently comes programmed with 16 frequencies in its 16 channels. What are they? Your guess is as good as mine, since the manual doesn't tell you. (Could they be set to US (or Chinese?) FRS/GMRS frequencies maybe?) Since the frequency coverage is so broad, chances are that some of the channels might be outside the US ham bands, and if so there's pretty much no way to use the radio out-of-the-box without breaking US federal law. Even inside the ham bands, it's probably not legal to transmit if you have no idea what frequency you're on (hardly can be said to be in "control" of your station). So if you want to buy a couple of these and use them as walkie-talkies and don't mind the use probably being illegal then they would probably work for that purpose, but you might find you're transmitting on a local emergency service (Fire, Police, etc.) channel and they might not take kindly to that. In addition, the FCC is an agency with little sense of humor and they issue fines in multiples of $10,000, so you really don't want them mad at you.So for many users there's just no way I can recommend this thing. However, if you're a licensed ham, and you don't mind waiting for programming software and the need for a separate cable (that might cost as much as the radio lol) then OMG! It's LIKE $20! They're practically disposable! And once you get over those hurdles you might love the thing.As soon as I get hold of software that can program the thing, I'll be back to update with some actual performance experiences. Until then, two stars, the second only because the quality seems really impressive for the price.Most users would probably be much better off spending the extra $10 to get one of the models with a display/keypad where you at least have some hope of being able to use it without needing additional hardware and software, like the Baofung UV5-RE for example.Update: I found my channel 4 is the output of a taxi dispatch repeater or something similar (GMRS conceivably?), so I can give some reception information. The signal from this repeater is good, though it's not enough to break the squelch of the radio so I have to hold down the monitor button to hear anything. The Red/Green TX/RX led however will glow in proportion to the received signal even when the squelch is closed which is nice. IF you have the monitor button pressed, then channel changes don't take effect until you let go of the monitor button (at which point the radio will speak the new channel number. This is annoying because you can't just hold down the monitor button and click through the channels to manually "scan" them. You have to go one at a time, let go, wait for the voice, etc.Audio is good and quite loud through the built-in speaker. Even at its minimum level, the volume is sufficient for listening in a quiet room.Some notes on charging: The drop-in charger has guides that need to line up with and mesh (which they don't always do) with the battery (which allows you to charge the battery either on or off the radio which is nice). There is a green LED on the charging base that turns red when charging and turns off after three hours of charging. The radio itself has no indication (and probably no idea) of charging. The charger is labeled Input: DC 10V, Output DC 8.4V 500ma. The actual input is 120V AC line via a captive cord with an non-polarized plug. There is no (correct) indication of what the actual input voltage range is, and there are no UL or CE registration/certification marks on the charger (you might not be able to take it into the EU with you when traveling if customs should notice, but it might not work on 220V anyway).There turn out to be a few radio functions you can configure via tuning to a particular channel, holding down MONI and PTT, and turning the radio on. The ones documented in the manual are 1-5,10,11,15 and 16, but some others appear to do *something*:1-5: VOX operation speaks "vox on" or "vox off" alternately (number = VOX gain sensitivity? (guess)) default=off6: no apparent effect7: no apparent effect8: Toggles unknown option, speaks "on" or "off" (default = off)9: Toggles unknown option, speaks "on" or "off" (default = off)10: Toggle voice prompts on/off (default=on)11: Toggle "Emergency Alarm" feature on/off (receipt of signal from compatible radio triggers alarm? (guess))12: No voice prompt when activated, power on beep, then TX/RX light turns and stays red (possibly transmitting?), no controls have any effect. Powering off returns to normal. Test mode? Baby monitor mode?13: no apparent effect14: no apparent effect15: Change voice prompt language (toggles between English (default) and Chinese)16: turn SCAN on and off.G.

This is good as a "missing manual" kind of book. If you're the sort of person who misses the days when software came with a big printed book that basically listed all of the features of the program and what each option did, then you will love this book.If you're looking for a book that will teach you how to be creative and how to become good at things like retouching photos, then not so much. There's very little creative advice in here. If you know you want to select an area of an image for some reason then this book shows you the tools and options to do that, but it never tells you why you'd want to be doing that selection in the first place.There are a few short sections that lean more towards creative issues, like Chapter 17: Ten tips for Composing Better Photos, but this is simply five pages of really basic photography advice like "use the rule of thirds" and it's not even about Photoshop Elements at all.As Dummies books go, it's nicer than average being printed in full color, about an inch thick (~425 pages).As a manual replacement it's probably worth four stars, but not many people these days want to sit down and read a user's guide from  cover to cover. As a "How To" book, I would only give it one or two stars, and if you want a book that will really teach you WHAT to do and WHY you're doing it rather than just HOW, then I think you can do a lot better. So I'll split the difference and give it three stars here.G.

These are very hard and dense and the dog (who normally demolishes every other form of dog treat in about three seconds) has to really work at them for a while. He'll run downstairs with it so you can't watch him struggle with them.They claim that if you give one of these to your dog each day it's the same as brushing his teeth twice a week (at the same time they tell you that veterinarians recommend daily brushing). I really don't have enough experience yet to say whether this is the case, but based on the effort the dog goes through in breaking them up I could believe it, and I'm tempted to get a couple boxes and see what the vet says after a month or two.While various product literature suggests the existence of a "large" size of these, only "mini" and "small/medium" appear to exist currently. These are so hard and dense that I wonder if when scaled up to large they would be just too hard for all but the most powerful dogs. The mini size is recommended for dogs 5-34 pounds.Because of how hard they are, I would hesitate to offer these to any dog who already has dental issues, as I would be afraid they might be too painful to chew.But these are the first "dental" dog treat I've seen that really seem like they might accomplish something.Four stars for now and I'll update if we get more experience with them.G.
They feel the way you'd probably imagine. Definitely more like briefs than boxers though. I found the long legs made them a lot warmer than regular briefs and were too warm to sleep in.G.

If you want to know about birds then this is THE book. I've never seen anything like it. If you're a bird fan then just stop reading and buy it, seriously.There are two approximately equal parts to the book. the first consists of nine chapters that tell you pretty much everything you could ever want to know about birds in general, starting with their origins and evolution, 64 pages on anatomy and physiology, flight, food and feeding, bird society and populations, breeding, where do birds live, migrations, and birds and humans.These chapter s go very deep into details and reading through them has answered pretty much everything I ever wondered about things like bird migration, how they survive in winter, and all aspects of behavior. All the little questions that other books never quite went into enough detail to answer. The book is easily worth its price just for this part of the book alone, and is pretty much the ultimate single reference work. I don't know how you could pack any more information into the same space, and it's a LOT of space.The second half of the book is a catalog of all the bird families, and for each family there is a really impressive amount of detail describing the behaviors and other attributes that make that family of birds unique and interesting.Most bird books and field guides are disappointing in that they try to catalog by species since the user will see a bird and want to look it up and read about it. The problem is that there are so many different bird species that even covering just the common or local ones in a reasonable amount of space means room for only a sentence or two about what makes this species different. So you have a big book and look up a bird and you end up with an unsatisfying amount of information. This book however has both the space (318 big pages) and by documenting at the family level you get a page or more (five pages and five pictures for "Hawks, Eagles, and relatives" for example) of detailed interesting information that's applicable to any member of the family.There is both a subject index and a bird families and names index that lets you look up birds by common name and scientific name for the individual species mentioned in the book.The author's English has a Welsh and English bent and occasionally uses analogies or comparisons to common British things that may be unfamiliar to those who are not from there. Overall the book is very readable, especially the first chapters about birds in general. In the detailed by-family part of the book the scientific names of all the bird species can sometimes get a bit overwhelming. This is a serious work though one that's highly accessible.The book is well illustrated with many good explanatory photos and diagrams in the general chapters. In the catalog of bird families there are one or two pictures per page showing example species, but the real value in the book is in the information presented in the text. This is neither a field guide nor an identification guide for individual species.If you were building a personal science library and wanted to have one volume on birds, then this would be the one to get, even though it's not a field guide and probably won't have pictures or information on every individual species you'll observe in your area. It will however tell you more than you could ever want to know about birds in general, and for any bird species it will tell you a huge amount about the behavior common to members of that bird family.Highest recommendation.G.

First of all, from the picture shown for this item (and even most of the pictures on the actual box), you might think you're getting some sort of Siamese-twin-duo-blender-appliance that has a dual base and can blend two things at once. But that's not the case as this is just a regular single blender that looks like one half of the picture. This is honestly pretty misleading and they need to have something to illustrate that what they're showing you in the picture is two views of the one device and not a multi-headed monstrosity. [Update: At least online here they seem to have gotten rid of the confusing pictures so yay]What you do get is a nice heavy-duty blender with a base that connects differently to two types of container. On the top of the base there are two concentric rings that connect to the containers. The outer lower-speed ring which the regular pitcher connects to, and an inner higher speed (5x faster it looks like) disc that mates with the "cup" style containers. The unit recognizes which type of container is mounted and enables only those programs (speed and duration) that it considers appropriate.You get the big standard-blender-shaped pitcher, and a 24-ounce and a 32-ounce bullet-shaped "cup". Everything is heavy duty, BPA-free plastic and it all feels good in the hand. You get one set of blades for the two cups, but you get two nice big screw-in caps for them that turn them into something like a spill-proof coffee container that you can pour out of and close.The blades for the cups look exactly like what you expect to see at the bottom of a blender, and when using the cups the system operates most like what you would expect in comparison to a standard (cheap) blender. In fact in the cookbook that it comes with, the 24-ounce cup is used for the vast majority of the recipes. The only real down-side to the cups is that they're small compared to the pitcher and you have to take them off and unscrew the blades to add or remove anything since the other end is sealed. Their size is good for one-two servings of juice.The pitcher is big (72oz+ though they tell you not to exceed 64oz for liquids) and has a somewhat unusual blade assembly which consists of a thick shaft the full height of the pitcher. It sits loosely on a hexagonal shaft that connects to the motor through the base, and the top tip goes into a depression on the base of the lid. Along the lower 50-60% of the shaft are three pairs of food-processor-style blades. You must have the lid on the pitcher in order to operate it, and you can either use its pour spout or you can take the lid off, at which point you must remove the blade assembly before pouring.Everything (apart from the motor base of course) is dishwasher-safe (they recommend top shelf for the blades and lids).It comes with a very nice 128-page cookbook of recipes specifically for this model. It give the majority of its coverage to "juicing" style recipes using the 24-ounce cup container. It has a reasonable variety of other recipes (soups, breakfasts, strawberry daiquiri and five other mixed drinks, etc.). All of the soup recipes have you cooling the soup down to room temperature before blending (and possibly re-heating afterwards) so it seems the blender may not tolerate high temperatures, thought the manual does not mention that as far as I've seen. There seem to be a few typos in the cookbook (in one place it calls for an 18oz blender cup for example).There's also a booklet with three-day starter juicing diets (one for men, one for women).The parts all fit together well, and all the parts of the system feel very heavy-duty and robust, though the moving parts deliberately fit together rather loosely. This, along with the 5:1 dual-geared base, make the system a bit louder than a normal blender and definitely nobody will be sleeping while you're mixing drinks :)Overall it's an interesting appliance, but one that's a little bit unsure of what it wants to be. There's a little bit of Juicer and a little bit of Food Processor in there along with a lot of Blender. It tries to be a bit more clever with its pre-programmed "Auto-IQ" timed operation modes than it probably needs to be, and that sometimes feels a bit limiting. It's big for a blender, though about on-par for a high-power juicing blender.There's a one-year warranty (though you pay for shipping both ways if you need warranty service).So, 4-4.5 stars I think, rounding down to four. I will come back and update this review after we get some long-term experience as to how it holds up.G.

I'm going to call this 3.5 stars (rounding up to 4). It does pretty well what it claims to, and if the idea of a less relaxed more frenetic version of Pictionary appeals to you and your family/group then by all means give it a try.Requires three AA batteries (and a philips screwdriver) not included. Has a physical on/off switch for when you finally want it to shut up :)It only includes 72 cards, but they have 7 clues on each side so just over 1,000 available clues which seems like plenty. There's no separate kids set of clues as in the current incarnation of the regular version of the game.The timer gadget thingy works fine. It's similar to what a chess clock would be if chess were a FOX sitcom with a laugh-track.It's OMG loud though, even on "low" volume (there are two levels selectable while pressing either of the buttons after the pause button is pressed). After a few minutes I taped a 1" square piece of thin cardboard over the speaker which made a world of difference.You get to select how much time each team gets for the complete game (5 minutes is the default) and the teams take turns drawing and solving clues (you really want 4+ people to play Pictionary). The first round and randomly thereafter are "all play" rounds where both teams play at once and the timers do not count down. This means a total game will last significantly more than the 5-10 minutes you'd expect from the default 5m per team setting.I think they missed out on opportunities with this. It would not have been hard to add a few more game modes, etc.The buttons are large and brightly lit, and the game announces via voice who is playing that round (also indicated by which button(s) light up), gives you a ten second warning at the end of the time for a round or the last ten seconds in the game. The first team to run out of time loses.The manual is skimpy so it doesn't hurt it you've played the regular game before.G.

These appear to be high-quality dog treats. Dick Van Patten is the sort of guy I'm sure would only lend his name to a high quality product.Our one year old lab loves them (but then he loves everything). In a sniff test between these and his favorite bulk Costco dog biscuits (which he will happily sell his freedom for when it's time for a nap in his crate) he seemed more interested in the duck jerky than the Costo biscuit.The idea of "jerky" though suggests something that will require some effort to finish chewing, but he is able to pretty much gulp them down in about half the time it takes to say "Dick Van Patten's Natural Balance Immunity Support Duck Jerky" so they're no good for occupying his time. Probably a (very) small dog would have more fun with them.His regular food is supposedly complete and balanced, so I doubt that he is deficient in vitamins C and E and I really don't think it likely that a little more is going to do much for him. In fact in recent human studies people who regularly took supplemental C and E died EARLIER than people who didn't, so once again our assumption that some part of biology is simple and straightforward turns out to be suspect.I'm not sure where the idea that vitamin C supplements are good for dogs comes from. Humans need vitamin C in out diets because our bodies (unlike most mammals) lost the ability to synthesize vitamin C at some point in the past so we get scurvy if we don't get enough. Dogs however can synthesize their own vitamin C just fine, and if you look at the ingredients of your regular dog food you may find vitamin E there, but they probably aren't adding any vitamin C since your dog is his own little vitamin C factory.So, great quality, trusted brand, dog likes them, possibly questionable health benefits, but if you're looking for a treat you can feel good about giving to your dog then these are great.G.

This is a very cool toy for younger kids. It comes with batteries (3xAAA) installed (you'll need a philips screwdriver when/if you ever want to change them) and has (thank god) an OFF switch as well as two levels of volume.There are a total of seven interactable components, and there's a light that illuminates both the lamp on the front and the headlight on the tractor on the right side.Every interaction with one of the controls elicits a response, and the package claims "50+ fun & learning responses" that it will cycle through.The interactions include:Pushing the blue button on the top flips the cow on the front down to reveal an owl (you could hide a small item inside there).The switch on the front will turn the light on and say "ON" and will say "OFF" when you turn the light off.The door on the front triggers a response both when you open and when you close it.On the right side is a key that rotates 90 degrees to and plays an engine start sound.On the back is a rabbit slider that can be moved back and forth and plays a response each time it moves.On the left side is a spider slider and a large pony/kitty/duck button.So there's a lot of interaction here to keep the attention of a 6-36 month old (probably with the emphasis on the earlier part of that range), while driving the parents crazy listening to the sounds over and over :)The box makes a lot of claims about its educational value for things like "learn the names of farm animals and the sounds they make" but honestly in most cases two or three animals are shown together so if you don't already know that it's the dog that barks and the pig that oinks, you might get a little confused.It seems sell and safely constructed and should stand up to a lot of abuse (apart from immersing it in water say).Good stuff. 4.5 stars.G.

You're going to need a bigger boat... Oh, wait this IS a bigger boat! It's about 21 inches long and 17 inches tall once assembled. That makes it pretty big for a bathtub toy, but it will be great in the pool as well. Its broad beam means it's pretty stable in the water.The interior space of the model appears to be filled with Styrofoam, so it won't fill up with water and/or sink. It's well designed for real water play. You may not be able to actually fly a Playmobil aircraft, but this boat can be put to real use.Design and construction are first rate as you'd expect from Playmobil. Assembly is pretty easy with the visual manual. It's not quire as foolproof as a Lego manual, but still you'll have no trouble getting it together properly (takes about 10 minutes) and figuring out where the stickers go, etc.Comes with three pirate figures, two functional cannons, a treasure chest, and an assortment of pirate swords, gold doubloons, and a few other miscellaneous play pieces. The only thing missing is a parrot.Very cool toy.G.

This review is of the device connected to an iPhone 5 running iOS 7.1.2.Packaging of the device and its construction are up to "Apple" levels of quality and design. They're trying to emulate Apple ("Designed by Marley in Michigan, Made in China") and the packaging has the same kind of presentation and layering that you would expect from an iPhone or similar Apple device.The speaker itself is solid and heavy. The front consists of a metal grille with holes cut in it, and a double layer of speaker cloth  behind that. There are four "high-output long-throw 2-inch woofers" and a microphone (somewhere) for use as a hands-free speakerphone. There's a wood panel on the back with "M A R L E Y" laser engraved into it. At either end of that are rubber flaps that fold down to expose an 1/8" stereo input jack and a micro USB input for charging. The USB input has a small red LED to indicate charging that goes out when it's fully charged (took aboutfour hours fresh out of the box). As far as I know the USB is power-only and the device does not show up on the USB bus when connected to a computer. It is labeled as 5.0V DC 2.0A, suggesting it might make use of high-power USB ports, but I haven't been able to confirm that yet.It comes with a 3' USB A to micro-USB cable for charging. That and the warranty info and manual are the only other things in the box. The manual is 84 pages long, though only four are in English, and two of those are safety and recycling info.The user interface consists of four buttons (power, bluetooth, volume up and volume down). The only of these that needs some discussion is the bluetooth button, as not all of its functionality is described in the skimpy documentation. You can press it for three seconds to enter pairing mode. No password is required and the device will only pair with a single device at a time. Each time it powers on it will spend three seconds trying to pair with the device it was most recently connected to. If it can't it will go into aux-in mode (the logo on the lower-right front illuminates red for AUX and blue for bluetooth).While playing audio, you can press the bluetooth button to pause or resume the playback. It turns out you can also use the bluetooth button to answer a phone call and to hangup a call. If you do this, then the call audio will be directed through the speaker and it will use its microphone providing full hands free capability. If you answer a call from the iPhone, then the call can be moved to the speaker (or back to the phone) using the "audio source" button in the iOS phone app.With the volume control on the speaker all the way up, it's proportionally equivalent to the iOS device volume, so it seems like keeping the speaker at full volume and using the phone to control the volume level works the best.So far the iPhone to Liberate bluetooth has been solid, reliably connects when powering on the speaker, has good range etc.One annoyance is that with the speaker connected, all the phone sounds go to it via bluetooth. This means key-clicks and things like the sound the phone makes when you press the top switch to put it to sleep come out of the speaker, and this is especially annoying if you have the volume turned up to the levels needed for reasonable listening. This is probably more a feature of iOS than this particular BT Speaker though. The speaker also has startup, shutdown, and pairing sounds that it makes, so it's not a subtle device :)Also I discovered that it seems to have an auto power-off feature if it doesn't see any activity from the phone for 15 minutes, even if it's plugged into USB power. This means if the phone rings you won't be able to answer it with or through the speaker without powering it on and waiting the approximately 5-6 seconds it takes to power up and connect to the phone. As far as I know, there's no way to adjust or disable the auto power-off.But, you ask, how does it sound? It's fine, and probably pretty good for it's size, but there's nothing about the sound that blows me away. Even up close there's no real feeling of stereo separation (I did verify that left audio comes out of the left and right audio comes out of the right correctly). The experience is basically that of ordinary inexpensive computer speakers placed side by side. Neither the low or high end is anything special, and while it gets pretty loud without distorting, it's really not much of a replacement for a larger boom-box setup. But then it will fit easily into a backpack and can turn a room into a party if you have nothing else available.I watched parts of a few movies with it, and had issues with the dialog volume being too low relative to the music and effects which had me fiddling with the volume a lot. While the experience was much better than using the "speaker" in the phone, it didn't sound  as good as headphones would.As a phone hands-free speakerphone again it works fine, with reasonable microphone pickup but again nothing spectacular.So you're not going to get an audiophile experience with something this small, but the design and construction are very nice, the operation has been smooth and reliable, and for a portable, wireless (or wired via AUX-in), rechargeable speaker it pretty much rocks and I would have no trouble recommending it as a model to consider if you're looking for a small portable BT speaker. It definitely feels like a piece of professional audio gear, all metal, cloth, wood, and some rubber, with no plastic externally visible unlike most of its competition.So somewhere between 3.5 and 4.5 stars I think. I'll come and update this review when my opinion firms up a bit more :)G.

These seem like excellent screen protectors. They go on very easily, and the slightly matte surface seems smoother to the touch than the bare glass screen. The screen definitely reduces glare and reflections off the normally mirror-like iPhone 5 screen.They came in frustration free packaging which is to say a small plain brown cardboard box containing an instruction card with simple visual directions, the four screen protectors each in their own poly bag, and nothing else. No card is included for pushing bubbles out (the instruction card isn't rigid enough really, so have a credit card handy) and there's no polishing cloth included as is with many other protectors. These issues are pretty minor though.Actually each screen protector turned out to be two stuck together, so there were actually eight(!) in the package. I suspect their package stuffing machinery needs a little bit of tuning. So maybe order fast and you'll get lucky like I did :)The protectors come with a protective film on only the adhesive side. The matte top surface is exposed from the beginning (though it's protected in its poly bag). The glossy protectors usually have an extra peel off film on the front as well, but it doesn't seem to be needed here.Their installation technique is to peel off the protective film over the adhesive side of the film, then pinch it slightly and touch the bowed out center line of the protector with the center line of the phone at the camera and home button holes, and this worked very well for the two phones I tested it on. Bubbles were easily coaxed out the edges, and only small particles of contamination resulted in an average of two small bubbles on each phone. I'm not sure what the source of these tiny dust particles was, whether it was something on the protector or (probably more likely) something that landed there between cleaning and applying the protector. When the phone is on they're not very noticeable.They each have five cut-outs, for the home button, speaker, front camera, and one hole next to the camera (proximity sensor?) and next to the speaker (for whatever that thing is there on the iPhone 5S).Comparing two phones side by side, one with the protector and one without, I see pretty much the differences I would expect between a matte and high-gloss LCD display. The protectored phone has much less noticeable reflections and a slightly more diffuse look. I think I like the matte look and feel of this screen protector better than the plain phone, but then I've always preferred matte displays over the mirror polished reflective kind. There will probably be people who would criticize the matte look as "softer", so if you're a fan of shiny displays then maybe you won't like these as much. For me I really like it and will keep it on my phone.I have no trouble recommending these to anyone who would like less glare on their iPhone 5/5s, and I think they enhance the look and feel of the phone over the default unprotected screen.G.

Ok, so, it's a power strip. And an extension cord. This is sort of an odd combo, since the power strip can't be plugged into the extension cord (the extension cord CAN be plugged into the power strip). It's like I would be going to shop for a power strip and then like "dang, I need a cheap extension cord too! This is PERFECT!". Or not so much.Anyhow, the power strip seems sturdy, has a short 3' cord, and a red illuminated switch (with integrated circuit breaker) on the top of the strip (easier to see and access than having it on the end next to the cord). The switch is on a raised part of the case relative to where the outlets are and it's about an inch from the first outlet, so a little bit of protection from turning off the whole strip accidentally when plugging something in. The individual outlets did not require excessive force to plug into (some strips require a lot of force the first time you plug something in) and seem to hold firmly. The bottom includes warnings about indorrs and dry location use only, and a UL listing holographic foil label. It is rated for 15 amps, and 14 gauge heavy-duty cord. Works great, does not take up excessive space. The outlets are all aligned with the ground pin towards the end away from the cord/switch as shown in the picture.The extension cord is a two-wire, polarized, non-grounded cord with three two-prog polarized outlets on the end. It is a 16-gauge wire and 13-amp-rated. It doesn't feel nearly as nice as the power strip. Also, the child-safety covers that you can slide over the outlets that aren't in use really don't work. they don't stay in place and will fall open under only the force of gravity if you hold it sideways.So 4.5 stars for the power strip and 2.5 stars for the extension cord.G.

This book may be to Data Science and Big Data what Freakonomics was to Economics.The author is one of the founders of the dating web site OKCupid and has spent a lot of time sifting through the vast amount of data collected by user interactions with their website and each other, and he uses this wealth of personal and private information to explore what it can tell us about human social behavior.The writing is excellent and it is a very fun read (I was hooked by the second page of the introduction, finished it in a couple sittings, and was never bored).There's lots of information in this book that will make you think, and a lot worth talking about more. I think it's at its best in the first part where the theme is "things that bring us together" and he talks about statistics relating to how people find each other on his dating site. In the second part of the book "what pulls us apart" he deals with issues like race and what his data shows about the prevalence of racism in American society, as well as the internet's capacity for rage. The last part of the book "what makes us who we are" continues with the relationships theme as he investigates a few more racial as well as gay and bi-sexual issues before covering a few miscellaneous topics like comparing the kind of uses of this data he makes and his vision of using it for good compared to things like marketing and government spying.People who consider themselves Data Scientists may be bothered by the fact that he does not go into much formal detail and actually few of his analyses require any fancy math or a PhD in anything.It's a book that I can strongly recommend to anyone, both as a fascinating look into human behavior as well as an introduction to the sort of things that web sites are doing with all that data they collect on you, and as inspiration for those who aspire to the new discipline of Data Science, both in terms of the sort of things you can accomplish as well as some of the moral and ethical issues involved.Probably the most interesting and thought-provoking book I've read in a long time.G.

This is a really neat book if you're interested in becoming an architect or learning more about what architects do. It's most interesting feature is that around half the book consists of Q&A interviews with architects asking about why they got into it, how they decided where to go to school, what they do in their current job, etc.It does a relatively complete job of giving an overview of the stages of an architect's career from education through later professional development.It's written from the pro-architecture viewpoint, and as such is generally positive about the profession. You can see though the interviews that not everyone who enters architecture ends up doing original building design on a day to day basis (in fact very few do) and some end up as "facilities managers" and the like, positions that they might have been able to reach more simply than by taking the route through architecture school.If you're considering architecture, then I think this will be a very useful book. I found it interesting and informative and well written (which one can't say about too many architecture related works from my experience).G.

Our 1yo Lab seemed to enjoy these. "Long lasting" is a relative term with an 80lb dog whose major avocation in life is methodically reducing his world to bite-sized pieces. It takes him maybe 5m to consume one of these. It's pretty clean without too many crumbs etc. No strong scent.So far he seems to enjoy them (the Turkey flavor) and they have not had any obvious negative impact on him.They're pretty small (4 1/2") and only three per package so you'll go through them pretty fast. They're a hard, vaguely rubbery texture and were obviously extruded without any other structure to them. Not terribly "bone" like IMHO.They're fine, but I'm not sure why I would chose these over anything else in the premium dog-treat category.G.

Expensive of course, but if you're reading this it's probably because your organization is relatively large and you've bought into the whole Fluke Networks suite of stuff, and I'm not going to base this review on whether this product makes good economic sense or not.The software works fine as a basic connectivity and mapping tool, especially if you have other Fluke Networks software and tools to share floor plan layouts with etc. But it does not do anything more than super-basic packet capture and honestly you could get most of the same capabilities with free open-source tools or less-expensive (but less name-branded) commercial tools.The big reason for the lack of stars in this review however is the horrible licensing process which makes it feel close to impossible to use the software once you actually have it. Creating web accounts, messing with license files, associating the license with a network adapter, having to wait an extended period for license delivery, multiple contacts with technical support, numerous web searches, etc. before I was even able to run the software for the first time (something like four hours invested just to get the thing working). This left such a bad feeling that I would actively avoid any Fluke software-based solutions in the future, which is a shame as their hardware-based tools are always the best.

I'm using it with a Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro, and this is an excellent dock choice for this model, as the Yoga has USB 3, and seems to make good use of the dock's features under Win 8.1. Great for getting additional USB ports including USB3 when operating in a fixed location with additional outboard USB connected peripherals.The stand is surprisingly heavy and provides a good foundation. The Yoga 2 Pro is very stable in landscape orientations either notebook or tablet style, and can even be used in portrait tablet mode if you're not pushing on the top 1/3 of the screen (which might cause the computer to tip over the top of the stand, but the stand itself is still very stable and won't tip). you can also use the slot in the stand as simply a place to store the computer while charging and get a slight savings in desk-space.I have not yet tested and exercised the mufti-monitor features as much as I would have liked to before having to write this review however, so I have no strong opinion yet on its video capabilities.G.

I also have the similar Makita FD-02. This Bosch is 12v, comes with two batteries, a soft case (that's easier to get stuff into rather than the rigid Makita case). The Bosch only has as simple metal (optionally installable) belt hook whereas the Makita comes with a holster. Functionally, both models are good and either would be a great choice for a light to medium duty driver-drill. They both feel good in the hand. I would give a very small styling and feel edge to the Makita in white, but that's mostly just a personal preference.Both are great tools that I have no hesitation recommending.G.

They advertise it as being good for soccer, volleyball, etc., and yeah, you can kick it and hit it etc., but it's hardly a replacement for the proper balls for any of those things.It's molded foam that's reasonably rigid. The holes are nice and it feels satisfying to grip. It can be squashed flat with a few pounds of force. Feels a bit like a foam bicycle helmet though somewhat softer.I think a dog could tear it apart pretty easily, and it will acquire nicks and tears from teeth marks, so I wouldn't recommend it as a dog play toy.It's about the size of a beginner level kids soccer ball.G.

So this is a really interesting phone with a very modernist design. The handset is very thin, though the speaking end curves forward to point at your mouth which means it's not entirely flat. It looks good, but can be slightly awkward to carry around (you can't stand it on end so hard to place it where you can see the display).The base has a black surface with flush buttons whose presence is revealed by illumination that reveals which buttons are usable in a context-sensitive fashion. The phone comes with a sticker over that surface that demonstrates where the buttons are (since otherwise looking at an un-powered one in a store you wouldn't even know that there are buttons there) and I guarantee that 75% of owners will never see the glowing buttons because they're never going to peel this sticker off.Mine died after only a few days unfortunately (handset went dead).The reason to buy this phone is its design and "look", so if that appeals to you then you'll probably be very happy with it. Some people may find the flat handset to be more of an annoyance than anything else and be happier with a traditional cordless phone.There's a default female voice for the answering machine. The DECT 6 is nice as it provides some reasonable security against eavesdroppers..G.

Yes there are cheap/free solutions out there, and it's oriented more towards business type use than something like fraps, but if it's what you need then there's nothing better than Camtasia for producing professional looking training and product demonstration screen capture videos. It has easy to use editing and a nice library of useful music and title graphics to give your screencasts a nice professional look.G.

The book has around 140 "rough drafts" which are basically of two forms: title gags as shown on the cover which honestly aren't that funny after maybe the first one, and alternative opening dialog or quotes which occasionally got me to chuckle. There are three sections, the classics (Jane Austen, etc.), contemporary literature (Harry Potter, etc.), and film and television (Pulp Fiction, etc.)It's a quick read, probably consumable in a half hour to an hour or so.More of a gift item than something I would buy for myself.3.5 stars rounding down.G.

Our 9 month old 62 pound Lab has eaten everything in the house (including parts of the house itself) and has obliterated any number of slippers, but these Nike slippers have so far been the only thing that can stand up to him. He loves to repeatedly rip the huge velcro flaps apart.I can recommend these as either footwear or as dog toys.G.

This is a great little tool. It feels rugged and good in your hand (like all Fluke devices). Definitely not waterproof in any way though!Operation is simplicity itself. Plug in a cable and push the button and watch das blinkenlights. Touch the button again to activate its WiFi hotspot and connect via your phone to see test details like the assigned DHCP address, ping/connect times, and  (if you have a modern switch at the other end of the cable) the switch and port identity information which is probably its most useful feature.In a home network kind of environment there's not too much utility you can get, but any time you have ambiguity in cable to switch port mapping, and a modern enough switch (i.e. something more than just a "wireless router") then this thing is really handy. I can't imagine any IT department troubleshooter without one of these in her pocket.It turns out you CAN reconfigure the SSID of its wireless, so you can rename it to something more personal and recognizable than just its MAC address.G.

This is a very dense book with a lot of information. It's illustrated in full color with lots of pictures of script blocks etc.While Scratch itself is very usable by motivated first or second graders, this book is written with the same sort of depth and style as you might expect in a book on programming in a traditional language such as C or C#. As a result the book probably has a much higher age requirement than the tool it is describing. It's definitely written as a book for adults as a opposed to a book for kids (though if I were a kid this is exactly the sort of book I'd want to have as soon as I was old enough to read/understand it).But if you're interested in learning Scratch for yourself, or especially with the idea of then using it to introduce programming to a child, then this is an excellent book that covers Scratch in great depth with lots of useful examples.G.

** I purchased this memory card at full price for my personal use.  This will allow me to record longer and more videos on my camera.  I'm so glad to get it before I take a day and go out shooting videos around local historical places that people never get to see because they are too busy.  I want to make a video of my town's historical places and make available to whomever wants a copy.This is really fast memory.  It records without any stutters and using USB 3.0, I'm getting huge uploads from the card to my computer in little time.  I'm glad I bought the Elite Performance, I have lesser cards but they are in my bag now and this is in my camera.  I honestly can't find anything bad to say about this card.  I know for more money I could get a faster card.  But this is so much better than what I was using, for so little money.

1:04 MinsThis 6 LED solar light arrived this week and I've had a chance to test it and write this review.The light is very convenient.  You can mount it anywhere that gets enough sun to charge it and it only takes one screw to mount.  They include a paper clip sized pin to turn it on to one of its two modes.  It will either be on dimly all the time and get bright whenever someone comes near, or it will be off all the time until someone comes near and then it will light up brightly.  Both modes work quite well.The solar panel is sealed in epoxy.  The unit is pretty well weatherproof.  The only hole to the inside is for the switch and it is angled down and raised to keep water from running into it at all.  So it is very weatherproof.  The screws that hold it together are on the back.The light worked as expected in the location we chose to mount it.  We chose a sunny location where we needed some light.  We have ours set to be off until someone comes near.  It is so nice to pull in the driveway at night and have that light come on for us to see the door lock and get inside easily.  We don't have to remember to turn it on or off.  We have a permanent electric light outside the garage door, but we never remember to turn it on when we leave and it's still light outside.  With this Solar LED light, we don't have to remember.We're happy with the operation of this light.*I received this LED solar light for free during a promotional period in exchange for this honest and unbiased review.  All opinions are my own and I am never paid.

I have used several of the leather punches in this set and they work well.  They are easy to clean after each punch and don't clog if you use them right.  This replaces a set I sent to a friend who needed some leather punches.  I'm glad I got these because they are really sharp and work great.  I love being able to put a hole anywhere in the leather and not be limited by a hand punches narrow reach.I've punched several holes since I got these and they have stayed very sharp.  They cut the holes very well.** I bought these leather punches at full price for my personal use.  I've found them indispensable.

This Hoppe's No. 9 Lubricating Oil works great!  It is highly viscose and provides superior lubrication.  I've been using it on my pistol and some fishing reels and I'm really pleased with its ability to lubricate.  I don't have to use it near as often as some other machine oils I've tried.You get a good amount of oil in the bottle.  The precision application tip makes it easy to get it just where you want it and not where you don't.  I have not had any problem with this oil getting gummy.  It doesn't attract dirt or dust like some oils I've used.This is great lubricating oil for anything mechanical.  Highly recommended by this user.** I purchased this Hoppe's No. 9 Lubricating Oil at full price for my personal use on everything that needs a good oil.

This Kershaw 1555TI Cryo knife is awesome!  I ordered on a day that Kershaw knives were offered at a huge discount on here and got what I thought was a fair price.This is not one of those $10 junk knives.  There are hundreds available and even I have been suckered in by some that looked nice but were junk when they arrived.  This knife is well-made from quality materials and is my current daily carry.  It's my daily carry on my belt because it looks great with any shirt and pants and the clip works well on all my belts.  The clip is high so none of the knife body digs into my love handle.  It's very comfortable to wear on my belt.The knife is very beautiful, in my opinion.  It is all gray and looks great.  The SpeedSafe opener works very well.  The knife opens as fast as you can flip your finger on the lever.  It's as fast as a switchblade knife but legal in most places.  Speaking of legal, the blade length is 2.75" and the knife is 3.5" closed and 6.5" from tip to end of handle when opened.  The blade is 1" high at widest place on the blade.I'm so pleased with this knife I am going to give one to my buddy for Christmas.  He'll really like it as well, I'm sure.  Anyone who likes a less flashy knife will appreciate the flat gray colored body and the gray blade.** I purchased this knife at full price for my personal collection.  I highly recommend this knife.
