I experienced a huge spike in sexual drive and libido - much more than I have from other tribulus products.  I also experienced increased drive in the gym and slightly increased recovery outside of the gym.  Over the past few weeks I have noticed the effect is subsiding - probably as a result of tolerance - but I can still feel it.This product is probably best cycled a few weeks on, then a few weeks off for optimal results.

Products like this are really a compromise.  No one likes large, bulky cases, but these protect the best.  On the other hand, no one likes to have their phone damaged when they drop it.  Unfortunately the best looking cases offer practically no drop protection.This case walks the line between protection and looks very well, IMO.There is just barely enough cushion to protect from a 3-4 foot drop, while still being slim enough to be attractive.  The case provides a little "grip" while not being overly sticky as to attract dust and dirt.This case fits the HTC one exceptionally well.  It slides over the phone firmly and snaps into place.  There is a significant lip on the front of the phone case to protect from falls on a flat surface.  On the back there are circular holes to allow for all of the microphone and camera hardware to do its job.  On the top and bottom though, the cutouts for the headphone jack and USB cable are larger than they really need to be.  I'm not sure if there is a technical reason for this, but it's something that caught my eye.Three weeks into owning the case I have had no issues with dust or debris getting in between the case and the phone - despite spending a lot of time in my pockets.  I also have had no issues with my phone overheating despite the very powerful hardware that the HTC one has.Overall I'm very happy with this case, and can fully recommend it to others looking for a slim case for the One.

I've been very impressed with the construction of this splitter.  My first thought upon opening the package was "wow, does it really have to be this thick?".  Without a doubt, you're getting a very durable, robust Y-adapter with excellent sound quality here.I am using this with the NuForce uDAC to output to both my speakers (Emotiva Airmotiv 5) and a subwoofer.  The uDAC-2 has a right and left RCA output, so I needed to split this output into two rights and two lefts.  I used two of these adapters to accomplish that and I've been very happy with the result.  Sound quality is excellent and I cannot hear any degredation at all in the sound - and this is with a nice pair of speakers and an uncompressed music source.Overall, I consider this a no-compromise splitter for those who are very concerned with audio quality.  Highly recommended.

Let me just get the negative out of the way up from.  This is not the easiest tire shine to apply. What you'll get is a small foam applicator with a ridge cut down the center.  You'll squeeze some product into the ridge then wipe your tire with it.  The problem is that most tires are not smooth and you'll have to "work" the applicator on the surface of the tire to get down into all of the grooves and print on the side of the tire.  This is not the easiest thing to do, and to be honest, a spray-on tire shine is a LOT easier.  You also have the issue of the foam applicator tearing if you apply too much pressure to it over rough tires.Regardless... you will great a great, long lasting shine with this product.  I've made my way though half a bottle over the past 8 months (which takes a lot of applications) and am happy with the results.A few tips about this product.  Apply it to a DRY tire and let it sit for a while before driving your vehicle.  Letting it absorb into the rubber a bit seems to help with keeping it on the tire and off the side of your car.  Likewise, resist the temptation to put too much product on the tire.  Just a little bit will do.  Any more than that and it will just sling off the tire onto your fender whens you drive.Overall a great product, I just wish it came with more than one applicator because I'm not sure if the one included will last the entire bottle.

I own a 2006 Acura TL with the optional Brembo braking package.  The pads for these brakes dust like crazy, so I decided to give this product a try on my wheels to see if I could help keep them clean a little longer than normal.I followed the instructions and waited for my wheels to dry before I sprayed the product on the wheels.  It went on easily, dried clear, and all seemed good.  That is, until the brake dust came.  What actually happened is that I didn't get the spray 100% uniform and there were some blotches on the wheel which did not receive proper coverage.  What I wound up with was a wheel with ugly blotches of brake dust where there was insufficient product coverage.  It looks very odd.There is also the issue of the "haze" building up on the wheel, though to be fair I only noticed this after a rainstorm.  The rain might or might not have contributed to the haze, so I'm not sure about that.So this product does actually work, you just need to be very meticulous with application.  Also, some wheel finishes might be prone to the haze issue more than others.  I used the product on silver, painted wheels.

I've used so many lip balms that I have lost count.  Lip Medex is, by far, the best one at healing and soothing chapped, damaged lips.  It has a strong medicated, menthol smell which is not the most becoming, but it tells you that this stuff means business.  When you first put it on, it goes on with a cooling sensation and makes you feel better almost immediately.  I usually apply it every 4 hours or so during the day.  After about a day or two my lips are almost always completely better.I always keep a tube of this stuff in the cabinet because when you need it, you really need it.  One tube typically lasts me about a year or so.

I'm a 30 year old man who typically does not put a ton of time or effort into grooming.  I want to look nice, but to be honest I have simple needs.This 2-in-1 shampoo is probably the worst I have ever used.  It doesn't make my hair feel particularly soft, smooth, or conditioned.  It feels a little like those "volume" shampoos (which make your hair a little sticky), only without the increase in volume.  Also, they could have left out the blue coloring from this shampoo and been all the better.  It just does not looks like something you should be putting in your hair.I've gone through half a bottle now and it's not so bad I would throw it way, but I certainly won't be buying any more of it.

I've found this cleanser does a great job of removing light to moderate oil/dirt from the skin without overdrying.  It is a cream based cleanser with no abrasives in it, so it's very gentle on the skin as well.I usually rub a little bit on my skin with my hands, then wash it off with water.  This is good for when you just need a light cleansing.  You can put a little on a wash rag, then rub your skin with the rag if you need a more robust cleaning.Overall a great product.

I have used this solvent a number of times to remove adhesive and badging from my cars.  For that it works wonderfully.  When used modestly it does not effect automotive surfaces or glass.  Since this stuff is so potent, I would recommend using the the spray straw in the nozzle so that you can more carefully target where you spray this stuff.  You want to be very careful where you put it.  It also evaporates rapidly so you need to work quickly when you use it.Just to reinforce a few precautions:- Do not get this on plastic (it will discolor it) or any soft/organic materials.- Do not use around high eat, as it is extremely flammable- Limit all bodily exposureOverall this is a wonderful product, just be very careful how you use it.

Before I start, some background on me.  I'm a 30 year old male who has been into weightlifting and "fitness" since about 13.  I was born and grew up in the south and was raised on some of the unhealthiest foods you can imagine.  Think about all of the obesity causing "southern soul food" and you'll get the idea.  I ate few vegetables growing up and through college.  Since then I've tried to clean up my diet with moderate success, though through the years there has been one staple which has not wavered - meat, dairy, and eggs.  In other words, lots of animal protein and animal fat. I was taught these food products were necessary for anyone who wanted to be a successful athlete.  I never really worried about the long term ramifications because I was "healthy" (to the eye anyway), I was young, and many other people ate the same way I did and were doing fine.My dad had a mild heart attack 7 years ago at age 56 and to be honest, I want desperately not to follow the same path as him as I age.  Issues of diet and how it relates to chronic, debilitating disease are something I carry a lot of interest in.  With that context in mind, I went into this book with an open mind, hoping to learn something.Dr Esselstyn outlines in this book his decades of experience in the medical community learning how to treat and prevent heart disease.  By using a low fat vegan diet he has successfully arrested and reversed heart disease in every one of the patients which have come to him for help.  That one point is worth re-iterating.  His success rate has been right at 100% with this diet.  People who have been turned away from surgeons because their disease was too severe for mechanical intervention and they had "no hope left" have been successfully treated with these diet protocols.  The logical framework he lays out in this book is extremely compelling and the evidence for it's success cannot be ignored by any rational person.After reading "The China Study", and this book, I decided to make some changes in my diet.  Given the heavy bias towards animal products in my diet, this would have to be a shift and a transition, not an overnight change, but I am getting there.  Four weeks in I have:- Completely eliminated egg yolks from my breakfast (previously I hate between 3-5 whole eggs per day for many years).- Removed about 90% of the dairy from my diet.  I still use a small amount of low fat cheese - primary for flavoring.- Completely eliminated red meat and all forms of fatty meat from my diet.  All of it.- Reduced my lean meat consumption (primarily chicken breast) by about 70%So after taking all of that stuff out of my diet, what have I replaced it with?  Vegetable and whole great products.  I try to use high protein grains and lentils to  support the dietary needs of my strength training.The results so far have been dramatic.  My energy and stamina are way up in the gym.  I'm able to workout significantly longer without fatigue.  I can run farther, more often, with less fatigue than I used to.  I have also noted improved sexual function and speech fluency.  I've struggled with a mild speech impediment since I was young and it's been a hindrance in almost every part of my life.  I am cautiously optimistic here, but I have noticed a significant improvement (I'd say 60%) in this condition over the past couple weeks.  This has been an absolute godsend for me and if the improvement holds I will never (ever) go back to eating the way I used to again.What are the drawbacks?  Well I'm concerned about the amount of high quality protein in my diet and how it relates to muscle recovery and strength development.  So far I have not noticed any significant reductions in strength or muscle mass, but it's still too early to tell.  I am losing a little weight (down from 184 to 180) even though I'm not trying to.  I think this is more due to a lack of calories than anything.  I'm confident though I'll be able to adjust my diet to compensate in the future as I get better at this.My recommendation to anyone reading this review would be to give the book a read.  You have absolutely nothing to lose, and everything to gain.  Even if you don't have heart disease, you can vastly improve your health and longevity with the dietary guidelines promoted by this book.

I'll let the cat right out of the bag.  The aim of this book is to open your eyes to the health dangers of animal based food products and to extol the virtues of a whole foods, plant based (vegan) diet.  Before you roll your eyes and groan, hear me out.The author of this book, Dr. Colin Campbell does an excellent job of outlining some of the very real health dangers associated with meats and animal proteins.  In particular, the link of these foods to certain types of cancer (colon, breast, prostate, and a few others) is very compelling.  Further more, the link of dairy products in children to type 1 diabetes is absolutely staggering.  In fact, this link is stronger than the link of smoking to lung cancer is.  Smoking increases your risk of lung cancer 10 fold.  Infants consuming cows milk based products increases their risk of type 1 diabetes by 13 fold.  In addition, he cites several studies linking casein (the predominant protein in dairy) as being highly cancer promoting.  The gist is that casein itself does not cause cancer, but it promotes the growth and spread of it rapidly and that by abstaining from this protein you can effectively halt the spread of certain cancers.Those are a couple of the highlights from the first half of of the book.  As someone who is very concerned with diet and health, it was absolutely enthralling and enlightening.Why haven't you heard of any of these things before?  Well, the meat and dairy lobby stand to lose billions of dollars by having their products vilified by official health organizations.  They spend hundreds of millions of dollars on an yearly basis to ensure that these products receive positive scientific press and the federal nutrition recommendations do not discourage the consumption of these products.  They will even go so far as to blackmail and strong arm respectable scientists to achieve their goals.  Make no mistake about it. Industry cares far more about their profits than they do your health.  This book outlines and clarifies this with great detail and does an excellent job doing so.So why give this book four stars instead of five?  Well, the center portion of the book is the weakest for me. This is the part where Dr Campbell goes through and lists the effects of animal based foods to various illnesses that plague western society - including heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and eye/brain disorders.  He is obviously a very intelligent man and he makes some excellent points, but while he spends 360 pages vilifying animal foods, he spends approximately 2 pages (I am not exaggerating) talking about the dangers of refined starches, sugars, and carbohydrates.How someone could write two significant chapters of such an important book as this and not mention the link of elevated insulin levels to both diabetes and heart disease is absolutely stunning.  In fact, this one omission is so damning that it really challenges the premise of the entire book for me.  The issue I see is that Dr. Campbell is so intent on vilifying animal products that he has not stopped to consider the very serious dangers of refined plant products.The title of this book comes from a huge study of nutrition and health done in China back in the early 80s.  It basically correlates certain types of modern diseases with dietary patterns in China.  People who live in the more poor, rural parts of China eat a mostly plant based diet and have few of the "modern" diseases talked about in this book.  Once these same people move into more urban parts of China and their diets change to that of a more "western" style of eating, they adopt many of these chronic illnesses.  The correlation is very compelling, however it is not the whole story.There are zero doubts in my mind that a whole foods plant based diet is more healthy than a traditional western diet.  People who eat a whole foods, plant based diet are not eating animal products, but you know what else they aren't eating?  Soda, fruit juices, sugars, candy, crackers, bread, pastries, etc.  All of these things have been proven to be strong promoters of heart disease, diabetes, and a number of other western illnesses.  Despite these facts, the condemnation of these products takes up literally 2 pages of this 365 page book.  WOW.Now before you think I'm trashing this book too hard, let me be clear.  This is an excellent book and absolutely worth buying and reading by anyone concerned with their health.  Just understand that while this book is not the last word in nutrition, it's a very good start.  Dr. Campbell is obviously an extremely intelligent and accomplished researcher.  The points he makes on the dangers of animal foods are very compelling - so much so that it has prompted me to make some changes in my own diet.  I will be reducing my consumption of meats and dairy (I've already stopped eating whole eggs) and filling the void in my diet with vegetables.  After two weeks of this, I already feel better and more energetic.  You owe it to yourself to add this book to your collection.

I already have a couple other Arkon mounts (one for each car) for my Samsung Infuse smartphone. Through a series of trial and error attempts, I have found that I prefer a traditional GPS many times while in the car.  Unfortunately my aging Tom Tom car mount has far outliving its usefulness.  Anyone who owns the OEM Tom Tom car mount knows how marginally impressive they are.This replacement by Arkon is worlds better.  The "Flip to lock" has a much more positive action and much more secure than the questionable "twist to lock" system used by Tom Tom.  To frustrated Tom Tom users, this is the mount you're looking for, trust me.One bonus to using the Arkon system is that if you own multiple types of mounts (one for a smart phone, one for a Tom Tom), you can interchange the front mounts.  That way I can leave the suction base-mount attached to my dash, and just change the front mounting carriage depending on what GPS I feel like using that day.  Very useful indeed.

Amazon is really bad about giving the full nutritional facts on products like this, so here goes:2.2lb Container:1 serving: 1 scoop (37g)Servings per container: 26Calories: 120Total Fat: 1gTotal Carb: 15gFiber: 4gSugar: 8gProtein: 15g(tons of vitamins and minerals, many in much larger than 100% doses)(large amounts of greens/fruits/enzyme blends)This powder is different than most on the market because it's not really a "protein" powder, it's more of a meal replacement powder.  The flavor is vanilla, but it doesn't taste like vanilla at all.  It has a deep fruity/organic taste and mixes very thick with water.  8oz per scoop is recommended, but I would actually suggest closer to 12 or 16 if you are mixing this by hand or with a shaker bottle.  It mixes very thick and you will have a hard time assimilating one scoop of powder into 8oz of water by shaking.  Blending should work fine regardless of how much water you use though.Taste is pretty non-offensive.  It's not great, but not terrible either.  It's actually better than I thought it would be given the high percentage of soy protein (which generally tastes bad).  I attribute much of this palatability to the high content of fruits and vegetables in this product.Overall a fantastic nutrition shake for those on the run.

These are great minimalist weight lifting gloves for those who don't need a heavy wrist wrap.  The velcro strap stops at the base of the wrist and gives practically no support to the wrist.  There is a moderate amount of padding on the palms and fingers in just the right places.  The fingers on these gloves are designed to come up to the middle knuckle on your hand.  This is enough protection for the parts of your hand which are the most highly stressed by weight lifting - notably on the inside of your hand at the base of the fingers.  The gloves seem very durable and are very grippy.  All good things.So basically I give this glove 5 stars for design and construction.However, I also deduct a star for the absolutely wonky sizing.  I'm a 5'8" male with moderately sized hands.  I bought a large and they are too small. I just don't understand how a male of below average height and average proportions can require an extra large sized glove.  I thought maybe the glove just needed breaking in, but I can confirm that it does not.  After two workouts the glove is still too small and doesn't appear to want to stretch out.  I've been working out for 17 years and this is the first time I've required an extra large size workout glove.  I guess next time I'll know better.My hand is 7-1/2" from the tip of my middle finger to the base of my hand.  I would say that the maximum size for a comfortable "large" fit would be 7".  Anything over 7" would require an extra large.  Be sure to measure your hand before you order so you don't make the same mistake I did.

ZMA is a pretty standardized product.  So long as you buy from a reputable company you don't have a whole lot of guesswork involved with the purchasing.For those of you who aren't familiar with ZMA, it's a mineral supplement which provides zinc, magnesium, and vitamin B-6 in a very specific ratio to optimize absorption.  Intensely training athletes tend to be deficient in one or more of these nutrients, which in turn inhibits proper anabolic hormone production.  If you work out hard and your diet perhaps isn't the best, it's a good chance you will benefit from ZMA.  You will fall asleep quicker, sleep deeper, and wake up feeling a little more refreshed than you would without it.  All other things being equal, this will help you recover faster and grow stronger from your workouts.  The effect is not dramatic, but it's generally worth the price of the supplement for most people.I've been using this brand of ZMA for a couple weeks now and it's worked just as well as other brands in the past.  I sleep well and wake up feeling great.  NOW is a very reputable brand that offers great value with their supplements.  This is one of the best deals you will find on legit ZMA.

I've been using Taiyo Yuden/JVC Watershield disks for the past year or so.  After going through 50 disks I was generally very happy with them, but wanted to evaluate my options before I bought another spindle of disks.  For me, 50 disks is about 3/4 of a year's worth for me.  I use these disks to burn digital images to for client delivery.  They need to look good and hold up well over time.  Given the importance of this product for me, it just makes no sense to pinch pennies here.  I wanted the best.After doing a little research, it seemed like these disks might be a bit better so I decided to give them a try.  So far I have been very pleased with the decision.I print these disks up on my Epson Artisan 730 printer using genuine Epson inks.  What I have found is that the tonality, color richness, and color fidelity with these disks is absolutely spot on.  It really took me by surprise how much better these looked to my eyes than the JVC Watershield disks.  The JVC disks seemed to have trouble with very dark and very bright tones, leaving me with an image which seemed to lack the tonal range that it should.  Also, while the colors were good they were a bit different than what I was getting with my calibrated monitor.These verbatim disks have delivered color which is absolutely spot on compared to my monitor.  I could not be more happy with them.  Furthermore, the sharpness and clarity I'm getting from the disks is right there on par with a high quality glossy print.  Color richness and gloss is exceptional.If there is one nit to pick, I would say that if you look very closely (closer than any client will look) you can see a slight graininess or lack of resolution to the printed image on the disk.  This seems to be more of a printer issue than a disk issue though.  This effect is extremely slight and in reality might be worth a 1/4 star deduction.I can easily give my full recommendation to these disks.  They are easily the best I've found with regards to image quality.

I am using this battery in a 20W Sony HVL-20DW2 video light and the performance is impressive.  I'm getting at least 30 minutes of battery life with no overheating or charging anomalies.  I'm charging it with one of the generic 8.4V, 600mA chargers often sold here on Amazon with no issues at all.So far it seems like a great alternative to the much more expensive Sony branded battery.

I've been using wireless triggers for the past 7 years or so.  The technology has grown my leaps and bounds since then, and to be honest, it's extremely impressive where things are toay.  These YN622s are the pinnacle of affordable ETTL triggers, right now.As a brief overview, these triggers will transmit an ETTL signal from your camera's hot shoe to a remotely mounted flash.  This will allow automatic flash control of remote flashes.  Anyone who shoots events and frequently changes camera settings, changes lenses, or subject angles, will greatly benefit from this.  Instead of having to go back to your flashes and manually change the power settings, the flash does this automatically as if it were sitting atop your camera.The big deal with these triggers is that the technology is now affordable - and it works well.  Radiopoppers are an option, but they are either expensive (Px system) or notoriously unreliable (Jrx system).  Pocketwizards are also an option, but are also pricey and have range/RF interference issues.  This is very new, very advanced trigger technology and the kinks are still getting ironed out.  I think Yongnuo might have finally cracked the code.The users manual for these triggers is quite long (28 pages) and intimidating.  Being automatic triggers, they have a myriad of options that most users are not going to be used to.  It doesn't helps that the manual was written by a non-English speaker, but that's another issue.After playing with these triggers for a while, here are the highlights for me.- Seamless ETTL transmittal.  Turn on the triggers, mount your flahses, set the channels, and start firing.  If you don't want to learn all of the advanced features in the manual you don't have to.  You can basically just turn the triggers on and they immediately work.  Plain and Simple.- Transceiver design.  These units can function as both a transmitter and receiver.  This is nice because you don't need two different units to perform two different jobs.  4 units can function as 4 receivers only, 4 transmitters only, or any combination in between.- Mount your flash on top of the Trigger.  No more unreliable cable connections to the flash (Radiopopper Jrx).  This is a solid, robust design with a good, firm electrical connection.  When the trigger is on-camera it will allow pass-through ETTL to the flash sitting on top of your camera.  This way you can use ETTL with an on-camera flash as well as ETTL with remote flashes as well.- Robust design.  From the first couple weeks of usage, I am cautiously optimistic about the build quality of these units. If you are carrying an on-camera flash on top of these triggers, then the flash acts a large moment arm on the trigger.  This has been known to fracture the base of the trigger - rendering it almost useless.  Any slop in the bottom or top mounting connections only amplifies this stress, increasing the chance of failure.  So far these triggers seem very solid and there is no slop at all.  I am confident in the build quality, though I would still be careful with them when using them on-camera.- Built-in IR focus assist.  When you aren't using a speedlite on-camera, these units can use their built in infrared assist beam to help with focusing in low light.  This is a huge benefit for dimly lit environments.  This feature is unique and to be honest I haven't seen it on any other trigger design like this.- Group Settings.  With the groups you can lock in the ratio of firing power to specified ratios.  This can be done in-camera for recent cameras which allow remote speedlite adjustment through the camera's menu (5DII and newer, generally).Drawbacks?- Complication.  28 page long user manual for a set of flash triggers should tell you something.  My strong recommendation would be to read the manual carefully and test the triggers out at home before taking these to a paid job.  Odds are you are NOT going to be able to figure these things out in the 5 minutes before your photo session.- Menu driven controls.  These triggers have a LOT of different options and functions, but relatively few buttons.  This means that to access many of it's features, you are going to have the use the camera's built-in flash control menu.  It's one of the drawbacks of having such advanced triggers, but a worthwhile tradeoff for many people.  Count on a little more involved setup procedure for these triggers relative to the earlier models.- Because of the transceiver design, you will need to buy some sort of mounting shoe for remote flash units.  There is no 1/4-20 thread on the bottom of these units like there is with other "receiver only" designs.  The little plastic feet that come with most flashes generally have a thread mount on the bottom, so for now I am using these.- You need newer cameras and flashes to take advantage of all of the features these triggers have to offer.  You can use them with older equipment, though many of the features are lost.  Check the compatibility list for more details.In summary, these are well-sorted, advanced ETTL flash triggers for a very attractive price.  Yongnuo seems to have learned from the  mistakes of other companies here and produced a trigger with no glaring flaws.  The fact that they did all of this and kept the price as low as they did is just amazing to me. I would highly recommend these for a flash power user.  For a beginner or anyone with more basic needs, a simple manual trigger is probably a better option.

I own a Samsung Infuse smartphone and like many other smart phones you cannot use it in the car for GPS purposes without draining the battery.  Even with the standard factory car charger (which is 500 ma), the battery still drains while the phone is being used as a GPS.After doing some research I came across this charger (which supplies 950ma) and from the buzz online it seemed like it would do the trick for me.  Well, it's an improvement over the standard 500ma charger, though not perfect.I find that on full brightness - which is typical of what you'll need for daytime car GPS usage - the battery still drains even when using this charger.  Bummer.  To be fair, the drain is much lower than the standard 500ma charger, and drastically less than using no charger at all, but the battery still slowly drops nonetheless.  If you drop the screen brightness, or turn the screen off for extended highway drives, then the battery drop all but ceases.So that is only a minor drawback.  A bigger drawback for me is that on several occasions my phone has overheated and frozen while using this charger with my phone's GPS fuction.  This required me unplugging the charger and rebooting my phone to remedy.  This is a HUGE pain when you are behind the wheel and driving somewhere you are unfamiliar with.  Keep in mind the standard 500ma charger would have no such overheating problems.  Apparently the engineers at Samsung specified the 500ma current in order to maintain full functionality of the phone under all conditions - even car GPS usage.  Anything over that is not within spec and could cause the phone to overheat under certain circumstances.That said, I am still fairly happy with the charger.  So long as I am not doing anything intensive with the phone in the car, it charges my phone very rapidly with no problems what so ever.  Just be aware of the above caveats and you should be fine.

This is one of those songs that you probably like but are probably embarrassed to tell your friends that you like.  It's ok, I was like that but eventually came around.  Even after hearing the song almost constantly for 4 straight months on the radio, I'm still not quite tired of it (yet).It's definitely a frilly pop song without a whole lot of substance, but it's light listening when you're in the mood for upbeat.

If you were expecting some super stimulant that doubles your blood pressure and leaves you tearing through the gym like a rabid maniac, you'll probably be disappointed by this product.  Truthfully there are MANY other pre-workout stimulants on the market stronger than this.  As far as I am concerned, that niche is filled.Instead, where this product steps in is for people who want a kick for their workout, but still want to be able to sleep at night.  For me, such a pre-workout would be worth its weight in gold.  After about a week of usage, I like this stuff a LOT.  I stack it with creatine ethyl ester and the amount of energy, focus, and stamina I have in the gym is as good as I can remember on ANY pre-workout supplement.  I don't say this lightly either, I have tried many of them.The sensation I get from this product is one of heightened focus, drive, and strength but without the jitters, crash, or trouble sleeping I get from traditional pre-workout products.  I go to the gym after work (from 5:00 to 6:00), so it's very important that I am able to get to sleep approximately four hours after I leave the gym.  With Hyper FX I can do that, with many other PWO products, I cant.I'm 5'8", 185lbs and about 3/4 of a scoop (a dose is one scoop) is all it takes to kick me in high gear.  The product works by dissolving in an effervescent fizz (it is recommended that you NOT shake this product), and takes effect very quickly.  I'd say 20 minutes after consumption, you are ready to go.  Unlike many pure stimulants, the effect is relatively short lived.  After about 3 hours or so, you are back to feeling mostly normal and shouldn't have much problem falling asleep at night.  Keep in mind there is some caffeine in here, so the stimulants effect is still present to some extent.  However it is much milder than you get from other similar products.So for those of you who train late in the day or are more sensitive to stimulants, this product is worth serious consideration.

I use a Think Tank Pro Speedbelt with two of these pouches.  I just didn't want to make the jump to the "35" size pouch, though I could probably use it.  This pouch is going to handle lenses no more than 7" long and about 3.5" in diameter (measure your lenses before buying!).Here are the lenses I own and how they fit into these pouches:Canon 16-35/2.8 II - Fits ok without the hood, VERY tight with the hood.Canon 24/1.4L - Fits wellCanon 50/1.2L - Fits wellCanon 85/1.2L - Fits ok without the hood, VERY tight with the hoodCanon 135/2L - Fits without the hood, does not fit with the hood.Canon 100/2.8 - Fits without the hood, does not fit with the hood.Like all Thinktank products, it is built exceptionally well and is lightweight.  The drawcord at the top keeps the pouch shut do you don't have to worry about your lenses falling out when you travel.  It also comes with a rain pouch.  So this is an excellent, padded bag for those who use the Thinktank belt system.  If you use larger lenses or lenses with larger hoods, I definitely recommend the Lens changer 35.  This "25" is really only for smaller lenses.  .

As far as dog bags go, these are some of the more affordable you can buy.  They are also at least partially bio degradable which is a plus.  Unfortunately they do not come in the little 2-1/2" wide rolls we are so often used to when it comes to dog bags.  Instead these bags come on a single 8" long roll that you will have to tear off one by one and use.  This is a mild inconvenience if you have one of those dog bag carriers on your dog leash that is made for the smaller rolls.That is a nit pick.  Another nit pick is that the bags are a little hard to get open, which is typical of most cheaper bags.  So if you are looking for affordable bags and don't mind all 200 coming on one giant roll, this is a good way to go.

I don't have a particularly large desk.  Unfortunately for me and my desk, the size of my keyboards have done nothing but get larger over the years - both in thickness and in desk area consumed.  When my gigantic Logitech Wave keyboard finally bit the dust I had decided enough was enough.  I wanted something smaller and thinner.This keyboard is 17" wide, 6" deep, and .6" at its thickest (.3" at its thinnest - it is sloped).  In terms of sheer volume, this keyboard is about 70% smaller than my previous keyboard, yet provides all of the typing space I need and nearly all of the buttons I could want.  There is no handrest, but since the keyboard is only .3" thick where you put your hands, you don't really need one.The keys on this keyboard are the flat "chiclet" style keys that feel like those on a high end laptop.  However unlike a high end laptop, this keyboard is the most rigid typing surface I've ever felt.  It literally feels like there is a solid slab of marble on the other side of the keys.  There is absolutely zero flex in this board.  To be honest, I'm not sure how I feel about this.  I think I'm going to have to learn to type a little bit softer.  Also another thing to note is since the keys are flat, there will likely be a learning curve if you are used to curved keys like I was.  Regardless, I am typing very quickly on this keyboard.Wireless setup was a snap.  I needed no drivers on Windows 7 64 bit.  I just plugged in the receiver, hit the connect button on the back of the keyboard and I was in business.  There are standard function keys (F1-F12), a full size number pad, and volume controls.  You can also access media player controls by hitting the "Fn" key along with the corresponding function key at the top.I would describe this product as a high end minimalist keyboard for those looking for a nice keyboard with a minimal footprint.  Both function and aesthetics are top notch with this piece.

I'm kind of surprised at the two star reviews here.  You're buying a ten dollar (as of August 2012) flash drive.  You can't expect world beating performance for this price level.  Instead what you're getting is a functional, reliable (so far) flash drive, with a couple nifty features.Functionally, the slide out connector is a nice feature.  It keeps the end from getting as dirty or damaged as it would were it constantly exposed.  One nit pick though is that I have found the button (for the slider) to be a little picky about how you push it.  Sometimes you have to be a bit deliberate with pushing it down or else it won't slide.  Not a ton of refinement here, but it works.As far as performance goes, I'm getting about 3.7 MB/s write and about 8 MB/s read speed from this unit.  Not great, but sufficient given the price.Overall this is a nice low end flash drive if you don't demand top shelf performance.

I've been using this little vac for the past 6 year or so to clean my car and to vacuum out various areas of my apartment.  It's been a trooper and overall I've been very happy with it.  The suction power is excellent for its size and I've found it more than adequate for vacuuming automotive carpet and for various household tasks.  The attachments make it especially useful for different surfaces as well.Overall this vac is both small and light, which can be good and bad.  One downside to the light weight is that it tips over easily.  There is some sort of valve inside the vacuum that if it gets tipped over, the valve will shut, preventing suction.  This makes the unit sound like it's going to explode.  So you basically want to make sure the vacuum stays upright and does not tip over while you're using it.  The light weight of the unit makes this a challenge at times.As for the filter inside the vacuum, I have never replaced the filter and never really needed to.  So long as you don't get the filter wet, you should be able to clean it with an air compressor fairly easily to maintain longevity.For household usage, this is just about the perfect mini-vac.  It's powerful, durable, and cheap.  I just wish it didn't tip over so easily.

I spend about 8-12 hours a day on the computer and after years of usage, I started to get pretty serious carpel tunnel on my right hand.  Switching to using a mouse with my left hand helped circumvent the pain, but it still did not address the problem.  For my work I need the precision afforded by using my dominant hand.At first I thought the pain was coming from specifically using a mouse, but it turns out it was the rotation of the forearm that was causing the pain while I work.  The vertical design of this mouse prevents that and helps the arm work in a more natural position.After about a month of using this mouse most of the pain in my hand is gone.  I can use my right hand for mousing all day and only experience a small fraction of the discomfort I used to.So why five stars if it only "mostly" reduced the pain?  Well, to be honest I feel like it's my fault for not switching to an ergonomic mouse sooner.  If you wait until you already have pain, then it's too late to catch the problem at an optimal time.  So while the mouse design is excellent (close to ideal even), if your hand is already in pain, you're probably not going to be able to use ANY mouse with complete comfort.  Don't wait until you already have pain to do something about over use problems with a normal mouse.Overall an excellent product.  I just wish I had found it a couple years back.

I bought this printer after two of the print heads on my artisan 710 permanently clogged and couldn't be fixed.  I expected this printer to be similar to the 710 and I was right.  In fact it's about 95% identical, with only moderate changes in a few key places.- The 730 has a new touch sensitive front panel display vs the button based panel of the 710.- The 730 has a new color scheme (dark blue vs solid black of the 710)- The 730 has firmware which is automatically updateable though software.- The 730 costs nearly half as much as the 710 ($98 vs $180)- The 730 does NOT take third party ink cartridges as well as the 710.Pay close attention to that last point.  If you are considering using this printer for high volume work with third party ink cartridges, I would consider a different printer.  Apparently the recent firmware updates by Epson don't like non-genuine ink cartridges.Ok so that's what is different from the Artisan 710.  What's the same as the 710?- Outstanding printing and scanning quality.- Same great print speed and print features (auto duplexing).- Built in CD/DVD printing with excellent quality- Very stable and reliable wireless performance (for printing and scanning)- Same flimsy paper tray- Same inconvenient paper loading- Same expensive ink cartridgesSo yes, the Artisan 730 has some of the same quirks the old 710 has, but it keeps enough of the good features to make it worth buying.  Overall I'm very happy.UPDATE (9/17/12):The printer apparently died over the weekend.  It will turn on for five seconds, do a partial pre-operation check, then freeze and shut off.  Espon support was completely stumped and is sending me a new printer.  Very disappointed in the lack of quality control here, but props to Epson for taking care of the problem.  Hopefully the next copy will be better.

I actually bought this tablet to help with carpel tunnel pain in my right hand due to spending 10-12 hours a day on the computer.  Turns out using a tablet like this is just as stressful - if not more so - than using a normal mouse.  I fully realize this is not the primary objective of a tablet, but it's food for thought.  Turns out most of the pain was coming from the twisting of the forearm and working with the hands horizontally instead of vertically in a "handshake" position.  Tablets obviously don't improve on this, so my pain hasn't improved, sadly.I've never used a tablet before and will confess there was a steep learning curve for getting the coordination down with it.  There is plenty of space on the tablet for general usage (much larger and you find yourself moving your hand around a lot).  Wacom's software is very good and there are plenty of options for customization of the buttons and inputs.  I found the responsiveness of the tablet very good with the stylus and mediocre with the "touch" finger-based input.  For some reason I found myself having to repeatedly click on certain things to get them to select.  Though I'm sure this would improve with time, I definitely found myself being much slower than this than I would be a mouse.So coming from a complete tablet newbie, I will confess that the usage of this device didn't meet my expectations, though that is probably more of an issue my expectations than the tablet itself. My recommendation would be to use this for stylus input and leave everything else to a standard mouse.

I drive a 2000 Celica GTS and decided to drop this filter in to replace an old paper filter.  Honestly, I did not expect a whole lot, but I figured it would be the last filter I ever put in the car and it might get me slightly better gas mileage on the highway.Well so far the gas mileage has panned out.  I have gained 1-1.5MPG on the highway.  As for power gain, there might be a little, though I don't push the engine hard enough to really notice.  I have no interest in redlining a 12 year old, 200,000 mile engine, so that theory will probably never be tested.  It's a safe bet though that if there are any power gains to be had, it's very high in the powerband.  Expect little to no low end torque improvement with this (as any) air filter.As an odd note, I have noticed that the throttle response of my car is now a little more sensitive.  This may or may not be preferably, depending on how you drive.  For commuter cars or family vehicles, this sensitivity would probably annoy most.  However for those who drive sporty cars in a semi-aggressive manner, the extra throttle sensitivity is probably welcomed.  For my tired daily driver, I honestly preferred the throttle response from the paper filter more.That said, so long as you understand the benefits of such a filter, it's a great purchase for the money.

For starters, this isn't your run of the mill whey protein powder.  This powder consists of protein, cocoa, natural sweeteners, and that's about it.  This is ideal for people wanting a completely natural protein and are steering clear of artificial sweeteners (sucralose and similar compounds).One result of the lack of artificial sweeteners is that this protein won't taste like chocolate brownie a-la mode.  I can best describe the taste as being "weak" and "unoffensive".  It's not very thick, so I would advise using less liquid as opposed to more when mixing.  And as always, this formula tastes better with milk than with water.There is one primary competing product this this one made by Optimum - which I had bought previously.  The only real difference between the Optimum Natural Whey and this Met-Rx formulation is the lack of protein enzymes to aid in digestion.  Everything else seems identical.  For the roughly $10 per jug savings over the Optimum product, I would say this is a worthwhile tradeoff for most people.Here are the nutritional facts per 33 gram scoop:Calories 130Calories From Fat 20Total Fat 2g 3%***Saturated Fat 1g 5%***Trans Fat 0gCholesterol 30mg 11%Total Carbohydrate 5g 2%***Dietary Fiber <1g 3%***Sugars 3g ****Protein 23g 45%***Calcium 124mg 12%Iron 0.5mg 3%Phosphorus 108mg 11%Magnesium 33mg 8%Sodium 55mg 2%Potassium 220mg 6%Stevia Extract 170mg ****(Stevia Rebaudiana) (Leaf)

This battery makes a good replacement for anything which takes a BP-511 or BP-511A Canon battery.  It charges up flawlessly in the Canon charger, holds a charge nicely, and lasts a long time.Older BP-511s tend to charge up fine, but lose their charge very rapidly.  I've got a couple that won't even last more than 50 shots in a Canon 20D.  These fresh replacements are good for about 10 times that number of shots, AND the charge lasts if you let them sit. Older batteries tend to run dead if you let them sit for a while.And for the price, you could buy 5 of them and still come out cheaper than a single Canon BP-511A.  Given that the performance is near identical for all I can tell, it's a fantastic deal.

My review probably won't be relevant to most reading this review, but hopefully useful to some.  I am a photographer and I bought this backdrop to use for a photobooth.  So far, it has been a very ideal solution, made even better by the surprisingly low price.Genuine, branded photobooth backdrops typically run 3-4 times this amount for what is basically just a fancy curtain.  This works just as well, looks fantastic, and only costs a fraction as much.The fabric in this curtain feels like a very smooth, heavyweight, high thread count bed-sheet.  It emits a very gentle sheen which looks fantastic against modest, indoor lighting.  The top grommets are perfectly functional and look great when you alternate them through your hanging rod.The fabric does have a tendency of becoming wrinkled if you leave it sitting folded up (like I do).  You can remedy this by putting it into the dryer with a wet rag or small towel.  Once it's out, immediately hang it up and the wrinkles should be gone by the time it cools.  This effectively "steams" the curtain without the need for a steamer.So whether used for photography, or as an actual curtain in your house, this is a great product that I'm very happy with.

I bought this for our bakery. It works well, seems sturdy, doesnt leak, dispenses a fair, not to small amount of soap reliably.It comes with 2 mounting solutions, one glue tape (works but is not ideal)  or a set of screws and ankers.There was a mounting drawing with drill holes but honestly, no need.Great little dispenser for the moneyIf you have questions, please ask, if I can I will answer.if you found this helpful, please hit the helpful button.Thank you!

So. I bought this as a cheap and clean solution to proof my sour dough loaves.It works fine. closes well and seems to be sturdy enough.The only minor problem I have seen, it needs a SERIOUS airing before you can use it around any food.It has quite a smell to it, but one night in my garage took care of that problem.If you have any questions please ask, I will try to answer as quick as I can.if this review helped you, please be so kind and hit the helpful button.Thanks!

I really like this cash drawer. It works great, opens reliably. the coin and paper money slips are working great.Feels sturdy, and we REALLY give it hard use.I can't say much more, but if you have questions, please ask and I will try to answer promptly

First of all, I did NOT buy this product of Amazon but another household staple. I made sure I document my statements with pictures, as some other reviewers have been attacked for bad reviews.So, let me start with the all over sturdyness, well it is not there, please see picture sturdy. When you press the release button you have to press real hard to release the latch, plus the box bends :-)  very good sign for a safe box. But see pic please and decide yourself.2nd problem, a small one tough, the Steelmaster product label came of before I even used the box.......see picture.3rd problem, as others stated, the person who designed the slots for the bills used templates for some currency, but not USD, because the bills do NOT fill the slot. I mean how on earth.....but ok.4th and 5fth problem: the opening mechanism is placed right on top of paper money slot 2 and 3. Ergo, many times money gets stuck under the mechanism. I ripper a 5er and a 10 at first AND last day of usage.Others stated the handle broke of, mine didn't, but I did not give it a chance to happen.Bad product, cheaply made for a product in that price category. Badly thought through and clearly NOT worth your money or time

Who needs 27 ounces of Maggi? You can't cook? Maggi will at least make it taste. The wife can't cook. Smack Maggi on top and it will taste.Soup is lame, 2 drops and you have a great taste. Boiled eggs? Add Maggi :-)But 27 ounces is a load. Even for a German.So, the original Maggi is a natural product and a staple in the German kitchen. It gives salad dressings a kick, gives soups the extra savory smack, and adds the little extra to many other dishes. Please be aware that this product is based mainly on a herb that is called Liebstoeckl, or Lovage.In the olden times, there was the rumor that  some drops of Maggi onto the right spots will spice things up........but lets be honest, if that would work, we all would bath in the stuff :-)So, lets spice up our soups instead!Have fun, and please hot the helpful button IF this was helpful

This book covers the life of a person.a comedian.a groundbreakerI admit, If you are no fan. You will be most likely bored.Even I, and I am a, fan was challenged at times,but none the less,I did enjoy the read.Keep in mind, this is not a funny book, no collection of sketches, but a memoir.

I am not sure what the ravings reviews are about, but within 1 hr of testing I found 2 clear "no thanks issues"1. toward the edges of the screen the touches dont register well (at least on mine) I can hit the fields like a maniac,all I get is....nothing...doesnt register2.I bought this solely to use it with square, which doesnt work, again, at least on mine.It is a cheap little tablet, I agree, but I really think you get what you paid for.....

I could have lived with all the nooks and crannies that are only cleanable when you take everything apart AND take a screwdriver, remove some more parts, and then clean them. But that the chrome comes of at the first use (maybe its not chrome but paint?), that is to much for my taste. I do NOT enjoy chrome/paint pieces in my food.I can NOT advise on buying this, no one needs this kind of things to happen this her/his food.Stay away.

Hard to beat the quality. Excellent taste, beautiful shine to it. very easy to temper.I do admit, it is pricey, but I rather buy something good and spend a little more then buysome low quality stuff. Ok, no I dont usethis for my personal medicine growing. This is finally real pectin without added dextrose and ascorbin acid as far as I know, but it is ridiculously priced.There is a company in california that imports a similar product and sells you 10 lbs of the same product for the same price.....Pomona, I understand you need profit, but this is a bit on the naughty side of things.......

Let's be honest here, this is first and foremost NOT pectin but dextrose and therefore a misnomer by default.It also has ascorbic acid added, which is by itself not a problem as it helps the pectin to work. But, real pectin is addedat a rate of 3-5% based on the amount of fruit you use, and allows the reduction of added sugar from 1-1 to down to 1-3 to  1-5 depending on the acidity (low ph) of your fruits. It can be basically used to use zero added sugar, in that case you do need to add ascorbin acid or a similar preservative.Again, the product works, that is not the point, but you pay a load of money for mainly dextrose.....

Let's be very clear here. All this products call themselves Pectins but are in fact very very low in Pectin.What you buy here is cheap dextrose and some ascorbin acid and maybe 10-15% of pectin.Unfortunately American laws allow this behavior, but thankfully, as clients here on Amazonwe are able to voice said concern. I know real pectin is hard to get, but it is available.You need between 3-5% of pure pectin (measured on ounces of fruit) plus you can bring the added sugars down safely to 20-25%.If you want to go lower then this, you NEED to add ascorbin  acid or another preservative.This is NOT a low calorie option.

This is the first book I’ve read by Paul Cleave. I definitely plan to read more. The characters and plot are among the most original I’ve ever read—and the writing itself is fantastic.In TRUST NO ONE, the protagonist is Jerry Grey, a best-selling author of crime fiction. Grey is diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer’s. He begins keeping a journal so he’ll be able to reference his thoughts and memories after the disease begins to worsen—but when that finally happens, the disease blurs the lines between Grey’s real life and the fictional characters he created using his alter-ego/pseudonym Henry Cutter … and Grey confesses to being a murderer.At first no one believes him, because the crimes he describes are straight out of his books—but then bodies start turning up on the same days Grey wanders off from his live-in care facility, and the police take notice and begin to treat him as if he really is a murderer.But is he really? Grey, in his rare lucid moments, doesn’t think so. But how can he prove that? He can’t remember what he had for breakfast, let alone what he did when he wandered off …The story alternates brilliantly between third-person and excerpts from Grey’s journal. The pacing is a bit slow for the first half of the book, but the pages are filled with tense, dramatic moments—and the final chapters are pure thriller.TRUST NO ONE is the best mystery/suspense novel I have read in a very long time. I highly recommend it: 5/5 stars.---This is a honest/unbiased review of a free digital edition courtesy NetGalley and the author.

There is much to admire about Maha Akhtar’s novel Footprints in the Desert. The prose is literary quality and the author paints an exceptionally vivid portrait of exotic locales embroiled in war – and it’s easy to feel the despair and loss experienced by the main characters.I pulled three quotes from the Kindle file to illustrate not only the high quality of the writing but also a greater point with regard to the book’s overall theme: “What has this war done to us? To make us not care about the things that really matter?”“Endings are inevitable, Noura,” Salah began hesitantly. “An ending can be the end of a year, the end of a summer, the end of a war, or the death of someone we loved. Whatever they are, endings always make us feel sad. But we move on. And the people we have lost along the way are the small clear voices in our heads that will be with us always.”“In the end, despite Lawrence’s efforts, the Arab point of view was completely ignored and the British and French promises made by Henry McMahon to Sharif Hussein of Mecca in 1915 disappeared like footprints in the desert sand.”As you can see, the writing is beautiful. What I think you can also see is a theme developing – the main characters all have struggles because of the war; and as the book closes, the author really hits home with the idea that this is a universal struggle still felt by millions of people today and asks readers: “will the conflicts there ever cease?”It’s a powerful book, for sure. Other reviewers already mentioned the two real criticisms I have so I’ll just echo their sentiments. The love stories in the middle and toward the end really killed the momentum for me. I get it, many readers will love them. But I didn’t care. Also, many of the dramatic fight scenes, spy scenes, sneaking around the souk in back alley scenes … it felt as if the writer had less command over her craft when it came to that aspect of the book. There were really beautiful passages dealing with loss and suffering and friends reaching out to help one another … followed by a dramatic chase that felt, well, silly.Anyway, I believe most readers of literary/historical fiction will enjoy this book. I would recommend it: 4/5 stars.---This is a honest/unbiased review of a free digital edition courtesy NetGalley and the publisher.

This is a very dark crime/mystery novel. The Harry Hole series is notoriously dark, but this one is really twisted. It's also great reading. Hole is an original and fascinating character, and as he hunts a suspected serial killer through Oslo, and deals with a fellow detective who might also be a murderer/gangster, Hole is forced to make some decisions with the direst of consequences. Excellent book. I highly recommend it.
This is one of my all-time favorite movies. The characters, dialogue, pace ... everything is perfect. Such a great movie and a real classic that everyone should watch at least once.

For such a talented cast this was a very disappointing movie. The book was much better. To be honest the movie was dull and laborious to watch. I guess the final scenes were supposed to be dramatic or thought provoking or ... something. But they weren't. I would not recommend it.

I really enjoyed this movie. Very little about this version of Jack Ryan meshes with the original Tom Clancy character -- but that's intentional. It's a complete standalone and a new iteration of the Ryan character. Just enjoy it for what it is -- a great thriller.

One of the best in the Harry Hole series. What I love most about this series is that author Jo Nesbo truly understands how ambiguous and messy life can be, and we don't really get resolutions tied up in pretty little packages. This is a gritty, dark, and exceptionally well written novel about a flawed man doing his best to persevere against inner demons and real life monsters. If you enjoy crime fiction then Jo Nesbo and Harry Hole should be on your must-read list.

Totally out of control and unbelievable on so many levels … and I absolutely loved it. I hadn’t seen Expendables 1 or 2 and had zero expectations when I watched #3, but the action was non-stop and the casting was just perfect for this type of nonsensical violence. If you like action flicks and tough guy catch-phrases, this is the movie for you.

This is the perfect size and design for a gym/outdoor/travel pouch. My iPhone fits perfectly in one compartment and the other holds my wallet, passport and keys no problem. The elastic band is very secure on my arm, but I can also fasten it to exercise equipment in the gym -- i.e. treadmill or elliptical. It is a very good product, especially for the price.---I received a discount code for this product in exchange for an honest/unbiased review.

Nice to see Race on Prime Video now. It is one of the best shows on TV, and season 10 is particularly good as you can really see how the show tries to revamp itself and add more exciting/challenging features that make for even better entertainment. The casting for season 10 was fantastic and the locations they visit are among the best selections of any season.

I love this series. Some seasons are obviously better than others. And some seasons have silly plot twists for no apparent reason except to fill the 24 hours. Season 6 is unfortunately filled with ridiculous plot twists. From rogue white house staff planning assassinations to Audrey being dead/not dead to Jack's father to the Chinese subplot in the final episodes ... just way too much. It grows tiresome. The first few episodes of season 6 are fantastic, as CTU and the government are dealing with a wave of suicide bombs on US soil. This season could have been so much better if it had stayed focused on that threat.

I would highly recommend this product. In truth I'm not sure why anyone would use a steak knife after using this.---I received a discount code for this product in exchange for an honest/unbiased review.

This is a powerful multi-generational story that begins with the author as a child in North Vietnam. The writing style is very readable, but the content is difficult at times as the author describes life as a child in war-torn Vietnam. I think one of the most vivid and heart-wrenching things I’ve ever read is the author describing the senseless and brutal death of her father, and the way she reacted at his funeral. It is inexorably sad.This book isn’t entirely sad though. There is a tremendous amount of hope and courage in this book. The author’s life is ultimately a story of resilience and perseverance in the face of overwhelming grief and tragedy. I would definitely recommend this to non-fiction/memoir readers: 4/5 stars.---This is a honest/unbiased review of a free digital edition courtesy NetGalley and the author.

This is the second story to feature Reese Carter and Juliana Farrell -- career criminals who a year earlier had clashed when, independent of each other, they both tried to steal the same special ruby at the exact same time.Now the ruby is back and it's creating more problems. Carter had "sold" it to another thief -- but the one he sold was a fake, and now Farrell is selling the real one, which puts Carter in an awkward and dangerous position when the whole criminal underworld discovers his earlier deception in a very public way.Police Officer Josh Williams is also searching for Carter. But despite all the uncertainty in his professional life, things heat up between Carter and his nemesis Farrell, further complicating matters.What follows is a well-written story of likable thieves that is full of twists and turns.

I enjoy reading this series. Brad Thor is a great thriller writer. However, two summers ago he wrote a book titled HIDDEN ORDER that was about the Federal Reserve and conspiracy theories … and in telling that story, Thor included history lesson after history lesson and for good measure he mixed it all with a lot of supposition. He did very little to support the soapbox he’d created through credible literary means and despite the fact the book got many great reviews, I’ve maintained my opinion that it was a complete mess.That being said … I loved ACT OF WAR last year and thought, great, Thor is back. And then comes CODE OF CONDUCT and I’m reading the product description and lo and behold Thor is on the conspiracy train wreck again. I was so annoyed, because it lowered my expectations for this book considerably.But … this book starts fantastic. I mean it is flying from the opening pages. One of the best opening few pages I’ve read in a long time. Harvath is putting his girlfriend and her family on a plane to evacuate to Alaska because the US is in total collapse. It grabs you, and then immediately shifts to a week earlier when the events building up to the evacuation began. I mean, you have to read it at that point. You can’t not read it, because the opening pages are that good.So I went from having low expectations to being really excited.The plot shifts to Africa. The Congo. Harvath and a team are tracking down a health facility run by a US charity. There are a few silly moments with a female doctor that tags along. Some cliché caricatures that weren’t necessary, but okay, no big deal. A lot of action though, and Harvath doing what Harvath does best. And no mention of conspiracies. Not yet. This time around Thor really let the plot build before hitting readers with the conspiracy part. In other words he did a much better job with it this time.Harvath and his team make some disturbing finds in Congo, however, and now he has to race back to the US to try and stop a truly devastating attack.OK, that’s where the conspiracy parts come in. Two things, but I’ll do this without any spoilers: the insidious attack that’s being planned, as well as the rationale for the attack, has been done many times by many authors and it’s not exactly a new storyline; and the conspiracy part … it’s so convoluted, I just had to bear it and push through until Harvath started shooting people again.This is a mix of mostly extremely good parts, a couple cliché caricatures, plus a silly conspiracy that requires a complete suspension of disbelief in order to get through the final third of the book.I am glad I read it. I will look forward to the next book in the Harvath series. I will hope against hope that it’s not another conspiracy job.I would recommend it to thriller fans: 3.5 / 5 stars.

0:19 Mins This product works great. It is especially useful for international travel because it is dual voltage and it eliminates the need for carrying multiple adapters. For international travel you only need one adapter to plug the USB charger into the wall, and then you can safely charge up to five devices at one time. The surge protector is also an added bonus, as I think most people are unlikely to carry such items on trips.---This is a review of a free product.

In my opinion this is the finest book in the Gabriel Allon series. Daniel Silva is more than just a thriller writer—he’s a literary genius. The writing is lyrical, chilling, mesmerizing … so many ways to describe it, all of them good.THE ENGLISH SPY is about settling old scores, a final restoration, and ultimately going home and starting over. The story is masterfully paced. It begins with an assassination and then carefully and methodically Silva begins to unveil the various layers.Gabriel and Christopher Keller—an assassin who once upon a time was hired to kill Gabriel—chase an IRA bomb maker with an insidious past. Only it turns out that Gabriel’s own past is closely tied to the bomb maker, and very quickly the chase becomes incredibly personal.This is simply a brilliant novel, on so many levels. No one writes literary thrillers even close to the level of Daniel Silva. I highly recommend it: 5/5 stars.

I was interested to read this book because I love to travel and I have a lot of respect for what people in the airline industry do on a daily basis to keep commerce humming despite the constant threats we face in our post-9/11 world. I think any job that is so unlike what most of us do on a daily basis has a certain glamorous allure to it – and flight attendant is certainly in that category.This memoir has a bit of everything – the chapters I found most intriguing however were the ones that dealt with in-flight emergencies, unruly passengers, travelers on the FBI’s terror watch list, and what it was like to be a flight attendant on 9/11.A great deal of the book is spent cataloging the glamorous party lifestyle of Virgin Air flight attendants. Richard Branson is in the book. It’s fun and entertaining and there are many “I can’t believe she did that” moments. A lot of alcohol, a lot of sex, and a lot of things that are included for shock value … but I wouldn’t make the mistake of dismissing this as a serious work. Along with the outrageous behavior is a powerful story of a woman who escaped an abusive relationship and succeeded in life.My guess is most readers won’t find everything in this book to their liking, but I think that’s true with most books. The writing is smart, funny and entertaining – and even if all the chapters don’t agree with your taste or sensibilities, there is a lot here to admire.---I received an advance galley courtesy Penguin Random House First to Read.

I, RIPPER was definitely “outside the box.” It’s unlike anything else I’ve ever read. I love the title and how “I, Ripper” is incorporated into the story. Stephen Hunter is a brilliant writer and I also love how he told this tale in late nineteenth century British English.The story is told from alternating viewpoints – a journal kept by Jack the Ripper and a memoir written by a newspaper writer who covered the crimes. The writer, Jeb, admits he is not very heroic, but assures readers there is a hero later in the story.I wasn’t real keen on this book early on. The opening journal entries are graphic murders followed by graphic sexual encounters followed by graphic murders. At one point I wondered if the book was simply going to be a fictionalized recounting of everything gruesome … but then finally, Jeb begins to channel his inner-Sherlock Holmes and work up a profile of who Jack the Ripper really is – and from that point forward I was unable to put the book down.There are some tense scenes as Hunter builds to a dramatic conclusion. There are some “twists” and a few predictable moments as well. Taken as a whole, this is an incredibly imaginative book that is sure to entertain horror/thriller/crime fiction fans: 4/5 stars.
The info is pretty basic but the book itself is put together nicely. Would be enjoyable for Yankee fans.

For the third book in this outstanding series, Quinn is faced with his most daunting challenge yet -- clearing his own name. A great plot, lots of twists, and original characters -- this is another terrific book by Brett Battles.
I enjoyed the Red Sox volume by the same title / author more than this one, but it's still a good read for any baseball fan. If you're a Yankee fan then it's a great read.
Great book for baseball fans -- particularly if you're a Reds fan.

Blake Snyder was a gifted writer. Save The Cat is one of the most helpful books on writing I've ever read -- whether it's screenwriting or novels you are interested in, this book provides a concrete step-by-step formula to help you be successful.
There is not much to this book and it's not challenging at all.
An epic, incredible novel. Everything about this book is brilliant and it's one of my top five favorite novels I've ever read.

I've had hit-or-miss / up-and-down experiences reading Stephen Coonts -- but along with THE ASSASSIN, this one is really good and among my favorites in the military/spy genre. THE DISCIPLE is a great espionage thriller and relevant to many real-world events that dominate the news today. Tommy Carmellini and Jake Grafton are great characters and Coonts was at the top of his game when writing them in this novel.

This is an interesting and timely thriller that tackles extraordinary rendition and black site interrogations by the CIA. Wells is a remarkable and complex character -- American hero, convert to Islam, covert CIA operative -- and author Alex Berenson brilliantly constructs an all-too-real scenario that brings into conflict everything that Wells is and/or believes. Berenson is a gifted writer and the John Wells series is second only to Daniel Silva/Gabriel Allon in the spy/thriller/action genre.

This is a violent book with a lot of bullets, but it would be a mistake to categorize it as simply an action book. Cole is always snarky and Pike is the ultimate tough guy, but above everything else the Cole/Pike books—and TAKEN especially—are about loyalty and friendship.Longtime readers will know that Pike always keeps his Jeep pristine … but Cole with his Corvette? Not so much. There is a beautifully written scene in this book where Cole is missing and Pike is in limbo waiting for something to do—and he washes Cole’s Corvette. It illustrates perfectly the many layers and complexities of this novel. It’s not only about the bullets.If you are an Elvis Cole/Joe Pike fan then all you really need to know about this book are two words: “Got you.” Pike is the one talking, and the first 300-plus pages are worth reading just to set-up this one statement.If you are not already an Elvis Cole/Joe Pike fan … then you should buy this book, because you’re missing out on an incredible series.

This is my favorite Jack Ryan novel. I also think it was the last truly great Tom Clancy novel -- nothing that came after it was even close to EXECUTIVE ORDERS. The pace, plot, tension -- it's extraordinary. In fact, I've never read a thriller by any other author that had me turning pages as anxiously as this book.There's a tense, climactic scene near the end where Ryan goes on television to a live national audience -- and he's got Ding and Clark covertly inside enemy territory, coordinating a strike to decapitate the enemy command structure -- that is absolutely mind-blowing in its intensity. It is the best sequence of events that I've ever read in a thriller.I absolutely loved this book -- and highly recommend it: 5/5 emphatic stars.

Alex Berenson is an incredibly gifted writer and in John Wells he has created a protagonist that is both complex and compelling. I honestly don't think Berenson gets enough credit for the literary quality of his writing -- I absolutely loved THE FAITHFUL SPY and have read every book in the series precisely because Berenson blew me away with his ability to write a literary thriller. I highly recommend this book and the entire series: 5/5 stars.

This is my favorite Tom Clancy book. John Clark is one of the baddest good guys in contemporary thriller fiction and this is the story of how he came to be a CIA legend. A lot is happening here -- a drug and prostitution ring is trying to take over the east coast and Clark crosses their paths with devastating consequences; in Vietnam, an American POW is interrogated by a Russian colonel; and at the Pentagon, a group of senior officers plan a rescue operation. Everything comes together, and the result is an extraordinary novel.

This is one of my all-time favorite books. Stephen Hunter's Earl Swagger and Bob Lee Swagger novels are the ultimate in tough, heroic good guy fiction. In this Earl Swagger novel set in 1950s Mississippi, war hero turned state police sergeant Swagger investigates the disappearance of an old friend. It leads him to a corrupt prison and a hotbed of racism -- and after it nearly costs Swagger his life, he rounds up a posse of like-minded tough men with guns and sets out to right a few wrongs.Hunter's writing is at its absolute best in PALE HORSE COMING. It is storytelling at its absolute finest. Suspenseful and fast-paced, it is an epic battle of good vs. evil set during a very dark time in American history.I highly recommend it to crime fiction / thriller fans: definite 5/5 stars.

I believe Brad Taylor’s Taskforce stories are among the best “shorts” on the market by a noted author – and certainly in the thriller/espionage/action genre there is none better right now. Taylor is on the same level as Dean Koontz and Lee Child in terms of knowing what readers want and delivering it in a fast, exhilarating read.THE RECRUIT is a fantastic story that takes place in Peru and features Knuckles and Decoy in the early stages of Decoy’s training/career with the Taskforce. It’s not necessary to have read anything in the series to enjoy this standalone short – but returning readers will certainly appreciate the backstory and added insights into the relationship between Knuckles and Decoy and their careers as SEALs and Taskforce members.As for the plot, again, Taylor does a wonderful job here – it’s a fast read, but it’s a fully developed story with page-turning action. Knuckles has taken Decoy to Peru for a real-world training mission. They’re practicing developing and maintaining covers – and in this case they are posing as contractors at the American embassy doing work with cellular communications. And of course, they manage to stumble onto something that quickly turns a training mission into a seriously dangerous covert act.No spoilers, but Taylor actually manages to create a seriously great ending for this short. A lot of authors are accused of looking for a quick buck with minimal effort when they release kindle stories in the build-up to the release date for a new novel – but no one will be able to say that with a straight face about THE RECRUIT. This is a very satisfying short read and I’d highly recommend it to thriller/espionage/action fans: 5/5 stars.

Cass Destry is the protagonist in this outstanding new novel from author Bart Hopkins Jr. Cass is a gun carrying black belt private investigator with a fast sports car and a penchant for running long distances, fast. She’s recently divorced and this week her fast running saved her life. And as you might have read in the product description, her week is only going to get worse from there.The author does a terrific job of piling it on early in the book. It’s humorous at times but definitely ratchets up the tension as the challenges confronting Cass continue to mount. Are they all somehow related?
