Or is her luck just really that bad?Cass tells a friend she’s doing the Beach Town Boogie trying to juggle everything and stay focused and aware as a stalker and potential murderer closes in on her.This is a fast, fun read from beginning to end. But don’t think the humor is slapstick and the detective story is cliché – no, not even close. Bart Hopkins Jr. is a talented author who writes with sparse, intelligent prose. He understands language and uses it beautifully to create a world on Galveston Island that’s pretty darn close to that magical word “literary” – and I don’t say it lightly. This is a smart book with characters that overcome flaws and face challenges and develop and grow to combat dire situations.It’s artfully constructed, beautifully written, and highly entertaining.Highly recommended: 5 / 5 stars.

Arnaldur Indridason's iconic Inspector Erlendur is only a traffic cop in "Reykjavík Nights" as the author spins a mysterious and murderous tale that gives readers a glimpse at Erlendur's early career. The story explores the motivations and circumstances that led Erlendur to become a police officer and to eventually become an inspector.I think a first-time Erlendur reader will likely not be as enamored with this book as someone who is already invested in Erlendur's fictitious world.As for the plot, a homeless man is found drowned in a muddy bog but is quickly forgotten when a woman goes missing. A year later there is no progress on either case and Erlendur is inexplicably fixated on understanding what happened to the homeless man, who is named Hannibal.The more Erlendur investigates the more we glimpse his own past and begin to understand his motivations. The story flashes back to moments when Erlendur crossed paths with Hannibal while working the long Reykjavik night shift as a traffic/beat cop -- and there is one specific moment when Hannibal tires of Erlendur's intervention efforts and shouts, "What are you trying to make up for?"That's pretty much Erlendur's personal theme -- as it is for many "good guys" in fiction -- the idea that we are haunted by something in our past and it drives us to do good things in the present.I did enjoy this book, but to be honest the first half is terribly boring. The only action is secondary to the story and felt as if it was inserted because the author recognized nothing was happening. The second half is more interesting, but even as it builds to the climax there simply are not any tense moments that cause you to turn pages at a frenetic pace.

It felt like the author was going for literary quality horror/mystery/suspense ... But I just didn't see it. There were a number of glaring formatting/grammatical errors as well.In the beginning, the protagonist Rath is trying to butcher a deer he killed while hunting, but Rath has back issues and the deer sits in the barn for two weeks until it's frozen to the floor. And I swear the author is either trying to make Rath human to readers in a really bizarre way or he's going for some kind of weird allegory -- but he keeps coming back to this deer throughout the book as a mechanism to introduce the next "twist."It was just very strange, for lack of a better word.Rath also had a habit of breaking one complete sentence into several fragments like: “It’s Dad. Just. Being Dad.” Which was fine, except suddenly every character in the book started talking this way.He's interviewing a witness who answers his question with: “Envy may be a sin. But. I’m only human."Soon other detectives are doing it: "Mandy might show any second. But. I don’t like it.”The "monster" and various suspects all do it as well.This might be the reason other reviewers have noted it felt like the author was talking the whole time instead of his characters -- because in fact there was no difference in the narrative and the dialogue with regard to syntax, cadence and etc. Essentially the characters sounded the same, lacked depth and substance, and it was very difficult to care about them.I know other reviewers have mentioned they felt put-off by the characters judging and ranting and railing against the pro-life mindset -- and I agree it felt like the author's viewpoint rather than the characters -- but in fairness Rath also went off against "liberals" for paroling violent criminals and allowing them to hurt more innocent people. But obviously pro-life thinkers are not monsters any more than people who identify as liberal want violent criminals on the street to do more harm. The narrative and characters were very judgmental and quick to label people and mindsets in negative ways -- but ironically the characters themselves were poorly drawn cliches.The plot ... It was ok, not horrible. At times it felt suspenseful, but I never reached the point where I had to keep reading to find out what was going to happen. In fact, it ends with a cliffhanger that's obviously meant to set up a sequel ... But I don't care enough about the characters to stick with them for a second book.I would have a hard time recommending this book to anyone when there are much better options for investing your time: 2/5 stars.

This was my first time reading Olen Steinhauer. ALL THE OLD KNIVES is incredibly well written and I plan to read some of the author's previous work as a result.The dialogue and narrative prose are sparse, sharp and witty. The characters are memorable and interesting. The plot and pacing are also excellent. It centers around a terrorist incident at the airport in Vienna, Austria. Five years after the fact, a CIA agent meets his former lover -- who is also former CIA -- for dinner to interview her regarding the events of that fateful night.The story moves back and forth from the present dinner to the night of the terrorist attack -- and the author does so with tremendous skill, as he builds toward a dramatic conclusion.I very much enjoyed the book. It's a quick read, but definitely not shallow.However, there are a couple of things I didn't like. The way CIA personnel are depicted on the night of the terrorist attack was not credible for me and it detracted from the story. The author also created an ending that is pretty much "love it" or "hate it" territory -- but for me, after 300-plus brilliantly written pages the ending felt gimmicky and was not on par with the rest of the book. Was it clever, tense and suspenseful? Yes, but also gimmicky.Overall though it's a terrific read for fans of thrillers and spy novels: 4/5 stars.

I loved this story. Chelsea Bates has a vision and desire to create beauty and a place for rest and renewal after her mother passes away. After a short visit to Starsdale, she settles in an buys an old house intending to turn it into a Bed and Breakfast.Unfazed by the various contractors who advise her to tear it down, she ends up meeting a retired builder named John who takes on the project. The two of them down care that everyone in town things they're crazy. They stick together even when John's son comes home and gets suspicious of Chelsea.Meanwhile, Chelsea's nemesis, her ex-fiance, is planning her demise.I won't give anything else away except to say that the suspense is tight, the characters are lovable, and the romance is sweet. You'll fall in love with the residents of Starsdale and wish that you could visit the architectural wonder that John leaves as his final legacy.This book deals about more than just romance and suspense, but also facing the death of loved ones. My favorite quote reminds us how we are all connected by the love we share which can transcend physical death.“Some call it energy, some say it’s spirit, but I believe it’s the love that people share that keeps them connected, even after death.”― Tallulah Grace, Cliffs of Starsdale

You will simply love Paisley and Malachi. These two were destined to love each other and their sweet innocent way of coming together despite Paisley's health and overprotective parents just makes you love them more. Malachi is a real sweetheart and has an awesome sense of humor. He knows how to humor Paisley and her parents and lightens the moment with his big heart and cheerful outlook.However, be sure to keep tissues for the ending. I can't tell you much emotion you'll feel at the end. The love that even through the despair and grief, hope shines through, and I feel touched by this story and will never look at clouds touching the same again.

I could tell from the very first page that Colorado Hope was going to be a rollicking fun read. Charlene Whitman immediately puts her goody-two-shoes, freaking-adorable, lovey-dovey couple in danger. Then she cuts away to her villain, Lenora Dutton who is hilarious in her self-talk, using words like nosiree, just dandy, skeedaddle, dunderhead, and sniggering or snickering with a mouth full of snark as she plots her nefarious deeds.You just know that their paths will cross and that Lenora's going to be an outrageously bad girl with a heart full of evil as she plots against the good, angelic Grace who happens to blond, and Lenora has dark hair. Meanwhile, confused Monty or Malcolm is acting like a dunderhead or Dudley Do Right, and even though you want Grace and Monty to get back together, you enjoy seeing the tricks Lenora plays on Monty, until it gets to be too much.While Monty rides to the rescue, Lenora figures she'd skeedaddle off with the gold. Well, I won't spoil the ending, but this is a very entertaining Western and brings you right back to the old Western stories and movies. I can practically picture the posse riding after the outlaws.I also love, love, loved, the minor characters, Clare, Eli, LeRoy, and Sarah. I can't wait for the novella between Clare and Eli. The other characters were well done too, from the hypocritical Quaker landlady to the meek county clerk who has a crush on Grace. Finally, love, love, love little Benjamin. What a sweetie and of course the ending when all's well and justice is served fits exactly how a Western should end.It is faith based and entirely clean, not to mention a great adventure and a sweet love story. It features Fort Collins in the 1870s. The characters are amazing: sweet Grace, heroic Monty, and the Banks family, part Cheyenne and expert trackers and horsemen, then there's Clare, the amazing rider and roper, whose my favorite.The romance is also sweet and heart tugging and everything ends happily with a lot of sentiment and good feelings. Can't wait to read more from this author.

I was really excited to find out about a digital cooking thermometer with a display and readout that sits OUTSIDE of the oven. If you know me, I hate roasting prime rib because of all the anxiety and disasters that await me. It's an expensive cut of meat and usually we don't have it unless there are guests. Some want well done and others want medium rare. Here's what usually happens. I use one of those probes that are attached to my oven, the kind that plugs directly into the oven.I set the temperature, thinking that there is ONE magical temperature where the meat will be done. I stick the probe in the center of the roast and set it to medium-rare [for beef]. What always happens is that I take it out and cut, and there's blood running from the inside.So then my family starts arguing. Some want me to return the roast to the oven. Others say let those who want well done stick their pieces in the microwave. My husband gets mad because it's an expensive piece of meat and he wants it medium, exactly with a tinge of blood but no more.I then slice off the more well-done pieces on both ends of the roast and stick it back in the oven. Meanwhile, the oven has cooled from all of the opening and closing and the roast looks awful with all of these cross cuts and pokes to test. For all about how to cook prime rib, and internal temperatures, see http://whatscookingamerica.net/Beef/ClassicPrimeRib.htm and http://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/prime_rib/The MeasuPro digital programmable cooking thermometer is a wonderful invention. It has a long, thin, braided 36 inch cord that allows the probe to be in the meat inside the oven, but the digital display and readout to be outside on the counter. It even has magnetic strips on the back so that you can store it on your refrigerator when you're not using.Using it is simple. You select the meat type you want: beef, pork, chicken, turkey, veal, lamb, ham, duck, ribs, ground beef, ground pork, ground chicken, ground turkey, ground veal, ground lamb, and preferred degree of doneness for preset internal temperature [set to USDA approved doneness level]. Stick the probe into the center of the thickest part, put the roast into the oven and close the door.The braided cord is thin enough to allow the oven to fully close. The package even includes the battery so you can try it out right away. Turn on the Audible Alert switch and there you go. There is also a pre-alert beeping that lets you know the meat is close to done. Finally a bar graph at the top displays the progress of your roast. It's too bad there is no "time estimate" so you can estimate when the meat will be cooked, but you should just use the estimate of your recipe.For this trial, I bought a four-and-a-half pound pork shoulder roast. I preheated the oven and stuck the probe into the meat about two inches deep. All I had to do was stick the roast into the oven and wait. Periodically, I'd take a look and the Measupro would tell me what the internal temperature of the meat is. The preset is 170 degrees for pork even though the recipe I used said 185 degrees. You can create a customized temperature profile by following the instructions.Perfect! I let the roast sit for a little bit and removed the probe. I washed only the tip that touched the meat and hung it up on my refrigerator [using the magnetic pads on the back].From now on, I'll have perfect roasts every time.

This was a delightful YA book and a combination of a coming-of-age and a romance. Anna is dumped at a school in Paris for American kids by her parents. All she wants to do is to be home with her friend Bridge and her crush Toph in Atlanta.But she's immediately befriended by the girl-next-door, Mer, and introduced to Mer's clique (minus one), Josh, Rashmi, and Etienne St. Clair. Etienne's girlfriend, Ellie, used to be in the clique but had graduated and gone to college nearby, so Anna fills in in the foursome.The dynamics between all the members of the clique were well delineated and gradually we see Anna and St. Clair bond over daytrips around town and movies, especially cinema and American old films.I liked the book for the most part, except it seemed drawn out to me and repetitive. How many times did Anna have to bang her head on the wall because St. Clair was too dense to admit his feelings and hung onto Ellie, who was for the most part, an invisible character.The ONE thing that totally bothered me and the reason why I didn't give this a five star was the continued off-screen sexual relationship that St. Clair had with Ellie. Over and over again, he was described to go back to Ellie's place and Anna would imagine them "doing it" and get disgusted and feel sick.I feel there's a double standard going on here. If St. Clair/Etienne were the girl in the "friendship" and Anna were the guy, and it was the girl who had a boyfriend she kept doing, while leading on and flirting with the guy, the character would have been labeled a slut and readers would have been disgusted.Instead, douchebags at the school label Anna a slut for kissing another guy, Dave, when St. Clair had made it clear he was NOT interested in Anna, who determined she wasn't going to keep waiting in the wings as an "almost" girlfriend.So, even though it's probably reality that a guy can keep having sex off screen and be considered a romantic hero, whereas a girl cannot, it distresses me that no one, not even Anna, thinks it's not okay for Etienne to have physical relationships with one girl, but emotionally cheat on her with not just Anna, but another girl too [no spoiler here]. Well, there's a passing reference to Etienne feeling bad about it near the end, but in general, it was passed off as A-OK in the book.This knocked the halo off of Etienne for me, and unlike other readers, it meant I did not imagine myself falling for the Etienne's of the world. Usually I can fall for a guy who's a player, because he's made an exception for the heroine, or that the playing was in the past. But an emotional cheater, hmmm... that's more insidious than a plain old player, you know, because in many ways, emotional cheating is much, much worse. So, even though the story has the typical happy ending, it came SO late and the school year was about to finish, that I had a hard time getting invested in the romance. It was more like, okay, is this car wreck going to happen or not?Anyway, I did enjoy the overall story and love the virtual travel of being in Paris. I will read the next book because it's based in San Francisco and Berkeley, which is where I live, so I'm interested to see what the author has done with my city.

Vera Rios is a single mother, a doctor, and lonely. But she doesn't have time for dating or relationships, especially when she's coparenting her daughter with her not so nice ex-husband.During her volunteer hours at a free clinic, she runs into Rowan who's getting screened for STD's and charms her into a date. The only problem? She thinks he's a male escort.Vera fights her attraction to Rowan, but who can resist such male pulchritude? She falls for him, only to discover he's hiding some horrible secrets, the type that can cause her to lose her daughter.What is love worth to Vera? Can Rowan clear his name? Read Aroused and find out.What struck me most in reading Jade Kerrion's romance debut is the clear, clean writing and gut-wrenching plot. There are no wasted words, and the pacing is fast and engaging. I'm really excited about the Life Shocks series and will be reading more.

This was a nice story about a woman running a charity for feeding the hungry and at the same time running away from personal relationships.Stacy's biggest worry is funding for her charity. So she enters a dance contest to try and win money to tide the charity over the winter. Along comes a real estate developer named Joe who has decided he wants more out of life than work and money. He tries to win Stacy's heart but she does not want to let him in due to the issues she has with her father.The romance portion of the story was cute, but not developed well enough. Instead we got a great story about Stacy working on the dance contest, the little "twist" at the end, and then some tension and everything is resolved.I'm not really sure that Stacy should just drop everything and trust Joe just because he volunteers at the gardens. But since the author was probably given guidelines of the length of the story [i.e. could not exceed a certain number of pages/words], she has to resolve the love story too quickly.It doesn't take away the enjoyment of reading about the heroines who help her community, but as a romance, it was light and on the surface.

I love how Colie and Grant had such a great friendship, but she kept missing the signals and tried to stay "professional" between them, even when he invited her to live at his house during spring training.However when Jace, Colie's ex, wants to see more of her, Colie is excited and swept off her feet. She also misses all the signals of how Jace is not right for her, controlling and arrogant.Meanwhile, there's Grant, trying to hold onto the friendship. Well, I won't give the story away, of course. It's a fun and sweet story and eventually, Grant figures out the right pitch to right all the wrongs.Full of fun and interesting characters. I can't wait for more baseball romances from Ms. Layne. Batter up!

Hot second chance romance. The backdrop of this book is a adoption fundraiser for a no-kill shelter. At the end of the day, a poor little sweet Chinese crested dog is left over. Ron, wanting a second chance at Cara, the woman running the adoption, volunteers to take the little dog home, provided she come along to help the dog get settled.That was just the pretext for Ron and Cara to fulfill all their fantasies. The action was hot and steamy, and funny.

I'm not usually a fan of virgin sexpots and at first this book seemed to head that direction. Rory Carmichael has escaped her strict grandmother and great aunt from her comfortable, but constraining suburban home to the big city of Chicago. However she wasn't truly striking out on her own because her grandmother found her a place to live with the son of her doctor, a family friend.Alec, the hunk with the house, is a reforming bad boy. For one thing, he's put himself on a celibacy diet after his little head gets him fired from an important job. Obviously sparks fly when they meet.The story was predictable and I would have not liked it as much if it weren't for the subplot, where Rory is looking for her long lost twin sister Michaela who ran away from home 10 years ago.Believe it or not, I would have rather had less sex stuff and more on the relationship between the sisters, but sometimes it felt like Rory forgot about her quest for her sister. It got better near the end, but because this was a short Blaze romance, the author was probably told not to explore more fully the dynamics of the sisters.I'm going forward to read the next book Up To No Good which is about Michaela, the long lost sister.

This modern Beauty and the Beast story is captivating and endearing. Archer's a hero you just can't help but side with. Everything's been against him his entire life, and he's become a recluse, a man the small town of Pelion shuns.Bree Prescott is running from her past and the visions that haunt her. She ends up in Pelion and immediately runs into Archer who mutely helps her when she dropped her items coming out of a drugstore.Soon, she finds out he's considered strange and that no one seems to know anything about him. But Bree is a woman of compassion and curiosity, and her attempts to make friends with Archer are heartwarming and full of possibilities.You can't help but get drawn into their love story. Only Bree can see Archer for the man he is, but he has been isolated so long that he doesn't have the confidence to deal with society. Meanwhile, Archer's cousin, the town sheriff, is determined to get his way with Bree by cutting Archer down every chance he gets, as well as leading Archer astray.I won't give the rest of the story away, but the villains do their best to ruin Archer and Bree's life.Watching Archer unfold and grow from the ruined, destroyed soul he was to a strong, confident hero was the best part of this novel. As well as the hot and frequent steamy love scenes as Bree awakens his dormant passion and desire.I love this story, especially how Bree kept going to his gate and slowly getting acquainted with him, even when he was so unsure and antisocial. A 5-star coming of age love story and a definite keeper!

This was a very interesting compilation of the lives of pro basketball playing wives. It was full of drama and intersecting story lines and personal tragedies. However because of the parallel subplots, it skipped all over the place, from one character to another character and some of the transitions were confusing. Like who are we talking about now?In any case, the book reads like a gossip column and provided some insights into the lives of the super rich and famous athletes and their women and problems. However the plot was fairly predictable and a lot of the issues opened up were brushed under at the end, for example, the violent past one of the wives hid caused her a lot of heartache and post traumatic stress. It was like, time for the story to finish and everything resolved heartily.The villains were also cardboard and pure evil and again, everything was resolved neatly without too much fuss once they were exposed.

If you can buy the "love at first sight" then the rest of the story was sweet, cute, and endearing. Avery, our prickly heroine, runs down the hallway and bumps into Cam, almost doing a faceplant, except he's there to help her. He almost runs her down with his truck for their next meeting, and then it turns out he lives across the hall in her apartment building.With that out of the way, Cam is like the perfect book boyfriend, loyal, quick to forgive, and persistent. He plays friend for most of the semester and every time Avery runs from him or cuts him off, he comes by and tries to talk to her. It helps that he has a huge ego and is not as easily hurt or demoralized by a woman who constantly turns him down and makes snide remarks about him.Without seeing his point of view, we don't have a clue why he is enamored with Avery. Sure, she's probably pretty, but there are pretty girls everywhere on college campuses. We don't know if he's aware that she has psychological problems. There's no indication he is clued in at first. Avery's best friend Brittney is a psych major and suspects something, but Avery is able to hide from her questions too well for anything to really come out.It was pretty easy for the reader to see that Avery had been sexually abused. This is a common trope in New Adult literature, and I was eager to see how this author handled it, particularly since a lot of stories use it for shock value and then pass it off as easily solved by hot, hunky, boyfriend who melts heroine's resistance.Ms. Lynn develops the story better than most. Avery is damaged and exhibits avoidance. She is also uncomfortable with certain positions and wonders how she'd respond if he tries to take things too fast, which he doesn'tThe ending is satisfactory since Avery confronts her ghosts and resolves her feelings for Cam. Of course, who wouldn't? He really is a knight in shining armor. I, at least, couldn't see any flaws in him. Even his supposed secret was justified and made Avery wish she had someone who cared about her that much [which she does now, but not before]I did notice quite a few editing problems, garbled sentences and typos. One even changed the meaning of the sentence when Cam said he "hadn't" been with anyone else, the typo said "had".

What a steal! Read them at the gym, in the subway, on the beach. These three fun and sweet books are a steal! I love the authors' voices and the humorous way the love stories unfold. Pick them up now while they're 99c and enjoy!Here are my reviews:[Cover (Story) Girl by Chris Mariano]Way too delightful opposites attract story. Min He and Gio couldn't be more different. He is a staid, solid, if not quite boring museum curator, and she's a colorful mysterious Korean girl prone to fantasies and make believe. But their romance develops despite their differences and each brings color and perspective to the other. Cover (Story) Girl is one of the most enjoyable stories I've read lately and I finished it in a few hours, staying up late into the night. It is also one of the few romances written in the male point of view. You'll come to love Gio, even if you think he's a stick in the mud at the beginning.I can't wait to read more by this author. I also enjoyed learning about the culture on Boracay Island.[Vintage Love by Agay Llanera]What a delightful book. I was sucked in from the very first line, "Life is full of expiration dates."When Chrissy's favorite grand-aunt, Mama Maring, dies and leaves behind a house full of vintage clothes, collectibles and furniture, Chrissy and her BFF, Bea, decide to hold a rummage sale to raise money for a well deserved vacation.The two friend meet an arrogant young man, Vince, who looked over Mama Maring's things as if they were fakes trying to rip him off. Chrissy is chagrined that such a beautiful face could be wasted on an ass. However, when they go to consign the rest of the loot, the store they walk into belong to none other than Vince and his father.Uh oh! I won't give it away except to say that the story is fun to read, the side characters are colorful, Chrissy is a heroine you want to root for, and Vince becomes more endearing as the story goes on.What I like the most is Miss Llanera's voice and the way she tells the story in a cheerful, humorous manner. I enjoyed this book and read it in one sitting. I definitely will look forward to more stories from Miss Llanera.[All's Fair in Blog and War by Chrissie Peria]I've been enjoying light-hearted Filipina romances and this is one of the cutest. Five Cuevas and competing blogger Jesse Ruiz have been invited by the Macau tourism board on a complimentary trip to Macau for publicity purposes. Five takes an instant dislike to the arrogant, stuffy Jesse who exudes superiority with his every gesture. He's the one with the hot shot camera, the expert in advertising, the know-it-all. But things change when Cuevas has a late night fright and ends up in Jesse's room. Not only were they assigned to be travel buddies together, but they enjoy being side-tracked to the less well-traveled areas on Cueva's sister's list, and a super kilig midnight photo shoot in front of an abandoned church.I've never been to Macau, but after reading this book, I have a hankering to go, especially if I get to be travel buddies with a handsome, sexy blog buddy. The descriptions are awesome, the food is to be inhaled, and the fun adventures make you feel like you're right there with them. It turns out to be a really sweet story and a happy read.

Genetically altered humans? Can too much of a good thing be bad?Lexus' thought her father had solved all the problems of being human. He had successfully engineered a Perfect human, born with no disease or genetic defect. The only thing, it doesn't work 100% of the time, and Lexus herself was one of the ones who "didn't take."Born as a Native in a Perfect world, Lexus is sheltered from the discrimination faced by Natives until she walks into a frightful scene. After she escapes her father's compound, she meets two Perfects who befriend her. Gabby is an awesome friend and character who takes her under her wing and Tanner is an ultra hot man who is totally swoonworthy.However even being friends with Perfects does not make Lexus' life easy. She experiences firsthand the great divide between Perfects and Natives and realizes how fine that boundary line is when her friend is injured. Because in a world of Perfects, one single flaw will cast you off the throne of privilege to live the rest of your life as a Native.A chilling book that says a lot about society. Highly recommended.

From the first page, tension sizzled as Max meets Rose after being jailed many years for her sister's murder. Rose is not sure what to make of Max, but all the unresolved feelings make it hard for her to ignore him.Add an overprotective sheriff and a town full of potential suspects, and we're off on a wild ride to figure out who REALLY murdered Rose's sister and who is after Rose right now.The action is fast and nonstop, gluing me to the pages until the wee hours of the night. What I liked about this story was that Rose was brave enough to give Max a second chance even when evidence pointed to him as still being a danger to her.The ending is a big surprise, but after looking back through the clues, it all made sense. Chantel Rhondeau does twisted villains so well. She'll have you looking over your shoulder at the ordinary people you think you know so well, but don't really. The stuff of nightmares?Pick up this book, but start reading early in the day, because you won't be able to put it down! Guaranteed.

Americanah follows the life of Ifemelu, a young Nigerian woman of Igbo origin who immigrates to America because it was the country her boyfriend, Obinze, admires.Predictably enough, Ife and Obinze end up going in separate paths, even though they had truly believed they were in love and had planned on marrying.The story jumps between Ife's life in America and contrasts it with Obinze's stay in England. While Ife succeeds in getting a sponsored green card and makes a successful career for herself in America, Obinze is an illegal alien who is eventually deported.Both Ife and Obinze are great observers, the silent types that analyze and catalog the behaviors of the people around them. This allows the author to make a lot of observations and present them to her readers.Through Ifemelu, we learn of the shock she felt when she realized that in America, she was black, and that every interaction she has with people in America was tinged with race, primarily skin color and hair texture. Her observations led her to write a blog about race and the observations of a Non American Black (NAB) on the condition of the American Black. She learned to be politically correct, to be offended by statements she didn't quite understand and to be interested in issues faced by American Blacks, even though she did not identify with them.Ifemelu's journey includes the obligatory White boyfriend, one who embodied Adichie's personification of White Privilege. Curt, otherwise known as the Hot White Ex was always optimistic, cheerful, entitled, and overly solicitous of her. Once, when an owner of a beauty salon said to Ifemelu, 'we don't do curly,' Curt loudly complained and made a scene, forcing the salon to perform their services. Ifemelu, meanwhile, feared they would do a horrible job. Later, she expounds that cross cultural relationships were too full of explanations and doubted that if it hadn't been for the explanations, if there were really anything to be said. She destroys the relationship by sleeping with another man.Next, she is in a relationship with Professor Hunk, an American Black. He is just a little too perfect, and much too polished to be real. Careful, fastidious and very judgmental, Blaine, or Professor Hunk, made sure Ifemelu ate non-GMO foods, did not waste her apple cores, and molded her thoughts and feelings to contemporary issues. He and his cohort of friends had a singular way of thinking, of viewing society and the country, and every thought Ifemelu had was measured against this standard. It was another stifling relationship, and again, Ifemelu took out the sledgehammer and destroyed it.All along, there was the thread in the background of Ife and Obinze's dealings, how they could be real and understood each other. Obinze observes how phony his classmates become when they marry, how they suddenly are interested in art collections or antique furniture, how effected the airs they take on. But he, too, has become corrupted, by taking a wife he does not love, but is a beauty queen, and going through the rituals of parties, and celebrations in the Nigerian high society.When Ifemelu returns to Nigeria, she avoids Obinze for as long as she could. However, as soon as they are together again, they rekindle their friendship and love. For to love is to be heard, seen, known, and understood. To not wear masks, and pretend to be what you're not. To be happy with what you are.Obinze: You know what I have felt for so long? As if I was waiting to be happy.Ifemelu: She had never had this before, to be listened to, to be truly heard, and so he became newly precious.And this, really, is the theme of Americanah, that of being authentic in a land of pretense, of seeing the truth and speaking it, because otherwise, you exist, "trudging through lives in which they were neither happy nor unhappy."To Ifemelu, authenticity is in Nigeria, in the land and soil and culture of your upbringing, among people who truly get you, and with whom you do not have to pretend.America, in many ways, is a dream, a concept, an idealization of the way things should be, but rarely are.Chimamanda summarizes America as follows:The best thing about America is that it gives you space. I like that. I like that you buy into the dream, it's a lie but you buy into it and that's all that matters.

This is a hot romance full of passion, anguish, and pain. It's heartwarming but dangerous. There's nothing tame about Morgan and Shay, not their lifestyles, their past hurts, and their determination to protect the ones they love.Block out some time, and arm yourself with tissues and a tranquilizer gun. This story will tear you up, raise your blood pressure, and have you shaking your fists. The Razor's Edge is a fine line between pleasure and pain.

I'll never go back to metal muffin pans. I poured my favorite muffin recipe into the pan. I lengthened the baking time by about 25% because the silicon doesn't transfer heat as well as the metal, but the bonus is no burnt bottoms. The mini muffins popped out clean and easy. The pan is very flexible so you can push the muffins out from underneath once everything has cooled. Great for making all those mini snacks that are so popular these days.

Rachel and Grant are both married to the wrong people. But despite their mutual attraction, they stand on principles and upload their values, even in the face of dastardly betrayal. Events conspire to force them to repeatedly cross paths, starting with the fact their children are dating. However both of them stand firm and do not take the easy way out.What I liked about Distorted Loyalty is the fierce conviction on Rachel’s part to be honest with those around her. Grant, while having equally strong convictions, is afraid to face his own feelings of inadequacy and rejection.  Many times, Rachel could have taken a less noble road, but she knew that any relationship based on dishonesty would end up in disaster.The other refreshing thing about this story is the emotional maturity of the hero and heroine. Even though they have a slew of problems that keep them apart, none of it is based on immaturity, silly misunderstandings and overreactions—the stuff you see in other romance novels. Instead, these are real people dealing with overwhelming problems. They are tempted, but do not fall into bed or do things that they would be ashamed of or regret. This book shows that not every romance book has to have sex and flowers, but that a love based on emotional strength is more likely to last and be satisfying for a lifetime.

This is it girls! The long awaited sequel to Finding Forever. Morgan has made her way back to Ben and what she imagines is a perfect life happily ever after.But the heightened emotions of the reunion get drowned in doubt and jealousy. Not everyone is happy that Morgan is back, least of all a woman who had her eyes on Ben.Unbeknownst to Morgan she stirs up trouble, causing enormous heartache and grief. However Morgan sticks to the project, learning to live in Paradise City and following its rules. She's giving up everything from her past life for Ben and she is determined to make it work.There are a lot of emotional ups and downs that will make you feel deeply for the characters. At the end, you can't help but smile.

At first I was skeptical that something which looks plastic can survive in an oven. It was floppy and you can actually fold it in half. However it can withstand up to 480 degrees F and 250 degrees C.The pan is clean and smooth. Because it is floppy, you should put it on a cookie sheet before filling the batter. It makes it easy and safe to place into the oven and remove.My muffins baked evenly without sticking. I didn't spray any oil or butter the bottom of pan. In fact, the little globs of spillage which usually burns onto a metal pan flaked right off.Once the muffins cooled, it was easy to push them out by using your finger underneath. I didn't try shaking them out, but I bet that works too. Everything peels away, including the little edges that got caught on top, so your muffins are uniform, round and clean.Simply shake it out and stick it in the dishwasher.Another use for the silicone tin is to use it like an ice tray to freeze soup bases and stock. Since it is floppy, you don't have to knock it to pop out the cubes. Simple push out the frozen sauce into a baggie. If you made a lot of tomato soup, or baby food, you can easily pop out serving sized pieces and thaw.This is a very versatile product and makes me want to throw out my old, rusted or scratched muffin tins.One more IMPORTANT note for bird owners. Teflon (non-stick) muffin pans are dangerous to birds. Better to use the silicone ones.

Both Major Pettigrew, a 68-year old widower and Mrs. Ali, a widow are highly observant and quick with droll remarks, much of which is lost on the the clueless buffoons at their small village of Edgecombe St. Mary's.The book opens with the death of the Major's only brother Bertie. Seems the Pettigrews owned a matching pair of Churchill shotguns that was bestowed to them by a grateful Indian prince for rescuing a princess, the stuff of family tales and legends. The Major's main concern was reuniting the pair of Churchills, one which went to Bertie and the other to the Major upon his father's passing.Mrs. Ali shows up in the first scene at the Major's door to collect paper money, but he is in an embarrassing state of underdress and fainting because his brother has just died. She quickly and efficiently handles him and they bond over their love of literature.When Mrs. Ali laughs, the Major thought it sounded like singing, and there begins a friendship that has the village gossiping about how unseemly it is.The Major is more concerned about his guns, which represents old England, the last days of the Raj, than about the people around him. An endless stream of frustrations and irritations in the form of his social-climbing son, Roger, the neighbors and members of the golf club, the other single women in the village with suitable English parentage, the vicar and his wife, his sister-in-law, and Mrs. Ali's impetuous nephew Abdul Wahid are thrown across his path.His feelings for Mrs. Ali deepen, but at the darkest moment, his concern over the guns overshadows his gallantry and he allows ... [okay, will stop here so there are no spoilers]Read the book. It's is full of dry humor and drama, and you can't help but pull for the Major to take the blinders off his eyes and see what is in front of him.

I've read all three of H. Elliston's romantic thrillers. My favorite one is Tick Tock Run. Elliston will keep you guessing and you never know what to expect. I love the choreography of the fight scenes and the touch of romance is sweet too.All of these books are an exciting romp, a wild ride, and not ordinary at all. It's all very enjoyable and even humorous in places.The boxed set is a great value.

Ms. Esguerra is a fantastic storyteller. She'll capture you from the very first page when Jasmine meets Lena and Marjorie to ask her to prevent their "shared" ex, Zack, from marrying the woman of his nightmares.In a series of back and forth flashbacks, we realize that Jasmine and Zack were never "just friends" or "fake exes," only Jasmine was and is too clueless to do a thing about it, even when Zack is days away from marrying a vamp who'd make Cruella De Ville seem domesticated.Jasmine's final stunt is the stuff of legends, but rather than spoil it for you here, you'll just have to enjoy reading it for yourself. Ms. Esguerra's characters are fresh, innocent, and adorable, and you'll soon be cheering for everyone as they nudge, prod, arrange, and pinch the two unlikely lovers into the sack.After developing so many vivacious side characters, Ms. Mina owes us more stories for Marjorie, Lena, Ramon, and Chesca, oh, and Harry as well. Poor Harry, even though he's from another book (That Kind of Guy), I still want him to win one at the end.

The Lost Flower is a multi-faceted story of intersecting lives. Lacy Stone is on a journey to find the source of her vision. Sampaguita Navarro has a dream but no confidence in her abilities to achieve them. Alejandro is torn between his love for Sampaguita and God. Adam Shaw is running from his past, and Frankie Lloyd is seeking closure to right past wrongs.Five people with five secrets collide on the white sand beach of Boracay, idyllic on the surface, but simmering with resentment and conflict between the resort developers and displaced natives, the Aetas. Lacy and Adam are the interlopers, but they have the money and the power. Sampguita and her family are the losers, but their paths cross in an explosive manner.I truly enjoyed this story and could not put it down. There is so much story packed into this book. It is fast paced, perhaps too fast. The scenes flew by with lots of actions and happenings. This is not a family saga equivalent to Hawaii, but a wonderful tale about ideals, love, loyalty, and sacrifice all set in the backdrop of an island paradise. Highly recommend.

I'm on a roadtrip and my husband is driving. I have two iPads, a kindle, two laptops, 3 paperbacks, and what do I read? That Kind of Guy, a feel-good, sweet, and twisted romance between Anton, the smooth hunky-dory player and Julie, manang extraordinaire, the perpetual big sister who gives everyone else love advice and predicts doom and gloom for all their relationships.When faced with a choice between Anton, sexy alpha-playa Mr. Wrong who acts differently with Julie than any other woman, and Harry, nice-beta literary type who is understanding and loyal, what does Manang Julie do?Well, I won't tell. You'll just have to go on this sweet little adventure and see for yourself. Trust me. Start reading and you won't drop the book until you find out.

This is a delightful if somewhat long, drawn-out story about a 30 year old Asian woman who is being pressured to find a boyfriend by her domineering grandmother. While the tastes of Chinese/Japanese culture sprinkled throughout the book was pretty cool, the story never gets deeper than the surface conflicts, a lot of which seem made up just to cause Lex, the heroine, more pain, embarrassment, and disappointment.Lex is supposed to be an ultra fit volleyball player, but she comes across as clumsy, prickly, and has the worst luck. She is also suffering from PTSD from a past experience with men, but the author only hints at it through the first half of the book. Although she makes great progress in her friendship with Aiden, she never really gets too close to him, and their interaction is limited to a lot of bantering, mock cut-downs,and competitiveness.Aiden really is a great guy, but the author does not let him really see or understand what Lex has been through. He and Lex never discuss the main impediment to her ability to build a relationship with a man. Instead, the author rushes the finish with a vague understanding of two things that are very important to Lex, whether Aiden has received Christ as his Savior [this was never made clear, only that he went to the church and spoke to the pastor], and dealing with her PTSD.Instead, she went into great detail on the MRI, the orthoscopic surgery and recovery, and all of the pain and suffering Lex goes through in losing her dream of playing volleyball at a professional club. I felt letdown at the end. The second injury seemed unnecessary, and nothing really was resolved about Lex's job, her knee, and even her temporary living arrangement. Instead, they force a victory on Granny by having Aiden declare he is her boyfriend in the last few pages.I felt shortchanged in not being shown Lex and Aiden talk about their relationship and experience the affection they had for each other. The other thing I found odd was Lex's father's detachment to his daughter when she was injured and in need of help. If she were my daughter, she'd be living in my house during her recovery, and not on her own in a ratty, one bedroom, ground floor apartment in a sketchy neighborhood. The family did not seem truly caring of each other, and all the members, with the exception of cousin Venus, seemed to be detached and manipulative, or maybe designed to give Lex maximum frustration. But in any case, it didn't leave me with a good, happy family feeling.

This book was ultrasweet, giving you all the delicious tingly sugared halo-halo feelings the entire ride. Matteo is deadly cute with light blue hair and Carlisle is too smart and too skittish for her own happiness. I love the geology jokes, nerd humor, the outrageously awesome notebook Matteo kept about his experiment on getting Carlisle to fall in love with him. The Evil Ex got his comeuppance too, and through the entire story, we see how capable Carlisle is, even while she doubted herself. I also love that she is a female programmer, although a front-end developer, she still provided the leadership to make sure the nightly builds were on track, while her douchebag boss (and Ex) took all the credit.Awesomely fun book. I can't wait to see what Ms. Tan comes up with next.

I've been enjoying light-hearted Filipina romances and this is one of the cutest. Five Cuevas and competing blogger Jesse Ruiz have been invited by the Macau tourism board on a complimentary trip to Macau for publicity purposes. Five takes an instant dislike to the arrogant, stuffy Jesse who exudes superiority with his every gesture. He's the one with the hot shot camera, the expert in advertising, the know-it-all. But things change when Cuevas has a late night fright and ends up in Jesse's room. Not only were they assigned to be travel buddies together, but they enjoy being side-tracked to the less well-traveled areas on Cueva's sister's list, and a super kilig midnight photo shoot in front of an abandoned church.I've never been to Macau, but after reading this book, I have a hankering to go, especially if I get to be travel buddies with a handsome, sexy blog buddy. The descriptions are awesome, the food is to be inhaled, and the fun adventures make you feel like you're right there with them. It turns out to be a really sweet story and a happy read.

This is a hot romantic suspense with not one, but two couples. There's Gillian and Drew, who are forced to work together when Gillian is hired to reform Drew's public image. Apparently he is too rough on the press and uses too many curse words. Then there is Audrey and Brett, who are on opposing sides to the MMA (Mixed Martial Arts) scene.Audrey runs an organization that is against violent sports, and Brett, of course is the fighter with the heart of gold.The storylines intersect around the villain, Millie, who works for Audrey as a reporter for the organization. She has had a run in with Drew Black and is out to get him.Both couples are immediately attracted to each other. Where Gilliam and Drew's interaction is confrontational and sizzling, Brett and Audrey are sweet and endearing. There is a lack of romantic tension to both couples. They like each other and are willing to see the good in each other.The tension comes from the villain and the acts of violence, bomb threat, hit and run, fire bomb, and shooting, all aimed at a vendetta against Drew. There really weren't any other suspects than the obvious one, so while the story was interesting, it was predictable and not suspenseful enough. Brett easily forgave Audrey, and Gillian easily went along with whatever schemes Drew proposed. The entire plot felt choreographed, where you knew that the only reason they went outside all together was to allow the villain the chance to get in a potshot.The love scenes were really good, and it was interesting how the two couples contrasted each other.

I happen to like Kimmy Domingo, the heroine written so the reader can hate her and be pleased that she is hurt and damaged. But then, I'm American and I think Kimmy is just brutally honest and has no time for fakery and conventions.Yes, she was selfish as far as ignoring her mother and friends while on her "gap year." And as I suspected, she was ultimately the cause of her groom ditching her, and was not a hapless victim of circumstances.She was self-centered, blamed people without understanding them, and didn't bother to look beyond their immediate effect on her. Reminds me of Rachelle Ayala's heroine Evie Sanchez.However once she understood the true nature of her relationships with her best girlfriend, her mother, and her childhood love, she realized she needed to see and understand others and change her ways. This delightful story of growing up, reconciliations, and understanding means Kimmy will no longer run from her problems, but stay and rebuild the relationships that are important to her.In the end, I loved the way Kimmy's warped friendship with Chesca was portrayed and resolved, as well as the ever loyal Isabel, and that Kimmy and Manolo have decided to try again as grownups with open communication and understanding as the goal.

Shelley Daniels is as tough as they come. She's a secret agent on vacation, recovering from a gunshot wound, and she's sworn off casual sex.Gavin Hart is a thief on the run. He witnessed a murder and now the crooks are after him. He crashes into Shelley's opera booth and convinces her to help him escape his enemies. It turns out they are the very ones who shot Shelley in her last job.Both Shelley and Gavin have had traumatic childhoods and have been unlucky in love. However, as they are on the run together they have to pretend to be closer than they actually are.What I really liked about this story is the unfolding of the romance between Shelley and Gavin. She's the tough one and he's the sensitive one. She knows how to shoot guns and he doesn't know how to handle one. But Gavin has skills too, those having to do with stealth, climbing, and sneaking. And somehow he sneaks into her guarded heart.I also enjoyed the humor and minor characters in this book. Shelley is smart-mouthed and knows how to throw an insult. Meanwhile, a confused grandmother figure and a frightened little girl capture your heart as they endear themselves to Gavin and Shelley.The only thing I have to warn you is that this book is a trap. I stayed up until 3:00 am to finish it because I just had to know what happened next. But it was worth it. The ending was satisfying and I can't wait for the next installment of Agents in Love.I received an ARC from the author for an honest review.

Min He and Gio couldn't be more different. He is a staid, solid, if not quite boring museum curator, and she's a colorful mysterious Korean girl prone to fantasies and make believe. But their romance develops despite their differences and each brings color and perspective to the other. Cover (Story) Girl is one of the most enjoyable stories I've read lately and I finished it in a few hours, staying up late into the night. It is also one of the few romances written in the male point of view. You'll come to love Gio, even if you think he's a stick in the mud at the beginning.I can't wait to read more by this author. I also enjoyed learning about the culture on Boracay Island.

This was a frightening recounting of the author's relationship with an abusive man. I was hoping to find more hints on how to predict when a man would become abusive, but from what the author wrote, it is hard to tell. Conor was charming and sweet, knowing how to play to Leslie's vulnerabilities. It was not until he got her in a committed relationship that signs of violence showed up. In some sense, he felt she was already trapped. Trapped by love, trapped by convention, and trapped by her own pride of not wanting to admit her relationship wasn't perfect. One of the signs was that she paid for and bought her own engagement ring because she wanted her family and friends to think of him as a knight in shining armor. In that sense, she colluded with him to keep his behavior toward her secret.In retrospect, the clues were small, overreaction when a male friend called her and possessiveness when other men spoke to her. Although Leslie's story is not easy to tell, it is helpful to women to know that ordinary people get reeled into abusive relationships and that it is no their fault for being clueless or somehow inviting it.

Hannah is an ordinary but not quite ordinary teenager at a private college when she is drafted by Quin the sun god to sub for the Goddess of Love. Hannah immediately has a crush on Quin. Who wouldn't? When he's the sun god and paints with lights and shadows?In the first two books, Hannah fixes things up for the students in Ford River College, but in book three, her own love life heats up. There's Robbie, a normal guy, basketball player and very charming. Unbeknownst to Robbie, Hannah can read his every thought, how much he admires her, how worried he is that she won't go out with him, how carefully he plans his date with her and then there's the LOVE LETTER. Swooon!!!If I was Team Diego in the first book and "eh" in the second book, I'm definitely Team Robbie in this one. Robbie is man enough to love a goddess in training, put himself out there, and not play the doormat. When Hannah is caught in Quin's arms and tries to throw Robbie a bone, he refuses it and walks away despite his broken heart.Meanwhile Hannah and Quin and the missing Goddess of Love sort things out with the interference of Vida, the Moon Goddess and Diego, God of the Sea, bent on getting revenge on Quin for a lost lover.Hannah makes some bold decisions and realizes the visions and dreams she sees in her mind are not of her past but of something else. And when you become a goddess, you now have eternity.[spoilers below]But Robbie. He only has this one life. In choosing between now and forever, Hannah makes a deal with Quin. She was born a human, a mortal, and please can she experience this one life with this one mortal without her goddess powers [means she can no longer read Robbie's mind nor control his actions or send him thought waves.]With that, she leaps boldly into the unknown and exciting adventure of romantic love with no guarantees, no strings, and no backup plan, because true love can only be known by faith.I'm sad to see this series end, but it is one of my all time favorites. I only wish there will be more Hannah stories in all her many lives, and I suppose there are, because she's there in every love story experienced between two beating hearts.

Hannah Maquiling continues her clueless adventure as the Interim Goddess of love. Her mentor, and secret love interest, Quin the Sun God believes in on the job training and keeping her in the dark.As Hannah wanders around the campus of Ford River, unsure of the extent of her abilities, her best friend, Sol, comes to her for advice. It seems that things are disappearing whenever her new boyfriend, Neil, is around and she cannot figure out what is happening. Since he uses the missing money to buy her things, she's not too concerned, except she wants to get him the "help" he needs.Soon, panic overtakes the campus as other people start losing and misplacing things. Hannah has a thief to catch, but it seems he has some powerful secrets of his own! Is Hannah helpless against him? Compelled to do as he tells her? Or can the other gods, Diego and the cantankerous Vida come to her assistance?This middle book of the trilogy spins Hannah around in circles. There's the sweet mortal, Robbie, who has a crush on her, one she is intimately aware of since she can read his mind. Then there's hot, sexy, and aggressive Diego Simon, god of the sea, who has an ancient heartache of his own.Finally, we are still in the dark about Quin and what has happened to him and the mysterious dream self Hannah experiences. Were they or were they not meant to be together? Is Hannah part of the old legends or is she just an ordinary girl caught up in an age old feud?Hannah gains some victories and ends up frustrated, not knowing her fate. I for one, like her adventures, and hope this series continues beyond the trilogy. I can see it as an ongoing serial since Interim Goddess of Love can only deal with one couple at a time, and there are billions of couples in the world who need her help.I'm really enjoying this series by Ms. Mina Esguerra. Bring on more!

The fan is large and quiet, compared to my Logitech which wasn't really cooling my Lenovo T series laptop very well. However, the holes at the bottom are quite large and I've accidentally stuck my finger in while lifting it and got a buzz. The fan is plastic and it stopped, so no sliced fingers, but if you have small children, you might want to watch that they don't hurt themselves.The LED is cool for looking to see how fast the fan is spinning.Update: It died already a few months back. Lasted maybe nine months max.

My Lenovo reports on the Battery (click on the battery icon in the toolbar and brings up Power Manager, go to the Battery tab) and says it was manufactured 2013-11-27 and first used 2014-03 (which is current), so this means it was a new battery. The sticker in the back says 70++ so everything checked out.

What a refreshing book. The first thing I noticed is the beautiful, expressive writing detailing the Manhattan art scene and the dreams of young artists. Kitsy Clare uses all five senses, a combination of dialogue, setting, and description to bring her characters to life.Sienna is a computer graphic artists. She loves order and craves balance. Her artwork is neat and pinned together with symmetry, making her feel like everything is verified and provable, and all is shiny and happy in her world. Intense, expressive work sets her nerves on edge and are too messy for her OCD personality.Sienna falls into immediate attraction with an artists' model, Erik, who is quirky, fun, and drop-dead gorgeous. He has the entire female half of the art class panting wet and the male half tense and looking for his faults. Erik is also an artist, but lack of credentials and his expressive work of swooping lines and free-spirited shapes fill Sienna with anxiety and uncertainty.Sienna is torn between dating Dave Hightower, a wealthy classmate whose aunt owns a high-class gallery and lusting over Erik, who she is sure has many women at his beck and call. Although Erik gives off no player vibes, Sienna is hesitant to let her heart go out of control.The story is set up well, with high stakes tension, adorable side characters, a lusciously paintable hero, and a heroine teetering between logic and emotional. Add to that, the beautiful descriptive writing is a joy to read. It captures details, nuances and sensuality with subtlely, without being long-winded or banging in your face graphic.However, the book is too short! It had so much potential to play out the drama between Dave and Sienna, Sienna and her friend who likes Dave, Erik and Dave, and of course the other women vying to model for Erik. I felt like it ended just when I thought I could settle in for a really good story.Also, Erik came off too perfect. There really wasn't any hidden dark secret hinted at by the description. The ending came too quickly and everything wrapped up too neatly. I guess what I'm trying to say is that I don't "buy" the love between the two. They haven't been tested enough and they don't know each other that well. Of course, the story is sold as a novella, and for the length, it does give us enough characterization to get to know the characters. It just doesn't have much of a try-fail cycle for the relationship that makes for a stronger happily ever after.For what it is, it was a delightful quick read with wonderfully skilled writing behind it.

I have been taking a probiotic supplement for several years, and, when I began taking it, noticed a big improvement in my digestion.  Foods that may have caused me a little stomach upset were not a problem, and my bowels became much more regular.  I was curious to see if the Advanced Digestive Enzymes from ZenWise Labs, which contain more ingredients (enzymes) in an herbal formula would be even better.  I still feel fine and don't really notice the big change that I noticed going from none to the capsules I'd been taking.  If a person is disciplined enough to remember to take a rather large capsule before every meal, this formulation would be fine.  I'm not a person who remembers to take supplements without fail, so I'll stick with one that requires remembering only once a day.  But a person who is plagued by rumbles through the digestive system should give these a try.  Probiotics do make a difference.

Five-year-old grandson is so excited about his chess class, so I chose the Chess Armory 15" Wooden Chess Set after it kept popping to the top of my list as I searched through Amazon.com and other sources and compared the possibilities.  Good choice, too.  In the price range appropriate for a kid beginner, this set offers a high-quality board that opens to reveal a felt-lined storage area for the chess pieces.  There is elastic on both sides that allows the owner to slip each piece into a slot to prevent rattling and to make sure all of the pieces are intact before putting the set away.  The pieces are all smoothly finished and have felt bottoms.  Frankly, I'm pleasantly surprised at the quality at this price.  There's a sheet of basic instructions enclosed in the set, and there is also a free chess e-book available from Chess Armory.  This is the perfect set for any chess player,

I bought this on a whim, and out of curiosity.  Surprise!  It works really well.  The package includes two sprayers for smaller and larger citrus fruits and a little stand to hold the fruit once it has the sprayer inserted.  The fruit gets knocked off this perch in the refrigerator, so I usually use a little bowl, but the sprayers are great. This comes in handy when I cut up fruit that I want to keep from turning brown.  It's faster and easier than putting the fruit in a bowl with lemon juice and rolling it around hoping all surfaces get covered.

I somewhat anticipated my grandson's reaction to this book, because I heard him speaking derisively about his little brother's books that were full of "talking animals and toddler stuff."  However, he was game to read it with me when I asked him to give it a try, as it is a chapter book and for kids his age, 5.5 years.  He could read the words, but the homophones went over his head, and he didn't seem to appreciate them even after I explained the meanings of the similar words.  The story is cute, but a bit sexist in its presentation and spends a lot of time on arguing between the two characters.Personal adult note that I didn't discuss with my grandson:  Why are pirates often portrayed as gallant sailors of the seas?  Most pirates were, and still are, vicious terrorists who plundered ships and often murdered or enslaved their captives.

Playing a traditional and fun board game with my five-year-old grandson, just as I did with my children, gives me hope that families can enjoy simple pleasures and don't always need to be within reach of an electronic device for entertainment.  This version of Chutes and Ladders is the same as the one I remember, the one we used so much with our three kids that it finally fell apart.  Just spin the spinner and make your move.  BUT...do not land on a chute.  DO NOT.  The game pieces and the spinner are all sturdy enough to withstand years of playing.  The board is bright and colorful and is well made.  And the best part of the game is that we have such a good time playing the game.

The material of these shelf liners is two thin decorated sides fused to a center core, with the entire thickness being quite suitable for shelf liner.  The shelves in my 40+ year-old cabinets are made of plywood which has seen much use.  My plan was to replace my plastic liners with this new material.  The material itself is similar to the viscose Sham-Wow cloths that were heavily advertised some years ago, but this is thinner.  I cut and washed a piece in my frontload machine as a test and found that it is washable, does not shrink, and there are bits of fuzz from the center core visible after washing.I would go ahead and cut pieces for the rest of my shelves except for one thing:  The material slips around.  If I pull a can or bottle from a shelf, the liner bunches or slips.  The best place to use this material is in a spot where items are not moved very often.  Changing strategy, I'll now use this liner in a cabinet where I keep glasses that don't get used very often, and now they won't rattle every time we walk through that area.  I'm going to put strips on top of the cabinets that are exposed to dust and kitchen grease.  The paper I've used for years has to be discarded each time I get ambitious enough to want to clean up there, and then must be remeasured and recut.  This will be more permanent.

My grandson is almost three, a bit too young for the concepts of adding and subracting, but he immediately knew the numbers and began trying to fit them into the proper-shaped slots.  I sat with him and showed him the school-related pictures on the big, chunky wooden numbers, as we slipped them into the windows.  Along came his five-year-old brother and showed him how to add the numbers.  And tried to explain the number card game to him.  He was delighted to be noticed by his older brother, but didn't understand the game.  That's fine; he'll enjoy this toy for a few years.Being the age he is, he also loaded some little people into the bus and climbed onto it to ride it around.  This toy is very well made and could take this unintended use as a vehicle.  All the pieces are carefully made with no rough edges or loose parts, this quality being a characteristic of Melissa and Doug toys.

The set is comprised of two vehicles that are cleverly designed in that the wheels of the vehicles are also little molds like cookie cutters for pieces of Play-Doh.  The child can then fill in shaped cavities on the vehicles with the shapes cut out by the wheel/cutter and form missiles and other essential weaponry from the three 2 oz. cans of Play-Doh that come with the set.  After forming all the decorations and ballistics, the cans, which have faces on the labels, can be set into the vehicles to be drivers.  The plastic toys are sturdy and roll nicely on the wheels.  My 5-year-old grandson loves Star Wars so he was very engaged by this set.In my maybe curmudgeonly opinion, this set is all planned play and does not encourage creativity in building with the material.  I can remember playing with modeling clay and making my own animals and trees, and so did my children.  These tiny cans of material and pre-determined shapes are one-time projects that serve mostly to advertise the movie.

Microfiber cloths are especially nice for cleaning and dusting because they give a "clean wipe."  They leave much less water and residue on the surface being cleaned, which, of course, speeds up the job.  This set of six microfiber cloths in grey/black tones are good looking, appropriate to hang on the sink when company is coming.  Frankly, appearance of cleaning cloths is not very important to me, but I was impressed with how well the napped side wipes counters, and the reverse side wipes mirrors and other glass.  I'm using the two black and white patterned cloths under the plates that hold houseplants; they're just too attractive for dusting the bookcase!

This little device comes with almost no instructions among the pages and pages of safety warnings in dozens of languages, but the few pictures were enough to get even a tech dinosaur like me started.  The HP power pack comes with a cord about 12" long that has a USB connector on one end and a somewhat universal cell phone connector on the other end.  To get started, plug the USB connector into a charger that is plugged into an electrical outlet and plug the other end into the HP power pack.  Lights flash while the power pack charges, and soon the lights stop flashing, and you're in business.  To charge my Samsung phone, I reversed the little cord, putting the USB end into the HP device and the other smaller end into my phone.  When I checked back in half an hour, the phone was showing four bars, full charge, although it never gave me the "charging complete" message I get from the charger that came with the phone.  Never mind, it worked fine.  Next, I charged my iPod touch.  Using an appropriate Apple charging cord, I got similar quick results.So, it works fine, and I can see how it could be a  game changer in a situation where I've waited too long to charge my phone and really need to make a call.  My only slightly negative comment might be that the short cord that comes with the HP power pack is very thin and appears to be the flimsy type that breaks and loosens at the ends near the connectors.  The safest way to protect the cord seems to be plugging both ends into the appropriate ports to reduce bending at the ends.  A little carrying case would be nice, but there are many options floating around in most people's desk drawers.

The English-language portion of the polyglot silver label of the box of Vichy Liftactiv Supreme says that a user's face will look relaxed and freshened after seven days' use, twice a day.  I have been following my normal pattern of moisturizing my face after showering in the morning and after I clean my face before going to bed.  My face does feel smooth and fresh, but I cannot really judge whether its condition has improved because I'm using this product.  My "normal" skin that has been covering my face for many, many years, just feels very good.The cream itself has a mild fragrance that I didn't notice once I'd applied it.  It did not burn my eyes.  A very small amount goes a long way, and there is no feeling of gumminess that I've experienced with other products that claim to minimize fine lines.I tend to be very skeptical of some claims that I read on labels and websites, and that applies to the superiority of water from a volcanic spring in France when used in a facial moisturizer.  The product itself, though, passes the test, whatever its claims.  Very pleasant product, soft, moisturized face - that's good enough for me.

The SpongeBob SquarePants series is a big step into the offering of complex, character-specific building sets.  I, the grandmother, am not nearly as familiar with Mr. SquarePants as was my 5.5 year-old grandson, whose eyes lit up when I placed this set on the table for him.  He started explaining the character nuances of the various, um, "people" represented.  What I noticed immediately was the intricacy of the finished products - a shower, hinges, a brass doorknob.  Also, the plastic itself for the stone walls of Squidward's house are a beautiful mottled grey tone.  The pieces fit together securely and evenly.  This is high-quality material, well manufactured.Grandson, who regularly puts together complex sets from Lego, was eager to get started.  This is where the shortcoming of the set, at least for him, became apparent.  With the Lego sets he builds, he opens the instructions to Step 1, and picks up a plastic bag marked #1 and builds the associated part, following the steps.  With the MegaBloks set, the clear instructions were there, but the pieces he needed for the first half of the project, Squidward's home, were mixed into a few big bags, along with pieces from the other half of the set, SpongeBob's house.  I attempted to assist by removing all the pieces that clearly didn't belong to Squidward and sorting remaining pieces by color and putting them into a muffin tin.  This helped a little, and he happily built the sidewalk for Squidward.  He lost interest.  Over the last couple of weeks he has, numerous times, as he lives in the other half of our duplex, decided to tackle it again, requesting that I sit with him; but he quickly gets discouraged by sorting the hundreds of pieces to find the right one to go on to the next step. I've decided to put the sorted pieces into separate containers and put the entire set away for awhile.  A key improvement would be to bag the pieces in sequentially marked bags to avoid the sorting of 498 pieces in order to start, and then having to re-sort for each succeeding step.

My husband is not an athlete now, but he was pretty active in his younger days and his knees are, well, on their last legs.  He'll probably need knee surgery in the next few years, but right now he is very faithful about using TheraBands tied around his ankles and stepping side to side for strengthening the muscles around his knees.  The problem with TheraBands is they come in a big roll that has to be cut to the right length and tied.  Each one wears out after ten days or so.  Now that we have the SKLZ Lateral Resistor and Pro Trainer, he can slip on the ankle wraps and sidestep for his physical therapy routine.  He started with the band with least resistance and says he'll move up to the medium resistance band in a couple of weeks.  Great improvement over the strips of rubber.  He's very happy with it.

This short hose is really the missing link for my V6 rechargeable Dyson.  When you want to use the motor without the floor wand and tool, you are left with a tool that has lots of suction; but the rigid nature of the nozzle makes it difficult to get in places that are handy to vacuum, such as inside a microwave oven, behind the coffeemaker, along the edges of cabinet shelves without taking out the contents.  This extension hose, plus the included multi-tool, makes it all very easy.The hose snaps onto the rigid nozzle of the V6, and the chosen tool snaps onto the other end.  There's a place on the charging station to hang accessories, and this hose snaps onto that and is always ready to go.  Why did I wait several months to buy this?

I'd read the reviews of Ahava Dead Sea Essentials witch hazel hand cream including all the comments about the fragrance.  So when my tube arrived, I immediately opened and sniffed.  The cream didn't seem to have much fragrance at all.  "What's the big deal?" I thought.  I washed my hands and applied just a little.  The feel is very slippery, and my hands felt slightly damp.  But soft.  After about half an hour, I noticed the fragrance.  It was strong.  It didn't go away until I washed my hands.  Some people love a fragrance, but not me.  I even use unscented laundry detergent.  The cream itself is quite luxurious, and it even softened my cuticles.  Maybe I could use it up on my feet.  I'd love using this if it were not so heavily scented.

I use Nitrile exam gloves mainly in the kitchen and while using house paint and other products that would stain or dry out my hands.  Comparing the Ammex APFN Blue Exam Gloves, Extra Large, to Kirkland brand from Costco, I note that the "extra-large" Ammex is almost exactly the same size as the "large" from Costco.  The Ammex gloves are slightly longer in the cuff.  Also, the Ammex gloves seem to be thinner throughout the glove, which could be an advantage for a person doing work that requires being able to handle small pieces of equipment or someone doing medical exams.  The gloves did not tear while I put them on and removed them repeatedly while gluing the rungs of a chair, so they are sturdy enough for my projects.

We gave this to grandson D soon after he turned 2 when we realized he is obsessed with trains.  He loved it from minute one, and now, nine months later, he still goes for it first when he gets here, which is almost every day.  Now, you don't just set this train up and go on a joy ride.  The conductors, who are not allowed onto the train, stand by the kitchen door and yell, "All aboard!"  It is a toy tiger who gets to drive and tells the other animals when they may ride.  D makes the train sound, "Ts-ts-ts-ts.  There's a tunnel under the kitchen table.What more can I say?  He loves it.

With all the Apple devices we own or family members bring over, we have charge cables near, it seems, every table and desk.  I wondered how the Amazon Basics Item HL-007370, differs from the others, particularly another, older model, Amazon Basics charge cable, Item A7R8.
