A quick look at the reviews for the older model answered my question.This new and certainly improved model is beefier in the cable itself, and also in the connections to the cable.  I compared the Amazon Basics model to others in the house and can easily see that this one either equal to or tougher than any others we have.  The end sheathes surrounding the actual connectors are molded and extend down onto the cable to prevent the breaks that have occurred with cheap, thin cables.  I did not receive any warnings about incompatible equipment when I plugged my iPod Touch into the new cable; we were good to go immediately.  Even though the location where I use this cable causes some bending and twisting to unplug the device, I am confident this will be working for a long time.  Probably until Apple decides to make the cable and my devices obsolete!

I hadn't used converted rice for years, but the Zatarain name on a product was tempting enough for me to try the offered sample in exchange for an unbiased review.  Well, it's really good!  At sea level, I followed the instructions exactly and was rewarded with a pan of rice that went very well under a chicken I'd prepared.  All of the rice grains were separate and just-right tender.  There was no sticky residue on the pan to scrape up.  I felt good about presenting the dinner to my family, knowing that the rice has a little more nutritional value and fiber than basic white rice.Zatarain products have shown up in my dinners from time to time for many years, but I wasn't aware that they made a basic rice.  I will definitely purchase their Extra Long Grain Converted Rice again.

The sturdy double box containing the Radio Flyer Red Rider Trike arrived right after I put 2.5 year-old-grandson down for his nap.  It was easy enough to assemble.  There are only a few screws and nuts, plus a sheet of instructions that is all pictures.  There seem to be a few more plastic pieces replacing the metal parts than I remember on my children's trikes, but the materials seem sturdy, and everything fit together without my having to force the parts into place.  The seat is adjustable by choosing one of two positions for the bolt, and the close-in position turned out to be fine, so this size trike will serve for at least a couple of years.  When grandson woke up, he was absolutely thrilled with his new vehicle.  He immediately grabbed one of his older brother's Lego projects and stashed it in the covered cargo area and took off down the hall.  The tires are thick and quiet, and the steering is smooth.  It looks very much like the iconic Radio Flyer of, well, forever, and in the package there's a page about the original founder of the company.

It's very easy to be the prepared hostess when there are mixes like Mr. and Mrs. T's Bloody Mary mix in the house.  To toast our good fortune in being asked to review the product, we chilled the four cans and the spirits and invited our new neighbors over.  We set out a platter of crackers and cheese, popped the traditional celery into the glasses and mixed the drinks to order over ice cubes. The taste is tomato/lemon with seasonings.  One person added hot pepper sauce to his drink.The four can pack is probably for the consumer who very seldom serves bloody Marys, as the cost is quite high.  Many consumers would be smart to by a 24 can pack and save a lot of money per ounce. But the individual drink can size gives a hostess flexibility when guests might be offered a selection of drinks.  There is no preparation necessary other than refrigeration, and there is no waste.

I've been testing the Ahava Moisture Gel Cream for about a week and find it to be a soft, smooth gel that spreads evenly and goes a long way.  The cream has a very faint fragrance that is of something familiar that I can't place.  In any case, it's not noticeable once the cream is on my face.  I find that my liquid make-up glides on smoothly without any patches that some moisturizers can cause.  The cream does not burn my eyes at all, which some other products do.My face certainly needs all the rejuvenating it can get, but it's not very dry.  I decided to put the cream to a real test - my elbows.  Twice a day, when I apply the cream to my face, I've also applied a little to my elbows and find that they have softened a bit from their previous awful condition.Five stars:  A very luxurious product to use.

Okay, it's an apron; I won't claim it's lifechanging.  However, I wear aprons when I cook and work around the house and find much to admire about the Now Designs Apron, Black with White Pinstripes.  I have a few professional quality aprons with logos from cookware manufacturers left from my years as a product demonstrator to use for comparison.  The Now Designs model is of the same heavy-weight fabric, and the pinstripes are woven in, not printed onto the fabric.  The length (32.5") and the width of the bib top (9") are the same as the others, but what I really like about this Now Designs model is the extra 6" of width in the lower part of the apron.  This means that when I wrap the ties around my body to tie in the front, I can tuck my towel into the front, and there is some extra tie left to make a secure knot.  Of course, the extra width also protects my clothes more at the sides.  There's a typical and handy deep pocket all across the front, all the stitching is neat and there are no loose threads.

Owning what may be the worst fingernails imaginable, I was very interested in experimenting with the Amope Pedi Perfect Electronic Nail Care System.  The entire apparatus, 7 inches in length, is comfortable to hold, and the  two-speed switch is easy to operate with the index finger.  Select  among the three inserts: File, Buff, or Polish, and easily snap it onto the handle.  Select Speed 1 or 2, and you're in business.  My thin nails are short, so it was difficult to file from under the nail because the filing insert is thicker than an emery board and not flexible.  However, I quickly filed as well as I could and moved on to polishing.  I was careful to polish quickly to avoid removing much nail, but the process did smooth out the roughest ridges.  The third, polishing, step quickly buffed the nails to a sheen, which from my experience with buffing, lasts several days.When I pulled this device out of the clear plastic shell, I was skeptical of the price, almost $40 at present.  I asked the next several people, family members and friends, that I encountered how much they felt it was worth to them; and they all said around $20.  I might pay that if the device came with some type of carrying case or even a bag that would contain all of the parts, which will probably be lost unless I supply something myself.This nail care system could be very valuable to someone with impaired ability to move hands and fingers, as it requires only a grasp, the three heads are very easy to insert, and it does its job quickly.  If it's difficult to reach ones toes, this device makes the reach a little easier.

Uddo's Red Lentil Pasta (penne) is probably intended for the gluten-free consumer.  We do enjoy wheat pasta, though, so I will compare to my usual product, Garofalo whole wheat pasta.  The first thing I noticed was a lovely deep-orange color, which makes a very attractive salad.  I used it instead of bread in a panzanella recipe.  The contrast against the basil and tomatoes was beautiful.  Next, I checked the nutrient labels on both products.  The whole wheat pasta has twice as much dietary fiber, 4 grams/serving, vs. 2 grams/serving for the lentil pasta.  The protein content of the lentil pasta is about twice as high as that of the wheat pasta - 14 grams vs. 8 grams/serving.  The comparisons of the rest of the nutrients required to be listed, and the calorie count, are nearly identical per serving.In addition to the salad, I cooked one of the 12 ounce bags in the box using a "cook-in-sauce" method.  I made a sauce using extra water, then cooked the pasta right in the sauce in a covered pan.  At sea level, the lentil pasta takes a couple of minutes more than whole wheat pasta, whether cooked in sauce or in a pot of water.  The texture of the two pastas was quite similar, with the lentil product seeming a little more chewy and "rougher" than whole wheat pasta.Uddo's Red Lentil Pasta is a fine alternative to wheat pasta, much better than rice pasta, which I have found to be inedible.

Neutrogena body oil (light sesame formula) is a quick moisturizer to use right after a shower.  Simply squirt maybe a teaspoon of the product into your hands, rub them together, then quickly spread the oil onto your body.  Unless you use too much, your skin will not feel oily, and the fragrance of so little of the oil is hardly noticeable, a plus, in my opinion.  The secret is to use it sparingly. I have used this product for years, both the unscented and the lightly scented version.  Five stars.

My husband chose this refrigerator to assist him in his small-scale home brewing hobby.  He plans to make lager, which has to sit at between 45 - 55 degrees F.  He reminds me to emphasize that he brews in 2 gallon batches, because a more typical 5 gallon container would not fit in this compact refrigerator.  He is sure that the refrigerator will maintain the desired temperature, but we will have to wait to see.  Right now, we are trying to fool some conifer seeds into believing that they are having a winter dormancy at just above freezing, something they would not experience here in San Francisco.  When the poor, confused seeds are ready to be planted, he will begin the beer project.  Ah, retirement!The refrigerator is in our garage.  I am often down there and never hear more than a very quiet hum and a slight pop.  The unit is attractive enough to keep in  a home bar or rec room.  It opens and closes smoothly, and seems well made for the price.

I'd never heard of K'Nex building sets even though I raised three kids and am well into enjoying two grandchildren.  I read on an Amazon.com discussion forum about some people being offered free sets to review, and, after checking the Amazon.com web page and the company's own webpage, I decided to buy a set for L, who just turned five.L loves building Lego sets, but I (and L's dad and mom) are a little disappointed in the Lego pre-determined sets that tell the builder what to build and how and that's it.  This 375 piece set is simply lots of pieces, wheels, connectors, rods, tires, and some suggested projects.  He and I built a very simple example of a milkshake together, but then he shoo'd me away because he had a plan.  On his own, he built a swingset with swings that go back and forth.  He urged me to push the swings while he pretended to be afraid because I was pushing him too high.  He also built a baseball diamond and revealed that his buddy has K'Nex pieces, but WON'T SHARE THEM.  L and his family live downstairs, and he has been up here many times to get in a little building time.  He even said that he's not sure, but he might like them better than Legos.The first day we were playing with the set, L managed to snap a tab off one of the pieces.  I called the customer-service line and told them what happened.  The woman promised to send a replacement, and a few days later an envelope with four of the pieces arrived in the mail.  Great service.

I've been using Pit Paste for about a week, but I remained skeptical until yesterday.  Two days ago, after showering, I applied a tiny dab of Pit Paste under each arm.  I detected no odor the next morning, and I wanted to do a workout stairclimb before showering, so I went on my way.  After climbing the Lyon Street stairs in San Francisco three times, I trudged home for my shower.  STILL NO ODOR!  I think this is outstanding performance and like that it is achieved without any perfumes or aluminum salts.Pit Paste is easy enough to use.  Simply dab a tiny bit under each arm and rub it in.  It works.  I will definitely buy this again, but it will be a long time before I use up this jar.

The Skip Hop take-along nightlight, monkey edition, features a really cute animal face on its front, a big red on-off button on its back, and a kid-size carrying handle at the top.  The soft light casts a glow for about three feet, no more, as  I tested in a dark closet.  So, it's for carrying around or using in bed or a blanket "tent," but not for lighting a room for activities.  The light gradually dims to dark in about thirty minutes, so it's perfect for chasing away any scary monsters that may be hiding in shadows when a kid wakes up in the middle of the night.  It seems solidly built, and it's cute as can be, but, more important, it gives a child a sense of ability to handle a situation by himself.  If he needs to walk to the bathroom, this light is strong enough to let him know what's around him.  We are giving this to 2.5 year-old L, who is about to graduate to a big bed, so this will be part of his coming of age.

The Color Changers work well, with the cars responding to various temperatures very dependably.  The body shop itself takes adult assembly, at least for our five-year-old.  But, the set goes together easily and stays put together.  Having another Color Changers set on the deck already, we knew that it's not necessary to be extremely accurate about temperatures of water.  The concept itself is creative; Ramone drives into the paint booth as a pale yellow vehicle and emerges two-tone.  The kids can spray the water/paint onto the car as it sits in the paint booth.  The set is fun water play on the back deck, and a treat for our grandsons since we won't let them turn on the hose to play because of our California drought.  Our experience with the other set is that they shriek and have fun until they get soaked, about 20 minutes, and that's it until another day.The set comes with one character car, Ramone, but others are available for purchase (of course).  When I showed the set to our grandson before we constructed it, I said, "You can use your other Color Changer cars with it, too."  To which he replied, "But they're not Cars cars."  How early they learn.  But, the additional cars are a bit pricey, so the other cars with no facial expressions will have to suffice.

I've had the Sargent Steam for over a year now.  I chose it because I am fascinated by the power of dry vapor cleaning, and because I wanted to replace my pressure steam iron that had died after being dropped too many times, and the Sargent offers an iron as an accessory.  This is an Italian-made machine that is marketed by a company in Utah, that has a website with a lot of valuable information and instruction and, it seems, just as much gushing and hyperbole.  My experience:The machine itself is easy to use.  Open the top and fill with tap water from an included bottle that has a spring-loaded top to prevent over-filling.  Two bottles full or so is about two quarts and this fills the machine.  Tighten the cap back onto the machine, plug it into an outlet, turn on both switches, attach the hose, and allow about ten minutes for the water inside to come to the proper steaming temperature according to a dial on the front of the machine.  Attach the desired nozzle or attachment and you're ready.  The volume of steam is controllable with two switches on the handle.  I usually turn on only one of the switches, which gives more than enough power steam to handle most jobs.The steam does an amazing job of blasting away greasy grime.  If you've ever watched the shopping channels demonstrate their wimpy little steam cleaners, you will be amazed at how much more pressure the Sargent emits.  The steam is most effective on greasy, but not burned-on dirt.  The top of my refrigerator sparkles, the bathroom tile is squeaky clean, and the track of the sliding door is clear of any dirt foolish enough to settle there.  Cleaning the inside of the oven requires both the power of the steam, plus the use of abrasive scrubbers, at least initially.My gripe is with the gadgets - brushes, pads, extension wands, - that are included with the machine.  They must add a few hundred dollars to the cost of the machine, and I find them to be pretty much useless.  They are very focused in direction and do not allow for flexibility to get into corners and awkward spots.  I almost always end up using the plain nozzle in one hand and a scrubber or appropriate pad in the other.  The Sargent company offers extras of all the little scrubbers, but I suggest starting with only what is included.  Many of the nylon scrubbing pads and the indispensible stainless steel scrubbers can be purchased in the grocery store and cut to size.The steamer must be cleaned out after every few uses, depending upon how high the mineral content is of your water.  This is probably the most awkward operation of all.  There's a cap on the bottom of the machine that is opened by using a wrench that is located in the screw-on cap that goes on the top of the machine.  So, you take the top off the machine, turn the machine over, and use this gadget to open the bottom.  Of course, while you're doing this, any water that's in the machine is running all over your arm and everywhere else.  Then when you get it empty, you must put the bottom back on, run more water in and shake the machine, then repeat the business of taking off the bottom cap with the top cap, having the water run all over while you're doing this, refilling again, opening again.  You really need a big laundry sink to do this.The pressure iron accessory that I bought is a dream to use.  Pressure irons work on several layers of cloth at a time, so the ironing gets done very quickly.Summary:  The Sargent Steam is a very powerful steamer, but it's not as user-friendly as it should be.

I think the fertilizer itself works fine.  Hard to tell, as we are fairly casual backyard gardeners.  However, I'd hoped to use this in my new Gilmour hose-end sprayer to fertilize our little patch.  It didn't take long for the rather cloudy fertilizer solution to clog the sprayer making it unusable.  So, I'm using the fertilizer by mixing it with water in a bucket, and will purchase something else next time.

Grandson L, 5 years old, loves to build with Lego bricks, but he seems to build once, then set aside and long for another set.  L's mom suggested a Creator set, which has three variations and can provide a longer term experience.  He spent about 2 hours building the first creature; the other two came together more quickly.  He proudly showed us each animal, and his beaming smile made every cent we spent on this and other sets entirely worth it.

Grandson L is five and is ready to go fishing with Grandpa.  L's tackle box, protected by Spiderman himself, is of a durable, heavy-weight plastic.  The handle and clasp seem well attached.  The inside contains a few compartments, like Grandpa's tackle box, but a little smaller.  They are going to a kiddie pond nearby for what I predict will be a very short trip, perhaps extended by a stop at the snackbar.

There's not much new and groundbreaking to say about a cable, but this Belkin USB 3.0 Micro-cable is thick and substantial feeling.  The insulation surrounding the connectors is also thick and seems very securely attached to the cable and the metal parts.  The 6' length is very user friendly, especially since our "office" shares space with home devices and we sometimes have to reach around something to get to something else.  It really makes backing up files to the external drive less of a chore.

I saw this device advertised on one of the shopping networks but am skeptical of everything I see touted by their hyper-ventilating salespeople.  However, the concept seemed perfect for my husband's old Lotus Europa, which never goes anywhere without needing some sort of first aid to make it to its destination.  So, when I read the excellent reviews here in Amazon.com, I ordered him one for Christmas.  Soon after, the outdoor editor of our local newspaper wrote in his column about how one of these devices had saved his trip into the wilderness.  My husband was so impressed that he ordered two more of these, one for his Lotus Elan, which has the same electrical system as the Europa, and one for our "real" car, a Honda Pilot, which will probably never need this assistance.  We keep them charged, but only one has been used, the one for the Elan.  Worked like a charm.

I have thick, wavy hair which is cut about 2.5 inches long in a style that encourages curling.  I was pleased to get an opportunity to review a shampoo that is compounded to encourage the type style I want to achieve.  I've used it a few times and have found that it cleans well and does not leave my hair feeling dry and coarse, but rather soft and smooth.  It produces quite a bit of lather, so each time I've decreased the amount I pour into my hand.  I'm now down to a dime-size spot on my hand, which seems about right.  The fragrance is quite faint, which is a plus for me.  It rinses out easily now that I've adjusted the amount.  As for the beach waves, well, I don't really notice any difference from my regular product.  That is not a negative, because this is an affordable, effective product that I would definitely consider ordering again.

I was eager to try this on my wavy hair which is about 2.5 inches all over and cut to encourage curling.  Another product, Marc Anthony Dream Waves, had given me beautiful results, but the coconut scent was so overpowering that I couldn't stand to be around myself.  With the TRESemme Sea SaIt Spray, I followed the instructions precisely, spraying it on while my hair was damp and "scrunching" to push in the waves.  The results were fine; I noticed perhaps a few more defined waves in my hair than when I use no product.  I put on a cap to walk in the sun and found my waves flattened out as usual, but I sprayed a bit more on, and the waves were revived.  Even with a couple of applications today, my hair feels soft, not at all stiff or sticky.  The spray has a slight aroma in the bottle, but I didn't notice any scent when it is on my hair.

My 2.5 year-old grandson D loves to have the treat of a "squeeze" when we go on an outing in the stroller, so I thought we should try Horizon Super Squeeze Mixed Berry Burst.  We refrigerated them first, as we usually do, and presented one to D.  He took a big gulp then shuddered and spit it out.  "I don't yike it."  So my daughter, D's mom, and I tried a little taste.  We both felt that although the flavor was right, not too sweet and with a pronounced berry taste, the squeeze had a definite chalky quality.  My daughter said it reminded her of drinks with added protein powder that athletes drink.  She also was unhappy that sugar is the third ingredient listed.  It's all a matter of taste, but we won't be adding this to our list of treats.

EXPRESS LANE COOKING by Shawn Syphus draws up 5-ingredient shopping lists, and gives three variations for each of the shopping lists.  Oh, man, what can I do with this piece of steak?  This book has answers.  If one has a (very) well-stocked basic pantry, picking up the five ingredients listed including the steak or another meat, could produce a different dinner for each week of a month or so.  Poultry, red meat, fish and seafood, and vegetarian selections all feature this array of quick-to-fix recipes.  Plus, there are five desserts.  If saving time making dinner is at or near the top of a cook's list of priorities, this is your cookbook.In selecting this book, it would be very helpful if Amazon.com would add a display of the actual table of contents so that a potential buyer could decide whether the ingredients listed are what he or she might want to consume.  The publicity on the webpage states that the recipes use "five whole-food ingredients."  I question whether canned cheese sauce, Uncle Ben's risotto mix, and deli-case pulled pork are whole-food ingredients.  Prepared foods such as these tend to be high in sodium and fat.  Over half of the recipes feature cheese as one of the five ingredients.  All of the dessert recipes but one use cake mixes.  Some cooks might want to serve these dishes; some may not.

My new Cuisinart stainless steel grill melting dome does exactly as the name implies.  When the chef (me) places it on, say, a hamburger or grilled vegetables over a slice or scoop of cheese, the dome concentrates the heat and smoke right onto the food allowing quick, even melting of cheese.  It should be used right before the food is ready to come off the grill.  The only downside is that it is 9" in diameter so it can be used only on small amounts of food at one time.  Two hamburgers pushed close together would become two lovely cheeseburgers.I started using a similar aluminum model after watching a chef in a restaurant pop a pan lid over eggs that were cooking on the griddle to finish them quickly.  I usually give the inside of the cover a quick rinse with water if I want to steam something a little.  In my kitchen the dome sits on top of the stove all of the time and is an indispensible tool I use almost every day.  The Cuisinart stainless steel model is MUCH easier to clean than the aluminum one.  It has a metal handle which doesn't get very hot on top of the stove in a quick use, but it becomes very hot in my covered barbecue.  Use a hot pad to pick up the dome.

After over forty years of owning some typically inexpensive baking pans, a year or so ago, I started replacing them with better-quality, heavier-weight pans.  I have another 8" x 8" pan of similar grade to compare this new KitchenAid Professional Grade nonstick pan.  Both pans have similar folded corners and are aluminized steel.  However the KitchenAid model weighs a few ounces more, and the KitchenAid is free of some rough edges that the other one has..  The finish is lustrous and smooth inside and out, with folded metal corners.  The inside of the pan is coated with a glossy non-stick surface that was perfect after I scraped bits of packaging adhesive off with my thumbnail.  There is a slight flare to the sides of the pan, as another reviewer noted, but virtually every other rectangular and square baking pan that I own has a similar flared design.  The heavier weight of the baking pans ensures heat retention that can withstand variations in oven temperature as the oven re-heats or when the oven door is opened.  I find that with the heavier pans, the times given in my recipes are very close to the actual baking time required, at least at sea level.  The KitchenAid pan feels similar in gauge to the pans I used at my job as a school cook,  baking brownies for 400 kids.Okay, so to test the pan, I baked cornbread without any greasing of the pan.  As soon as the timer chimed, at the lowest time given in the recipe, I tested the product with a toothpick and found it to be ready.  I let it sit on a cooling rack for ten minutes then flipped the cornbread out and then back onto another plate so the top shows.  The cornbread came out perfectly, with a little residue, but no chunks, left in the pan.  This residue is normal.  This was an experiment, and it worked.  However, I almost always use either a baking spray product or solid shortening or butter to grease pans; sometimes I also use parchment paper on the bottom of the pan only and then grease the paper, especially for low-fat recipes.  When the pan cooled, I put water and a little liquid dish detergent in and left it to soak, and it washed up by hand beautifully.  Although the pan probably will not be ruined in the dishwasher,  the glossy finish and the pan will last longer with a simple hand washing.This quality bakeware is a joy to use.  Anyone who is using battered and beaten thin aluminum pans, as I was, should try one professional weight pan.  What a treat.

I bought these suspenders to hold my jeans up instead of an uncomfortable belt.  The snaps front and back are stiff to use, but maybe that's why they hold onto the pants so securely.  I've worn them a few times, but last week I discovered a little problem.  Ladies, when you rush into the bathroom, and you're wearing a pullover of any type, you have to remove it before you can slip off the suspenders to take care of business.  This is not so much a problem with a button-down or zippered top.  It happened to me in a little stall in a public restroom, and I was in a hurry.  Just be forewarned.Over-all (that was not meant to be a pun), they are comfortable and seem well made.  Good product in the proper situation.

I love polyester tablecloths.  We use our dining room table often, so it's great to be able to whisk one off to the washer after a family dinner.  I pull them out of the washer, and either machine dry them very quickly or hang them over a rack to dry, which doesn't take longer than overnight.  The maiden voyage for this one included my young grandchildren and pizza.  After I laundered it, there was no sign of the cheese and tomato sauce the kids had spilled.  No ironing; it just went right back onto the table.This DII damask, wine colored tablecloth is a bit heavier in weight than others I own, with just a bit of sheen.  The slightly heavier weight gives it a rich look and cuts down on the slippery nature of polyester tablecloths.  However, slippery is not a problem.  Just put down some plates and forks, or a centerpiece,  and the problem is solved.  The hems are nicely sewn, and there are no loose threads.  I really like it.

The Dyson AM09 Fan Heater is the latest, most advanced model of the sleek, bladeless air-movers from this innovative company.  I am very excited to have an opportunity to use and review this product, because the odd design of our old house creates some dead air zones that require mechanically moving some air, heated or not, a good part of the year.  Also, we often don't want to turn on our furnace and heat the entire house to use one room on a chilly day.  In keeping with that thrifty nature, I looked for the wattage usage on the machine itself and on all of the packaging and instruction book and couldn't find any information.  Naturally, wattage use will vary with the fan speed and with the heat setting, but I was curious about a range.I won't go into detail about each of the features of the fan heater, because they are right there on Amazon.com's website.  The heating function is especially welcome.  The Jet Focus control of the heated area allows focused heat toward my husband while he practices the piano, for example, but, without moving the device, the diffused mode warms the entire room when more people are in the room.  I set the temperature about 10 degrees above the actual room temperature, and within five minutes the entire 18' x 10' room with 11' ceilings felt comfortably warmer in all corners. Even on fan setting 10, the warm air wafted around the room without disturbing curtains and papers on the table at about its height.  Very nice.  The fan heater can be set to oscillate, but it really wasn't necessary to warm the entire room.  At setting 10, I could hear a slight whooshing sound, but at a perfectly reasonable speed 6, there was almost no sound.  The casing inside and out was warm, but not blistering hot.All of the advertising for the AM09 shows it sitting on the floor, sometimes with a baby a few feet away from it.  I would not feel comfortable with such an arrangement, despite the tipping turn-off feature.  If a couple of kids rushed by it with arms extended, or if a pet ran by, the fan heater would be on its side.  It is stable on its base, but could easily be knocked over.  Also, the magnet at the top of the fan heater and the remote must be somewhat carefully aligned to keep the remote in place.  If you misplace the little remote, your manual operation option is to turn it on or off.The price of the unit has been mentioned in several reviews.  All high-end appliances receive comments like this, but perception of value is individual.  Some might be willing to pay for the features, the style, and even the name; and some would not.  That should not detract from the machine itself.  This fan heater is attractive, efficient, and lives up to its publicity.  Five stars.

My usual cup of espresso is very dark with almost a bite.  The Yrgacheffee blend is lighter, smoother, and more herbal than I am accustomed to.  Coffee, like any other food, is in the mouth of the beholder.  There are people who will discover that they love this blend.  The capsule produced a rich, strong drink with very nice crema.The Cap'Mundo capsule popped easily into our Nespresso machine, and required only the normal amount of pressure on the lever to begin the brewing process.  I am an avid recycler, so it is frustrating that these capsules cannot be easily sent for recycling as the Nespresso brand capsules can.  However, I am opening and cleaning out each capsule to recycle it with other plastics.  This is a real pain and reason enough for me to stick with the Nespresso capsules.

Click, click, and the new Dyson V6 Absolute Cordless Vacuum was assembled.  The battery was charged, so I tested it where I plan to use it most, the kitchen floor.  The motor is relatively quiet, and the machine is relatively light-weight (around 5 lb).  To operate the vacuum, hold the power tab against the handle and go.  Holding the tab in is not a burden, as it has almost no resistance to touch and is placed very conveniently.  The direct-drive cleaner head picked up debris like pieces of cereal and bits of cardboard with ease and with no kick-back, and it picked up fine dust as well.  The suction seemed sufficient to do the job.  I also like to vacuum the crumbs off my countertops.  The small profile of the battery and handle and the angle possible with the included combination tool allowed me to do this very easily.  I had planned to purchase the optional extension hose to assist with this job, but that probably will be unnecessary.  I used the combination tool to reach some tight spaces, and the job was finished.  There was no need to use the "max" speed.I moved to the dining room which is also the path from the kitchen to the rest of the house, and gave a quick touch-up to the path of the plush carpet.  The pick-up was fine, maybe not as aggressive as my big and old Dyson DC07, but the place looked clean.Now, to explain the use of the word "relatively" in the first two paragraphs:  About a year ago, my electric broom gave out, and I searched for a corded machine that would clean both countertops and floors.  The heavily advertised product I bought is similar in appearance to the Dyson V6 Absolute, but it is larger.  And heavier (about 8.5 lb., 3 lb. heavier than the V6 Absolute).  Weight is an issue in a vacuum like this, because as you vacuum the floor, your arm supports most of the weight of the vacuum.  I am not particularly weak, but the downward pull of the larger machine is very tiring on my arm.  The motor head of the other machine kicks crumbs around on the bare floor.  Those two features and a few lesser ones make me realize how silly I was to insist upon a corded vacuum, and that my attempt to save money was less than successful.It's an easy task to walk over to the trash can and open the little trap door to release the picked-up dirt.  I haven't cleaned the filter yet, but it simply lifts out and can be rinsed and allowed to air dry.The V6 Absolute model is similar in basics to the V6 Motorhead; the additional $125 or so for the Absolute is charged for additional features and accessories.  Consumers should consider the value they will get from these accessories before choosing between models.On the Absolute is a HEPA filter to catch the tiniest particles of dust and allergens that the standard filter doesn't trap.  This HEPA filter sits at the back of the handle and is easy to remove to rinse, along with the other standard filter.  It is easy to remove, but it never FELL off as other reviewers mentioned; the door must have been re-designed to prevent that fault.  If one is very sensitive to dust, this might be worth the expenditure.The most notable accessory included with the Absolute is the new soft roller cleaner head for hard floors.  This snaps onto the vacuum in place of the motor head and cleans the floor with a combination of velour rollers and very soft brushes.  It is EXTREMELY effective in vacuuming and almost polishing the bare floor.  It may be very beneficial to cleaning high-gloss floors, where every particle of dust could show.  It is the same length (10") as the motorhead, but it is attached to its connection with a flexible hose, which allows it to bend into slightly tighter spaces.The mini-motorized tool, only 5.75" long, is designed to pick up pet hair from upholstery and more.  I don't have pets, but I was able to vacuum off little goose-down pinfeathers that were clinging to a couch.  The brushes are firm, but soft, so I felt comfortable using it on upholstery.  This could be my answer to getting into the tight corners of the floor where no upright vacuum could ever reach.Another handy accessory is the mini dusting tool.  I purchased a larger version of this tool years ago and use it every time I vacuum, on lampshades and the grills that cover some stereo equipment.  This smaller version will have similar uses and could reach into some tight spaces.Kudos to the Dyson company for packing the vacuum into its carton with recyclable cardboard instead of Styrofoam..

Click, click, and the new Dyson V6 Motor Head Cordless Vacuum was assembled.  The battery was charged, so I tested it where I plan to use it most, the kitchen floor.  The motor is relatively quiet, and the machine is relatively light-weight (around 5 lb).  To operate the vacuum, hold the power tab against the handle and go.
