The impact driver is like using a hammer and a screw driver at the same time - it pounds away at the screw while twisting it into position - all you have to do is keep the impact driver on the screw head. This is a tremendous assistance for working with long deck screws or driving them into hard woods. I have been able to drive 3" deck screws into construction - grade 2x4's from an up-side-down position (don't ask :-) ) without having the bit jump out of the screw head. Try that with a standard drill/driver and you'll find that the bit bounces out of the head - causing you to stop and reset the bit into the screw head. Driving these babies home in one shot was a huge time saver (and I was able to keep the peaceful zen in the house on Sunday morning.. namaste).However, this is NOT a quiet tool, due to its hammering ability - it sounds like a woody-woodpecker on steroids when the hammer mechanism is engagedThis is a well balanced tool for one handed operation with the 2 a/hr battery installed.The DrillI really like the tri-LED light on the front on the tool - that stays on after the drilling is finished. This is a big help when trying to work in low light level areas. I also like the trigger control and the where the fwd/rev switch is located - they were easy to operate and stayed in position even during rough drilling (try drilling with a 7/8" spade bit into two 2x4's - better hold on tight, an let it cool down when done!). The chuck locks into place and holds on about as good as the Jacobs replacement chucks. The variable speed option maintained the proper torque need to keep the bit spinning in the hole when drilling into deeper material (yes, they would really tap the battery). All in all - this is a great drill  with a good balance between power and weight. It might be a little heavy for some with the optional 5 amp/hr battery installed (only the 2 amp/hr comes with the kit - you get two of them).The Light:I took it out to the yard the other night and was able to light up the phone pole on the adjacent street - which is about 100 ft away. It produces a narrow beam - for distance - and a fairly wide corona (the area around the center beam of light) for working in tighter locations. I found it cool to rotate the head to any one of 11 positions (indexing) within 120 deg rotation and have it stay there - this is just what I need when working on hanging up the Christmas decorations or fixing something where you need light to stay.Being LED is won't suck down the battery if you've left it on while working under house and forgot to turn it off. It is plenty bright at 110 lumens (what does that really mean in terms of useful light? Plenty of it, AT the right color spectrum, and at anywhere you want to point it!).The Bag:Hey, you've got to have 'more places for your stuff' - is what dear ole' George usta say - so, pickup your toys and put them in the bag .. so you too can be a bag "person" (but with cool tools :-) ) The bag is very well constructed and a great place to keep all your new tools in one location.

I am not normally a buyer of a lot of different face products.  I try to cleanse well and make sure I moisturize and use sunscreen, which I normally prefer as part of my moisturizing routine.  I have started using this but really only at night since I don't want to add sunscreen on top of this for day wear and am happy with my normal product.  This is pleasant, and light.  Actually, a bit lighter than I would expect, I expected something a little thicker.  The smell I expected to be more apple like but it was more of a citrus scent, but nice, nonetheless.  I would say this has done a nice job on my skin making it feel soft and may have eased a few fine lines but I don't know that I feel it is worth the price that is charged.  It might also work even better with their other products but I am not looking for a cleanser, and serum AND a moisturizer (thanks, I have other hobbies besides my face....).  I will definitely use this up and it should last a while, but overall, it was a nice product, glad I tried it, but I don't think for me that I will use instead of my tried and true.

We buy bars like this quite often but the difference in these is that they actually boast a 1/4 c. of veggies in each bar, which is not too shabby.  We aren't talking brussel sprouts here, so don't get judgy.....the add ins are carrots and sweet potatoes.  I also had the hubby try the bar and he LOVED them and said they are perfect when he goes walking.  I liked them, but didn't feel there was enough peanut butter taste, although they were good and when I got over the PB thing I could like them on their own accord.  They are 210 calories and you get as much fiber as 2c. of kale from what the box states.  Again, not too bad.  Chock full of vitamins and 10 g of protein, if you didn't have time for a meal, this would definitely fill you up if you drank a bit of water.Overall, we both liked them, he did a little more than I did and we probably would purchase again, especially for us when we are out hiking and don't have time for a sit down lunch, but need quick energy.

I went to a corporate event recently where they tossed these out and I thought, "Wow, I think this would be so cool for Halloween....".  Well, I was right, in fact so much so that I had kids that wanted to know if they could just take two bracelets and almost forgot we were also giving candy (good stuff....we're not talking raisins here...).  Anyway, we had a couple duds, but overall the sticks were all aglow and the kids had a great time picking a bracelet....Boys and girls little kids, tweens or teens.  It was pretty much a hit with our best response from two tweens who commented this was the best house that they'd been to all night.  (Ok we have cool pumpkins too, but they LOVED these...).  So, we felt good.  The kids got a nice treat and we also lit them up a little so they were more visible along our busy street.  I would definitely purchase again.  Easy to assemble by breaking the stick, shaking and putting a connector at the end.  I thought they'd be a hit, but the kids really liked something different and a little out of the ordinary.  Our tube came with an assortment of colors, orange, yellow, red, green purple, pink.  They looked awesome in our basket!Overall, no complaints here....a few duds keep me from a 5 star review, but what a great value and a fun little giveaway.  We would do this again for sure and it was a great value!

I used this the other night after staring at a computer until my eyes felt raw....why do I do that?  Anyway, I did this a few hours before bed and my eyes instantly felt better and when I woke the next morning they felt back to normal again.  I plan to keep these on hand for my husband when his allergy kicks in and when we go all dry eyed staring at the skating rink watching the Sharks play (Go Sharks!).Overall, no complaints here.  Perfect to put in a bag or purse to be prepared and give your eyes the rest they deserve!

This bar was a bit of a surprise.  When I first saw it I thought "who on earth would eat this?".....then I kind of became interested in trying it out.....So I tried the one bar that amazon sent and had the hubby give it a go too and I would have to liken it more to when you buy flavored nuts in a can....you can buy bbq, wasabi, etc.  You know, savory flavors....same deal here, but they are in a bar.  Kind of ingenious actually.  So, we both enjoyed the honey smoked BBQ and I have to say I would buy a box of these, great when you want something salty with a tinge of sweetness from the honey BBQ.  Nice smoky flavor, just about all nuts, nice texture and chewy.  You have to go into trying these with an open mind.  It kind of seems weird since they usually do more of a chewy granola bar, but if you taste it like you would flavored nuts I think you will be quite surprised and pleased.Overall, I was really surprised I liked the bar and would definitely purchase.  Someone was really thinking outside the box!

This is the 10th Sigma Force Novel and as with the others, they are full of thrills, conspiracy and scientific.  Sometimes it is a little hard to follow some of the science speak, but overall, Rollins puts out a great thriller.  The premise is that the earth is heading towards its 6th extinction and Gray Pierce and his team are to help discover what is happening and how they may be able to stop it.  The story opens as a mayday is sent from a military research station in Northern California near the town of Bodie.  The person making the call advises them that they must "kill us all".  The call brings about a chain of events that take the team to Antarctica, where there are hidden secrets that they must uncover, to Brazil and back to the site.As always, there is technology at the center of the story and the work can either be for the good of mankind or towards the 6th extinction if it falls into the wrong hands.Your favorite characters are once again back in the stories, Painter Crowe, Gray Pierce and Kowalski and Monk among others, so those of you familiar with the series will enjoy seeing these characters once again in the thick of things.  If this is your first novel, it is not necessary that you read the others, but it does give you a better handle on the characters.  As I was enjoying this so much my husband purchased the kindle version and enjoyed it just as much even though he had just been introduced to the characters.Overall, another thrill ride from Rollins that won't disappoint.

I have several OXO products for my kitchen and decided to give this a try.  I had a very old plastic canister that I used for my baking mix, it had the recipes from the manufacturer for making waffles and pancakes and so I kept it and kept it until the lid tore a bit and then it was time to move on.  I now have this canister and it works great-see through, so you can immediately see how much you have left and a top that pops up with a press of the lid.  The handle side has indents so you know which end to pour from.  It is well made and I taped my recipes to the front so now I have a brand new container that is 100% times better than before and still have the ease of having my recipe right on the container.  This would be great for cereal, snacks for the kids, goldfish crackers or anything else that you want to store tightly and be able to pour out easily.I would definitely purchase this if I needed more and would recommend to family/friends.

I currently have a bright pink carry-on that I sometimes check and sometimes use as a carryon and love the bright color, even though I'm not a kid-hey, why do the kids get all the cool, bright colored fun stuff?  I would have to say this would be a great suitcase for a car trip or as a carry-on for a kid or a woman with a fun streak who likes to have snazzy travel accessories.  I am not sure if this would do well as a check in piece of luggage as I'm not sure if it could withstand any rough handling.  You can definitely feel a "give" if you press on it, so it is semi-hard sided.  It is well organized with little pockets within and gives you plenty of room.  I would caution on the suitcase cover that it is flim-sy.  It did not fit over the suitcase easily and I actually pushed my finger straight through it, so if you use that I caution you to do so gingerly.  It is made of a very light reusable shopping bag type of material....not a great choice to cover a suitcase, or to fit so snugly.I LOVE the colors and it rolls great and has the handle at the top that collapses or on the side if you need to pick your suitcase up.  I like it because it is different and will be perfect for a weekend away.Overall, I would not use necessarily as a check-in, but would be a great little suitcase for a weekend away or as a carry-on for your next trip.

My husband and I received this CD as a gift  and we love it!  I was under the impression it was country, but it really is so much more than that.  Some of the tunes reminded me of Patsy Cline, but then I'd hear another and it reminded me of the group Pink Martini.  We played this back to back a few times.  You can find my fave "Bad for You" and it's clever video on youtube and get a sampling of Carolyn Sills.  I must say, normally, I don't gravitate to a lot of female singers that are designated as "country", but again, she has a much wider range, with a real talent, she most likely could sing just about any genre and sound amazing-what a find!  I'm now hoping that I'll find that they will be somewhere in town soon so we could experience the Combo live.  Great tunes and a really pleasant surprise!!!!

I am always in need of a good apron and when the hubby and I cook together it is nice to have an apron that is unisex so we can just grab one and get to cooking..... This apron is very long, I am just under 5'7 and it came below my knees by a couple inches, The top adjusts as does a normal apron and there is a small gap it the front, though nothing big.  The top of the apron does come up higher and that is nice considering that a splash up or spill can occur in that area too.  The pockets , two divided in the front came up quite high, but I rarely use a pocket in my apron, so that is not anything that is a big deal either.  I love the feel of this apron!  It is extremely soft and doesn't seem to hold wrinkles quite as much as regular linen, as I have just put it on again after it was folded up tightly and put in a drawer.  It is machine washable and you can iron if that is your thing....me?  I'm in the kitchen not strolling around wearing an apron and entertaining, so, good to know, but won't be ironing this....I also tried this out on the hubby and it fit him nicely as well with a little less gap at the top.  I did find that for the fit to be right for me I had to adjust the top pretty significantly which left a long "tail", you can just let it hang, or if that bugs you just flip it behind your neck to the other side.Overall, a nice apron, good quality, nice packaging, all tied up with a little bit of twine and would make a thoughtful gift for the cook.  Though mine is the light brown model with the stripe I would love this in one of the bright patterns.  They are gorgeous!I would definitely would consider purchasing either for myself or as a gift.

I am a big fan of Sandford and have read all of his Prey & Virgil Flower novels and was interested in seeing what this YA (young adult) would bring to the table.  It's an interesting premise, with the two main characters being Shay & Odin Remby, two extremely bright teens who have bounced around from foster home to foster home when their parents die in their 30's in two separate events leaving them orphaned.  Shay is the semi-responsible one and Odin is a hacker who has joined a group of animal rights activists to hit a company called Singular and bring to light their experiments which do not appear to be all that the company claims they are.  Shay is drawn into her brother's world when he gives her the thumb drives he steals and a lab dog that has had some unspeakable tests done on it.And the chase is on.......the company continues to stalk her brother and kidnaps him and Shay is on the run, along with some friends and the owner of a homeless youth hotel, who is an activist and goes by the name of "Twist".Overall, a good read and I will most likely pick up the 2nd installment as this is a start of a series.  The characters are interesting and the plot unfolds quickly.For those that are wondering the difference between Sandfords's YA novel I can't really say, the language may be a little tamer, but overall it reads just like an adult novel with the exception being your main two characters are teens.  This would be enjoyed by an adult or teen in my opinion, so don't shy away because it is packaged as a YA novel.  Some of the best stuff out there is geared to kids....

This is being used for projects at work.  It looks like a little briefcase and has a pocket on the inside for essentials and a spot for a pen.  There is room for a lot of paper in here.  I filled it with 175 pages and it didn't make a dent.  This could organized with tabs and could really be your all in one holder for notes, plans, etc.  The construction is alright...some of the sewing is a little "off", and the zipper seems to get lost in the side a bit if you zip it too far, but overall, pleased with the styling and the overall look and functionality.  I would consider buying this again if the need arose.

Pretty decent toothpaste overall but I can't say that I will be changing to this brand.  I currently use Crest with scope and I like the taste better than the icy, which is a little more in your face with the mint flavor.  As far as whitening in a week, I would say it does about the same as my regular brand, it cleans and whitens some but not anything out of the ordinary for any of the whitening toothpastes.  To be fair though, I do drink coffee and red wine, so I don't expect miracles in an over the counter toothpaste.  I would purchase this brand if mine were not available, so I'm glad I tried it, but I think I still prefer crest overall.

I love green tea and peppermint is one of my favorite regular tea flavors so this combo really appealed to me.  It is light on green tea flavor and you have to love mint, but for those that do it is really refreshing.  I am very pleased with this tea, which is also organic.  I plan to purchase the 6 boxes because between hubby, me and work I think the price also can't be beat.  I would have to say this is my favorite peppermint tea at the moment and perfect for any time of the day.  It would also be delicious and refreshing iced.  Overall, no complaints here.  Highly recommended from a daily tea drinker!

I like cheerful and fun office supplies and I still like to take notes the old school way, so this fits the bill for me.  I was impressed that the cover is cardboard and sturdy.  No wish-washy flimsy cover here.  It will stand up to being shoved in your  backpack, bag or briefcase.  It is 80 pages of standard rule paper, so no surprise there but the colors and design make this a happy addition to your desk at work or school.Overall, more than I expected and love the pretty design.  Why not have supplies that don't bore you?

It is always difficult to read a description of perfume because everyone's chemistry is a little different.  I think that is the case with this eau de toilette.  My attention was drawn to the product for a few reasons, it is a good brand, I like citrusy/fruity scents and am willing to try something new.At first spray I was a little disappointed because it definitely smelled more woodsy, like sandlewood with a little vanilla, but as I sniffed my wrist throughout the day I found that by the end of the day it took on a more citrus scent, not sharp by any means, but moreso than when I first sprayed it on.  It stays on all day and I would say it is a pretty smell.  No one note really takes over, so it it seems to have many layers to it and is a more sophisticated/elegant scent.My husband tends to like fruit/citrus scents on me the most but said he thought this was a pretty feminine scent and not overpowering, just right in his words.Overall, I enjoy the perfume and have worn it for a few days now.  It won't take the place of my favorites, but it definitely has a place in my perfume rotation.

These placemats are so much nicer than the picture gives them credit for.  Closely woven bamboo and a stripe of fabric down the middle, these placemats are both simple and beautiful.  Perfect for the patio, kitchen or dining room and easily rolled up for storage. I originally thought that I would buy another set, but we have a really new cherry table and these seem like they may scratch that kind of surface though I can't be sure (and don't want to find out), so we are going to keep our set for the patio where 4 of them will be perfect under the umbrella table.Overall, a very well made product and at the current price of just under 12.00 a fantastic deal.  I would highly recommend.

This is a great little tablet for meeting and project notes.  9.5x6" with a pocket in the front and 80 pages of lined paper is just what you need to take your notes and put your important papers, agendas, etc. into the front pocket so that you can find he information quickly.  Great for a student or for work to keep your notes together and organized.

I've read all of Karin Slaughters previous novels and couldn't wait for her first stand-alone novel.  Again, she doesn't disappoint.  The book takes us back to Atlanta circa 1974.  Maggie Lawson follows her brother and Uncle into the force and she is a tough as nails cop, trying to overcome the boy's club atmosphere of the force at that time.  She is shocked when she finds that her brother's partner has been killed by a shooter they believe has targeted pairs of cops called to bogus crime scenes.  Though relieved that he has survived the incident evidence that is put together seem to bring about more questions than answers.  Maggie is also saddled with a new female rookie, Kate Murphy, who is a young widow from a privileged upbringing.  She not only is taking the heat from the men, but also from the women and other minorities on the force.  Though extremely green she starts to put information together with a fresh unbiased eye but is not sure how to get her new colleagues to look at the case with a different set of eyes and possibly come to grips to events and evidence that seem to go against everything that they believe.Overall, a good thriller.  I enjoyed the retro dateline and the crisp writing.  Slaughter again gives you a raw and gritty look into the Atlanta police force and their hunt for a serial copy killer.  The characters feel real and you can't help but get sucked into the story line from page one.  For those that are not ready to start one of her series yet, fans that are looking for her next book or anyone that enjoys a well done cop thriller, this one is for you.

I'm not sure why this toy is always the go-to toy-It seems so simple a long piece of wire with a few little card board pieces that are rolled into cylinders at the end.  My previous cat who wasn't big on play loved it, and her favorite activity was chasing it as I ran a figure 8 on the floor.  My new cat loves it whether you do the figure 8, make her jump or climb into her cat perch to retrieve it or just bat it on her hind legs.  She almost looks ticked off when I roll it up and put it away for the evening.  Relatively inexpensive and pretty durable for what it is, I bought 3, one for now and two more to put away.  If your can enjoys playing or stalking they will most likely love this toy!  I would highly recommend!

I usually purchase DK guides for our travels and find them to be my favorite of the guidebooks for any trip, domestic or foreign.  Unfortunately, I was having problems finding one for Wyoming and went with the Moon Handbook.  I'm doing ok with this one, and am finding a lot of good information but it is not nearly as comprehensive or well put together.  Another thing that I find a little disappointing is to see the first 24 or so pages in color to then drop off to all black and white pages....what happened?  Did we run out of ink?  Kind of tacky in my opinion.  So, overall, I am getting information about the two parks, surrounding areas and general information but would not be making a switch to this guide as my go-to unless I couldn't find DK.  I find it to be not as top notch.

This book appealed to me because it has been a tough year and though I am healthy, I run around a lot and sometimes don't take time to slow down as I probably should.  I liked the title and thought this would be a good book to help me do just that.  It is good, however I expected more writing.  The book is broken down in three sections, Morning (Inspiration), Afternoon (Perspiration) and Evening (Exhalation).  Morning was my least favorite, just because it was just one (albeit beautiful) picture and a couple words.  I found myself more interested in the next two sections because they had pictures and more detailed writing about relaxing and how she took care of herself when she found out she had throat cancer and would need to take a leave.  My favorite parts were making yourself a "kindness" kit....(I thought this was a great idea, not just for yourself, but for someone you know that could use it).  Also, movies to watch, books to watch etc. in her "shopping list" at the back of the book.  I feel like the book could have been a little longer with more writing as I felt her writing was something that I could relate to and liked her style, so though I liked the book, I wish it had had more writing in the morning section.  Overall, a nice book, good for someone that is ill, does too much, is stressed or just is plain burned out.  Make yourself a comfort kit and get a little much needed rest.  The world will be able to get along without you for a little while :) .

This memoir is a series of essays written over a 30+ year period, many of which have been published before. They flow together nicely with only two twice introduced items.  Like all collections, some essays are better than others.  They range from “Food Mysteries” which I would give a single star to “An Unsolved Mystery: The Lost Friend” which I consider a 5 star telling of teenage best friend anxieties.I almost didn’t read it.  The book begins with “Happy Chicken” which had me wondering where this could possibly go. Because this was Oates, and because it was Niagara County (I’m from there too), I stayed with it.  It turned out to be an artful portrait of childhood memories where the chicken and the child can be one and sometimes separate, all under the eye of indifferent adults.The writing is atmospheric and you can see “place” oozing out of the Niagara County, Madison, WI and the Detroit sections. You learn about Oates’s childhood, her sister, meeting her husband and the outline of the previous generations that produced her.You see the culture of the time that preferred boys and men. Oates reflects on her internalization of this and how she and others accommodated rather than challenged it.If you are not an Oates reader, or if you are not interested in Western NY, this book is not for you. If you are and Oates fan or if you are from Western NY you will be interested in some of these essays.

This is a fictional treatment of the story of Rachel Pomie Pettit Pizzaro, mother of the famed impressionist painter.It has a strong beginning as you get to know Rachel and the St. Thomas social structure.  Rachel is an assertive girl and woman in an age when this was not accepted. You come to understand her dreams and how due to her family’s needs the dreams could not be realized. After one of the tension points is resolved, the book begins an all too slow unwinding.A main focus is the generation gap in a culture where parents by controlling resources and marriage has tremendous control of their children. Issues of religious, racial and gender discrimination are part of the story.This had my attention early on, but once Rachel was developed as a character and Jestine got her news, the narrative, despite some observations on the pecking order in Paris, lost its potency.This was a pleasant read and the author did a lot of research. Unfortunately, the story seemed to end before the book did.

There is a lot to like about this book. It brings the story of Lady Byron to life, but you will find yourself flipping back to see what you missed (only to find that it wasn’t there) and being jarred by sentences with that don’t exactly hang together. The ending has some overly long (i.e. the death of Ada) parts.In the first part of this book you meet a young naive “belle of the ball” who has wealth, doting parents and suitors. She falls in love with the dreamer poet, the rock star of his day. There are glimmers of her his instability which come out full steam just after the marriage vows.  Author Julia Markus takes you through this stormy marriage, the terrible legal situation of Lady Byron (after a year’s marriage to this totally abusive man, her family cedes him access to half their estates on the iffy prospect of keeping their grandchild, to whom this abuser has legal claims) and the how she held her head up through her husband’s vile portraits in his famous works.In the early 1800's there was limited to no understanding of abuse, incest and mental illness. It is painful to imagine a sheltered innocent like Annabelle Milbanke unexpectedly walking into it. You have to marvel at her courage and tact.Rid of Byron Annabelle leads a quiet life as Byron libels her in his poems and his personal life. Following the deaths of her parents she came into great wealth. She founded schools (one attended years later by Peter Townsend, Ronnie Wood and Freddie Mercury), supported working people, and fought against slavery. She raised the daughter of this disastrous marriage and later adopted and raised a child of Byron and his half sister. She told her story to Harriet Beecher Stowe.While the author has done some excellent research, the book needs an editor. The significant issue of Byron’s relationship with his sister and how/when Annabelle knew it is a muddle throughout the first third of the book. There are many smaller episodes, such as daughter Ada being made the Countess of Lovelace, when preceding paragraphs have her mother’s unable to schedule an appointment with Queen Victoria.There are sentences that don’t connect such as on p. 174 “The place was locked down, a fortress, though Colonel Leigh visited her 3 times, her mother once and an aunt, but she didn’t recall which one, sent the religious materials.” Thoughts can dangle, for instance on p. 189 the sentence “Lady Byron was.” leaves you wondering: was what? Preceding sentences suggest she was thinking about Medora’s fatherhood but that should be a given by this time. Another example of many is on p. 192 where it is unclear how Ada’s husband, who had been marginalized long before this, “seemed replaced”… by Ada’s letter from her mother? by Ada’s interest in electricity?There are some characters whom I’d have liked to know more about. Colonel Leigh (and how he came to know and marry Augusta) and John Crosse (and what Ada saw in him).This is an important story and needs a better book. It illustrates not only the sad position of women at the time, it shows how celebrity excuses abusive/amoral behavior. Lord Byron with his “daring” (mental illness/psychopathy) captured the imagination of academics and aesthetes for generations not only by his poetry which was amplified by "Byronic" life.  He crafted a public image of someone he was not. As long as his wife, sister, children and others close to him could be silenced, he could have his fortune and fame, fame which continues today.

I never thought of Beowulf as a superhero story... but it surely is.Gareth Hinds shows that the graphic novel media is perfect for telling this story to modern audiences.These drawings would be even more amazing in large format.The book is well designed, carefully laid out and printed on a good grade of glossy paper.

Gyalo Thondup, The Dali Lama’s brother, tells his story which gives the reader an inside look at the recent history of Tibet.Thondup takes the reader through the Lama selection process and the changed status of his family when his brother was selected. His brothers became monks and Gyalo, who had been destined to support his parents in traditional ways, was selected instead to be educated in China.  As the Chinese increased their control of Tibet, Gyalo, educated, traveled and multi-lingual was able to serve in many ways.There are many sad chapters telling of the suffering of the Tibetans through combat, imprisonment, starvation and the loss of their civil rights in their own countryThe story of CIA involvement is reminiscent of the many attempts to use locals to take on well armed and firmly positioned communists in the 50s told in "Legacy of Ashes".  The source material for this is not dry CIA files, but from personal involvement. This is the first time I’ve read or heard the remorse of a survivor, since there have been so few.Through his recounts of meetings with Nehru, Chaing Kai-Shek, Zhou Enlai, Deng Xiaoping and lesser known officials, you get an inside look at how positions are negotiated, disinformation is spread and how the Dali Lama planned and made his flight to India in 1959.There are sad stories of the continuing suffering of the Tibetans and the complicity of its aristocrats and the government that propped them up.The book begins and ends with Thondup’s retirement from politics in a new career as the owner of a noodle factory. He writes of his sadness at not being able to help his generation of Tibetans. Technology has brought more awareness of the world for today’s better education and he is guardedly optimistic for a better future.Anne Thurston, cited as a co-author, contradicts some material in an Afterward. I have never seen this in a memoir.  I presume there is a story here since some of the contradictions appear to be matters of opinion.

Laurence Wright tells of his growing awareness of the world as he experienced the major events of the late 20th century.  His family had moved from Oklahoma to Dallas where this book begins and ends.  He is embarrassingly honest about his early views and awkwardness.Wright remembers the dull Dallas of the 50s, a city of few minorities and strong right wing opinions. LBJ was spat upon and JFK was greeted to Dallas by ads accusing him of treason. It was the home of General Edwin Walker who was influential in the John Birch Society, but more famous for Lee Harvey Oswald’s assassination attempt. Remembering people and events of his youth, Wright sees Texas, with Dallas in particular, as a part of a regional block, which through “new money” rivals the social and political prominence of the “Eastern Establishment”.The Kennedy assassination looms as Wright describes the guilt feelings of the Kennedy-hating establishment of Dallas and the collective shame for having citizens such as Oswald and Jack Ruby.  The conspiracies are touched on and personalized when Wright meets a former employee of Ruby’s in New Orleans (Oswald’s home town), Marilyn “Delilah” Walle, who 8 months later was shot and killed by a man to whom she had been married for one month ((see http://www.amazon.com/Hit-List--Depth-Investigation-Assassination/dp/1620878070/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1446409840&sr=1-1&keywords=hit+list  #24. She could testify about Oswald’s visit(s) to Ruby’s club)).Never using the word “generation gap”, Wright shows how it played out in his family. His parents are part of the “new” America who had sacrificed to win a war against a real and definable evil and afterward saw their lives improve.  They believed in Richard Nixon particularly in contrast to the “Old Establishment” represented by the Kennedy's and through this faith in the nation, supported the Vietnam War, even at the potential cost of their son.He writes of traveling in Europe and reading the French philosophers and finds America wanting.  He visits socialist countries.  In telling his experience of the draft he shows how middle class whites were able to skirt service, leaving the burden to minorities and the poor. Wright seems too easily receives conscientious objector status and went to Egypt for his CO service. There is a lot of reflection on race and the Civil Rights movement. He never mentions the women’s movement.  Expanding roles for women are mentioned as though they just happened. He tells how he changed when at 30 he decides to have children, which he formerly shunned due to his dismal view of politics and the environment.Wright re-recreates the Watergate era when Americans were riveted to the black and white daily drama. Through his parents, Wright shows the effect of the Watergate hearings on Nixon’s “silent majority”.  He writes of southern pride with the subsequent election of Jimmy Carter and gives some detail on Georgia politics of the time.The book ends in 1984  Republican Convention in Dallas, where Ronald Reagan, representative of the “new”, “non-eastern establishment” is confirmed as the new power in the nation.  Here, Wright connects with delegate Eldridge Cleaver, who’s book Soul on Ice once spoke to him years ago and where  General Walker had been busted for lewd behavior and had sold his home to Hari Krishnas.This is not a nostalgic romp of the past.  This is a meaty narrative of how a real person actually grew to adulthood in this unusual time.  In this as in his other early works, Wright shows the talent which will later have recognition in highly acclaimed reporting on 9/11 and Scientology.  Like Wright, I’m a baby boomer and the book is the story of our shared history (inclusive of living a time in Cairo). Being from the northeast and female, I have a different take on the “new” vs. the “old” establishment and place more importance on the women’s movement than Wright and never heard anyone admire Charles Manson, none of which detracts from revisiting this time with Wright.  I’d like to see Wright bring this up to date, with a book on Aging with America, or similar theme.

Because (presumably) the reader had read the first three volumes, the beginning is like catching up old friends.  You read it hungrily.  Then, it bogs down seemingly lost in speculation about the feelings of the characters and their possible motives (normally Ferrante’s forte). You wonder if Ferrante has lost her steam.  100 or so pages later Elena Ferrante shows she is the master as she connects all the material from the long introspective passages and you are off to more powerful events.This set of novels is enormously complex.  While it is a story of friendship, it covers the post-war changes in Italy in general, and, specifically, in a small town that becomes incorporated in Naples.  You see the social differences of rural/southern and urban/northern Italians, the changing attitudes towards family/divorce, the opportunities posed by technology, the rise of the Camorra and the turmoil in government through the eyes of people who lived through and in the maelstrom of change.I was sad to start this volume that ends the Neapolitan series. I steamed through it. I should have slowed down and savored it, but I needed to know the ending.There is some hope for a volume 5 since there are still mysteries.  The neighborhood, which is like a lead character, has changed and many of the people are gone so a Volume 5 would mean a whole different time and place. It would be a challenge, but Ferrante has enormous reach and I believe, could actually do it.

I read this 3 sittings over 24 hours - fully riveted.Juan Reinaldo Sanchez has seen a lot of the world and even more of life in service to Cuba, or more accurately, Fidel Castro.  Upon his 2008 defection, he must have been a treasure trove for the CIA.Because of his top security position he is able to tell how El Lider Maximo was able to elude over 600 assassination attempts. Castro’s personal security apparatus is a marvel, well supported with personnel and technology. You learn of his special food, how his clothes are laundered, how his double functions, how the staff is trained and scheduled and how Castro is involved in every detail. Besides his security work, Sanchez helped in compiling his boss’ diary/daily log, which if it survives, will fascinate scholars for generations.Dr. Selman, Castro’s physician also deserves respect for his work. He has kept alive his only patient who has had some form of cancer since the 1980’s.  Dr. Selman has at his disposal a private clinic for this sole patient and has on hand two men who share Castro’s rare blood type.There is more here on the Castro family and their living situations than I have ever seen. Castro’s many houses and their appointments stand in contrast to his wardrobe.  The book opens on Castro’s yacht and a description of an island estate. Later there are descriptions of his other homes, each more fitting a capitalist and the head of a poor communist nation.  Sanchez tells of his 9 children by 5 women and where they are and what they are doing today.I have read of  Castro's friendship of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, but no where have I seen how close it was. Gabo had his own living quarters in Havana and appears often in this book.  He surely knew of his friend’s double life.Sanchez reminds the reader of Castro’s influence world-wide.  While he has had mixed success with his international interference he is celebrated in communist countries, dictatorships and countries in rebellion. Sanchez has some interesting observations and anecdotes on traveling with Castro.Following his incarceration (and torture) for wanting to retire early (although he doesn’t connect it, it could be his son and daughter’s defections or Castro’s paranoia following the Ochoa affair), Sanchez’s defection took 12 years.  He was closely followed and foiled by his need to be successful and discrete, the weather and other circumstances. His security training served him well in his escape.I expect that a lot here is not just new to me, but truly new. The book is full of information. While it is written in a conversational voice, there are few spare words. Besides the light shown on Castro, you also learn Sanchez's remarkable story.

One of the few upsides of the Trujillo dictatorship is that it has spawned great literature.  Two Nobel Prize winners have covered it: Gabriel Garcia-Marquez’s  The Autumn of the Patriarch, does not name its subject, but the description surely fits. Mario Vargas Llosa’s  The Feast of the Goat: A Novel is a riveting true to life fictional account of the Trujillo assassination.  Junot Diaz’s Pulitzer Prize winner, The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao  shows the long arm of Trujillo’s reach.  Here is another piece of literature, by a notable author with another treatment on life under this dictator. This is a probable story of the Mirabal sisters who dared to defy Trujillo.I was unaware of these women, but from their Wikipedia page (and those of their offspring) you can see their influence and how it continues.The story is told through narratives of the four sisters. Each writes of the everyday concerns of her life and the family.  As Minerva becomes radicalized, you see how her thoughts, determination and actions pull the family in. I was unaware of these women, but from their Wikipedia page (and those of their offspring) you can see their influence and how it continues.Julia Alverez tells their probable story through narratives of the four sisters. Each writes of the everyday concerns of her life and the family. As Minerva becomes radicalized, you see how her thoughts, determination and actions pull the family in.The book is very good, but I’ve withheld a star for a few reasons. The first is that it begins as a page turner. Somewhere around the sisters' imprisonment it becomes wordy. It recovers during the eventual trip through the mountains, but then the wordiness returns. The second is that while the concerns presented by the sisters are individual, with the exception of Maria Teresa’s diary, all the voices (the writing styles) are the same.  Third, but important is that while purists do not like historical fiction that strays from the facts, I admire the imagination, but want more clarification sorting out truth from fiction in a statement from the author.  A chart of the family with the names and nick names would have been helpful.

This is an historical survey of the study of American grammar and lexis and the development of its reference materials.Author Rosemary Ostler begins and ends with the work and spirit of Noah Webster who felt strongly that American English should be embraced. English as spoken in the US had evolved to a new language, as was fitting for a new country.  British grammar texts or dictionaries were no longer relevant. Webster created an American English grammar text which he promoted by lecturing all around the country.  The dictionary that bears his name came after an editing career.Controversies raged as to whether grammarians should promote a “correct” form or merely describe the language as it is used. Ostler shows the demise of teaching Latin for learning grammar, and then demise of teaching grammar for learning English.  Today, grammar takes a back seat to style (“precision”, “brevity” and “clarity”, p. 236) but the debate on “correct form” continues on the internet.You learn the genesis of the bans on double negatives and split infinitives, the elimination of the “k” in “music”, “public” and similar words, the introduction of sentence diagramming and more.  Ostler shows the very heated debates over the changing language: “It is I” vs. “It is me.”  For purists “jeopardize” and “finalize” were not really words and a should be a “scientist” be a “sciencist”?Author Rosemary Ostler also defines the historical and literary sources for new words.  The Jacksonian Era, the era of the common man (think Davy Crockett), brought new words from frontier and a greater acceptance of grammatical informality.  The Grant years brought words of excess and Theodore Roosevelt, slang. Dime novels added sensational words, and Mark Twain supplied regional vocabulary. As new words were added, many were condemned as “base”, “deplorable” and “unspeakable”.A host of personalities are given a personal treatment along with their contributions.  Besides a long narrative on Noah Webster, you learn about seldom spoken of people. For instance more than 10 pages are devoted to a bio of Lindley Murray, the author of a foundational grammar text and another 10 for Fitzedward Hall, a Sanskrit scholar and major contributor to the “Oxford English Dictionary”.  Stripped of the many bios, the book would be reduced by, perhaps, 30-40%.This is a user friendly niche history. If you are interested in the topic, it is a must read; If you are not, it will not pull you in.

While the title doesn’t promise much in this regard, I chose this book to learn more about Aaron Burr and Alexander Hamilton.  There isn’t a lot on them (they make their appearances after 1/3 of the book), but author Paul Collins gives you a very readable a glimpse of New York 1799-1800 along with a murder mystery.The book opens with a body found in a well owned by the Manhattan Company, a water utility founded by Aaron Burr.  The victim was a resident of a Greenwich Street boarding house, where the defendant also lived.  The defendant’s brother was an important construction contractor with ties to both Burr and Hamilton and hence (perhaps) the country’s first legal dream team of Burr and Hamiliton joined by celebrity lawyer, Henry Brockholst Livingston, was formed for the defense.Most interesting are the slices of New York City Life.  You learn the 1800 landscape of what is now a fully built island.  You learn how boarding houses were run and furnished, about sanitation problems, how summer diseases affected the city, the practice of journalism, the state of prisons and who was in them, how people grieved the death of George Washington and more.Best of all, the narrative shows the criminal justice system at the time. While the “adversarial” system (making arguments for guilty and not guilty) was in its infancy, legal tactics as shown by the defense are advanced. They object to witnesses in the courtroom, they object to points of law taken out of context, and through questioning they get witnesses to discredit themselves. At one point a juror asked a question, which is different from today. As the trial unexpectedly went beyond midnight (the defense made a clever use of candles) there were makeshift plans for sequestering the jurors. Collins shows the improvements in formal court reporting and in the popular press reportage of trials that had their genesis in this trial.New York City was small at this time (Greenwich Village was considered north) and trial participants had interlocking relationships.  Collins shows that a mob would do damage to lawyers and prosecutors if they didn’t like the results.This is a nicely crafted micro-history which will be of interest to general readers of the period, particularly those interested in the evolution of the criminal justice system.

This is a modern telling of the story of Achilles and the Trojan War is said to be true to the original “Illiad” by Homer. It is very readable and builds to a climactic ending.There are many highlights.  The first is the description of how suitors for Helen of Sparta (later Troy) vied for her hand and the last is the burial of Achilles.  Ancient battle, as experienced by Patroclus, is a marvel of creative writing.  Well conceived and compellingly written episodes include Achilles and Patroclus living with and learning from (the centaur) Chiron; Patroclus’s search and rescue of Achilles on the island of Scyros; the deception of Iphigenia; and everyday life during the 10 year encampment outside of Troy.The book is said to be faithful to Homer’s work, but wonder if the detail that brings it life is part of the original.  For instance on p. 260 we learn that Nestor used heated honeyed syrup for his throat, Menelaus used opium for headaches and Ajax had an acid stomach.On the weak side, at times the portrayal of affection between Achilles and Patroclus was melodramatic and Achilles was not always in character.  This is small compared to the full narrative.  Madeline Miller has put new life into what may be the oldest surviving piece of western literature.

Writing for the general audience requires decisions that academic writers never need to make. The scholar can report the facts but reported facts would quickly lose a general readership. Academic writers can present issues and controversies and build a logical interpretive case. The general audience needs a condensed background and a wants a good story with the settled facts.  Academics don’t often deal in personality, and the general reader wants to know and relate to the characters.This is the third Nancy Goldstone book I’ve read. In this one, for me, she has hit the perfect style.  I had very little background, and Goldstone gave just enough to get me into the story. As I came to understand the people and their situation it was more and more riveting.  Last night I couldn’t sleep until I knew how Marguerite got out of her captivity.The two women come alive. Goldstone not only describes, she interprets:  Catherine’s abandonment of  the Huguenots (she only needed them when she had no access to power), her hatred of the Guise family (too powerful and too popular), her  travels  (to “sell”  herself or to dazzle Henry’s court with the beauties of Paris); the reasons for Marguerite’s patience with her husband (appearances for her mother and brother; her safety, her lack of attraction to him,  etc.) her flights (to counterbalance her brother or fear for her life) and more.The men come to life as well as Goldstone interprets the reasons for Henry of Navarre’s conversions (youth, loyalty, kingship); Henri III’s view of Poland (no parties!), his favorites (and how they dressed); and poor young Charles IX (overwhelmed by his mother) and more.  Most compelling was the understated reaction of Henry (of Navarre) when Catherine (de Medici) offers him with a deal in which she and her son (Henri III) will kill his wife (her daughter, Henri’s sister).The epilogue gave me what I need to situate this as prologue to subsequent French history of which I am more familiar.The Index worked for the few times I checked it. I read all the on page footnotes (a sign that they are useful). All the color photos are great; I wish there were more.I highly recommend this book for the general reader. It is a story of adventure, a dual character study, a story of the mind set of the times and a thoroughly engrossing read.

Once I understood that this was not a book about Pope Francis or about the future of the Catholic Church, it was a better read. I still cannot help but feel deceived by the title.The book is a series of essays showing how the Catholic Church has been changing, or more precisely, evolving over its long history.  Five major issues are used for illustration: the change from Latin to local languages; the relationship of Church and state and as envisioned and promoted by Vatican leaders; how anti-Semitism emerged and waned;  the reliance on natural law (women and issues of sex) and forgiveness. There is an Epilogue which is a short essay on Pope Francis and how he admitted an error how it changed his life and approach to the priesthood.For me, the most informative section was on how Anti-Semitism evolved in the Catholic Church over 2000 years. Earlier this year I had read the Pope and Mussolini which gave a detailed description of this short relationship, which Wills shows to be the result of a long chain of church policy.The footnotes were good. Their placement at the end of each chapter was helpful.I think this book was put together to capitalize on the Pope’s visit to the US.  This does not diminish the quality of the material, but the quantity of the material (lots of white space and indented lay outs) also suggests a rush to feed "popemania".  I got this book from the public library. I would be very disappointed were I to have purchased it.

Alanna Nash has done her homework. Each paragraph is packed with info on this extraordinary man and his “work”. While there are some parts that could be improved, taken as a whole, this is a landmark presentation of “the Colonel” and his most important relationship.The beginning is riveting. You learn of the lonely, abused, animal loving Andreas Cornelis van Kuijk who abruptly left Holland to begin a life in America.  Nash describes his hand to mouth carnival career and how his huckster tricks informed his approach to the promotion of Elvis. He began using the name Col. Tom Parker during his stint in the US Army where had an unusual honorable discharge. His pre-Elvis life included work for the Tampa Animal Shelter and the start of his unusual “marriage”.The parts on how Parker changed from the carnival life to promoting country acts, how he obtained Elvis’ contract  (i.e. how did rumoring that the Elvis contract was for sale  make it so?) and the early years of managing Elvis are weak sections.  Some paragraphs seem to stand on their own with no connection to each other. Some areas need more attention, such as Parker’s relationship with Gladys Presley, the entrance of Pricilla into Elvis’ life and the relationship with the Carter family which seems to be important (Mother Maybelle plays poker with Mrs. Parker and the quote from June on p. 337-8 implies a close friendship.)Nash does a good job of showing how Parker’s self dealing hindered not only Elvis’ earnings but also his artistic development. Parker required that Elvis sing the songs he had the rights to and that Elvis movies had to support marketing of the songs. Working with Barbra Streisand or other artists who offered partnerships was out of the question, as was international travel.  Parker saw that Vernon Presley was sufficiently conned and schemed to keep Elvis dependent and docile.The ending is strong as she shows the impact of this unorthodox relationship on Elvis.  The Presley heirs were sufficiently confident in Parker’s management that it to a Probate Court staffer to uncover the issues for which the fast-talking Parker had ready defenses.Throughout the book you see the how the “establishment” managers saw Elvis as a fad. Parker is right in that he made Elvis his priority as no one else had.  The reader is left to determine whether or not there would be an Elvis if there were no Colonel.There are some good black and white photos, the most interesting ones being of the Parker's early life.  I used the index a lot since many easily forgotten minor characters re-appear, and it always worked.

The painting was new and different when first shown at the Paris Salon of 1883 under the name “Portraits of Children”.  It defied the norm for childhood paintings in that the girls were not formally dressed or sweetly posed as was the period’s norm for childhood portraits.Critics were mixed.  Most responded based on their acceptance (or rejection) of impressionism as a new style of painting and/or of Americans who seemed too visible in the established Parisian world of art. Today, Sargent is considered the leading portrait painter of his generation and this painting to be one of his masterpieces.Author, Erica Hirshler, had little to work with since not much is known about the conception of the painting or the lives of the girls pictured.She begins with the character of the Bois family, their wealth, their itinerant lifestyle and the birth and loss of their children.  She describes Sargent and art world that he and Edward Bois faced on two continents. There is discussion of the setting which is clearly their home and the Japanese vases that have crossed the Atlantic several times with the family. You learn about the painting and its reception. The end, which tells of the later lives of the girls and modern interpretations of the painting, was the highlight for me.Sargent, known for bringing out the essence of his subjects, was on to something. That “something”, whatever it is, is the allure of the painting.  The girls stand apart and alone. There is the suggestion that they have been interrupted while playing, but only one has a toy.  The atmosphere is stark, but its opulence is suggested by the size of this hallway or foyer, the seemingly valuable vases and the immaculate “play” clothing of the girls, two of which are getting too old for pinafores. The painting’s title does not acknowledge their mother (deceased at the time of its final naming). It is hard to define the expressions of these girls, but the three who acknowledge the viewer seem to be either uncertain about him/her. Hirshler shows various schools of thought on these girls, their expressions and their later lives.Quotes embedded in the text and in their own indented paragraphs account for, perhaps,  of the book. There are quotes are from Edward Boit, himelf; Boit’s Edward brother; Sargent’s friend Henry James; a host of critics and writers of the day such as Edith Wharton.  They describe the luxurious life of Americans abroad, the Boit family and the opinions of the art world.There are lots of visuals. Black and white photos of art work, people appear with the related text. There are two sections of color plates. One section of color plates is devoted to this painting with several plates showing detail. This book would have worked well in a larger size (coffee table) volume.The index worked for everything I checked. The Notes confirm the reliance on primary sources.It is hard to tell if the narrative is dry due to the lives of the subjects or the author's distance from her subjects. There was admittedly little to work with, and what she found was patchy, but Erica Hirshler has provided insight into this landmark painting.

This is a fictional treatment of Virginie Amelie Avegno Gautreau, the “Madame X” of John Singer Sargent’s famous portrait.  It was published in 2003, just one year too soon to benefit from http://www.amazon.com/Strapless-Deborah-Davis/dp/158542336X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1442602920&sr=1-1&keywords=strapless,  the first book length biography of Madame Gautreau.Gioia Diliberto created a thrilling escape scene (the Union Army threatens the New Orleans plantation home of Gautreau as a child) worthy of Hollywood movie. In reality, it was probably quite dull.  In Paris they did not settle into flea-bag apartment; they went to a property they owned, but Diliberto’s imagination is much more fun.Where Diliberto may be spot on is in grafting a personality on to the portrait.  Written in the first person, Gautreau shows herself to be adventuresome and daring particularly when it comes to being the center of attention. She is obsessed with her looks and who notices them.  Her social climbing mother tries to get invites to parties with royalty (and former royalty – this is belle epoch Paris) and marry her daughter “up”.  Diliberto shows how these were perfect conditions for someone to agree to this project, which was daring for its day (think: Janet Jackson, wardrobe malfunction).The author’s ideas in creating Gautreau’s life are excellent, but the text seems too detached to be the voice of her subject.  For instance, descriptions of Gautreau’s mother’s reception and the brief text of the Salon unveiling are well done as are how Gautreau’s marriage was sprung on her and how the “folk” expressed pride in their mistress’s picture.  These events are excellent imaginings for conveying what may have happened but the narrator does not sound like the person who lived it.  Similarly the situations depicting her conflicts with the mother, how her teenage heart was broken, the realities of a “marriage blanc” an affair with a politician, the boredom of sitting for a portrait and the issues that arise when someone takes control of your image is are excellent creations. They are told like a reporter and not like a survivor.Purists will not like this book because it strays from the facts. I appreciated the creativity of the author and believe authors of historical fiction should have this sort of poetic license as long as they separate fact from fiction in the preface or the notes as Diliberto has done.

Anna Erelle (pseudonym) developed an online identity to gather info for free lance articles on ISIS.  After several years of presence, her online avatar Melodie catches the eye of, perhaps, an ISIS recruiter.  This man, Bilel, is more than a recruiter, he turns out to be a French speaking confidant of ISIS leader, Abu Baker al-Baghdadi.She Facebooks and Skypes with him and arranges for a photographer document the conversations. Events move quickly and within weeks Bilel proposes and says he has accomplished their marriage. He has arranged for her to join him in Syria.The text has three main flaws. One is the wordiness. This is most distracting when author’s comments on her “husband’s” quotes.  This is unnecessary since his words speak for themselves.  The other is imprecision which may be the fault of the translation.  I couldn’t tell if Andre was taping or merely shooting stills of the conversations.  On p. 165 was Charly’s comment about being recognized a joke, when p. 161 implied that they had met? These are small, but they add up.  The third flaw is the lack of analysis. This would not be important if this was a mere reporting of what happened, but it is not.She writes on what it is like to live with, first, her double identity and, then, with a fatwa on her life.Having had this experience and with her background in working with families of ISIS recruits, I expected more from Erelle.  While the sweet talk mixed with bullying was clearly odious, why are others falling for it?  Words wasted on interpreting Bilel’s comments could have been used for more real journalism on Vanessa, the Hamza family, Bilel’s 3 wives, Fatima, etc., and how they fit into the currents of the ISIS brand of jihad.While this as a book is a 2.5 or a 3; the author’s work is important and she has created a gripping read, so the book is getting a 4.

In high school I learned that neither matter nor energy could be created nor destroyed. Any girl scout sitting around a campfire would know this not to be true, but it took 30 years later for text books to get on board.  Guy Deutscher challenges the parallel linguistics axiom: “The fundamentals of language are coded in our genes and are the same across the human race…  All languages share the same universal grammar, the same underlying concepts, same degree of systemic complexity” (p. 6).Deutscher questions who explored all the languages, their methods and how they arrived at these conclusions, and refutes one major ramification of the assumption: that language does not influence thinking.  Those who get to know speakers of other languages are sure to have heard the phrase, “it doesn’t translate very well.”The first part of the book is devoted to how language reflects the culture, and the later part on how the language can influence the thought process.Deutscher is a great story teller. An interesting sketch of William Gladstone who (prior to being PM of Great Britain) noted Homer’s very limited color vocabulary, introduces the debate on the consciousness of color.  He describes several landmark studies that suggest evolving vision and color vocabulary. Color is revisited in the discussion of language shaping our thoughts. Speakers of languages with a rich vocabulary for color demonstrate an acuity not present in those whose languages are not as precise in color.The perception of space varies in language, with (often) rural cultures speaking of the object on their “east”. Directional phrases for languages in developed countries are left, right, and specific prepositions for behind, in front of, etc.  Lest this leads you to think that a more developed culture will have a more specific language, Deutscher introduces Matses (Peru/Brazil), where verbs have a specific time and certainty, besides properties of tense and number.The concept of “gender” in language is used to demonstrate how thinking is influenced by words. A number of word experiments are described showing that gender, while in all practicality is divorced from sex identification, influences concepts and memory.This is a good read. Complex ideas are clearly presented, while Deutscher can be wordy at times, he can be very entertaining.

I didn’t finish this book. The two stars represent the experience up to p. 210, which showed no sign of improving.  Normally, I drop books like this before p. 100 and put them aside without review.  I’m writing this because I wanted to know about Keynes and this book was such a let down.It is organized around his different roles: “The Official”, “The Public Man”, “the Lover” (where I gave up), “The Connoisseur” and “The Envoy”. This means that you run into things like Keynes’ traveling with his wife to her native Russia, after you learn that he is gay, and before any other mention of her, and at p. 210 – still no mention of courtship/marriage. The text can be bumpy; a reference like “this book” can be used but its antecedent is two or three pages prior.There is a reliance on subjective and personal opinions. You learn what people think of him and what he thought of others. While you might expect them in "Lover" sections, they are all over the career sections.  An example of this chatty/catty trait on p. 56 is the description of the Apostles (a Cambridge philosophical group) who are described as “charmless”, “gawky” “unlovely”; One member had acne and walked comically. On p. 176, the “New Statesman  said of Keynes: “He seems to have almost every defect … almost certifiable, extraordinarily tendentious in a frightfully boring way, with bees in bonnets…”  This type of quoted material can be strung together over several pages.Either the book or Keynes is Euro-central to a fault. The Treaty of Versailles is only discussed regarding Europe, with no mention of the carving up of the Middle East. Virginia Woolf (his good friend who thought “he looked like an eel” (p.191)) through long quotes critiques economic and political theory.If I had more background in British history of the WWI, the post war period and its players this may have helped, but it would not have changed the text which is full of petty tidbits (i.e. Keynes flirted with Einstein). People and events for which I had no context were listed and/or named in passing. I just gave up.

This may be the closest we can come to seeing African-American culture of Florida two generations away from slavery.  Some may say that the book comes from a woman’s point of view, but the story rings so true that it can hardly be called a slant or opinion.Zora Neal Hurston’s knowledge of American folklore shines in this novel.Janie, the protagonist, is a woman of endurance and high spirits. She does not let a bad marriage get her down and twice takes a chance on adventure.  Husbands re-locate her to different Florida communities, each of which operates outside of the white world, interfacing only for employment, the legal system and in times of crisis, in this book, a hurricane. The whites are also present in the mixed race off- spring, like Janie, whose mothers are left to fend for themselves.Through Janie you see how women, even those in comfortable situations, had to cope with the men who, through marriage, ran their lives.  The culture permitted violence against women, sometimes merely for the man to make a point to others.The story is mostly told through the dialog, of the characters. The characters’ speech, flowing in a thick dialect, is a pithy, idiomatic and direct; While it reflects little education it is imaginative and at times, poetic.. An educated narrator interprets, providing commentary and linkageThis book is on so many reading lists I imagine my literary friends have presumed I’ve already read it (once or twice). I started it a few times but found the dialect exhausting and put it aside. It recently came as a birthday gift from my sister, so it got my attention and I’m glad I stayed with it.Hurston, who was unappreciated in her time, through this book alone, has made a great contribution to American literature. The dialect, which I previously felt exhausting, was the star of the book.  It allowed the characters to reveal themselves through their authentic voices. This peek into a world that no longer exists is a rare literary treasure.

In 1913 Leda married her cousin Dante by proxy (his father stood in for him) and left her small town in Italy to be with him in Argentina. Upon arrival she finds he had been shot in an anarchist demonstration.  This is the story of her luck and pluck as she seeks to make a life for herself. Music, tango music, is her passion and chosen profession.Besides the story of Leda and descriptions of life in southern Italian towns and in the conventillos of Buenos Aires, the reader is introduced to the birth and growth of tango.  It starts small among the poor with available instruments. It seeps into brothels and to fancy clubs. It adds new instruments, vocals and female dancers.The book provokes thoughts on gender roles and the difficulties of women in meeting society’s expectations. There are great scenes when Leda looks men in the eye and spits on the sidewalk with an appreciation of these gestures. I had not expected the plot.In the early part of the book it seemed that the writer was stretching the story.  As the story comes to a climax it’s a page turner.Credit needs to go to the Knopf book designer. Not only is the cover beautiful, you see the care with which the paper, the print and binding were selected.I would give this book 4.5 stars because of the early labored writing, but I’ll give that a pass and give 5 stars for the difficulty of and daring in telling this story.

Ashlee Vance covers the multiple aspects of Elon Musk’s life and work. Since Musk’s work consumes the better part of his life, most of the text is on his business projects, each of which is a breakthrough for its time.His South African childhood was marked by bullies at school, hints of abuse at home violence over apartheid in his area. His mother has an interesting background; there not much about his father.  Although his grim childhood is referred to as influential in his character, the section is too short for the reader to draw conclusions.Musk’s goal was to go to America.  He took a chance on finding an “anchor family” (his mother’s relations whom did not know) in Canada and from there was able to get to the University of Pennsylvania.  There is no info on how he (and his brother) managed the visa system or on their current citizenship status, but Musk appears to be in the US to stay.Vance shines in presenting the engineering and business aspects of Musk’s life and evaluating Musk’s products. He walks the reader through their development, financing and the decisions and management style that brought them about.  He writes clearly so that non space-geeks can understand the problems of a rocket’s seals, fuel and its weight, specialty parts and launch sites and non-car buffs can appreciate designs that do not need a dash board to muffle engine noise, that enable ease of entry and are wired such repair via the internet is possible. It is an extraordinary person who can write the code for PayPal, understand the physics of a space launch and raise the price of pre-ordered cars.  The experience in losing control of PayPal highly influences his decisions for keeping a tight rein of SpaceX and Tesla. His personnel management can be and has been brutal. I’d be interested in the forced turnover data. There has to be a trail of paperwork, perhaps litigation.We can pretty much agree that swallowed up by an industry giant there would not be a rocket that can return from a trip built at  the cost of its peers or an electric car with the range, style and safety features of a Tesla.  These industry giants would certainly would never tolerate talk of a colonizing Mars.Vance gives you an appreciation for Musk as an inventor and entrepreneur. You come to learn about his hard work and the challenges he faced, but you don’t understand much about Musk.This is just about all of what is presented in Musk’s personal life: His brother is with him through Zip2 and then he appears now and then and they vacation together. Musk seems to be in business with his cousins. His mother is a model, at 60+ years with covers on fashion magazines. (Is she living in the US? Is she part of his life?)  After he suddenly ended his marriage he married almost the first “woman” (22 years old?) he met. He divorced her and married her again and is now divorced.  (From her quotes in this book and her cameo in “Revenge of the Electric Car”, she doesn’t seem like a committed partner.)  At age 7 he banned stuffed toys for his sons, with whom the hours he claims to spend don’t add up.The book is a good presentation of Musk and his empire. Filling in the areas it lacks (childhood, family, personnel management) would make it a much longer book, and may be outside the author’s expertise. There are some photos. An index would have been helpful.

Written in 2002, author M.T. Anderson saw the internet as we know it today with the added dimension that it could be directly “fed” into a brain.It is hard to tell when this takes place. Internet development is contemporary with banner ads, chat functions and a version of “liking”. It is far enough into the future for travel to the moon and planets (and other items whose mention could be spoilers). There are references to what will probably be anachronisms by the time holograms can be school teachers, such as malls and fireplaces, and maybe Coca Cola, Nike, and countries too.The themes of advertising and consumerism predominate but there are some unexplored concepts, for instance the trade marking of “clouds” and “school”. There is a “conceptionarium” which seems to be an advanced way of producing/designing children. The popularity of “lesions” is not explained, but seems rather extreme to be a metaphor for tattoos.Social issues are touched on, such as who can afford access to the feed; how lives are more difficult without the feed; insurance doesn’t cover (feed) software malfunction even though it can ruin mobility and overall health, like 2002  (pre-Obamacare) preconditions.There are words that may be the slang of the future (or maybe these words have come and/or gone from US high schools).Stripped of all the once and future talk, this is a quasi-love story. The most provocative discussion question at the end of the 2004 paperback edition is: “In a consumer society, once things have outlived their usefulness, they tend to be discarded. How might this affect the way people interact with one another?”

It was only weeks ago that I learned that the Kardashians were related to Kanye West and Bruce Jenner. My life doesn’t intersect with theirs.  They are creatures of web sites, cable channels and glossy magazines that are not in my world.  Realizing their status in popular culture, I felt the need to bone up.  For my limited purposes, this was as good a book as any.While this is the romantic story of Kim and Kanye, the focus on Kim gives the reader a glimpse of the life of a reality TV celebrity.  While at the top of her game, Kim remains in the “B” celebrity niche:  Paris Hilton dropped her; she is a bad fit for a wedding at Versailles; she had to endure snubs from Anna Wintour for years before she made the cover of Vogue (and sales plummeted, but Amazon shows the issue to be a fledgling collector's item);  her second husband sued her for using their marriage to boost her ratings; she has a Playboy spread and a similarly, not “A list” motorcycle video with Kanye; despite Kanye’s best friend relationship with Beyonce’s husband, Beyonce will not warm up to Kim.There is an inordinate amount of time and money devoted to her looks.  There is a staff, exercise equipment (in each house and travel location) and devotion to dieting. Her “fans” are very harsh about any weight gain.  Image maintenance extends to her daughter who at one year old has carefully selected ensembles laid out each day (no variation allowed when in the care of others) and an exercise program.Kim (or maybe her staff) is constantly tweeting, blogging and posting Instagram photos. The story line is that Kanye shuns the limelight, but his engagement surprise certainly belied that stance.  Wedding guests had to surrender cell phones (and were given limited phones for the duration) and carefully controlled pictures emerged from the wedding Kanye did not want promoted.  Kardashian brother, Robert, did not attend the wedding, it is said because he had gained 40 pounds… (not so good in a photo).The book is a trip into the world of ostentatious living…a giant diamond wedding ring and a run through of 4 jewelers to set it, a gold bathroom boxed up for a wedding gift,  a “bottom” room with 5 machines devoted to Kim’s butt, fireworks,  a rented stadium for special (private) occasions and more.Despite their materialism and narcissism they both seem like very positive people. They brim with energy.  They are generous (giving tips in the 4 digits) and seem to be much in love.The content is thin. A lot is repeated as though not previously mentioned: for instance for 3 seasons of the reality show the Kardashian’s will be paid 4 million; Kim sees parallels of her life to Kate Middleton’s; President Obama has called Kanye a “jackass” twice.The book is OK.  I didn’t expect much.

He had lost all of England’s land in what we now call France. As he died England was in a civil war and fending off a foreign invasion. From the distance of 8 centuries it may be impossible to determine what went wrong.  On the 800th anniversary of the Magna Carta, King John’s accidental achievement, Stephen Church gives us some tools to try.Church shows the power of a medieval king.  John held between 20-33% of the Kingdom’s money and through taxation and confiscation could take more.  As is demonstrated in the end, he had the power to disinherit anyone, to take their lands and give them to someone else.
