Like many of his aristocratic peers, he was able to do most anything financially, but his access to royal favor is staggering.  Was he the bastard son of Alexander II?  The Wikipedia portraits of the two men strongly suggest this is so. Sophia Tolstoy claimed to recognize and cadence his voice in the voice of Alexander III, whom, again checking Wikipedia, Chertkov also resembles.What was his motivation in attaching himself to Tolstoy and his movement?  Was he a "groupie" to the rock star of his time?  Was he working for the tsar's secret police?  His family participated in what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian movement.  Did the youthful Chertkov have idealism? Guilt? Altruism?  Was Tolstoy the love of his life? Was Tolstoy being manipulated for status, for favor with the tsar? Was the manipulation merely for Chertktov's own sadistic pleasure? Was cashing in on Tolstoy's copyrights from the start?We can conclude some things about his personality, the two most salient being his incredible power of persuasion and his lifelong lack of empathy.How Cherktov survived and thrived in Stalin's Russia needs a more thorough treatment.  There is surely more to know about how he convinced Stalin to grant him a full bureaucracy devoted to publishing a work so at odds with Stalinism. There is only an outline on how he got preferred housing, first class rations, a budget, space and staff for his work, support for an artistic community and travel privileges for his son. He got to have paintings and a sculpture made of himself.  He was able to keep documents that would cost others their lives.  Can it be that Popoff has uncovered all that is knowable?Sophia Tolstoy and her suffering are in the background here.  This book should be read in tandem with Popoff`s Sophia Tolstoy: A Biography to get a full portrait of the effects of Chertkov's corrosive partnership with her husband.I first became aware of Chertkov through Paul Giamatti's rendering of him in The Last Station, a film I will have to see again with this added background.

Two interesting things I learned about De Niro were that while he plays a convincing Mafiosa, he would never be a "made man" (only ¼ Italian and culturally more Bohemian NYC than ethnic) and a lot of his films lost money... a lot of money... even award winning films.The first part, the description of De Niro's childhood, pulls you in.  He lives with his artist, poet, activist, typing and real estate entrepreneur mother and visits his father (a credible, but mostly starving artist) in his nearby studio.As De Niro becomes an actor you see how his single minded devotion to his craft (like his father before him) runs from collecting costumes to sculpting his body for a role, most famously, Jake LaMotta's fighting body and then its dissipation.  De Niro's attention to detail is enormous. His learning Sicilian is just one preparatory element as he studies Brando's "Godfather" to bring the character backward in time.  He records and practices regional dialects for US roles.  He learns to play the saxophone and studies everything from horseback riding to prison culture, to cop culture, to the mentally ill and illiterate for his roles. For the role of Al Capone, Capone's own tailor was enlisted to make his suits and De Niro wore Capone's style of underwear.There are interesting stories about how some of the films were made and not made. Some of the roles were filled with people merely glimpsed and brought in for screen tests. There are De Niro and Scorsese family members in background scenes.  There is the "discovery" of the boy actor, Leonardo DiCaprio.Because the book is like an annotated filmography, the last third or so of the book is not as strong as the first reflecting De Niro lesser creative choices.De Niro is famously elusive, shunning interviews and his public speeches are noticeably terse. Much of his personal life comes from public records, such real estate transactions,  messy child custody/divorce actions; his potential use of a prostitute; contract performance insurance related to his prostate cancer; large (the owner of the gallery where his father sold his paintings stole $2+ million of them) and small (the housekeeper taking jewelry and clothing) theft and more.There are other bios of De Niro. I don't know how this one stacks up. If you want to learn of De Niro through his films, this is the book for you.

This is a good book for those who (like me before reading it) know only a few facts about William Tecumseh Sherman.  Robert O'Connell gives a good outline of his highly eventful life showing him to be a military man through and through. He likes people, theater, the Union and winning. He has a great sense of geography which enhances his strategic thinking.  He knows how to cut losses and thereby save lives.It is a book of surprises.  The first one was on p. 5, a drawing Sherman made as a Cadet at West Point.  Other surprises are Sherman's banking career, his role in the discovery of CA gold, his marriage to his foster sister, his powerful political family (his brother is the Sherman of the anti-trust legislation), his leadership in a Louisiana military academy,  his affair with Vinnie Ream, his son's entry into the priesthood and more. The last surprise is General Joseph Johnston serving as a his pall bearer.I appreciated the early discussion on the West Point curriculum, what it was and what it wasn't.  The professional relationships of Sherman and Henry Halleck and General Grant are well drawn.  Sherman's planning for and execution of the Atlanta Campaign and the March to the Sea it are good summaries for the general reader as are the occupations of Memphis and Savanah.  The "March" was quite different than I envisioned it.O'Connell shows a more enlightened man than the image of brutality that often surrounds his name. He is ferocious on behalf of the Union but when towns surrender, their people are treated as fellow citizens. His war is his passionate defense of the Union. His liberation of slaves is to strike at the plantation owners who tore the Union apart.  Having newly freed men give him information, assist on campaigns, he comes to be ahead of his time on race and race relations.  His marchers at the Grand Review include the Blacks who worked along with his troops.The book is arranged such that the career history is separate from the personal life.  This seemed to create two different Sherman's. In the career part he is pictured as a "good" husband and family man (despite his wife Ellen's father's demands and her strong religious commitment) although his work keeps him many miles and many months away from the family.  The second part shows the couple's quarrels over money, religion and Sherman's affairs making hard to imagine a successful marriage.The author does not address Sherman's middle name and it is not clear if Tecumseh was his first name, changed to his second by his foster father, Thomas Ewing.  Whether it was his first or middle name, why would Charles Sherman name his son for a Shawnee leader (p.272) "determined to prevent white encroachment"?  O'Connell calls Sherman (p.xix) "virtually a human embodiment of Manifest Destiny" without irony.  Whatever the issues, Sherman must have been attached to this unusual name and gives it to his son, known as P. Tecumseh Sherman.O'Connell succeeds in showing Sherman's complexity, his major role in keeping the Union united and then tying it together via the railroad. You come to see Sherman without the war crimes baggage and think of him as O'Connell does:  as one of the few historical figures who would fit right into the current age.

This unconventional artist needs an unconventional book.  Author Leil Liebovitz has delivered, mixing his chronology with artistic and social commentary.  You learn how Leonard Cohen was shaped by his Jewish heritage and his Canadian upbringing, how he became a poet and how he put the poems to music. At times the author is as poetic as his subject.The book has only 246 short pages.  The content is good but not all of it is on Cohen. There are pages devoted to related subjects such as Canadian literature, Jewish history and Bob Dylan.  In the first chapter "Prelude", Cohen does not emerge for 12 pages.There are some good insights such as the difference in Canadian and American artists, the concept of "duende" (which suits Cohen's voice and content) and Cohen's views on his work.  There are amazing episodes such as the visit to/escape from Cuba, recording with Phil Spector (dinner with Phil Spector!) and the two performance tours in Israel.Liebovitz, in some places uses Cohen's own words to describe him.  His opening to his audience in Poland shows how he refuses to be used by anyone (to me, they related to the episode where Dylan seems to expect Cohen to perform at his concert); his speech in support of the Bereaved Parents for Peace in Israel shows his long apolitical view; and his reflection on the embezzlement of most of his assets show his forgiveness and resilience.Each chapter is introduced with a full page photo of Cohen, so you watch him mature. As of this writing he is 80 and has maintained audiences through at least 4 generations (depending on how you count, maybe 5).  He has just released a new album and in 2013 performed in tours in Europe and the US.If you are a fan of Cohen you probably know all the biographical material that is eliminated or pruned and will appreciate the commentary and insight.

The hotel of the intriguing title is in the background as the horror and tragedy of the Spanish Civil War is shown through the stories of three couples.Arturo Barea is juggling a wife and a mistress at the beginning of the war when he falls in love with Ilsa Kulcsar.  Ilsa, a leftist activist from Austria, left her marriage to go to Madrid for the anti-fascist cause. Robert Capa from Hungary and Gerda Tam of Poland met in Paris, the first destination for anti-fascist expats on their way to Spain. Ernest Hemingway traveled to Spain in part of the republican cause and in part for romantic (with both small and capital "r"s) adventure.  Marsha Gellhorn a writer in her own right, traveled with her famous writer partner Hemingway to cover the war.  These women show bravery, commitment, and enterprise, at least equal and maybe greater than their more famous partners.In the beginning the expat situation is defined by Barea as he opines that they were "self-satisfied posers, playing at helping the war effort; they didn't really care what happened to Spain." This is borne out by the accounts of lunches, dinners, shopping and furs.  As the war grinds on, these accounts wane (although where there is Hemingway, there is booze) and many of the expats show enormous courage.  Gerda gives her life and everyone but Hemingway takes significant risks with theirs.This author has done a very good job.  The war itself has a simple premise: should a general be able to make war on his country's democracy in order to attain power?  Unfortunately the politics of it, so well portrayed in this book as seen through the experiences of these 6 people, were not so straightforward.While the writing is good throughout, it does take a while to get into the narrative and there are a few lulls.  Overall, the book is riveting because you come to understand and care about the characters and the deplorable abandonment of Spain by the world's leading democracies (who later had to face the war with fascism they had tried to avoid in Spain). The ending describing the stream of refugees and the purges that followed overwhelmed me.There are good photos, several showing the power of Capa and Tam's work.  The index got me all the info I needed. The list of principal characters is helpful.This is a heavy read and an achievement for the author. It is recommended for those interested in this period and/or the 6 people profiled.

Coming of age stories for males focus on sex - that is the act of sex - with relationships minimized and often lampooned.  For women the stories are more complex and there might not be any sex.  Relationships with family, the neighborhood, friends and the pecking order at school are front and center as is reputation since it can disappear from jealous actions, rebuffed suitors or idle gossip.  Elena Ferrente brings all this to life in her story of two friends growing up in a small town, just outside of Naples.It begins with so many characters that if there weren't a Character Index, I might have had to take notes to keep it straight. If it had not been Naples, and had there not been compelling reader reviews, I might not have stayed with it. The glimmer of the complex novel this becomes does not emerge until after page 75 when the narrator considers Lila's motives for playing hooky.As the book unfolds, you see the background, the baggage and the harsh reality of the lives of Elena Greco and Lila Cerullo. Both girls have an escape route (Elena through education; Lila through marriage) but do they really?  Despite the violence and emotional abuse of their parents, the girls are pulled to them.  The parents tear down their daughters, and what assistance is offered grudgingly results from the interest of outsiders.While relationships as portrayed are timeless, there is a lot that is particular to the time and place.  Despite being walking distance to Naples, this town is so isolated such that some of Elena's friends have not heard of high school. The curriculum of Latin and Greek is hardly useful and very dated. Shoe making and shoe repair (the Cerullo family business) are no longer viable businesses in our throw away culture.  There were victims and winners of the fascist period and the war. While Elena and her friends did not experience this violent history, there is plenty of violence in the town and the specter of ill-gotten gains hovers over some relationships.I'm hooked.  I await the second book  (The Story of a New Name (Neapolitan Novels)) in the series which I've reserved at our State Library.  That I am #9 in a queue of people in Hawaii waiting for this two year old book, translated from Italian about a small town near Naples, says something about  the power of this narrative.

It's a well machined drill press vise. Vise action is smooth, jaws are replaceable with grooves for tubing both vertically and horizontally placed. Most importantly the mounting slots are 4" center to center with 3 1/4" inside edge to edge.

This is an awesome little bookshelf set.Sound wise:I'm very happy with the sound that is coming out of this system.  It feels full and rich while the highs are quite articulated.  Is this system going to compete output-wise with large bookshelf speakers powered by a dedicated receiver?  No it won't win the volume wars, especially of the speakers and receivers are quality components, but that should be expected.  Still, this system will sound just as good as some of those systems in smaller spaces and absolutely runs rings around those portable Bluetooth systems that seem to be all the rage right now.Design:Classic is the best way to describe this.  Handsome piano gloss-black speakers and a simple, understated main unit in matte aluminum.  Design preference is very personal, but the design here replicates some of the best, in my opinion, looks of the old "hi-fi" era.  I really like the looks of the this system.  It goes great in a office or in a dining room or in a small apartment, blending very well with a modern deco.Features:* CD player* Bluetooth* Apple lightening-adapter docking station* USB input* Radio* AirPlay functionality* DLNA compatible* Simple effective remote included (includes batteries.)All work great and setting up you network is very easy, especially if you use your iPhone/iPad to import your network settings.  If I had a small gripe, it would be that unlike my Denon receiver, off is really off.  This means you need to power the unit on before attempting to use Airplay.  Not a big deal but if you are used to your receiver being in a constant "ready state", then just be sure to be aware of this.Summary:I love this unit.  It sounds great, works well, and looks quite nice in my opinion.  I currently have mine set up as my dinner party system and am happy to finally provide great music quality for guests.  And for myself when tooling around in that room.  Ok, it's more for me and I love it.

It's a Christmas ornament.  It's classic and understated and a great baby's first Christmas memento.  There is some subtle sparkle to the finish.If I had a gripe it's that the cast ornament is heavy as far as ornaments go. Just be aware that you won't be putting this near the top or outer edge of any real tree and you'll be fine.

First let me say that I generally love Aveeno and that it's my go-to in the winter for dry-chapped hands.That said, I really dislike this face wash/scrub as it is like they crossed a face lotion with a face wash and through in some mild exfoliators.  I just don't feel like I've cleansed my face after using this and yet I still need to out lotion on it after I shower.  Additionally, my wife who has completely different skin than I do doesn't like it either. (Mine runs oily, hers is much drier.)On the plus side, the exfoliators are mild enough to make this a daily use product unlike many face scrubs on the market.

This is a fairly basic product, so the questions are really:Does it work? Does it look nice?The quick answer to both is yes.  The machined aluminum dock is quite handsome with a modern aesthetic.  It seems well built and it is compatible with my 5S and my wife's 5C. There is space enough to accommodate a thin-ish case and pivots just enough to not put pressure on the lightening connector when not in a case.But there's the rub, it only works with "open-bottom" cases, i.e. cases that don't wrap around the bottom leaving only a small opening for the lightening connector. I really wish this dock worked with a greater variety of cases as neither mine or my wife's case is this style meaning we have to take the phone out of the case to use the stand.  Upgrade season is here so we'll keep all of this in mind when getting cases for the new phones.Summary:Great looking and functional docking stand that is case dependent which is my only major complaint.  If you have a compatible case, or no case at all, then this stand will work for you, otherwise you might want to consider a different stand or a new case.

This is a very cool little product that does a decent to good job of what it is intended to do, i.e. be a very portable presentation quality projector.  So here are the pros and cons of this unit as I see them.Pros:* Very compact.  The projector is downright tiny, roughly the size of one of the new "phablet" phone/tablets that Samsung and Apple now make but just a little thicker.  This means the device will fit very nicely into a bag or even a pocket considerably reducing the weight you need to carry when making presentations on the go.* Auto-focus.  I found the auto-focus technology to work well.* Manual image correction.  There is a plethora of image correction adjustments for keystone, focus, color, etc.  That said, I found one of the preset keystone auto-correct settings to work perfectly.Cons:* Low light output.  I'm not sure why others are reporting excellent light output, I found I needed to run my unit with all lights off to get a viewable image.  This was tested in battery powered mode.* Toggle/select control scheme.  All controls other than power are selected via a single toggle to scroll, press to select switch. I found this control scheme to be a complete pain.  sure it is very compact but I had a hard time getting press to select to work while not accidentally toggling to another choice.  Splitting up the two would have been a much much better and user friendly control scheme in my opinion.* Slightly blurred image.  The crispness of the image just wasn't there when comparing to the Epson projector of the same resolution (roughly 720p) I received at the same time.  It was perfectly acceptable for slides and presentations but smaller print, like a word doc not zoomed in was borderline illegible.* Included "stand" is terrible.  The stand is really just a plastic piece that you can attach to an edge to raise when using in horizontal mode (wall projection) or keep upright (ceiling projection).  In ceiling projection mode it doesn't work at all, and in wall projection mode it barely works if you can manage not to bump it.  All of this is made worse since there are no rubber bumpers on any other these pieces, stand or projector to keep it from sliding around on the table especially when not using wireless mode.Summary:The technology behind this device is incredible, but the sacrifices made to get here make it tough to recommend to anyone looking for something other than an ultra-portable projector.

This is a nice budget "all-in-one" convertible car seat.  Here are the pros and cons of this seat as I see them with comparisons to the Graco 4Ever car seat.Pros:* All-in-One design.  Designed to go from a fully rear facing baby seat (5-40 lbs) to a front facing toddler seat (22-65 lbs) to a belt positioning booster (40-100 lbs.* Soft material.  Softer than the material on the Graco though the Graco feels like it would be more durable in the long run.  This has a bit of a polyester feel but should be fine on babies skin.* Handsome color scheme.  The gray on gray on black looks quite good in person in my opinion.* Height adjustable without having to take apart or rethread the car seat.* Shoulder harness clips to keep them out of the way when loading baby into the seat.  These can be pretty handy and are something that the Graco lacks.* Weight.  It weighs a LOT less than the Graco 4Ever.* Harness is easy to tighten and loosen.  Maybe a touch stiffer than the Graco but not much.* 2 cup holders* No intrusive decorative piping on the armrest or side bolsters.Cons:* Only 3 recline positions.  Not a lot of adjustment in either rear or front facing modes.* Fewer height adjustment positions than the GracoDebatable:* Cup holders are molded rubber meaning they are very flexible and feel somewhat unsubstantial.* Height adjustment mechanism works perfectly fine but the execution is much less refined than the Graco.* I'm not a huge fan of having a car seat that is designed to fit an 8 year old padded up to fit a baby.  These are designed and tested to meet those needs but it's just something I personally have a hard time coming to terms with.Summary:This is a perfectly functional car seat that is comparable to the Graco 4Ever seat in function but designed to be sold a lower price point.  If function is your greatest concern with weight being just as important this is worthy seat for consideration.  If you are looking for greater refinement in execution and functionality and are willing to pay for it, the Graco is one to consider.

This is a phenomenal projector.  Here are the pros and cons as I see them.Pros:* Bright.  Really bright.  In a darkened room the brightness was on par with some of the best rear projection DLP TVs of the recent past or even movie theaters.* Color representation.  Colors were vibrant and far from the muted colors that are so common with low end DLP TVs and projectors.* Crisp clear image.  Yes, the resolution is _only_ 1280x800 WXGA (close to 720P but with a little more space vertically) but it looked great.  Watched some Pixar Brave (iTunes version so the resolution was only 720P anyway) and reviewed some photos I took with my DSLR.  The photos did look better on the 4K monitor I have but they looked really great and the movie actually looked better on the projector than on my laptop.  Maybe it was the distance, or the matching resolution but I would prefer watching these movies on this projector than on my laptop screen if pressed to choose between the two.* Speaker.  Was actually very surprised about how well the speaker on this projector sounded.  Projectors aren't known for their speakers but if my only options were my laptop speakers or the projector speaker, the projector speaker wins easily.* Keystone and other image correction.  Buttons for keystone correction and a slider are all easily accessible without having to dive into the menus and they work very well.* Compact.  Projectors have been getting more compact over the years which wouldn't make it all that noteworthy here except for the pro-level brightness that is packed in this relatively tiny package.* Wireless connectivity with easy setup QR code* MHL compatibility to charge and connect your MHL-compliant devices.* Connection options including HDMI, USB, and standard monitor connector.* Cables are included, USB, power, and standard monitor cable.* Remote included (with batteries)* Padded travel caseCons:* I don't really have any as I had no real issue with any of the performance aspects of this projector.  Could it be smaller or brighter or be 1080P?  Sure and they make those but at an increased cost.  So what this projector is spec'd at it does a phenomenal job.Summary:This is a great projector that is designed for office presentations in tough lighting situations, but it's compact and bright enough to double as a home movie projector or for picture slideshows based on it's image and color quality.

They're Huggies.  Not much else to say.  They fit well, hold a ton and are soft on a baby's bottom.Admittedly, each baby is different and it's possible that's these might not work for you but it's worth trying to see if they will.

This is my second experience with bamboo material in textiles.  My first experience was with TASC brand workout shirts.  Compared to regular poly-blended shirts my TASC shirts were much softer and really nice to wear.  So why bring that up?  Because these towels are just as nice as those shirts, super soft out of the box and almost as much after washing.These towels have pretty much put all our old baby cloths to for use as backups or bathroom cleaning rags.  If I had one complaint it's that there isn't any washing instructions, anywhere, not on the box, in the box, or on the towel.  Weird.  There's a tag on the towels but that's just for the brand; makes no sense in my opinion.  Otherwise these towels are highly recommended.

This is the best car camping pad I've ever used.  3 inches thick might not sound like a lot if you're used to an air mattress, but it is a ton when considering a foam pad.I used the LuxuryMap this past weekend and it was simply a dream to sleep on. Admittedly this was coming right after using a completely inferior big box store-branded pad.  I also have a couple Basecamps to compare this to and while those are nice, this really is that much nicer.  The basecamp is borderline hike-able, like if you've only got a couple miles into the campsite while the LuxuryMap is pure car camping only.Summary.If you're planning on using this for car camping or similar, than I can whole-heartedly recommend this pad. And with a great r-value (insulating value) it will keep you comfy and warm.

This is a fun strategy game where the strategy with a different take on strategy.Basics of the game:Goal- This is a card based game where you use a set of four character cards to continually work at defeating dragon cards in order to get their treasure - think a bunch of Smogs from The Hobbit.Play mechanics - you are dealt 4 adventurer cards that you use to attack any of four dragons cards on each turn.  Each adventurer (warrior, thief, wizard, etc.) has a different attack value and each dragon has a set of health points.  Once enough adventurer cards are played on a dragon that dragon is defeated and the loot is won.  A dragon can be defeated by a single player or a group of players.  It's when it is defeated by a group of players that things get interesting - how to divide the treasure.  A timer is set and there is one minute to mutually agree on who gets what or else it's lost to all involved.Scoring - Dividing the loot and keeping track of what each piece is treasure is where the strategy comes in.  Metallic pieces are set in point value while you need to get the most of clear colored pieces in order to have them be worth something, but if you can get the most of a set of colored pieces it's worth big points. So do you let your opponent get away with a colored piece or do you dispute it or do you accept a number of metallic pieces in trade?Additional Rules - There are advanced rules that concern when wizards or thieves are played and another reason why there are treasure screens included. (Can't see what the other players currently have and can't see what you might be stealing under a certain rule.)  There are also advanced scoring rules and additional magic cards that can be played if wanting to go deeper into the rules and strategy.Ease of Understanding - the game under basic rules is really pretty simple though the mechanics behind scoring can be a little intricate for the younger set.  My 9 and 7 ear olds could understand basic gameplay but scoring was a bit much for the 7yo.Nitpicks:* The gold and silver look way to much alike in most light.* The treasure screens are pretty flimsy.* Would be nice to have a larger variety of dragon designs on the cards.* Gameplay is straightforward but the rules could be laid out in a much simpler fashion and like others have noted, some play examples would go a long way towards clearing up some of the intricacies of the rules.Summary:Fun party game that is a moves right along after you've cleared that first learning hurdle.

This is a great shirt.What it is: A fast drying poly-cotton blend with an anti-microbial treatment.  Basically a gym shirt that is cut to be more of an everyday shirt.  The material is soft, and while it could be softer, I own some other brands that are worse in this regard.  I also find the cut, longer in the torso with a slimming at the waist, flattering on my wife though that is purely personal preference.As for sizing, we received the small, 4-6, which fit her a little on the big side.  My wife is usually an XS but is sometimes an S if the cut runs small, which in this case means I would expect that an XS would fit my wife.  Based on this I would say that these should fit to the size you normally buy.Summary, this is a nicely fitted gym-material shirt that doesn't look like it walked right out of the gym.

Unlike other reviewers I was able to get this camera setup with less hassle than they experienced.  Some background on my tech capability and need for this camera.Experience: I'm no networking pro but I have set up multiple routers, a modem, a networked hard drive, and some wired internet solutions.  I do appreciate automated solutions, but I have dug around the menus of a router to tweak settings when necessary.Need: To use an IP camera like this with my iPhone or Android tablet instead of a boxed-solution baby monitor.  Better resolution, all the functionality and cheaper to boot.How this camera performs:Right before I got this camera I also bought a Foscam 9821 so I can directly compare the two cameras.Setup - like I said, I didn't have much trouble getting this camera setup on my Win10 PC though, I wsa viewing the feed not on the PC but on my iPhone.  The Foscam was trickier in that they're software seems incompatible with Win10 though I could get the camera to work with my iPhone.Image quality - Both gave crisp images in 720P* but in a low lit room the Foscam would still output color while the TRENDNet would aggressively switch to black & white wit the infrared LEDs lit up.  (*720 is max resolution though you may want to lower it to get better image lag performance.)Lag - The TRENDNet was insanely lag-y compared to the Foscam.  The Foscam had a fraction of a second delay while the TRENDNet had over a second, close to two seconds.  I can't say whether it was due to the app or the camera but the net effect was that the Foscam was borderline real time while the TRENDNet was not even close.  This lag was also evident and excruciatingly painful when trying to re-position the camera.  The Foscam would move and stop very closely aligned with the inputs coming from the app.  Conversely, the TRENDNet would stutter seconds after the app input was made moving in small chunks.  I often overshot how where I wanted to end as the unit would keep stutter-stepping long after I had finished tapping the direction control.  Also, note that if image settings were driving the laggy results then I don't believe I should've had the pan/tilt response issues I had.Audio - both have two way audio though I had a hard time getting the Foscam to receive audio.Design - Both are white balls on circular pedestals.  The TRENDNet is slightly more compact but neither have that sexy tech look that some products have.Brackets - the TRENDNet comes with a sturdy steel mounting bracket while the Foscam comes with an adjustable plastic bracket.  Like the adjustability of the Foscam bracket but the sturdiness of the steel TRENDNet bracket.Winner - Easily the Foscam due to price, low light performance, and most especially a LOT less lag.

This set is awesome - like the review says "slot cars without the slots".  There is really a lot of value here so here are the pros and cons as I see them.Pros:* Slot car racing with the slots.  The AI and the sensor track allows you to navigate the completely by using the throttle only.  No need to steer at all, though if you do you will be able to navigate the course at a faster speed.* Everything included to race but batteries.  Track. 2 cars. 2 remotes.* Track is quite large, easy to set up and can be arranged in multiple configurations.  Really surprised at how fast it was to tear down the track when you were done playing for the day.* RC mode.  Tired of just zipping along a predefined course?  Switch to RC mode and you basically have two RC cars to play with and race, really extends the play value in my opinion.* Remove-able wheels.  About 10 minutes into our very first racing session my son crashes his car into a wall and a wheel flies off.  I thought "well that goes that" until he brought over the car and said "the wheels go back on" and pop we were back off to the races.  I was pretty relieved to know that the set wasn't trashed within the first 10 minutes of using it.* Plenty of different races modes.  Practice, racing, different skill levels, AI obstacles (oil slicks are a blast)* Wireless.  They're RC cars so of course right, except, they're also slot cars so they have that over most of those sets as well.* Sounds.  The remotes all have programmed race sounds which add to the racing experience.  (Can also be a little loud, so....)* Headphone jack.  For when you need to be a bit quieter.  Screaming at your siblings is unfortunately not covered by headphones.Cons:* We seemed to be going through the AAAs in the cars pretty quick.  I'd recommend rechargeables for this set for that reason.* Batteries not included.  6AA and 6AAA is quite a bit of batteries needed to get going.Aside from what seemed to be a healthy battery appetite this is a really great set.  Tons of variety and the kids and I are having a blast racing each other. And when we're done with that we can bomb around the house chasing each other.Highly recommended.
Lots of action and adolescent humor. A decent time waster, there are plenty of worse choices, that could have been a LOT better.

This kind of product has been around for a while, and is the same kind that therapists use to rehabilitate patients after surgery. (I used one after my shoulder surgery.)  The way it works is that it send small electrical impulses through electrodes into the muscle that cause the muscle to spastically contract.  It works well for when motion is tough, like in rehab work.This unit is fine as far as that goes, there are a lot of programs from beginner to advanced, very fine level of tuning between impulse strength, and it remembers what program you had it on last.  My biggest gripe is that you only get one set of gel pads, which aren't cheap (3 cost the about a third what this unit costs) and need to be replaced after a while. Gotta love that razor blade revenue model - sell the razor cheap, charge for the blades.As to the efficacy of the unit, it will help in tightening the mid-section but it won't produce miracles.  For those flat abs pictured on the box you would should really incorporate a full program of healthy eating and exercising which includes traditional core exercises.  If you just want a place to start in tightening that core or using this to supplement what you're already doing, this isn't a bad place to start.

The title pretty much says it all, once you get the hang of the rules the game is very easy to play.  It's in creating and executing the strategies and understanding how much can be accomplished in a single round where the strategy really kicks in.The game plays like a very simple game of risk, a sort of cross between Ticket to Ride and Risk where you use cards to "buy" bridges between the islands  and once you occupy more than half the bridges to an island you "own" that island.  The basic mechanic is quite simple and my 9yo picked it up right away.  But the scoring is done after a complete play through of the cards and there are 3 scoring rounds.  The deck is also quite small (as game card decks go) so you can zip right through a round.  But figuring out where to put those bridges is key as is knowing when to replace an opponents bridge with your own.If I had any kind of gripe is that the game is only for 2 players otherwise, it's nice break from other two player strategy games.

Handsome ladies watch with a quiet Japanese movement and mother-of-pearl face. Other details abut the watch:* Real leather backing to the band* Sapphitek crystal face - a synthetic sapphire, should be more durable than a glass face.* Mother-of-pearl fae has a subtle swirl design that radiates outward.* Handsome navy band, (my favorite aspect of this watch).  The material seems to be a tightly woven synthetic.  Not sure how durable it will be to abrasion or wear and tear, but it looks great.* Date indicator above 6 o'clock position* Larger and thicker than most women's watches.  Think mid-sized men's watch, though not as thick as many automatics.* Japanese quartz movement.* Polished stainless steel casing.* Crystals inset on face and bezel.  The bezel crystals are quite small, which may or may not be a plus depending on your preference.Summary, this is a handsome watch, though a tad "bling-y" in my humble opinion.  It's quiet and accurate though, so if the design and price works for you I'm sure this would be a good choice.

Here are the pros and cons of the Braven 805 as I see them.Pros:* Attractive and modern design.  The unit is really quite nice in hand* Loud.  The 805 is larger than most portable Bluetooth units and is therefore able to output greater sound volume without distortion* Lots of bass and a decent midrange when using Bluetooth.  Great for music that is heavy in those frequencies.* Charging port.  You can use the internal battery to recharge your USB devices, like a cellphone.* Battery level indicator.  5 LEDs let you know the rough percentage of power left in the battery.* Aux input.  If your source doesn't have Bluetooth you can plug it right into the Braven with the included cable.* Can take calls over the speaker.  Even includes a pickup/hangup button on the top.* Charger includes swap-able international plug-in tips.  Great if you plan on travelling overseas with the unit.* Auto-shut off after 90 minutesCons:* High end frequencies are quite unrefined.  The weakest point in the sound quality of the unit.  Disappointing.* No LED indicators. No lights telling you if the unit is on or if you've made a sync with you BT device.* Charging brick.  Biggest charger I've seen in quite a while.* Sounds worse when plugging in directly.  I'm was actually really surprised to find out that the unit sounds worse when plugging my iPhone in directly.  It seems as the reduced compression from this method allowed the weakness in the articulation in the upper frequencies to really shine through.  I wouldn't recommend this connection method because of it.  Sometimes this is because of overamping the source signal but I tried lowering the volume on the iPhone and upping it on the Braven to see if I could alleviate the high end scratch.  Unfortunately that didn't help.Summary:This is a handsomely designed unit that has decent sound quality over Bluetooth (favoring low and low-mid frequencies) but misses a couple execution niceties like a power LED and a reasonably sized charger.  Maybe at a lower price this would be an easier recommend but at over $200 it's tough unless the goal is to pump out certain kinds of music at high volumes and have the ability to charge your phone at the same time.

Beautiful hat but be sure to note the following:* It runs on the large side .  I'm usually a medium/large but in this hat, a small/medium is the size that fit best.* It is a "high crown" design.  The height of the at from the brim is a bit bigger than normal, so the hat sits off the foreaed rather than curving around with it. Still looks great in my opinion even if I do tend to prefer smaller crown designs.* I've found the New Era 39 hats to be pretty random in fit.  I've tried some MLB hats that fit as M/L size and some that didn't.  Just be aware that you might have to go through a couple of these to get the right one.

This is a great professional quality laser level.  It's accurate, solidly built, powered with regular AA batteries (4) and includes the Bosch modular system hard case.For most of us DIY'ers it's most likely overkill, and additionally with all the options out there important to mathc the tool to the job.  This specific tool includes only a slightly adjustable floor stand, no tripod or wall mount.  Those will be need for like mounting cabinets, or work, or hanging things off the ground - basically anything that requires a horizontal level that isn't with 6 inches of the floor.  In that  case a tripod or a different laser level kit would be needed.  This kit is great for truing a door or framing out a wall.A nice feature in line with the intended use is the ability to lock out the self leveling mechanism.  Self-leveling basically means letting the laser hang and letting gravity make sure the lines are level.  Works great but if you bang it around, the accuracy can be impacted.  When turned off the unit locks out the ability of the lasers to swing freely, thereby giving it some protection from rough handling.  I wouldn't toss this around but it definitely makes the unit sturdier than units without the lockout.Additionally, you can use the in self leveling and locked positions.  The locked out position is perfect if you need to set a line the is intentionally out of level but needs to be straight.On the note of accessories, the case that this level comes with is half full and contains an insert that is meant to be filled out with those accessories.In summary, I'm very happy with this kit but for those considering it, be aware of what your uses will be, whether this is right tool and whether or not the jobsite-level durability is worth paying for.

For the money, I am blown away at the quality of this set-up.As someone who hasn't ridden in a long time (outside of firing up the board I owned as a teen last year), and who was a huge Powell-Peralta fan back in the day, I am extremely satisfied with this board.The wheels spin very freely, the deck has a great shape, the tape was well applied and the wheels and trucks (mini-logo) are really nice.  Sure, the deck was made in china but you can see the plywood layers and I suspect the entire rig will hold up well just like others have mentioned.Summary:Whether you're just starting, an old pro getting back into it, or an experienced rider looking for a bash-around deck, this should easily suit your needs.Of note:* Depending on you height/weight/shoe size this may or may not be the size of deck you need, or the shape want.  PP makes complete skateboards of different dimensions so there should be one that fits your specific needs.  This deck is geared to riders of average height, weight and shoe size and are looking to skate street/park.  I'm 6ft with a 9.5 shoe and this fits me great - though a slightly wider deck would also have worked.* I had to back off a couple of the axle nuts a quarter turn or so to free up the bearings just a bit.  Now all four wheels spin nice and freely.

This is a beautiful knife.  It arrived sharp; sharp enough to easily cut through a ripe tomato, and in a very nice box (though quite a bit oversized).About the knife:* Nice weight and balance in hand.* Sharp. As I said earlier, the knife was sharp on arrival.* Blade. Made of Ice-tempered German steel.  Inspection of the blade showed it to look very much like the Henckels 4 Star knives that I own.  With proper care should be as durable as any Henckels or Wusthof knife.* High end look.  The 3 rivets with the larger center rivet and it's stamped logo all give the knife a quality feel.* Handle.  Has wood graining, but I don't believe it's real wood.  Most likely a composite resin, which is still very handsome in hand.About the box:* Admittedly not the most important part of the knife but in case this should be a gift, the knife comes in a very handsome charcoal gray box with magnetic latches.  The knife is placed in the box in custom foam insert.  The overall presentation is very nice.Summary:While KitchenAid might not be your first thought when thinking about premium knives for your kitchen, the knives in this line are worthy of consideration.

This is a phenomenal kit that makes the awesomeness of custom made pedal cables accessible to anyone.The is a reason why custom made cables are preferred for a pedal board.  Depending on your pedals and layout the perfect amount of cable between pedals and the orientation of the jack is rarely the same.  this kit gives you the flexibility to achieve that perfect layout without having to go to all the work of buying the cable and jacks and then stripping and soldering the connections.  It additionally gives you all the tools you need to get the project complete including the wire cutter and screwdriver needed.Some thoughts on the kit itself.* Wire cutter.  Worked surprisingly well.  Built like a cigar clipper the cut that I get out of it was a LOT cleaner than the one I got from using my wire snips, something I totally did not expect.  Awesome.* Screwdriver.  The weakest part of the kit as it is pretty cheap and a bit undersized for the screw heads.  No biggie as I have a ton of screwdrivers around the house and another fit perfectly.* Cable.  On par with other cables I've gotten in the Planet Waves line.* Jacks.  Very solid and obviously all L-shaped.* Adjustable.  After putting together my first cable realized I had the orientation of the jacks misaligned.  Loosen the screw rotate and retighten and everything was ready to go.Durability.  Well a pedal board isn't generally something that is torn down after every gig but the should last as long as you aren't constantly pulling on the cable.Other thoughts:  I hope that Planet Waves releases some straight jacks as some of my pedals would be better off with those over L-shaped jacks.Summary:I can't recommend this kit enough if you are interested in looking at an easy way to clean up you board with custom cables.

As someone who has read many of Kathy Reich's books, here are my thoughts on this new book in her Temperance Bones series.For those new to the series, this book, and those in the series are based on the Temperance Brennan character. She's a forensic anthropologist working at the Smithsonian and is roughly the same character that the series Bones on the Fox network is based on.Thought on the Storyline:* Somewhat formulaic. Gets involved in a case, gets herself in trouble/puts herself in danger, gets out of said danger, solves case.* Still some twists to be had.* The love interest subplot moves forward but still isn't resolved.Pacing:* Moves at an engaging pace that drives the story forward and kept my interest.Summary:If you enjoyed her other books you're going to enjoy this new one even if the basic structure is one we've come to expect.  It's not a challenging read, but for those that enjoy a good crime mystery book, this is an easy recommendation.

This is a really nice looking pan with a great heft to it but unfortunately I didn't find it to measure up to the visual appeal.  Here are the pros and cons of this pan as I see them:Pros:* Beautiful looking pan.  The blue enamel looks great and the cast and polished aluminum handle are really handsome and give the pan a high end look.* Heft and weighty construction.  Well it is cast iron so the pan will be heavy but the solid handle, stainless steel - mostly likely clad aluminum, and large rivets give it that extra bit of high end build quality feel.* All the pros of cast iron cooking.  All the performance you'd expect from using a heavy gauge cast iron pan.Cons:* My pan was warped.  Place the pan on the granite countertop or the cooktop and it was easy to see the pan was warped as it wobbled when touched it.* Cast iron surface is coarser than other cast Iron I own.  We've been using cast iron for a while so this isn't our first pan and part of properly using a cast iron pan is seasoning it.  When I went to season this pan, by slowly heating it up and then working some high flash point oil into it (I used safflower oil) the pan kept shredding the paper towel.  I couldn't work the oil without leaving bits of paper stuck to the side of the pan, which was quite frustrating.  I don't have this problem any of our Lodge pans and I not to keen on having bits of Brawny in my food.* No lid.  I can understand not including a lid with a griddle but this is so close to being a large fry pan that not having it seems like an omission.  I suppose this is why they make spatter guards but still, it would have been great to have a lid included.In summary, this is a beautiful pan, designed in Ireland but let down by it's Chinese manufacturing.  A course casting mold and uneven quality control let down what should have been a winning design.

I have been a big fan of Cetaphil Moisturizing face lotion for a while now.  I have an oily t-zone (forehead/nose) so I try to use products that won't clog my pores or leave my face even oilier.  Cetaphil doesn't do either and it has some SPF protection which I like as someone who cares less about being tanned as I do the overall appearance of my skin as I get older.So now we have Cetaphil for Men in exactly the same bottle as the old Cetaphil Daily Facial Moisturizer.  Looking at the ingredients lists even has the exact same ingredients in the exact same order.  Is this the same stuff?  Consistency is pretty much the same and neither are really scented so it could very well be the same product just rebranded.Either way, whatever it's called it's a product that I use and can highly recommend.  It leaves my skin feeling great, isn't oily, won't clog my pores, and gives me some SPF protection.  What's not to love about that?

This is a excellent hair roller with only a couple caveats.  Here are the pros and cons of this curling iron.Pros:* Heats up very fast.  The box says 30 seconds but my wife while not paying attention to the clock simply said, "this heated up really fast".* Forward, back, and reset buttons.  It was really nice to hit the reset button and have the roller return to the start position.* Solid build quality.  This just feels like a quality product.  From the higher gauge (thicker) power cord to the included velcro strap to keep it bundled up cleanly, to the ceramic barrel, and ergonomic feel of the handle.* Digital temp set with LED display and power button.  Very simple to use.  Default temp was 360 F* 410 F top end temp.* Very comfortable in hand, though the solid build and internal gearing does add to the weight.Cons:* Gets quite warm up near where the barrel meets the handle.  Unfortunately you need to rest your hand up in that area when using the barrel clip thumb button.  You move your hand down the handle to comfortably use the left and right (forward and back?) buttons but when placing hair into the clip you do need to get your hands up near that area.  This is due to the fact that the barrel clip button is so short because it has to move with the barrel as it rotates.* Barrel clip is very short.  No flips here as you can only get so much hair in the clip at one time.  This is really the achilles heal of the product or rather the thing that makes it more a specialist tool and less of a does all kinds of curls tool.Summary:This is a very good curling iron, well built and thoughtfully laid out.  Still, it's important to remember that depending on how you like to do your hair this might not be the last curling iron you buy but rather the one you go to for easily putting together a specific look.  Beyond that our biggest gripe was that it gets pretty warm around the spot you need to hold when putting your hair into the barrel clip.So if the specific look you're going for is smaller curls on roughly uniform length hair, then this is an iron you should definitely consider.  If you need more of a jack of all trades iron, it might make more sense to consider or rollers.

As someone who very much dislikes feeling like they have put lotion/moisturizer on, this is the perfect moisturizer for me.  This is also very different from how my wife feels about lotion.  She's someone who uses lotion religiously out of the shower, while I'm much more of a "needs based" kind of guy.That said, when I do need some lotion I tend to go for Aveeno as that is the best lotion I've found that cures my chapped hands in the winter while being about as free of that "wearing lotion" feeling as I can get.  Luckily, Aveeno is my wife's go-to lotion so whenever I need some, it's right there for me to use.Which brings us to how does this lotion/moisturizer compare to regular Aveeno and consequently to the admittedly odd title of this review.  I liken the difference between the two lotions as the difference between whole milk and 2% milk.  One is much richer than the other but both are great for the purpose that you want to use them.  Some like drinking only whole milk, while others prefer 2% (or even 1% or fat free) for drinking.  Tht richness of whole milk is too much for them to take when drinking it but it might be the better option for putting in your coffee or using in a mixed drink.That's roughly how these two lotions compare.  Sheer hydration is a lighter formulation that indeed feels even less like you're wearing lotion than the already very good regular Aveeno.  Now that lighter feel might be too light for some, my wife included, but for me it was perfect as a daily moisturizer.  Comparing the two directly, I much preferred the light lotion-free feel of the Sheer Hydration formula for a go-to daily moisturizer.  But on one of those cold dry winter days, I'll still be going for the regular Aveeno because I'll need the richer more hydrating regular formulation.  Just like how I prefer cream or whole milk for my coffee.In summary, this is a great lotion that can both compliment or replace regular Aveeno for those that prefer a very light moisturizer while those that really prefer a richer formulation are most likely better off sticking with regular Aveeno. Now will that be cream or milk in your coffee?

What did I need? A filter to replace the filter in my Tassimo.Did this filter fit the bill?  Yes, this filter was compatible with my Tassimo and I couldn't notice any particular difference in performance.  Neither filter left black sediment in the bottom of the water reservoir and the flavor of my coffee wasn't impacted for the worse (or better).Would I recommend this filter? Considering that the Mavea brand filters are $5-$6 while this is $8, doesn't work with Mavea pitcher replacement meter, and doesn't have a recycling program it really is hard to recommend it over the original considering performance appeared similar.Notes about the app:The filter app is purely based on time, yet the filter is rated at gallons OR time. It has no way of knowing how many gallons you've used so it simply says "time's up".  Ok, if you're only worried about letting too much time expire between changes.  Additionally, the app will let you know where to buy more filters, if you live in the UK.  The rest of us get a list of distributors.  Oh, but they've been generous enough to make the app ad free, so says the app description.

This is an excellent monitor.  Color reproduction is excellent and comes factory adjusted with the compliance sheet showing it's been done.  I love reviewing my DSLR pictures with this monitor as they just pop, as well as highlighting any mistake in focus that I didn't see on my laptop monitor.Viewing angle.  The viewing angle of the monitor is so much better than that of my laptop.  Last night my wife and I were comparing winter hats on both monitors.  She swore the laptop monitor was showing us a navy hat while in fact it was grey. The laptop monitor was tilted just enough that we couldn't even tell what color it actually was.  We had no such issue with this Dell.About build, design, connections.This is your typical Dell monitor.  Average bezel, spring loaded easy to assemble stand, 90 degree rotation, front and back tilt, and multiple ports including USB 3.0, HDMI, and Display Port (in and out for daisy chaining), and speaker line out . USB, Display Port, and power cable is included.  No HDMI.This monitor should be a killer gaming monitor but I couldn't test response times as I don't PC game.  Specs are: Grey-to-Grey. 8 ms (typical), 6 ms (fast) according to Dell.In the end, specs are just specs.  All I know is that the pictures I took with my Canon never looked better.  It's like seeing the photos for the first time all over again.Highly recommended.

This is a very nice watch, one which my daughter is constantly trying to steal away from my wife.Notes about construction and design.  The band is real leather and the clasps and casing are real stainless steel.  The face is mother of pearl (or imitation mother of pearl) and looks quite nice with against the rose-gold band and case.  The overall design is simple but elegant.If I had any quibbles it would be that the foil finish on the band seems quite delicate - be careful not to scratch it.  Also, the watch does feel a little light.  The mineral crystal face should prevent scratches on the face which is a nice benefit.Finally, depending on the monitor you are using the watch might be a tad rosier than it appears in photos, i.e. a touch pinker and less straight gold in tone.

Here are the pros and cons as I see them with this product:Pros:*Taste - Has a real strawberry smoothie taste - somewhat similar to Yoplait Strawberry banana yogurt.  If you generally like strawberry/strawberry banana smoothies you'll most likely like this flavor.*No artificial sweetener aftertaste.* Mix-ability - I'd rate the ease of mixing of the powder in the 3.5 to 4 out of 5 range.  Better than average but not best in class for being able to mix in milk with just a spoon or other utensil.* Compact - a smaller-than-average scoop delivers as much protein as most larger scoops.Cons:* Very noticeable fiber.  I am definitely not a fan of fiber drink products and the added fiber in this mix gives it a very Metamucil like consistency and in-mouth feel.Debatable:* Soy protein: Could be a pro, could be a con depending on your preferences* Bag size.  I received 4 small bags in this order.  Considering the size of protein jars and bags that I usually get a single bag of this powder is much smaller than the usual.  This almost definitely has something to do with the smaller portion sizes, but still I was taken aback at the actual size of the bag.  0.6lbs says it all right here.Summary:This is great tasting, in my opinion, protein mx that is brought down slightly by the very noticeable fiber content.  If you're a fan of strawberry smoothies and don't mind fiber in your protein mixes then this is a great product for you.  Also if you enjoy smoothies and are looking for a non-dairy protein mix - though I assume you wouldn't be mixing it with milk.Side note: my package arrive with one of the 4 bags burst and powder all over the inside of the box.  I'm sure Amazon would take care of this for regular orders but something to note all the same.

Here are the pros and cons of this machine as I and my experienced sowing-machine user mother-in-law see them.Pros:* Directions:  The were well documented on paper (included), online, as well as on the machine.  Made starting to use the machine easier to do.* Sample designs.  Lots of built in sample designs to choose from (over 50 on paper, 2800 on the USB stick).* Ability to incorporate new designs.  Memory stick included to ease in transferring designs from computer to machine.* Software to help making your own designs.* Set up.  Sewing machine layout and physical design is similar to a traditional sewing machine making navigating the machine more familiar.* Start/stop button.  No clutter from a foot pedal (though a foot pedal wouldn't really make sense here.)* Compact design: Takes up roughly the same amount of space a traditional sewing machine would.* Ease of use.  After figuring out how to use the machine, producing embroidery was pretty straight forward.Cons:* Single color at a time.  You need to load each color onto the spool one at a time as they are needed for the design.  THis means you can't program your multi-color design, hit the start button and come back to a completed piece like you would at those mall kiosks.* If you don't use the correct thread or backing, you run the risk of getting excess thread excess loops.  Basically shortcuts could cost you in the quality of the finished piece.Debatable:* Machine aesthetic.  A personal question as to whether you like the white and gold design of the machine.* Uses a ton of thread, but really what do we expect for an embroidery machine.* Learning curve.  While learning the machine is easy to do with well documented instructions that are easily accessible in multiple formats, it does take a while.  It took as about an hour to study the instructions.In summary, this is a great home embroidery machine that loses a point because of the need to switch colors as needed and for the slightly finicky nature of needing to use the right materials or risk excess thread loops and slightly misaligned outlines.
Witty and fun British indie film.

This is a fine little kit.  Scissors are sharp, comb is just the right size for your mustache, but will also work for sideburns and around the ear.After going through numerous cheap hair scissors and finding they all pull, it's great to get a sharp pair that doesn't pinch/pull.  And although marketed towards men, they would work for anyone needing a set about this size for trimming/grooming.If I had one gripe, they are barely big enough for my hands, which as far as guy hands go are probably about average.

Here are the pros and cons of these towels as I see them.Pros:*Soft after washing.  The marketing text says these towels will stay soft after many times through the wash.  So far so good and while they arrived not overly soft/plush, they were much better after that first wash.*Absorbent.*Size.  These aren't huge towels but they aren't on the small cheap side.  The size felt just right for a guy that's 6ft.Cons:*Don't seem to dry any better than my regular cotton towels.Debatable:*Color.  I think the color is very handsome and goes really well with my bathroom deco, but this is obviously personal taste.  the color is rich but a bit more on the olive-y side than the picture shows.*Material.  These towels feature a cotton/modal mix.  The towels are soft but do have a bit of a rayon or synthetic silk feel to them.  This is what gives the towel the soft feel but is different than brand new ultra plush cotton.  I think it works but if you're set on a specific "plush cotton" feel you might be disappointed.

This is a pretty straightforward product.  Place the cap in the open bottle, put the pump on top and pump like you're blowing up a bike tire.  The problem is that the pump just slides over the cap without a latch or hook to keep it attached or locked in while pumping.So while this works as advertised, I felt I needed quite a bit of pressure to keep the seal when pumping.  Maybe I was using too much force but I could see how someone would get quite fatigued using this product.  Additionally, it was much easier to get a level of vacuum in a fuller bottle than an emptier bottle.On the plus side, it looks great which won't look out of place on a well appointed wine bar.

Here are the pros and cons of this bar.Pros:*No artificial sweeteners.  Which means no chemical aftertaste.*Not too sweet.  Not bland but just sweet enough in my humble opinion.*20 grams of protein with only 6grams of fat.  This is a nice medium size bar, not a full meal replacement bar like a Big 100. It has a nice amount of protein for it's size - many other medium or snack sized bars are only 15 grams -  but also not at the cost of extra calories (only 210 here) or fat.  Some bars get up into the 8 to 10 range for a 20g protein equivalent.*12 grams of fiber which is not noticeable.  Unlike drink mixes that include fiber and have a very thick and almost pulp-y feel in mouth, the fiber in this bar isn't really noticeable.* Banana flavor.  Banana flavor comes in two distinct varieties: fake banana that comes in candy, like Laffy Taffy, and real fruit banana.  This bar is more real fruit than fake candy banana.Cons:* Dry and chewy.  That lack of fat comes at a price.  The bars I had were dry and somewhat chewy, which in my opinion were the worst things about this bar.Debatable:* Peanut butter and banana flavor.  The bar really does taste like a peanut butter and banana sandwich, which is a flavor I personally like. Admittedly isn't for everyone so your mileage will obviously vary on how much you like that flavor.* Not coated.  The picture is somewhat deceiving in that it looks like the bar is possibly coated in a yogurt-flavor coating.  It isn't.  Additionally, it looks like the inner bar has an almost granola bar consistency.  It doesn't, it's much more like a non-oatmeal cookie dough.  Very consistent throughout.In summary, the best way to describe this bar is to compare it to another Met-Rx product - the Big 100 Cookie Dough Bar - but smaller, without the chips, less sweet, somewhat drier/cheriwer, and banana peanut-butter flavored.  This for me is an almost perfect downsizing of what is one of my favorite bars.  If only the bar was a tad moister it'd be perfect in my humble opinion.

I really enjoyed it. I guess I'm left a bit bitter over the ending though. I think another thirty pages could have made this book go from good to great. This has the typical aw shucks hero tale flavor that Alan Black is a master of and we all like. It's a good book, just not as good as the first one. By the points:-The end could have been a lot better and more complete. It left a lot in the air and came on suddenly. Not quite a cliffhanger but let's just say a sequel is mandatory.-Definitely a "ground pounder" tale, not a spacer tale (for better or worse)-Like all Alan Black, the characters are a bit goody-goody and circumstances are a bit too handy-Main character wastes less and less time on self doubt-Started good exploration into several alien species-Like what happened to the main character's evolution, both figuratively and literally-A lot of things were nicely positioned for a strong sequel-Kind of got tired of the random scenes where the one barely dressed hottie dropped in to shoot/stab something or reveal some handy info all while we had to receive gratuitous commentary on her butt, nipples, or outline. I'm not a prude - it just became a bit repetitive.-Would have liked to have had more insight into the main villain race's viewpoint / motivationsThis is #2 in the series, so if you haven't read the first do that first. It has necessary background and you don't want to miss out on the goodness of the original book.

Kyle Riggs' stories had been a lot better than Cody Riggs' adventures until now. This is the best Star Force book I've read in a long time and finally made Cody shine. They are all good but this one was really good.-Cody matures into his own legacy and accomplishments escaping his father's shadow-Tons of plot threads are wrapped up, so many I had even forgotten about some-The number and diversity of races involved is excellent, and we now have several as crew-All the pagetime dedicated to Marvin. I won't give anything away other than to say there's a rich and surprising story there-This book wrapped up the Cody Riggs trilogy: The end was a complete end with no cliffhangers whatsoever-There were some heart tugging moments of humanity from things like brainboxes-Strong dialog with the ancient race. Like how Cody handled that.-The Cody relationship scenes were handled better than usual-A gratuitous bit of nostalgia at the end that brings things full circle nicelyThere weren't any major bad point in this book either. So again a highpoint in the series. I'm sure there will be more and I'm glad for it. I didn't like how Cody's arc had been dragging down the series but this book redeemed the whole lot.

Put in family's 3 houses all over the place in every application imaginable. Wasted $100 of my money. Every single one failed (flickering/strobing) in 2 months or less. You have to mail them back for replacement, wasting more dollars of your money and time. I figure paying $2 every 2 months to return a bulb is pouring good money after bad. I'm not replacing them by the trashbag full every two months either. That defeats the purpose. I would have been happy had they lived a year on average. 2 months? My incandescents do better.Should have bought Phillips. I see most people now are having similar issues. Stay away.Only thing good was the bulb is all plastic and didn't tear holes in my trashbag when I tossed them out.

Surprised/misled by all the positive reviews. This was, at best, very bland and predictable in my opinion.x Premise was okx At no point was there really any "one more page" addiction/intensityx Wasted a lot of time/pages on stuff that didn't matter (good editor could have tightened this up a lot)x Characters were terriblex A lot of things were absurd or skipped over (found a whole new world after missing the target?, Pan vs. Soldiers vs. Normals, ...)I don't give bad reviews often, and I usually like this kind of "back in time" story. Unfortunately I just didn't see any part that was good and a lot was bad. I would have been happy with a book that was good by YA standards, but it didn't even meet that bar. I'm putting this author on my do not read list.

You only have a few pages to work with, but this takes things into an interesting direction...x Emphasis is on relationships and lossx Explores the different ways we can relate to AIx How AI might perceive usOther than being short, my only issues really were that the last AI made some really odd decisions and actions.If you have 30 minutes to burn and like AI stories, snag it.

I don't see many reviews up on this yet so I'll add my own. I was surprised how good this was. Other reviewers have given a good description of the plot points, so I'll just add the following:x Excellent Twist/foundation - The "lines" really work to create a good story and enhance insights/personalitiesx Solid Characters - Not just a superhero coming of age retreadx A full book - No cliffhanger, but there's definitely more to explore in the next book coming Feb 2016I think this book was great, and given the background we receive reading it I expect the sequel to be even better.

There's nothing out there like these Hank books. The author has kicked out another one with the same great elements as the past.X  Typical hilarious absurd moments (the Dredel Led butler, the Soup, Delavoa anything, Hank running down a hall naked tearing down artwork, ...)X  Great totally unique characters (all the favorites are back)X  Hank's supremely practical perspective on lifeX  Some insight into Hank's backgroundX  End was in a good placeSo many awesome moments in this book. Man I love this series. Was not disappointed in the slightest.

This is a bit of an odd series in how the author is able to tell the story. I've really enjoyed the earlier books. However - I think this one suffers significantly based on the following points:X  Too many characters - Without re-reading the previous books you get lost in the cast of hundreds and forget who's whoX  Story elements were disappointing - The big plots were pretty vanilla. This is upside down from what we've come to expect. Take the first book where a nobody ambassador goes on crazy dates and amazing things happen! Here it's the reverse - A whole armada of ships visit the station and pretty much squat happens except a bunch of mooching and dancing. The new show, the adopted girl, the wanderers, a new race... so many opportunities that turned out to be dudsX  The world/situation/characters are the same at the end - We learn a bit more about the Stryx but that's about it. It was all a bunch of nothing at the end of the day.X  This was a hard book to pick up - It's important to remember the specific attributes of all the races, what made each of the humans unique, etcetera... and the last book having been so long ago you forget all of it with few recaps or remindersX  This book was a hard book to finish - I found myself able to set it down easily. Not a compelling page turner. I kept waiting for those subtle conversations with a Stryx that flip the whole world upside down or a crisis the humans turn around into a miracle or some other typical fare of the series.Bottom line it seemed like we were just going through the motions to cash in on another book. I'll give the series one more chance because I've loved the first books, but if the next iteration in October ("Vacation on Union Station") isn't any better I will be permanently abandoning the series in disappointment.

This book was, appropriately, about rebuilding after the big battle in the previous book. Rebuilds are normally boring, but the author did a great job on this one and found several ways to keep the action up. By the points:X  The scene where The Admiral deals with his Tractoan problem made the book. That one scene alone. The rest is just gravy.X  Major focuses: Rear admiral Janeski/imperials, Nikomedes, org growing pains, family issues, reputation/role of the MSPX  Don’t like how Nikomedes storyline was left, nor how it played out with AkanthaX  Like how the old Middleton crew rec’d a nice setup for another fun side adventureX  Would have liked more than a tease over the clover heartX  C’mon with the clover timeline alreadyX  Thought the babies would be a bigger dealX  More info on MEN / MANX A quick readThe end was where it had to be and not bad considering.I'm giving this the full 5 stars for the Tractoan scene. The overall book was a 4, but that scene and its dialog is one of a few I've read over the years that will stick in my mind long after I've forgotten everything else about this series. Like when the main character gets the silver talent pipes in the scene from Rothfuss' "The Name of the Wind".

I give credit to the main concept. Of the 100's of stories I've read this setting seems pretty unique and interesting. On that basis alone I read the book and feel I got my money's worth.The author does a solid job of exploring this meat world given the short few pages he has to tell the tale, but I take a full 2 stars off because:1) There really isn't an end. The story runs out in an odd place that I would say doesn't even qualify as a cliffhanger. It would be a poor place to start for a sequel.2) I also felt that the events which occurred at the end were rather wasted/pointless as nothing was achieved and a day of storyline was thrown away on travel at a time when every moment counted.3) The disparity in the surface people's level of education/tech seems a bit absurd. The time spent on the creature wasn't that great, but you've got people using computers in one place and the equivalent of 18th century country bumpkins in anotherSo, I'd say read this anyway. Especially if he expands with a subsequent story. Just go in expecting an appetizer... not a meal.Also - At the end of the book the author explains how he came up with the concept for this book. I found it a very interesting twist of perspective. Kind of like how children sometimes see broccoli as little trees.

The first book was a little weak but had some interesting concepts and the powerful human reaver units to read about (3-stars-ish). Here comes the sequel. I thought the author and the tale would get better with experience. Well... neither did.By the points:1) The end sucks. It's a cliffhanger, but that's irrelevant. It basically announces "hey we're officially jumping the shark - stay tuned!"2) Too many pages of fluff and internal character thoughts. Repeatedly took many pages on what should have been edited down to a paragraph or two3) Regarding editing, it's clearly not professionally edited but it isn't too bad either.4) Humans are super-uper-duper powered and nothing touches them. No challenge. No fun. No suspense. Even tough bad guys have to go 3-on-1 or more to stand a chance.5) No new elements of strategy, ability, or what-not.6) Not a page turner. I put this book down and walked away from it 3 times only coming back in hopes of an interesting finish. Even the action scenes weren't engrossing.7) Main characters are very dry and two-dimensionalMany more books are planned in this series. I will not be buying any more of them. There are bad books in every series, but this one is so bad, and so clearly sets the storyline in a silly direction, that I have no interest in continuing.I hate writing reviews like this, but it's that bad. I have trouble citing anything this bad that I've read recently, even the cheap/free indie stuff I take a chance on.

This is as good or better than the previous books, and very long to boot. The end is a bit of a cliffhanger, and leaves things in an interesting place, but the ride had to stop somewhere.By the points:-Learn more about the soft krall-Learn more about the olt ships-Scale/stakes get elevated-Interesting new combat/tactics/abilities introduced-Hub world/Kobani human cooperation and conflicts explored-Continued growth/exploration of the 3 slave races-Continued human tricks, but Krall learn fast-Some wins and some losses, not just a one-sided beat ‘em upI think there’s probably one book left in the main storyline, with maybe an offshoot story or two that gives backstory on a major Prada, Torki, or other some such character. After that the Krall are done. Not a lot of fight left to hash out. Author has given us some good hints that there’s a bigger story to explore though after we get done whupping the Krall.FYI – Saw a complaint about the $6.99 price. C’mon! This has turned into a consistently great story. There were some editing issues but very few and much cleaner than most. The story is also 2 or 3 times as big as the cheaper indie stuff. You get what you pay for. The indie stuff is occasionally great too, but this is a big pile of top-notch win.
