Be glad you no longer live in the bookstore era and aren’t stuck with a $25 first release hardback price to squeeze every drop of revenue out of your pocket like the old days.Regardless, if you’ve read the first 3 there’s no stopping you at this point. Just prepare for 2 or 3 sleepless nights instead of one because it’s a whopper.

There was a small bit of romance, but this really isn't a romance tale. The dates were just a framework rolling out a nice story. It's a fun read with some nice unique elements in it.I put off reading it until there wasn't anything else because of the reviews calling it a romance. When I saw there was a whole series set up after this, I took a chance and I don't regret it. I even pre-ordered the last one Spy Night.The stories are short, but the characters are good and the events / circumstances keep the book rolling along with suspense, mystery or other interesting things. Was really surprised how good this was.

Like others have noted, this is just as good as the first Hard Luck Hank. The series is great, and even better is the fact that there's really nothing like it. Only book I can think of that actually made me laugh out loud at several points. Gritty parts, sad parts, a really nice emotional buffet. The author has a talent for making the mundane seem special and conversely the special seem mundane.I'll only leave this one review, but all the books were great. No cliffhangers either. Even the early years / Delavoa short stories were solid. If you like HLH #1 I dare say you'll like the other books even better. The author keeps the core characters and adds other interesting ones, the events are fresh but always uniquely Hank.

I don't care what the author's political views are, and don't even necessarily disagree with some points... but I didn't want a treatise on his philosophy. I wanted a sci-fi book.Normally I give a detailed review, but I can't here. The book was just reheated fluff and ranting.As others have noted, 30-40% of the book is political detour and commentary. The whole story is a retread. Nuttall writes some good stuff, but this isn't it.Characters - Weak and naveCombat - The best part of the book, but it's only really at the summary levelHad the chance to do some neat exploration and relationships with the other races, instead just took a boring obvious path.A lot of time just wasted extrapolating silly decay scenarios on earth due to racial over-sensitivity, anti-union, and pandering politicians.A lot of time wasted on taking two characters through boot that don't really do anything amazing. They just provide viewpoints to tell the story with but aren't pivotal in any way.

So there are "animen" that are part animal / part man. They are second class citizens. Rhinos, wolves, leopards, eagles, possums, you name it. This is set in a universe where megacorps run the show and you want to reach "buyout" where you've paid off all your debts incurred from childhood which makes you a free man/beast/whatever.My biggest complaint is the writing. It just isn't very good. 2/3 of the book is everyone having sex with one another. That is literally true... no exaggeration. Mad? Have sex with them. New to the ship? Have sex with them. Save their life? Have sex with them. Just had sex with them? Have sex with them again. Leopard on leopard. Leopard on human woman. Leopard on pretty much anything and everything. Sex. I'm definitely not a prude, but it's like a 12-year-old wrote a harem novel. The scenes aren't even steamy or relevant to anything else going on.My next biggest complaint are the characters. They are all Gomer Pyle level naïve. Nobody gets developed but the main character.Beyond that it isn't too bad. The writing has really bad editing, but you should have seen that coming just by looking at the awful cover that looks like it was created with MS Paint. A lot of pages were spent trying to make a big deal of how the leopard became a pilot and how that made him different only to have him throw it all away for the life of a ground soldier the last third of the book. Stereotypes like weasel men acting like weasels, sand worlds being middle-east-like rich slave nations. Just nags like that which a good editor could have tightened up.What was good and earned three stars (rounding up) from me was the combat scenes. The conflict was along simplistic philosophical views which was rather weak, but the writing covering the action was the best of the book.This story had a lot of interesting tidbits which could have been explored, they just weren't. The author obviously is able to lay down a solid concept. I might check back on him in three or four years once he refines the execution side of things.

First, despite the title, you're actually buying books 4, 5, and 6 in the Conrad series: "The Flying Warlord", "Lord Conrad's Lady", and "Conrad's Quest for Rubber".1) Buy and read the first 3 books in the series first, they really are a must. They are also available in another omnibus: "Conrad Stargard: The Radiant Warrior (Conrad Stargard Series combo volumes Book 1)"2) If you liked the first 3, you'll like these 3.3) With the last book it starts getting weak and sloppy, and Conrad isn't even the main character4) Do not read Conrad's time machine until you've read everything else. I would not recommend reading that one at all actually because it was terrible and again doesn't have Conrad as a main character.5) Stop here. Don't bother with the further books 7 and 8 (only sold individually) as the storyline jumps the shark at that point and isn't really consistent in style and character with previous books (note the additional authors in the credits of future books as further proof)This is a "fun" read. Four stars for fun, not really quality or originalism. I would normally give something this silly and stereotypical with such terrible harem fantasy stuff 3 stars at best, but I found myself consistently entertained with each page so I'm bumping it up to 4. Just know going in you're not getting something complex.

This book was disjointed and unexciting until chapter 7, about 30% through. Then it's night & day change... becomes a fun read. If you buy, gut it out till you get there and you won't regret it.Things to know:-Stereotypes - Every. Single. Character. If you've read a lot of space stories none of this will be new to you.-This is not really a pirate tale (nor does it have anything meaningful to do with trading either)-This really isn't a robin hood / prosperity story, money is barely a background motive and plays little emphasis in the overall story-The main character (Webber) could have been a lot better/unique/mysterious and rec'd more pages-Space combat is basically "both ships shoot all your missles, see how many get through"-I guess a lot of people come into this excited from the prior series in the same universe, I did not so take that for what it's worth-The end is very weak an unsatisfying (The synopsis ends right where the story ends)-Lots of opportunities aren't taken (derelict ships aren't salvaged/towed, weapon systems aren't improved, etc.)-The secrets revealed turn out to be boring (why/who's house is Webber paying on?, what's Webber's background?, the secret tech? all really disappointing when revealed)So the first part would get zero stars, the rest would get 3 stars. I think the series has promise and will read the next one, but if the next one isn't any better than this one I will not be going any further.

So we're now on our second story with Cody Riggs (Kyle's son). The plethora of aliens continues to expand, a big plus, but the story isn't as exciting as it was in the first 10 books under Kyle.When just B. V. Larson wrote and Mark Boyett narrated the earlier stories, it was a consistent action-packed roller coaster with a clear struggle/goal they strove for in each book. I wonder if the slump this time is because another author is a major contributor in this book as Larson is still writing consistently excellent stuff in his other series.By the points:-They are trapped/cut off from earth, but that struggle of getting home is background noise at best and I felt it should be more of the focus-Sokolov and his temptress sidekick were a waste of pages that really just enabled better intro of "the new blues" / big bad guys-I like what was done with the raptors-The new communicator was interesting-Cody character is a mere shadow of Kyle Riggs, and his girlfriend is 2D window dressing-This was a big chance for Marvin to shine, I don't feel that he did (I'm a Marvin fan)-The end was a good tease-I like the hints at connection to past & future story arcs (e.g. Cody's first girl getting killed)-Macro cameos kind of left me feeling burned out, they're just not exciting anymore-Machismo couple interactions / love scenes were even more awful than usual. Take them out or have them add to the story. Build a real relationship/bond that's tested, make them erotic, anything, just give them a purpose and some semblance of reality.I'll read the next one in the series and give time for the authors to develop Cody and give readers greater investment, but only because this is part of a great series and Larson is a consistently good author. If this had been book one of a series by a new author I would probably have tossed it and put that author's name on my do-not-read-anymore list. It wasn't bad per se, it just wasn't that good. I wasn't compelled to turn the next page and stay up till 2AM reading it. Only the teases and hints that were leveraged from the series kept me going until the end.

Ignore the "Age Level" and "Grade Level" info in the book description. (I was almost put off thinking this was a simple young adult story.)It's a trader / first-contact tale. It can get light on details. The main character being fantastically rich oversimplifies a lot of sticky issues. The race contact and trading without language stuff has been done before in other books pretty much identically to this. However, the key is it's woven together very well with good characters and a (very) fast pace. If you like trader tales you'll like this one. Reminds me a lot of Cherryh's books.Like the book before it, the end is similarly abrupt. The spelling/grammar/name mix-up is there too. Only one time was it bad enough to jar me from the story though and this is on par with books of similar caliber. If you liked book 1, this is more of the same but in my opinion bigger and better than the first story. It's going to be at least a trilogy though, and likely 5 or 6 books. I went ahead and read though as this author seems to be publishing new books at a good rate.Don't take my review as negative, the author did a great job continuing a very fun series. Basically, he took the best pieces of several excellent stories from others and wove them into a compelling single tale that keeps providing answers as well as new mysteries, growth, combat, economics, politics, the whole cabbage. The pace necessitates that many details get glossed over, but I'm ok with that in return for never having to read a boring viewpoint or slow buildup.Looking forward to the next one in the series.

Bought for someone interested in comfort where they are worn in heat/cold while performing hand-labor. Been through a lot of lanyards. Most would chafe when sweating for hours or had super-cheap hardware that broke resulting in a lost (and very costly) badge. The lanyard material is comfortable and holds up to wear. It's a no-frills construction, but still holds up to heavy wear and tear. Length seems ideal (doesn't hang too long). Only reason I would say not to buy might be if your work has a safety requirement for break-away lanyards that separate if caught in machinery (these don't have that feature obviously).

These are hands-down the best crates for quality, style, and (almost) price. Buy them now.If you need a little more convincing...Be careful of the cheaper Sterilite file crates that don't have the circle-shaped side cutouts. This version (16939006) is the best of all crates on the market and on the lower end of price spectrum as well. You can stack these top-to-bottom, as well as side-to-side (e.g. create a bookshelf). MOST OTHERS WON'T stack side-to-side. Each way you can stack it has tabs or grooves to lock into position (versus cheaper ones that don't lock into place on side-to-side configurations).Another reviewer complained about the price of these crates. I can understand, but they were spoiled due to getting an awesome deal. These nicer ones go for about $7 + tax at a certain superstore retailer, so Amazon is 5 bucks high right now ($50 for 6 instead of about $45 after tax in a store). Amazon apparently does do (or has had) sales where they went down into the $30-dollar range on these nicer ones. However, it's worth the extra 5 bucks for me not to wait in line and haul these monsters home (they rarely have this many in stock anyway). Just bite the bullet and get the good ones here & now, you won't regret it. They are worth it at this price ($50).Ideal uses:-File folders (can easily replace an expensive file cabinet and is better because you can haul a single crate anywhere and sort through it)-Bookshelves (put them on their side and stack them to fit your space)-Raw papers (I store reams of legal docs too large to put in individual file folders with a fancy colored-sheet to separate and they fit great)-Kid-stuff organizersThese are sturdy and handle being filled to the brim with paper. I have some as old as 5 years that are still like new and take heavy use.Once you've used a file crate, whether this model or not, you'll never go back. The modular aspect is a game-changer:1) You can take just what you need into your living room or put it into your car.2) Each crate can keep a different category of stuff (vs. just 3 or 4 drawers to choose from in a file cabinet)3) You can keep the most frequently used crates on top / near at hand4) You can stack/configure the crates to suit your space/whim (vs. a gigantic file cabinet - these can be put in tight cubby holes, under desks, in closets)5) You can grow your storage as you need it (I add crates to my "bookshelf", my legal cases, every new year of taxes, etc)6) You can use them for random needs in a pinch and haul it somewhere (the circles are small enough to keep most things inside, great for game system cables and discs, dvds, etc.)7) Dirt. Cheap.8) Lasts. Even the best quality boxes fail after moderate handling or age. Heaven help you if one gets wet. These babies are tuff.9) Even full they are manageable (think hauling around a huge heavy box / plastic tote full of paper vs. this smaller crate)The only reasons I can think of not to buy these at Amazon would be 1) color preference or 2) a requirement for sealed containment. They do come in variations such as purple in stores.Welcome to a better way of living. If you buy these, they will be the first of many. They are the kind of thing that is so useful you give them to friends as gifts.

There is a better choice.This model is flimsier and doesn't lock in when stacked side-to-side (e.g. when using them to create a bookshelf). If you just need crates that will hold file folders and stack+lock top-to-bottom, these are fine, but there is a nicer / more-expensive version that will ALSO stack+lock end-to-end. Search on here for "Sterilite 16939006 File Crate" and you'll see it.The main way to tell the difference is the sides. The sturdier all-way-locking has circles cut out of the side, little half-rectangles at each corner that look like feed scoops (these are what lock in on the sides, opposing corners are slightly smaller/larger to fit into each other), and a little more plastic. This version contains less plastic and is more of a grid pattern.A 6-pack of the good ones as of this writing was only ten bucks more ($50.00) so I'd advise going with them. I've used the good version for years to hold books, legal papers, file folders, just about everything and they are strong enough to last decades. These? Still decent but not as good when considering there's a better option for a few bucks more.

Unfortunately there doesn't seem to be a "perfect" case out there yet ([...]) for the 5-inch GPS screens, so I settled for this one. (I use this for my Garmin Nuvi 1490LMT 5-inch...)-Holds the unit nicely-If I jam things in right, it will hold the power cable too-No way the sucker cup and mount will fit inside-The little exterior carabiner clip is cheapo plasicky (don't plan on attaching it to the outside of your luggage and it making it to your destination)-Shipping took SEVEN DAYS from the seller bestpricecenter (guess amazon prime shipping has spoiled me)Also, if you just stumbled across this, note that this shell is available in many colors and a few fabric/material coverings.One other weird thing to know - When you first get it the toxic plastic smell will knock you out. I'm no sissy, but just holding it for about 3 minutes after opening literally gave me a headache, and my wife smelled it from the other room. (Think new car smell times a million.) I actually had to leave it outside for a few days just to air it out. I saw other reviews commenting about this and just dismissed it as some oversensitive person being picky, but be prepared. You will not want to leave it inside your house for the first couple of days.Would I buy it again? Yes (But only until something better comes along.)

Other reviews tell you what you're getting, let me tell you what you're NOT:1) The rear wireless speaker transmitter/receiver. That piece is model # SH-FX71, about $130 bucks as of 3/27/2011, and NOT in the box. The unit is COMPATIBLE with wireless rear speakers, but the only wireless transmitter that comes with the unit is the USB Wireless LAN. (Other home theatre models have this piece included at similar price points.)2) Speaker wire that is long enough. Worse, the speaker wire even has a proprietary connector on it you have to use when connecting at the main unit (I guess you could splice in additional length). The rear speaker wires aren't long enough for even the smallest of living room runs assuming you'd like to run both cables cleanly along the same wall/baseboard. In my 10x12 room I would need at least an additional 8 foot in length.3) High-quality earth-moving sound. Seeing this system listed as a 1000-watt system you might think it will be a super-awesome system like some of the other 1000-watt systems you've heard (e.g. Bose). You can run 1000 watts through a potato but it won't make the potato sound good. You're getting a $500 sound system, nothing more / nothing less. It sounds really good for that price point, but it will not touch even the worst of the higher end $1,000 and up 1000-watt systems so please don't think "more watts = more better".4) Tons of inputs and outputs. You get 1 HDMI out, 1 LAN in, 1 red/white audio in (AUX),  1 yellow video out, 1 digital audio in, an FM antenna connection, a USB connection for the Wireless LAN adapter (that is included), and a custom port for the wireless speaker transceiver (that isn't included). Notice there is NO COMPONENT OUT. If you have a TV from the early HD days you'll probably not have an HDMI port, only a DVI in and some Component inputs. The solution here is to get an HDMI->DVI cable for about 10 bucks (you're losing nothing, DVI is just a subset of the HDMI standard with a different plug type). You CAN NOT use this unit to consolidate a lot of inputs, you'll have to rely on your TV. If your TV doesn't have room for all of your inputs, this unit isn't going to solve your problem. If you have 3 or 4 sources of sound going into your current receiver, that will have to change under this model's limited input availability.Other random food for thought:1) If you don't need the 3D aspect, consider a very similar but slightly earlier Panasonic model SC-BTT730. Seems to be otherwise identical to this model, but quite a bit cheaper AND it comes with the rear wireless speaker transmitter.2) Also, at time of writing Amazon as well as others were selling this same model on Amazon. I always prefer to buy directly from Amazon stocked items when I have a choice because you're going to get the fast shipping, great support, and no tax. The "other guys" at time of writing are charging at least $70 more and who knows how slow they ship.3) Remember you are buying a sound system and blu ray system glued together. One breaks = you replace both. You're obviously getting the whole package cheaper, but don't whine 5 years down the road if the Blu-ray player breaks and you have to throw out all the speakers because you must buy a totally new home-theatre-in-a-box (HTIB).Final overview:-At the current price of $530 I would not buy this model again (I have to turn around and spend another $130 for the wireless because my cables are too short)-If this model ever starts coming with the wireless unit for speakers (or you think you don't need it) I would say it would be a good buy then-If I was doing it all again, I would buy either the SC-BTT730, a sony model, or an LG model. They offer the full package for $550 or less. (What I got in my box was a $500 dollar sound system that I have to pay $660 total for.)-Not a bad unit, just there is equivalent on the market for significantly less total cost-------------------Update: Originally I gave this 2 stars, Let me take one away upon update for the following reasons:First the remote. The play/pause/forward/nav buttons you use the most are almost at the bottom of the remote and you can't tell by shape/feel in the dark which way is "up". Why would you put the buttons you use the most somewhere on the remote that is awkward to reach? I know this seems like a little thing, but it really starts to annoy over time. (Try holding your dish or directTV remote upside-down and you'll get the idea of what this is like.)Second is the sound quality. It seems to vary a lot, "creep down", has poor low end, and poor voice range. First out of the box when I did this review Blu-ray is all groovy. After over a month of watching normal TV, satellite and DVR programs I miss my cheap-o system that broke. I've fiddled with the settings for a while, but it gets quieter and I keep inching up the volume then I flip a channel or source and BAAAAMMMMMMMOOOOOOO it's stupid loud. Clear Voices and Crisp Bass on anything but Blu-Ray? Forget it (even with digital audio in on a high quality source.) I guess the reason they built in a "whisper" mode was in attempt to compensate for the poor voice range. When you turn on whisper it goes from awful to just slightly less awful.Third is rear speakers. My original review noted the ripoff that this system did NOT come with the wireless speaker transmitter. I coughed up and bought it for $130 anyway. The connection drops about once a day now and the little connection LED goes red, so I have to climb behind my couch and reboot it. Joy.This thing is now such a piece of junk I'm moving it out my living room as soon as I can afford another brand. After this, I will think long and hard before ever buying a Panasonic anything again. I've owned a lot of their gear before, even another HTIB, but this is a complete disaster.If I was reading this review I would interpret it as some guy really angry at the product looking to run it down. I typically dismiss such reviews. In this case though, please be aware that I'm not mad, it is genuinely a piece of junk because it fails on so many points. One thing or two and it might just be me or a bad set of equipment. There isn't anything "good" about this, and a long list of "bad". I'm just really disappointed. I read the reviews on this before I bought it and they were very favorable. At the very least listen to it in a store beside something comparable, that alone should convince you to buy another product. I wish I had.

To understand this review, know that Name of the Wind (book one in this story) is one of my top 3 books of all time, along side George R. R. Martin's Game of Thrones. Tolkien is a pulp hack beside these works. The two parts from Name of the Wind where (spoiler alert for Name of the Wind:) Kvothe saved the girl from flames in the fishery and played the lute minus a string to earn his pipes will stick with me for decades.(end of spoiler) THIS BOOK, HOWEVER, has NO SUCH SCENES. It is 1000 pages akin to a shallow pool. Just when a certain story begins to take shape and become interesting, he ends it and moves on to another point in Kvothe's life. The writing is as strong as the first book, it's just that the stories are disjointed and brief. The only thing connecting them is that they are all Kvothe's past experiences. If you've ever read a collection of short stories, you'll know the feeling. You can't tell a 5-star story in 25-pages. Jamming twenty decent ministories together in a single book cannot make it somehow collectively better. This book should have been 3 or 4 separate books each giving time to create the richness I appreciated before. A 5-star story makes a grown man laugh and cry when he reads it. It's not a bad book, but it's light-years away from the first one. The disappointment factor alone is worth the loss of a star. As far as the ending, the only way I could tell the book was done was because there were no more pages to turn. It stunk. No cliffhanger, no real closure, no unification of the disjointed stories, squat. Just some kind of weak acknowledgement that he has to stop this trainwreck at some point. It might be some kind of foundation for the next book... not really to be enjoyed itself. Only time will tell I suppose. Is it worth the price and a good read? Yes. Will it satisfy your appetite for more Name of the Wind? ABSOLUTELY NOT. Should you just put it in your queue for two years till the next one comes out? I would.

(Please read update further down...)Orignial impression: I actually bought this for my toddler so he'd stop borrowing daddy's maglight and smacking it on my tile floor. I find myself using it quite often now. The batteries have lasted two weeks with him leaving it on a lot, etc. The light is better than what my mag provides. However - A lot of reviews give you the impression the light shines for miles at super intensity... that's just not the case even on the first day of fresh batteries. It's an LED light and if you have owned LED lights before you know how they provide an inferior light. That said, for and LED light it's one of the best I've owned personally. Combine with the price and you have an amazing value. There are two circumstances for which I wouldn't recommend this - 1) Professional/heavy use (it's built pretty well but wouldn't hold up to demanding daily use for more than probably 3-6 months) 2) Someone needing a portable spotlight that is brighter than the sun (for that go buy the black & decker someone mentioned in the other reviews)UPDATE: I've had this little flashlight for a few months now. The end connector/screw cap is now loose and I have to overtighten it for the battery circuit to stay connected and keep the beam on (the cap is square so it sits funny now against the matching square column). Another thing annoying that you discover from use is that the light won't stand up easily lens-end-down. You never realize how often you do this by habit until you can't anymore. You either have to lay it on its side or hang it by the strap. I would not buy this product again and will have to replace it soon. I think I'll try the black & decker torch that people keep talking about in these reviews. This one will go in the trash.

Wife had trouble finding thermals long enough that would stay tucked in - these definitely fit the bill. After wearing she was happily surprised at how warm (but not hot/sweaty) they were under her work shirt in 20 & 30 degree F temps. They are across the board superior to all the other thermals she has owned and the price is quite fair. Would (and will) buy again.

Main issue: They leak quickly. Also, the ziplock-like seal at the end is cheapo with a little plastic closer comb that falls off and gets lost. I'm generally pretty forgiving with minimal expectations but I threw two pillows in a bag, sucked it down super thin... the very next day the pillows were swollen back to half-size, after two days the bags were just bags with no vacuum left at all. I tried all the bags I received, followed directions carefully, all of that. Continued failure. I'm really disappointed.

This Adora Playtime Baby weighs less than a pound and is about one foot head to toe. Wee ones will find her easy to carry and maneuver. She smells like a freshly powdered baby. Her face is detailed simply with lightly painted eyebrows above big eyes that close when she “sleeps” and pink lips pursed just so to be forever ready for her bottle (included). Molded hands and feet are similarly simply detailed with suggestions of finger and toenails. Her pajamas are cute with a polka dot pattern and matching cap with little pink bow. Beneath the pajamas is a stuffed cloth torso to which limbs and head look to be securely attached. The “baby” and her outfit are machine washable, something that I consider a major plus. I refrain from buying anything that contacts skin that can't be cleaned before putting it into play or use. There are less expensive “first baby” dolls to choose, but I'd have no issues paying a bit more for the extended longevity that I perceive comes with an Adora Playtime Baby.

This DII Professional Bib Apron is functionally designed to cover just about every body shape and size. The apron’s length and width are generous and the neck and waist straps are long. The waist straps simply tie together. At the neck, one of the straps has double metal rings hanging at the end. To secure, the second strap is passed through both rings and then reversed, over one and through the other, tightening as it's pulled. Overall, the construction looks to be strong with stress points double stitched. If I could change anything, it would be the weight of the fabric. I found it too light to repel liquid or keep voluminous splatters from passing through to the clothes beneath. Everything considered, I recommend this DII Professional Bib Apron to anyone, with the caveat to avoid being splashed, especially by tomato sauce and the like.

I like these Philips Wireless Bluetooth Headphones. For one, they are a fraction (1/4) of the cost that I paid for the Bose headphones DH desperately wanted for his birthday. First, I have had no problem connecting with multiple devices. It may be as simple as the fact that I read directions, but I’ve not experienced any of the problems DH has encountered with having to repeatedly re-pair with his devices. Second, the Philips Headphones are drastically lighter; I might forget they were on if they weren’t snug (perfect to stay on without slipping). The third reason, range, is probably the clincher for me. It’s not necessary to even carry my phone when wearing my Philips’ Headphones. I didn’t lose bluetooth wandering through the whole house, up and down stairs, going in every room, and finally walking out to the garage. DH can’t go more than a room away if he doesn’t take his phone with him. I admit that I’m no audiophile. DH is all about making sure he gets the best hi-fi sound. He says he can tell a difference between the two headsets and that his Bose reproduces sound better. He has nuanced perceptions in many aspects of our life and is a casual musician, so I’m sure he’s telling the truth; but I'm neither nuanced or a musician. I couldn’t tell any difference in sound between the Bose and the Philips headphones. I think there’s no going wrong with buying these headphones for non-audiophiles; the price and quality are the biggest selling points. I also think that anyone that’s paid two to three hundred bucks for headphones, might want to leave them at home if there’s a chance they could get damaged; these could be a less expensive backup to wear out. All in all, I’m impressed and recommend.

My expectations of the Lifefactory’s Hot Beverage Glass Bottle weren't very high, I expected it to be not much more than a restyled travel cup, not much different than any that have taken over an entire kitchen cabinet shelf. The Lifefactory's Hot Beverage Glass Bottle, aka the Hot Bev Glass Mug, turns out to be both more and different.Normally, for the first couple of hours every morning, I keep a coffee cup in my hand or within arm's reach. Those mornings I'm running slow and have to leave before getting fully caffeinated, I switch to one of the travel mugs.Reading the Hot Bev Glass Mug’s accompanying product copy, I came to understand that the company intends it to be more than just a travel mug. The Hot Bev Glass Mug is meant to serve as an everyday mug.It looks nothing like my everyday mugs and the idea of using it as such made me raise an eyebrow, but it also makes sense for my personal circumstances: I'm clumsy to the point of sloppy. I'm responsible for daily spills, dribbles, and coffee cup rings on the kitchen counter, vanity and desk.I'm giving up on cups in the morning. This Hot Bev Glass Mug makes so much more sense. The glass is the same as that in our Bodum coffee press, so I know it's tough, high quality. A wide top allows plenty of room for stirring. The sleeve over the glass is thick and substantial to not be burned but still comfortable to hold. The cap screws down to seal tightly. The one I received has the classic cap and functions much like a sippy cup. With the cap left open and the bottle turned on its side, as if I knocked out over, leakage is slowed giving plenty of time to catch before making a major mess. If I could change anything, it'd be a slightly bigger handle to accommodate larger hands or fingers bearing big rings. I'll be buying additional Hot Bev Glass Mug for home and now have a great gift idea for my caffeine co-addicts.

Lenox’s 2015 Merry and Bright Santa is a glazed ceramic holiday figurine designed with small cutouts to look like a quaint, old fashioned tealight holder. However, this Santa isn't old fashioned. The candlelight like glow from within is actually thanks to a 21st century battery. Sitting on the couch with Santa in front of me a few feet away, the battery powered light flickers and looks surprisingly realistic. It's only up close that he gives away his secret. Somewhat sculptural, Santa has a jolly face and big beard and a nicely detailed cap, jacket and belt. The figurine has a smooth, uniform clear coat  glaze that looks kiln fired. Depending on point of view, one might consider it charming that some painted portions appear to have been applied by a somewhat amateur hand. A swatch of Santa's red coat in back looks to have been missed being painted at all and his black belt wanders outside the line. As a long time lover of Lenox, I have a higher expectation. I don't particularly like that there wasn't more attention paid to applying the paint, but these little flaws are all but invisible in dim light. Other than that, the figurine looks perfectly made without some issues others noted with the switch and battery cover. I like that an old fashioned appearing decoration is built with a high tech feature and appreciate the novelty and its whimsical nature. This Lenox Santa figurine would make me genuinely smile if I received it as a gift, and I like it enough to buy and gift to someone else.

It was probably a mistake that I read some previous reviews about the EZVIZ’s mini 720p indoor Wi-Fi camera. They left me with such a sense of trepidation about the install / setup process and my chances of success that I procrastinated for days.Deciding that today was the day, I prepped over coffee this morning by rereading the instructions, downloading the app and setting up a cloud account, then I went for it.None of the issues others have had were encountered. I’ll share what contributed to my flawless install. My device is a HTC M9. The app was downloaded from Google Play. ISP is cable, 60 mbps down, 5 up. Network is via a separate wireless router dedicated for media and smarthome gadgets (Echo, WeMo, etc). The coffee was whole bean Jeremiah’s Hawaiian and the music was tunein’s “Difference FM” station.It took longer for me to decide where it would be used than it did for the entire installation and setup which included drilling screw holes to secure the metal plate. In less than fifteen minutes, I was done and watching live feed.The live feed is available to watch all the time. Still pictures can be taken and recording can be manually activated through the app. Otherwise, the EZVIZ captures when there is activity.The camera is said to be motion activated, but I think sound may factor too. Viewing our cloud clips, I noticed it records immediately before there's motion; each clip I watched starts with an empty hallway shot followed by the motion of the person or dog entering the frame.Motion and still picture quality is good enough to identify objects, animals, people, etc. It's far from high def, but I didn't downgrade my review because high def wasn't promised or expected at this price point.I love this little camera and am buying at least two more, one of which will be the model that allows two way communication (this model only captures audio, you can hear but not reply through the camera).Speaking of more cameras, it appears one account will cover cloud storage for multiple cameras, but I'll be double checking. The first year of the cloud comes with the camera; afterwards it's $5 a month or pay $50 at once for a year subscription and save $10.For anyone thinking of a WiFi camera for remote surveillance, EZVIZ has models with better picture quality and more options (2 way audio for instance), but I'm very pleased with this one for now. It works great, is easy to install, uncomplicated to use and is priced just right for testing the remote camera waters.

I understand a discount when it applies to an old model after a new model comes out, or when something is out of season and no longer in demand, or the item just isn’t a good seller and there’s a big inventory to move. I don’t understand discounting almost everything almost all of the time; I mean, is a permanent sale really a sale? I don’t know, but it makes sense to me to ignore the lure of the discount on any brand that seems to have a perpetual sale. There have been multiple times that I’ve been attracted to Invicta watches for sale on Amazon at a hugely discounted prices. I never made the jump to purchase, but I kept looking and realized Invicta watches are on sale a lot, if not always. For instance, drilling down today, 96% of Invicta’s wristwatches, 2,013 of 2,093, are on sale at a discount of “70% Off or More.” I’m not saying it’s a bad thing, but to be aware.This Invicta Men's 21658 Specialty Analog Display Swiss Quartz Gold-Plated Watch has a luxury look and some components of higher end watches. It has a Swiss quartz movement which are generally considered to be more reliable and accurate than mechanical movements. On the other hand, collectors consider watches without batteries, ones with mechanical movements, to be more valuable because they demand more craftsmanship. The dial is synthetic crystal, praised much more than the alternative mineral dials on less expensive watches. Another hallmark of luxury is the clasp on the band of this watch; it’s a foldover with two button operation. It looks to be solid metal with no plastic components, at least that I can see, which is another plus when determining whether a watch is high end or not. Being water resistant isn’t as great as being waterproof, but resistant to a depth of over 300 feet is respectable. The 36mm 18k gold plating is the same as what’s used on many Rolex models, so it’s also a good sign. In fact, just about everything that’s visible on this Invicta is comparable to way more expensive entry level and mid level luxury watch lines. They all come together to make one leans toward believing that this watch, priced 85% less than List, could be an incredible deal for less than $100. However, if I was being asked to pay full price, I’d probably not jump before considering other, more revered watches priced the same as this when (if) there’s no discount.I love this watch for all it promises to be and for the savings opportunity it might represent, so five stars for the watch at the current 85% discounted price, three stars at full price, four overall.

Scharffen Berger Chocolate is the company that brought back “bean to bar” processing in the United States. When the chocolatier began manufacturing their own chocolate in the late 1990’s, the norm was to make products using already processed chocolate bought in bulk from wholesalers. The first American company grinding their own beans on site in fifty plus years, the Scharffen Berger Chocolate production process began by selecting beans as a winemaker selects grapes. Like grapes used for wine, Scharffen Berger Chocolate used beans from a particular location to produce “single source” bars, each with their own particular flavor. Scharffen Berger shares its San Francisco home base with Ghirardelli Chocolate and See’s Candies; three of the nation’s top ten chocolate producers.I am most familiar with Scharffen Berger’s Venezuela bean and Tahitian vanilla, high cacao content dark chocolate. It was the “secret” ingredient of a flourless chocolate cake recipe that I made on and off for a decade. Whenever I ordered the chocolate, I’d get extra for a not too sweet treat.When I didn’t have as much time to spend  in the kitchen, homemade complex desserts were the first things I stopped making. Plus, it wasn’t necessary to make my own flourless chocolate cake after I found an almost as good one locally for little more than I used to pay for ingredients.Seeing this Scharffen Berger Chocolate gift box made me salivate a little and I jumped on the ordering opportunity. I prefer dark chocolate, but good milk chocolate makes me happy too. I was just surprised that half the bars being sent were milk chocolate because I remembered dark as Scharffen Berger’s claim to fame. The explanation was clear when the bars arrived packed inside a box inside another box labeled “Hershey’s Chocolate.” The original company being acquired by Hershey’s wasn’t a disappointment to me or anything; I appreciate Hershey’s and have eaten a lot of their chocolate in my life.Tied with a bow, a window box wonderfully displays the individually wrapped, different colored bars. It’s a nice presentation. Given as a gift, it would require wrapping to not reveal the contents. Not seeing my once favorite dark chocolate and vanilla bar disappointed me, but just for a moment.All four bars have nuts. Two dark chocolate and one milk are flavored with salt. The second milk is a coconut and macadamia combo. Although I liked it, it wouldn't be my first choice to indulge. The salt flavor is pronounced, not subtle, but I recognize that salt is an individual thing. My preference would be a lighter touch with the salt, especially in the milk chocolate, but I’m the only one that shared that opinion; no one else that sampled the bars with me mentioned salt as a negative.I can't compare these dark bars to my memory of Scharffen Berger’s original. They either had a higher percentage of cacao or there's more sugar in the dark formula now. Even though Hershey's owns the company, I don't think the milk chocolate in these is the same used in Hershey's confections. Again, I'm a Hershey's fan, but their chocolate isn't as smooth feeling as that used in these Scharffen Berger Chocolate bars.I like these bars a lot but it's not quite love. For one, milk chocolate and the Scharffen Berger Chocolate label don't go together in my mind. Still, I'd very much appreciate receiving this box of chocolate as a gift. I believe most chocolate lovers would feel the same. I'd have no qualms giving it to someone else either; the box is attractive and feels substantial and I think the chocolate is higher end, better than most.

I'm looking at this BLACK+DECKER BDCS20C 4-Volt MAX Lithium-Ion Cordless Rechargeable Screwdriver from the perspective that it's smaller and less powerful compared to the Black & Decker BDCS80I 8V MAX Impact Screwdriver . I'm guessing that the volt difference is why this one is more affordable, although neither is that expensive anyway. Regardless of volts, cordless just aren't as powerful as plug ins. I see that this one needs to be kept on its charger whenever it's not in use. The battery is not replaceable; once it stops taking a charge, it'll be time to retire the entire tool. That said, I'm not taking off anything for it inevitably going dead; it was made to be inexpensive, not to last a lifetime. All in all I like this little Black & Decker, it's a perfect size to have handy for little jobs. Ours sits ready to go at all times in the laundry room. The one thing I don't like is the change in design that removed the little rubber bit holder. We're lucky to have a drawer beneath where it's plugged in or I'd be more aggravated. impact screwdriver is non-reactionary. Also, because this isn't an impact driver, when there's resistive torque it twists and stalls. In other words, you'll only use this little Black & Decker for small, easy jobs. I recommend getting one of the bigger impact drivers for primary use, look at corded first if you expect to do any jobs that need real torque or will take more than an hour. All in all, I like this one for its convenience and small size, but as a backup to keep near.

Lenox’s 2015 Snow Majesty Snowflake is big, shiny and resplendent with sculptural details. Marked as 11th, It looks made for collectors, but I imagine it would be liked by just about anyone that decorates for the holidays. It's a sturdy piece with some real heft. Weighing over a third of a pound, it is at least twice as heavy as the heaviest of our tree ornaments. Given its heft and size, it seems best suited to be displayed on its own, as a focal point, or to accentuate another item or decoration. With its included luscious red ribbon, this snowflake (or better, a few) would look beautiful hanging with stockings above the fireplace, or as part of a centerpiece, or from a light fixture above a dining table; just about any place where the brightly finished snowflake could capture enough light to get its twinkle on. I'm hoping to get lucky and am waiting on a sale to grab more Lenox ornaments because I think they’d be great to give to favored teachers, neighbors, etc.; I'm thinking cash tucked inside would be a cool way to take care of those people we tip at the holidays. I love these for the decorating and gift giving possibilities they provide.

Two different age ranges are given on the product page for the Baby Genius Talking DJ Interactive Hand Puppet with Electronic Sounds by Manhattan Toy; twenty-four (24) months to (5) years is quoted in the “Product Detail” section in the middle of the page, but twenty-four (24) months to thirty-six (36) months is quoted at the top in the bullet points just beneath the Amazon banner, near the “Add to Cart” button. When the toy arrived, I checked its label. Per the manufacturer, the correct recommended age range is twenty-four (24) months to thirty-six (36) months.Regardless of recommended age, I’m not great at determining what level of excitement a toy will bring until I see it in play. If the child was living with us, I’d have a better shot of getting it right more often. Still, I’m right more than I’m wrong; not bad as I only sit for a few hours a week immediately after pre-school and the occasional weekend when mommy and daddy need a break (the frequency of which has increased proportionally to the child’s age, almost monthly now).This is one that I got wrong. At three, she’s already a fan of Melissa & Doug Farm Friends Hand Puppets. In anticipation of watching her with the different brands of puppets, I asked her mother to include Melissa & Doug’s in her bag. The Melissa & Doug puppets don’t speak and their mouths don’t open; they have stuffed heads, so one’s hand doesn’t even go all the way up. After giving her the Baby Genius Talking DJ puppet, I expected it’d quickly achieve favored status because it’s more easily animated. Instead, the moment it spoke, she took it off and only pick it up again during the next hour or so of puppet play when I asked her to show it to me. It was the only one that she didn’t bring to me to put on and play with her. There’s something special about the Melissa & Doug puppets that captivates her, but I have no idea what it is; I really like DJ; I'm betting he'd have been my first choice when I was three years old. Mom picked her up this morning and DJ went home with them, maybe he'll grow on her.From a construction perspective, the Baby Genius puppet is made of higher quality fabric with a moveable mouth and detailed eyes; it’s smaller overall, but it doesn’t look dwarfed. I like most things about it, except that it’s super tight. I don’t find it the fault of the Baby Genius Talking DJ puppet that she didn’t seem to have interest. Afterall, if it had been me making the decision on the puppet(s) to buy, I’d have gone with the Baby Genius Talking DJ. That said, I’d recommend everyone take a look at both; for the price of one Talking DJ, I could get four mute Melissa & Doug puppets.

In 2007 I was given Norton's new protection software, called 360, to evaluate and review. I liked that so much functionality was bundled together: virus protection /detection, phishing protection, maintenance and backup all in one. I bought licences 2008 through 2013 and especially liked when the option to buy it for multiple devices was introduced. In 2014, shopping around to find a good renewal price, I learned Norton was pushing renewals to Security, that 360 was being phased out. I went with Security and remained happy; from my perspective, I couldn't tell any difference except for the product's name change. This year I was approaching the deadline to renew and was still trying to find a discount. I've learned that software is an item that can vary widely in price; it's not unusual to find it from 3rd parties for as much as 75% less than buying from the manufacturer. Obviously, I jumped on the chance to get the 10 Device version of Security free to evaluate. However, I'd have happily bought it for the price it was being offered at that day (still that price today). I like everything about the product, but have some issues with the degree of preplanning and extra steps necessary to not pay full price, but that's my hangup. For convenience, Norton will happily store account information and automatically walk customers through the annual renewal process for which they bill whatever the full price is at the time. Personally, I hate software renewals setup to auto bill and download. Therefore, I don't agree to it and choose to do it manually. Norton doesn't make it as easy. In the last few years I've become accustomed to using Norton's removal tool to get it off each device on the day I'm going to review. Then I do a complete install of the latest year's version and reconnect each device to my Norton account. It's a hassle, plain and simple, but worth it to me to save some money. People whose time is worth more than mine can avoid the hoops I jump through to save a buck; just sign up for Norton's EZ-PZ auto renew process. In the years that I've been using Norton, I've not had any intrusion, virus, etc issues. Some fiends that use freeware have experienced the opposite; one's pc was completely taken over because he proceeded to a site Norton would have warned me away from. I love Norton Security for all it does and because I can work around their auto renew process and save a buck, or opt for convenience and let them do the heavy lifting automatically for full price. It's all about options and functionality for me, and Norton delivers consistently.

In August 2009, I bought my husband a Panasonic ES8109S Men's 3-Blade (Arc 3) Wet/Dry. He didn't warm to it at first and it took a week or more of use before he decided that it shaved him just as close and was easier than his hand razor. We later learned his reaction was pretty much the norm when guys switch to electric. He got into the groove of it and I became accustomed to regularly hearing the cleaning mechanism cycle through the process.In 2011, during a maniacal cleaning frenzy (pre-inlaw visit), I knocked it hard and caused its suicidal dive from bathroom counter to hard ceramic tile below. I immediately replaced it with the newer model Panasonic ES-LT71-S Arc3 Men's Electric Shaver. Two years later he said the razor didn't seem to be performing as well and began to drop hints about wanting a new one. I went online and learned that the manufacturer recommends replacing the Outer Foil yearly and the Inner Blade every two years. I ordered both and, following the simple instructions, I had them installed minutes after they arrived. The next morning I made a point of staying nearby when the shower turned off. Shortly after I heard the razor buzz on, it turned off. He came to the door and found me standing there. Wide eyed, he thanked me and said it worked like brand new. I was amused that he went back to shaving, not even a little curious to know what made the improvement. From then on I've ordered foil and/or blade replacements from Amazon as needed.I expected him to be excited when I showed him this newest model, the Panasonic ES-RT97-S Men's Electric Shaver and Trimmer. Sitting in place of the old one, I had it charged and ready for a test drive. Excited? Au contraire mon frère. He was more interested in what I'd done with the old Panasonic and I had to show him it was stashed beneath his sink before he'd try the new one. His reaction was basically "meh." It isn't that he dislikes the new ES-RT97-S, he says it's every bit as good as his old one, but no better. The few design changes aren't enough to give him preference and without a beard or mustache, the addition of the comb attachment isn't important. When asked whether he liked it more or less than the ES-LT71-S Arc3, he'd rate both the same, 5 stars. For him, he'd be happy with the Panasonic ES-LT71-S Arc3 Men's Electric Shaver Wet/Dry with Flexible Pivoting Head and Automatic Cleaning System, but if he grew a beard and mustache, he'd be appreciative of this ES-RT97-S's new trimming comb attachment.

I've got to say that using canning jars to drink from didn't feel really trendy back in the days we were working part time, pinching pennies and going to school. I absconded with a case of my mother's jars to use when four of us set up house off campus.At a holiday party last year, the same type of canning jars were the focal point of a catered dessert bar. Some were pre filled with brownie slices in layers with chocolate mousse and chips, others had pound cake and strawberries and there was a version with lemon curd and shortbread pieces. "Chefs" in white jackets stood ready to complete the jars with each guest's desired combination of toppings: fresh whipped cream, liqueur based chocolate and fruit sauces, toasted warm nuts, etc. I couldn't help but think of the old jars we had to use in place of glasses and smiled at the irony.This Aladdin Classic Mason Salad Jar represents a new level in the beverage / salad / meal / dessert in the canning jar concept. Its obvious plus is that it is less likely to break than a glass jar and some may put a high importance on its nifty, built in container that holds dressing separate until serving time. Things I'm not thrilled with include the cautions regarding its potential to be marred by utensils that can scratch plastic or stained by certain foods. It has a high price compared to buying an old fashioned 32 ounce glass jar (when on sale, I can get a dozen glass jars for about the price as this one jar). It's true that the Aladdin Classic Mason Salad Jar's plastic lid won't rust and is less likely to discolor, but the glass jars' metal lids are super cheap to replace, plus plain plastic screw top lids are available from most glass jar manufacturers.The big difference and singular option that I can't find available with glass jar alternatives is the built in dressing container. Personally, I don't see a need for it as most of the salad in a jar recipes begin with a first layer of dressing. I could work around keeping an ingredient separate if required until serving. Any old jelly jar or other reclosable small storage containers would suffice.That brings me to my last thoughts of cost and efficiency. I see them as the Aladdin Classic Mason Salad Jar's major disadvantages. If I'm dicing and slicing, prepping for a handy to go meal, I want to do more than one at a time. It saves more time to do three or four at once; when I calculate the price of buying three or four containers, I'd go with buying multiples of the old fashioned, less expensive glass jars. All in all, I find the Aladdin Classic Mason Salad Jar to be thoughtfully made with its own advantages,  but for my life, it's just okay and only as an alternative to my first choice of buying basic canning jars.

This is our fourth "Classic Accessories" cover. We've had the first, a blue Belltown Patio Lounge Chair Cover for about a year. We used it mostly through fall and winter to cover a couple of chairs that we didn't stow away with the rest of the patio furniture at the end of summer.It can get cold in the Pacific Northwest during the winter, but it isn't like it was in the Rocky Mountains. When it's not raining on the Oregon coast, it still gets into the sixties and we jump at those opportunities to have the occasional cocktail hour on the deck at sunset.Both the Sodo and Belltown designs have generally the same features (ties, drawstring, built-in storage bag) and the fabric seems to be the same weight and density. The Belltown cover is  two toned and looks a bit more higher end than the one solid color Sodo cover.Each cover has plenty of room to easily fit over two of our patio chairs when stacked on top of each other. This one is a perfect fit for our love seat. The covers' ties and drawstrings help make them fit snug. The fabric is light, but feels strong, and moisture beads up noticeably instead of soaking in.As for easy on / easy off, I have run into problems with the off when I haven't taken care to not tie the cover down around decorative edges or scrollwork on our old iron chairs. It's probably not a problem for most patio sets.The only potential negative for me is that the covers don't completely wrap, leaving possible entry points at tops of chair legs near and at the seat's underside. Most people probably don't worry about accidentally surprising nesting rodents and such, but it's a concern when living outside of cities in areas with tons of wildlife.I like Classic Accessories' covers and don't think you can go wrong with either the Sodo or Belltown styles.

My child strolling days are long behind me, but I jumped at the chance to get this Diono Buggy Tote Bag. These days walking or hiking means pushing around a senior weiner dog that has a bad hip and separation anxiety. His younger bros can go all day, but he's good for twenty minutes tops before he's hurting, dragging a leg and in need of a ride. This Buggy Tote solves a couple of long standing issues I've had, the first being accessing my phone without coming to a stop. I can now position my phone to see caller ID. It has multiple compartments including a sleeve that perfectly fits the take along water bottle. The large area has plenty of room for the collapsible water bowl, poo bags and his harness and a smaller one now dedicated to hold treats. The tablet sleeve is a decided plus if I should ever have cause to take mine along when hiking. Luckily, it's easy to put on and take off, so I'm able to remove it from the handle and stash it in storage space below when it starts to rain. That brings me to my one enhancement recommendation.. a pull over flap or cover so that it could be left in place during inclement weather. Over all I found this to be a smart solution and think anyone regularly pushing a buggy or stroller would love one. Picture is the Old Man waiting patiently in his ride.

Walnut Hollow has been around forever. Beginning as a family tree farm, they evolved to manufacture wood surfaces (and more) sold in craft and hobby stores, often as part of a kit. If you've done any wood crafting from kits, like decoupage on wood, wood burning, etc, there's a good chance you used a Walnut Hollow basswood product. These three foot stakes, a dozen in all, are from kiln-dried, furniture grade wood that's been cut and sanded so that little to no prep is necessary before use. I spotted no spots or knots or discoloration; each stake matches the next. For those of us that find it important, these stakes are made in the U.S. by an American, family company. I wanted these stakes to use for signs through 2016 (we're obnoxiously political); after that I'll retire them to the yard where they can live out their years stakeing up blackberry and raspberry bushes. I can find cheaper wooden stakes than these, but I can't find better.

I agree that giving a dog a treat is infinitely easier than trying to brush his teeth, but one treat wasn't enough to substantiate Nutri Dent's claims that their 3-Prong Edible Dental Chews freshens breath or reduced plaque and tartar. The "Filet Mignon" flavor was strong enough to get all three of our dogs interested, but only two actually ate their whole treat, in comparison to Greenie Dental Treats which all three gobble in their entirety. Like Greenies, these are priced higher and are designed to help maintain good oral health compared to more simple treats one would use for training or rewards. I appreciate that Nutri Dent's 3-Prong Edible Dental Chews were created with a natural formula and have no preservatives, artificial colors or flavors, added sugar, animal digest or corn. Because of all that and since Nutri Dent is made in the USA, I'll definitely consider them again, but since our dogs seem to favor Greenies more, it'll be as a backup. Over all, I like this Nutri Dent product and am happy to have had the introduction.

We were introduced to bamboo charcoal when we received some from a friend after she finished her service in the advanced medical clinic at Torii Station Army Base in Okinawa Japan. Her gift to us was loose pieces enclosed in a lovely, loosely woven cylinder shaped bamboo basket. She explained that the charcoal would absorb odors and to use it instead of baking soda to keep the fridge smelling good. She said she also kept a bigger basket hanging over the clothes hamper in her teenaged boys' bedroom. I tried the fridge trick and found she was right. When it seemed to lose effectiveness, I followed her instructions to put the charcoal in direct sunlight for a day to refresh and use again. It continued to work for over a year until one day even the sunlight refresh trick wouldn't work. I tossed the charcoal, went back to baking soda and filled the basket with potpourri and gave it a home in a bathroom. Four years later and I was happy to see bamboo charcoal available on Amazon. The bag's bigger than the old fridge basket and I've already used its handy loop to put it to work. Our dogs go through two dog doors to get outside. The area where they first come back in is smash and can get a funky smell during the rainy season. Even though their run area outside is covered, they still manage to get a little wet when doing their business. Plug-ins and sprays barely help with the wet dog smell. I'll update if it does not, but I have high hopes that my new bag of bamboo charcoal works as good as the basket of charcoal used to in the fridge.

Seeing some reviewers' negative ratings, I was prepared to be disappointed. As it turned out, my experience wasn't the same; the Mudder 0.01 pH Accuracy Digital pH Meter worked flawlessly for me. I prepared nine samples, three each using faucet, filtered and distilled water, and tested each with this Mudder Meter, my regular digital PH Meter and a manual PH test kit (color gradient). I expected to at least have to calibrate, but it wasn't necessary. For each sample, the difference between the two digital meters was .01 The manual test kit's corresponding color guide confirmed the measurement range was within that of the digitals for each sample. Comparing the reviews by some others to my own results, I can only assume that if a problem existed, it's been fixed. I'm very satisfied with my Mudder 0.01 pH Accuracy Digital pH Meter and am happy that I received it for free to test and review.

The options that were available before Poo-Pourri were a joke or embarrassing to use. The aerosol cans in particular are a bane; they don't work great and, big as they are, aren't exactly discreet; plus, there's the grossness factor of picking up a can that others have touched after their grand finales. I knew that my bottle of Lavender Vanilla Scent Poo-Pourri had leaked before opening the delivery box. As recently as this morning, the scent left on the broken down cardboard box is making our trash can the best smelling one on the curb. There was still a third or so of liquid left in the bottle, so not a total loss. When used as directed, the Lavender Vanilla scent is all that's detectable and it stays around for a good hour or so after flushing. I am impressed with the effectiveness of this product, especially since I ordered it as a gag. Anyone that wishes to be discreet and / or courteous will appreciate having Poo-Pourri handy. I'm crossing fingers that there's a version on the horizon for those that don't care; a Poo-Pourri that fits internally (in the toilet, not the person) and auto dispenses. Now, that's a version I'd buy by the case; for now, I'll buy a bottle or two at a time and place prominently by the throne. It works.

We bought this new 880 made specifically for pets and allergies. The purchase severely hurt the budget, but the return is bringing comfort to an allergic household member that is not physically capable of vacuuming. I had no idea of the importance of vacuuming until this highly sensitive individual joined our home; it simply has to be done daily. My spouse and I have done a good job of staying on top of it, but we've each had our misses and realized we needed a contingency plan; I recalled seeing a Roomba at someone's home and decided it could be the solution. Having a home with tile, hardwood and carpeted floors, my expectations were that we'd have to limit the Roomba to one area at a time. As it turns out, it's not necessary, the Roomba moves seamlessly from one floor surface to another. In an area with a thick rug on top of hardwood, it's usually a matter of it just rolling on and off, but I have seen it take two attempts. On tile and hardwood, I think the Roomba works better than any vacuum we've had. I deliberately set the Roomba to vacuum the kitchen's tiled floor immediately after using a Dyson Animal. Considering the floor had just been vacuumed, the amount the Roomba picked up was amazing. We've been playing with configuring the two included "lighthouses" to effectively guide the Roomba room to room, but I think it's going to require manual intervention to completely work. We're currently running the Roomba on a nightly schedule in the open plan area of the house. By the time I wake up, it has run its course and recharged. In the morning I empty the bin and carry the Roomba (handy carrying handle) to a different room and let it clean until it stops. The first few times, before letting it roll free, I'd forget to scan for obstacles. After a few loud incidents, it's become habit to remove or raise all that I can (chairs and trash cans on to tables and desk; shoes, dog bed and toys to closet; floor fan set outside of door, etc). In the short month we've had it, I love it. If my opinion changes, I'll update here, but right now I highly recommend.

Wellness is one of a small number of pet food manufacturers recognized as producing a legitmately premium food. Wellness makes their food in the U.S.A. without fillers, meat by products, artificial ingredients or anything sourced from China. Since WellBars Natural Wheat Free Oven Baked Dog Treats are from Wellness, consumers can be assured that they're high quality and pooch worthy.The difference between dog food and dog treats / snacks is nutritional. Treats aren't made to meet daily nutritional needs and often contain ingredients that aren't considered essential nutritionally. It's like me and my daily chocolate fix. It might not kill me to eat nothing else, but it wouldn't be healthy. Chocolate doesn't contain all that I need to meet my daily nutritional needs, but I can  "treat" myself daily in moderation.These are different from many empty calorie treats. Wellness WellBars help supplement a dog's diet with antioxidants (vitamins C and E and Beta-Carotene). They're small, chunky shaped rectangles. For my dogs, I like that the shape, size and texture encourages chewing versus gulping. All of our dogs went for these without hesitation, despite being meatless. They smell good for dog treats, sweet even; I was reminded of the sweet smell that comes with opening a box of gram crackers. As with every other Wellness product we've purchased over the years, I trust them completely to give to my furry family members.

Since this is my first drone, I can't verify TX Juice's claim that this is the "easiest to fly drone." I can say that the learning curve is easier than what I went through with my first remote controlled helicopter.If your instructions aren't in English, don't do anything before downloading the correct ones from the company's website (TXJUICE DOT COM). Many thanks to the reviewer that previously mentioned this, or I'd have gone a little nuts.For instance, without the instructions, I wouldn't have realized why the drone's best feature for learning, auto-hover, wasn't working. I tried first in the work area of the garage that's covered with rubberized mats. Because they're flat black, there is little reflectivity and the sensor, the a.i. component, is useless. It wouldn't hover until I moved it to the smooth concrete floor.At first, it moved left and backwards, it wouldn't stay hovering in the same place. From having flown my helicopter, I knew it was a trim problem, but would've been lost for a fix without the instructions. Playing with the forward and right trim buttons burned battery time and the drone had to be charged again before it was ready to try again.I've some way to go before I'll be proficient with the controls, but I'm much farther along in a day than I was in week one with my helicopter. Being able to keep the speed on low and have the drone maintain its height while playing with the directional joystick is a big benefit to getting a feel for its operation.So far, I'm liking it. Even though I was disappointed by its small size (my fault, the dimensions were there for the reading before ordering, but I didn't), I'm okay with having it in order to build skill.A neighbor flying a drone with a "ghost" hanging below it scared the bejebus out of me, my sister and the kids last Halloween. I'm hoping TX Juice's AI drone will build my skills enough that I can justify ordering a bigger, more powerful one to have my own fun this Halloween.

I checked earlier reviews of Zillionz Voice Activated Safe after ordering it. If I'd seen them first, I would've passed. As it worked out, the safe I received works better and opens more consistently than expected. For the price, I didn't anticipate the voice activation to be state of the art, and it's not. We recorded a pass code that failed to work at all at first. Tired of the alarm, I ended up using the reset feature to get it open. Since setting it a second time, it's worked every time, but not always on the first try. I'd love to share what made the difference, but I'm clueless. We didn't play with it for more than a couple of hours, so only time will tell if the problem reviewers previously reported had been fixed. For us, after the second setting, it continued to operate within two tries. If there's a change, I'll update the review. That said, I'm still not going to love the safe even if the voice activation continues to work. I understand that this is labeled as a toy safe, it's not made to safeguard the family jewels, but it's really more like a piggy bank than a safe. With very little pressure, hubby popped open the door with his thumb. It caused no damage and once closed, it was impossible to tell it had been opened. As a kid, I wish my sister would have had this safe. I could've snooped in her diary or snatched from her candy stash without leaving a trace. Unfortunately, she had a lockbox (very much like this Schylling Locking Cash Box). Overall, Zillionz Voice Activated Safe is a piggy bank in the shape of a safe, unique only for it's voice activation access function; without which, it wouldn't be that interesting. For a kid's novelty, it's okay, but to give my kid a sense of having real treasure security, I'd go with the tried and true metal bank or box with a key of combo lock.

Our bathroom has a soaking tub and  separate shower. I wanted to find a spray hose to fit the tub's decorative faucet. It's long, wider than it is tall, and tapers down from the wall to a rectangular opening. Water runs from the faucet projecting over the tub, about a foot past the the tub's edge. This was the second hose that I tried and is a third the cost of the first. I like it because, even though they looked the same, the rubber nozzle on this one is less firm. I couldn't squeeze the first hose's round nozzle to fit over the rectangular opening. This hose looked like it would present the same problem, but the rubber nozzle proved to have just enough extra flexibility; it slipped right on. Don't misunderstand, it's not something that I want to regularly put on and take off. It's being left on and it doesn't hinder the filling of the tub. For the price, fit and flexibility, I rate it 5 stars.

I've always been leery of electric space heaters, but this Duraflame Infrared Rolling Power Heater completely changed my mind. It's a good looking wood unit that appears and feels quality made and comes fully assembled. I've no worries about tripping over it or tipping it over; it's substantial in size and heavy. It heats up quickly and, thankfully, without the ticking bomb sound or high pitched whine that turned me off space heaters in the first place. The kitchen, dining and family room are part of a large open floor plan area divided only by half walls and bookcases. We tested the heater there; it's a bit over 1000 square feet, but the Duraflame Infrared Rolling Power Heater was able to warm it corner to corner (with two reverse slow spinning ceiling fans running). One cautionary note: be cognoscent of where you plug in the heater. The plug I initially used is on the same 15 amp circuit used by the flat screen, stereo, gaming system and back lights. Turning on the heater tripped the breaker and shut everything down. I checked and learned the heater is rated at 12.5 amps. Gaming and watching TV would be out with the heater running if another circuit wasn't available. There are other circuits in the area, but a space heater isn't needed there anyway. I only wanted to see how it performed in a big space and it performed great. The included remote really ups the utilitarian factor. Turn the heater on and off, set its timer and change the temperature all from the other side of the room, thanks to the easy to use remote. The timer function in particular is a plus. Considering the heater maxes out at 1500 watts, some big money could burn up if left running longer than necessary. We'll use the heater only occasionally, in a space that was created when we added storm doors to each end of a breezeway. It's a nice, bright room with wicker furniture and lots of plants, but gets too cold a few months every winter to enjoy. Not anymore. I love that our Duraflame Infrared Rolling Power Heater can make the area usable all year.

I'm a fan of "Would You Rather." As a party or conversation game for adults, it's an icebreaker and a means to get insight. Sometimes it's way more revealing of aspects of others you never wanted to know. I like that there's a version for the young. "I don't know" and "I don't care" are rarely acceptable answers from adolescents in real life. They're never acceptable in this game. The game requires that a decision be made in order to move on. It represents an exercise in, maybe even an introduction to, critical thinking, with the ice breaking benefits of the adult version. Like the adult and teen appropriate versions, it is the cards that make the game. Player pieces, game boards, etc seem extraneous, fluff, but their inclusion is understandable from a marketing perspective since multiple websites provide Would You Rather questions for all ages for free. For this age range, there's probably not much that's appealing about home made games delivered via mom's ink jet printer. If a colorful box with cards and extras works to spark interest in playing, I see the worth. Otherwise, I'd pick one of the websites appropriate for the age range and print the questions and put the money towards something not so easily reproduced at home.

This is a new themed edition of a popular game called Fluxx. The original Fluxx, unthemed, has been around at least a decade. The basics of the generic original and the newer themed versions of Fluxx are the same. None are complex and all are easy to learn, a group of novices can be up and running in ten minutes; having experience playing doesn't give an advantage. Set up consists of not much more than shuffling a deck of 100 cards and dealing three to each person. The cards are color coded and labeled: Action, Goal, Keeper, New Rule and Surprise. The card category, Creeper, is in some versions / themes, including this one. You'll want to note that not all themes have the same age range (there is at least one 18+ version). The principle of game play is the same in all versions / themes: follow the rules and be the first to achieve a goal of obtaining and keeping specific cards. Play begins with one simple rule; each player must pick and play a card. It's all about luck of the draw. From there the game can end quickly or spin into chaos. At any one time, only one rule and one goal directs the game, but the rule and/or goal can change with every player's turn. One draw can change hopelessness to hopeful or blow up an imminent win. Moans and laughter travel equally around the table. Fluxx is one of those games that rates high enough in the household for regular occasional play. It doesn't sit long enough to draw substantial dust, but it's not first out of the bookcase of games. Once out, it's good for at least four rounds before interest wains and other games get pulled. This Fluxx deck, "Adventure Time," is going to best suit fans of the show with Finn and Jake. The manufacturer's recommended minimum age is 8. I'd guess 15 for the top range. If your game closet doesn't already have a Fluxx deck or two, check out the variety of themes available. There's something for most gamers.

Of three brands of jeans ordered in the last six months, these Wranglers run the most true to size. The waist, 36, is perfect. The length, 32, is closer to 33, but if they're going to be off, I'd rather see longer than shorter, so these are fine.
