I should mention that they were washed according to instructions before wearing. The fawn color is a nice break from regular blue jeans and looks less casual. The material mix is also a plus. Oregonians are bike riders. The spandex in these pants "give" in the right places and helps prevent the baggy knee look that comes with bike riding. For the price, the fit and the style, I'm rating these 5 stars.

Axe's Apollo 2 in 1 Shampoo + Conditioner didn't rank as an Axe product that would find a permanent place on our shopping list. It's marketed as a shampoo and conditioner in one, but it didn't seem very conditioning. I've used a number of the combo shampoos, in comparision Axe's Apollo 2 in 1 Shampoo + Conditioner left my hair feeling dry with more flyaways. A plus for me is that the shampoo's scent isn't as strong as others by Axe that I've tried. I'm not rating it less because of it, but the shampoo and conditioner leaks out along the line where the bottle and the cap snap together. It's a flaw because the two pieces aren't undone or loose, I can't get it tighter. Overall, Axe's Apollo Shampoo and Conditioner was decent smelling and cleaned well, but I prefer more conditioning.

I try to minimize staining my teeth, but sometimes stains are unavoidable. Coffee is the worst but I can't quit caffeine, it's all that keeps me from being mistaken for the walking dead and shot. Red wine is another staple, but whitening be damned,I'm not going to look the fool and drink wine through a straw. In between professional teeth whitenings I rely on bleach strips, but I don't use them as diligently as needed because I find them to be a hassle.I've only used the Crest 3D White Brilliance Daily Cleansing Toothpaste and Whitening Gel System for a week, but can see the results are better than I get with the strips. I already brush twice a day for two minutes (actually, my Philip's Diamond Head goes for 2.5 minutes). It doesn't matter that I need to stop after a minute to apply the product's second step, the process still feels like my daily routine. I don't have to be extra diligent. Without making any big changes except toothpaste brand, I can brighten my teeth in between dentist visits without the fuss and expense of strips. For someone that wants to whiten teeth for the first time, or has gone longer than recommended since their last whitening, I doubt this will bring the results as quickly as wanted. On the other hand, for anyone like me that struggles with bleach strips in between whitenings, I whole heatedly recommend trying Crest 3D White Brilliance Daily Cleansing Toothpaste and Whitening Gel System. For me it's really a simple solution in comparison and I'm very pleased. I can see staining is reduced and I love how super fresh and clean my mouth is left. Five stars.

I'm so old that I used to pull music from vinyl to make mixtapes for our parties and road trips. That evolved to CDs for dinner parties of every kind, from barbeque to blacktie. These days, I have playlists for just about every event or activity. With streaming music services I can set up an entire list or just que a couple of songs. Doing it on the fly and being able to have songs flow into the next makes me feel like a Junior DJ. I've played with a few mobile apps for mixing with some success, but I never thought of having my own DJ Controller. I've thought of them as something for pros, too expensive and too steep of a learning curve. I am pleased that the Hercules Universal DJ proves me wrong on every point. Don't get me wrong, I am not looking for a DJ gig now, anytime soon, or ever. I am, however, looking forward to becoming more skilled. After the easy initial setup (software install) I knew I was going to have some fun. The Hercules DJ Controller lets you control two deck wheels, plus has a mixer and sampler and effects. The PC display portion shows a BPM (beats per minute) box and wave line with each deck. The BPM number and the wave line show each deck's tempo and lets you look ahead point-by-point in the song. These help big time beat matching, sampling, and adjusting fade, flow, etc. There is much more to the controller, but I'm not there yet. DJUCED mobile apps allow music to be pulled from multiple sources, not just the PC and one gives the ability to use a smartphone as the controller, in case you want to join guests instead of sticking behind the device. There is a way to make and share playlists and even have people vote on what they'd like to hear. The Hercules website has a promo video that shows lots of what I have to look forward to accomplishing. If you too have had fun with mixtapes and playlists, and especially if you've used an app to sample, fade or flow or played with itunes preferences for mixing, I'm positive you'll love going to the next step with Hercules' DJ Controller.

I question why the ambiguous "Holiday" is in the title. Check out the colors, candy canes, stickers with Christmas tree and wreath decorations and the little Santa. There are no fireworks or valentines or turkeys. Heck, Thomas says "Merry Christmas" as he rolls; no references to Mothers' Day or any "holiday" except Christmas. This is a Thomas The Train CHRISTMAS Train Set.The age range is three to six years old. That's got to be for play, because assembly is a completely different matter. Six should be the minimum, not maximum; even then, I'm talking about a six year old destined to skip some grades. These are not ready made individual pieces of track that connect  to make a loop for Thomas; the sections don't come assembled. Rails, buildings, hills, candy canes, various shapes and lengths of track, etc get snapped together, in different ways, to make the individual sections. I can't say how long assembly would take one adult; I'd guess about an hour without a little helper, if you know what I mean. In retrospect, from a saving time and hurt feelings perspective, I'd say it's better to surprise any little loved one under six with the set completed.The track is designed with added interest in the form of hills / bridges that raise and lower the train as it moves through the slightly pentagon looking loop. Interactive play is accomplished with start and stop switches on the track. At one, Thomas "pops out" Sir Topham Hatt (Santa) from his house and stops to let him aboard. A plastic barrel full of imagined candy canes can roll down a ramp into a car at the next stop. Thomas pushes through a door to enter a tunnel on his way to his next stop, the school, where the cargo car of gifts can be unloaded. Santa and his house, the barrel, the tunnel door and the gifts will stay as they are from that point on unless replaced and reset in their original positions.Putting the pieces back in place and running Thomas around the track again in order to pull the switches again seems to be the extent of play. Big Thomas fans could find it eternally entertaining, especially hearing him chug, chug, chugging along, yelling holiday greetings and whistling, always whistling. Personally, I would have appreciated the option of turning Thomas' audio off, but to each their own.I'm rating this four stars for Thomas The Train lovers, less for non-fans. Without a big Thomas lover in the house, like our house, I think it'll prove to be more decoration than toy. Whimsical and Christmas themed, I'll enjoy it decorating the space beneath our tree this Christmas season.

This "Cool Brown" shower curtain has a subtle damask pattern that contributes to its high end look. It's functional alone, but the manufacturer recommends using a liner (extends the curtain's life). Note the length of 72" (6'). I prefer 84" for head to toe coverage plus splash allowance, something to consider if you want the curtain to fall almost to the floor outside of the tub when it's not in use.

The joy of having blooming plants in the home year around, plus the peace that comes with starting seeds, taking cuttings, transplanting and nurturing plants that burst with big beautiful blooms, led me to explore less expensive options than high intensity discharge (HID) lamps, specifically the metal halide and high-pressure sodium (HPS) I had been using. The electrical cost of running a 1000W light twelve hours a day, plus $100 annually for replacement bulbs, became too much to pay for a hobby that produces no income. One choice considered was going with less wattage, like running a 400W or 600W HPS instead of 1000 to reduce the required amount of electricity. There would still be an annual cost to replace bulbs, plus the added upfront cost of a new ballast. Workable, but still more money than I want to spend on my hobby. I became fascinated by the possibility of a using LEDs. The idea of a less expensive fixture, lower wattage consumption and bulbs lasting ten years versus one is super appealing. I explored LED possibilities. Reading some hobbyists' online gardening journals was a big help, I saw that the OSRAM SYLVANIA PAR38 LED is Grow Light with many fans. At the heart of the popularity and ingenuity of OSRAM SYLVANIA PAR38 LED Grow Light is that it is optimized to make the right amounts of reds and blues available for every grow stage. I know next to nothing regarding the effects of applying different qualities of light, except that it's important for the plant to be able to pull what it requires as it ages. OSRAM SYLVANIA PAR38 LED Grow Light's spectra appears to do exactly that. The OSRAM SYLVANIA PAR38 LED Grow Light's appears to match HPS lighting's color spectrum at a lower cost. The decision on purchasing them is no brainer. LOVE this light.

The show, Blaze and The Monster Machines, is a huge hit with our three year old test subject; she squealed when she saw Blaze come out of the box. Fisher-Price did an excellent job of turning the two dimensional animation into a three dimensional toy; Blaze's personality shines through. His voice doesn't sound as good as he looks, but there's no indication that the little Miss noticed or cared. The first time he spoke she fell back on her butt and laughed as if she'd been told the funniest joke ever. Within very little time she got how to use the spoiler to "rev" Blaze up and was playing without assistance, which consists of lots of running and jumping around. Blaze's five stunts keep her thoroughly entertained. Even if she's bored with it next week, this toy rates Five stars from me for the sheer joy on her face today.

These are Foodsaver rolls labeled also as GameSaver. If you wonder what makes them different from regular FoodSaver rolls, their website explains: "There is no difference in the design or the quality.. GameSaver bags and rolls are conveniently packaged with multiple rolls. FoodSaver® rolls are sold individually."Bags or rolls, I like both. The pre-made bags are easiest, but a roll gives lots of flexibility to make bags sized just right, which can make rolls the more economical choice.Whether I'm buying bags or rolls, I only buy the FoodSaver (GameSaver) brand, despite the cheaper options available. I received samples of an alternative brand promoted to be as strong as FoodSaver. There was no need to test the claim, it simply took a side by side comparison to determine it was bogus. The plastic is textured differently and is noticeably thinner than the FoodSaver brand.My objective when vacuum sealing is to keep food fresh longer and/or save money by buying in bulk and freezing in portions. It makes no sense to me to risk a bag failure.I think that using cheap bags with a FoodSaver vacuum sealer is like putting cheap tires on an expensive sports car; the car will be drivable but it isn't going to perform as intended and if a tire fails, it could be ugly.Having tried multiple brands, I continue to prefer, use and recommend FoodSaver products as the best available

This is the second Lasko #3720 20" Box Fan I've purchased from Amazon. It's not my first choice for the bedroom because it does make more noise than I like when all else is quiet. Since the need was for a non-sleeping area, I chose to buy this again because it really moves the air and the other we have is still going strong after two years of almost constant operation. It's not fancy and it's loud on high but it works great and I love the price.

I couldn't be more pleased with the Archer C3200 Tri-Band Wireless Gigabit Wi-Fi Router. The wireless router it replaced was already going to get the boot for ghosting, disappearing and reappearing on the network and slowing things down while devices reconnected. I was going to replace it with a different brand router when this 1G TP-Link was made available in Vine. Even with a networked home office, multiple wireless smart televisions, tablets and laptops, 1G exceeds our needs. A one processor router rated at 100 Mbps would still suffice, but this bad baby's in and I'll be taking advantage of its options (setting up networks to prioritize devices is number one). An amazing benefit that was unknown to me before hand is that it's eliminated the need of two network extenders. With the old modem, there were two problem locations; one at the opposite corner of the house was a complete deadzone. Adding extenders was necessary to solve the problem. They're no longer necessary because of the Archer C3200 Tri-Band Wireless Gigabit Wi-Fi Router's incredible range (it has six antennas). It's slightly heavier than its predecessor with a solid, stable feel when set in place. Front LEDs are in front and very visible. Despite its advanced qualities, setup was as easy as any other router. Admin functions are easy through a user friendly interface that's intuitive to a degree with easy to understand directions.  I look forward to growing into the capabilities this router offers.

We didn't have to go far to try out this Five Star Extra Tall Locker Shelf and Drawer. We have a PrimeTime Locker by Gladiator GarageWorks GarageWorks,GASL1TAMDG in the family room for extra movie and game storage. The plan was to use stacking plastic crates on the inside, but it proved near impossible to find crates that fit and stacked. The movies and games that have accumulated are in messy piles and I've been thinking it wasn't such a great idea after all. Then, lo and behold, Five Star come out with little gem that appears to be just the answer to getting the locker organized. Unfolded, it fits exactly; the shelf sits on legs that raise it more than a foot above the locker's floor. What makes these shelves perfect is that they stack! For our purposes, I'll be ordering two more. With three stacked, they'll be about four feet high. Consider the floor, and the top shelf the locker came with, we can have five levels to stack movies and games. The plastic drawer is barely an inch tall and doesn't look to hold much. I'm not discounting its value just yet, but it isn't much of an add for me right now. If three units turn out to be unstable or if I change my mind about anything, I'll revise my review, but for now I'm loving this shelf.

This little notebook is made tougher than most. The cover is plastic and the spiral binding is protected by a cloth sheath. Given the extra attention to details, I was disappointed to see that it is one use only; the paper can't be refilled. It's very handy for making the almost daily to-do-list and it fits perfectly in my SUV's console. A movable plastic sheet can divide the notebook into sections; each section could have its own purpose or be used by different people (for use as a shared his and her to-do-list perhaps). The built-in pen loop eliminated having to rummage around in the glove box or console for a writing utensil. I would recommend this highly to anyone looking for a small notebook that's easy to carry and can take a little abuse.

I'd agreed that a couple of little eight year old special someones could stay up until they got this constructed, so I thought that I was being played when two hours came and went and it was still in pieces. It was my night to be "off," so it fell to my spouse to bring it to an end. Using his own kid friendly profanity (snuggerfuts!) and infinite patience, he was able to help them get the various scattered bits assembled into a final product. The problem was one of strength; some pieces required real muscle power in order to achieve a full connection. Play finally began after a few test runs identified which tracks needed additional adjustments. They barely played an hour before being done with it for the night. The next morning they had another hour before their mother picked them up and they spent every possible minute with it until they left. It waits for them on the dining room table and I notice it wobbles a lot when I pass by. I spoke to T2 (twin two) this morning and asked if he loved it or liked it (like) and if there was anything people buying this should know; he said to say that it needs more marbles. In short, this The Learning Journey Techno Gears Marble Mania Zoomerang Building Kit (100-Piece), Multi may require adult assistance to put together and, if you buy it, you should consider buying extra marbles too. Any toy that can inspire hours of play is a plus in my  book.

We use Avery's basic white peel off label sheets for inkjet printers. They're available in different sizes and are easy to customize with Avery online templates (no need for word processing software). This line of tags and labels from Avery are more upscale; better paper in a variety of shapes and sizes and just as easy as their regular labels to personalize at Avery online. I tried and liked the Pearlized Address Labels, the White Scallop Rectangle Tags and the White Adhesive Flags. The Pearlized Address Labels are the same size as Avery's Easy Peel Address Labels, the ones that run about a penny apiece and come 750 to a box. You can tell immediately from weight and look that the pearlized labels are better quality. The pearlized labels are four to one small sheet. They can be printed right to the edge, not so with the letter size sheets filled with the penny labels. If I needed to label twenty items, I'd have to debate with myself about whether the cost difference is worth having fancier looking labels. For mail, I'd go with the Avery penny labels. Twenty cents versus about twelve bucks. If the mail was "formal," I'd go the Miss Manners route and hand write the addresses and not buy labels at all. The special shaped and sized labels and tags are a different story. I can buy personalized wine tags including strings and delivery for less from an online printer, but if I need something the same or next day, it's good knowing I could pull it off by printing my own on an Avery product.

It's been almost sixty years since Edward Lewis Wallant's "The Pawnbroker" was published. I think the writer of the forward sums it up perfectly: It`s "a novel about not only about the Holocaust, but about responses to trauma.." This is a post-Holocaust story. Sol Nazerman survived the Holocaust but is the first to say he has no heart. He shares the home he pays for with his sister's family plus supports the household of his girlfriend and her father, but this is a man who is alone. He seems to have little regard, or even care, for those people closest to him. His pawnshop in Harlem is really a money laundering front for a gangster; even when his life is threatened in the course of business, he shows no interest in life; at the same time, he isn't suicidal. He has an apprentice, Jesus, a young man that works at the pawnshop to learn Sol's business secrets as a means to escape his life's circumstances. Jesus is also a survivor of trauma. The pawnshop customers are depicted as people trying to survive their individual traumas. The story builds to an unexpected moment that forever changes Sol and Jesus' lives, as well as those around them. This is a novel I think worthy of reading regardless of decade.

This Tyrannosaurus Rex is not a toy that moves or functions on its own with a flip of a switch. It has to come to life in the same way toy soldiers, baby dolls and cars without engines do, with imagination. The "stomp" sound feature is activated when T-Rex is moved manually. Pushing the tail controls the "chomping jaws." The chomping feature is not designed to break skin or cause pain; but it could help give flight to fantasies of chewing on enemies (like toy soldiers) or prey, or whatever a kid can dream up. The stomping and chomping are imagination enhancers. It's great details will help. They show in its different textures and shading, and the little beady eyes and wicked looking teeth. When imagination wanes or play time is over, any dino lover would find it worthy of display. I think this will be a fav toy for many.

Suave's Professional Line products seek to "work as well" as the products sold in upscale salons. This Firm Control Sculpting Gel was developed to work as well as Sebastian Gel Forte, 6.8-Ounces Bottle. Without having used the Sebastian product, I can't compare the two. As a daily user of gel, I still have an opinion. The company is marketing a product as able "to work as well" as a more expensive competitor. My regular gel, L'Oreal's Strong Hold Gel, is priced about three times higher than Suave's product. Both purport to provide a strong hold and shine. I like that Suave's scent is subtle and neither masculine or feminine; from that perspective, it would work for everyone in the house. An amount of Suave's gel that was equivalent to the amount of L'Oreal's that I apply, didn't prove to provide the same hold. Strength of hold was about the same, but not the amount of time that each gel held. I had to add about half as much more of the Suave gel to hold for as long. For the price difference, it's still a money saver compared to mine. I also thought it was Suave's gel that won a shine comparison by a hair (sorry!). A not-so-great difference showed up, literally, the morning after using extra of the Suave. I ran my fingers through my still semi-stiff hair and saw flakes of dried product fall. Ugh. No doing that in bed again. Against the dark red pillow case and sheet, enough were visible to make me think of dandruff. I concluded that while the price is better, the extra amount I had to use created the dandruff snow. With shorter hair, I probably wouldn't have run into the problem, but since I don't, I'll stick with my tried and true. I like Suave Professionals Sculpting Gel, but not enough to switch.

One serving microwave convenience meals in a bag or box have been handy to have around. I can't say I've loved any, but they work when things get busy and I can't make myself a meal, or go out for one. My biggest complaint is many have homogenized flavors and textures. Bite after bite tastes and chews pretty much the same. The Pace Ready Meal bag is see through at the bottom and designed to open easily and then function as a bowl. I looked at the contents through the bottom of the bag before putting it in the microwave. From what I saw, I expected another unmemorable microwaved "shelf stable" meal. I was wrong. For one thing, I could make out the flavor of the cumin in the smell and taste. I'd like more of it, but what it has is more than I'm used to tasting in instant meals of this type, so kudos for that. I'm not saying the flavors are nuanced, but for a sixty second meal, I was happy that I could taste the spice and enough of the two types of peppers to tell one from another. There's a note of lime in the sauce that pairs well with the cumin. There is more sauce than I expected compared to the bag's picture. I was expecting something closer to casserole consistency but it's more like a super thick soup. The rice didn't disappoint because I didn't have high expectations, but I'd have enjoyed the meal more if it had been firmer. This meal's rice reminded me of the squishy, super soft texture of instant rice that's sat too long in liquid. That said, at least it didn't turn into the hot cereal consistency that I've experienced in other shelf stable meals with rice. I could take or leave the chicken. I found the taste, density and texture of the all white pieces of chicken acceptable, but nothing to crow (sorry) about. Marketers have noted that "ALL WHITE" chicken seems to be perceived as being better by many, but cooks know that in casseroles, soups, etc., it's the dark meat that brings the flavor. I wouldn't serve it to dinner guests or use if for anything else than what it is, a time saving alternative for killing hunger. I don't love it, but this Fiesta Chicken & Rice Ready Meal from Pace is the best shelf stable meal I've had yet.

I was at an 'in-between-books' impasse for a couple days, then picked up a book I'd found at a library sale last summer. The book is EVERYMAN, Philip Roth's 27th book, published in 2006. It's a grim little tome, with a black dust jacket, the one-word title framed by a thin red-line square, the author's name writ large in white block letters, and a black and white photo of a stern-faced Roth, arms crossed, on the back cover.I only vaguely remember reading the original EVERYMAN - a 15th century morality play - or some version of it back in graduate school. Its Christian theme of life and death and a final accounting of ones deeds in life to determine whether one deserves salvation - heaven - or not seems an odd thing for Philip Roth to be writing about. I mean, he is Jewish, after all, and, judging from his writing, he puts little stock in any kind of an afterlife. So I was not surprised to find this story a pretty dark one. The unnamed protagonist - Everyman, I presume - is retired to the Jersey shore from a successful career in advertising. He has been a philanderer and hedonist, married and divorced three times, and now, at 71, finds himself alone and in declining health, having survived numerous heart surgeries, with six stents inserted, as well as a defibrillator, and faces more of the same on the immediate horizon. His two sons from the first marriage have little to do with him. His daughter, from the second, is devoted to him, but, divorced with young twins, has problems of her own.Everyman, alone and sometimes agitated and afraid, reflects back on his life, summing up his many mistakes. He wonders how he's ended up this way, and how it's all gone by so quickly, still mourning the loss of his beloved parents, as well as his own youth and virility.I don't know if EVERYMAN was a bestseller, but I strongly suspect it would not have been a popular choice for book club discussions among the elderly. It's just too damn dark, too starkly honest about the winding down of life, too sad. But I love the writing of Philip Roth. I'm frustrated too that I've not managed to keep up with his prodigious output. (I felt the same way about Updike's stuff.) The first Roth book I read was PORTNOY'S COMPLAINT, which, at 25, I found howlingly funny. My first year of teaching, I even used it in a literature class, and this was in a pretty conservative, solidly blue-collar sort of community. What was I thinking? I still wonder, over forty years later, how it was that I was never summoned to the Department Chair's office over a complaint from an outraged parent. Nope. Never happened. But I do remember it was kinda hard to get a good class discussion going about Alex Portnoy.After PORTNOY I went on to read several of Roth's other early books. One of them, LETTING GO, remains a special favorite. Of his later books, I loved AMERICAN PASTORAL and THE HUMAN STAIN.But this book, EVERYMAN, despite its dark theme, touched me with its truths. I nodded in agreement when I read the following passage, about a trip Everyman makes to the beach community where he spent summers with his parents and brother. He has lost interest in his painting and doesn't know what to do with his time."... it was still his beach and at the center of the circles in which his mind revolved when he remembered the best of boyhood. But how much time could a man spend remembering the best of boyhood? What about enjoying the best of old age? Or was the best of old age just that - the longing for the best of boyhood ...[?]"An interesting question, no? Indeed, I spent five of the most enjoyable years of my own retirement doing that very thing - remembering, and not just my boyhood, but my whole life. And writing it all down, or trying to. Four memoirs in six years, and now nothing for the past five. And I wonder. What's next? Do I have more to write of my own life? Or do I keep on doing only this: writing about other people's books? It's a question I ponder on an almost daily basis, as I continue to read and read and read some more.Yes, I could relate to Everyman. At a particularly low point near the end, he has just visited his second wife, who has had a crippling stroke; then he made some difficult phone calls to friends who were terminally ill and to the wife of his former boss, newly widowed. And then, "what he wanted to do ... [was] to revive his own esprit by phoning and talking to his mother and father."His parents by this time are both long dead, of course, but I understood that urge, that 'want.' I've had it myself.I understood too the sadness of Everyman at no longer possessing "the productive man's male allure." And I nodded sadly yet again at his realization of what was probably left for him -"But now it appeared that like any number of the elderly, he was in the process of becoming less and less and would have to see his aimless days through to the end as no more than what he was - the aimless days and uncertain nights and the impotently putting up with the physical deterioration and the terminal sadness and the waiting and the waiting for nothing. This is how it works out, he thought, this is what you could not know."Yes, EVERYMAN is a pretty unrelentingly sad sort of book, full of grim, unwelcome truths about how things really often do turn out. If there really is a final reckoning, as the 15th century EVERYMAN play suggests, then Roth's Everyman would undoubtedly "have some 'splainin' to do" as Ricky Ricardo might say. But Philip Roth? Yeah, I know he's had a couple of wives, and all the scholars and experts say a lot of his work is highly autobiographical. But even so, I think I would LIKE this guy. I think it would be great to sit with him over a coffee and talk about things - about books and writers and writing, and, and well, about life in general.Roth was featured in a PBS special last year, and, if I remember correctly, he may have said he's done writing. That he is retiring. It's not something you hear very often from writers. Mostly they just keep on writing until, well, until they die. Updike did. A couple friends of mine, Curtis Harnack and Ed Hannibal, did. But then I remember that another author, mystery writer Lawrence Block, recently announced his retirement too. So what the hell, if Philip Roth wants to retire, then he should. But I hope he enjoys it more than his own poor Everyman did. I just wonder what he'll DO, ya know?So, anyway, if you should happen to read this Phil, and you're bored, call me, okay? We could meet at McDonald's and get our senior coffees, and we could talk books. Seriously.- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

PEPPERLAND is Barry Wightman's insightful and imaginative look back at the music of the seventies, the last years and simmering aftermath of the divisive and unpopular Vietnam war, as well as the birth of the personal computer, a development that will move the world from an analog to a digital basis, an "epoch-making paradigm shift, that ... will change the world."That's a mouthful, I know. But it works in this page-turning rock and roll love story narrated by Martin "Pepper" Porter, a Chicago kid who studied computer science at U of M in Ann Arbor, where he met Susan (Sooz) Frommer, an ahead-of-her-time computer whiz in a field dominated by men. Following a passionate affair between the two at a summer camp, Sooz disappears, becoming part of the notorious Weather Underground, on the run and under cover. She reappears a few years later when Pepper, having rejected employment offers from IBM and other major firms, is just hitting it big with his quirky rock band, Pepperland (which features an insurance-selling accordion player a la Weird Al), co-founded with his brother, Dave. It is 1974, the year of Watergate.But, putting PCs, politics and protests aside, PEPPERLAND is, perhaps more than anything else, about magic. And not the Lovin' Spoonful kind (although that's in there too), but a more mysterious kind of magic involving unexplained coincidences, a Dark Stranger, an Epsteinian manager named Cool Papa Creach, and a guitar. That guitar - a Felix the Cat model - seemed to have magical qualities of its own. I was reminded of Roy Hobbs's bat, Wonderboy, in Malamud's The Natural, with all of its dark Faustian intimations. And I wondered too if Creach's musical nickname 'Cool Papa' might have been a subtle nod to the famous Negro league pitcher, Cool Papa Bell. Because Wightman adds touches of abundant authenticity to his tale everywhere you look. The small record company that Creach manages, Checkers Records, is obviously a nod to Chess Records, a Chicago Blues scene institution (think Chuck Berry), which actually did have an even smaller subsidiary named Checker Records, whose biggest act was Little Walter, who gets a brief mention. And the bands Pepperland opens for, some coming up, some on the way down, are real ones you might remember: Mott the Hoople, Pavlov's Dog, and even that Houston funk band, Archie Bell and the Drells, who taught us all, back in 1968, how to do the "Tighten Up."Wightman obviously knows the seventies music scene inside and out, with numerous references to the blander pop acts of the era, with gentle jabs at Tony Orlando, The Archies, Don McLean, and America, and reveals the music of the Carpenters as a secret guilty pleasure of even hip types like Pepper and Sooz, who sing lustily along with "Top of the World" on the car radio.Chicago in the seventies figures prominently in the plot too. Wightman uses it, wending us through its suburban streets and various downtown places like the Playboy Club, the Quiet Knight saloon, the Martha Washington Apartments for Women, the diners, delis and pizza joints.PEPPERLAND has nothing to do with the Beatles, but I couldn't help but think of them - the Sergeant Pepper album, the Magical Mystery Tour, and Yellow Submarine (which soundtrack even featured a George Martin orchestral piece called "Pepperland"). And I think Wightman intended us to remember all those things. Because this is a book so rich in reference, so dense in details that you may often find yourself drifting off in memories of your own, memories often triggered by a word, a phrase, a song lyric. And that's not a bad thing. It's good. Good books will do that, you know. They make you think. They make you remember. PEPPERLAND is one of those books. I loved it. Highly recommended.- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

TRAPLINE is the third in a series of Alison Coil mysteries by Mark Stevens set in the Flat Top wilderness area of western Colorado. I haven't read the first two (Antler Dust and Buried by the Roan), but thought I'd give this one a try, although I seldom read mysteries, mostly because I prefer novels with well-developed characters to plot-driven novels, and mystery-thrillers usually fall into the latter category. TRAPLINE is a typical mystery in that respect, but the story-line is one that rips along at such a brisk pace that I was very quickly sucked into this surprisingly literate and extremely topical tale of "murder most foul," as Agatha Christie might have called it. In fact, the horses that served as one of the many forms of transport in this wilderness mystery made me keep remembering Murder at the Gallop (1963), a Miss Marple film based on a Christie novel (After the Funeral: A Hercule Poirot Mystery) that I watched at an Army post theater in Sinop, Turkey, more than fifty years ago.But I digress. Because, although hunting guide Allison Coil does ride horses in her job, we also see SUV's, trucks, cars, helicopters and even ultralight aircraft featured throughout this story, with various elements "ripped from today's headlines," as Kirkus Reviews has already commented. It starts off with a bang, actually multiple bangs - shots by a hidden sniper attempting to murder a prominent Senate candidate during a campaign stop in Glenwood Springs. Many readers will undoubtedly flash back to the 2011 murder attempt on U.S. Representative Gabrielle Giffords in Arizona. And, in addition to the political assassination attempt angle, the hot button issue of immigration and illegal laborers from south of the border figure front and center in TRAPLINE. In fact, these illegals are brutally hunted and victimized and become pawns in a struggle between ruthless opposing factions of big business and powerful shadow corporations. Coil, along with her partner and lover, Colin, is drawn into this bloody mess when a mutilated half-corpse is discovered near one of their hunting camps in the Flat Tops. Local newspaperman Duncan Bloom becomes involved as he digs for stories about both crimes. Another unwitting participant in this increasingly complex intrigue is Alison's friend, Trudy Heath, a businesswoman who specializes in natural and organic foods with her company Down to Earth.Allison and Trudy are closely connected in their passion for nature and protecting the wilderness. Allison's devotion is obvious when she says -"You can't go back ... If you destroy the wilderness, it stays destroyed. It could take centuries or longer for nature to repair the damage ... We owe it to ourselves to preserve the wilderness. We owe it to the animals too."Trudy's investment in nature is similar, in her beliefs about farming and growing things -"She promoted going rustic. She was growing home crops with the same attitudes as farmers from the 1930s, before things got complicated ... Don't over fertilize, don't over water. Listen to your soil and sunlight, let it tell you what it wants and watch what thrives .. [She] emphasized care of the soil as a living organism and managing the ecosystem so the garden could take care of itself."There is something of the hippy mentality of the sixties scattered throughout the story, and I thought often of Joni Mitchell's words, "And we've got to get ourselves / Back to the garden." There were also distinct 'foodie' touches much in evidence here, in the meals prepared and lunches packed. Things like "a pot of pork-less possole," with an "organic red wine." And Trudy is regionally famous for her "herbs, pestos and other natural food products." She and her closest neighbors, Allison and Colin, often enjoyed breakfasts like blueberry scones with poached eggs and broiled tomatoes. And there are lunch sandwiches she packs for them -"Whole wheat baguette with cucumber, bean sprouts, tomatoes and some sort of olive tapenade that served, as Trudy put it, as a binding schmear."These frequent foodie touches, which to me suggested just the tiniest hint of the snob, took me back to another regional mystery series I have on occasion read and enjoyed, Traverse City author Aaron Stander's Sheriff Ray Elkins novels (there are seven), set in northwest Michigan. Elkins, a highly cerebral and literate lawman, is something of an epicurean gourmand and wine lover who often imports meals and ingredients from the trendy Zingerman's Deli in Ann Arbor.TRAPLINE also brought to mind other books and stories read. The most famous would be Richard Connell's grim and much-anthologized "The Most Dangerous Game," a story I read in high school. Other lesser known books, all about the immigration and illegal workers issue, are John Mort's fine novel, The Illegal; and two non-fiction works, Johnny Rico's Border Crosser: One Gringo's Illicit Passage from Mexico into America and Ted Conover's Coyotes: A Journey Across Borders With America's Illegal Aliens.Mark Stevens, like Aaron Stander, knows not just his mysteries, but pop culture and literature in general, with some sly nods to yoga, George Strait, Rick Bass and Ralph Waldo Emerson. But perhaps the most important reference here is a fragmented quote at the novel's conclusion from Walt Whitman's melancholy "I Sit and Look Out," invoking "the slights and degradations cast by arrogant persons upon the laborers, the poor ... the meanness and agony without end."Yes, this is a mystery-thriller, and just one in an evolving series, but Mark Stevens comes across as a guy who reads a lot more than just mysteries (although I'll bet he knows his Christie and Doyle well). He is so much more than just another mystery-writing hack. He is a fellow booklover and it shines through between the clues. So yeah, I liked this book, and will recommend it unreservedly. (four and a half stars)- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

FRIENDSHIP AND OTHER ESSAYS is a conveniently shirt-pocket-sized collectible little book with a leather cover - yes, you can smell the leather - probably published around 1924. I have briefly sampled its contents. "Friendship" begins with the intriguing line: "Friendship is evanescent in every man's experience and remembered like heat lightning in past summers."This tiny book also contains Thoreau's more famous "On Duty of Civil Disobedience," an essay I found hard to get through back in college and probably still would today.This is a book I would probably only recommend to serious collectors of antiquarian books, but not for their 'value,' as there were more than a million of these Little Leather Library Corporation books published during their heyday back in the 'teens and twenties of the 20th century. Today they would be primarily curiosities or conversation pieces. I value my own copy because it was a gift from a dear friend. (three and a half stars)- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

I loved this book. Gary Reilly's novel, THE ENLISTED MEN'S CLUB, succeeds on so many levels. It's a dead on accurate portrayal of army life in the late sixties; of the anti-war climate of protest, the 'flower child' era, and the summer(s) of love, particularly in the Haight-Ashbury section of San Francisco; and it's also a funny, moving and poignant coming of age story.Reilly's 20-21 year-old protagonist, Private Palmer, starts out the story as something of a kind of blank slate, who wants only to keep a low profile (although he also wants very much to be promoted) and get quietly obliterated on bowling alley beer busts as often as possible. But throughout the story the reader gets further insights into his background, born into a large Catholic family (numbers a bit vague, but there are at least two brother and two sisters), after high school Palmer drifted between dead-end jobs, waiting to be drafted. Trained as a military policeman (MP), he is initially assigned to the Presidio of San Francisco (perhaps one of most 'plum' assignments in the Army), while he awaits further orders to Vietnam, an unpopular war which lurks just offstage throughout the story. Little by little, almost against his will, Palmer is drawn into the lives of his fellow MPs of Company D and even makes a few friends. Things happen, serious things which Palmer cannot ignore, things which force him to grow up and get involved.The thing is, at first I wasn't sure if I even liked Palmer - the loner who wants nothing more than to get wasted on beer. What I liked was the way Reilly depicted the reality of enlisted life in the 60s. Reilly had it down. Here's an early example, describing the mad scramble in the barracks after duty hours -"Everyone is getting out of the company area as fast as he can because nobody wants to get nabbed for sh** details which might spring up without warning, which is the nature of sh** details."Oh yes, I remember that rush to evacuate the company area during my own early enlisted years in the sixties. And then there was the drinking. Palmer tries several times in the course of the narrative to quit both drinking and smoking, but never quite succeeds, at least not for long, because they are -"... the two things that always go hand-in-hand or else lead to one another. The problem with sobriety is that it makes you feel so good that you feel like going out and getting blasted."Stuff like this made me chuckle. Too true, and this is absolutely genuine GI thinking when you're only 19 or 20, believe me. I've been there done that - fifty years ago. These kinds of details kept me turning the pages while I tried to decide if I liked this Palmer guy. And then there are the other details of time and place, like the liquor store on Stanyan Street (the home stomping grounds of Rod McKuen, the uncrowned poet laureate of the sixties), the numerous references to the music - "Crimson and Clover," Moby Grape, the Electric Prunes, and the summer of love, the Smothers Brothers, Laugh-In, and the rumors that Paul McCartney was dead. All this attention to detail served to keep me going until a pivotal event in the story that began to turn Palmer around. He is assigned to funeral escort duty, accompanying the body of a soldier from his company back home for burial.The dead man, Thorpe, misunderstood and avoided, had been even more of a loner than Palmer, who feels confusion and remorse over how he had regarded and treated the man. Carrying a tri-folded flag onto the plane with which to drape the casket upon arrival in Wichita, Palmer becomes super-sensitive to the importance of his task, and wants so badly to do things right that he won't drink any alcohol, afraid of getting drunk and screwing things up -"His concern is mostly for the flag, which is why he decides not to smoke, afraid of getting ashes on it, or burning a hole in the fabric. When turbulence jostles the plane, he worries about spilling his soft drink on the flag, and drinks the pop quickly."From this point on, Palmer became a much more sympathetic character and began to think more about other people and less about himself. He becomes involved in helping a girl he is half in love with who is in an abusive relationship with Palmer's best friend, Courtney. And he selflessly finagles a way to have his older brother's orders to Vietnam rescinded, because of an AR which disallows two siblings serving in a combat zone.Gary Reilly was obviously a guy who read. Because Palmer's story shows many influences. There's a bit of Holden Caulfield in this young man who tries to salvage a sense of self and individuality while part of a system that discourages this, that tries to tear you down and make you an unquestioning cog in the machine of the military-industrial complex that Eisenhower had warned America about. (Indeed the Oakland Army Terminal, the shipping point for troops bound for Vietnam is described as being "industrial" looking, "civilian and factory-like.")There is something of Catch-22: 50th Anniversary Edition here too, particularly in a passage where Palmer, in trying to change his brother's orders "was only beginning to understand: if you want to get anything accomplished in the army, talk to a Spec Four." I mean shades of PFC Wintergreen. And there was also Palmer's executive officer, Lt Norbert, comically reminiscent of Heller's Lt Scheisskopf.And the final lines of THE ENLISTED MEN'S CLUB, which find Palmer sprinting desperately away into the darkness, again bring to mind Heller, as well as Updike's Rabbit, Run, and a few more recent works of military fiction, books like David Abrams' Fobbit and Kevin Powers' The Yellow Birds: A Novel.Tragically, Gary Reilly died in 2011. But he left behind more than two dozen completed and unpublished novels. THE ENLISTED MEN'S CLUB is book one of a Vietnam era trilogy. You can bet I'll be first in line for book two.I could say more, but I guess I'll just repeat what I said at the start of this. I loved this book. Very highly recommended.- Tim Bazzett, author of the Cold War memoir, SOLDIER BOY: AT PLAY IN THE ASA

James Kilgo is not a famous author, except maybe down south, where he was an English Professor at the University of Georgia, in Athens, for thirty years. I happened across his book, Deep Enough for Ivorybills (Brown Thrasher Books) a couple months ago in a thrift shop, read it and loved it, even though it's largely about hunting and fishing. I am not an outdoorsy type, but Kilgo has a way of making those subjects, dear to his own heart, branch out to encompass larger and more important subjects, like life itself and what are we here for.So I wanted to read more Kilgo, and now I have. This book, COLORS OF AFRICA, may be even better the IVORYBILLS. It certainly has an added poignancy, knowing that Kilgo died very soon after he finished writing the book, and he obviously knew this would be his last book. COLORS OF AFRICA is another book about hunting, but this time it's about how he fulfilled a life-long dream of going to Africa, as an observer and photographer on a three-week safari in Zambia with a big game-hunter acquaintance. Kilgo had thought his own hunting days were behind him, but when the hunter offers him a chance to shoot a Kudu, he decides differently.Kilgo keeps a record of his time in beautiful history-laden Luangwa River valley and all the various animal trophies his host bags, as well as his own bird watching and that stalking and shooting of the Kudu (a large antelope). But he also weaves in a lot of reading and research about Africa, citing passages from the books and journals of Dr. Livingstone, references to Burton and Speke, as well as a more modern African scholar, Stuart Marks. But Hemingway keeps coming up here too, with frequent quotes from Green Hills of Africa, a book that Kilgo first read and fell in love with during his high school years. He also mentions the film, Mountains of the Moon, which dramatized the explorations and competitions of Burton and Speke. It is a film I too remember vividly, making me wish all over again that I could have known Kilgo and talked with him about books - his and others too.Perhaps what makes Kilgo's books so readable and fascinating is the constant struggle in his own mind and heart about hunting and killing, but his enormous respect for nature and animals comes through loud and clear. This was a complicated guy, who came from a long family tradition of hunting and fishing and spending time in the outdoors, in the Carolina and Georgia swamps and woods mostly. But he also loved literature and thought deeply about the many questions that literature raises. About life, death, and what is our purpose here on earth. Perhaps one of the most poignant parts of the book, that stays with me, is a moment he has about two weeks into his African adventure. One night he is lying awake in a roofless blind in the jungle waiting for a lion to approach the bait - a rotting buffalo quarter - they've hung in a tree. And a huge flock of vultures begins to circle above the blind and land in front of it to feast on the bait. Watching these enormous carrion birds suddenly caused him to remember with a start that he had cancer. But it was the first time he had thought of it since he got to Africa. That's how absorbed he was in this once-in-a-lifetime chance adventure.This is a book filled with history, literature, natural wonders and personal memories. And the kind of wisdom that perhaps only comes when one knows he is nearing the end of things. Kilgo made the most of it, of all of it. Jim Kilgo died in December 2002. COLORS OF AFRICA was published the following spring. It's a beautiful book, Jim. Thank you. Highly recommended.- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

On the opening page of Jack Driscoll's 1998 debut novel, LUCKY MAN, LUCKY WOMAN, he gives you a pretty damn good hint of what this book is all about. His forty-ish protagonist, Perry Lafond, unable to sleep, is browsing through an old college textbook of his wife's, The Portable Nietzsche (Portable Library). A line from it that sticks with him is this: "When marrying, one should ask oneself this question: Do you believe that you will be able to converse well with this woman into your old age? Everything else in marriage is transitory ..."Man, old Fred knew what he was talking about, ya know? Especially about that "transitory" stuff. After 47 years of marriage, I figure I can tell you that with a certain authority. And yet so many people, like Perry and Marcia (Benoit) Lafond, are in such a hurry to get through college (they met at U of M in Ann Arbor), then get married and start their 'real' lives, that they would put little stock in Nietzsche. At that age, late teens and early twenties, the sap is flowing strongly and everything seems so Urgent. And now, after nearly twenty years together, Perry and Marcia are having some troubles, some failures to communicate, as it were. At nearly forty, Marcia is desperate to be a mother, no matter what the cost. Perry is not quite so sure about being a father. He's got some 'issues' to resolve from his northern Michigan childhood: a little sister who died tragically and parents who never got over it.And, in addition to Nietzsche's thoughts on marriage, Perry also has the thoughts of his older best friend, Wayne, a war-damaged Vietnam vet, who thinks the only common language between men and women is silence. Well, lately Perry and Marcia have been stuck in that ominous silence. Perry, a Connecticut parole and probation officer, has gotten a little too personally involved in the lives of his 'clients," and finds himself being attracted to other women. And then he has to fly back to Michigan for a family emergency, even as his marriage begins to go off the tracks.Yes, this is a book about marriage and family in the 1990s. The locales of New London and Groton in Connecticut and Traverse City in Michigan are woven seamlessly into the story. (Driscoll is a kind of state treasure in the latter state, where he taught writing at Interlochen Arts Academy for many years.) But the characters here are just so damn good, so REAL, that I genuinely felt for them. And there is much here to "feel" - grief, sadness, tragedy. Driscoll is damn good at this writing thing. I can't recommend this book highly enough. Just READ it, okay?- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

Deirdre McNamer's RED ROVER is something of a puzzle, but in a good way. Its diverse characters and its time jumps from 1920s Montana to the post-war 1940s and then all the way to present day force you to pay attention, so you can put the various pieces of the story together. Like the jigsaw puzzles that are depicted as popular with the patients of the Missoula rehabilitation center/nursing home where some of the characters end up - and where lives which once touched only tangentially finally intersect, perhaps for the last time.The story is of two brothers, Neil and Aidan Tierney; one becomes a B-29 pilot flying out of Saipan over Japan, the other an FBI agent sent undercover to Argentina, supposedly to ferret out Nazis. A third man, Roland Taliaferro, who has escaped a hard life in the Butte copper mines to attend college and law school, figures prominently in their lives and stories as a 'good friend' of Aidan, who follows him into the FBI just before the war. Other characters are Opal Mix, an eccentric rural nurse who becomes a town coroner, and Wendell Whitcomb, fatherless and rudderless, who straightens himself out and becomes a newspaper reporter. McNamer skillfully weaves all of these disparate characters into a web of intrigue, betrayals and ruined lives, but she makes you work. She makes you think about how lives really do come together, drift or ricochet apart, and then converge again - all over a period of several eventful decades.I was riveted by this complex tale. McNamer is an outstanding storyteller. Add her to the growing list of great writers coming out of the modern American West. Highly recommended. (four and a half stars, maybe even four and three quarters)- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

I've never been a big fan of William Faulkner, and this book, SOLDIER'S PAY, didn't change that. It seemed overly pretentious, verbose and pompous to the point of being boring. Faulkner's language has always been dense and ornate, but it simply did not work with this subject - a damaged and scarred veteran returning home to Georgia from the war. I'm always interested in reading books about the World Wars, but this one was just too tedious and did not work at all for me. I gave up on it after about 100 pages. My apologies to the late great Mr. Faulkner, but I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this book. (Although I did like the retro cover of this old paperback version.) P.S. I kept reading SOLDIER'S PAY, but it didn't get any better - too many characters, mostly unbelievable. Just a muddy mess of a novel, really. But it was his first one, and I know he got better, so ...  (two and a half stars)- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

Full disclosure: Michael Bazzett is my nephew, so naturally I was eager to read this book. YOU MUST REMEMBER THIS is Bazzett's first full collection of poems (although he has previously published a chapbook, THE IMAGINARY CITY, in 2012).For someone of my generation, the book's title is perhaps misleading. I guess I was expecting something more in the "a kiss is just a kiss" vein of poetry. No such luck. These are poems to ponder, to wonder over. I won't lie. There are some pieces here I'm still trying to figure out and may never fully understand. Maybe it's because his influences are so diverse and, for the ordinary reader at least, pretty obscure. European poets Antonio Machado and Tomaz Salamun ("Imperfection") figure in, and maybe a little Borges. Homer's The Odyssey ("Cyclops" and "Elpenor") are in the mix, as are Saul Bellow's Herzog (Penguin Classics), and even a nod to former Sex Pistol Johnny Rotten ("September Picnic").Dreams figure prominently here, in "After Machado" and "In Vladivostok" for example. And settings range variously from Mexico ("The Horse") to Canada and Siberia. And there is a definite playfulness displayed in poems like "Recollection" in which a nameless narrator puts himself together from his various parts, from his tongue in an "embroidered box on the bedside table" and "pale twinned arms / lie nestled together in a battered cello case," to his pelvis "on a wooden saddle" and "the hairy coil of my privates / rests on the dresser, next to a pile of coins." And there is the "silent" ink central to the fanciful "The Sinclair Gift Emporium."Sex and sexuality also play frequent roles - in "Manhood," "The Crisis," "Aria," "Some Party" and others.A few poems here particularly resonated. "The Dark Thing," a creature stoned and poked with sticks, evoked the "kill the pig" frenzy of Lord of the Flies; and "The Book of _________" maybe Heinlein or even Stephen King. And "Orangutan," in which a daughter's dalliance with an electric ape produces a result reminiscent of James Dickey's "The Sheep Child."I am sure that my brother (the poet's father) will find a favorite here in the final poem, "The Last Time I Saw God," with its nameless narrator rocking along in a night subway car, seated next to God - "That is when I noticed his slight resemblance to my father."For some reason as I read this book I kept remembering the Housman poem, "Terrence, this is stupid stuff." There's probably no correlation, except that I want to say: Michael, this is strange stuff. But then poetry often stumps me, and if obscurity equals talent, then Michael Bazzett is full of it. (Talent, I mean.) Highly recommended.- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

These are delicious and definitely not a compromise over 'regular' marshmallows. I find the flavor better, so I use these when making both vegan and non-vegan crispy rice treats.My one quibble with these is that they melt more slowly when making the treats, but I can live with that. They are also pricey. I do find that Amazon ships fresher ones than I find in local stores, so I tend to buy mine here rather than at my local health-food store.If you want to make vegan, GMO free treats, use these and Trader Joe's Crisp Rice Cereal and of course Earth Balance instead of butter or margarine. Adding a little salt brings out the sweetness and flavor of everything else and improves the taste of the vegan bars a LOT. I use the regular Kellogg's recipe, just with these two substitutions; for non-vegan bars I do the same but use butter.

I used this to make eggnog, not kombucha, but I'm thrilled.It is nicely made, the top fits well and it's attractive.The inside paper liner of my top came off when most of the eggnog got drunk and the container was empty--it created a vacuum that pulled the paper inside and caused it to drop in the eggnog. No biggie, but thought I'd mention it.

This is a very nice quality robe. It is lightweight and short and soft. If you want a skimpy lightweight robe, which I personally find more comfortable than the heavy terrycloth, you'll love this. If you're looking for a plush thick heavy robe, you won't like it.There are two ties, one thin cord on the inside to close once and then the big belt.It is, as shown in the pics, pretty short. That was what I wanted so I'm thrilled. Sizes run a bit on the small side so unless you like your robe on the snug side, order up a bit.

The flavor of this nutmeg is wonderful. Just opening the jar releases a wonderful aroma. I've been micro grating it, and it is delicious.I love that it is organic and non-irradiated.One area of disappointment: In the past when I've had whole nutmeg (it was a gift from a foodie friend so I'm not sure where it was purchased) the shells were on. Each time you need a fresh seed, you crack the shell. This product has pre-shelled seeds.That's fine if you use it fast, but I'm figuring it will keep it's wonderful flavor for a briefer time period than the whole shells, which lasted me years.I will repost as I see how long these retain flavor and aroma. If they don't last long, I'll get the shell-in kind next time.

I purchased one of these for a simple purpose, making tuile (those curled French cookies), and ended up using it so often I bought several more.These are an excellent non-stick paper. The size is 13 x17 size, but the super convenient thing is that they can easily be cut to fit your cookie sheets or other pans exactly. I cut several to fit my professional-sized baking sheets and a couple more in circles to fit my round layer cake pan ,which I usually line with a fresh sheet of parchment paper each time.My original purpose was making tuile, which are small circles of cookies that are removed while hot and folded into the shape you want. You need to be able to get the cookie off the sheet fast, and oiling was a pain for large volume so I got these and my results were great, with a lot less fuss than trying to grease the sheet first.After finishing the tulle project, I realized this is very handy for making other recipes for which I normally use parchment paper underneath, such as baked Chinese pork buns. Another use was for making dumplings: instead of greasing and flouring the cookie sheet to store the just-made dumplings without sticking, I used this. Basically, whenever I  might use parchment paper, I use this instead and wash instead of throwing out.Several reviews note it stains with grease. I haven't used any oil or butter on it since it's nonstick--if I use oil or butter I'd just put it directly on metal. My tuile cookies have a good amount of butter in the batter, but they aren't leaving a stain on this.And another caveat: I have not used this as a liner to make cookie other than the tuile, so I can't vouch for this use. That isn't to say it wouldn't work, but  it isn't an application I'm interested in. Cookies bake great directly metal baking sheets (with no grease usually or sometimes with a thin layer) so I don't have any desire to change, especially given that this is, in fact, a chemically coated product.And yes, another review helpfully states, this product is made with Teflon non-stick coating. Amazon's listing does not state this, but I did check Regency's site to confirm. I am not a fan of Teflon, as well, it's a chemical and I prefer not to have it near my food. I do not have any other Teflon cooking items in my kitchen. However, I knew this was Teflon when I purchased it, and decided to make an exception due to its convenience. FYI, you can also get silicone baking liners, which tend to be more expensive. Some top experts (like Alton Brown) swear by them and say they are inert, and don't react with food. Others argue there just isn't enough research on them yet to know they are safe.For me, these things are a matter of moderation. I don't think science is going to absolutely resolve the safety of this in our lifetime. Personally, I wouldn't have a kitchen full of Teflon or silicone I used daily, but once and a while is probably okay. Make your own call of course. Since I'm not certain silicone is better safety-wise than Teflon, and I like these, I'm happy with the product.To clean, I rinse, or wipe lightly with a soapy sponge as needed, and drape over various kitchen objects to dry if I don't feel like towel drying it.As of this writing, I have used and washed each sheet a dozen times or so and they show no sign of wear.

This is a very nice, well designed and constructed Lazy Susan.The wood is a pretty unfinished blonde, which you can leave as it is, or apply varnish as you choose. The item I got was nicely sanded and smooth.I purchased this to serve Chinese meals on for a group, but returned it because I misjudged how it would work for my particular table. The good part is this will hold 3-4 serving platters nicely, but the bad news (for me at least) is that on my table it is so large that it felt cramped when we added the place settings.My miscalculation is not the vendor's fault, and the vendor was prompt and professional about the return, so I'm still giving the item five stars. My caveat is that this size is only going to work on an unusually large dining room table or other big surface; I recommend prior to purchasing that you actually place a test object of this size on your table and then actually set the table to make sure you like the fit before purchasing.

I bought these to hold dumpling sauces for a home dim sum party. They are attractive, well-made and well-designed.Each side holds two tablespoons of liquid exactly, but since filling to the brim would risk spillage we put about 1.5 Tablespoons of sauce in each side. With each person having two different sauces (one soy scallion and one ginger vinegar), this item held just about the right amount for one meal, with none of the eight guests needing to refill the sauces.

Finally, a bra that takes into account the way many women use our bras anyway--as a place to stuff things!This item is ingenious, well-made and well designed.It has a double layer of fabric over the chest, allowing for the construction of a small pocket in the front. This pocket is handy for money, keys, kleenex or cell phone if you're going out for a walk or jog. I use it for biking to hold snacks so I don't have to go digging into all my other pockets when I need some energy quickly...it's very easy to grab fast since the snack is tight to my body and convenient.If you put a large item in there, of course it sticks out a bit, but when you're exercising it's better than stuffing it in your sock or wearing a fanny pack or a backpack. It's also better than putting your house keys under a rock because, you know, the thieves know that trick!Other than the pocket, this is a standard well-made sports bra with good support and fabric that holds up over time with washing and tumble dry. It wicks moisture well.I used one for a year and then purchased two more. Once you get used to having that little stash pocket it's hard to give up!One warning on colors: I love the black, and have several, but I tried the rocket red and it wasn't red at all. It is a bizarre neon orange. Which is great for those who like that kind of thing--but if you are looking for a nice red, don't buy the rocket red!

I purchased and returned this as soon as it arrived.First, it was WAY too small. It technically fit the chest size stated if you want your pajamas to fit like a skintight latex dominatrix suit. However, this was intended as a gift for someone who wanted to actually sleep in it, and wanted it to be comfortable.I might possibly have gifted it to a smaller person, rather than going through the hassle of sending it back, except that the item had a strong unpleasant odor. I suspect it is probably formaldehyde, a chemical put on clothes to make them permanent press and improve stain resistance.This is a standard practice in the clothing industry--but there is 'normal' and then there is over the top. In this case the odor was so terribly strong that I had a headache just from handling it a few moments to check the size and then to repackage it to send back. I am not particularly sensitive to odors, and have never before sent back a clothing item due to its smell.I suspect this odor would disappear if you washed it a bunch of times, however, if you are sensitive to odors, or if you intend this as a gift, and expect to give the item to the person prior to washing, definitely stay away.

This is a very nice quality chalkboard paper. To put it up, you cut along the helpful grid on the back to the size you want, then peel and apply.I purchased this because the brand I used for years, Wallies Peel and Stick Chalkboard Sheet, Slate Gray, Set of 4, while it worked great, comes in paper-sized squares and I wanted a larger chalkboard by my desk without any dividing lines.Compared with the squares, it is harder to install. First of all, you need a sharp scissors. However, even using my sharpest scissors, I did not have the dexterity to make a line as straight as a machine, and I can slightly see the difference. An exacto-knife on a work bench with a protective sheet of cardboard might have done a better job, but I didn't have that level of obsession for the project. I also found it a bit difficult to get perfectly flat without bubbles, however that, and the cutting, are the nature of this type of product and I am not taking stars off for this. Just a warning that if you want a picture-perfect permanent installation this may be a bit more difficult to make look professional than putting up smaller squares and lining them up against each other.This product does not come with chalk--you need to supply your own chalk or use the markers sold by the company for this purpose, which the company says give a better visual result. I chose to use regular chalk, rather than the markers, since I want the board for quick notes to myself rather than for display. Regular chalk writes very nicely on this--similar to a regular chalk board. Several brands of chalk I had available worked great. To erase, you need a damp cloth--in fact I'm finding outright very damp works better than slightly damp, as if you don't have enough water to wash it, it tends to leave wipe marks.The part I'm most happy about: Unlike a competing brand of similar-style peel-off paper, Fancy-fix Vinyl Peel and Stick Chalkboard Sticker with 5 Free Chalks 17.7 By 78.7 Inches,  it appears to be sticking well to my wall. It's been up nearly six days now with no signs of peeling or coming off.The reason for the four stars instead of five is that I so far have only six days' experience with the product, so I'm being cautious. I plan to see how it sticks over time, and how it holds up to repeated washings, and will update my review and star rating based on its longer-term performance.Updated May 6 to upgrade this product to five stars. I have now been using it for four months. It has continued to stick great to my wall, and it has held up nicely under repeated writing and washing. So yes, score, great product!

This is a good enjoyable read--but not the best of Eileen Yin-Fe Lo's Cookbooks.It's a romp through Eileen's childhood in China with her artistocratic grandmother, learning to cook the old-fashioned way with the help of a team of servants. She eventually escaped to the west when she was worried the communists would assign her to manual labor.If you love Chinese food, and are interested in Ms. Lo's past, it's a good book to curl up with in the evening.Compared with Ms. Lo's other books (I have four others), this is the least useful as a cookbook. I virtually never use it now that I have the Chinese Kitchen and the others.The selection of recipes is not as big as most of her other books, and I have found them to be hit or miss. In general, I've had more consistently spectacular results with her other books. One standout for me in this book is noodles with young ginger, which became a regular favorite in my household;  I never found "young" ginger, but it tastes delicious with regular supermarket ginger!For me, this book was my first Eileen cookbook, and it was a gateway drug. Once I tried it, I wanted more, stronger, better! If you're not (yet) highly motivated to learn authentic Chinese cooking and prefer a book that's fun to sit down and read, with a few recipes to get started just in case you do get inspired, this is a great choice. If you are already a fan of Eileen Yin-Fe Lo and think you would enjoy spending some time getting to know her Ah Paw's life and views on cooking a bit more, it's a also good choice, since it has the most personal material of any of the books.However, if you are a dedicated cook, already have several other Chinese cookbooks and are looking to expand your repertoire, you'll probably be disappointed. If you're looking just for a cookbook, buy the Chinese Kitchen or, if you already have that, Mastering the Art of Chinese Cooking or the Chinese Chicken Cookbook.

I was new to Sichuan peppers when I got these, and after extensive tasting and testing I determined these will not be my brand. The short version is that I got interesting but underwhelming results in three Sichuan recipes using this, but amazing stunning results with another brand readily findable in my Asian grocery.So here's the story: When I got these, I made a three Sichuan recipes with them, including the iconic and wonderful Kung Pao from Land of Plenty: A Treasury of Authentic Sichuan Cooking. So, first of all, the positive: These peppers give a strong numbing sensation which is a hallmark of Sichuan peppers, and which some say allows you to eat more hot chilis in your dish! There was also a pungent unusual flavor--also good. But then I was also detecting an unpleasant bitter aftertaste which I perceived as moldy or camphory.To figure out what was going on, I bought another kind, "Green Bay" brand from a local Asian grocery. With a friend, we did a side by side test, biting into each one in turn. The Green Bay had a more powerful woody citrusy flavor and I was overwhelmed..I LOVED it. This pepper had a weaker version of the positive flavor notes we liked and also an additional strong aftertaste, the same thing I was tasting in the dishes. I found it bitter and musty and intolerable. My friend described it more charitably as a 'strong cardamon," but still preferred the Green Bay head over heels.I then re-made the Kung Pao chicken and the difference was dramatic. My earlier attempts had been pretty good, somewhat marred by the strange aftertaste, while the version made with the Green Bay was unbelievably amazing. So that settled it...I'm tossing these and using the Green Bay. To be fair, these had sat (in a sealed bag) for four months in my pantry while the others were fresh from the Asian grocery. In theory, however, these should last two years, so I'm not going to give them a pass on the flavor. Another point in fairness: I am not a Sichuan pepper expert.Another fairness note :It is very possible that this aftertaste is actually a feature not a bug. One Web site has a quote from a chef suggesting that you can tell the difference between a good pepper and a rotten one by the bitter aftertaste; the site doesn't say clearly if it's the rotten peppers or the fresh ones that have the aftertaste.All I can say is that I'm having much better cooking results with the other brand. In terms of overall quality, these appear to be good quality peppercorns as the husks are mostly whole and empty with the bulk of the seeds removed. There are a few seeds lot of stems on the husks and in the bag, but less than in the Green Bay I bought which has a lot of seeds to remove. However, removing them isn't a big deal as most recipes call for no more than a teaspoon of these peppercorns at a time.

This is my favorite shampoo.I have had occasional issues with dandruff over the years, and I bought this when the problem got really bad last summer.This shampoo seems to keep it under control.I use it twice a week and leave it on a couple minutes, massaging it in well. It also smells nice and is a good overall shampoo and comparable for my hair to other quality shampoos.

This is my favorite white rice!It's got a wonderful mild flavor and, when cooked according to the package instructions, has exactly the right texture--soft, but not mushy, to accompany other dishes, from lentil curries to Chinese food!I really appreciate the package instructions on this product--as I often burn rice, and with this method I don't. The instructions say to use a bit of oil, 1 cup rice and 1.5 cups water. Bring briefly to a boil, then lower to a simmer, partially covered, and cook 15 minutes. Then turn off the heat and cover fully and let sit for ten minutes. It works awesomely well!This bag is enormous. I used two large plastic Cambro Round 6-Quart Storage Container, Clear containers to hold it.

These are a good product for the price.If you pay a lot more, you can get better. For example, these are softer and less crunchy--overall less fresh tasting--than Blanched Almonds from Sicily 200 Gram at more than double the price.For eating out of the bag, I would choose the more expensive ones any day and happily eat half as many. However, for baking cookies or other recipes where they may be combined with many other flavors, these will be fine. I bought these to make baked fish with almond paste from The Food of Morocco, as well as for baking cookies and making almond milk; after I've used both these and the Sicilian products in the recipes I will post on whether I taste a difference in the finished product.One comment on the "raw" designation. I suspect the manufacturer called these "raw" almonds to make clear that they aren't roasted--and they aren't. However, they can't be raw for several reasons. First, the blanching process involves immersing the almonds in boiling water, so just by definition, they can't be raw. Also, actual raw almonds are not legal in the U.S., due to government regulations aimed at protecting us from a small chance of harmful bacteria. Under U.S. law, all almond must be either cooked or fumigated--and believe it or not, after steaming or fumigating, they are still labeled raw. Helpful, huh? The packaging on this product doesn't give details on how these are processed, however, since they are not labeled organic I think it is likely they are fumigated while they still have the skins on and then blanched (or boiled in water) to remove the skins.If there is a manufacturer rep reading these reviews I would appreciate details in the comment section on this and I will update my review based on your comments.
