These are more than twice the price of the other option for whole blanched almonds on Amazon, Raw Blanched Almonds (1 Pound Bag), and of course I was wondering if the price difference is justified.After buying both, and doing a taste test, the answer is absolutely yes!These are crunchy and fresh, with no bitter taste at all. The almond flavor is more pronounced and sweeter than that of the less expensive nuts. The biggest difference I notice is the more pronounced crunch here and overall fresher taste.If you are buying these for eating out of the package, or for a very special recipe, I would say they are worth the cost. If you are using them in a recipe with a lot of other flavors, you might be better off buying the less expensive ones, as you may not notice the difference. I will be using both kinds in recipes and will post later to say if I see a difference in particular recipes. I also suspect the fresh crunchy taste won't last, so if your plan is to use just a few and store them a long time, it may be a waste of money; if I still have any of these left in a couple months I'll post on whether the crunch lasted with the product stored in a ziploc.I have also made my own blanched almonds using fresh organic almonds from a farm. It's a simple but laborious process--drench briefly in boiling water and then peel the skins...I find my hands hurt after doing a big batch! These are comparably good to the homemade kind, but much much less work! Blanched almonds are great just for eating, or roasting and eating, or for making almond milk. You can also make almond flour for cookies, or slice and put on top of cookies. I bought these mainly to make an almond paste to stuff a sea bass in the recipe "baked fish with almond paste" in The Food of Morocco.The package says certified organic. That means they aren't fumigated, like nearly all non-organic almonds are even if they are labeled raw.

This book is must-have for any serious recreational cylist who wants to have fun exploring some of Massachusetts most gorgeous biking routes.I give five stars for the variety and overall awesomeness of the 40 rides in this book, but two stars for the organization and level of detail in the book.First, the positive, is that you could bike just these routes for years and be happy as a pig in s--t! Two routes that I've very much enjoyed so far are the Whitinsville Challenge, which winds through country roads, past a reservoir, on very hilly terrain, and the Tri-State Cruise, which takes you through three states, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut!This book is ideal for a fit recreational cyclist--regularly doing at least 30-50 miles on weekends and comfortable with hills. It's also great for beginner cyclists, who can test out the easiest routes--such as the North Andover Ramble, with 33 miles of gentle rolling hills-- and gradually work up to the harder ones. The easiest route in the book is the 17.4 mile Marion Ramble, a tour of the waterfront near Buzzard's Bay.Sadly, however, the level of helpfulness and detail in the book does not match the awesomeness of the routes. To be fair, it was originally published in 2007, and some if its flaws seem more pronounced now that information is available on the 'Net with a few clicks. But in any case, the book for me at least has been mostly a list of ideas, while I rely on the Web for better info on critical things--such as where to find bathrooms and better turn-by-turn directions with landmarks.PROS--Awesome routes, with a lot of variety in difficulty, terrain and scenery--Fun organization with the route name suggesting its difficulty level. A challenge is very hard, and a ramble is the easiest--mostly flat and less than 35 miles. In between there are the "cruises." And then there are the "classics'--long and hard, and most people, even fit riders, will want to do them in two days.--A helpful map in the beginning showing locations of each route, so you can figure out which one(s) are feasible as an afternoon escape if you are, say, visiting your Aunt Bertha out in the boondocks of the state.--Elevation grid shown for each ride so you can see where the hills are.--A couple dozen black-and-white photos of the routes. I like the photos. Color, and more of them, would have been nice--but maybe too expensive to be practical.CONS--The route directions are really basic. They mostly appear to be computer generated with no apparent human input. They just say turn right on xxx street, left on yyy street. Few landmarks, such as turn right at the traffic light, or the donut shop etc.. There is occasionally helpful info, such as a note that there isn't a street sign at a turn, or that there's a dangerous hairpin turn. But mostly, very frustrating to follow; I spent a lot of time squinting at my iPhone when I missed turns.--Other than the map showing you where each route is located, which I found very useful, there is no other sorting provided. So if I'm looking for a challenge this coming weekend, I have to use the table of contents to find all the challenges and then go look  where they are, how long, how much climbing etc. There should be a list in each difficulty category with the distance and elevation climb summarized. I spent an hour typing out a spreadsheet of the routes, as the book is difficult to use in its current format.--Start points are described in words rather than with addresses. For example, one route says, "Burger King on State Route 228 at the Rockland-Norwell Town Line, immediately north of state Route 3." Okay then, but what is the address of the Burger King, so I can put it in my GPS? Even in 2007 the address of the start point would have been a basic piece of info, but today: indispensable.--Most routes don't have information on bathrooms at the start point, or on the route. The attraction of this book is to discover great biking areas far from our homes, so we will have been in the car for easily an hour or more before arriving. Bathroom info is essential!--Not enough info on convenience stores or rest stop--and the info there is isn't conveniently presented. The text description accompanying each ride does highlight places to stop, and occasionally you see a note about a convenience store in the turn-by-turn directions. But first, this should be highlighted in the summary section so you can plan your stops ahead of time at a glance. And second,  the suggestions are often not where you need the stop ie. too early/too late in the route.  Part of the problem here--and not the author's fault-- is that these are country routes and options are few. But that only makes it more important to list every single option in the remote areas, which hasn't been done.--Ride times are clearly based on the very fit, fast author and his friends. It would have been good to poll a wider range of riders on how long it takes them. The Marion Ramble, the one really easy ride for beginners is supposed to take an hour for 17 miles; sorry, but only very fit experienced cyclists do that...most people will need to leave 1.5 hours for that ride. I'm a pretty serious recreational rider and today, going with a friend who goes at a similar pace to me, we did the Whitinsville challenge in about three hours and 50 minutes, not including rest stops. The book says it's supposed to take 3 to 3.5 hours...and last year, when I was less fit, it probably took me five hours. The irony is that the super-fit riders are veterans and do not need a time range estimate--they'll simply look at the elevation grid and the mileage and they'll know how many hours to plan. Ironically, you're new enough to biking to need the time estimates to figure out how much time you need to do these routes, they probably won't apply to you; allow way more time than suggested!--The restaurant and hotel recommendations, highlighted in the summary of each ride, are so generic as to be useless--particularly in the Internet age. I really don't need to know there's a Holiday Inn nearby to stay. I can find that in a heartbeat with Google maps. I actually would like to know if there is an amazing, little-known B&B with great muffins for breakfast and a garage for bikes!--I didn't take off any stars for this because, well, the book was published in 2007. But really, it feels completely backward not to have ability to get these routes into a smartphone or a GPS. The maps are really, really small and hard to read. How about a a password protected website for people who purchase the book, with GPX files we can use for our iPhone navigation programs? If this sounds risky because people will simply share the files and cannibalize book sales, consider that awesome, easy to follow routes in gpx format are already available all over the Web for free. A lot of people are already using those instead of buying books. To compete, the next edition of this book will need to offer everything the free resources offer, and then add to it. The bar is way higher now.But yes, despite my quibbles, buy this book. Supplement the sparse directions with a GPS if you have one, or an online program. such as Ride with GPS's new iPhone app. But the great routes are worth it: You'll enjoy many hours of varied and challenging biking.

Yes. Just YES!This is the simplest design one could imagine--just a very sturdy adjustable rubber band that holds the phone in place over a soft rubber backing. It's exactly what I would have jury-rigged if I made one myself out of what I had lying around the basement. And it's brilliant in its simplicity.To use it, you simply place it on your bicycle either vertically on the handlebar stem (my choice) or horizontally on the handlebars themselves. It's one-size-fits all so you just pull the rubber band until it's tight over your smartphone. I have an iPhone 4s with a bulky Mophie case and it fit beautifully.The downside, compared with some holders that encase the phone around the edges, is that--depending on where you place it--you may you lose up to an inch of visibility. In my case, I was able to place the rubber band on the bottom portion of my 4s below the screen and did not cover any of my screen.The advantage over other types of designs is that NOTHING (barring putting a bank vault on your handlebars to hold the phone) is more stable than a strong band of rubber with a phone held on a bed of soft rubber. And the proof, I took it today for a 15-mile ride that happens to be the very bumpiest ride I know: potholes galore, poorly placed manhole covers, a bike path with sections of giant pepples and tree roots bulging through the concrete. I bounced along happily and the phone didn't budge at...it didn't even rattle. It was part of the bicycle. (UPDATED October 5, 2014: I've had this on my bicycle for 250+ miles and it still hasn't budged.)And mind you, I am fussy. I have been looking for a handlebar smartphone mount for years, but never found one that met my standards. I spent an entire afternoon once reading all the reviews of handlebar mounts on Amazon and all over the Web, and every single one of them seemed fussy, annoying and worst of all, likely to drop your phone. Every time I saw reports of dropped phones and shattered screens, I moved on.Given the lack of options, I've been keeping my iphone in my handlebar bag--majorly suboptimal given that I navigate using GPS on the phone. I used Cyclemeter to log my rides, and whenever I wasn't sure where to go I had to unzip the bag, take out the phone and look at the map. Since Cyclemeter didn't have turn by turn directions, I needed a cue sheet anyway so having it stowed away was not a complete tragedy...it was basically a fallback for when I got lost.Well, just a few days ago Ride with GPS just came out with its awesome new app with turn by turn navigation (I'll review that separately after I have more time to test it!). Based on this sweet new technologyI became strongly motivated to get a handlebar mount. Ride with GPS recommended the Handleband, and sells it on its site, but Amazon's price was better so I bought it here.I was skeptical, at first, but after I read the reviews here I purchased and I am thrilled! The only downside I can think of is that removing it and putting it back feels a little bit fussy. It is not time consuming at all--no more than 30 seconds to remove or place it in the holder. I was a bit clumsy though, and in grasping the phone near the top to place it in, I kept turning off the phone. That was mildly annoying, but I suspect with practice this will feel easier.And a note on fit. The mount is designed to fit most bicycles. I have three--two road bikes and a hybrid--and it fit all of them just fine. The tilt mechanism is rudimentary, but for my setup worked great. It's amazing how simplest is best sometimes! When the phone is in horizontal position on the handlebars, you can (ideally before you tighten the rubber) tilt it toward or away from you to place it at the best angle for you. In the vertical position on the stem, you can only tilt it right or left (not useful!) but its only possible position happens to be at a great angle for me.If you are a person who needs an easy-in, easy-out solution for your phone while riding (for example if you may get an important phone call and need to stop and remove it quickly) this may not be your best option. However, if you're like me, using it to run a bicycle GPS app, Google maps or other navigation, you'll love it.

Such a simple little thing that makes ALL the difference in a pleasant ride. I use this for cue sheets for club rides, but you can also of course put in your own directions or a folded map.It is sturdy and nicely made. The velcro straps hold firmly to my handlebars, and the edge closure is easy to open to place items or remove them but stays firmly closed when riding.You can put it flipped as shown in the pic or if, like me, you have a small handlebar bag, you can flip it over the bag and rest it on top, which for me is the ideal position for reading cue sheets on a racing bike since I'm hunched over the handlebars.I would also like to address the reviewers who said it is too small, preventing them from including a full cue sheet for a long ride. This is a good point: For a 50 mile ride I usually need three sheets and for a 35 mile ride two; that means I have to either stop briefly to flip to the next sheet or fumble with it while riding, which is do-able but not optimal. Usually I follow other riders until I have a moment to do it safely.From my perspective, this is a small inconvenience and SO worth it to have a manageablely sized rather than humongous item on my handlebars. A map holder twice this size would interfere with my hand posiiton and maybe even obstruct my view of the road. However, everyone's bike set up and preferences is different, so I definitely would suggest buying the largest cover which doesn't interfere with your riding. You can quickly figure out what size works for you by cutting out a piece of cardboard and using a butterfly clip to attach it temporarily to your handlebars. Take a ride around the block and you'll quickly know if you like the size or not.

I like this food because it is grain-free and very high quality meat. Cats, as obligate carnivores, don't need grain, and in fact--if you give them something with a lot of carbs, they will continue eating until they have enough protein.Since I switched my cats a few years back to this brand, both lost weight even though I feed them as much of this as they will eat. It completely transformed one of my cats. He was dumpy, overweight and middle-aged and since the food transition he lost weight and has become more active. His fur looks amazing! I also recommended this food to a friend, forgot I made the recommendation and six months later was over his house and said, wow, your cat looks amazing! He said, yeah, it's the food change we talked about.That said, the Wellness line is not my cat's favorite by any means. The reason is that it's like switching a person from potato chips and McDonald's to good healthy food. The supermarket brands such as Fancy Feast are filled with rendered fat, which smells great and makes cats go crazy. This has none of this, so they miss it. I transitioned VERY slowly, mixing the food they liked with a small amount of this and gradually increasing the proportion over months.Now, years later, my cat eats this with gusto--though, of course, if I brought Fancy Feast back he would go nuts again for that, but I don't. This is is his second favorite flavor after this one: Wellness Canned Cat Food, Chicken and Herring Recipe, 12-Pack of 12-1/2-Ounce Cans.The nice thing about this food is that, while he now eats it with apparent pleasure, my cat never overeats. I can give him as much as he wants/asks for and he stays the same weight. I'd say he eats an average of a half 12-ounce can a day, but it varies--some days he eats almost a full can, other days less than half. So essentially he self regulates, whereas with the kitty crack and dried food, full of grain, he overate.These large cans must be opened with a can opener. I buy them because they are a better value economically--the small cans of this brand are way expensive. Even this is expensive per ounce,, but if you actually do a calculation of dollars paid per protein this one stacks up just fine to the less expensive brands.  Which means my cat gets the nutrition he needs in fewer ounces. Any wet food is more expensive than dried food, but based on my cat's consumption, feeding Wellness is not significantly more expensive than feeding mass-market wet food.

There are very few brands of detergent that have no scent or dye. I'm not allergic to scent but I don't particularly like most of the scents out there and I see no reason for the dye. Why should I have additional chemicals on my skin, and in my life, when they are fully unnecessary?This detergent works great, and since it is HE, a little goes a long way. I generally prefer powder detergents since I have a front loader but I used this while living for six weeks in an apartment with a washer for which the manufacturer recommended liquid detergent.

Solid and seems well made. The four slots are large enough to hold letter-size paper, and the front portion can be used for various supplies; I ended up using it for small notebooks.One disappointment was that slightly larger than letter sized construction paper did not fit in this. I didn't take points off for that, since the size is clearly marked. However, if anyone made one slightly larger I would prefer it, as my desk drawer is a tad wider! But I didn't find any other sizes.I did see one reviewer had an issue with theirs coming apart. So far so good for me, but if I have any issues over time I will re-post and change the rating on this review.

When I saw this product was made with all natural materials, it sounded like a win! It looked like rope, and wood.Not exactly. When it arrived, not only did I notice that the rungs are held together with glue, it was poorly applied--resulting in visible glue spots on many of the rungs--one of them the size of a quarter.That in itself might have been okay.  But then I noticed that several of the rungs were completely loose, sliding up and down on the rope. I gently pushed one that seemed solid, and it, too, moved.Rather than return it, I fixed it by taking it apart and using another (longer) piece of rope. I placed a knot under and above each rung. Now the rungs are solid.

I bought this with the idea of putting it on the pullout keypad shelf to make using my laptop more ergonomic. The big advantage of this keyboard was it was the only Mac-specific one I could find that has a trackpad on the keyboard. The Mac bluetooth keyboard (which is nicely built) has no built-in trackpad so must be used with an external mouse or trackpad.I really really wanted a built-in trackpad since I find it more convenient...I hate taking my hand off the keyboard all the way to the right every time I have to do something. For people who prefer external trackpads or mice (which are probably the majority), I heartily recommend you skip this product and buy a nice keyboard, either the official mac one or another. Practically anything will be better than this one.The picture looked sleek and nice, and I clicked "buy" before reading the reviews. Big mistake. When I took it out of the box, I was immediately disappointed. The plastic is cheap and lightweight. Two AAA batteries needed, not included. Eager to use it, I ran to the kitchen and took some out of the baking scale.Bluetooth setup with my Macbook Pro took seconds and worked flawlessly, so I stayed optimistic. But typing on this thing was like driving a plastic car on the highway....rattle, rattle, rattle. For full disclosure, I type 100 wpm and expect a keyboard to perform. But this didn't even come close and I wouldn't recommend it even to someone with lower standards. The keys are spongy and annoying and slow and every stroke reminded you that you were typing on a cheap piece of plastic.But the real dealbreaker is the trackpad, which after all is a main reason to consider this over the Mac version. It is jumpy and uses 1990 technology . While it's billed as a Mac keyboard it doesn't include any of the keypad functions, such as scroll up and down or swipe, of the modern OS. I can't even tap to click--you have to use the hard keys, which require a very firm press which takes time and effort. I really tried for an hour to make myself use this keyboard, but every time I needed a mouse action, my hand kept flying to the laptop high on the desk--defeating the purpose of having a separate, lower keyboard!And the straw that broke the camel's back? The 'a' key didn't work at least half the time. nd truly, tht is nnoying.Above, I mentioned that batteries are not included. Which brings me to this: If you use your keyboard a lot, I would expect you are going to be constantly replacing these batteries. This is not good design. Unlike the official Mac wireless keyboard, this one  won't turn off automatically when not in use...you have to remember to flip the switch. People buying external keyboards often want them for ergonomic reasons, which means they are using them a LOT.So, when panning a product I try to suggest alternatives. If you are looking for a media-server keyboard, consider this tiny little beauty: FAVI Entertainment Mini Wireless Keyboard with Mouse Touchpad and Laser Pointer (FE01-GR) - Green. I also will be checking out the Logitech diNovo Edge Keyboard (Black)Logitech, which has been discontinued but they are still selling the stock. This is not a Mac specific keyboard, but it can be used with Mac as long as you are willing to take the time to figure out the corresponding keys for the Mac-specific functions. I have one I used for years as for my media server, and I liked the rechargeability--just plop it in the stand when done and no batteries needed. I never had the issues of the battery dying prematurely (mine lasted five years) posted in other reviews. However, I've never used it as an external keyboard for Macbook, so after I do I will post a review.

In the last week these have been used to chop whole canned tomatoes into smaller pieces, cut apart dishwasher tabs because we want to use half, cut string and a zillion other little things. They are constantly being used and they work great. Dishwasher safe. Another win for OXO.

I really appreciate the opportunity to buy organic, nonGMO cornstarch at a reasonable price. I don't see a difference in performance or taste, but I prefer to avoid GMOs when I can and all non-organic cornstarch is very likely to be 100% from roundup ready genetically modified corn.

I bought this on Amazon because there are no preservatives or additives, unlike most sun-dried tomatoes in the grocery store which have sulfur or other preservatives.They are absolutely delicious and I use them mainly to make the "tomato magic" (substitute tomato paste recipe) in Paula Wolfert's The Food of Morocco. The great part is you make the tomato paste and freeze it in tablespoons on a cookie sheet, then put it in a ziploc and you have a small amount of delicious homemade tomato paste whenever you want it. When I used cans it tasted less good and there was a lot of wastage since I would open one can just to get a few spoonfuls.

I'm following recipes in Eileen Yin-Fei Lo's Chinese KItchen. I bought this to make the wonderful spicy-sweet Hunan (authentic) orange chicken. The author gives you the choice between gin and this Chinese wine. I used both and they are both delicious--about the same level of delicious!I couldn't find this anywhere locally, even in the Asian groceries, so I was delighted to find it on Amazon.

When you want to premeasure ingredients and not use up every medium-size bowl in your cabinet, these are great.For example, if your you're making a stir fry you have a lot of ingredients you need to pre-measure--a few tablespoons of scallions, garlic, sauces etc. And you have instants to put them in the wok in a specific order. These work great and are a pleasure to use.They are solid, nicely made and shaped and have a little finger hold on the side, which makes them easy to grasp.You could also use these for dipping sauces when serving a meal.

I used this to make my own yoga mat cleaner: Water, lemon grass and tea tree oil. It smells wonderful and costs  fraction of the price of the commercial cleaner I bought.This lemon grass smells great and appears to be of good quality.

If you've read Steelheart and want just a little more to tide you over until the next book, this is for you. It's short, it's fun and gives a little more insight into what happened to the world after Steelheart.

I bought this because I wanted to make pecan pie and couldn't stomach the idea of putting corn syrup, most likely full of GMOs, in it.I used this instead of corn syrup in a Bourbon pecan pie recipe and it was stunning! Best pecan pie I've ever made or eaten.Later, when I needed to use this for a vegan pecan caramel bar, I contacted the company to ask if the product is vegan. They confirmed it is.

This grinder does a great job grinding for the price. I have owned two of them.First, the grinding is decent--pretty even, and the adjustability works well. I also like that it dumps the coffee into a little drawer so you don't have to unscrew anything to get it.What I dislike is that little timer dial you use to start it running is not attached. It comes off regularly, and the result is I'm always rooting around the counter for it. I don't understand why they didn't attach this part securely.The third thing I dislike is that you can't program it to grind a set amount of coffee. You can guesstimate with the timer dial but it's really inaccurate so I always overground or underground. Overgrinding resulted in stale grounds in my basket overnight (defeating the purpose of grinding mself) and undergrinding means I have to turn the timer again...likely meaning I'll end up overgriding.Anyway, my last issue with the Baratza is that, at least in my hands, I owned two and each lasted only 2 or 3 years each time. I did not clean it often, so it is possible it is partly  my fault.In terms of what to buy instead: I couldn't find anything else that looked promising in this price range. A friend has a Breville she loves which does a nice job of dosing--but hers is from 2011 and I see recent reviews show quality issues with the newer models. I ended up splurging and buying a Mazzer Mini--very expensive but I hope it will last much longer than this.NOTE: At least one review says Baratza has since changed the annoying knob design. If so, that is really great and would make this a four star product.

I use this mainly to bake and to make fresh organic brown sugar. To do this, take organic white sugar, add a little bit of this and mash with a fork until you have beautiful fresh fluffy brown sugar. It's way more economical than buying brown sugar and it's organic!A friend of mine likes it so much she eats it on rice cakes. Since this comes in a pack of three huge jars, I ended up gifting her one to take home.

These are classic wax markers, handy for marking many items when you don't want to use a Sharpie.On ceramic plates, if people write their names to reuse their plates, I find this washes off better than Sharpies which I have to get off with alcohol.

This is a beautifully made heavyweight yoga strap which is a pleasure to use. The closure works great and holds securely. It is wider than many yoga straps, distributing weight more evenly.The six-foot works great for most applications. For certain poses, such as supta bada konasana (particularly if you have big hips!) you may be happier with the 8 foot.

Since almost all the corn in the U.S. is made from GMO corn, it's hard to find cornmeal that isn't. The GMO debate is too large for this space, but suffice it to say there are political, environmental and (possibly) health reasons to avoid GMOs.Bob's Red Mill has made 100% commitment to avoiding GMOs, which I love.This is also delicious cornmeal. I have used it to make polenta and it was flavorful with a lovely texture. I also use it regularly in a shaker (RSVP Endurance All Purpose Shaker) to coat my pizza peel before making homemade pizza using dough from The New Artisan Bread in Five Minutes a Day: The Discovery That Revolutionizes Home Baking.

I bought this to make the absolutely fabulous vegan salted caramel bars in Vegan Cookies Invade Your Cookie Jar: 100 Dairy-Free Recipes for Everyone's Favorite Treats. The recipe is great with this syrup. I also made a version with Steen's Cane Syrup, which is also vegan and which I slightly prefer in taste.But I can say the rice syrup is nice because it's not overly sweet and takes up a lot of space, handy for this kind of cookie. The taste is a little new to me but not unpleasant at all.

I used these to make the Corsican soup in Paula Wolfert's Mediterranean Clay Pot Cooking: Traditional and Modern Recipes to Savor and Share. Soaked them overnight and simmered them with fatback before they went in the soup. I'm making it again and again.

I used this for the Pain de Mie recipe on King Arthur's website. It turned out stunning.For those of you who have never tried Pain de Mie, it makes great tea sandwiches and the grilled cheese sandwiches you cn make with it are pretty much state-of-the-art never-had-better!I look forward to making a bread with all or mostly potato flour and will post when I do.Bob's Red Mill products are awesome as they are all GMO free and delicious.
This is an EXCEPTIONAL overall great lubricant. Worth the price. Buy it, hoard it.
And Twining's brings me back to my younger days when I could never get enough of this-- it has the same smoky wonderful powerful flavor as the ones I was used to enjoying back in the 1960's

Now if I ever get the money I want another one-- and this book will help me restore it to its former glory. It's very specific, has great info -- and even though I have been working on cars since 1968, I think this book spells it out very plainly for anyone who has an interst.

Oh the great Techno music of the 90's!!! Technotronic's music blasted from my car's stereo cassette player (4 speakers) late at night on my way to and from the local watering holes in the early 90's. Now this CD blasts from my car's CD player (6 speakers) as I roar thru the night.. Dance Dance Dance!!! Thump Thump Thump!! -- I love this album-- it is timeless. Funky. Moody, Dark and Powerful.
but they are kind of small -- nevertheless, they are nice looking and make happy noises. The price is right too..
It's perfect for my printer. the price is right and I hope it lasts a good long time. To Be Continued

Dives right into the soil, picks up a hefty load of dirt, and goes back for more. Stainless steel blade is ez to keep clean -- a little oil or silicone on it will ensure that the next load of dirt will sliiide right off into the receptacle it was meant for.The price is right and this should last a good long time.It's big but easy on my hands, which have arthritis.Has a sturdy loop to hang it on a hook.

I LOVE this -- slim enough to fit in my shirt pocket but thick enough to contain the names and addresses of my adoring friends and fans.The cover looks like real leather and the whole book is very sturdy.

It's OK --  Bags are long enough to cover my shirts on their stacked hangers. Each bag is connected to the other by perforations and need to be very gently pulled apart, as sometimes the perforations do not "tear" open correctly -- so I have to patch up the loose ends/tops. Other than that each bag is long enough to fold over on the bottom or  knot, for those who want extra protection for their clothes.The plastic is thin gauge but not too thin -- easy to handle once I am placing the bag over the clothes.

This is ADORABLE!! KITSCHY! FUN!! WRY!! FUNNY!! I love it!!! Everything Madam Prez would need for the next 8 years. I would suggest getting this now, so you can add to it once presidential history starts to unfold.Bill is there, so is Oprah, as well as many other friends and "foes"  -- and the fold-out backgrounds are really well illustrated!! Cut out the paper dolls very carefully as they are a bit thin -- but with a little imagination, craftiness and a glue stick, you can reinforce them-- Heaven knows they have to last for the next 9 years (starting now). The White House Ghosts are intriguing and imaginative, and the extra Hillary faces (with appropriate expressions) are too too funny!!I would go to the local 5&10 or whatever passes for one nowadays and try to find a little brass saxophone for the Bill paper doll, so he can while away the time as The First Guy.The book is hardcover and has a nifty ribbon to keep it closed to keep everything from spilling out.I'd keep this away from the kids -- unless they are old enough to Vote.

What's not to like about these Heft Slider Freezer Bags?!! They don't fall apart like the cheaper store-brands, they hold anything from food to snacks, to car parts to buttons, etc etc. The slider bar works and works and works-- It's a sin to throw one of these out if it's still reusable.If I'm storing food I sometimes wrap it in aluminum foil (old habit, I know) and then write in marker, on the bag. The writing stays on (which is great because once I accidentally made stew using frozen unlabeled cat food).For the price they last forever and ever. Worth every penny.

I bought this because it was suggested on Amazon for my Winbest Pro Edition Metal Detector by BARSKA. The top third of the detector sticks out of the case-- it's too small-- I guess I can use the case for my fishing rods........ Now I need to look for a case that fits my Winbest Pro Edition Metal Detector by BARSKA and protects the readout

I have IBS and sometimes have major problems (pain) after taking any kind of gut enhancing product. I take one capsule of the Viva Labs Advanced Probiotics every other day or every 3 days - just for me to be on the safe side - and so far have not had any adverse effects. I don't tempt fate by eating anything that I know has caused me problems in the past but other than that, these probiotics have not caused me any adverse effects and since I know they are good for me, I will continue taking them.The price is higher than what I have normally paid for Probiotics in the past but they certainly seem to be doing a good job, so that is the least of my complaints.

to cope with a significant handicap when you are becoming a young adult, but it is even worse when it was caused by someone you loved, who dies (Parker's mother) causing your blindness, throwing you into a world of sightlessness -- then losing your father... then having to move in with cousins and aunts, uncles, not all of whom you find particularly endearing.But what does Parker Grant do? She SURVIVES with a toughness and practicality, creating her own world, hugging herself tightly to her soul and determination  -- and yes like any young teenager, worrying about her image as a person (not as a blind person), learning about love and loss, friendship and how to cope with people who only want to get in your way and cause trouble.It's hard enough trying to navigate your world as a sighted person when you are young and about to inherit the world and adulthood -- Parker takes this with determination, sometimes anger (which fuels her strength) and always it seems, with a muted hope and general faith that she WILL get what she wants -- how, she sometimes does not know, but she appears to have high hopes for herself, and will not take no for an answer.My favorite part of this book are the running sequences. She is free, she flies like the wind, she ooops-- bumps into things, she is headstrong and she thrives on all of this.Surely this is a book that inspires, that alerts young teens to the fact that people who are "different" are really much more like them than they realize. Hopefully this book will create empathy where there sometimes is none, and challenge and give hope to those in Parker's age group, who are trying to navigate a world that has placed physical roadblocks in their way.

Lenox quality is something I have come to expect naturally --  and I have NEVER been disappointed. Lenox takes a theme and turns it into a soothing balm that can help to override the daily problems one faces. No matter what the theme is-- cats, dogs, angels, cute tchotchkies, religious themes, they are approached with dignity, flawless construction, sometimes humor, and always the Lenox QUALITY we have come to know and love.The porcelain is constructed in such a way that it brings a muted dignity to the flowing forms, and reflects ambient light in a way that flatters the folds of the garments and the faces of each figure.This Holy Family Nativity set is no exception. It speaks of quietude and reverence even if it is just placed somewhere and left unlit. However, the lighting brings a special "life" to these images, reminding me of warm flickering candles in the old time churches I would visit as a little kid with my Italian Nonna, and the way the lights brought to life the legends and stories behind the saintly images and statues there.Although the price of this set may be high to some, this will be a cherished heirloom that will last for ages, if properly cared for.I know this set will light my way to Christmas this year, and I certainly know that I will keep this set up in a special place, long after Christmas is over.

VERY Rich is the subject matter of this book. Consisting of twelve essays by theologians concerning the proceedings of the Los Angeles Theology Conference of January 2015, "Locating Atonement" is not  a book to read once and put down-- neither is it a book that one can skim over. Every single thought, word, phrase, has a centralized meaning relating to the original theme of Atonement, and this book is basically a guide, a reference, a deep delving into religion, wisdom, realism, hope, interpretations, of the meaning of Atonement in, by and from God, The Trinity (and there are some beautiful interpretations of the Triune God here!), and The Word Made Flesh. And of course, every single author brings a new, fresh interpretation which is sometimes at variance with what other authors in this book have put forward as a basis of argument or interpretation.Of particular interest to me at the moment (as I am about 1/3 though this book, where every word matters) is Benjamin Myers chapter on "The Patristic Model", with its "implied metaphysical assumptions".I give this book 5 stars, but I give the typeface and the color of the paper stock 2 stars, as the (11 point?) thin typeface looks to be dark grey, which does not stand out on the ecru colored pages. This is bad, considering the fact that every single word in this exceptional book really must be read fully in order to gain the richness of the dialogues within. Perhaps the publisher will atone for this oversight in the future by reprinting on white stock with a more readable typeface.I AM recommending this book to my pastor.

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL!!! Stunning gold colors. very good looking face  -- I expected this, as a woman's watch to be much smaller than it is-- I welcome its bold statement and large features. I need to have two of the links removed as it is too long for my wrist and I will make sure I find a REALLY GOOD jeweler who will treat this watch as the gem it really is.Even the cardboard box it came in -- is  a very arresting design -- black with the logo . It opens up front-wise, to reveal a beautiful presentation box which is very handsomely made!!The manual that comes with this watch is unobtrusively situated in the back of the box. It is a good manual concerning several different watch models...... BUT I would have liked to know more about removing the links to make it fit, and about that -- there is nothing..

Rugged, handsome, very utilitarian.  Dense but thin enough not to bunch or get stuck in the door. Very nicely made.  I will wait to add any more stars until it proves its worth when it starts to get snowy and ugly out there.
No one knows who I am when I wear this. Except maybe my friends, and relatives and people who ride the bus with me and.........
Really Really cute! Makes me wanna take it for a walk on a leash.

Once again I'll say it -- this book is PRECIOUS -- it is an OmniReligious (well...... within the Christian Faith) expression of viewpoints, experiences, opinions -- short (3 or 4 pages) absorbing articles touching upon the questions that Jesus asked of his followers. The authors, all Christian spiritual leaders, open a vista to the reader, who can also pose his/her own questions, solutions or observations concerning the questions Jesus asked his followers.My favorite one was by Spencer Reese "Woman, why do you involve me" -- was  eye-opening, touching, even in some instances, humorous -- but I almost cried reading his essay.I cannot read through "What Did Jesus Ask?" without wanting to pick up this book and read it again. The essays are rich and thought-provoking, comforting, inspirational.In the very back of this book is a Biblical Reference Guide, with the actual questions themselves and a short description of the context in which they were asked.I have a question myself-- why were there no essays by Non Christian religious leaders? Surely everyone knows something about these questions that Jesus asked, and Non Christian leaders most certainly would have their own "take" on them. We know Jesus was not talking to one specific religious group when He was on Earth, asking these questions. I would have loved to have read the opinions of Non Christian religious leaders.This book would be a great addition to a weekly/monthly religious book group.

When I first started to read this book, it induced some flashbacks that had been semi-buried in my past. Me, Mom Sylvia and Sis, striding down the rain soaked bridge over the Schuylkill river in Philadelphia in 1962, on our way to the annual Notre Dame Navy game. Poor Mom took a face-plant on that bridge but undaunted she sallied forth and we had a great day at the stadium despite the torrential rain. Dad was not a sports fanatic, Mom was rabid about ND and we'd religiously attend the ND/Navy games, watching the other ND games on TV. While celebrating one last-minute victory, we cheered so hard we broke the springs under the couch, Dad was totally mystified.Mom would have been 95 this year but cancer took her away before she reached 72. She loved Notre Dame football until she could not see the TV screen anymore, And our days of going to the Notre Dame games were long long over. So it is a real breath of fresh air to read about this 95 yr old man with fresh memories, an ebullient attitude towards life and football, and the gift that one son gave this man, his father (and vice versa) -- the ability to once again attend the games of their beloved Ole Miss, share hot dogs, corn dogs, camaraderie and memories.Reading this book was an exercise in Joy. Fresh wit, dry humor, and thoughtful introspection -- mixed  in with great anecdotes, history and lore. Stuart Stevens recants highlights of past games, his boyhood impressions and experiences, and the general attitude of the people he and his father meet while at these stadiums-- the mantra "Hotty Toddy" shared by strangers and old friends alike, the deeper thoughts about racial attitudes in the olden days, the riots, the early days of desegregation, and the time when all-white teams were suddenly being supplanted by exceptional black athletes, and the history and impact of segregation in that area and era. The Last Season reads in a friendly familiar matter like a late autumn walk through a sun warmed campus, and the heart beats faster, and one's ears almost perk up when Stevens describes the unmistakable beat of marching band music filling the air long before the stadium comes into view.The Last Season is a riveting narrative of an exceptional bond between father, son and the football team they have loved forever.

Unlike some of those transparent gloves you can buy in the supermarket or hardware store, these nice blue X3 Extreme gloves are form fitting, swaddling your hand and fingers in latex -- enabling one to be dexterous (pick up coins and smaller objects) and forming a thick protective barrier when working with dirt and liquids. I can put lotion on my hands and then put these gloves on without worrying that (as has happened with other, thinner gloves) about resistance, or the bottom band on the cuff ripping off. These gloves glide on. I can reuse them as well, the next day, or the next time I need them as they do not seem to stick together and fossilize as some of their competition does.They are note powdered inside which is great, as the powder tends to dry up the skin on my fingers.

Handy Dandy little gadget to keep near where I throw my mail when I get home from work. Roll it across my name and addy and account number on my magazines and they become ANONYMOUS for sure and I can read in peace on the bus without someone trying to find out who I am.It's easy to hold and easy to store. The bright yellow handle makes it easier to find should it plunk itself onto the floor.

The Pros:This Brita pitcher is nice looking, streamlined, sturdy and bigThe filter has much less charcoal fallout when it it first used.The filter is easy to insert.Usage/Replacement indicator is a great idea. I click the button every day just to see those lights (LOL)-- a very practical idea however!!!The Cons:The first time I used it the (very nice idea, and it's a lot better than my using a Post-It) flap that covers the spout went flying off backwards.Ditto for the filter cover flap with usage/replacement indicator.BOTH are now secured with tape-- they still flap but they don't launch themselves into the dish drainer anymore.The black plastic sleeve inside the pitcher at the top half - doesn't that come off for cleaning? I tried and it seems to be stuck there as part of the design. You KNOW mildew is going to love growing between that sleeve and the inside of the pitcher. Sure, the instructions say rinse itand let it dry upside down but I'm not happy with that half hearted attempt to thoroughly clean that area.The finished product- the filtered water, is enjoyably tasty.

These Party Variety baking cups by Reynolds, would make nice stocking stuffers, each set in its own sturdy plastic container (which I hope is recyclable).Thye designs on the papers are fun, cute and festive.They certainly make cupcakes and muffins look showy!! The paper is sturdy enough to hold batter without wilting, and peels off the finished product easily,

Emma and Isaac are at odds with each other, Isaac, seemingly enjoying his rumschpringe, may not be the man Emma (who can sometimes be quite headstrong herself)  wants to marry after all although her heart and emotions are still very much involved with him. Isaac on the other hand is standoffish, loud and sometimes rude to her.. Emma does have her community to fall back on, which includes the sisterly love of her friends that she works with, and her family as well. Isaac is torn between the English world and the community he grew up in. But neither he nor Emma will give way to one another, and the tension builds.We follow Emma and Isaac, their families and friends, through good times and tragedies. The Amish community is, as always, close knit as this book illustrates, with one individual pitching in to help another, whether they be family or friend or co worker, but Isaac seems to be keeping a secret from Emma and her heart only breaks even more.When Isaac, who is actually more responsible than Emma believes him to be,  makes his final decision, the Bishop does not make it any easier for him. Neither does Emma, who thinks she knows Isaac's "secret", and is miserable because of what she believes to be true. Will love conquer all? Or will a good thorough soul-searching conversation pave the way to reconciliation?"Crossroads", as in other Barbara Cameron's books with an Amish theme, conjures up the warmth of family and friends in the Amish community. It is a friendly book to read, as it takes the reader into a world that most of us know very little about. The glossary in the back defines the Amish words and phrases found sprinkled liberally through these pages,, and as before in her other books, contains several pages of Amish recipes.An enjoyable read, nothing unexpected as per the plot, but a nice foray through the life of an Amish young lady,, the man she loves, and their close-knot community

A Purple jacket, purple text, purple illustrations -- fabulous!! I just happen to carry a small purple duffel so this book looked great inside and outside of the bag.I think every page of this book was spellbinding, fun to read, and engrossing, The "teasers" and illustrations at the end of each chapter added to the suspense and the mystery.Of the characters Libby and May, May was the more believable one, She was serious, adventurous, fun loving and pragmatic. Also a little "dizzy" - when your laptop battery runs out all you need to do is recharge it.....When May found the Princess X stickers, the book took on more substance and suspense. Meeting Trick (Patrick) was the beginning of some super sleuthing, trying to unravel the mystery of Libby's disappearance and the identity of the "Needle Man.The comes along Jacob, slim enough to be a wisp of fog that weaves in and out of everyone's lives, the Needle Man included."I am Princess X" takes the reader through the streets and underground of Seattle Washington, and on some fast paced action on the city buses (as someone who rode the bus for most of my life, I vicariously enjoyed the mad dashes to catch a bus and the equally frantic dashes to make a connection or to get someplace before it closed). I also enjoyed the very ricj descriptions of local stores, as well as the rotting underground that the four sleuths raced through in order to reach their objective and elude a killer/.There is action galore in this book, which I found very hard to put down, This is not a book you skim over, as you will lose precious details if you do.No romance, which was great, as each character was a unique person who added to the depth of the plot and the action.And for those who may think 15 an 16 is too young to unravel subtle clues or think up new ways of solving riddles, that of course is not true, Sis and I at the tender age of 10 and 11 as well as several of our schoolmates,had our own super sleuthing club, with meetings - we fancied ourselves young detectives making our neighborhood safer..The ending of this book, the culmination of sleuthing, running, hiding and unraveling the mystery, is

It is a bit too sweet for my tastes and the sweetness has the slightly bitter edge that occurs when I use a little too much Stevia in any of my other drinks. Zevia mixes with fruit juice and gives it a Special zing, but it mixes...just....o...k with spirits . It would shine in its own right, if it was a little less sweeter. It IS refreshing, cold, right from the can, but there is just a little too much sweetness here.I had a really nasty reaction to this the other night -- I see that it has 3 different sugars in it -- something in it definitely made me lightheaded with a significant sugar high. I had even mixed it with water to cut the sweetness but I became very dizzy from it.

These are nice, durable appearing labels, The Avery website had more than enough template choices (utilitarian and/or attractive) to use, and to easily customize, for this specific label. The label is large enough, the typefaces are visible and colorful and it sticks well to plastic and glass alike. I will see what heat, cold, humidity do to the labels in the next few weeks - Update...The labels are still stuck on the glass and the plastic-- no peeling. They do what they are supposed to do.

When I first saw the ad for this on TV I thought it was a joooke -- nooo it was not!! Arriving in a discrete Amazon Vine brown box with brown paper padding inside (note the use of color here....) I pulled out a very lovely white bottle with a beautifully designed label- excellent camouflage for an item that helps dispel unruly personal aromas!!!!! Come to think of it-- maybe even helpful in detoxifying the odors from the NEXT stall(s) over!!So... even before I skipped to the Loo, I sprayed one little test spray ("White Flowers and Citrus" scent)  into the air-- my fellow employees told me they could still smell it hours later. But now to the REAL test of this Toilet Spray's Prowess -- Once in the confines of the employee's rest room, I sprayed as directed and immediately had a sneezing fit -- Which, in thinking back on it-- was quite efficacious in assisting the job at hand.OK-- so I'm a bit allergic to it? Maybe in confined spaces only. As it was -- PooPourri REALLY masked any offensive odors that had the temerity to occupy the loo at the same time I did.I will try it at home. And if I still have the same reaction, there is always...the smoker across the hall, whose pervasive odors creep under my doorsill, and the cracks under the baseboards.GOOD JOB, POO-POURRI !!!!!

They work very well as long as I am not doing anything like trying to take apart a greasy bicycle chain -- THEN they run the risk of shredding. However, these are good gloves, lightweight and very service-able. They fit well and allow my fingers to be very dexterous -- while picking up small parts or working with thin objects. I can use a wrench without the gloves slipping-- they are tenacious enough to control and not reduce torque. Note-- these are not "sterile".

Right side up -- the little bumps are really annoying to step on with my bare feet.Yes it's well made, heavy duty,  looks nice, is a good size, washes and dries easily, but I had to turn it upside down in order to be able to step on it comfortably in my bare feet without feeling those annoying little bumps on the soles of my feet.So, I will continue to use it-- it performs its function well - but for me, upside down.

Well...... first the Pros. Nice color, sleek design, very handy USB charging port. Nice dimmable nite lite (or you can switch it off) big numbers, with varying degrees of brightness and sound (the alarms), battery backup.  I have no trouble with finding the Snooze button, as long as I am not in an irascible mood, which causes me to then hit the whole top of the alarm clock.Now, the Cons....This clock is TOP heavy. In order to keep from knocking this over with a loud SMACK every morning, I put double sided tape under it so it would stick to my night table  - that's the only way I can keep it from obeying The Laws of Gravity. Setting the alarm should be done in increments of hours and minutes, not just in many and multiple increments of minutes. I CAN live with this but only with some modifications at really should have been addressed when this design was being tested before production and distribution.

BLESS whoever invented this. Now I don't have to worry about someone turning up the heat on the apartment bldg's dryer ruining some of my clothe$, while my clothes are in it, just so my clothes can dry quicker ...!!!So it doesn't handle a boatload of clothes-- that doesn't matter to me. I can dry my laundry while I do other things and then.. dry some more later.

When I first took this doll out of its shipping box I thought the doll's box had been smashed in transit. Not so -- it is a skewed, almost triangular-but-square box-- which makes it hard for little hands to open and close should they want to put Lonnie back into her box (which has a pretty interior). The next problem was those wormy little barely-expandable elastic ties that securely held her very very securely in place. I almost cut her neck trying to remove them but once done she emerged, beautiful and radiant, in an attitude (if dolls can have attitudes) that almost says "Here I am and isn't this FUN!!?" . She is VERY fashionable -- and her long flowing HAIR is sliky and gorgeous!! Her face, her elegantly posed hands, her posable joints, all add to her top notch looks and appeal. The purse is hard to open and there is a little surprise inside that can easily get lost. Her dress is nicely made, with removable apron as well -- her accessories are tiny and if taken off, can get lost, and of course are way too small for little kids below the age of 5 (or 6) to safely play with.I would have liked it if the inner box had some little detents/storage cut-outs where her accessories and her purse can be placed after being played with. I would also have liked it if there was a QR code printed on the side or front of the box that would play a few frames from the Mulan film-- I doubt many of these little girls who now own this beautiful doll know much about Mulan at all. But this doll is definitely a Five Star beauty and the price is right as well.

The first thing I like about these gloves is that they do not stick together in one flat lump inside their box. Perhaps that is a trait that Nitrile has -- whatever, that is fine with me. They do not have powder inside (which makes my hands dry out) and that is GREAT, they slip on easily, they do not bunch up under hard (or easy) use and that is wonderful.They are reusable, they do not puncture or tear easily, and I can pick up gnarly ugly smooshy viscous smelly things with them and work with solvents (house-grade, I clean up stuff and am remodeling my apartment and work on my car) and still have a recognizable glove and untainted skin on my hands when I am thru. They ARE reusable so far, and they look way cool because they are black.Because they are compatible with many of the oils, solvents and grease that shade tree mechanics encounter, I now have these stowed in the car. They are sturdy enough to be reusable as well. After a while, the rubber "band" on the ends of the cuffs will come off in your hands but that is a trait of many types of thin gloves like these

Nexxus has been my favorite hair care brand for over 30 years. As their website claims -- you can Create Salon Gorgeous Hair With Nexxus Salon Hair Care Products." I consider the Nexxus brand, in its multitudinous variations,  to be the best mass marketed product for caring for my hair, and I trust the people behind Nexxus products to use quality ingredients for quality results. Yes - Nexxus New York Salon Care Shampoo, Emergencee Reconstructive System is pricey, but worth it. I wash my hair daily, and the only thing I would like to change is the shape of this bottle-- it is not easy to grab in the shower-- a bit slippery, and the top needs coaxing to open up -- so I just leave it open. But the results from this shampoo are evident and positive -- My ultra-fine hair shines, has body and looks great with minimal care, during the day. There is a conditioning product that pairs with this shampoo, but as I am on a budget, it will have to wait, unfortunately.

Although my skin is clear, there are always pollutants in the air and my skin is no stranger to what's in the air (especially humid summer air). When I have used facial masks in the past, they tended to dry, be stinky or irritating, so I stopped using them, However, I was surprised by the friendly ease-of-application and removal of AHAVA Time to Clear Purifying Mud Mask, and when I removed it after about 15 minutes, my skin looked clearer and it almost glowed.AHAVA Time to Clear Purifying Mud Mask is more expensive than your usual over the counter facial masks, but this is one serious product that is friendly to this user. I wouldn't use it more than twice a week, only because my skin is clear and has no problems.

This Charmin Ultra Strong Toilet Paper is plush, thick and soft.You use a lot less of it in comparison to the other brands of toilet paper-- even the 2 play ones.It IS A Mega roll, but I had no problem fitting it onto the archaic toilet paper roll that came with my old apartment.And.....It IS Ultra strong. Vigorous use does not cause any unforeseen surprises to be discovered later on down the line.

This is the first book of  the series that I have read. What a swashbuckling person this Jacky Faber is!!! I delighted in reading it, and in following not only her exploits but the machinations and actions of her acquaintances, her friends and "friends". There are some "suggestive" passages, but they fit in well with the whole story.The dialogue is rich, sometimes bawdy, sometimes very wry and funny. This book is one that could easily be read (over several hours) in one sitting. I would suggest a tankard of ale and a leg of mutton to add to the ambience.Spellbinding, dramatic and with a twist at the end, "Wild Rover" makes me definitely want to start from the very beginning, and read all the books in this series.

Pleasant taste, easy to grip bottle.  I have been using this for a week now. I like the taste, the childproof twist off cap, but I think the instructions on the back, although comprehensive (especially when it comes to supervising young children who use this product) should be in a slightly larger typeface for more visibility.Having just had my semi-annual dental checkup (no cavities) I will see how well I do after 6 months of using this product..

The happy beautiful Latina I see on Sesame Street had a very trying youth!!  This was so melancholic!! What horrible way for a precious little girl to grow up in such an abusive atmosphere! but Maria-- you persevered and reached the top-- however, I wish you could have let us know how you dealt with your demons, and how you became the person who just radiates beauty and happiness!! The book was very melancholic and, as a survivor or childhood abuse (in the Bronx too), I worked long and hard to get away from it, physically mentally and spiritually to get to where I am now -- I think a lot of readers would also want to read about our journey-- surely you did something-- it shows in your ebullient personality.OK I added a fifth star-- I happened to hear Sonia Manzano talking about her book on a PBS radio broadcast-- THAT was fascinating, and really filled in the gaps!!!

.... that draws the reader into the two characters, opens up the reader's  understanding of "Handicaps" and makes this reader understand that handicaps are NOT the whole person-- rather the ability to give and receive love, the ability to be introspective, TRUE to one's self, COMFORTABLE in one's skin,  and the ability to FOLLOW YOUR DREAMS and develop your personality, your place in life and a develop a stability that cannot be found by trying to explain yourself or become prey to the untruths spoken by the bullies around you -- THAT is the real sense and worth and identity of a person-- NOT their "handicap". Let the bullies Say What They Will-- we know better.

Well, I like to read ingredients especially when it comes to Cat Food. This is what We;;ness Divine Duo has:Natural, grain free wet cat food recipe• 3 delicious cat food flavor combination varieties, including Beef Pté & Diced Chicken Liver, Chicken Pâté & Diced Turkey and Chicken Pâté & Diced Duck• Wet cat food with two layers and textures: savory pâté topped with tender cuts in gravy• Wet cat food comes in convenient, clean plastic can with easy-peel lid• Healthy cat food with no wheat, grain, corn, soy or artificial flavors, colors or preservatives*** NO grain, no artificial flavors or colors or preservatives. *** Wellness ROCKS!!Cee Cee LOOOVES this and I am SO HAPPY!! I opened the first cup (please recycle the plastic) and was greeted by a smooooth Pate with chunks of meat and carrots in a juicy gravy. Now Cee Cee is a 14/15 YO kitty with some significant health problems, so getting her to eat is sometimes a chore ("Here kitteh! Have this? oh... well, have THIS!! uh oh...hmmmm...then....try this????") and I am so happy she LIKES this!!Knowing that chunks of cat food have sometimes been the bane of Cee Cee's after dinner adventures, I took the fork and squished the chinks and the carrots so they would go down and stay down when she ate them -- BUT the chunks are really soft and I probably should have just left them as they were.If this kitty gains weight from eating this tasty great smelling food, I will be OVERJOYED.

Yes this is a nice cotton blanket with a heavy feel to it and more warmth than I would expect from a cotton blanket. The weave is nice, it is generously sized BUT when I unfolded it from its reusable zippered plastic carrying case (with a nice handle), placed it on the bed and sleepily slid under the sheets, I turned to my cat (who was reclining sweetly on the other pillow) and said "Did you DO Something???!!!"No she hadn't-- it was the smell of the blanket. I had to wash and dry it before it smelled fresh enough to once again put on the bed.

When I first get a new dry cat food, I...taste test it. Why? SO I know what my cat is tasting -- although I'm sure her taste buds are better than mine. Anyway -- this Nutro High Protein Adult Food has a pleasant aroma and taste-- is crunchy without being a tooth-breaker. It has chicken -- it has pea protein and I swear I could taste the peas -- so I wondered- "will Cee Cee like this?"She dove into her dish and snarfed it down-- I was SO happy -- Cee Cee, being elderly and frail, has become VERY picky about her foodies, both canned and dry -- and has lost significant weight from shunning some of her food (the vet and I are on this - last exam was in late July) so seeing her eat this made BOTH of us happy.The actual list of ingredients appear to be natural, and well-thought-out -- the combo of Chicken and Salmon bring proteins and oils into the mix.  I will update this when the bag is down to half its contents. BTW the innovative zip-opening is very handy to use-- it is pourable-- but I just stick my hand in and grab enough to plop into her dish, then I zip up the bag (it takes a little getting used to but when zipped it's closed securely)
So I hope this one does too-- it plugs right in as a module with no problem. Let There Be Light.
But I will, and I like it -- since I LOOOVE Tuna this is highly palatable as far as I am concerned.
Has a lanyard loop AND a belt loop so you can decide how to wear it-- my glasses fit in it with no problem. There is even a liddle pocket in there for...whatever

These rough and tumble wipes are about the size of your usual shop "paper towel". They come in an industrial-type dispenser box of 125, and they feel rough and tough and do a good job cleaning up "stuff". Wet them and ball them up and add scouring powder or soap and they get at the dirt or spills, and usually can be used again at least once more time. I like the feel -- they feel tough and don't tear apart in your hands like many other lesser quality paper shop towels can.The boxing material is minimal, and can probably be recycled. I wonder if the towels need to be white-- not bleaching them would help in water conservation.

Engaging, deep, pleasantly readable -- even with the pain of bullying -- the book gives hope, in an allegorical description of an unusual friendship between three people, one of whom is a ghost. What I took from the book was the feeling that we can help to attack and solve and transcend the trials and tribulations of growing up "different" if we act with imagination, and hope and realize that not all friendships are perfect, but they are precious in their own right

Squid Ink. Blackened dinner pot. Scary diagnosis. Tenacity, hope, inventiveness, fear and fortitude. Friends who get over the initial shock "Why didn't you tell us?" and a Haiku endSeventeen year old Sora lives in an increasingly final world-- the walls and life slowly closing in on him-- a kid in love with sports until his legs start to fail him -- then given just a few years to live, with ALS. He sports a  fatalistic but optimistic air and continues to stay in touch with classmates, even though his world is now his home, his computer and his beloved grandparents. Living with his mother, in a humble apartment in Japan, treated with love and joy by his grandparents in the country, although worried about his slow descent into immobility, he is determined to stay connected with the outside world even as his disease progresses and his friends grow scarce. And  so he begins to live on line. He is Samurai Man ("Farm when it's sunny, read when it rains"). trying to keep a lid on his fears while continuing to reach out to friends, new and old, on line.I found the writing introspective, dark, humorous, hopeful -- a typical 17 yr old kid chatting with his friends and classmates on line. I found his new friends Mai and Kaito believable -- including their initial shock and reaction. I liked Mai's " you better not be some fat creepy dude. I'm giving my friend your address before I come". Humorous, true-to-life.And why not an instant friendship? Kaito and Mai have a "reaction" at first but think about it and reach out as friends to Sora, not as people who feel sorry for him. Do they understand what Sora is going through inside? It appears they do, a little.Meanwhile Sora, who "willed the universe to have rest me in my sleep" understands that he will soon become immobile--an active mind trapped in his body. He resolves to take care of that before it's too late, and his reaction to his last day with his unknowing mother is profound and moving.  Kaito and Mai are there for him. The "dreaming tree" that Mai creates is like the tree of Eden in reverse. A goodbye to suffering and a hello to Eden.And like any good book, a thousand questions, like the one thousand cranes, remain unanswered, as it should be.

This is fun, for a one-sided lazy day game of table tennis . First of all, it is very nice looking, sleek, with a see thru design.. Stick 4 AA's in it (their weight helps to ground the base) load it up with ping pong balls (4 yellow ones for $2.99 at my local super market) and wait for the first one. Pop! Out it comes! The iPong Mini Portable Solo Table Tennis Server...  serves at a regular speed, no smashing line drives, so the direction is predictable, and each hit is the final one for that particular ball, but it's fun. After using up all the balls (30, of which I only have about 16) you have to go pick them up unless you jerry-rig something that will collect them after you hit them). Sis and I used to play a mad game at the kitchen table, balls all over the place at dizzying speeds until Grandma had to yell at us so she could set the table. This Table Tennis server is one speed, one lob only. For the price, it's ok. For the fun factor it is also good.
I had some papers in it -- they cut a hole in the fabric-- I sewed it up and so far so good......

"A week and nothing happened?" Then I touched the big nasty callous under my little toe with my finger and realized it was coming off..... and come off it did! Now I can walk around without limping and without pain. Woo hoo!!!!
Nicely made, but WAY too big-- It was supposed to fit my car-- nu-uh -- too big. I returned it
But I never turn down a great date. This is good-- just not as sweet as I expected (could always add sugar I suppose). Goes well on toast

I realized I had this tatt on my bare shoulder (in all fairness the other shoulder was sporting a Black Widow Spider Tatt as well -- also temporary). It is TENACIOUS!! Lasts a good long time. Looks great and Fur-oh! Shuss!! as well. Until the day comes when I can afford the tattoo I want tattooed on my shoulder THIS is my mainstay.
Cool cap -- I like it and I am sure any skunk I encounter would be jealous.
Not as good as they were touted to be in the reviews. Not happy with them but I am sure I can use them for something else.

It's nicely made-- no sharp cheapo edges, and it does what it's supposed to. I clean it out with Carb cleaner every so often and it is good to go once again until it gets really gooped up. Then it's on to the recycling bin .......

This has been THE Bible for my Vega -- I have thumbed thru it so much that I had to order a second. Great index. The photos and drawings are excellent-- they show what you are working on and how to work on it (for the most part). I had also supplemented this with Chilton and other types of small manuals specifically written for the 1973 vega -- that is until some ....xxxxx........... broke my window and pulled them from their HIDING place....... Anyway THIS manual is extremely helpful.
Beautiful!! Endearing! Well-made!!  Tigeriffic!! Love it !!!

Taylors of Harrogate Yorkshire Tea comes packed in a sensible box covered with pleasantly bucolic illustrations -- and all the cute little tea bags are nicely arranged inside, like quiet little babies in a nursery.That being said, I almost feel like I am reviewing wine. The tea, once brewed and without sugar, has a dual taste - it tastes bold on the tongue but once on the palate mellows to an almost sweet aftertaste. Quite pleasant!! I believe it would nicely accommodate an addition of some cream as well, while retaining its pleasant taste.I will report back again, once I have tried it iced -- and hot with cream, but as it is hotter here right now (East Coast, USA, heat index of 100+)  than the English Countryside will ever get, I know the cream will wreak havoc on my innards -- so I will wait until later in the year to report on the addition of cream. Not to worry as I have MANY MANY little Taylors of Harrogate Yorkshire Teabags awaiting me in this fine little box.

The fact that this does NOT contain Sucralose or sugar makes me OVERJOYED!!! I can't tell you how many whey products I have had to pass up because of the "S" word in their list of ingredients!!!Jarrow-- you have NEVER let me down!!!!

Not enough orange flavor (my tastebuds' opinion), which can be remedied by adding some undiluted OJ to it. I don't do much BBQing so I used this on store bought BBQ'd chicken and it was ok -- but it just did not permeate the chicken as much as I would have liked.My next adventure with this will be to pour some over ice cream-- THAT should be an interesting adventure.And yes it is a bit too sweet for my liking.

This very good book is one continuous drill. If I'd had something like this when I was a math-challenged kid, I would have enjoyed doing the first several pages of problems (there IS an answer sheet), and after several pages I would have yelled, grabbed my baseball equipment and run out the room, leaving this very nice, comprehensive quite-thorough book behind to gather dust. Well, not really -- my sister, on the other hand,  would have picked it up and read it through and worked out all the problems, probably not even touching the answer pages.My sister would have aced this, as she turned out in later years to be a Calculus whiz and nothing mathematical daunted her.So this IS a good book-- learning it over the summer months is a great idea -- Mom Sylvia used to tutor us kids during the summer from K-12th grade. But alas, mom Sylvia was definitely not a math whiz. To this day we do not know where my sister got her genius from.

A bit oversized, but my recipes do fit in there with plenty of room. I like the design on the cover -- I like the transparent window where I can place my own title(s) -- I think it could have come with more sheet protectors for the price, but Avery is always producing new and innovative products and this one fits right in-- their website is chock full of ideas and templates. Good job!!

And delicious ice cream, witty sayings, great prose, excellent FUN colorful zingy illustrations, and a lot more fun!! Look closely -- you will see ice cream cones where you didn't think you'd find them. The prose and action move forward, the illustrations catch the eye and move the action in circles, or spirals, or forward. Fun Fun Fun!!! This kid is truly having LOTS of fun with ice cream -- and his grandfather is none the wiser. Doesn't matter-- I think both are having fun. I like the flavors depicted and I am impressed with the author's ice cream "research"!!

William Guarnere and Edward Heffron are better known as "Wild Bill" and "Babe" from the 101st Airborne Division's Easy Company.  We first met them in Steven Ambrose's Band of Brothers and then saw them portrayed in the movie of the same name.  This book tells their life stories, beginning in the neighborhoods of Philadelphia, coming together in the chaos of WWII Europe, and continuing together as close friends back home.These two friends offer perspective on some of the events in Band of Brothers, but most of the stories are uniquely theirs.  They include:- A girl chasing a departing troop train with suitcase in hand to catch up with her soldier--who she will never see again.- Two soldiers filling jerry cans with water for their thirsty platoon and noticing human brains in the stream and water.  There was no time to get water anywhere else.- How far soldiers were willing to go to get rid of an officer they believed would get them killed on the battlefield.- How American soldiers and officers fought and what they thought of their French and British allies.- The common procedure for accepting the surrender of members of the German Gestapo.These soldiers' stories have the same tone and repeat many of the same lessons about war that their fellow soldiers in Easy Company have shared.  Soldiers did their jobs in all weather, without proper equipment, support, or ammunition.  Often they fought out of loyalty and concern for the men around them as much as they did for their country.  And when one of their comrades-in-arms died it affected them deeply and forever after.This is a well-written memoir and is enhanced by the back-and-forth narrative between the two old soldiers.  Readers will forgive them for bragging a little when interviewed by their female coauthor.  It makes them seem young again and gives readers an unguarded glimpse of the boys they were when once they walked across Europe with their rifles in hand.

These thirteen science fiction stories by Kenneth Schneyer are about the law, the human heart and how the two are entwined.  The title is well chosen.  The stories are divided into three sections:  The Law, The Heart, and The Law & the Heart.The stories in The Law section didn't capture my interest.  The author is an attorney and writes from experience.  He obviously knows the law and has found a few odd corners to look around.  He also seems to think like a lawyer, in a structured and ordered way.  Some of these stories even take the form of legal documents, which describe by implication a state of affairs in the world.
