Have no doubt I'll get plenty of years out of it so long as I don't manage to drop it outright on the cement floor of our basement!  The price coupled with free shipping sealed the deal for me at the time.  Definitely recommend.

For whatever reason, I have found that this product is harder to find in stores by me lately.  The scented Hydrate version is still readily available, but I choose this one for a reason.  Two areas on my neck have been sensitive to shaving since I was a teenager.  Back then I was using a straightedge razor.  Now I use an electric razor.  I have found that using the latter helps reduce the potential for irritation.  One other safeguard for me has been using mild and/or unscented face wash.  I was using Nivea for Men sensitive face wash for a few years before it disappeared off the shelves by me.  Picked this up as a replacement when it came out and while it is not entirely unscented, it is mild, lathers well, rinses easily, and causes no irritation.  Have been using it for a good 8-10 months now and am very happy with it.

My wife and I first used Goof Off to remove labels from wine bottles that were being used as part of our centerpieces for our wedding.  It's particularly helpful at removing the glue that inevitably remains after the labels are worked off.  They ended up looking smudged and cloudy when some of that glue was left on there.  More recently I have used it to remove labels from beer bottles that I have been using for home brewing.  Soak the labels fully, let it sit for a few minutes and then work it off with steel wool or a coarse sponge.  It still takes some effort, but this did a way better job of working the labels off then hot water, soap and water, olive oil, etc.  Would definitely recommend it if you've got a stubborn label or glue that won't let up!

What I wanted was a well built, portable set to play Washers during the summer.  I accepted two things when placing the order - I was willing to pay more to have it show up on my front porch.  I was not interested in taking the time to try and build one myself.I have owned a set in the past and played heavily on one that a close friend built, so I had some points for comparison.  The simple truth is that you are tossing metal at wood and plastic.  While one set can be a bit more rugged than another, they are going to get chewed up with regular play and time.  The box will inevitably dent and splinter and the washers will get nicked.  That being said, this is what stood out about this particular set to me:Pros - The hooks that hold the boxes together when not in use are great.  A spring is used to keep the hooks from sliding out of place.  This in tandem with the rope handles make this set easy to pop in and out of a car trunk.- Indoor/outdoor carpet received was blue as pictured.  It's a nice touch, albeit largely cosmetic.- PVC for the "cups" is much preferred over coffee cans, etc.  These arrived well secured.- The game overall is well crafted.  It has taken the usual knocks this summer and is still in good shape in spite of it.Cons - While the washers have been coated to be zinc and gold in color, and this does serve its purpose, the coating (and/or the effect) is rather light.  I have used RiverCity powdercoated washers in the past and prefer a heavier and brighter coating to help distinguish between washers at a glance.- The base of the boxes have a thin layer of plywood screwed onto them as some reviewers have referenced.  As such, there is some puckering.  I usually end up tossing these down on grass anyway, so it hasn't effected play.Overall, it has met my needs and gives me a solid set to keep in the trunk of my car.  I have no reason to doubt that that I will be using this same set several summers from now.  Seller maintained good communication throughout the transaction and ensured that my item was received in time for a camping trip that I was planning for.

The Benebone MINI Peanut Butter flavor is now officially our corgi's 2nd favorite chew toy (bacon flavor wins out for her every time).  She is an aggressive chewer, so we try and keep a handful of different chew toys in rotation at any given time.  It is not dissimilar to a nylabone in terms of the consistency of the material or the effect that aggressive chewing has upon it.  This was one of the first Benebones she had in a few months, so she was more than excited when it hit the floor.  Over the span of several nonstop hours of committed chewing, she was able to do some damage.  What I have noted is that Benebones seems to be a bit less inclined to develop harsh corners or sharp edges than nylabones. Areas of wear are a bit more flaky and softer to the touch. There is always a concern about very small pieces begin eaten during the course of a good chew session (which is inevitable), but if she must, I'd rather they be smooth and pose less of a risk for her intestines and tummy. If I took away each chew toy that exhibited signs of "damage", she'd have no toys left. Even with close supervision, she inevitably eats rice sized pieces while she chews.  So far it has held up as well if not better than a nylabone and she always goes for a Benebone first when she has a choice!

The Benebone MINI bacon flavor is now officially our corgi's favorite chew toy.  She is an aggressive chewer, so we try and keep a handful of different chew toys in rotation at any given time.  It is not dissimilar to a nylabone in terms of the consistency of the material or the effect that aggressive chewing has upon it.  This was her first Benebone in a few months, so she was more than excited when it first hit the floor.  Over the span of several nonstop hours of committed chewing, she was able to do some damage.  What I have noted is that Benebones seems to be a bit less inclined to develop harsh corners or sharp edges than nylabones. Areas of wear are a bit more flaky and softer to the touch. There is always a concern about very small pieces begin eaten during the course of a good chew session (which is inevitable), but if she must, I'd rather they be smooth and pose less of a risk for her intestines and tummy. If I took away each chew toy that exhibited signs of "damage", she'd have no toys left. Even with close supervision, she inevitably eats rice sized pieces while she chews.  So far it has held up as well if not better than a nylabone and she always goes for these first when she has a choice!

This is both the lightest and thinnest long sleeve shirt that I have worn. Truthfully, you hardly feel like you're wearing a shirt at all. I opted to purchase it because I have been very happy with both of the Echo short sleeve t-shirts that I own and I wanted something similar for layering.  Great for cool summer nights, wooded hikes, and early fall.  It is quite breathable while offering some basic protection from the sun. It wicks water and sweat away, dries quickly, and is not particularly absorbent, all good things when the weather is unpredictable. It claims to assist with odor control, which I am willing to give it credit for.  I'm not generally a stinky person, but I did not reapply antiperspirant or shower during a recent weekend car camping trip and the shirt came out smelling way better than the rest of my clothes.  I grab it when I want to be ready in case it gets a little cool but don't feel like bringing along the heavy stuff.

We use this cable for our SUREswivel when we take our corgi to the park or on a car camping trip. For our needs, it has been perfect. Sometimes you just don't feel like passing a leash back and forth all weekend, but you want them to be able to enjoy the outdoors with you.  We also have the 15' cable, but tend to prefer the 10' for those times where we want her to be outside with us, but she needs a shorter line to limit her momentum and keep her out of trouble. She is 25 lbs. and we usually secure the cable to her harness. She is not the type to tug aggressively, but she does get excited when she sees other dogs, squirrels, etc.  She still makes a run sometimes instinctively when that happens, but the cable is secure and the shorter length minimizes the harsh jerk back response you can get when an excitable pup is getting familiar with being tethered.  We only use it occasionally, so rust and wear have not been an issue. Solid construction and secure. I trust it, but we are always with her when it is in use anyway so there is far less concern about a malfunction. Metal clips are sturdy (thus a bit heavy) but fine for a medium sized dog.

We use this cable for our SUREswivel when we take our corgi to the park or on a car camping trip.  Sometimes you just don't feel like passing a leash back and forth all weekend, but you want them to be able to enjoy the outdoors with you.  We also have the 10' cable and find that we alternate between the two depending on the circumstances.  For our needs, the 15' has worked very well.  It gives her room to explore while keeping her out of trouble.  She is 25 lbs. and we usually secure the cable to her harness.  She is not the type to tug aggressively, but she does get excited when she sees other dogs, squirrels, etc. She still makes a run sometimes instinctively when that happens, and the 15' cable inevitably allows her to gain more momentum  than the 10'.  The cables are not forgiving, so when this does happen and she hits the end of the line there can be a harsh jerk back once the laws of physics take over.  For that reason, we used the 15' more sparingly early on while she adjusted to being tethered with the 10'.  We only use it occasionally, so rust and wear have not been an issue.  Solid construction and secure.  I trust it, but we are always with her when it is in use anyway so there is far less concern about a malfunction.  Metal clips are sturdy (thus a bit heavy) but fine for a medium sized dog.

I wanted something simple, safe, and secure that could be used at our local park and while car camping.  Sometimes you don't want to be passing a leash back and forth all weekend, but you want your pup to be able to enjoy being outdoors with you.  For our needs, this has been perfect.  We have a 25 lbs. corgi and usually attach a 10' or 15' tether to her harness when needed.  This gives her some room to explore while keeping her out of trouble.  She's not the type to pull aggressively and there's only so much momentum you can gain with 10-15' of line to work with.  I have not had an issue with the included plastic stakes yet, and use a hammer to strike them in and remove them.  Anyone who has ever used plastic camping stakes before knows that you are always one stubborn rock or root away from a bent, cracked, or shattered stake.  Thankfully I have accumulated a variety of metal stakes from past tents and have them available should these eventually fail me.  Given the size and relative strength of our dog, we have found that using all 6 stakes is rarely necessary.  4 stakes in dry earth has sufficed.  The full impact of darting to greet a passing pup has loosened it slightly, but it has not come close to ever coming out of the ground. Not easy to pry up when they are hammered down all the way.  Have to carefully use the claw of the hammer to work up the base first, then the head of the stakes.  Swivel is smooth, consistent and helps limit tangling.  Very happy we opted to pick this up!

After several let downs, I just wanted a functional and dependable shaker.  No leaks, less rust, reliable pour.  At least for me, more visually appealing options have disappointed when it comes time to make drinks.  Look nice standing on top of the bar, but that's about it.  Not much to praise here as far as looks go.  Very tubular, brushed stainless steel, with a top and cap that are largely plastic.  More importantly though, the silicone seal offers a snug fit for the top, the cap is not difficult to hold in place while shaking, the capacity is appropriate, it pours smoothly, and traces of rust have been minimal.  Simple but effective shaker.

I'm not an ultralight backpacker, but I'm also not a huge fan of lugging around an overweight pack.  With things like this you just have to decide for yourself if a pillow is a priority.  For me, it is.  There are plenty of lighter options out there, but I don't know that you'll find a more versatile and comfortable one.  First, it has a built in stuff stack.  It folds into itself and closes securely with a drawstring.  It is notably more compact than my therm-a-rest pillow.  Second, it has a simple, quick, but reliable inflating system.  Push the nozzle to lock it in place.  Pull it out to inflate.  Air goes in and out easily as needed.  Inflate or deflate in a few seconds.  Make no mistake, an inch of memory foam only goes so far.  This is not a Tempur-Pedic by any means, but it is as close to it as you will get on the trail.  Lastly, it has elastic cords underneath that allow you to stuff clothes in for added leverage.  I haven't had to use it personally, but if you have broad shoulders and you're a side sleeper, you might find it useful.  The microsuede cover is removable and washable as well if needed.  Nemo generally makes pretty good gear.  This is no exception.

Such a simple tool, but worth every penny on the trail.  When I'm backpacking I bring a few "2 serving" Mountain House freeze dried meals.  In the past I've used plastic and titanium sporks as well as an Eat'N tool to dig my way to the bottom of a bag.  Doing so is a very careful dance.  You're usually tired and just really want your food, but you don't want said food all over your hands, your lap, the handle of the spork, your gear, or the ground.  The 2 serving bags just don't lend themselves well to a shorter scoop.  This was a simple but very worthwhile addition for me.  No trouble reaching the corners of the bag whatsoever and it was way easier to control (and avoid) a mess.  Can be attached to a carabiner on your pack through the base or tucked away in a tall side pocket.  Light weight and because it's titanium it cools quickly.  If you routinely use the tall bags, you'll thank yourself for leaving your spork at home.

This particular battery is not carried by my local market or pharmacy, so I was happy to see that it was readily available on Amazon.  I went for far too long using the key to enter my 2007 Honda Accord EX after my replacement battery died.  Not the end of the world, but when you're juggling groceries, a dog, camping gear, and life in general, it's nice to be able to lock and unlock your car before you get to it.  This battery was only available as an add on item, so it came with a larger order, and once I was able to get my hands on an eyeglass repair kit at CVS I was good to go with the installation.  These generally last a good long while in the keyless entry remotes, but I picked up a spare this time just in case.

When you're backpacking, light is good.  For that reason, I opted to pick up one of these shirts before a trip to the Green Mountain National Forest in VT.  I didn't change out of it for 3 days.  We covered 18 miles,the weather was kind, and afternoon temps were in the low 80's.  I found it very comfortable throughout that time.  It is both the lightest and thinnest shirt that I have worn.  Truthfully, you hardly feel like you're wearing a shirt at all.  It is also quite breathable while offering some basic protection from the sun.  It wicks water and sweat away, dries quickly, and is not particularly absorbent, all good things when the weather is unpredictable.  It claims to assist with odor control, which I am willing to give it credit for.  I'm not generally a stinky person, but I did not reapply antiperspirant or shower during the trip and the shirt came out smelling way better than the rest of my clothes.  I have since picked up a second of these as well as the Echo long sleeve duo tee.  This was definitely a good call for me for summer hikes!

Overall, I'm a big fan of this line of trail maps.  This particular one I could take or leave though.  Did the Bourn Pond-Stratton Pond loop this past weekend.  This map is good for general orientation, estimates, and trail head parking, but it lacks the detailed trail distances that many hikers would be seeking to help plan their routes.  While the area seems to be woefully documented for some reason, that information is available on older publications and I would have expected to find it on here.  I'm the type of person that wants one good reliable trail map on hand, not a combination of 2 or 3 to piece the necessary information together.

I was willing to pay a bit more to ensure that I was getting the same coffee filters that originally came with the coffee maker I have in my office.  I realize the cheaper knock offs would likely serve their purpose as well, but I can't help but be a little skeptical of unmarked and/or unpackaged 3rd party products.  They serve their purpose well in removing impurities and keeping the taste of the coffee consistent.  To help keep the cost down a bit I switch them out every other month rather than every month.

I have these pants in both the charcoal and the walnut, having picked them up for backpacking trips and hikes.  I would warn that the walnut is notably lighter than the image would have you believe.  I was hoping for a caramel color and got something much closer to a light khaki.They are lightweight, stretchy, and fall somewhere between a slim and standard fit.  They are reinforced in both the crotch and the knees and hold up well on the trail.  Pants are water resistant, quick drying but breathable.  My complaints are minor - the front pockets are a little shallow, the zipper pocket on the right leg is a little deeper than I would want, and the back wallet pocket has a stubby zipper that isn't always the easiest to pull open.  Definitely need a belt for these unless it's a snug fit because the belt loops are thick and the material is lightweight throughout.Overall, they are a very versatile pair of pants to wear on the trail.  They've got some give to them but they are very well constructed.  Fine to wear out casually as well for a laid back evening.

Had these in my pack for a recent multi-day backpacking trip to the Pharoah Wilderness Area near Schroon Lake, NY.  When you've gotta go, you've gotta go.  The top peels off and then sticks back on to help keep the wipes moist.  Advertised as composting down to dirt in 21 days.  Wipes are thin but strong, not unlike a face or hand wipe.  Amount of moisture is comparable as well.  Not lightweight for the ultra-light backpacker, but if you're willing to sacrifice some weight for a few creature comforts, you could certainly do worse than this.

I had the Nemo Espri 2p for a few years and opted to sell it to upgrade to the 2p LE.  Now that I have spent some time with both I actually prefer the older model.  Three primary differences stand out for me.  First, the older 2p utilized jake's feet.  A simple system in which the tent pole snapped securely into each corner.  It made for a quick and reliable set up and take down.  The LE uses a system similar to some MSR tents where the pole ends slide into a metal grommet.  The shape of the end of the pole coupled with the tension help hold it in place.  This serves its purpose, but they don't click out nearly as smoothly during breakdown as the jake's feet did.  I've had to fight with these a few times between the ground cloth, the tent, and the rainfly.  Second, the poles for the 2p were one criss-crossed unit that was secured with plastic clips along the length of the tent and at one point at the top.  It wasn't perfect, but I felt it was easy to set up and folded up tightly to put back in the pole bag.  The 2p LE includes 3 separate poles.  The two main poles slide in along mesh sleeves for the first third of the way before locking in place with plastic clips for the rest.  They're a bit more cumbersome and the curved ends don't always fold in right.  Lastly, there is a shorter pole that goes across the top of the door and secures between two grommets on the sides of the tent.  It's a very snug fit and just doesn't seem necessary as it was absent from the 2p.On the plus side, the tent itself feels a bit more substantial than the 2p and the optional trekking pole vestibule is a big improvement over the 2p version.  Like the 2p, the craftsmanship is solid and the seams, zippers, and stitching are legit.  Similarly, the floor of the tent and ground cloth are a bit thin and the door and vestibules are quick to catch in the zippers.Make no mistake, this is still a well crafted backpacking tent.  But I think it took a few steps back from the 2p in terms of ease of set up and break down which matters when it's raining or you're tired after a long day on the trail.  If you were jumping right into a Nemo tent for the first time, you'd likely be pleasantly surprised.  I just had really high expectations from the 2p and in some ways the 2p LE let me down.

I  purchased a Pacsafe for my honeymoon in Spain.  It is certainly not a guarantee against theft, but for me personally, it was worth the peace of mind that it brings.  It is best suited as a deterrent for opportunistic thieves.  We stayed in reputable hotels in Barcelona, Denia, and Valencia, but when it comes to passports, cash, and technology, I'd rather err on the side of caution.I secured it to immobile bathroom fixtures each time that we left for the day.  It accommodated 2 kindles with thick padded cases, 2 iphones, 2 passports, a camera, cash, and paperwork.  That left it full to the brim.  For our purposes, it was the perfect size.  I disagree on it being cumbersome for travel.  I had it in a 70L backpack with enough clothes, toiletries, and electronics for 11 days in Spain, and I did not even come close to going over any weight limits for my pack.It does arrive stiff, but the bag softens after a few days.  The locking mechanism takes a few tries to get used to and needs a little muscle in the beginning.  I would recommend practicing a few times before you put it to active use.  I never had an instance where the bag could be accessed from the top when it was locked and secured properly.The bag has mesh wire through the body with a cable neck closure, hard plastic catch, and small lock.  It is big enough to hold the necessary valuables, but small enough to tuck under a mattress, a piece of furniture, etc.  I personally secured it and kept it out in the open.  It's one thing to have some money or a piece of electronics disappear after your room has been cleaned, who can prove it anyway?  But it's quite another to have your portable safe cut open.At the end of the day, it probably wasn't needed during our honeymoon.  But I left each day confident that when I returned to my hotel in the evening, my valuables would be there right where I had left them.  Everything made it home safely, and I intend to use the Pacsafe for backpacking and camping trips in the future.  Definitely recommend!

I decided to pick up a stick after using Beyond Coastal's sunblock last summer.  I was very happy with their product overall, but I found that it inevitably worked its way into my eyes as I sweat.  Thankfully, the face stick provides the same reliable protection without the sting.  It's important to note that this probably isn't for everyone.  It has the consistency of lip balm or vaseline.  Because of that, It can feel thick and greasy on the face.  If you worry about clogging your pores, you might want to keep looking.  That being said, it provides consistent protection, it stays put, it has a pleasant lemon scent, it's very portable, and it won't leave your eyes stinging throughout the day.  For me it was a trade off.  Yes my face feels a little greasy when I'm by the lake or beach, but at least I'm not squinting and rubbing my eyes all day.  Product looks like a stick of deodorant but it's notably smaller than one at .5 oz.

I wanted lightweight, waterproof, and affordable (it was on sale when I bought it).  This jacket met those requirements and has exceeded my expectations.  I knew I wanted an all purpose jacket.  I work in NYC, and have a 15 minute walk each day from the train station.  I also enjoy camping, backpacking, kayaking, and hiking, so I wanted something I could wear to work, on the weekend, or when I'm on the trail.  I have only had positive experience with Outdoor Research products, so the Helium II ended up on my short list.  I ended up getting the Pewter one which has zippers that fall somewhere between electric green and highlighter yellow.Pros:- Incredibly lightweight.  You forget you're wearing it sometimes.- Water wicks right off of it.  Your upper torso will stay dry.- Zippers are seam sealed.- Hood is adjustable.- Feels like it has a bit of a slim fit to it, overall a sharp looking jacket. Less likely to bunch or ride up while wearing a pack because of that.- Fits true to size.  I'm 5'11 and 177 lbs.  I typically wear a medium and both sleeve and base length were good.- Small pocket above the chest is good for a phone or wallet when it's raining hard.- Quality materials.  It's thin and lightweight with the feel of something far more substantial.Con:- There are no hand pockets.  The chest pocket suffices to keep one or two small items safe, but the hand pockets were definitely missed.  The only thing keeping it from a 5th star for me.  Just easier to use, more convenient access, and it's nice to be able to tuck your hands away while you walk through the pouring rain in midtown.Overall I'm very happy with my choice.Update - 9/2/14 -  I have owned this jacket for over a year now.  I keep it stuffed in the top of my Gregory Z30 Backpack - Men's - Medium - Prussian Blue at all times so I have it on hand whenever the weather turns unexpectedly.  It has held up very well and continues to keep me dry.  Very happy with this lightweight shell!

First a disclaimer.  This particular trekking pole vestibule is getting harder to find.  This accessory is for the Nemo Espri 2p, and is not compatible with the similar Nemo Espril 2p LE.  I found that out the hard way and they are discontinued items at this point for Nemo.  That being said, it really is a must have item if you ever intend to have 2 people along with 2 packs in the tent.I have had 2 adult males in the tent several times with Therm-a-Rest air pads.  It's doable, but you'll find you're shoulder to shoulder or touching the edge of the tent.  At least for me, it left no room for two fully loaded packs.  When this vestibule is set up properly, there is room for both.  It utilizes a hiking pole as a central point of stability and then stakes down at two points in the front.  It also snaps onto the rainfly at two points.  What you get is an extended entryway with a separate zipper and velcro closure point.Pros:- Like the tent, it's very lightweight.  You won't notice the addition to your pack at all in terms of space or weight.- It's relatively simple to set up.- Helps keep packs, gear, and shoes dry.Cons:- Like the tent, the material is thin.  It's actually more thin than the rainfly and a slightly darker shade of green.  Like the rainfly, it has a tendency to catch in the zipper.  No holes to speak of yet, but it does take some additional care.- If the wind is whipping and it's raining hard, it's not always a fool proof cover for your packs and gear.  It was not made to go flush with the ground, so some rain can work its way in if it's changing direction and coming in at an angle.  Obviously for the same reason runoff can sometimes find its way to your stuff.  I usually keep my pack on its back with a rain cover on, keep it near the center of the vestibule, and trench lightly if I feel I need to.All in all, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this optional accessory if you have the Nemo Espri 2p.  It helps you get the most out of your tent and provides cover for the stuff that matters when you're out on the trail.  With some simple precautions you should wake up to a dry pack and boots in the morning.Included some images for a visual.

I was looking for a mid sized notebook to carry around with my Lamy Al-Star fountain pen.  I picked it up primarily for quick notes and passing thoughts.  I have had only positive experiences with Clairefontaine stationary, and this one is no different.  The 6" x 8.25" size has worked quite well for me.  It's large enough to offer adequate space while writing, but compact enough to toss easily in a bag on the go.The cover is a pale green color with the Clairefontaine name and logo raised inconspicuously on the corner.  The notebook is cloth bound with linen thread in a darker shade of green.  As it's not a spiral notebook or pad, it does gravitate naturally towards closing until the binding is worn in a bit.  The pages are white with 23 light purple lines on each.  I have been using J. Herbin Lie De The ink and it takes to the pages nicely.  Elastic band is attached to the back cover to keep it securely closed.  Overall, I am very happy with this notebook and will likely look for the same when I need my next one!

I spent a long weekend backpacking in the White Mountains of NH last summer with a cheap borrowed pack and 55 lbs. of gear.  Towards the tail end of the trip, the hip buckle snapped.  An already uncomfortable pack became much worse.  For the last few miles, my brother and I traded packs intermittently to help ease the load home.  He had an Osprey pack, and it was during those last few miles that I swore a high end pack was in my future.  The difference between the two was night and day.I put in a lot of time researching packs and finally settled upon the Gregory Baltoro when all was said and done.  It's definitely pricey, so it became a birthday gift request between my parents, wife, and brother.  This is an instance where you get what you pay for.  I have every intention of wearing this pack for many long rugged years to come.A lot can be said for this pack, but three simple points have impressed me most:- It helps carry your burden.  I had 60-65 lbs. of gear during my last trip to the Pharaoah Lakes Wilderness region in NY.  I did 17 miles in just over a day during the winter melt and was amazed how well it distributes the weight.  It's rare to be able to say your pack feels far lighter than it actually is.  I'm 5'11" and 178, so I was comfortably carrying roughly 1/3 of my body weight.- It moves with you.  The hip belt and frame are made to shift with your body.  Whether I was bending over to tighten the laces on my trail runners, reaching back to grab a water bottle, or stepping carefully from rock to rock over a brook, the pack works with me, not against me.- It's well constructed and durable.  Cheap buckles, weak stitching, inconsistent zippers, and faulty straps will all show themselves eventually.  No pack is invincible, but I have been very impressed with the craftsmanship across the board here.  It has given me no reason to believe it won't hold up to many years of abuse.  And if you do unexpectedly run into an issue, it has a lifetime warranty.This may well be the last pack you ever buy.  In my case, I would be very content with that.  It has everything I need and I am truly glad that I opted to go with this pack in the end.  Highly recommend it!

Had this map on hand for a backpacking trip around Pharaoh Lake and Pharaoh Mountain last weekend.  On-line forums, search engines, and web maps are great, but there is no substitute for a detailed and well developed trail map!  It helped considerably pinning down both parking options and trail heads.  It was also great for route planning and shelter options if we needed it.  We experienced high winds and heavy rain during our trip, so I can confirm that the map is indeed waterproof and tear resistant!  The map includes everything from lean tos to boat slips and everything in-between.And on a simple level, these maps serve as a good reminder of just how many trail options there are in the area.  Hope to hit up Tongue Mountain and some of the other trails around the Pharaoh Lake Wilderness we missed in the near future.  Trails do inevitably change a bit with time, but you can toss this in your glove box or pack and rest assured that you'll get a few good years out of it!  For the price, it's definitely worth it.

This has been a good choice for backpacking.  First and foremost, it is far more compact than my older thermarest.  I have not gone so far as to try a compression sack for it, but it certainly takes up a reasonable amount of pack space when it is secured with straps.I have been using it with a Nemo Equipment Espri Ultralight Backpacking Tent, so size and space were also an important consideration.  I went with a large, and as a 5'11" male I'm content with that decision.  The fact that it tapers off down towards the legs saves space and weight.It's comfortable as airpads go, and takes minimal effort to fill.  I find the material and density of this pad is far more agreeable than my older one in terms of folding and rolling it up as needed.  The instructions stress that it should be stored flat and at least partially inflated as often as possible.I can't speak too much on its relative warmth.  While it is supposed to help retain heat, that's a bit harder to gage.  It got down into the high 20's/low 30's when I used it last. There's only so much a sleeping bag and airpad can do.  I was cold at times, but I made it through the night.It's pricey, but if size, weight, and comfort are a factor, you won't do better than this one.

It has one or two shortcomings, but overall this tent comes highly recommended for backpacking trips.  I have used it through some very windy, rainy, and cold nights, so I feel I can give it a fair assessment.Pros:  - It's lightweight and compact, yet it stands sturdy and holds firmly when set up properly.  Compresses like a champ in a compression sack (less the poles and stakes).  - Zip off door and small vestibule offer some customization depending on your needs.  Additional items offered separately offer even more.  - Quick set up time.  The jake's feet and pole structure are great.  Not a big learning curve for using them at all.  Remember black poles go in the back and you're good to go.  - Holds up very well to both high wind and heavy rain.Cons:  - While certainly well constructed, the tent material is definitely thin.  The floor in particular and area around the zipper are the primary concern.  The separate footprint helps, but it has the same core issue.- Because the material is so thin, there has been a number of times where I have had to very carefully coax part of the rainfly back out of the zipper.  Not fun when it's pouring.  No holes to speak of, but it does call for some extra care.  - I have experienced a bit of condensation here and there, but that is the trade off for some ventilation in the rear of the tent.  It also depends which entry system you are using.  I opted to spring for the extras, so I also have the trekking pole vestibule, the pawprint, the foot print, and the gear loft.I have had 2 adult males in the tent twice.  One of those times included 2 therm-a-rest airpads.  It can be done, but the trekking pole vestibule is a must if 1-2 packs will also be on hand.  Certainly tight under those circumstances, so you're either touching the side of the tent or you're shoulder to shoulder.When all is said and done, I think it's a good option when weight, functionality, and flexibility are important.  I trust the tent, and while it isn't perfect, I know I can sleep soundly through whatever nature sends my way.  It's an even better backpacking tent for 2 people with the add ons, but as is, I think it's still a good value for 1 with the occasional 2 tossed in as needed.  Be mindful when buying accessories.  This is the Nemo Espri 2p, not to be confused with the more recent Nemo Espri 2p LE.  It has undergone some dimension changes over the last 3 years and I ended up finding that out the hard way.  The accessories are not interchangeable.  Also, note that that the tent has been discontinued by Nemo.  The trekking pole vestibule for the 2p is getting harder to find because of this.  Make sure you can get any accessories you might be considering before you decide to buy the tent.Included a few images for a visual.

This is my 5th Outdoor Research airpurge dry compression sack.  I have two 15L ones from their last line and two of the 10L.  I decided to go with the 2013 model because they offer a 20L.I have an old bulky Swiss Gear 20 degree sleeping bag that wouldn't fit into either the 10L or the 15L.  For that purpose, this size was a good choice.The changes from the previous model are pretty simple.  The bag is thinner and a bit lighter.  The straps and their buckles are a bit smaller.  The air permeable band towards the base is lime green instead of orange.I would say that the older bags feel a bit more substantial.  This really only comes into play when you are wrestling to fit a bulky item into the sack.  Now that the material is a bit thinner I do find myself taking a bit more precaution when doing so just in case.  Also, ratcheting down the straps usually takes a little extra tugging between the smaller buckles and thinner straps.  Those are really minor inconveniences in the grand scheme of things, but they set the bar high with their last model and I have them as a comparison point to work with.Overall, the positives remain consistent - these compression sacks are durable, easy to use, waterproof, and truly help you make the most of the space that you have to work with. When not in use, they fold up very compactly into themselves and zipper closed. They can always cinch down a little bit further than you think and it's nice knowing your gear will stay dry no matter what when you're out on the trail. Air can go out, but water doesn't come in. They are a little bit pricier than some other options, but they are definitely worth it!

I'm old enough to remember when TicTacs were introduced, as a neat new breath mint.  That's quite awhile ago now, so change was inevitable, but it seems fair to say that when your new flavor is cherry cola, you're marketing a straight up candy, not a breat product. [Does anyone worried about their breat really seek to have it smell like soda?]That said, these work surprisingly well in conveying that taste.  Not only did they get the Dr. Pepper/Cherry Coke/Mr. Pib flavor down, but there's an almost carbonated effect, kind of like pop rocks without the oral explosions.

We received both the single port and triple port chargers free for review.  Besides making long trips for Soccer and hockey, I need a car charger b ecause my phone is generally dead by the time work ends, but I still have to drive kids to sports practices, rehearsals, jobs, etc.These chargers work at roughly twice the speed of others we've tried.  I've been getting about 1% charge for every two minutes of driving.Even on a short drop-off ride around town that yields enough extra battery life to matter.

We received both the single port and triple port chargers free for review.  Besides making long trips for Soccer and hockey, I need a car charger b ecause my phone is generally dead by the time work ends, but I still have to drive kids to sports practices, rehearsals, jobs, etc.These chargers work at roughly twice the speed of others we've tried.  I've been getting about 1% charge for every two minutes of driving.Even on a short drop-off ride around town that yields enough extra battery life to matter.

There are a number of things that will make this your go to food transport system:(1) it's decent-sized.We have three kids involved in all kinds of sports, theater, etc.  You end up having to send a lot of food with them.  This will hold enough chili to feel you've done your part.(2) It keepsfood warm, at least long enough to get to your events.(3) it's rugged.(4) The seal means you won't be wiping up spills from the trunk

Somehow, I don't have an iPhone but every snot-nosed 13 year old in town does.  The boys test drove this case--which we received free for review.  They love the way it feels in the hand and for the iPhone 6, which doesn't seem to have the same battery life as the 6S?, it added enough power to get them through full days.  They also were impressed by how much easier it is to put on and off the phone than other models.

The Youngest likes to block out when he has hockey games and other events, so he loves these full year wall calendars, that let him see the whole season at a glance.  That said, the nearly $50 list price is insane for something that is, by definition, disposable.  Right now it's marked down closer to $20, which is more realistic.  But wait until December and you'll likely find it for $10.

The decision on these guys will be largely a function of price.  Anyone who uses and likes the regular duster--as we do--will find this a comparable product.  The 360 degree gimmick doesn't really add that much.  But I've seen these listed cheaper than the originals, in which case, buy them instead.

I found another alternative use for them.  I walk our dog 4 miles every afternoon and Winter is fast approaching in NH.  These are excellent gloves for breaking the wind and keeping you warm in non-freezing temps, while retaining considerable dexterity.

At the point where they even thought to make the index finger out of soft cloth so you can wipe your nose, you know they've gone all out.  I use them for walking the dog as Fall descends upon NH and they're warm, work with the phone and are reflective.

Fortunately, I got this watch free through Vine because I fear that for most of us it simply isn't wearable, which is too bad, because it's quite handsome.  But, as you can see from the photo, it's just gigantic.  It weighs over a pound and it's huge.If your Dad is a lumberjack or rugby player it may be appropriate.  Otherwise, it's just too much of a good thing.
The Oldest is a cross country skiier and such pants are a must.  He's a big kid--6'3" 230--and the XL fit him perfectly.  They're warm enough for a NH winter but flexible enough to wear racing.

True confessions : unitil we were offered a bracelet for review and I read up on it, I didn't realize these ubiquitous fellas were a convenient way of carrying cord in the wild.  I found the clasp a bit hard to work because the tools built into it make it stiff.  But the cord is easy enough to unravel--though that obviously ends its life as a bracelet.  And the whistle's a neat idea.

Got these [free for review] for The Daughter to use in her room.  The sheets are very thin and super sticky, so she had some issues with getting them arranged and mounted properly.  Nor do they clean up completely, We went with a large vinyl rolled sheet instead.

When The Wife and kids demand that you carry a phone, it sort of defeats the purpose if it runs out of juice after lunch every day.  We've test driven a bunch of these packs and this is the best one so far.  It's less bulky than many, has a helpful display with the remaining power available and turns on and off with a shake.I use it to recharge the phone in the afternoon at work.

We're headed to Iceland in the springand have been shpping for a couple good passport holders.  This one has all the good points of those we've tried, plus one feature I've really been looking for--a clear sleeve where you can display an ID.  You'd be surprised how hard that was to find.

These are designed to alleviate concerns about what's in the plastic we generally use in our water bottles, which has been freaking soccer moms out for years now.  They're certainly more stylish than your old nalgene bottle and the glass is as crystal clear and smooth as advertised.But they're very much for office use.  They hold considerably less fluid than the older bottles and let's be honest, you're not sending teen boys off to sports practices with glass bottles.

Goji berries have a good health reputation--and are at worst as good for you as other berries--we got these free from the vendor, so the price was right. The first thing to prepare yourself for is that while folks compare them to cranberries, these are not craisins--they are dried, dried. You can eat them from the bag, but they are crunchy, not chewy. And straight they have a distinct sour taste.For smoothies, I use a cup of orange juice, a cup of low fat plain yogurt, a frozen banana and a handful of gojis (to taste).  They add a distinct but enjoyable taste.

We're always looking for ways to, at least theoretically, make our near daily smoothies healthier and more guilt-free.  I got this hemp protein through the Vine program and added it to my peanut butter, banana and almond milk smoothie.  For that peanut butter cup effect, I also added some of the same company's cocoas nibs.  To the extent the hemp changed the flavor at all, it may have added an earthy/nutty tone.  But the overall taste was still great.

Just to reiterate the prior review :(1) No novice (like me) would ever be able to figure out this watch clasp.  Unfortunately, the box does not include instructions.  I had to watch this video:https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=2&v=fkiriX9ksOcBut you can search for deployment clasp buckle(2) The watch face is nothing like as clear as the image accompanying the product at Amazon.  It's quite dark.  I can't actually read the numbers--though we all know what they are by their position.(3) It is a heavy, very masculine, watch.All that said, it's very stylish in a steampunk kind of way and everyone who sees it will comment on it.I got mine for free through the Vine program.  If you're going to spend over $100 on yours, be aware of what you're getting.

This is our grass seed of choice, and after a rather dry Summer here in NH we have plenty of brown patches we'll have to repair in the Spring, so we leaped at this Vine offer. We've tried some cheaper alternatives but none have regrown our grass as well.  Whatever this WaterPlus stuff is, it has worked for us.

We live iphill from the Middle School.  The youngest likes riding to school instead of taking the bus.  Riding home?  Not so much...So with his propensity for leaving the bike at school, a good lock seems like a good idea.  He and his brother like these word locks, the cable is rugged, and, while we gout ours through Vine, the price is very attractive right now.

I do inventory in a retail store and we only have one bar code reader, so when the vendor offered this one I snagged it.It's as good as or better than the more expensive models we have at our registers.An inexpensive quality option.

This is one of those items the kids fought over.  First, the youngest asked why anyone would make a glass water bottle and when I explained how scared soccer moms are of BPAs he wanted it.But his big sister thought it was stylish and likes how the double wall prevents condensation, so she claimed it.We received ours free for review, buit would purchase it.

Two big points in their favor : (1) the varied colors make them eassy to distinguish in a family where everyone is always stealing your cord; (2) we're big fans of braided cords, which seem to have a better chance of not being frayed when you steal them back from the kids.

There's nothing more annoying about travel abroad than the fact other countries don't have a standard electric plug--and ours at that.  Forget the metric system; this is the real universal system we need.In the meantime, this is an excellent travel adapter for charging your devices, with a variety of extensible plugs, a standard US fitting and nightlight, and a travel pouch.We received ours free for review and will be taking it on all our trips.

It's foliage season here in the Upper Valley of NH and most of us natives enjoy it by getting out walking and hiking.  These fine poles from DOATS are perfect for the task.They extend easily and lock into place simply and firmly.  They have ski pole type grips and baskets, to prevent planting too far in soft soil.Once collapsed they fit in a nylon bag that comes with them and will store awaty compactly, making them good for travel.Right now they're $33 for a pair, which seems a very nice price.

I'm not a big wearer of jewelry, but thought the boys would like this one.  It's a tad too long for the 13 year old, but fits me and the 18 year old.  It's colorful and stylish, but still rugged looking and the purple tint is more subtle than you might fear.  It's pretty lightweight and smooth too.

For whatever reason, The Wife and kids are hell on cables. You can hardly find a charge cable around the house that they haven't tugged on until there's fraying and exposed wires. The boys have even managed to fray HDMI cables when they pull out the Roku to plug in their Xbox.I've become a believer--on admittedly sketchy evidence--that the braided cables are more durable and will withstand the family for longer.So when offered these cables for review we snapped them up. They're inexpensive (at least with the current discount) but there's no drop off in performance and the braided cable is eaxactly what I hoped for.The Wife particularly likes this color scheme for her car, where she and the kids have managed to wear out even the last woven cable we had....

For whatever reason, The Wife and kids are hell on cables.  You can hardly find a charge cable around the house that they haven't tugged on until there's fraying and exposed wires.  The boys have even managed to fray HDMI cables when they pull out the Roku to plug in their Xbox.I've become a believer--on admittedly sketchy evidence--that the braided cables are more durable and will withstand the family for longer.So when offered these cables for review we snapped them up.  They're inexpensive (at least with the current discount) but there's no drop off in performance and the braided cable is eaxactly what I hoped for.

The other night we were walking the dog and found a horse chestnut tree--incredibly rare these days.  The Wife didn't even recognize the nuts because of their outer pod.  So I cracked one open and showed her how the smooth nut inside virtually demands to be thrown at a brother or other neighborhood kid.It got me thinking about all the other natural stuff we used to play with and eat when we were growing up : honeysuckles; birch bark; grapes; raspberries; clover; ants and mulberries.Serrendipitously, I received an offer from Immortalitea that night to review a free bag of their sun-dried white mulberries.  While not the stuff of Proust, the fruit does carry me back and it's still delicious.  For those who've never tried them it will be a real treat.  Even dried they retain some of their juiciness and the taste can only be described as berry-sweet but somehow more floral.

Like, I suspect, most of you, we had a cheap printer that came packaged with the PC we bought.  It was an HP and while it did a nice enough job copying/printing, it frequently lost its wireless connection and the ink was pretty expensive.So, when Vine offered this odd seeming printer, it was worth it just to replace our old one.  Then I started reading reviews from professional publications and got quite excited.  Epson's theory here is that by using a different sort of ink delivery system, you can make one batch last up to two years, given normal use.  With three kids in school that would be awesome for us.In turn, they charge a premium price for the actual printer.We set ours up fairly easily.  I got it connected and it has maintained the connection.  The Oldest filled the ink wells, which is a bit messy and potentially very messy.  You'll probably want to wear gloves.The real test though is going to be how long that ink lasts, which is why I didn't go to 5 stars yet.  If it's still going strong into 2017 we'll be extraordinarily pleased with the item.

We went to Paris last year for a week, based solely on the concession  that we could also visit the D-Day Beaches and the Bayeux Tapestry.We did the latter on our own, but had a guide show us around the beaches.  An expensive proposition, but well worth it given our time limitations.If you have a few days to spend there though, this Lonely Planet guide is fantastic.  It will help you plot out discrete trips so that you can see everything.  It made us want to go back.

I'm one of those awkward sizes, probably a 39" waist.  And most of the size 40 belts I have are now on the last hole.  So we gave this belt a shot when it was offered free for review by the vendor.I got the size 40 but there are several holes to either side of the one I use and, whatever sort of leather this is, the belt is light enough not to pull your pants down with added weight.My one complaint is that the belt is so wide not all your pants will have big enough belt loops to accomodate it.  Be warned.

I honestly had to watch a Youtube video to even figure out how to put this case on the phone, but now that it's on I'm quite satisfied.  It has a relatively slim profile; the controls are not impeded by the case; and it seems protective enough.

There's a very fine piece of reporting hidden within the fake moral/legal quandries that frame this book.The analysis in Mr. Shane's book is even sillier though.  To his detriment, he's a terrific journalist.  So he gives a detailed account of how Awlaki came to make war on his own country, on behalf of al Qaeda, which group Awlaki himself acknowledged the US was at war with. But then Mr. Shane wrings his hands over the legality of killing Awlaki, because he was an American citizen.  Instead, he suggests that the jihadi was entitled to due process.Can't you just see General Meade bellowing down the hill to George Pickett to stop his charge and surrender so that he and his men could face trial?  And that, of course, was on American soil. Not in some corner of the world that lacked any sovereign power for us to deal with.Meanwhile, there's a tremendously amusing theme in the book as the author wonders how President Obama can have gone from a candidate willing to criticize George W. Bush's brusque prosection of the WoT, including even torture, to a commander-in-chief willing to order the remote-controlled murders of Salafist jihadis, despite the lack of courtroom trials.  The answer is that Mr. Obama is actually responsible for national security now, not grandstanding for liberal activists and fellow legal professors.  Responsibility is a tough taskmaster.

The eldest is headed off to college, so it seemed worth getting this iron for review and sending him off with our ancient one.The really attractive feature here is the auto shut-off.  The Wife and Daughter aren't big fans of fire and fret about stuff like an iron burning the house down.As others have mentioned, some of the design stuff is sketchy, particularly the visibility of the water in the well.As it stands, we'll send the boy off with this one, so he doesn't set the dorm on fire, and keep our older better designed model.
These shorts are well made and good looking, but the 13 year old isn't enchanted by them.  He's a genuine 30 but found the fit loose and somewhat uncomfortable as a result.

The two youngest love penguins, so we got this piece for The Daughter via Vine.  At least in the opinion of a 16 year old girl, it's the cutest thing you'll ever see.  She loves it.  And it's currently at a price point appropriate to a young girl.

One of the most famous movie MacGuffins of all time is the glowing object in the briefcase in Pulp Fiction.  Speculation about the contents ranges from gold to uranium to Marsellus's soul.Our family thinks it must have contained this Skittles and Starburst variety pack.If you're a fan of these candies, this cornucopia is thrilling.  We're fighting over who gets the Sour Skittles.That said, the price point isn't terribly attractive.  I can get the same amount of candy for 2/3rds the price at the local dollar store, if not necessarily all the flavors.

We're not exactly world travellers, but we do get abroad a bit now that we're older.  Still, we remain pretty cautious.  We do extensive research and try to travel safely.  To that end, when we go to Europe we try to minimize the likelihoof of being pick-pocketed.So The Wife really appreciates that this wallet is lightweight and slim enough to wear comfortably under clothing and that it has RFID protection.I'd still like to find one that has a transparent pocket where you could put your ID card.
The lack of inuitive controls make this one difficult to use, even for a technologically profficient and persistent son.

After several years of disagreement over how awful our last toaster oven was, The Wife did some reasearch and bought this one. Lifehacker recently rated them the best line going.  We all agree.  It's the best we've ever owned.
Parks & Rec is on pretty much a continuous loop in our living room and the Daughter bought this as a gift for her Mom.  They love it.  I don't get it.
The kids use these for circus camp, because they need flats for wire work in particular.  The Daughter is on her third or fourth pair over the years and swears by them.

You can't ask more from a puzzle/game than that your 13 year old son snatch it out of your habnd and work it til it's done.  The finished product is quite cute and has been a conversation piece for visitors.
Bought this for a survival bag to keep in the car.  Nice simple mobile device.  Fact the shaft is a fairly pliable plastic leaves me worried about its longevity/durability.
The 13 year old has been using it.  Likes the extensibility.  Lost a star because it doesn't collapse and extend smoothly enough.
Greatest sneakers ever.  The 13 year old intends to wear them until they rot off his feet.  Used them at circus camp for his wire act.
Not helpful.  Feed did not show up.

I'd been using this in the morning to tame an unruly beard and been pleased.  But Lifehacker ran a story this week featuring another use for coconut oil--as a treatment for cracked heals.  You just rub some in at night, put on a pair of socks (to protect the sheets) and let it do its stuff.The mutliple uses make it worthwhile, especially at the current markdown price.

With a head like a cinderblock, my primary criterion for exercise headphones is that they actually stay in my ears.  The design of these headphones accomplishes the task better than any I've ever used.  The frame is flexible but firm and keeps the ear plugs stationed comfortably even on a 4 mile walk.

We haven't had a chance to try ours on hot sand yet, which is our only caveat.  The blanket is light and packs up small.  The material is a durable seeming nylon.  And there are pockets in the corners that you can weight (with sand if you're at the beach) to prevent it blowing around.  It's getting a workout on the lawn and as the youngest's "summer blanket".

The Wife test drove this one on our dogwalk, after some initial skepticism about women's wear from Dickies.  She liked the color and found the fabric quality and performance a match for brands like Under Armour.  Her one complaint was the cut.  She's a classic medium, consistent across all brands, but this shirt was a bit large and not cinched in at the waist as much as one would expect.

We're a Bounty and Dawn family, so these are a natural.  The Wife is impressed by their functionality, but is going to make the supreme sacrifice and send our samples to college with the eldest, where the combo will be ideal.

Our youngest is a hockey player and we swear by Shock Doctor. He is getting braces this month and we're trying to find a good mouth guard for him.  Like all their products, this one has a nice feel in the mouth, but he's made it clear that under no circumstances will he wear a device that looks like a binky.  Ah well....

I think I tried the Axe first when it was in the clearance bin at Shaw's, but it got my teenage boys hooked.  They won't use any other brand now.I tend to use dollar store knock off brands.  But even I have to concede that the Axe does stay noticably fresher smelling for longer.

One of my buddies has boat and a condo where you aren't allowed to have a bbq grill on the balcony.  So I got this for him and after test-driving it this weekend he's ecstatic.  The grill has a small footprint and contains heat well enough he can use it on the boat.  It's portable and cleans up easily.  Just be aware, you have to buy the propane for it.

Everywhere you turn these days in the entertainment world there are monsters.  So perhaps it isn't surprising that this novel features literal wolves, and werewolves.  But I'm not entirely sure why.The bulk of the story concerns one of the world's richest but least public families and the manner in which they accumulated their fortune.  And that story is terrific and very well told.  The fortune is based in media acquisitions and affords the author the opportunity to riff on the history of the information age specifically and on capitalism generally.But, as it happens, the men of the family are werewolves and have to be locked away for three days every month.  Now it seems like that must be a metaphor for something, but I didn't get it.A simpler story would have made for an even better book.  Perhaps the monster angle was just the hook you need to get published these days.  Which would be sad.

Like most folks, we had a servicable enough old crock pot, but this item seemed interesting, so we got it through Vine.  We made  pulled pork in it first and were very pleased with not just the performance but with how easily the non-stick pan cleaned up.But, next, we roasted a chicken in it and that was the real clincher.  First of all, the heat signature is low enough that we could do a roast on a warm July day.  Second of all, even after considerable fat cooked out of the bird and sizzled away in the pan for awhile, it once again cleaned up easily.A fabulous appliance.

Decided to try putting together a survival kit to keep in the car after seeing them featured on Lifehacker.  This pouch ($12.56 today) was only 2/3rds the cost of the Maxpedition.It seems durable enough and zips easily.  It could use a few more pouches inside but holds a flashlight, pen, multi-tool, notebook, etc..And it is so compact it fits in the glovebox of the car.

I got this to put in a survival bag and it is compact and functional.  Haven't had to test it in extreme conditions yet, and presumably never will, but experts recommend it.  Now the trick is to prevent "borrowing"

I'm still having trouble even figuring out the controls for this player and the included instructions are so minimalist as to be little use.  It does produce some decent sound when you're playing MP3s, but good luck navigating them...

We receive a fair number of products for review and getting the family to test them out can require a fair amount of coaxing. But the youngest opened this package, took out the puzzle and had it done in a half hour.  He enjoyed the challenge and it looks great.

We play ultimate after work a couple times a week and The Boy wanted to practice with a "regulation" disc.  This one was reasonably priced, nicely weighted and has been more durable than the Wham-o he broke two of...

One of my buddies at work owns a motorcycle, snowmobile, boat, two cars and a Suburban, so I got this for review from the vendor and let an expert test it out.  He loves the thing.The fabric is lightweight but durable and we've had enough rain lately to give it a good try out.The feature he particularly loves though is the ease with which it goes on and off, thanks to a clever mounting system where you attack one end in your trunk and that holds it fast while you pull the rest over the car to the hood.  He says it's the easiest car cover to use that he's ever owned.

As mentioned elsewhere, we've always fed our dog Canidae all life stages.  I even give him bits as his "treats." And I'm personally skeptical that dogs care all that much what you feed them as long as they get fed.But this dog food was available on Vine and looked good, so we got a bag.  Now I have to confess : he really does devour this stuff with unusual speed. If paws had them, he'd give it two thumbs up.

we received a sample from the vendor for review and I really like it.  I add it to my peanut butter smoothie (Almond milk, frozen banana, peanut butter [or peanut butter powder from BJs], and some of this.) It's chocolately without being cloyingly sweet.

This is a nice, light, sturdy passport holder with space for other items, but with one drawback.  There's no see-through holder for your ID, not a flap to tuck the passport into so that you can just flip it open.  You'll have to remove ID to present it.

This item was a huge disappointment.  Even the blades and the loop at the top are made of plastic, the light didn't work and the firestarter is a second piece.  Is a tool all in one if it has two pieces?

There's so much to like anout this phone, but then one deal killer : it's not Verizon compatible.A couple years ago I switched to a Samsung droid phone because I wanted a bigger screen, better camera and the better Google integration you get with the OS.Unfortunately, my Galaxy 3 actually has a worse it camera--it was only subsequent iterations that offered a huge upgrade.  But I'm not eligible for a new phone until December.So when we were offered this review unit it seemed worth checking out.It has an even bigger screen.  The camera is terrific.  It comes with a silicone case. It unlocked.  It's very lightweight. The upsides go on and on...But we live in central NH and if you don't have Verizon you get sych spotty phone service it's alarming. BLU uses only GSM Networks, which do not include Verizon.For now, we're using it like a tablet and the youngest can make calls using Facebook, which is good enough for his purposes.  When school starts again in the Fall we'll see about adding a line to it via Tracfone.  In the meantime, it's a great product we're disappointed by.

20th Century Fox's big-budget bid to reboot their second most valuable Marvel-based property has come out under a foreboding cloud, one much more menacing than a certain antagonistic cloud from the third act of the largely forgotten Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer.  Perhaps prompted in part by stories of on-set conflict and drama, including director Josh Trank's (Chronicle) subsequent firing from an upcoming Star Wars project, critics have torn this film to shreds without mercy or pause.  For around an hour and 10 minutes, I disagreed and enjoyed myself.  Miles Teller, Michael B. Jordan, Kate Mara, and Jamie Bell inhabit their iconic roles with aplomb.  The tone is serious and even contemplative at certain points, and there are neat, unexpected moments of almost body horror (in one scene right after the four are transformed, Reed believes he has freed his leg from beneath debris, but then realizes it has simply stretched as he crawled away).  Qualms?  Sure—it could use a memorable action sequence or two early on, a few character and storytelling arcs are overly compressed by a one-year-later title card, and they should have shot the Planet Zero scenes in a real desert versus on a green-screen-clad sound-stage—but the film held my attention and even drew me into its characters and their dynamic.However, in the final 30 minutes, Fantastic Four crashes and burns.  Its fall is cleanly and clearly signaled by the reintroduction of Victor von Doom (a previously compelling, brooding Toby Kebbell), now mummified, blandly set on world destruction, and sans the "Victor von."  The film bumbles and fumbles and stumbles to an anticlimax, laying on inauthentic eleventh-hour fan service ("It's clobbering time!" is so unearned here) and completely failing to generate any tension even as we are told the earth is in peril, etc., etc., yawn.  It is almost fascinating how rapidly any character, depth, momentum, and wit completely vanishes during the rushed third act, and it will be interesting to one day learn who is most to blame:  reportedly misbehaved/opinionated hotshot director Trank, a boardroom full of nervously avaricious Fox executives, or another culprit.

I am not a member of youth-oriented novelist John Green's expansive readership, but I found last year's The Fault in Our Stars to be a very pleasant surprise:  at once a bit hip and very earnest, it features charismatic, well-matched stars and earns its heart-wrenching sentimentality.  Paper Towns, this year's Green adaptation by the same production company, is sadly inferior in almost every way.  The story focuses on Quentin (Nat Wolff), a high-school senior who has long nursed a deep, unrequited love for his popular neighbor Margo (Cara Delevingne), whose moving in he describes as a miracle in an opening voice-over preamble.  When Margo vanishes on the eve of prom and graduation, Quentin begins a type of investigation, desperate to interpret what she left behind in order to discern her location.  The search culminates in a road trip with his best friends, Ben and Radar (Austin Abrams and Justice Smith), as well as a concerned friend of hers, Lacey (Halston Sage).As a film, Paper Towns has one undeniable quality, and it is a potent one:  Wolff is a gifted, welcoming lead with an open face, spot-on comic timing, and an ability to convey neuroses while remaining entirely grounded.  He also generates a nice sense of camaraderie with Abrams and Smith.  Their friendship, the sense of conversational shorthand bred by intimacy and trust, rings true in an otherwise rather false picture.  Supermodel Delevingne is fine, if a bit rigid, but Margo is a disaster of a character:  cruel, indulgent, navel-gazing, overly precocious, and very far from endearing.  The major set piece of the first act (Margo and a nervous Quentin go on a destructive spree, complete with spray paint and dead fish, to punish a cheater who has wronged her) is intended as an empowering and poignant feat of playful disobedience, but it simply grated on me.  "Just go home, you over-privileged imps," I thought.  Even when she is not in a scene, the film is constructed upon Margo, her aura of "cool," and her bland declarations of angst ("paper towns for a paper girl"), and her mediocrity betrays it at several turns.  This dynamic might have proven rewarding in the end if the film were more cynical (or even just a tad forcible) in its investigation of the dream-girl archetype and the way it can warp perceptions, but it never goes anywhere particularly interesting, let alone insightful, on this level.  It is too cute, too soft, too ready to slip into a slow-motion montage set to a contemporary pop song at the drop of a dime.  Genuine moments of anger or longing or misery never enter into the equation.  Every low-key (read:  dull) tension is easily soothed with one-line wisps of pop-psychology wisdom.  A paper movie set in paper towns populated by paper teens.

In Southpaw, a highly committed and intense lead performance cannot compensate for an uneven, at times even risible screenplay and a general air of the old hat.  A boxing drama so archetypal as to be almost primordial, the story turns on Billy Hope (Jake Gyllenhaal), a light-heavyweight champion whose career and lavish lifestyle evaporate in the aftermath of a violent tragedy involving his wife, played briefly by Rachel McAdams.  Impoverished, separated from his daughter (Oona Laurence), and raging against the world, he focuses anew and trains harder than ever to regain his former status.Every element in Southpaw is ultra-recognizable.  There is the athlete on top of the world who does not respect and control his craft, subsequently falls from grace, and then rises from the ashes, enlightened and enriched.  There is the frequent contrasting of the promoter (Curtis "50 Cent" Jackson), avaricious and flashy, with the hard-nosed, soulful trainer (an excellent Forest Whitaker).  There is even an over-the-top antagonist our hero must fight by the end to complete his arc of redemption with a dash of...healing vengeance?  Yes, the wheel is never threatened with reinvention here.  Yet if the performances connect and the writing has integrity and spirit, old-fashioned ingredients such as these can still result in electrifying cinema (as evidenced recently by The Fighter and Warrior).Here, the acting is of a high quality—the star's chiseled physique has already awed the media, and his depiction of his character's slow transcendence of inward fury and self-loathing is poignant, if predictable—but the writing is often excruciating.  Note the way explanatory information is crudely shoehorned in via commentator voice-over.  For instance, the audience is told more than once how Hope hails from a Hell's Kitchen orphanage (surely located on the corner of Rags Avenue and Riches Boulevard), and the serendipitous fact his surname is a synonym for aspirational belief sadly does not go unexploited.  In general, Southpaw is plagued by a confusion of purpose, playing as a revenge melodrama trying to be a profound character study; the pulp pleasure of one pursuit is sanded down without achieving the level of authenticity and depth required to satisfy as the other.  In the moment, yes, it entertains and holds one's attention (the fights are exciting and well-shot, if a tad too tidily organized into round-by-round montages), and Gyllenhaal is undoubtedly striking, but the stale core, the sense of a film halfheartedly assembled with mercenary clichés, is a constant distraction.

Though already on the popular-culture radar as a gifted, at times divisive comic and writer due to her series on Comedy Central, Amy Schumer boldly establishes herself as a true-blue film star in the risqué, yet heartfelt Trainwreck, directed by Judd Apatow, the godfather of the mainstream American comedy in the 21st century.  She plays another Amy, a hard-living, fidelity-averse journalist who is unsure how to react when she develops a genuine romantic interest in an interview subject, an orthopedic surgeon for celebrity athletes (Bill Hader, sweet and subdued).  This is instantly recognizable as an Apatow film.  I say this as a compliment and as a modest criticism:  it runs long, pursuing a few characters and subplots past their natural expiration date, and much of third act functions as a halfhearted soap-opera paean to redemption via domesticity, a crowd-pleasing, if rather square and predictable pet theme of Apatow's.  Other stretches of the film are supercharged with uproarious improvisational flair, however, and Schumer is awarded ample time to create a dynamic, flawed, sexy, and vital heroine, a three-dimensional character both driven and haunted by the depth of her desire and exuberant enjoyment of life.

Last year, the Marvel-Disney union scored a gargantuan hit with Guardians of the Galaxy, a bright and zany space opera set in a distant corner of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, the shared space dominated by such flagship heroes as Captain America and Iron Man.  In general, Ant-Man has a similar spirit:  the story of a thief with a heart of gold (Paul Rudd) and his discovery of a suit which can transform a man into an insect-sized soldier, it is a type of outlandish Marvel side note.  And it is an entertaining film, escapist by nature and light as a feather at its best, though it falls short of Guardians of the Galaxy for a few reasons.  The references to the central storyline of the overarching franchise, including a shoehorned-in fight with a second-string Avenger, are more strained; there is a certain cut-rate-serialized-television quality to every scene mentioning S.H.I.E.L.D. or Hydra.  And while Rudd is a charismatic presence, lacing the heartfelt heroism with moments of deadpan humor, he cannot top the magic of the Guardians' combined chemistry even with the help of a game Michael Douglas (exuding cool authority as a curmudgeon slash mentor), a fetching Evangeline Lilly, and a few others.On the plus side, no prior Marvel film's action-and-suspense set pieces have amused, fascinated, and riveted me as much as the ant-scale chases and fights here.  I simply never grew tired of the neat and wondrous spectacle of an ultra-minute Rudd riding atop a winged ant, clinging to a speeding toy train, etc.  And while his antagonistic character is nothing special—a chip-on-his-shoulder corporate fiend who scowls and blandly gestures toward his evil master-plan while awaiting an inevitable third-act vanquishing—Corey Stoll's Darren Cross has the most chic and menacing costume of any cinematic-universe heavy to date, and this instantly renders him more memorable than such dullards as Thor: The Dark World's Malekith or the Winter Soldier.

I strongly suspect Self/less will be criticized more for what it is not than what it is.As the film begins, icy real-estate magnate Damian (Ben Kingsley) is diagnosed with cancer and facing the end of his life, beset by fear and regret.  Out of desperation, he agrees to a highly expensive and unlawful medical procedure developed by an enigmatic scientist (Matthew Goode, exuding very British malevolence).  The treatment involves the transfer of his mind into a youthful and reportedly laboratory-grown new body (Ryan Reynolds).  At first, Damian enjoys his extended lease on life and renewed vigor, but disorienting, opaque memories he cannot identify lead him to investigate the true origin of his new form.To be honest, this film does not cover much ground as a piece of cerebral and/or psychedelic speculative fiction, a fact which may dispirit viewers since it is by Tarsem Singh, a music-video veteran and the director of such stylish cult favorites as The Cell and The Fall.  The first-act cognitive switch is utilized as a plot-inciting device, à la the wrong-man dubiety in North by Northwest or amnesia in The Bourne Identity, rather than an invitation to travel inside the human mind and explore its contradictory, ever-shifting complexity.  And though both are in fine form, Kingsley (featured only briefly) and Reynolds do almost nothing to emulate one another, not even in the early scenes in which Damian undergoes physical therapy to become comfortable inside his just-purchased figure.  No trace of the elder English actor's fierce, guarded, stern turn can be found in Reynolds' instantly more charismatic and relaxed performance.However, its shortcomings as science fiction notwithstanding, Self/less is a very well-executed action film.  A certain one-man-against-a-deadly-conspiracy tension builds at a steady and involving pace, and twists and turns are well-placed throughout.  The plentiful sequences of chasing and fighting are staged with spacial clarity and laced with a modest-but-still-recognizable amount of Singh's characteristic visual whimsy.  One key scene, for instance, unfolds in an out-of-the-way industrial field of discarded, decaying Mardi Gras floats and props.  There is also a grounded and low-key charm to the film's set pieces, perhaps because it is a comparatively inexpensive studio release, particularly at this time of year.  It entirely eschews ultra-over-the-top, physics-defying computer-generated wizardry.So, Self/less may bend one's mind only slightly, but it does raise the pulse and warmly satisfy as an escapist summertime jaunt.

An intimate, smartly constructed, and, of course, ultimately very sad documentary charting the meteoric rise and drug-and-alcohol-fueled fall of Amy Winehouse, the late British soul singer who electrified the popular imagination, particularly from 2006 to 2008.
