There's not enough money in her bank account that she can just up and quit because her moral compass says it's best.Michael Devereaux has a deep love and protectiveness for his family and will do whatever it takes to keep everyone safe...even risking his own life to help the FBI. Bringing down a secret fraudulent financial organization that seems to create one ponzi scheme after another is his mission. Unfortunately, there is only one person with the elite computer knowledge who can help Michael convince this organization to let him and his company invest, Lori Briggs.What is completely unexpected is the the fire that's lit in the bellies of these two as they work together to accomplish a greater good.I absolutely love this book and it is now my favorite of the series. There was just something about these two characters that appealed to me in a deep sense. I highly recommend this book for your reading pleasure. Even though it can be read as a stand-alone, it is advisable IMO, to start at the beginning. Each book sets up the characters for the next. Thank you Mallory for another great read. I don't want this series to end...ever!

****4.5 Star Rating****In this story we have our hunky hero, rancher T. J. Malloy, his very seldom seen next door neighbor, Heather Wilson, and her two-year-old son. T.J. has been feuding with his neighbor for months because her stallion continues to escape and impregnate his mares.This books comes from a great series, 'Montana Mavericks: Rust Creek Cowboys, about six foster brothers who ended up at Last Chance Ranch instead of juvie or jail. They were mentored by the owner, Hank. and he helped these six troubled teens grow into good men. Each book tells one brother's story and they are all very good reads.Rust Creek Falls has been receiving a lot of rain and it just won't quit. The town is now flooded and it only worsens. T.J. heads for his ranch and when he is about to turn off onto his drive he notices a car further down the way and clearly sees it's in trouble. He drives down the road and when he arrives at the other vehicle he ends up rescuing his neighbor and her baby from a quickly sinking car. They are both drawn to each other but they are stubborn individuals. It is interesting watching these two grow a little closer then retreat. Advance and retreat several times. A very good story that I will re-read in a few months.

In 'Trusting The Boss' we meet Billionaire heiress Emma Devereaux who lives in her family's Georgia mansion. She has led a safe and, if I may say, boring life. When she finds out her sister has been arrested for attempted murder she heads to New York to see what she can find out. She has no doubt of her sister's guilt but feels it is her own fault for breaking off her relationship with Joslyn. Their parents died some years ago after their vehicle had been tampered with and Joslyn was a suspect and the case never solved. She was advised to break all ties with her because she is dangerous.Her first full day in town she literally runs into former military man, Jace Lance, who is the man responsible for putting her sister behind bars. Jace is also the man who stopped Joslyn from murdering his former client. Emma asks him to help her with her investigation and he flatly refuses...until Emma's two cousins, Luke and Michael, contact him and offer him a huge payday to keep information away from Emma. Info that will undoubtedly hurt her further.This is a good read and I do recommend it.

In this tale we have Dr. Thomas North, a young, gorgeous surgeon who had to leave his previous position because of a scandal that was out of his control. He had been lied to and deceived. He has decided you can't be a doctor and have love and marriage so as it usually goes - he is down on love, relationships and marriage. Blah blah blah!!! Heads up...I did not particularly like either of the main characters.Annabel Cates has her masters degree in English and works at the city's library. Her spare time is filled with her golden retriever, Smiley, who is becoming certified as a therapy dog. She visits the hospital frequently and wants to begin a program there using her dog. She meets Dr. North and there is an immediate zing arcing between them. He surprises himself when he asks her to dinner. Following each date and or time spent together (which was very few) he swears to himself he won't see her again and when time passes and she doesn't hear from him like he promised she goes chasing after him. That got very old very quickly. She would use her therapy at the hospital as a reason to stop in and visit him whenever she was there but he never put forth the effort to seek her out. He had asked her out on a couple of dates but other than that she made herself available and let him know it every time she saw him. Gag!! Sorry...but she seemed very weak-willed relationship-wise. He really didn't have to put much effort into their relationship because she handled all of that and it appeared to me to be very one-sided.Towards the end, after the third break-up, it is going through his head that he made a mistake leaving her and lets you believe he has a good plan to get her back. I have no clue what that plan was because it was never mentioned again. Then....you guessed it...she runs into him again and instead of beating feet the heck away she goes right to him. It sickened me. Her mother treated her pretty crappy making sure to let her know every chance she got that marrying a surgeon would never work and they wouldn't make it. She discouraged her the whole time letting her know over and over every mistake she had made in her life and how this was one more. Then crazy Annabel would hug and kiss her after she made her feel less than an inch tall.Just not my cup of tea and I don't care for one-sided relationships.

I love this series but could have done without this story. Very Frustrating!Sutter Traub is back in town. He took off five years ago for Seattle leaving behind his family and the love of his life. He had a disagreement with his family, the town and his girl involving his brother, Forrest, who was signing up for a second tour of duty. Sutter thought one tour was enough as he could see the emotional soul-deep changes that had already taken root. It was only his opinion but everyone, besides Paige-his one and only, turned against him. Without much thought he wanted out of there. His only concern had been his brother's mental and physical safety. He asked Paige to get engaged and leave with him. Paige was not in a good place to leave. Her beloved grandmother was ill and dying and she was one of her caretakers. She was also in college locally earning her teaching degree and didn't want to leave in the middle of it. He refused to try and understand and left without another word and had not been in touch for five years. I must say that these two were supposed to be madly and completely in love. Their future together had been planned and mapped out. How could she be 'his one and only' and never get in touch with her while he was gone? He only came home to assist with the flood damage and he was heading back to his new thriving business in Seattle. In my heart of hearts I have to say I question what he really felt for her. I don't think it could have been the kind of love he claimed it was. He easily moved away and had women at his constant disposal while Paige struggled to live day to day with her brokenness and crushed heart and spirit. She spent those five years grieving for him, doing whatever she could to stay busy and keep her mind off of him. You may say that she could have made a move. I understand why she did not. He left her...point bland and never checked in with her again to see if she changed her mind which she had. He had a constant flow of hot women in his bed. Does that say he loved her beyond all others?And to top it all off he placed all the blame on her, saying it was all her fault for not making an immediate decision to go with him. It made me sick to my stomach. I stayed angry and frustrated throughout this book and was relieved when I had finished. For me, this was the least favorite of this series and it still bothers me every time I think of it.

The question is: Hitched for love—or business?Dr. Brooks Smith, our favorite hunky veterinarian, the most confirmed bachelor in all of Montana, is starting a practice in Rust Creek Falls. His father is also a vet and has a practice there as well. Brooks wants desperately to go into partnership with his father. His pa's health is failing and he eagerly wants to take the load off him. His father refuses with the same old ultimatum. Brooks cannot join his practice until he is married and settled and he is dead set in his ideas. So Brooks does the next best thing by starting his own practice in Rust Creek Falls hoping to get some of his father's business which will lighten the old man's load, hopefully sparing his health. What Brooks did as good his ole man only sees as betrayal.He knows he needs help setting up and running his new clinic and decides to go to the Ace in the Hole for a beer. There he runs into Jasmine "Jazzy" Cates and they strike up a friendly conversation and hit it off. He hires her as his new assistant as she is saving money to complete her business degree. She's a visitor from Thunder Canyon who has been volunteering for the town's restoration efforts since the flood. They develop a close friendship and when his father has a heart attack he asks Jazzy to wed him in a marriage of convenience. She accepts but the MOC is not easy as their feeling for each other only grown and strengthen. Brooks was jilted some years back and was extremely heart-broken. He refuses to get seriously involved with anyone, including his marriage of convenience bride. The road to happiness is quite a bumpy ride but enjoyable nonetheless.This is a very good read and I love the series. I highly recommend both.

*****3.5-Stars*****We are, once again, back in Rust Creek Falls and this book is about Gage Christiansen, the beloved Sheriff, and volunteer coordinator Lissa Roarke from Manhattan.Gage Christiansen is not only the sheriff of this town but also a rancher. He has been angry and upset since the flood that came close to destroying the whole town a couple of months ago. He blames himself because he was out of town when it happened and he believes he could have saved the mayor's life if he had been there...not so but it is what he thinks.Lissa Roarke is a volunteer coordinator from Manhattan and has arrived to give the good people of Rust Creek Falls everything she's got to restore their homes, businesses and schools. She seems to rub Gage the wrong way. She talks too fast, she's too bossy, and she's just too darn irritating. He thinks she's incompetent and he treats her as such...but deep inside he is drawn to her as she is him.After the barrier around Gage's heart begins to crumble they team up in more ways than one. What they have is sweet and hot but they both know they will part when her job is done. She is honest about her feelings for him, but Gage...not so much. As the end of her stay approaches what will become of the two of them?I enjoyed this book but I do get a bit aggravated when one half of a couple refuses to give in to their feelings and pulls away for the other person's own good. That is a common theme that runs through a lot of books these days but I am growing weary of it. Other than that it was a nice addition to this series.

This was a great find and exactly what my college aged son needed. He really likes the text and says it is easy to understand. Amazon has a great rental program and we rented this for one semester for $39.64. Purchasing it new costs $157.68 and used prices began at $149. We have saved a lot of money through this rental program, more than $300 for a few books we thought we would have to purchase. I highly recommend this textbook as well as the rental option.
Great for my son's university class and it is just what we were expecting. I appreciate that textbooks can be rented and this book plus a few others saved us over $300.

4.0 - 4.25 StarsThis was a very good book that was sweet and comical. I will explain later in the review why I marked it down from a 5 stars. This is Book 8 in the 'Cowboy's by the Dozen' series. Each book is about one of the twelve brothers and when and how they succumb to the women who become the loves of their lives.In this story we have our hero Archer Jefferson. He doesn't do long-term relationships nor does he ever want marriage or children. The book led me to believe he was a man-whore or was having a lot of casual sex. I wish it had been more clear. I do not like man-whores and I do think he was one. It sounded like most of his brothers were as well. I also despise when the man you are with makes comments about the kind of women he likes (in bed and other areas in his life.) With that said it was enough to mark it down a whole star for me. I am worn out reading book after book that contains man-whores. It is just getting old. Had he not been a man-whore I would have rated it a 4.75 - 5.0. If I am wrong about his man-whorish ways, please, someone set me straight. I will gladly change my rating.Because he doesn't want any entanglements he has been corresponding by email with a gal from Australia, Clove Penmire, who had seen his ranch online and had a few questions to ask him. They kept up their emails for two years.Clove and her sister own a farm in Australia and it was fast going down hill. Her brother-in-law knew nothing about farming and became frustrated with he and his wife living on the farm with Clove. Threes a crowd, ya know. They were also having infertility issues. He became hard to live with having the knowledge he could not give his wife what they both wanted, a child, so things began going south.In the meantime plain jane Clove thought she would travel to America and show up in the city where Archer Jefferson lived. She had her mind set on hooking up with him and hopefully conceiving so she could give the baby to her sister and save her marriage and head home with none the wiser. She gets her wish and boy is she ever pregnant. A good while passes before she tells him who she really is and why she seduced him. He is shocked to say the least but she was now going to be the mother of their triplets.It was kind of a long road to happiness and Clove was her own worst enemy. As so many others in the books I read she was living in the past and making decisions on what had happened to her years ago instead of following her heart.There were several inconsistencies on the time line. She told him when she was three months along. Then we have a couple of two week periods that zip by. Next there is a two-month period where she had no word from him and then he receives a call that she is in labor and getting ready to deliver. There was also the time he spent in the hospital with his brother after that 2-month period had passed. In my estimation she would have been at about seven months along which isn't horrible for triplets but in the book her sister and Archer say that she is only five months along. I did the math several times and reread the passages thinking I misread. Maybe I just misunderstood.I definitely recommend this book. I am going to start on the other books in this series as this was the first one I read.

I am not going into details as most have already been covered. I struggled to give this a two-star rating because I did not care at all for the Hero and the heroine was a weak, doormat-like woman with a woe-is-me attitude.The h said that she had been teased in high school for two years after being humiliated by the H. I believe, if she would have done her best to act confident and untroubled that never would have happened. She was her own worst enemy. I didn't care at all for the hero and the heroine was just way too weak and doormat-like for me.  Not how I like to find the H/h in books I read.She let this one incident have a huge impact on her life which showed how weak she really was. And boy was I let down and ticked off to find that in the ten years that had passed the H never thought of her. She made a huge mountain out of a tiny molehill. Was what he did nice or kind? No way but they were immature high schoolers. Get over it already! Allowing one incident to negatively affect the rest of your life is ridiculous. If she was that troubled she needed to see a good therapist or minister.

I normally love anything to do with mail order brides or grooms but this book was disturbing on so many levels I am sorry to say I cannot make a recommendation.Our heroine, Addie McGilvray follows her best friend to Montana and becomes a mail order bride. She has hopes that her fiancee appreciates her intellect and love of reading.Our hero (and I use that description loosely,) Emmett Cartwright, and a few words to describe him: man-whore, drinker, gambler, abuser, a man who is easily tempted and has trouble avoiding it. He is hoping his new fiancee will be a Plain Jane. Perhaps if she is she will be more willing to overlook his sordid, sorry past. When Addie arrives he is shocked that the red head is lovely and much more than a bookworm. She is the most talented, intelligent woman he's ever met and wonders how she could settle for someone like him. He quickly realizes that Addie is so smart that it will be difficult to hide his past.She first gets wind of his true character when a soiled dove standing outside the saloon calls to him by name...wanting his business. He has not been philandering since two months before he began writing to Addie and he has women everywhere. He was so charming he usually did not have to resort to the saloon girls and bedded most any woman in town who was willing and that was a very large number.While in town he runs into an ex-lover who is pregnant and claims he is the father. She begins to blackmail him or else she will expose his habits and horrible past to his wife. He is scared spitless that his wife will find out so he agrees to the blackmail even though it bankrupts him and Addie.I despised this man! He treated his wife horrifically. He was mentally, verbally and emotionally abusive. He lied to her constantly and kept the pregnancy with his ex hidden. He began going into town every night after work and drank himself into a stupor even hiding alcohol in the barn.  By the time he made it home it would be very, very late and she would be asleep or at least pretending to be. He also picked his gambling habit back up to try and win enough to pay off the ex. He was simply disgusting and spent zero time at home or with his new bride. Honesty was not in his vocabulary and he was anything but an honorable man.I couldn't get through this book fast enough. Run, don walk, away from this book unless you like slimy heroes and women who take all they dish out and remain by their sides.

Rating - 3.0 - 3.5 StarsTim Duggan has been a widower for four years and is raising twin daughters alone. He has no interest in dating or relationships, thinks he'll never love again and doesn't want to. He is much too busy with his medical practice and his daughters. His plan is to put all that on hold until his girls go to college. He has a long time to wait since they are only seven years old. A friend of his has asked him to take his place at a bachelor and bachelorette auction because of a brief illness. He agrees but is a bit scared and very nervous.His friend and hairstylist, Cassidy Kaye, salon owner has promised to get the bidding started because he fears no one will bid on him. Casey goes up against another young woman who is also bidding on him and Cassidy knows this gal is not the kind of woman that would be good for Tim. Cass outbids the other woman and decides to take the stuffy but good-looking and friendly doctor out on a date he will never forget.Tim and Cass have a blast but she doesn't hear from him after their date even though she would love to see him again and get to know him better. Tim started feeling a bit too much for Cass during their wonderful day together and decided not call her because he tells himself his girls are too young and he is too busy to give a woman the proper attention and support she would need. After all, his wife complained constantly about him not having enough time for her and he won't do that to another woman.I enjoyed the story line and it is one of my favorites. I was also pleased with the growth and development of the characters, although the hero came around a little too slowly.What I did not care for:1. Slow and draggy. I have read three other books in this series and everyone moved much too slowly for my taste. It could have easily been covered in the shorter Harlequin that has approx 192 pages. Some areas seemed like wash-rinse-repeat over and over. I honestly don't plan on continuing with this series because I become too frustrated with the pacing.2. For me, the hero was a bit too week. There were many times he should have stood up to his horrid mother and told her what was what but instead he listened and even though he didn't think it would influence him, it certainly did. His mom would say horrible things about Cass and call her awful names and then he wouldn't call her for a couple of weeks. He let it affect him in a negative way. That is simple weakness to me. This kind of thing happened several times and it made him appear untenable, a mamma's boy, unmanly if you will. He should have given his mother an ultimatum and threatened to keep the children away from her if she could not behave. That is a turn off for this reader. When you consider how strong, independent and outspoken the heroine was, I feel she needed and deserved a stronger male for her counterpart and one that could bluntly tell his witch of a mother to butt the heck out of his life.

4.5 Stars'Bidding on Her Boss' is book two in 'The Hawke Brothers' series by Rachel Bailey and my favorite. I highly recommend all three books. I thoroughly enjoyed Faith's and Dylan's love story and how it came to be and the obstacles they had to overcome. It was somewhat unique and out of the ordinary which made its appeal that much more beguiling.Our Hero: Dylan Hawke is the youngest in the family and the CEO of Hawkes Blooms, his family's floral business. He is your typical gorgeous man who is a playboy but is trying to clean up his reputation. Soon his whole family will be in the limelight when his brother marries a princess (The Nanny Proposition) and he is doing damage control to improve his image and not cause any further embarrassment. When asked, he decides to become one of the bachelors that will be auctioned off at a fundraiser.Our Heroine: Faith Crawford is a very talented florist for Hawkes Blooms and has been wanting an audience with the CEO, Dylan Hawke. What better way to have his undivided attention than to outbid the other women and win him as her date. It takes her life savings but she manages to do just that. In the past she has submitted many floral designs to her manager to be handed over to the department that selects designs for their many stores and catalogs. She feels she and her floral designs are constantly being overlooked and she wants to get to the bottom of it. She knows she is very good because many of the customers request that only she designs their arrangements. Getting the CEO alone and giving him an up close look at her designs might make all the difference.Once Dylan sees her designs he knows there is some funny business going down at the location where she is employed. He also knows that the No Fraternization Policy for the company is placing a damper on the instant connection and attraction he feels for Faith and vice versa. The stolen kiss the night of their 'first date' is a shocker and he definitely wants a repeat performance...but the policy...Rachel Bailey wrote a great story and took us on an adventure into the world of flowers that was interesting. She brought the blooms to life and I could picture them in my mind's eye. The characters were so well developed and the story progressed at a realistic pace. Kudos for this series and especially this book which was my favorite of the three.Read this book to find out the story of Dylan and Faith. Although it is a stand alone, I would recommend reading the series in order for complete understanding of the characters from previous books in the series that are present in the following books.

This was a fairly good read but it moved along slowly and I thought I would never reach the end. I don't like to feel that way about a book. What I want is to feel captivated throughout, a tugging in my heart that propels me forward towards the final destination of a HEA.This is about a couple who were engaged and he was a baseball player. When an arm injury ended his career he threw everything away, including the only woman he ever loved, and decided to pout for quite a few years, wallowing in self pity and why me. He left the family ranch for the big city to work in finance but was never truly happy.When the heroine comes back home to regroup and heal from a devastating divorce they run into each other again and she is extremely wary. She is determined that she will never consider a second chance with him because his desertion just about destroyed her beyond repair. It has been eight long years apart and although she married she now realizes it was to move on and get over him...but she never did and this greatly affected her marriage.I did not care for the fact that the hero continued to make mistakes with her, hurting her and pushing her away again. That was just too much after all she had been through. He was a very bright man but not when it came to her. He really didn't make a lot of sense for someone who was so deeply in love with the heroine. The ignorance of his act was a real disappointment. If you were that in tune with someone you would have known better.Would I recommend this book? I will just say that I won't re-read it. Once was definitely enough and I don't think I will continue the series.

2.5 Star ReviewThe Billionaire's Unexpected Heir was a fair read that could have been very good but....it pushed some no-no buttons for me that I have difficulty with which took it from a 4.5 to 2.5 star rating.A little over a year ago, Jack Garnier, partying playboy and man-whore extraordinaire, spent the evening and night with the beautiful Heather, the first woman who ever got to him. After their time together he has regretted not getting more than her first name, or at least what state and city she lied in, so he could keep in touch with her. She did something to him that no woman ever had. Recently he and his siblings found out they are the grandchildren of a very wealthy grandmother, their father's mother. They never knew her because their father left the family as soon has he and his twin were born and the grandmother was unaware that her philandering son had produced six offspring by four different women. It has been her mission to meet all her grandchildren and give them some of her holdings, their heritage. Jake is now the new owner of Hickory Hills Thoroughbred farm thanks to her and has traveled across the country to check out his new operation.After arriving he is anxious to check out the barns and the horses. He introduces himself to the ranch manager who refuses to speak to or look at him. When he gets a side glance he realizes it is Heather, the one he has not forgotten. He is thrilled to see her but quickly realizes she is certainly not happy to see him. In fact, she seems extremely angry towards him and he doesn't know why.The next day he follows Heather into the ranch house and notices that the housekeeper is holding a baby. The little one isn't feeling well and Heather decides to take her to the doctor for her fever and fussiness. It is then that it dawns on Jake that the child is Heather's. When Heather picks Mandy up and places the baby on her shoulder, Jake is stunned. He is looking at the same face, hair and eyes that he sees every morning in the mirror while he shaves.What I did not care for:1. Jake was one of the most arrogant, alpha males that did exactly what he wanted even when Heather pleaded for him not to. He was beyond determined and it was just too much for me. He was in no way respectful of her and her wants and needs. What was more troubling was he did things in a backhanded way. I didn't look at him as an upfront, honest man. Example: He was determined to have Heather and his daughter in the mansion with him...and Heather in his bed...instead of her living in her own home, the carriage house. To get his way after she strongly objected and refused he waited until she left to go to town and emptied everything out of her home and hired workers to remodel it so it would not be suitable to live in. Pretty underhanded and with each of the underhanded things he did I liked him less and less.2. He freely admitted, in his self talk, that he partied every night with his party animal friends and had a different woman on his arm (and his bed) every evening. I hate man-whores. Despise what they stand for and he was really into it and had been for many years. He was thirty-five years old and had been sexually active since his teens. Do the math if he had a different woman every night for many years. That is just sickening. I was hoping it was not that bad but it was and I almost began to hate him by this time. Such a womanizer and women NEVER said no to him. GAG ME!!!3. Heather was not strong enough. She wasn't a total doormat but he always got his way. ALWAYS! And it left the story feeling very unbalanced for this reader and made me feel sorry for her that she ended up with such a cad.

'For the Sake of Their Son' is Book 5 in The Alpha Brotherhood Series by Catherine Mann. I enjoy Ms Mann's writing but I did have a couple of issues with this book that didn't allow me to award anything better than three stars. I will explain below.Our hero and heroine in Book 5 are Elliot Starc and Lucy Ann Joyner, lifelong friends of three decades. They met in kindergarten and have best friends ever since. They both come from abusive homes, Elliot suffering mental, physical and verbal abuse while Lucy's was mental and verbal that included abandonment issues. Lucy's mother went from man to man and these men (four stepfathers) attempted sexual abuse but were not successful. Elliot and Lucy were each others safe place, playing and dreaming, escaping their abuse and abusive parents.Elliot was sent to a form of military school for wayward teens instead of prison and while there was groomed to become an agent for Interpol. He also love racing and became a world famous race car driver touring the world and also working for the Brotherhood to right wrongs. He hired Lucy to be his assistant for his racing business and she also traveled the world with him. He was your typical (as we read about way too often these days) playboy, man-whore.****SPOILER ALERT CONTAINING REASONS FOR LOWER RATING****After a big win he and Lucy celebrated and one thing led to another. He told her he was finished with his girlfriend, Gianna...except he forgot to tell Gianna and she walked in on them the next morning. She was devastated and left in tears. No, this did not sit well with Lucy. He had not officially broken it off with Gianna like he claimed and both women were heart broken. (I think in his heart and head he had ended the relationship but failed to convey that to Gianna.) Lucy is so broken that she tells him she doesn't want to see him again and resigns from his employ...out of anger, of course. Within a very short time he ran back to reunite with Gianna and was engaged to her within three months of being with Lucy. This act destroyed Lucy and Elliot had left her with a quickly growing gift. Eleven months pass and he never once contacts Lucy, his best friend. (Infuriated me!) His friends from the Brotherhood kidnap him because they found out that there is a baby boy, Eli, that Elliot knows nothing about. He is taken blindfolded and cuffed to Lucy's aunt's home where Lucy and the baby are living. This is basically where the book begins. I will add that Gianna broke off the engagement with Elliot several months before the kidnapping takes place. Yet, he never once made contact with Lucy to check on her...his supposed best friend, while most likely he was back to his man-whoring ways. This is something the author was not clear about so based on his history we are left to assume he was back to his bed-hopping ways.I will be upfront and tell you that I do not like playboys and man-whores. It seems I find them in almost every book I read and I am so past tired of them and their bed-hopping antics. I abhor cheating and although Elliot didn't technically cheat on Lucy, in my head and heart he absolutely did. He ran back to Gianna so speedily after his brief time with his best friend and that definitely demonstrated for Lucy that he cared nothing for her all along. He did, however, cheat on Gianna with Lucy and broke both their hearts. He flagrantly abandoned his best friend of thirty years by not staying in touch with her or at least checking on her to see if she was okay after their night together. She had tried to contact him about the pregnancy a few times but she always got his voicemail or either his assistant didn't know where he was...right! She gave up...I would have, as well. It makes me wonder how many other women he was intimate with after Gianna broke it off. OH YES, I might add that most of this mess ended up being Lucy's fault because he didn't know she was pregnant, having his child, and she sickeningly apologized over and over until I wanted to regurgitate. I do wish the author would have elaborated a bit more on Elliot's sexual involvement those eleven months he was away from Lucy. I could have handled it if he had not slept with Gianna or any other women but we are left to assume that he most certainly did.In a word, I was disappointed. I had just finished a book where the hero left because of a misunderstanding and was gone for year...but he managed to remain faithful. That I can handle.

I was torn between a one-star and two-star review. Only because it had a happy, positive ending did I give it two-stars.This is the first book I have read by this author, finding the story included in the 'Lucky 7 Brazen Bachelors.' I did not find the book interesting seeing as how it was one sex scene after another. I have nothing against intimate relationships in books but this was all about the sex and very little about the characters' development or their advancing relationship. The story line, if you will, was very shallow and I struggled to get past the first two chapters. Yes, I did finish it so I could give an honest review from my personal point of view. I simply did not like it and, as sorry as I am, I can't recommend it.

This is not the type of story line I enjoy at all. Early on I figured out what was going to happen...actually the blurb describing the book gave it away for me.****SPOILER and RANT****I simply have great difficulty enjoying a book when a couple meet, get to know one another and fall in love...then BAM the Hero finds out he is a father from a past lover or one-night stand. To complicate matters it is the child his young sister is trying to adopt and she has kept it a secret from him! Can a man not keep it in his pants...or use protection? Does he not have a brain cell in place when it comes to sex and pregnancy? UGH...this trope exhausts me. I have read three books with this exact scenario in the last week. I am done! If I even suspect a book has this type of story line I will not be reading it.Sorry for the rant but I was so disgusted by the other two similar books I read and this one really put me over the edge. I wish I had at least one positive thing to say about 'The Baby Contract' but I don't. I wish I had not read it and was happy to return it to the electronic library the minute I completed it.

I read this last evening and was not impressed. I will try not to give too much away but it is very difficult in this situation. I really didn't care for the characters. Jared and his secret just didn't do it for me. He did everything else possible but the deed and that made it lose a lot of importance...so it wasn't like saving himself for the one. The way it read, to me anyway, was that there had been plenty hands and mouths on him. It certainly detracted from what could have been sweet, innocent and very special union between the two. So it just lost me there. It also sickened me a bit how these 'other' things he did would be in public places. The whole thing was just plain weird and I had a hard time believing it. He just seemed very odd, wimpy, unsure of himself and gee whiz did the whiny man talk too much. He was supposed to be a badass Navy Seal but was a instead an insecure, whiny girl.Cassie was lacking in several areas, as well, and when they got together there was no relational development. I didn't feel the closeness. He went from one day not wanting anything other than friendship to the next day wanting to talk to her about their future. It was all convoluted and I cannot recommend this book from my perspective but maybe your should read it and develop your own opinion.

MacKenzie Fire: A Sequel to Shine Not Burn***4.25 - 4.5 Twinkling Stars***Boy oh boy, this was a very good read. I was greatly fond of  'Shine Not Burn'-Book one. In fact I had thought about the story several times since I originally read it in 2014. Unfortunately, for me, I couldn't remember the name of the book to save my life. Then, I was scrolling through Bookbub.com where I found an Elle Casey book and went to her author's page on Amazon. There was a book that indicated I had previously purchased...'SNB!'  Bells went off and I hurriedly grabbed my Kindle and dove in. I really liked that story. I love anything to do with Vegas weddings, cowboys and watching the experience as the couple falls deeper in love. So I felt I had hit pay dirt and enjoyed the re-read. I have to be honest and say that I was only able to give SNB 4-stars because of the whiny and indecisive heroine. She carried it on way past my comfort zone. But once I completed it the second time I thought I would really like to know what happened to Ian because we all know he was a real guy...right? (I wish.) Yes...in my head he was.I was anxious to find out who the woman would be to finally bring Ian out of his ridiculous funk and learn more about her. I was praying it was not Hannah Banana who made me throw up in my mouth repeatedly. I was pumped to begin the story. What was it going to take to bring this immature, wallowing in pity, woe is me, I hate the world and the farm - hunk of man who was acting like he was twelve - out of the depths of his self-made and self-imposed despair?So we get reacquainted with Candice, Andie's best friend from book one. She is visiting for two weeks as Andie prepares to give birth to her and Mack's first child. She is a real hoot and boy is she a straight shooter, in more ways than one and that will crack you up. She especially lays it all out for Ian and sets him straight on his pain and heartbreak...woe is poor, pathetic me, please coddle me and feel sorry for me...and for the pain and heartbreak he is, in turn, causing his family and friends. Everyone continues to walk on eggshells. Grow a pair and get a life bud! You've cried in too many beers and been in too many beds so it's time to grow up!What bothered me about this read, knocking it from a 5 to a 4.25 - 4.5 stars: I had way too much of how huge Andie was while pregnant and how fat she still was after birth. Let's not forget a belly full of stretch marks (I couldn't believe her friend brought that subject up.) I don't like to read about that because women do have some control over over that. Pregnant with a single child that ends up weighing 6-7 pounds and is eighteen inches long does not have to make a woman so huge (she was quite small to begin with) that she tries to slide in a booth and has to sit sideways. Her belly is protruding out 4 inches too far for her to sit in said booth normally. Good grief. I thought she would have twins or triplets by the way Candice carried on. I was a bit offended, especially with all the negativity added in. This woman seemed irresponsible, to me, to let herself get so she could barely walk, get in and out of vehicles and rise up out of chairs. People had to get behind her and shove up on her rear end to boost her into the truck. I felt this aspect was a little over blown and took Andie's character down a couple of notches for me. This was a woman who was in control and responsible. At least, for me, she was made to look like an ignorant, hugely pregnant country bumpkin. It was just not in Andie's character to be portrayed that way and for that I was disappointed. It would have also been nice to see her enjoying her pregnancy instead of most everything that came from her being negative. (Please know that I apologize profusely if I have offended anyone. I know there are some women who get quite large and ungainly while eating as their doctor recommended and exercising regularly. I do not mean to slight anyone in that position.) To the best of my memory, I recall several instances that spoke of how much she was eating...but I can't look it up to be sure because I borrowed and returned the book. My impression, be it right or wrong, regarding Andie's size and discomfort was because she overate. Maybe this was untrue but it is the impression I got while reading. Another clue that she had been overdoing it in the food department was how fat they said she was after giving birth. Yes, it takes a while to get back into pre-pregnancy shape (if that is possible) but that is not how I understood what was implied. I could be totally off-base and if so, I apologize.Many commented that Candice was very immature and ditsy. I completely disagree with those comments. She was a great friend and desperately desired to help Ian through his heartache and sadness so he could return to his kind, nice, loving self instead of being an awful jerk who was mad at everyone and the world they lived in. Her goal was to help him heal and move forward so he could be a better man for his family and for the woman he would eventually meet and marry. She was kind, thoughtful, loving and wanted the absolute best for the people she cared about. She knew Andie deserved to have the kind of brother-in-law he should have been for her.Ian was satisfied with nothing and he was his own worst enemy. Everyone coddled him because of his heartbreak...if you can call it that. To me, he should have been thankful the witch was out of his life. He acted so immature for a while that I didn't care for him but began to see what was underneath as the story progressed. You will see there was really no reason for him to behave the way he had for the past three years and I think it made him appear like a pretty dim bulb. He was a college graduate without a lick of common sense in the love department. He was hanging on to something that was not real to begin with.Candice was hilarious and I laughed so hard tears streamed down my face, wiping my eyes so much they became irritated. It was so funny. I really ended up loving them as a couple. I would gladly welcome a book boyfriend like Ian turned out to be once he stopped wallowing in the muck. You will find that it is Seventy some-odd % of the way into the book when they have their first sexual encounter (there were only two,) so be prepared for the wait. The book also got off to a slow start but picked up the pace half way through. I could have used more time with them truly together. It kind of went from them arguing and ragging on each other to love and jealousy. Then the book was wrapped up nicely but pretty quickly. I really was not ready for it to end but I did think it was pretty awesome and I will read it again in a few months. I found I liked this book a little better than the first..maybe half a star better.I highly recommend you read this book, but I would also suggest reading book one first as you will have more back story. Great job Elle Casey. You are a mighty wordsmith!

Oh my! I have nothing nice to say and I hate that. I so wanted to love this book but it was unbelievably bad.I will preface this review by saying that I find no pleasure in leaving a negative review. In this instance I have no choice. There is not one redeemable quality in this whole book that I liked or found positive. Nothing...Nada!!Wow, what a disappointment! Were my expectations too high? I have waited for this book to arrive at our local library and now I am sorry I read it, sorry that I anxiously awaited its release. It was a waste of time and energy.The heroine was an okay character and I liked her even if she was somewhat whiny but the hero of this book was one of the worst I have read about. He treated Mari terribly because he felt unwanted by his parents since age four. His Game plan: Withhold love from everyone so when they walk out he won't be crushed! He claims he will love the baby Mari is carrying but he refuses to love Mari (telling her many times) and has no desire to be a family. He is 29 years old for heaven's sake. Is he so immature that he did not realize that every family in the world is not like his? There is simply no excuse for his behavior and withholding love from the woman who loved him. And to top that off when she went to him and told him she was pregnant he was awful, making sure she knew he didn't want this baby, a family or her and asked her if she was going to abort or give the baby up for adoption (apparently that was his preference.) Crude. He upset her so deeply she began vomiting. I don't really know any words strong enough to describe what a horrible man he was. It was beyond anything I have read.He acted like he was two years old and was ignorant of life outside his little cocoon. I really hurt for Marianna and the way he treated her. He was a selfish ass and I would not waste another minute on this book and will not read anything further in this series. That is how upset I am over this story. It was awful and there will be no recommendation from me.The way Ryan treated Marianna is what I consider emotional and mental abuse. Sickeningly so! Even though there was a HEA there was nothing that happened that could redeem him.

Wow, I am really torn on this book which makes it a bit difficult to rate. The last half of the book was a solid 4 stars but the first 50% was agonizingly slow and filled with not much more than gardening information. I could not give the first 50% anything higher than a 2 star rating.Our Hero, Declan Grant, is a broken, brooding man living a solitary existence since his beloved wife and premature baby girl died in childbirth two years ago. He is a gorgeous man who is only 30 years young but he made a vow, on the day he lost his family, to never let another woman into his life, to never again love or be loved...and he was leading a celibate life never leaving his home. He had a great need to punish himself by not allowing happiness to enter his life...trying his best to atone for the guilt he carried because he blamed himself for their deaths. When neighbors began complaining of the lack of upkeep in his monstrous gardens he was forced to do something about the overgrown mess.A horticulturalist, Shelley Fairhill, bravely stopped by the disheveled gardens at a mansion she passed by traveling to and from work to offer her gardening and landscaping services to the owner. The owner refused but after the neighbors filed a complaint with the city he had no choice. He contacts Shelley and she accepts the job, Shelley makes a strong impact on Declan and they are immediately attracted to one another. His walls begin to very slowly crumble bit by bit but he is still so heartbroken over the loss of his wife and baby it is next to impossible for him to move on. As time passes they are drawn closer and closer together but still he's struggling with his grief and self-induced punishment.I consider this to be a fair read. The slowness of the first half had me on the cusp of not finishing this book several times and to move on to something else. It was somewhat dark with the negative thoughts and feelings Declan had for his deceased wife, baby and excessive guilt. It became very redundant to the point of choosing to skip over them.Recommendation: Read this book and make your own decision. I, for one, would not read it again. It was too sad for me.

***4.5 Stars***This is the first book I have read by Kate Hewitt an it won't be my last. This author is an excellent wordsmith and I look forward to more books in this series.Leo Marakaios and Margo Ferras have been dating exclusively for two years only she didn't know he was not seeing other women. She assumed he was. They got together when Leo was in Paris for business and at other odd times as well. They had never shared their pasts or talked about their private lives beyond their affair although Margo knew he has been with an obscene amount of women. They actually knew very little about one another. When out of the blue Leo purposes marriage she is beyond gobsmacked and was also shocked to learn he had been faithful to her. He was very clear that he DID NOT love her but I think he did. Now that his brother had passed the running of their empire to Leo, at age 32, he thought it was time to settle down, marry and have a family. Margo never wanted to marry or have children because of something devastating that happened when she was young. She carried around so much guilt it was a wonder she could walk beneath the weight of sadness and fear.Margo had a horrific childhood and raised herself since she was seven or eight. The lesson she learned was to protect herself from loving and being loved because everyone she had loved left her.Leo grew up heartbroken and it continued into his early thirties. His father rejected him constantly favoring his older brother to dote on, love and mold into the next CEO of their family business. Leo was given a token job that was completely uninspiring and he was left so empty. Maybe that's why he had affairs with what he jokingly said was about 40% of the female population of his city. Leo learned much of the same lesson that Margo did.After turning down his proposal she knows she has to think up something to tell him so he will leave her alone. She wanted things to stay the same but now knew it wasn't possible. He makes love to her one last time and walks out without a word. But, he did leave something behind. Something she would not discover for another month. Yep...you guessed it.She decides to tell him about the pregnancy and ask him to marry her. It did not go well and he punishes her with his words and actions. He has many demands and she is so horribly ill with her pregnancy that she goes along with it. She was too sick to fight him. He would marry her but it would be a business arrangement, no emotions or feelings involved.This is a great story and I enjoyed every minute. I removed 1/2 star because these two people were adults and surely they could see that not every human being was treated as they were. It made them appear self-absorbed and a bit shallow as far as their thought process and how they were so sure it would end badly. I found that a bit immature for a 29 and 32 year old. They have friends. They witness happy marriages and relationships but they act blind to it.I highly recommend this read and hope you love it as much a I do.

Not real sure what to say about this book. The story line was not the typical but still I didn't care for it. The whole premise of the story is heartrendingly sad and emotional.Ali and Ronan were both workaholics and met while they were each on vacation. They clicked together like puzzle pieces and had one amazing night together. Ronan abruptly left without word because he received news that his sister and her husband were killed in an auto accident. They had been on the way to the hospital to deliver their child...who survived and was now under Ronan's guardianship.Ali was divorced from her husband. She thought they were happily married until they found out she could not conceive. Her husband began an affair with a homewrecker and divorced Ali for this woman. Ali was devastated to say the least and it did a number on her self worth as a woman.Ronan calls a baby-planning service to help him prepare to bring his newborn nephew home and is shocked when he opens the door to the business owner, Ali.  She is furious with him for leaving her without a word while they were vacationing but eventually he gets her to listen. She helps him prepare for baby Josh (why in the world would they call him Joshie throughout the book) and serves as a temporary nanny for the baby who she grows to love.When Ronan's family is gathered together, including Ali, she discovers horrifying, heartbreaking news that rocks her world. She packs and leaves Ronan's refusing to have anything to do with him and she won't tell him why.I did like Ronan's strategy and how he fought for her, what he was willing to give up to have her in his life. For me, that was about the only plus to the story. The rest was just too sad and heartbreaking.Would I recommend this book? I will just say it is not one I would reread.

Wow..this was a bit of a good story but with little depth. There was definitely a Filth Factor with gutter language and sex...making love doesn't really enter into it. It resembles a hot mess of a whirlwind of desperate need. Dropping the F-bomb 83 times was overkill although I have read a few other books that have had more. I was disgusted at the objectionable name they called her girly part no less than 22 times. What they called his package 57 times was not as insulting but over-usage...you think? When the frequency of the words become meshed in everyday language the word/words lose their effectiveness.Unfortunately, I am unable to rate this above a 2-star. If we could have had the story without some of the, what I call filth, it would have had more meaning. If they could have made love to each other and not meet in such a desperate frenzy of need...well, it would have been more realistic.***BIT OF SPOILER***The ex-fiancee was a witch and treated his new wife very poorly. When he decided to comfort said ex after something happened at work and his wife sees it...she is done with him, heartbroken, shattered!! He was too smart to do something that stupid like comfort the ex when she had verbally attacked his wife multiple times and after her betrayal to him when they were together. Just made me feel sick inside. I know how that situation would have made me feel. Even though it was because of a tragedy I lost all respect for him.
Good stuff. Stops bleeding immediately and works great on animals' nails if you nick into the quick area by accident or the dog jerks right as you snip.
Very nice soft grip Pin Brush. I purchased this for my mom's two Havanese pups. It works great and makes quick work of tangles. I highly recommend this brush.

Purchased two of the Cetacea Soft Martingdale Quick Release Collars for my mom's two Havanese pups. They work great and I feel they are much more humane, especially for smaller dog breeds who tend to have problems with collapsing tracheas. I definitely recommend them.
Very nice puppy shampoo with a pleasing baby powder scent. I use this on my mom's two three-month old Havanese pups and i highly recommend.
This is a nice comb and works well with medium and long haired dogs. Makes grooming simple and it is easy to grip. I highly recommend this comb.

Love this double leash that can also be used as a single. It has a newly patented swivel design to keep the leash tangle-free and makes correcting either dog easy. It works well and I highly recommend this product.
Nice file for animals. Smooths out those sharp, rough edges that seem to always be left after nail clipping. I recommend this file and it is also easy to use with a nice grip.

I read 'The Springtime Mail Order Bride' this afternoon and I have to be honest and say I am not quite sure what I just read. It was a bit all over the place for me and I tend not to like stories that include an evil woman trying to steal a husband away from his bride...even before they had the opportunity to consummated their union.The first half of the book was a bit better than the last half but, even with that, it seemed somewhat pointless.Still confused...

For me this was a 2.5 to 3.0 star read.Five years ago, Janine Hart fell in love and had an intense affair with Micah whom she had met in Italy while attending cooking school. She fell so hard and deep and then her world shattered along with her heart. On the evening he took her to meet his awful parents they treated her like a criminal, like trash. Told her flat to her face that she was not good enough for their son and refused to even speak to her etc...it was really quite horrendous. After that visit Micah turned cold and pulled away from her. She knew her future with him was over because of his parents influence and the facts that he was commitment phobic, didn't want to marry or have children. What was really left for her since he was pulling away and barely looking at her through cold icy blue eyes. She packed her bags and went home to her family.Five years later he shows up at her business and tells her he wants her. Why did she leave him? What had happened etc. He would have swiftly found out if he had contacted her and she was tired of leaving message after message about the babies with him not answering a single one. She never heard back from him and was devastated.This was a pretty predictable story line with a Hero who was not at all likable...at least I didn't care for him. Micah was way beyond your alpha male who was not endearing in the least. He was horribly arrogant, a dishonorable bully, and a jerk to the inth degree. Apparently he was well adept at charming the pants off women..many, many women if my understanding is correct. Most of the book moved a bit too slowly for me and really lacked the depth I like to experience in a romance novel. Quite a bit of sex for a short book and yes it seemed it was SEX as there didn't appear to be love-making, just frantic sex.I liked the heroine except she had such a weakness for him and was not strong enough to stop his constant advances. The way he treated her made her feel as though she was being held captive, a prisoner. He would refuse to leave her home or give her space of any kind. Oh yes, and lest I not forget, he was a man-whore and had financially kept mistresses. I thought that went out ages ago. Did not add to the likability factor. Also he told her in no uncertain terms that he turned to other women...to try and get over her. Boy, nothing says love like screwing other women to get over your one true love...oops, I just threw up in my mouth over that.I hate to complain but the cover appeared to me to be of an older man. Not so great!

I read 'The Cowboy's Pride and Joy' last night and enjoyed it. No way I could go to sleep until I finished this read.The Hero:  Jake Hunter, all six-foot four-inches of gorgeous male with black hair, blue eyes, and a body made for a woman's consumption. After two tours of duty and a two-year disastrous marriage to a retched woman who hated his ranch, he wants nothing more than peace and quiet on his grandfather's Montana Ranch that is now his to run. Although he was born and raised in Boston, every summer he and his sister visited their grandparents for several weeks and this beautiful ranch was in Jake's blood. It was his heart and soul, his future. He wanted absolutely nothing to do with the family empire, Hunter Media, but his mother was not about to give up easily on luring her son to the family business. Jake has sworn to never open up to a woman again, no male-female relationships...ever (except random sex occasionally), never marry or have children, no sharing his life with anyone but the ranch workers. He lives as a hermit to some degree and that's the way he's determined to keep it.The Heroine:  Cassidy Moore, a beautiful, blonde curvaceous woman who is outspoken and works as his mother's assistant at Hunter Media. Her life consists of work, work and more work. She is leery of relationships because she watched her father walk out on her mother, herself and her two younger siblings. Her mother went from man to man...to man! Cassie was left to raise her brother and sister and this great job she has at Hunter Media is allowing her to put her sister through college and eventually medical school. Her personal life has been on hold since the day her father walked out on his family and her mother decided men were more important than raising her three children. Unfortunately Cassie doesn't trust any man to stick around, so certain he will leave like her father did.Sparks fly when she arrives at Jake's ranch in Montana. She has been sent there by his mother to have Jake sign the irrevocable papers giving up his chance to run Hunter Media. He does not like what being around her does to him and wants her gone posthaste. Then there's the blizzard that has them snowed in for almost a week.Flash forward fourteen-months:  Cassie has had Jake's son that he knows nothing about. She shouldn't have kept it secret but her reasons for doing so were somewhat valid. Jake had stated his case letting her know he wanted no relationship, no wife, no family or children. She deeply feared her son, Luke, would suffer heartache at his father's hand because she was sure he would reject him sooner or later since a child was not what he wanted. She also knew Jake didn't want her either. She couldn't allow Jake to reject her precious son like her father rejected his wife and children. When his mother interferes once again Cassie goes running back to Jake, the only one who can help her, with baby Luke in tow. Imagine his shock when he opens the door and there stands Cassie, the woman he has not been able to get off his mine for the past fourteen- months, with a baby on her hip that looks just like him.My thoughts: I really liked this story, thought it was good but it could have been great with a few tweaks. I was bothered by the wounds that these two grown, educated adults clung to like a life raft. Wallowing in the pain and misery of their past, terrified to love and trust, to take a risk, take a chance, move forward, realize the knowledge that not everyone in the world is out to hurt them or leave them. For me that was just a bit too unrealistic and drastic and I found it to be quite immature for these two. Yes bad experiences can leave you wounded but it should not be that difficult to work through these issues and move forward making your life the best it can be. To open your heart again to joy, happiness and family.I do recommend this book and will be watching for more of Ms Child's books.

This housing is exactly what we needed and is certainly doing the job it was meant to do...or now. I recommend this item as a replacement for the original housing that surprisingly didn't last nearly as long as it should have.I cautiously rated this 4-stars until we see if it makes it a couple of seasons since we were quite disappointed with the original that came with the motor. I will re-rate it at a later time when I see how long it will last without cracking.

I won't go into specific detail but I did not care for this book. It is difficult for me to become immersed in a book when I don't like the hero or heroine which in this case it was the hero. I thought Ronan was a royal jerk and Laura just did not deserve someone who could treat her so heartlessly, so uncaring. I truly think she could have done better but I realize she had the baby to consider.I am sorry that I cannot recommend this read. It did not leave me with the warm fuzzies. I was too disgusted with Ronan's behavior throughout most of the book.

WOW!!! This is the best book I have read in a long time. There was something special that drew me in and refused to allow me to put it down, even for a moment, until I completed it. I was sad when this great love story ended. I wanted it to go on endlessly. I hope Amie is considering a sequel or series about the other characters we met in this great read, especially Roxanne's brother. It would be fantastic to be updated on the lives of this super couple as well.Our Fab Heroine: We have the beautiful, brilliant mag rag writer, Roxanne Ackerman, who lives in Chicago but is on her way to cover an Elvis convention in Memphis, TN. After driving all night and using her map to soak up a spill she is totally lost and ends up in Jefferson County, Tennessee, with a broken down car and a murder charge. She can reach no one to pay her bail, the judge is out of town on a fishing trip and the jail is being fumigated. Here enters.Our Hot Lawyer: The gorgeous and ultra-ultra conservative attorney, Malcolm B. Daniels IV, has the pleasure and aggravation of being assigned to Roxanne's case and the responsibility of her custody for the weekend. They both are a bit flabbergasted when he enters her cell. They are instantly attracted to one another and you can see the sparks arcing between them when they are in the same room. Roxanne is a strong-willed, independent and a very smart woman who has never been able to please her father. He wanted a lot for her...too much...and the result caused her to make decisions based on what daddy wanted instead of what she wanted. On the other hand Malcolm has been groomed for the presidency since his birth. He has his whole boring life planned out to the smallest minute detail and even an almost-fiancee who fits the exact image of a successful politician's wife. He's had that engagement ring for six months but for some reason he just can't make it final. But what's a future president to do when Roxanne inspires him to abandoned his ultra-conservative ways when they are alone together. She brings out his wild side (he never knew he had one) and he fights it tooth and nail all the way. After all, she is not and would not be good for his image.I highly recommend this book for your reading enjoyment. You won't be sorry!

For me, this was an easy, light, relaxing read with minimal angst. I loved this book! What a refreshing tale!The players: Sydney Stone writes a popular blog dispensing dating advice and it is revered by many. She has one published book and is invited to a National TV talk show along with her long-time boyfriend, Scott. Sydney decides to follow her own advice, break the stereotypes and propose to Scott on air. He flatly refuses telling her he he doesn't lover her and has been having an affair. She is beyond shocked and devastated not to mention humiliated beyond what words can express. Poor Syd watches as her book sales plummet and her reputation is shattered. America's love doctor goes down the tubes pretty quickly.Sydney's best friend wants to come to her aid and introduces her to Drew Young, a talented publicist. At first meeting Sydney does not care for Drew but as time goes by they spend times together and begin to fall in love, a very sweet and devoted love. Drew wants to teach Sydney how to have fun and fun they had as Drew showed her what true love was all about.Such a refreshing book. One I highly recommend and will re-read a few months down the road.

This is an edited review as I removed the original and am rewriting it after a second read through. This was an okay story that, in my opinion, could have been better.Jocelyn Bennings, a chestnut-haired beauty, walked out on her wedding when she found her groom-to-be in the coat closet getting down and dirty with her cousin. She had given up her apartment and quit her job to move with her soon-to-be husband once they got married. She had no commitments so she decided to go on her honeymoon alone needing to get away from the craziness.Jason "Jace" Traub is as gorgeous as his sexy but he doesn't believe in love or marriage. He has been a player his whole adult life and began feeling something important was missing. He also decided that he no longer wanted to be in the family oil business and his family was driving him mad, insisting that he rejoin the company. That was not at all what he wanted and he held strong. He had been absent from his family for six months following a break up with a gal he was in lust with. After she refused to marry him he just needed time to himself to figure out what he really wanted out of life. The family thought he was brokenhearted about the break-up but that was not it at all. He felt adrift, unsure of what he wanted his future to look like. He was the last single brother in his family and there wasn't a woman alive who could tempt him settle down...until he went on a week long family reunion. Yes, it was in the exact same place that Jocelyn went for her un-honeymoon. They met one evening at a bar and that was all it took. They agreed to a friends only relationship with no benefits, best friends for a week.As I said it was a fair read. I actually loved it until it arrived at 90% and then as this sweet read was reaching the pentacle everyone seemed to go haywire with antics and fighting that appeared so out of place and took much away from what was a five-star read up until that point. I had considered removing three stars for the chaotic ending that spoiled the book for me but I decided to only remove two. I have to say it was not only disappointing but also a let down for this reader. I love Ms Rimmer's writing but not so much with this one.

4.5-StarsChristine Rimmer has done it again but that is nothing new!!The Characters: Clara Bravo, a beautiful restaurant owner, needed to get away and went on a two week vacation. She met Dalton Ames, recently divorced and gorgeous, when he was vacationing at the same resort. They hit it off beautifully and he offered a no-strings-attached 2-week fling while on vacation and she took him up on his offer. They had a beautiful time together and Clara wanted to continue seeing him once they returned home. He shot the offer down because he had failed at his first marriage and he felt it was his fault. It broke Clara's heart because she was already in love with him.A few weeks later she found out she was pregnant with his child but did not tell him because of false information she received. He tried to forget her but failed and hired a PI to find her and the PI was told she was marrying her best friend, Ryan. She couldn't go through with the wedding because she didn't love him in that way but he did love her and wanted to step in to be the baby's father.So the story begins with her contacting Dalton Ames at his business and driving to Denver to meet him in a park six-weeks before her due date. He had no idea she was pregnant with HIS child because he was told the child belonged to Ryan. It was really quite a mess with misunderstandings galore on both sides.I have to say that I felt sad for Dalton being the only child of older parents who only had him to pass on the family enterprise. He was unloved and trained to step into his father's footsteps from the time he was born. There was no time me to play or have fun and no love involved in their very strict, extremely dysfunctional household. The were tyrannical in the way they raised and groomed him and it was so very heartbreaking. My heart went out to him.I was not completely sold on Clara. She just refused to give the guy a break and he did everything he could for her. I believe her fear was that he would be gone from her life soon after the birth and she was protecting her heart. In all not a bad idea since he had broken her heart at the end of the vacation and she has yet to recover. I did become a bit disenchanted with her constantly keeping him at arms length and it hurt me to see and feel his hurt. He was so alone and she had a large family and so many friends.This was a very good read and I highly recommend it. It was nice to read a book that had more than a few pages of happiness. I am tired of reading about heartbreak and betrayal only for the couple to get together in the last two or three pages. This was a refreshing book!!

**4.5 Star Rating**I read this last evening and I loved this book. It was such a pleasant surprise to not have the big break-up at 3/4 of they way through before the HEA.Shane Colborn is the CEO of a billion dollar jet manufacturing company and he is in a downhill spiral since his ex-girlfriend writes a tell-all book that is mostly lies. It's damaging his business as well as his reputation and could bankrupt him and put 800 people out of work.Darcy Rivers owns her own website design business with her best friend. Her father passed away three-months ago and she has now recovered enough from her grief to go through his things. Her dad raised her alone after her mother walked out when she was very young and they lived a very modest/meager lifestyle. In a small box with her father's things she finds a letter that was never mailed and learned that her father had been cheated out of millions by the Senior Colborn, the father of Shane. Darcy can't let it go and knows the documents she needs to prove that fact are somewhere in the records department at Shane's business or the basement of Shane's mansion. She is determined to find out the truth. Will she get more than she bargained for?What a fun and lovely read. This is one I will reread. I highly recommend this book by Barbara Dunlop and I am on to book 2 in the Chicago Sons series. I sure hope there will be more to come. That you Ms Dunlop for a great read!!

***4.5 Glittering Stars***Christine Rimmer does it again. There has not been a single Christine Rimmer book that I have not liked/loved and I have read so many. I had the pleasure of reading this yesterday and thought it was a darling. I highly recommend this book and was glad to find the angst was minimal. So many books I've read lately have a great deal of angst with only a few pages of happiness at the end and, for me, they are depressing and somewhat sad. I enjoy a better balanced book and that is what I get from Christine. In this case I found 'The Maverick's Accidental Bride' uplifting and very feel good. It is formulaic but that is what we expect from this publishing company.The Players: We have beautiful, innocent Jordyn Leigh Cates who is reunited with a family friend from her childhood, the dashing Will Clifton. The are both from the same hometown but Jordyn left two years ago looking for something more. Unbeknownst to both Will and Jordyn they end up living in the same city and attend the same wedding.Something peculiar is happening to the guests and one or two fear someone spiked or drugged the punch. Take Jordyn Leigh and Will for example. They had a wonderful time together at the wedding, danced the night away and shared some scorching hot kisses. The next morning they awake to find they are in the same bed, married and have absolutely no recollection of their ceremony or the simple fact they had married. Jordyn is especially distraught because this was not in her plans and she does live by her plans.Read and see what happens when they decide it's best for them to 'play' house and stay married for a short amount to please their family and friends who are all is so excited and happy for them.

********SPOILER ALERT******SPOILER ALERT*******  There may be more than you want to read as I rant out my frustration with this book.I actually like the premise of the story but then came more details that caused a complete about face for this reader.Barry arrived back in the US after serving as a doctor with the Peace Corp for two years and remaining celibate during that time. He is joining his cousin's pediatric medical practice and is anxious to find a wife and start a family. He has, in his mind, the perfect picture of what his wife will be like and look like and a list of all of her abilities and accomplishments.The first night home he wants to hit the clubs for some action. Who would have thought it would end up being his receptionist, whom he has never met' at the clinic where he is starting work on Monday? She saves his butt that night after someone drugged him. He never intended to spend the night with Chelsea who is his exact opposite of and totally wrong for the image of the woman he intends to find and marry....and guess what malfunctions during the course of their lovemaking?? Of course. I do believe this is now a trend. Condoms malfunction and then a pregnancy.A couple of months pass and he never checks to see if she conceived that night. Instead he is too busy dating women his family and friends have lined up for him which has kept him very busy for a few months - dating several women a week. He is determined to find the right fit for him and sweet and sexy Chelsea is not it. I was bothered by the fact that he sees her every day and after informing her of the epic failure he never asks her if she got her monthly or if she is pregnant. She has not given it much thought because she has never been regular. I thought it was somewhat callous that he did all this wife-seeking right in front of her on a daily basis. He is a doctor for crying out loud and here he is going out with so many woman while she is carrying his children. She didn't know she was pregnant at the time but could he not have waited until he knew if she was pregnant before he began his wife hunt?? That really turned me off to the story. Took it down a few notches.She dealt with it all silently but it was still troubling for me and it hurt me to think he could have cared so little. He actually appeared prejudiced to me so set on only one certain type of image even though he found he still wanted Chelsea. What kind of man is that? And through it all he is still drawn to her. No one he dated so far has lived up to the time he had spent with her but he would not allow himself to go there. Everyone around them seemed disappointed with their baby news, angry even. All of his family, his other doctor partners, and all the females who worked in the large office building were upset because they had his dates lined up months in advance and some women even came in the office and demanded Chelsea give Dr. Barry her approval/permission//blessing to date them...while she carried his children. What the heck? It disgusted me. Of course there was also the cracks made by doctor charming about how big and wide she was carrying his twins. Yes, real nice guy. It didn't seem there was much she could do to please him there for a while.The whole thing just did not set well with me and I certainly cannot recommend this book. I am sorry I read it because it made me angry to think a man could and would be that thoughtless. Grrrr!!

What a disappointment! I was so ready to love this book but it certainly didn't live up to my expectations.Cole was the love of Tina Sanchez life but the feelings weren't returned and he went out of his way to show her he didn't care about her until one night of passion their senior year of high school. Then the very next day she asked him to the 'girls ask guys' dance at their high school and he crudely and hatefully dismissed her, soon left town and moved on. Her heart was shattered and she was broken almost beyond repair for a good while. He returns home five years later to help his sister after her second divorce and runs into Tina again.
