I saw John Walkenbach's name (AKA Mr. Spreadsheet) on the front cover but yet he is not the author of this book.  I've read a couple of John Walkenbach's Excel VBA books from cover to cover and he is a very good writer for those wishing to learn Excel and Visual Basic for Applications (VBA).  I found out that John Walkenbach is the Series Editor for a series of Excel books such as 101 Ready-To-Use Excel Macros, Microsoft Business Intelligence Tools for Excel Analysts, and Excel Dashboards and Reports.The 101 Ready to Use Excel Formulas is the lightweight book on how to use Excel formulas. It is just over 200 pages long and does not include any VBA or custom functions written by the user.  The comprehensive Excel formula book written for the professional that also includes VBA and custom functions is John Walkenbach's 800 page Excel 2013 Formulas.  This 101 Formula book is about the same price as John's 800 page book, so you get a lot more with the book that John Walkenbach authored.Some basic points about the 101 Ready to Use Excel Formulas book:  The introduction states that the ideal candidate for using this book is someone who has some Excel skills such as doing basic data analysis, using tables, aggregating data, performing calculations, and creating charts.  You should have Excel 2010 or 2013.  The book does not provide any explanation as to any differences in Excel 2007 or earlier versions.  (Note that John Walkenbach's Excel 2013 Formula book states that it is for Excel 2013 as well as 2010 and 2007.  John states that if you have a version of Excel older than that then you should consider one of his earlier books on Excel formulas to avoid confusion.  (Excel 2007 was the version that Microsoft introduced the somewhat controversial ribbon menu.))  There is no CD included with the book but page 4 gives a webpage where you can download the sample files.What types of formulas are included in this book?  The book covers a wide range of Excel formulas on topics such as calculating percentages, running totals, divide by 0 errors, counting values, and conversion tables (such as miles and kilometers).  There are text functions or formulas for joining text strings, extracting parts or a text string, substituting characters in a string, and formatting numbers in a text string.  There are date and time formulas such as calculating the number of work days between two dates.  There is conditional analysis, such as sum the values that meet a certain condition.  There are lookup formulas to lookup values in a table, finding values using multiple criteria, and alternatives such as Index and Match.  There are common business and financial formulas such as calculating profit margins, break even points, depreciation, net present value, loan payment calculators, and amortization schedules.  There are statistical calculations such as mean, median, and mode, smoothing data, frequency distribution, and trendline forecasts.  Lastly there are formulas with conditional formatting such as highlighting cells that meet certain criteria or highlighting values that are in list 1 but not in list 2.  There are only a couple pages relating to array formulas.Here is an example of the format of the book:  Formula 48 is Sum All Values That Meet a Certain Condition.  A simple statement of the issue is given, such as you want to sum all of the negative values in a column of a table.  The formula is =SUMIF(C3:C12,"<0").  A screenshot shows the formula and result.  An explanation of how it works is given.  Each argument in the formula is explained, as well as options.  Another example and screenshot may also be included.  Alternatives are also given, such as constructing the criteria in a SUMIF statement.So there is a broad range of formulas in the book that you might find useful in improving your Excel capabilities and saving time.I thought the book was good but a bit pricey with a list price of $39.99, even though it is well discounted by Amazon.

These Scotts Titanium shearers are nice. Blade length is about 7 inches.  I couldn't tell that they were a whole lot better than my old $10 shearers which are a similar style.  The Scotts shears have a slight curve to the blades, while my old shearers have "teeth" cut into the blades.  Both do fine on the boxwoods and other small branches.  The Scotts shearers do a little better on cutting tree branches of about 1/4 inch.  My old shearers have a bit of rust on the blades.  I'm hoping the titanium blades will not rust.  The lifetime warranty is nice.

A dock is a stand that holds your phone upright and has an integrated charging/syncing cable just like the cable that came with your iPhone.  So the dock doesn't really do anything that your original charging cable doesn't do except hold your phone upright so that you can easily see it or access it. The Belkin is a nice dock.  It has a solid feel to it.  Plug the dock into your computer's USB port and it will charge your iPhone 5 (or iPod Touch 5th generation) and sync it--the same as plugging your phone into your computer with a USB cable.  The dock has some weight and has a nice feel to it.  However when you begin using your phone while plugged into the dock, you will find that your phone and the dock may tilt back as you sometimes press on the screen.  That is to say that the base does not remain flat on the table.  And unfortunately the Belkin dock does not come with a power adapter to plug it into the wall, so if you don't have a USB port you can't charge your phone with it.  And it may not work with your phone's case.  The box states, "Compatible with open base cases.  For best results, remove case to dock."Unfortunately iTunes is pretty much the only game in town for syncing your iPhone. Some people have described iTunes as malware.  Anyway, iTunes would not sync all of the apps.  Then after it synced everything I wanted to see the pictures that were uploaded to the computer and delete some of the pictures on the iphone.  There's no menu option for that--or if there is, it is well hidden.  I did not deduct any stars from my Belkin dock rating for iTunes.Belkin typically makes good products.  (I think sometimes Belkin gets a bad rap because other sellers list cheap knock-offs on the same Amazon page and then Belkin receives bad reviews for those knock-offs.)  But at $35 (or $27 on another Amazon webpage) this dock seems over priced.

I can't believe that this is a Belkin product.  I thought their products were supposed to be better than the cheap junk that you can buy from China.This Belkin case does not offer much protection for the iPhone 5C.  It's just a hard plastic case that doesn't fully cover all of the phone's edges.  And for $8 you don't get get any screen protection.  You can buy a similar case on that big auction site for about $2 (I'm not allowed to give the site name).  If you really want more protection for you iPhone, try something like the SUPCASE Apple iPhone 5C Unicorn Beetle Dual Layer Case - Black/Black, Compatible with iPhone 5C/iPhone Mini (2013 Version). It's only a couple dollars more than this piece of plastic.If you have a $2 phone, buy a $2 case.  It clearly does not offer the protection that some of the better cases offer.

1:26 MinsThe stock fan on my AMD Phenom II (AM3) CPU started going bad, so it was time to shop for a new CPU fan. There were a number of higher priced CPU fans that probably would cool the CPU down more, but they had one thing in common. They all needed a backplate to be installed on the back side of the motherboard. (Maybe there were some other fans better than this that didn't have this requirement, but I didn't find them.) With my CPU case I have access to some areas of the back side of the motherboard but not where the CPU is located, so I would have had to have pulled my motherboard out of the case in order to install one of those fans. I've built a number of computers but was not in the mood to pull this motherboard. Enter the Logisys MC2002GX. It costs about $20 or less and I decided to give it a shot.The CPU fan installation was fairly easy. (See my video for instructions. For the best viewing, click to view full screen. Pause as necessary. The video shows how to remove the stock AMD CPU fan and install the new fan. The last two frames on the video are for Intel CPU's only.) The only tricky part was the last step when I had to push the fan down firmly onto the CPU, align the mounting bracket and then clip the mounting bracket over the plastic tab next to the CPU. But once you get that done you're finished. And normally I use a better thermal paste when I'm installing a CPU fan, but in this case I opted not to remove the thermal paste that comes on the fan.The CPU fan is pretty quiet. It has been keeping my CPU temperature between 29 and 42 degrees C. The high temperature was shown when I had all 4 CPU cores at 100% usage.No complaints at this time.NOTE: This CPU fan will work with more CPU's than are listed in the description. See the picture that I uploaded that shows the full list of CPU's on the side of the box.

My osteopathic doctor recommended these Wholemune capsules.  I took them when I was having some sinus problems and they helped my immune system to respond.This is what the Ortho Molecular Products website says about Wholemune.  "WholeMune is formulated with Wellmune WGP, the most well-researched, single beta-glucan, proven in clinical trials to prepare and protect the immune system from repeated and ongoing stressors.  Wellmune® WGP is a highly purified, yeast-free beta-glucan extract derived from Saccharomyces cerevisiae; it is standardized to contain 75% pure beta-glucan and is considered to be the most effective single nutrient to naturally prime immune cells to enhance immune function.  WholeMune’s primary active ingredient is Wellmune WGP®- a natural beta 1,3/1,6 glucan derived from the cell wall of a proprietary strain of baker’s yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae). Once swallowed, immune cells in the gastrointestinal tract take up Wellmune WGP® and transport it to immune organs throughout the body. Specific immune cells called macrophages digest Wellmune WGP® into smaller fragments and slowly release them over a number of days. The fragments then bind to neutrophils (white blood cells), via complement receptor 3 (CR3).  Neutrophils are the most abundant immune cells in the body, accounting for 60-70% of all immune cells. The activation of neurotrophils by Wellmune WGP® fragments allows these cells to move faster throughout the body, resulting in a significant boost in immune defense."A UK reported stated the following:  "A new nutritional product called beta-1-3, 1-6-glucan is one of the most exciting things happening today in the field of nutritional supplements.  Obtained from purified yeast, beta-1-3-glucan has a long scientific history and a reference list including literally hundreds of papers. Research originated in the 1940's when Pillemer and his colleagues described a crude yeast cell wall preparation, Zymosan. They reported that this material was able to stimulate nonspecific immunity. It was unknown at that time which element of this composition, containing a relatively crude mixture of proteins, lipids and polysaccharides, actually activated the immune response.  The answer came later in the 60's, when Dr. Nicholas DiLuzio at Tulane University experimented with beta-1-3-glucan2 . In the late 1980's Dr. Joyce Czop, at Harvard University, described the mode of action of this material in stimulating the immune system: there is a specific receptor for beta-1-3-glucan on the surface of certain cells, called macrophages3 that when activated, stimulate a cascade of events turning the body into "an arsenal of defense".  April 28th 2014 - the most recent research confirms the safety,efficasy and immunomodulatory effect of beta-glucan 1-3, 1-6 in humans.  A clinical human trial published January 23rd 2013 in the European Journal of Nutrition, based on a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multicentric study in healthy subjects, suggests beta-glucan 1-3, 1-6 helps prevent colds, improves symptoms and increases the body’s potential to defend against invading pathogens."

The Kitchen Supreme French Press Coffee & Tea Maker bundle is a great addition to any kitchen, or would make a lovely gift for the coffee or tea drinker in your life! This french press is perfect for getting the most out of your coffee beans or loose leaf tea. The Stainless Steel Francois et Mimi Vintage Double Wall French Coffee Press holds 34 ounces of liquid (which is good for about 3-4 cups of coffee in our house - so nice for a relaxing morning for my teenager, husband and I to all get a cup, or serve up some coffee with dessert). This is a fantastic USB hub if you need extra USB outlets on your computer / laptop. I really like this food chopper! I am always in the kitchen cooking something or other, and we use a lot of diced peppers, celery, carrots, and onions for casseroles, soups, salads, stews, stir fry, etc. so I spend a fair amount of time chopping things! This food chopper is awesome, very easy to use with just three components, and you can get your vegetables / fruits finely diced with a few extra pulls, or just rough chopped depending on what you're using them for. I was able to fit half of a large onion in the bowl, and with about 14 pulls I got good, pretty evenly sized rough chopped onion pieces, with another 10 pulls I got pretty well minced onion. I received this product in exchange for an honest review based on my personal experiences.

This is a very nice drying rack, I love that it collapses up and takes up little space when not in use (this makes it very convenient to take if you're traveling as well). I received a bottle of this pet odor & stain removal spray to review and it is something that has and will continue to come in VERY handy in my house! We have 3 dogs and 2 kids - so between them all there is pretty much always a stain on my carpets somewhere needing treatment; especially when it rains and the dogs track in red Georgia clay, and leave behind that lovely wet dog smell which seems to soak right into the carpet. Most of the stain came right out with very minimal effort, and the scent left behind was actually fairly pleasant, not chemically like many of the stain treaters we've used over the years. Easy to use - remove from the protective cover, insert into the item you are checking temp on, read the display, wash off and dry the probe and return to its protective cover! Good quality, sturdy stainless steel pastry cutter. This is a wonderful, natural soap that I feel really good about using. This is a fantastic toddler plate and bowl set! If you like the idea of a natural deodorizer product to limit your family's exposure to chemicals in aerosol odor neutralizers, then I think this is a really terrific alternative. This is a fantastic fire starter that will give you really good, hot sparks. My husband is really big on survival gear, and he and I put this to the test when we received it. It is very easy to use - just scrape off some of the magnesium shavings into a small pile, firmly hold the grooved side of the striker against the flint and apply pressure while quickly sliding the striker down along the magnesium rod, allowing the sparks to land on the pile of shavings. Have tinder or paper ready to add to the burning magnesium, blow gently, and once the tinder has ignited, build your fire with larger kindling / logs until fire is established. Keep this great little tool in your camping or hiking gear, keep it with your survival kit, or a go-bag, or emergency bag for your car. I received this product in exchange for an honest review based on my personal experiences.

4 starsI used the Sketch It Nail Pens Salon with a six year old and an eight year old who are big fans of manicures. The set comes with 5 polish/pens, a sheet of tiny gem stickers and another sheet with stickers you can color in with the pens. There are five colors of polish, and we all agreed that they are pretty colors. The polish goes on easily, although the green/yellow was a little thin so it required two coats and it also took a little longer to dry (this seems to be a problem with many green polishes). The other colors dried pretty quickly which was awesome with kids. The pens are under a cap at the top of the brush - they act as the handle for the polish brush. After some initial fumbling on paper, we realized you have to squeeze the middle of the pen in order for it to draw. It’s a super fine point pen and worked great! We wrote letters on their nails and colored in the decals. Worked very well! The gem stickers are tiny but really cute. They’re nice colors, too.The set comes with a tiny needle discretely stuck to the bottom of the wand for unclogging the tip. The directions tell you about that, otherwise it might easily be missed. Word of caution - It is *very* easy to accidentally unscrew the cap of the polish while trying to remove the cap to the pen. This spells disaster for kids or anyone not paying careful attention. All in all, I think this kit is a very good value and makes a nice addition to a home manicure set.

The packaging says this will feel “luxurious” and it sure does. It’s super soft - feels like a really nice teddy bear - and so comfortable to snuggle up with, even if you’re not using the heat. Unlike many throws, it’s big enough to keep me toasty and happy on the couch or in bed. The cord length is generous, which is also unexpectedly convenient. The sand color is a nice, warm light beige which I feel would coordinate in most any room. I’m always cold in the winter, no matter how high the heat is, and I know I’ll be using this the minute the temps drop a few degrees and winter really begins here in New England.  Love it!

This novel didn't measure up to past books in the Rosato and Dinunzio series, which generally has offered "quick reads" with focused plots, interesting characters, and insightful to the workings of our legal system. This book focuses on Bennie Rosato, the founder of a successful Philadelphia law firm, with very little interaction with her business partner and legal staff. The first half of the book starts in the present day when she is asked to represent Jason Leftkavick, a client  in his early twenties who she  represented in a juvenile case ten years earlier. It then goes on to give details of that case as well as a personal love relationship that she developed with Declan or  "Mr. Right" as Lou, her firm's investigator, referred to him. The second half describes the current trial of her client and the return of her  paramour. Bennie is conflicted about her feelings about the man she thinks she loved/loves as well as the legal system and its dispensing of  "justice".  I liked the main story and related characters and I liked the insights into Bennie's thoughts while presenting her client's defense, but Bennie's personal love relationship was unrealistic  and overdone.

I LOVE THIS THROW BLANKET! The packaging says this will feel “luxurious” and it sure does. It’s super soft - feels like a really nice teddy bear - and so comfortable to snuggle up with, even if you’re not using the heat. Unlike many throws, it’s big enough to keep me toasty and happy on the couch or in bed. The cord length is generous, which is also unexpectedly convenient. The sand color is a nice, warm light beige which I feel would coordinate in most any room. I’m always cold in the winter, no matter how high the heat is, and I know I’ll be using this the minute the temps drop a few degrees and winter really begins here in New England.

Four stars for these well made cloths, which are light, strong, and nicely dyed. They also launder well, and dry quickly. The only complaint I have is that they're mostly microfiber, which I find to absorb liquids poorly and to leave surfaces rather wet. Good for washing dishes, though, and cleaning the glass surface of the stove. Reasonably priced, too.

This is a nice eye cream, but like all the other OTC wrinkle/anti-aging products out there, it will produce no miracles. Pleasant, subtle scent, light, non- greasy texture, and doesn't make my eyes puff up like some others I've tried. Good for general moisturization of the skin around the eyes, and probably also for other delicate areas like neck and upper chest.
Easy to apply, no unpleasant odor, and so far, working as promised. No fleas or ticks present on either of our cats. Fair price, too.

This product arrived when promised. Right off the bat I was very impressed with the sturdy packaging that the materials came in. Heavy cardboard, foam rubber and styrofoam kept all of the pieces free of damage. The instruction manual contained helpful illustrations showing the parts needed as well as the recommended procedure to put them together. It was easy to follow.  At one point I had a question and called South Shore Customer Service. They were very helpful and friendly. The assembly package was complete and packaged well.  By taking my time and following the directions, the dresser turned out great. It looked exactly like the picture that I based my purchase on. The drawers all fit and worked easily and it seems like a good purchase. My rating  based on my initial experience, and I expect this piece of furniture to function well.

"The Falsies" is quite a provocative label for a product like mascara, and prompted me to order it just because it prompted a smile. Anyway, it promises to deliver the thick, upturned look of false eyelashes, which I tried a couple of times when I was young and foolish and nearly glued my eyelids shut. I can't say that this mascara mimics the look of professionally applied "falsies"' but it does go on neatly and provides a lusher appearance than your basic mascara. Though billed as washable with soap and water, it's better to use makeup remover first because it does have staying power.

Wow, this is a big, hefty bar of soap, which must be why it's billed as for men. But Irish Spring has always been advertised for men (remember the Irish lass saying "But I like it too"?) Well, I like this one too. The scent is lighter than that of the green bars, refreshing without overpowering. It doesn't seem to do much in the exfoliating department, in spite of the flakes of oatmeal dispersed throughout. But it doesn't seem to have a drying affect on skin, whether used on body or face.  At $4.99, these 6 inch blocks are a great bargain; they certainly last a lot longer than standard soaps.

History repeats itself at an estate high above the shores of Lake Garda, where a century ago, renowned playwright Galeazzo D’Ascanio wrote a drama, considered to be his masterpiece, expressly for his muse, actress Celia Sands. She disappeared without a trace on the eve of its opening, leaving him broken and bereft, and locals believe that she has haunted the estate ever since. Now his grandson, Alessandro, has endowed the property to a historic trust, and as a final tribute to Galeazzo, he plans to stage the play for the public before relinquishing the villa. For the leading lady, he has engaged a fledgling English actress, another Celia Sands, who with trepidation accepts the role and travels to Italy for rehearsals. At the villa, she is assigned the very same room once occupied by her namesake, whose portrait hangs above the bedstead. Celia’s nervousness about taking on her first starring role is exacerbated by tales about ghostly encounters, and the fact that two household staff members are missing adds to her uneasiness. When some unsettling incidents occur, she tries to chalk them up to imagination.Season of Storms unfolds at a leisurely pace. It’s clear from the outset that events from the past will be mirrored in the present, so the book relies on characters and the process of staging a play as its center. Character development is uneven, however, and it’s unfortunate that Celia remains a reactor, passive and unsophisticated. Although she will come to feel real fear, the reader never does. Part mystery and part romance, both story lines fall a bit flat in spite of the spectacular Gothic setting in which they play out. What works somewhat better is the gradual reveal around modern Celia’s own family history, which is cleverly plotted and does come as a surpriseSusanna Kearsley’s books have been compared to those of Mary Stewart, which is fair, and I’m also reminded of Daphne DuMaurier (excepting the incomparable Rebecca).

The detergent is fine but it received an F in online safety ratings. I think that’s really scary.I typically use one of the free and clear detergents because I’m very sensitive to fragrances and will often break out with contact dermatitis from them. Because I occasionally feel nostalgic for the freshness of fragranced laundry, I thought I’d try this one to see how the lavender scent was. From the bottle, it doesn’t really smell like lavender but isn’t unpleasant and after drying my clothes, I really couldn't smell it at all. It did seem to perform well - my clothes were clean and I haven’t had any skin reactions. I have to admit that after looking up the safety of this product, I was very disappointed to see that this detergent received terrible ratings. Instead of chancing it, I think I’ll likely stick with my usual detergent which was rated very safe.

I don’t have eczema but I am prone to itchy skin due to dryness or irritation for no discernible reason. I was pleasantly surprised by how cleanly this lotion absorbed into my skin, although it did leave an almost silicone feel until it completely absorbed. It’s nice that it’s truly fragrance free and doesn’t have a heavy feel. It moisturized well enough but I didn’t find it helped to relieve my itchy skin. From what I read, it does seem to provide excellent relief for those people suffering from eczema so I would recommend it to someone looking for relief from those symptoms.

Richard Papen is chronically depressed, a loser in his own eyes. Penniless, he leaves his native California and his dismissive parents for Hampden College in New Hampshire, where he hopes to reinvent himself. Still very much a fish out of water, his knowledge of the language of ancient Greece eventually comes to the attention of the school's elite, a group of five wealthy students who study all things Greek under the tutelage of distinguished scholar Julian Delgado. To Richard's astonishment and delight, he's invited into this exclusive coterie. Soon, as a result of the mythology and philosophy in which the students become immersed, one of the group will die at the hands of his fellows. This is the secret. As narrator, Richard's job is to guide readers along on the journey that leads to murder and its inevitable tragic aftermath. This is the history.The Secret History owes much to such classic forerunners as Crime and Punishment, Brideshead Revisited, and Lord of the Flies, as well as the body of Greek Mythology. To the credit of its author, however, this mystery cum coming of age tale is no mere derivative.This is an accomplished first novel. Yes, it has its problems. The plot, though certainly compelling, is not complex enough to warrant nearly 600 pages, and it drags in places toward the middle. Readers who expect to "like" the characters will probably not like The Secret History; while they each possess a level of intellectual brilliance, morally they are bankrupt. Self-appointed elitists, the totality of their self absorption will ruin them all. Except for Richard, whose self-contempt paralyzes him to the point that he watches their actions as though watching a game or a movie. But Ms. Tartt is spot on in her portrayal of the 1980's texture of life at a small town college during a snowy winter, well enough to invoke some nostalgia for my own college days. While revealing the secret in the prologue saps the story of suspense, knowing what will happen evokes a strong sense of dread that grows as the plot plays out, rather like watching a snake from a distance when you know it might strike. Rather like we do whenever any heinous act splashes itself across our television screens.Fascinating work by a talented writer. Can't believe I didn't read it years ago.

These capsules worked perfectly in my machine. Though not as full flavored as the description claims, I found the flavor relatively smooth and not too acidic or bitter. It definitely gives some strong competition to my favorite, Nespresso. One of our European friends, a die-hard espresso fan who prefers Nespresso in lieu of a "really good" espresso, also tried it and was pleasantly surprised. At nearly $1 per pod, it’s pricey, almost 30 cents more than Nespresso pods. It appears these capsules may be recyclable in my area and that would certainly give Puroast some extra points in our book and also softens the blow of the higher price a bit. In the end, the price alone will likely deter me from adding it to my capsule lineup… BUT, the scientific claims regarding much lower acidity and high concentration of antioxidants (more antioxidants than green tea) appear legitimate and sound, so if your stomach is usually irritated by coffee (or if you don’t mind the price), I think you should definitely consider this one!

NAll of the flavors in this line of breakfast biscuits are good, but the blueberry, to me, is the standout. The whole grain biscuit is thin, crunchy, and tasty, and the bits of dried berry add just the right amount of sweetness. And actually taste like real blueberries! They come 4 to a packet, and I find myself choosing them frequently as a mid afternoon snack with tea. Delicious and relatively low calorie, better than a cookie.

Easy to use, without mess. The non-genetically modified seeds sprout quickly and are nourished by the Miracle-Gro, which is mixed into the planting medium. The peat pod absorbs a lot of water, so it's important to check for dryness on a daily basis, especially when the sprouts are small.This product provides a simple, effective, and affordable way to start your own vegetable and herb plants indoors.

Brightly colored, whimsical, and durable, this product is useful for large seeds only, due to the size of the mesh. It also accommodates suet cakes, but it's necessary to split the square commercial in half to fit. Within the first five minutes after hanging the lady bug outdoors, a downy woodpecker alighted and went to town on the suet. I don't mind when squirrels feast at our feeders ( they have to eat too, and this has been a very snowy winter),but those who do will not be able to access the suet from the ladybug. In early spring, we have to remove the wooden suet feeder because, without fail, the newly active raccoons manage to open the gate to the cage and make off with the entire cake. I'm guessing that that will not be the case with the ladybug, but that remains to be seen.

I like the design of this double hook a lot. The non-slip design makes it better than nearly every over-the-door hook I’ve owned! The spring arm gave it a secure fit against the door without the bouncing I’ve had with other hooks. I think this will keep it from scuffing wood or paint effectively. The hooks are a little close, but its slim profile is nice if it’s being used in a closet and the grip on the hooks is nice for keeping things like towels in place. The only downside is that I don’t have enough clearance between the top of the hook and my door frames to be able to close my doors completely with the hook in place. Otherwise, this has a nice, subtle look that will blend well in the room.A message for OXO: the packaging is OVERKILL and it was comical trying to get it off the thick cardboard it was overly secured to with thick wire you couldn’t unbend with anything but pliers. A message for consumers: This should not dissuade you from purchasing this hook.

Ordered this for my daughter, and here's her opinion:I’m a long time vegan protein powder user and I was pleasantly surprised by the Vega One All-in-One Nutritional Shake, chocolate flavor. The nutritional profile is great, and the taste was much better than I expected. I made a straight up shake with coconut-almond milk and it blended nicely. I shared it with a couple of family member who aren’t big shake drinkers and even they enjoyed it. My only complaint is it’s slightly chalky if you mix it plain, but when you add some fruit in the blender with it, it’s a little smoother and much less noticeable. I have been using vegan Plant Fusion up until now, but this is a viable contender for my protein powder rotation. Next time I’m having a chocolate or sweet craving, I’m going to blend it with the coconut-almond milk and some ice for a dessert shake. I’ll try the vanilla next, which I think I’ll enjoy more in the morning blended with fruit.

It's still the middle of winter here, so it's difficult to judge the efficacy of a flea product. But having been asked to review it within a month, I applied it to my cat as directed. Easy to use, inoffensively fragranced, and reasonably priced, if it does what it promises and actually kills eggs as well as live fleas, and all sorts of ticks, this will become our new go-to product.

"All Day And A Night" is the latest in Alafair Burke's series with  NYPD Detective  Ellie Hatcher and her partner JJ Rogan.  It is another fast paced, easy read.  The characters are easy to  like or hate, and also include a few that you aren't so sure about. The story plays out like a good movie in your head, with twists, turns and surprises,  just as all good books do.In this case, the NY District Attorney's Office has received anonymous information, following the murder of a prominent  psychotherapist, that suggests that a serial killer who was believed to be in jail, may still be free.  This leads to the possibility that someone may  have been falsely convicted of  a crime that he did not commit. Under the authority of the DA's office,  Hatcher and Rogan are paired as part of the "Fresh look" team to investigate whether an innocent person has been incarcerated and to also find the killer of the psychotherapist.  Of course, nothing is that easy and there are many subplots to keep you actively involved in this story.

Funeral Music is the introductory volume to the Sara Selkirk Mysteries. Sara is a world renowned cellist who has lost her will to perform following the sudden death of her husband. But that is not the mystery in Funeral Music. Sara's well meaning friend and accompanist, James, cajoles her into playing a charity concert at Bath's famous Pump Room, after which she makes a horrifying discovery. Someone has stabbed to death the museum curator, dumping his corpse into the Roman baths, and Sara is the first to find him. He wasn't a very popular or principled individual, and there are any number of possible suspects. The investigation falls to Sara's cello pupil, DCI Andrew Poole. The plot thickens when Andrew falls for her, and when James becomes a suspect.This is a simple enough plot with enough interest to permit its competition with the setting, the spectacular city of Bath. Each of the main suspects is given his or her own chapters, and it doesn't become clear who did it until very close to the end. Along the way, a couple of imaginative yet believable alibis liven things up, but one of those alibis proves to be a cover. I was truly surprised when the murderer was finally revealed. Will Sara return to the concert stage? The answer to that question is left a bit unclear.A genuine mystery, a cast of engaging (and not so engaging) characters, and an appealing protagonist make this book a quick and pleasant way to spend a few evenings.

England, in the aftermath of The Great War. Few soldiers who fought in France returned unscathed, and Alastair Gellis and Matthew Ryder are no exceptions. Deeply affected by their experiences in the killing fields of France, they have decided to make a study of death and the afterlife by researching and writing about spirit manifestations. Their current case involves trying to rid the Falmouth House barn of its angry, often violent ghost, that of a servant girl, Maddy, who hanged herself there several years ago. Because of some girlhood trauma, Maddy cannot abide men, so Alastair arranges to hire a female assistant. Sarah Piper ekes out a living as an employee of a temp agency, so when she’s sent to interview with Alastair, she cannot resist the chance for a bit of adventure, not realizing that much more will be required of her than simple transcription.Simone St. James’s description of Sarah’s first encounter with Maddy is atmospheric and chilling, and she spins out this tale in an effective Gothic style. The ghost hunting team quickly recognizes that, before they can hope to calm Maddy and send her on her way, they must ferret out the source of her terrible rage. Interestingly, each of the three comes to encounter her in very different ways, and by comparing their experiences, they begin to tease out the truth. The author enlivens the remote country village setting with good period detail and an array of very English characters, ranging from the new owner of the manor house to the suspicious inn keeper to the surly churchyard sexton. Having recently read, enjoyed, and reviewed Bellman and Black, in which crows play a prominent and symbolic role, it was pleasantly surprising to me to encounter crows in this book as well, fulfilling an even more active function. Maddy’s ghostly behaviors are anything but trite, and while Sarah’s budding romance (I won’t say with whom) could easily have detracted from the book’s central theme, it was well integrated into the plot as a whole. Alastair, Matthew, Sarah, and Maddy herself emerge from their brief but intense relationship quite changed.The Haunting of Maddy Clare is an impressive debut novel. If it has an outstanding flaw, it is that some of the characters telegraphed their implication in Maddy’s mystery. But the overlying ghost story maintained its appeal, and readers who enjoy modern Gothic will probably enjoy this book.

This pasta is a tasty alternative to white pasta, similar in texture to Barilla’s whole wheat pasta. We prepared it with olive oil, garlic and sautéed vegetables and were happy with the flavor and texture. We didn’t really notice much, if any,  veggie flavor from the pasta itself. Our family of carb lovers all liked the idea of consuming “one full serving of vegetables” hidden in our pasta. However, on closer inspection of the nutritional label, I’m not quite sure we’re getting much more nutrition per serving than we get from regular white pasta. The only differences are some vitamin A (30% RDA), magnesium (8% RDA) and phosphorus (15% RDA). I thought there would be more added value than that in a “full serving” of tomatoes and carrots. Regardless, I suppose any extra vitamins are a good thing and the color is a nice change up from white or brown. I’m sure we’ll use it again.

Livy Jackson seems to be a normal person to whom most readers can relate. Life isn't easy for Livy right now.  Her family  is in turmoil. While her 7 year old boy, Zack, is still an "angel",  12 year old Hannah is spewing  contrary behaviors and attitudes filling the house with tension. Worse still, Will, Livy's husband, has had and may still be having an affair,  is  rarely home due to his demanding job, and  is irritable when he is at  home. Life hasn't been easy for Livy. She feels guilt involving the unsolved death of her younger sister, Kara, from 18 years ago as well as the resulting breakdown of her relationship with her parents. To make matters worse,  now  a close friend, Julia, appears to have committed suicide, and a disbelieving Livy wages  into a personal battle to prove that Julia was murdered, contrary to what the police are saying.While the story was interesting, it was not very believable. There are too many people that Livy can't trust. Too many places that she investigates without getting caught. Too much investigation without police involvement.  All this while still trying to hold her family together.A quick read that is enjoyable if you can suspend your sense of reality.

W is for Wasted is the 23rd in the Kinsey Millhone series. Twenty third! While most series and their characters grow stale after a while, that's far from the case with Kinsey. To say Sue Grafton has honed her craft is an understatement. Among her many awards are the Grand Master Award from Mystery Writers of America, and Bouchercon's Lifetime Achievement Award. Over the years, I've read and enjoyed novels A through V, but W is her masterpiece.Kinsey's now 38, still unattached, still living the simple life with few encumbrances. And it's still the 80's in her home town of Santa Teresa, CA. As the book opens, she's asked to identify a dead homeless man who carried her name and number in his pocket, but she's never met him before. Since she's between cases, Kinsey's always active curiosity spurs her to find out what she can about the man. She also learns of the death of a sleazy PI whom she did know but didn't like or trust. Too much free time can be a dangerous thing when you're K.M.Author Grafton incorporates the usual stock characters, whom her readers have come fondly to know well, and adds some interesting new ones, especially Ed the cat, some heretofore unknown cousins, and a trio of homeless people who lead her on quite an adventure. This is an intricate plot written on several levels with several disparate threads, and it's a joy to observe how deftly Grafton is able to consolidate them by book's end. It's impossible to decide whether plotting or characterization, dialogue or description, is her outstanding forte, she's so good at them all. If you like mysteries and haven't yet had the pleasure of meeting Kinsey Millhone, treat yourself to W is for Wasted. It's not necessary, though it is fun, to read this series in order. Sue Grafton's Grand Master and Lifetime Achievement Awards, and all the others she's been presented over the years, are richly deserved.

I grew up using Mead Five Star notebooks and always hated how the pockets would eventually rip with use but am happy to see they are reinforced now with a tape-like strip around the top inch of the pocket, including the seam of the pocket. This should solve that issue. Plastic front covers are nice, rich colors and seem durable. The back covers are thick cardboard which looks like it will be durable, too. My only complaint is that the paper is thinner than I remember and my gel pens bleed through too much to use on these pages. These are good, everyday notebooks and now that I’m not in school anymore, I really like them!

Sometimes it really is true that fact is stranger than fiction. You know those little men in the pointy hats that we generally refer to as garden gnomes? They now have a history. You know those classical little “folly” buildings that dot the stately English garden landscape? Well, it turns out that some of these were not strictly decorative.  Gordon Campbell, a Professor of Renaissance Studies at the University of Leicester, has published The Hermit in the Garden: From Imperial Rome to Ornamental Gnome , the first book to describe the phenomenon of the ornamental hermit in Georgian England.Professor Campbell believes that during the Reformation, the ancient custom of religious persons, sometimes called hermits,  choosing to shut themselves away from the world for constant prayer and meditation came to an end with the dissolution of the great religious houses.  During the 18th century, it became fashionable among the educated and the elite to be “melancholy”, devoting time to the admiration of nature and the study of philosophy. Gradually, some began constructing small rustic cottages, to use as retreats for deep thinking, or, in many cases, to impress visitors with their erudition. It wasn’t long before the wealthy began to  hire men to live in their garden “hermitage”, pretending to be a reclusive but romantic part of the landscape. Although this book is a serious and impressive work of research, Professor Campbell injects threads of humor where appropriate, as when he describes the difficulties inherent in finding men willing to don rough robes, go barefooted, allow their hair, beards, and nails to grow, and, perhaps hardest of all, remain silent, for a period of seven years.Much of the book is a survey of historic and modern “hermitages” in England, Scotland, France, and parts of Europe, many of which are illustrated. There are numerous extant sites that can still be visited, though they’re no longer inhabited; health regulations prohibit! It ends with some speculation about how the ornamental garden hermit morphed slowly into the ornamental garden gnome, helped along by Disney’s Grumpy, Sleepy, et al.It’s probably safe to say that there is no  more extensive compilation of information on this topic than The Hermit in the Garden. It’s a valuable addition to the field of garden history, and has much to say, or imply, about Western Civ.Now I must search out the perfect gnome for my own garden.

Cary Grant portrays Mortimer Brewster, a famous arts critic who marries the girl next door on Halloween. He returns to the Brooklyn home he shares with his two maiden aunts to pack for his honeymoon (at Niagara Falls, of course), when he discovers a corpse in the window seat. Mortimer is shocked to learn that his sweet old aunts have been poisoning lonely old men with arsenic laced elderberry wine,  and burying them in the "Panama Canal" that Teddy has dug in the cellar. He spends the rest of the movie frenetically trying to have Teddy committed, in the hope that if the authorities should happen to learn about the bodies in the basement, they'll blame it all on Teddy. Midway through,  long lost, psychopathic third brother Jonathan appears on the scene with his plastic surgeon and another corpse in tow.Arsenic and Old Lace was released in 1944. It's in black and white and  very much like the stage play that inspired it, but when viewed as a period piece, one of the "madcap comedies" of the time, it doesn't come across as dated. Cary Grant bears the weight of the plot, and he's brilliant. It's a joy to watch him convey a full spectrum of emotion in a ten second sequence of facial expressions.  Raymond Massey plays the role of Jonathan, who becomes enraged whenever anyone mentions his resemblance to Boris Karloff, and Peter Lorre that of Dr. Einstein, who keeps promising to make him look like someone else. The aunts, some cops, Mortimer's new wife, and the sanitarium director make frequent appearances to move the story along.In spite of its macabre theme, this is very much a comedy, with lines that hold up quite well some seventy years after they were uttered. Great fun, full of laughs, and vintage in the best sense of the word.

I have used this charger on both an iPhone 5 and an iPhone 6 and am very happy with it so far. It seems to consistently charge both phones quickly enough for me - about 10% in 10 minutes. My iPhone 5 is in a LifeProof Nuud case and the plug fits fine without removing the case, which has been an annoying issue with other cords in the past. My last charger would also occasionally give me issues charging and gave me the warning that it wasn’t a certified Apple product. No issues so far with this charger, which I was hoping since it says it is Apple certified.I like the lower profile of this charger as well as the general feel of it. Not a big deal but it’s nice that it doesn't feel bulky or cheap like so many of them do. Yes, the green light is bright and yes, it annoys me at night, just like my previous charger’s blue light (what’s up with the bright lights?!) My fix is to just rotate the plug so the base of the USB cable blocks most of the light. Usually I’m not leaving it in for the duration of my drive anyhow. I’m just happy it works like it’s supposed to.At $13.99, I consider this charger a good value, especially considering it comes with the cord. So far, so good and I’m excited that this may finally be a car charger I’m content with.

If you're looking for a run of the mill, inexpensive screen protector, these are no better or worse than any others. You still have to attempt to create a lint free environment of the type that is only found in ORs. The sheet is relatively inflexible, and on the thick side, making it difficult to eliminate all bubbles. The chances of a perfect application are close to nil. But if perfection is not an issue, this product will suffice. The truth that you get what you pay for applies to this case. More costly screen protectors, such as the Zagg line's, produce much better results with much less effort.

Someone is killing baseball superstars. There's another players strike underway, and the self proclaimed Vindicator wants to teach a lesson to the greedy, overpaid sob's who are ruining the sport, players and owners alike. Randy Larkin, insurance agent, is basking in the satisfaction of having successfully taken down a cop killer,  when news about the baseball murders breaks and grabs his attention. Now Randy starts to think about becoming a real PI, and is itching to tackle this case.Once you accept the premise that the FBI would actually accept assistance from rank amateurs, Three Strikes and You're Dead takes on momentum. Working under the supervision of a licensed PI mentor, Randy, his brother Graham, and soon-to-be girlfriend Rosanne soon find themselves hot on the trail. The narration alternates between their efforts and those of the Vindicator and the terrorist who controls him. The feature that most grabbed my attention was the use that the novice investigators made of social media, especially Facebook, by setting up a discussion page about the crime and asking speculative questions of the participants. The plot moves along briskly and reaches its culmination in Grand Central Station.The author, an online friend and fellow Connecticut resident, provided me with a copy to read and review objectively. I'm glad I did. The decency and unpretentious attitude of Randy Larkin makes him a refreshingly appealing character, and, since this is his second outing in a Mike Draper production, I hope there's a series in the works.

Avery labels are almost always the most convenient choice for whatever I'm working on. I love the texture and shape of these scalloped labels and I plan to use these in several ways to add some whimsy to otherwise dull projects and packaging.Now, printing? That's another story. I've never had an issue with downloading templates, but there aren't any for this one! Avery pushes you into the online design program on its site. I was irritated with the thought of having to play around in attempt to get what I already had designed in Illustrator. Apparently, the solution is to save the file as a .jpg and upload into the online program as an image. From there, you can save the file on your computer, but you have to open it online via the Avery program. Very frustrating. I ended up downloading a template for a similar round label which took some maneuvering & measuring to get right, but I'd rather not need to deal with going to the website just to print labels. I printed a bunch of test prints on paper to be sure I got it right. Why can't I just have a template? ARGH!Of note, the templates they provide are not business-professional and more suited to someone who wants a cute design or something casual or for kids.  I just wish that since Avery is forcing us into this program they offered some designs that were a little more sophisticated or suitable for a more serious, polished business feel.Since I've gone throughout the effort of essentially creating my own template, I'm sure I'll love the labels going forward.

This beautifully designed scale lives up to its product description in every sense. The transparent platform makes it much more unintrusive in the room. Though we probably will use the calorie and BMI index infrequently, having those reading when you want them is great. The dial is easy to read; so far, it seems to read a couple of pounds over our old scale, which we know was comparable to the MD's office. The only thing I'd change is the use of a battery that will need replacement. (Our old scale does not require one and has worked for over 20 years. Unfortunately, the platform developed a crack and we needed to replace it.) So far we're happy with our choice. Very nice product, excellent quality at a fair price.

In the 1700's, most Americans relied upon linen for their everyday textile needs; cotton had to be imported and was costly enough to be considered a luxury fabric. By 1830, however, the invention of an efficient cotton gin and the emergence of Southern cotton plantations led to a reversal in that state of affairs. But what if an efficient flax gin had been invented first?Jodi Lew-Smith has written a historical coming-of-age tale built around that question, set in the first decade of the nineteenth century. Ella Kenyon is an unusual young woman, one who feels more at home in the woods than the town. Her beloved grandfather, a blacksmith by trade, has helped her develop an unusual talent for engineering, and together they design a machine that can extract linen fibers from the plant. When her grandfather dies suddenly, Ella is determined to perfect and patent their flax gin. The Clever Mill Horse is the tale of her struggle to achieve that goal. On her long journey to Washington City, she must face countless obstacles, among them forest fires, horse thieves,  accidents and illness, and unscrupulous lawyers. Before her journey ends, Ella will discover the truth about who she really is and why.Ms. Lew-Smith fills her story with vibrant characters, vivid descriptions, and realistic dialog. There is even a role for a real inventor, Oliver Evans. Does Ella achieve her mission? Yes and no. Now that so many things in her young life have changed, in what direction will she head? This book, the first in a promised series, is suitable for adults and young adults alike.

I love oatmeal and prepare my own instant version with dried fruits and nuts, so was curious to try this topping mix in my cereal. It tastes very good, and I'm pleased with it, though the nutty flavor rather masks the blueberry flavor. It's convenient, tasty, and provides some variety for my go-to winter breakfast. I'm interested to try some the other Mrs. Mays products.

Let me open by admitting that most corkscrews don't work very well for me. Or I don't use them properly or something. Anyway, that's why I ordered this Rabbit Zippity. And I've found that it works pretty much as described by the manufacturer. It screws very smoothly into the cork, and the two level lever system prevents that maddening phase when the cork is halfway out and then refuses to budge. The handle is beautifully designed, and even though I'm left handed, it's comfortable and efficient to use. My four star rating is do solely to the fact that the foil cutter does not retract automatically, as was promised. It's sharp, handle with caution. All in all, however, I'm glad to have this gadget.

The author of Dark Digital Sky contacted me to ask if I'd be interested in reading and reviewing his new novel. Techno-thrillers are way out of my preferred genres, but I agreed to give this one a go, and I'm glad I did. The 21st century version of the brilliant but deeply flawed investigator has arrived in the persona of Chalk (Chaucer). He's bipolar but doesn't take his meds properly, mixing in a touch of alcoholism and much emotional baggage, which he has no idea - none whatsoever - how to handle. But he's an accomplished hacker, and was recruited and trained by the FBI, although that career tanked quite early. But his new PI gig pays better, and he always delivers.As the novel opens, Chalk has been hired by the Hollywood Hyena, on obscenely wealthy megalomaniac. The Hyena is dying and now wants to meet the offspring he sired via the sperm bank. Chalk locates and stalks three of them, all male, using up to the minute technological tools. Not one of sons is what you might call smart or  pro-social, and each has been recruited by a sadistic terrorist. The reader enters this world along with Chalk, who certainly knows how to find his way around in there. Along the way, he encounters Bacchus, who seems to be a vicious serial killer who kidnaps young women. Among Bacchus' personal foibles is the cannibalism which he inflicts upon unknowing others. This is a complex plot that moves along briskly, and you never know what might happen next. I know there is an vast audience of readers who would enjoy this book; I found the story line very intriguing, and Chalk is certainly an interesting kind of guy (Chalk would love Lisbeth Salandar), but it's spattered with the sorts of violence that I don't like to have floating around in my mind.A promising start to what promises to become a popular series.

The High Price I Had To Pay by Jamila T. Davis is the second book I have read from this author. I enjoy books about crimes that are true. There is nothing like a true story to really make you think. I remember  when the big mortgage/bank fraud thing was going down and a lot of people got caught up in it. Jamila T. Davis was one of them. She was convicted of bank fraud, for her role in a multi-million dollar bank fraud scheme, and sentenced to 12 1/2 years in federal prison. Most of the real culprits never saw the inside of a prison.Most people wouldn't have been able to come back from that. But Jamila is sharing her story and bringing light to a lot of things some of us were not privy to when all this was going down. It may have been a tough lesson, but after reading this I think the author has become a stronger person for it creating a series of books geared towards women empowerment. Really a good read.

Think What You Want: An Adaptation of James Allen's As a Man Thinketh (Champion Change Ability Book 1) by Bruce Lee Whitney is a short book that packs a powerful punch. There is so much to pick up from this book in the art of positive thinking and laws of attraction. This book gives excellent guidelines on what it takes to change your life for the better.My favorite passage being:Man is controlled by circumstances so long as he believes himself to be a product of external forces and outside conditions. Once you realize you are a creative force of your own and you control the nature of your being from which each situation grows then you will master the life you lead.This adaptation of A Man Thinketh is something to read and take to heart.

I have watched this movie a few times now. And I just loved it. You see what it is to be a teenager in a world where the need to be popular and social media rules. It really touches on some very deep subjects. I think every teenager should watch it. The acting was amazing. It is very deep and truly thought-provoking. Anyone who watches will take something away from this movie. 5 stars all the way!!

This Mondaynoon Languishing Austrian Crystal Tennis Bracelet is absolutely beautiful. I got the sea blue color. It feels weighty not like it will break. And it sparks so beautifully. I wish I had a better picture. I have worn it only once and have gotten a ton compliments on it. It comes in a beautiful box so if you want to give it for a gift. The photo does not do it justice. It is a gorgeous piece I love it.Note: *I received this product for low cost or free in return for my honest, unbiased opinion* My review is my own personal opinion of the item.

I thought this was a good movie at least for it being a Lifetime Movie. I tend to like those movies for some reason. It is a movie of a teenage girl struggling to fit in after post-Columbine when tensions were amongst students and administrators. It was a good movie with a good message. It definitely good one a lot to ponder.

A Light Within (Three Keys Book 2) by Dana Alexander was a good read. I read the first in the series Beyond a Darkened Sky back over the summer. And I was thrilled to get my hands on the second one. In this book, we pick up again with Sarah Forrester and her protector Kevin still looking for the three keys.I think this book flowed nicely. I was glad I had read the first in the series prior to this one. So I knew exactly what was going on. The characters are well developed and the plot keeps you drawn in with lots of action, sci-fi, suspense and love. Dana Alexander has created a beautiful world with her words for us to get lost in. I would recommend.

I love the Tahari Acrylic Roving Yarn Slouchy Beanie With Pom Pom. The photos do not do the beanie justice in my opinion. I chose the teal colored beanie which is just stunning. It is soft, fits nice and feels comfortable. I can't wait for it to get colder so I can wear it more.*I received this product for free in return for my honest, unbiased opinion* My review is my own personal opinion of the item.

The Monster Chase, by Marion A. Stahl, was an interesting fictional account of the multitude of problems that seems to be running rampant in our healthcare system right now. When I was a child growing up I wanted to be a doctor. I wanted to be able to help people but after reading this I am thankful I chose something else. There is so much that goes into being a doctor outside of actually practicing medicine.The story follows a doctor who  unfairly of persecuted for insurance fraud. Though the story is fiction you can imagine it is truly something that is would happen in today's medical field. You can tell the author has been in the medical field. She knows what she is it talking about. Through a story of fiction, the author has brought to light some very real and troubling things that are probably going on within our healthcare system today.

I absolutely love Rose Red. I have watched it many times and I never get tired. It is right up there with Stephen King's It and The Stand. I know a lot of my friends don't like the made for tv movies. But we all love this one.

25 Negotiating Strategies of Highly Successful Women by Natalie Disque I thought would be a good read because I am wanting to do ask for a raise with my new promotion. I have been nervous and anxious about it. So when I came across this book I thought I would give it a chance and see if I could find some helpful advice.I found some really great information. Some information was common sense and some information definitely gave you food for thought. The book covers 5 common mistakes women make in negotiating. 5 of the biggest advantages women have. 5 strategies on asking for a raise or promotion. 5 strategies for negotiating with investors, presenting business proposals, or improving your sales. And 5 strategies to help you nail a job interview.The book was a quick read. It was very straight forward sharing only what you need to know. I would recommend it. I will update if I get the raise.

Jeez, I wanted to like this movie so much more. I just finished this movie. I can't put my finger on what the problem was. It just wasn't as funny as I thought it would be. This movie was 2 hours and 9 minutes long which to me is a little long for a comedy. The good laughs were so spread out. I would stopped watching for short periods and come back and watched more. I wasn't sitting there laughing my butt off which is what I was expecting. It wasn't completely horrible. It just wasn't as funny as I thought it would be. I would never add this to my collection. It is a rent and return.

I finally got  around to getting these up and getting rid those plastic things. These worked just great. They were easy to install. It was a nice elegant touch to my shower curtain. I have a heavier shower curtain now I never worry about it just falling down because these are really sturdy. I am happy with these shower curtain hooks. I think they will last a while.  *I received this product for free in return for my honest, unbiased opinion* My review is my own personal opinion of the item.

Send My Love by Mike Crowley is the second in this Shotgun John and Scorpion series. I read the first book, Send Flowers, some months back and really enjoyed it. I was not disappointed with the latest in the series. This book offers even more action and suspense than the last. It kept me intrigued and guessing page after page.A hunt for 3 nukes has put our leads Shotgun John and Scorpion on the hunt to track them down. Getting the nukes back proved difficult with so many government agencies involved along with terrorists. The plot has so many twists and turns and takes place all over the globe.I thought this was an excellent follow-up to Send Flowers.  It was just as fun and exciting. I think anyone who likes a good political thriller might enjoy this.

I got this set of books after watching Gone Girl which I was very impressed. I thought getting all 3 was a deal even though I had no clue what the others were about at time of purchase. It was worth it. I loved every book. Gillian Flynn is great with twists.  Just when you think you have it nailed nothing is as you expected it would be. And she does this flawless. She creates this characters and most are truly unlikeable but you can't stop reading. I definitely want to see more from this author. I am a total fan.

I actually liked this movie. It was actually recommended by a friend. We tend to like the same things. I am not sure what that says about us. The plot 4 boys get 3 girls to come off on their yacht with them for fun and frolicking. People are partying, having sex and having a good time until one of the  girls ends up dead. It becomes a struggle girls against boys. The girls want to go to the authorities and the guys do not. I don't want to give too much away. I know this movie has gotten some pretty negative reviews, but I liked. I thought it was interesting and different.

Face of Our Father by G. Egore Pitir is an international terrorist thriller that is so intriguing it becomes a real page turner. The story is about a husband and wife Angie and Stu. Stu is Pierce is a retiring fighter pilot and his wife Angie is an attorney and women's advocate. Angie is on the hunt for a Middle Eastern criminal who has managed to escape justice. When Angie is threatened Stu steps in to help and protect his wife.This book had so many things going for it. The characters and plot are well written and developed. It is like watching an action movie playing out in your head as you read. The book kept my interest piqued. I read this was the author's first novel and I must say it is impressive.

I watched this the other night on Amazon Prime. I though why now. I was little interested in the beginning then it seems to me it just went right off the rail. A girl may or may not have gotten raped at a party amongst her peers. The alleged rapist is then killed fighting with the other kids. I get somewhat where they were going with when it came to complicity but after that I am not sure. The acting left a lot to be desired as did the ending.

I have watched this movie so many times over the years. And it still gets me. It has a wonderful cast Helen Hunt, Kevin Spacey, Jay Mohr and Haley Joel Osment. Trevor McKinney played by Osment is a young boy who is given an assignment by his teacher Mr. Simonet played by Spacey. The assignment is something you can do to make the world a better a place. And Trevor comes up with the idea of Paying It Forward which at first didn't seem like it worked but it did and it took on a life of it's with a host of characters paying it forward in their own way.

I have been using Axgio Vigour Bluetooth Earbuds for a month now. They are good so far. They fit well and the sound quality is decent. I have used these with my iPod, Mac Book Pro and my Windows phone. I had no problems linking them. I have had linking issues with other brands, but this linked up just fine with all of my devices. I am happy with this product. *I received this product for free in return for my honest, unbiased opinion* My review is my own personal opinion of the item.

Mail Order Bride: The Big Feisty Bride Tamed by Her Scarred Banker: A Big Beautiful Woman's Unconventional Tale (A Pioneer Western Romance: Brides OF Perry Lake Book1) by Faye Sonja I felt overall was a good read. It held my attention. I enjoyed the storyline and the characters. There was plenty of action and romance. It is not a long book which is why I am not going to go into a big plot breakdown. It is good for when you want to read something quick. Though it was lacking in the editing department, there were some grammar and spelling issues. I didn't think it took too away from the overall story too much.

Atlantic Island by Fredric Shernoff is a teen/young adult novel that I totally got caught up in. It was an easy read. It held my attention. I kept wanting to know what was going to happen next. The book follows Theo Essex and his group of teenage friends who are headed to the island for some fun like any normal teenager.s But there is nothing normal about what happens next. An event..something was cataclysmic. When it is over there is nothing left of the U.S, but the island they are inhabiting and something evil is there with them.The synopsis to the book really drew me in. So I am happy I gave the book a try. The book kept me on my toes. There are elements of science fiction, romance, action and adventure all wrapped up in this novel. I look forward tor reading more from this authour.

Cup of Evil by E. Groat was an interesting and intense read. I was shocked by how much the author got in considering the book was short enough for me to read in one sitting. I was really impressed with how many things were going on but the author kept the story line and plot tight. The characters are well written and the book was very easy to get into.I am not going to go overboard into plot details because it really is a good read. You want a book that has it all I would recommend this book. It has politics, blackmail, murder, corruption, and more. It didn't take long for me to become absorbed and before I knew it I was at the end of the book. The author really knows how to write and keep ahold of you.

I read the first in this series and this second one Detour Allure: Detour Paris Series Book 2 by Jack Dancer is just as good and entertaining as the first in the series. Once again we are following Tucker and Monica on their wild adventure. I enjoyed how the book had reminders from the previous book so you felt caught up. You could probably read this as a standalone.This book definitely is very graphic in the violence and sex. It is certainly a book for a mature audience. I think that is definitely something that need to be said. It didn't bother me personally.I enjoyed the main characters. I thought the author did a great job at establishing them and making them interesting. I enjoy a book that has love, mystery and intrigue at every page. I look forward to the next installment.

Full Circle (The Belanger Creek Ranch Book 2) by Gloria Antypowich was a book referred to me by a friend. I was a little hesitant because it was the second in the series, but it didn't matter. It can be read as a standalone.The story is about Shauna Lee who runs a bookkeeping and accounting service in her Canadian town. She is well known in her community as a savvy business woman. Shauna Lee on the outside is well put together and appears to be successful and thriving. But you know the saying behind closed doors. She soon meets Brad who is smitten with Shauna but wants nothing to do with her nsa type relationships. He still falls for her anyway but realizes he may not get what he want because of her past. Shauna Lee is the way she is for a reason.Without giving any more away. It was a good read. It is more than just a romance there is a lot of drama and emotions throughout. I will be reading book one at some point.

Relentless Savage (Peter Savage Book 2) by David Edlund did not disappoint. I really enjoy a good thriller with a lot of action. And I got both in abundance in this book. The story is about Peter Savage who is on the hunt for his son Ethan who has been kidnapped by rebels in Sudan. Peter is having to do everything he can possible to get his son back. He recruits some friends to help in his rescue mission but when they get to Sudan things are far more disturbing than anyone could have thought. Without giving too much away, I will say I was drawn in within the first few pages of reading. It was fun and kept me entertained. I look forward to reading more from this author.

First off I have to admit for this book to be listed under teen and young adult I was surprised at how much I liked. A friend shared this book with me to give it a shot. I thought why not after reading the synopsis.The story is about Lillie Carmichael who has no idea who she is. She has no clue who her parents were or where she came from. She was found as a baby. Lillie has  been carrying secrets all this time. She has abilities. Men seem to just be taken with her. After an incident in the woods, she meets Kyle. He is dark and mysterious and seems to know an awful lot about Lillie from there it is all adventure.I love the characters, Lillie, and Kyle. The author did a great job bring the characters to life not to mention the Kingdom where a war is threatening to destroy everything. I don't want to give too much away, but this was a very enjoyable book.

I actually ordered this for my mom. She had recently purchased a Straight Talk Galaxy Core Prime phone. She was worried about it getting dented or banged up. So she asked me to find a case for it. She loved. He loves the outside. We had no problems getting the phone inserted in the case. She loves that she don't have to worry about it getting scratched up in her purse. The magnet closure works great. I have come across problems with other cases but this case is top notch. My mom has gotten tons of compliments on her phone. She is happy so I am happy.

Greylock by Paula Cappa is a captivating read. The author definitely has a way with words that really draws the reader in. I think this is one of the most detail oriented books I have read. The plot and characters are truly brought to life which makes the book all the better. The book is about a musician Alexie Georg. Alexei harbors a very dark secret. He found an old Russian sonata in a 19th-century sea chest. When he plays the music something dark appears. I love how the music is so deeply woven into the story line.I thought this book was intriguing. It has a number elements that keep you glued to the pages. I am a big fan of anything dealing paranormal, thrillers or crime. Cappa mixed them all together and it turned into something wonderful. It was a truly captivating reading.

Deacons Wives 12 is part of a series. This particular book in the series focuses on Annie. Annie is a divorcee she was married straight out of college later on when her mother passes away Annie finds faith in the church. Which prompted the divorce between her and Dylan the first husband. Annie eventually meets Tom who is a religious man. He seems perfect so they get married. Annie learned quickly Tom believes the man is in  control and the woman is to always submissive in the household. Tom also has a big jealous streak. Annie went to the church with  to the church taking marital intimacy courses. She didn't realize how many issues she would have with Tom after their marriage.I like how this book is written. It is like catching passages in someone's journal or eavesdropping on someone else's conversation. I have always been fond of that style of writing. I love the characters of Annie and Stephi. I could go on, but I would give away the entire book. This is the first book I have read in this series. I am curious to read more.

I have been waiting forever for this movie to come out. I wanted to like this movie a lot more than I actually did. It only gets 3 stars from me, and that is only because that 3 way was freaking hot. It was something just off about it. Keanu Reeves acting was over the top like overacting. I am not sure if that was intentional or not, but it was less than stellar. I also guess Eli Roth is going to become one of those directors who always casts his significant other in his movies since she is all so be starring in Green Inferno. Lorenza Izzo is hot so I can see why. Her acting and Ana de Armas wasn't that bad but Keanus was just not good. This movie keeps getting compared to Hard Candy and it isn't even close to being in the same league.

I love the Coolife 4-way Garden to Hose Connector. I have the 2 connectors as well. I use this one when I go to work in my mom's yard. She has a big yard with limited spigots. I love this one just as much as the one I use at my place. It is sturdy and is of high quality. I love the shut-off valves for each individual hose connection. It never leaked once and I have used it multiple times. And it was very easy to attach which I love. I am happy with this item. And I would recommend it. *I received this product at a free or discounted rate in return for my honest, unbiased review* My review is my own opinion of the item.

I borrowed this book from a friend per their recommendation. And I was not disappointed. And When by Wendiann Proteau drew me in especially with the well written and developed main character Jade Prency. Jade as many of us has been dealt a series of life smack down blows. So I could relate to her immediately. Jade uses the internet to find solace through online chat groups. I love the correspondence between her and the people she connected with online.What I loved most about this story was how it pulled you in emotionally. You really felt for Jade and all she was going through. You connected. The author's writing really tapped into your emotions through this story.  I really enjoyed this book. I can't wait to read the next.

I love the necklace. It is gorgeous I have the ring to match, and they look gorgeous together. Every time I wear them I get compliments. I love the price and the quality of these this pieces. Very happy!!Disclaimer: *I received this product at a free or discounted rate in return for my honest, unbiased review* My review is my own opinion of the item.

I am so impressed. This ring is so beautiful. I purchased the necklace as well. They make a wonderful set. I have worn it several times since I purchased it. And I have gotten compliments every single time. It is a great price and great quality. It doesn't feel cheap. And it looks amazing. Very happy with my purchase.Disclaimer: *I received this product for free in return for my honest, unbiased opinion* My review is my own personal opinion of the item.

The Heartbeat Thief by AJ Krafton is my kind of story. The story takes places in 1860 following Senza Fyne. Senza has it all. She is smart, beautiful, young, wealthy and well connected. Yet in this time the only thing a woman had to do was find a suitable husband, but Senza is preoccupied not with life and all that lay before her. She is focused on what is to come...death. With people dying all around her. She begins to worry about her own mortality. Enters Mr. Knell a man who can help Senza maintain the life she so craves, but at what cost.The character of Senza was well written. And I was drawn into her story completely. I may not have taken the route Senza did, but I understood where she was coming. I really enjoyed the story. It was a little slow in some areas, but overall it was a great.
